Enhance stream habitat in Olalla Creek by installing 28 logs and 20 rootwads to slow water velocity, promote increased stream complexity, and increase the amount of spawning gravel.
Provide resting pools for adult and juvenile salmonids in Ashland Creek by placing porous rock weirs instream.  Plant native vegetation in the riparian area.

Project Name: Bear Crk Dam Mod Fish Jump at Jackson St Dam

Project Name: West Fork Canyon Creek Culvert Removal
Project Summary: Replace three problem culverts with rocked low water crossings, and smooth road areas damaged by failing culverts for better drainage.  Road is gated.  Site is above a reservoir and not accessible by anadromous fish.

Create thirteen upstream "V"s in the Upper Smith River using 195 boulders and twenty rootwad/boulder combinations.  The goal of this project is to create instream habitat complexity and collect spawning gravel in an area dominated by bedrock.

Using the Rosgen methodology, produce information that will help insure that instream projects in the Umpqua Basin will be compatible with the geomorphic system and will contribute to the long-term stability of the watershed.

Restore approximately 300 acres of riverine wetlands and estuarine marsh habitat by removing a levee and tidegate from an outlet channel and removing the spoils from the inlet channel.  This project will restore natural flows and tidal fluctuation.

Fence 1,000 ft. of a creek in the South Umpqua sub-basin, install a stock watering system with five tanks, plant conifers in the riparian area, and install a bridge crossing for vehicles and livestock.

Place 63 logs, 21 rootwads, and 95 boulders on a .6 mi. section of Brads Creek for habitat enhancement.  Make accessible an additional 3 and 1/2 miles of coho, steelhead and cutthroat trout habitat by replacing culvert on Whitehorse Creek.
Place 150 to 200 tons of rock riprap along 120 feet of Silver Creek to prevent further erosion.  Plant native species in riparian area.  Collect water quality data for ten years.

Project Name: McKenzie-Willamette Rvr Confl Hab Enh / Flood Prot Proj Plan
Project Summary: Develop a plan for implementing fish and wildlife habitat enhancement actions at the confluence of the McKenzie and Willamette Rivers.

To improve fish passage for anadromous species and allow for continued provision of safe drinking water for the City of Yamhill, the city proposes to install a new fish passage system, construct a new debris passage system, and replace a fish screen.

Plant native vegetation in  and fence riparian areas, and create underground outlets and grassed waterways and forest buffers along streams in the Pudding River Watershed to reduce problems with concentrated flow across farm lots and fields.

Project Name: Pudding River Watershed Assessment Phase I
Project Summary: Monitor water temperature and turbidity at specific locations and assess riparian health throughout the watershed.

Project Name: Bslne Mntrng of Macroinvertebrte Pops w/in Tualatin R & Trib
Project Summary: Fund macroinvertebrate monitoring at 52 sites to supplement and enhance historic and on-going fisheries and water chemistry monitoring by the USA.

27 of Oregon's 90 Watershed Councils do not have email.  Provide computer hardware, software, internet connection and training to 10 watershed councils that do not have web-based resources, such as email or a web site.

Project Name: East Fork McKay Creek Culvert Removal
Project Summary: Restore McKay Creek to its historic natural condition in a landslide area.  Remove culvert and road, excavate slide, stabilize slopes, and plant with native vegetation.

Project Name: Deer Creek County Park Stream Restoration Project
Project Summary: Create a demonstration project at Deer Creek County Park.  Increase stream complexity, hydraulic roughness, and riparian diversity by increasing stream bottom vegetation, and reshaping and vegetating the banks with native plants.

Provide wetlands education at the Oregon Garden in Silverton.  Garden staff would study wetland buffer systems, and then provide public education about the wetlands, including interpretive signs, brochures, tours, seminars, and website information.

Project Name: Integrated Watershed Information Model (GIS Database Model)
Project Summary: Integrate watershed condition information from various sources to provide a foundation for collaborative planning activities for fish and wildlife habitat restoration projects.  Identify sites for land acquisition.

Replace two culverts in Mad Creek with a bridge designed to accommodate 100-year flood flows.  Build a temporary ford to allow continued access to private properties.  Riprap banks immediately up and downstream of the bridge.

Project Name: South Gilliam Cnty Uplnd Stockwter Dev & Streambnk Stab Proj
Project Summary: Construct 19 ponds to capture sediment and provide upland stock watering.  Stabilize eroding streambanks with juniper riprap.  Use cross-fencing to allow better utilization of vegetation.

Stabilize streambanks in highly eroded steelhead streams in the Eastern Hood, Eightmile, and Fifteenmile Watersheds, by constructing rock deflectors, and upstream facing rock barbs, toe rock, and willow plantings.  Repair or replace riparian fencing.

Project Name: Alder Springs Riparian and Upland Restoration
Project Summary: Implement road and trail management, and revegetation of the area with native plants on an 860 acre ranch within the Crooked River National Grassland recently purchased by a consortium of federal public agencies.

Project Name: Gilliam County Direct Seeding Incentive Program
Project Summary: Provide an incentive for farmers to implement direct seeding on 1,000 acres to reduce sedimentation and erosion in the Lower John Day Basin.
Fill current inefficient irrigation ditches which deliver sediment and nutrients to Nuss Lake and the Lost River, and replace with irrigation pipe.  Seed area and protect from grazing for two years.
Install livestock watering system and fencing to prevent livestock from watering in Wallowa River.  Plant vegetation in uplands for wildlife habitat.
Construct pond to filter sediment and nutrient runoff from crop and pasture land before it enters the Malheur River.
Provide block grants to landowners for the installation of large woody debris and boulder placement in fish-bearing streams where spawning and rearing habitat is critical.

Project Name: Jones Streambank Protection/Fish Habitat Imprvmnt Lostine R
Project Summary: Install three vortex weirs in the Lostine River (Wallowa River Basin) to direct water flow away from eroding streambank and improve fish passage conditions.
Reduce streambank erosion through bank shaping and the placement of riprap.  Replace irrigation diversion headgate and ditch with a pumping plant and screen to remove barriers to fish passage.
Upgrade water diversion facility on Mill Creek to prevent bull trout and steelhead deaths due to inadequate fish screen.

Convert flood irrigation to center-pivot irrigation on 300 acres in the Ladd Creek drainage to increase in-stream water flow and reduce sediment and nutrient inputs.  ESA-listed bull trout and steelhead are present in Ladd Creek.

Reconfigure irrigation water withdrawal system to augment late-season water flow in Rudio Creek, a spawning and rearing habitat for steelhead.  Construct pipeline, install pump, and obtain supplemental water right.

Project Name: John Day River Basin Water Quality Monitoring
Project Summary: Purchase water quality monitoring materials for volunteer and educational use.  Requested items include clinometers, GPS, dissolved oxygen meter, notebook computer, macroinvertebrate collection materials, and orienteering materials.
Fund operational costs of the Monument SWCD Native Plant Nursery.

Project Name: In-stream Water Right & Harris Park Addition Land Protection
Project Summary: Acquire two parcels of land adjacent to Harris Park on the South Fork of the Walla Walla River.  Acquire a water right to increase instream flow.

Project Name: Lower Rudio Creek Watershed Enhancement Project
Project Summary: Design and install a low-pressure pivot sprinkler irrigation system and a low-volume solid-set irrigation system to replace existing flood irrigation, which is marginally efficient.  Connected to App. No. Z99-610.

Project Name: Lower Columbia River Estuary Salmon Evaluation
Project Summary: Collect baseline data on sites in the Lower Columbia slated for restoration.  Monitor restoration sites to evaluate post-project effectiveness.  Compile data into a report identifying successful restoration strategies.

Project Name: Juvenile Salmonid Survival Into and Through Oregon Estuaries
Project Summary: Document the survival of smolts from upstream release points into and through estuaries located along the Oregon coast by surgically implanting hydroacoustic transmitters into the body cavity of five wild smolts in six study systems.

Project Name: Surveys for Early Detection of Cordgrass in Oregon Estuaries
Project Summary: Conduct aerial surveys of 15 estuaries along the Oregon Coast to detect the presence of Spartina, a noxious weed detrimental to estuary health.  Field inspect same estuaries and map for treatment.
Fund position to monitor riparian conditions in the Bully Creek sub-basin and determine effectiveness of the Bully Creek Landscape Area Management Plan (LAMP).

Project Name: Mapleton Schools Natural Resource Education Program II
Project Summary: The Siuslaw Institute, in collaboration with the Mapleton School District, has initiated and carried out the first two years of a Natural Resource Education Program in the Mapleton Schools. This programis a school based educational effort.

Project Name: WS Collections-Creating Opportunities for Outreach in
Project Summary: This proposal seeks to complete the historical conditions assessment of the Oregon Watershed Assessment Manual and use the acquisition of this information to engage many of the landowners who are not currently involved in the Oregon Plan for two drainages in the Mid-Coast.

This project/position will continue to implement and coordinate Citizen Involvement Action Plans described in the Tillamook county Performance Partnership's Comprehensive conservation Management Plan.

Project Name: Tillamook Cnty Perfomance Part. Streamline Fencing 2000
Project Summary: This project augments  existing SWCD riparian enhancement program efforts by contracting for additional project implementation  to help with existing backlog of willing landowners while also recruiting new landowner participants.

This project will hire a Riparian Specialist  to oversee, coordinate, and seek funding for riparian management activities in the Tillamook Bay basin. Specific projects undertaken will include: writing grants for riparian enhancement and protection; designing a riparian project assessment protocol for project prioritization; and developing a prioritized plan for riparian enhancement.

The Siuslaw River Estuary Restoration project will involve the acquisition and restoration of 500 acres of estuarine habitat near the mouth of the Siuslaw River, including 2.5 miles of riparian habitat. This restored salt marsh will become part of a larger corridor of  restored salt marshland within this estuary.
This project is aimed at restoring the eroding banks due to the meanders of Beaver Creek which is a tributary to the Upper Nehalem River.

This project is designed to put established trees on banks of sloughs and streams to increase shading of water. We would transplant trees that are normally cut or treated with herbicides to accomplish this task.

This project utilizes the OWEB watershed assessment manual to complete an assessment of the Tillamook River watershed and the watersheds of 13 streams that flow directly into Tillamook Bay. 10 of the streams are named, and 3 are un-named.
This project would reconstruct and map the historic floodplain habitat of both sides of the lower Columbia River from Bonneville Dam downstream to the mouth.

This project would develop a high definition, geographically accurate data set for the lower Columbia River aquatic and wetland habitat structure using a combination of satellite and airborne remote sensing imagery with existing GIS data.

Project Name: NC Gaging Station Installation Monitoring Project
Project Summary: Construct/upgrade 20 streamgaging stations in priority basins and monitor water quantity, water quality for two years. The stations were identified through a coordinated effort by the Tillamook County Performance Partnership, Oregon Water Resources Department (OWRD), as priority basins for restoration and implementation of the Oregon Plan for Salmon and Watersheds.

This cooperative monitoring project is designed to monitor native anadromous salmonid in the Upper Umpqua as they outmigrate from the spawning grounds. Data will be shared with other state and federal agencies and help to track the aquatic health of Upper South Umpqua fish stocks.

Project Name: Private Road Inventory and Sediment Yield Anaylsis
Project Summary: The project evaluates the relation between private roads and non-point source, sediment pollution in the East Fork sub-watershed of Williams creek by conducting an inventory of private roads based on protocols established by the Oregon Plan. Sediment loads will be analyzed in tributaries affected by or in close proximity to these private roads. These monitoring efforts will provide us with essential information necessary for developing work designs for future on-the-ground, sediment reduction projects with private landowners.
Install 12 streamflow monitoring stations on the Bear Creek tributaries, Medford Irrigation District and Talent Irrigation District canals and record flows for winter season.

Project Name: Coos Curry Co. Ag Lands Monitoring Program
Project Summary: This Monitoring grant directly supports the SB 1010 planning effort now occurring in both Coos and Curry Counties. The data collected is also being used to formulate a new seat of reference conditions for use on agricultural lowlands in the South Coast areas that would eventually be adopted by DEQ (with their oversight and guidance).

This project will produce a watershed assessment for the Upper Rogue Watershed using the most current data available.  The fly-over will produce 3 products (CD ROM, Video and aerial photographs) which will aid in the education of locals, agencies, stakeholders. These products will be compiled with other data for assessment to prioritize areas of concern.

The project will finalize the draft Wagner Creek Watershed Assessment (1999), complete an Action Plan and hydrologic analysis. Wagner Creek is currently a high priority basin for planning as defined by the Department of Environment Quality. The project will extend planning efforts by City of Talent beyond the UGB to encompass the entire sub-watershed.

Project Name: Bear Creek Storm Water Management Planning
Project Summary: We are proposing to use OWEB funds to develop a regional approach to meet the requirements of NPDES Phase II.  OWEB funds will be used to create a collaborative environment in which the Phase II regulations can be met effectively, efficiently, and on a regional basis. The project includes a 4 step process: 1.)educational workshops and materials, 2.)develop regional strategy to meet Phase II, 3.)obtain local commitments to implement regional approach, 4.)identify funding sources for implementation.

This application proposes to develop a long-term strategy regarding the future operations of Gold Ray Dam. The original log crib dam was constructed in 1903, then a concrete dam, was constructed in 1939 for hydroelectric power generation. ODFW has operated a fish counting station at this dam since 1942. Jackson County accepted Gold Ray Dam in 1972 when there seemed to be consensus of opinion that the dam should be public ownership in order to preserve the condition of the upstream natural resources. Since 1973 there has been very little interest shown by other agencies in preserving the dam and appurtenances.

Project Name: Rogue Basin ESA and CWS Integration Phase 2
Project Summary: This is a pilot project designed to integrate the requirements of the Federal Endangered Species Act (ESA) and Clean Water Act (CWA) with the watershed level planning guidance developed by the State. This project will support local watershed management approaches to conserving sensitive species and habitats, protect and restore water quality, and make it easier for private landowners and others to meet regulatory requirements.

This project will produce a streamlined version of an already widely accepted educational tool. The Portable Living Stream (touch tank) and comprehensive curriculum development will educate our youth and raise the awareness of Oregon citizens about watershed concepts. This will teach the long term benefits of healthy watersheds and encourage good stewardship practices by people of all ages.

Project Name: Spirit of the Rogue Nature Center
Project Summary: Funds will allow us to continue yearly program delivery to over: 2,000 youth on site; 1,100 is schools and 70,000 site visitors. This project is part of a phased overall program of Spirit of the Rogue Nature Center & identified in URWA's work plan (high priority). We are proposing to hire a full time project director to provide implementation of the Master Plan and an administrative assistant. Other funding is for operation while we develop a marketing and fundraising program to insure future continuity.

This project will support a public information specialist (Susan Davis) for the Umpqua Basin Watershed Council to develop and coordinate education and outreach to landowners in the Umpqua Basin. The project will also support specific educational efforts, including a newsletter: development of a display: tours of successful restoration projects; a media campaign targeted at specific audiences, including small woodlot owners, ranchers and farmers and urban residents on rural nonresource lands.

The purpose of this project is to provide citizens local governments of the Bear Creek Watershed with information and tools to assist them in better understanding and improving the conditions of their watershed.  All materials produced will be specific to the Bear Creek Watershed, RVCOG will accomplish this through development and publication of four newspaper inserts, which will provide basic information on watershed issues. RVCOG will also sponsor a State of the Bear Creek Watershed Conference and coordinate six community workshops.

Project Name: J Herbert Stone Constructed Wetland Education Project
Project Summary: This project will provide Bear Creek students, educators, and the watershed community with increased opportunities to study wetland and riparian ecosystems and the impact these systems have on water quality and anadromous fisheries. We will accomplish this by developing the J. Herbert Stone constructed wetland into an interactive educational site. RVCOG will develop an interpretive trail system, interpretive materials (site guides, activities guide, study kit, study protocols), and coordinate workshops.

This project will improve water quality in the main stream of the Upper Rogue River by relocating Old Ferry Road. Relocation of the road will reduce turbidity and sediment cause by run-off, vehicle use, and flooding, and will improve water temperature and habitat by restoring the riparian area.

Project Name: South Fork Guill Seitz Reach-based Restoration Design Engine
Project Summary: The LBCW Council has identified a reach that meets multi-objective restoration goals. This reach of approximately 8000' is contiguous and encompassing three stakeholders. The goal of the restoration is to support and foster the natural recovery of riparian vegetation, maximize the creation of sustainable natural processes, and enhance the migration corridor and overall habitat for anadromous and resident fish populations.

Project Name: Antelope Creek Diversion Riparian Health Preservation
Project Summary: The Antelope Creek Irrigation Diversion and Fish Passage is in the final stages of wrapping up. The Bureau of Reclamation has asked the LBCWC to assist in the riparian planting and then conduct follow-up watering and noxious wed eradication in 2001 and 2002 to assure survival. The Council has agreed to take on the oversight and coordination of this project.

This  project will address the two major "limiting factors" negatively impacting native coho of the Tenmile Lakes' Watershed; 1)Predation and 2)limited summer rearing habitat. This application is a resubmittal which has addressed the questions of fish passage and access, that arose from the LAC. This project will increase the native coho production within the Tenmile Lakes' Watershed and for the state of Oregon.

This is a cooperative project between the Umpqua Basin Watershed Council and Oregon Department of Fish & Wildlife to rebuild an inadequate fish ladder on a diversion dam on Rock creek, a tributary to the North Umpqua River. The ladder will allow wild juvenile and adult winter steelhead, summer steelhead, coho, spring chinook and cutthroat trout to access an estimated 45 miles of good quality habitat in upper Rock Creek Basin that has had inadequate passage at high and low flows.

This project is designed to restore an outstanding aquatic habitat located in Dumont Creek, Tiller RD using large woody debris placement imitating natural recruitment. This phase of the project will collect large wood from a ridgetop blow down site and transport it to storage sites located alongside Dumont Creek. Phase 3 of the project, scheduled for implementation in FY 2002 will place the LWD into the stream channel. In FY 2002, this project will be the Umpqua NF's highest priority instream project.

This project proposes to fund a field technician (Glen Brady) to assist the watershed council coordinator with project development, planning, implementation and monitoring. Glen was hired July 5th, 2000 and is currently funded for 5 months (until March 31) through OWEB funding associated with 7 projects. Because the number of UBWC restoration projects is accelerating rapidly, the workload for a field technician is expanding proportionally.

Pull existing culvert at the confluence of Peach Creek with the West Branch of the North Fork Smith River and replace with a bridge. Culvert is currently a partial barrier to adults and a full barrier to juvenile anadromous salmonids to 2.5 miles of habitat in a key watershed under the Northwest  Forest Plan and also in a high priority restoration and protection as rated in the Bradbury Process conducted by the Umpqua Basin Watershed Council.

Project Name: Clausen Farm Erosion Control and Dam Restoration Project
Project Summary: This project seeks to stop upland watershed erosion and reestablish wetland wildlife habitat by restoring and rehabilitating two earth-fill dams along the North Bank Road of the Coquille River between Coquille and Bandon.

Project Name: Across the WS - S Frk Little Butte Creek Project
Project Summary: This project will restore a 10,000-foot segment of the South Fork of Little Butte Creek. The primary goal will be to restore the natural stream process to create a self-maintaining environment that is hospitable to fish. Objectives include creating a more suitable transportation corridor for migrating fish and providing resting, refuge, and rearing habitat for historically resident fish. OWEB funds will be used as match for a Section 206 Grant.

Project Name: Bear Creek Riparian Tree Planting Project
Project Summary: This project will develop a watershed riparian planting program for the Bear Creek Watershed. The goals are to improve watershed conditions by decreasing water temperature, stabilizing stream banks, and providing for greater habitat diversity, RVCOG will accomplish these goals by implementing the following three phase project: 1. RVCOG will assess riparian conditions to develop a prioritized planting plan. 2. Plant approximately 15,000 native trees and shrubs. 3. Develop an effective maintenance and monitoring program. In addition, RVCOG will coordinate landowner workshops and produce a riparian planting guide.

Project Name: Upper Bryon Creek WS Fish Habitat Restoration & Enhancement
Project Summary: Using ODFW and BLM protocol, continue pre-project monitoring of fish counts, stream habitat/morphology and water flow/quality. Project manager has competed OSU/DEQ/Douglas county sponsored Master Water Quality Manager program.  Use existing landowner road repair organization to inform and educate all landowner participants about watershed health and potential fish habitat restoration on 2.5 miles of Byron Creek. Maintenance issues surrounding gravel road run-off in relation to sedimentation will be discussed with all participating landowners.

Project Name: Marys River Long term Water quality monitoring
Project Summary: This project is the first phase toward developing the capacity for high-quality, long-term water quality monitoring within the Watershed Council by training dedicated volunteers and strengthening our existing partnership with the local high school advance science classes, collecting the first year of data, and presenting the results to the community at the first annual Mary's River Watershed Conference.
This project will continue to provide stream gaguing for the Marys River.  This project will maintain the data necessary for the continuation of water quality improvement efforts.

Project Name: Assessment Fish use in Restored Lower Columbia Basin Flood
Project Summary: Fish use of three floodplain wetlands in the Willamette River Basin between Harrisburg and its confluence with the Columbia will be investigated. Different restoration strategies are being tested, but each are expected to improve ecological requirements for native fish. Using an established monitoring protocol, we will evaluate these strategies with particular reference to early life history requirements of salmonids. Information will be assembled to direct future restoration.

The Tualatin Watershed Citizen Monitoring Program fulfills 3 main purposes: 1)Provide an infrastructure, workforce, and quality assured data to monitor restoration project effectiveness. 2) expand citizen monitoring and create greater awareness of watershed land-use interactions, and 3) fill gaps in our knowledge of watershed conditions. The program is a Collaborative effort among OGI, Saturday Academy's Student Watershed Research Project, the Tualatin Riverkeepers, and the Tualatin River Watershed Council.
Assess physical condition and watershed health of Pedee Creek to set restoration priorities.

Assess road/ stream crossings in the Dairy-McKay Creek Watershed to develop culvert prioritization matrix that includes transportation as well as fish passage needs, integrated into database and GIS format for use by others. Include information obtained by Tualatin River Watershed Council, ODF&W, and Bureau of Land Management into a consolidated database that accurately depicts opportunities for stream recovery for threatened and endangered fish species.

This pilot project will plan, develop and initiate a watershed technical assistance program to support watershed councils, Soil and Water Conservation Districts and local governments, who are faced with developing plans and work tasks to address the Endangered Species Act (ESA) and the Clean Water Act (CWA) in the Willamette Basin.

Project Name: Coast Fork Willamete WS Preliminary Assessment
Project Summary: The Coast Fork Willamette Watershed Council proposes to complete a Preliminary Watershed Assessment, using the Oregon Watershed Assessment Manual as a guide. The Council will employ an independent contractor to conduct the project. The preliminary watershed assessment process will require the organization of existing data and conclusion from multiple stakeholder sources. Collected information will be analyzed and published in report form, summarizing past and current conditions of the watershed. The document will help to identify data gaps and issues that need further consideration. Additional data collection and action plan priorities will be based on the results of the Preliminary Assessment.

The CSWC will compile/evaluate existing information/data to assess current condition, identify threats to watershed health, identify data gaps, and set restoration/protection objectives for Columbia Slough. This will be the first fully integrated assessment covering the entire urban watershed. It will be powerful too, made available to all stakeholders, to assist in implementing Statewide Planning Goal 5, Title III, Endangered Species Act, and TMDL, regulation facing the many local government jurisdictions.

Project Name: Clackamas Deep Goose and Basin Wide Assessment
Project Summary: The Clackamas River Basin Council and it's partners intend to conduct a Watershed Assessment and develop a Preliminary Action Plan of the Deep and Goose Creek Watersheds. We also propose to conduct a basin-wide watershed assessment in the second year. A contractor will be hired to work with the watershed council, it's partners, a technical advisory committee and local citizen volunteers to complete the assessments using the Oregon Watershed Assessment Manual Methodology. The project will include private landowner contacts, community meetings and public presentations throughout the watershed.

Metro is requesting $200,000 to go towards the acquisition of Rock Island in the Willamette River. The total cost of the island is estimated at $550,000 not including real estate expenses. Rock Island is almost 67 acres in size and of which 22 acres are heavily forested with mature Douglas fir, Oregon white oak and pacific madrone. A meadow on the east side of the island supports a small population of rare plant, pale larkspur (Delphinum leucophaeum) and native grasses. The island is highly visible from Hwy. 99

Three Rivers Land Conservancy requests 25% of the purchase price of a 50-acre property along Wilson Creek, a tributary of lower Tualatin River. This purchase is one phase of a long-term plan to protect approximately 300-acres of natural area along Wilson Creek in the lower reaches of the Tualatin Basin.

To acquire and restore approximately 390 acres of prior converted wetlands. This project will be a cooperative effort between the Oregon Dept of Fish  & Wildlife (ODF&W), the US Fish & Wildlife, East Lane Soil & Water Conservation Dist, The Natural Resource Conservation Dist (NRCS), and the landowner David Jampolsky, to restore, and enhance the property to wetlands and wetland habitat for wildlife and watershed quality.

Restoration of the Turner Creek Watershed to improve and protect the water quality for the City of Yamhill and to enhance the once thriving anadromous fish habitat of this basin.  The project will provide fish passage, debris passage, control and abatement of silt from slides caused by logging operations.

The proposed project is to restore Richardson Creek to a natural channel and restore adjacent habitat that was filled during construction of the reservoir. The modifications will restore channel substrate and facilitate restoration of riparian, emergent and submerged vegetation with and along the drainage.

Removal of non-native, invasive plants and replacement with appropriate native vegetation to restore a 77- acre wetland complex that connects with a salmon bearing stream. This will increase biodiversity, water quality, fish & wildlife habitat, and reduce invasive plant populations.

Project Name: Marion County Fish Passage Restoration Project
Project Summary: The project will open up 66 miles of upstream habitat to fish, including the threatened salmonids, by remediating existing road culverts to make them possible by fish.

This project will positively impact channel habitat, ground water recharge, flood attenuation, soil erosion and fish and wildlife habitat in the Tualatin River watershed through restoration of a historic oxbow lake, native wet prairie, shrub swamp and riparian forest buffer.

This project will restore seasonal and semi-permanent wetlands and riparian forest buffer on 88 acres of private land along the Willamette River. The completed project will improve water quality in the Willamette River and provide important wetland habitat for a multitude of wildlife species. The project will be completed by a diverse partnership of state and federal agencies, private landowners, and a non-profit conservation organization.

This proposal involves the restoration of Smith and Bybee lakes. Historically, this interconnected wetland system functioned as a seasonal marsh in the Columbia River floodplain near the mouth of the Willamette River. The construction of a fixed outlet in the early 1980's transformed this marsh into a permanent lake, resulting in the loss of productive wetland habitat. With this proposal the historic hydrology and marsh habitats will be restored, providing benefits to salmon, water quality and other wildlife.

This project addresses water quality and wildlife habitat by restoring 40 acres of wetlands on private land within the North Unit of Sauive Island Wildlife Management Area. The restoration plan was modeled after the ODFW wetland restoration project on the adjoining property. Restoration will focus on mimicking the natural hydrology by installing two manageable ditch plugs with fishways and 3 small earthen ditch plugs. This project meets the landowners objectives and provides juvenile salmon rearing habitat.

Wetland Education Component includes design, development & evaluation of: a) an overall Interpretive Plan for West Eugene Wetlands Project; b) a site-specific Interpretive Plan for Site 1135 & implementation of site-plan including structure(s) & signage; c) teacher and volunteer staff training component; d) education materials, including conventional and digital training manuals/guides and advanced technology-base study skills training that uses "supported text" to reach wide audience.

To help local established groups (neighborhood associations, businesses, granges, non-profits, school, etc.) develop watershed restoration activities. It would initially staff one person including benefits and support materials. This person would do outreach to local groups, connect them to related efforts and establish a watershed advisory committee. To work in areas that currently have no watershed council.

Sherman County SWCD will provide .5 FTE for two years for a watershed assessment of Grass Valley Watershed using the Oregon Watershed Assessment Manual. OWEB funds will be used to pay for .28 FTE, the remainder will be donated by Sherman County SWCD.

The Sherman County SWCD proposes to conduct a watershed assessment of the Grass Valley watershed.  The assessment will follow the OWEB "Manual".  Funding is to support a part time staff person to conduct the analysis.

The Water Education Foundation proposes to make a poster of the Klamath Basin showing hydrologic features, major restoration projects, fish species use, wildlife refuges, agricultural activities and water conservation and use challenges.  The poster would be distributed widely.
Provide Watershed Education tools to Landowners and the Public in the Upper Klamath Basin.

The Deschutes Irrigation Water Management Partnership will improve and help stabilize stream flows through distribution system improvements and applied Irrigation water Management (IWM) techniques for agricultural water users in the Upper Deschutes Basin. The IWM Partnership will provide the dual benefit of greater efficiency and production opportunities for private landowners as well as improve water quality, salmonid habitat and riparian in the Upper Deschutes Basin.

Project will implement best management practices (BMPs) and riparian vegetation in the Grass Valley Watershed.  Implementation will take place as elements of farm conservation plans. A riparian restoration on the Sherman High School campus will provide a convenient educational resource and will compliment the Sherman SWCD Conservation Nursery recently established on the high school campus.

This project seeks to implement a model county-based cost share program as a one year demonstration in Wasco County pursuant to the Legislative budget note, "Soil and Water Conservation Districts are encouraged to apply to OWEB's Watershed Improvement Grant Fund for cost share projects involving local watershed council participation_" Practices locally reviewed and approved for cost share will meet the legislative intent of implementing measure to improve water quality or the Oregon Plan for Salmon and Watersheds.

Fifteenmile Creek is currently eroding into a tilled field. Because of the lack of permanent vegetation, this site has the potential to erode very quickly, destroying many acres of valuable cropland and depositing many tons of sediment into Fifteenmile Creek. This proposal seeks to stabilize this bank with bioengineering techniques, to create a stable vegetated bank between the crop field and the creek and stop any streambank erosion at the site.

The Crooked River Watershed Council and the Ochoco National Forest will partner to hire a full time permanent position hydrologist that will be available for council supported, private land project design and oversight of implementation. The initial augment between the council and the forest covers a 2 year period. 7 projects will be implemented.  Additional private stream restoration projects will be prioritized and developed.

Project Name: Sprague River Water Quality and Water Conservation
Project Summary: This project will collect irrigation water from a hayfield and redistribute it over an adjacent pasture. Currently irrigation tail water drains through a washed out culvert directly into 303(d) listed Sprague River potentially contributing to increased in water temperature, nutrients, and sediment. The project will install a new culvert with headgate, pump and pipeline for recycling, and provide for water quality monitoring before and after implementation. The water quality data will determine project success.

Project Name: Bartell Ranch Irrigation Water Recovery System
Project Summary: This project will provide a system to recycle irrigation water from 104 acres of pasture. The system includes a toe ditch, pump, return ditch, and pipe. The system will reduce nutrient loading, sedimentation, and temperature in the water quality impaired Sprague River.

The project will enhance and develop an existing 5 acre pond. The pond will be deepened and wetland vegetation will be established. Livestock will be excluded by fencing and be provided with off-site watering. The project will provide excellent waterfowl habitat, particularly for nesting, and reduce non-point source pollution entering the water quality impaired Sprague River.

Project Name: Sprague River Ranch Irrigation Recovery System
Project Summary: This project will provide a system to recycle irrigation water from 200 acres of pasture. The system includes a toe ditch, pump, drain tiles, diking, and culverts. The system will reduce nutrient loading, sedimentation, and temperature in the water quality impaired Sprague River.

Project Name: Logan Valley/Malheur Headwaters PFC and Hydrologic Potential
Project Summary: Assess Current Function of Streams within the Malheur Headwaters Sub-watershed including private lands administer by the USDA Forest Service. Plans are to use PFC, Rosgen stream classifications and potential, riparian vegetation status, road drainage/culvert effects.

Project Name: Grande Ronde Basin Monitoring Plan Development
Project Summary: Develop a comprehensive Monitoring Plan and program for the Grande Ronde Basin that will assess restoration project effectiveness and determine baseline water quality conditions and water quality trends. The monitoring Plan will be prepared by a technical specialist in  collaboration with the Grande Ronde Water Quality Advisory Group (WAG). The Monitoring Plan will identify key issues and monitoring objectives, and develop the Basin-wide monitoring strategy and design.

Project Name: Affordable Soil Moisture Monitoring Education for Irrigators
Project Summary: The project seeks to introduce irrigators in Union and Wallowa counties to a recently developed affordable soil moisture monitoring device which can enable them to improve their irrigation scheduling and water management skills. The device, the AM400 soil moisture sensor technology in its operation. The project seeks to demonstrate this technology to as many irrigators as possible as an aid to increasing more efficient water use.

The purchase of 73 acres of land and water rights is a necessary element of a project that will expand the Walla Walla River floodplain where it is currently constricted by 7 miles of levees. This land and water acquisition project is one facet of a $2.6 million levee setback and riparian restoration program with the US Army Corps of Engineers and the Umatilla Tribes. If funded we will restore one and half miles of riparian habitat along known steelhead and bull trout habitat. Both species are ESA listed.

This group of projects will convert approximately 110 acres of flood irrigated land to sprinklers. The irrigated parcels are located east of Joseph, Oregon in the area known as upper Prairie Creek. This area receives irrigation water for the Wallowa Valley Improvement Canal, which diverts water from the Imnaha basin and brings it into the Wallowa Valley. 80% of the lands serviced by the Wallowa Valley Improvement Canal (WVIC) is sprinkler irrigated. Reducing the acreage of flood irrigation in the area will require the WVIC to divert less water from the Imnaha basin, less water will be delivered into the Prairie Creek area, reducing the streamflow of Prairie Creek.

This project is to improve irrigation on approximately 50 acres of irrigated ground by:  Installing 1600 feet of 5-inch PVC pipe to replace an earthen ditch and supplement existing pipeline.  Install a shut off valve in existing 5-inch mainline.  Add an additional 1/4 mile of 4-inch, 30 foot sections, of handlines to irrigation system.

This juniper abatement project covers approximately 85+ acres of sloping canyon walls. Dense juniper stands are shading out the native pine seedlings and grasses. Shallow soils made up of small pebbles move easily with spring run-off. The project will promote a healthier balance through juniper thinning and aerial grass seeding. Soils will be stabilized with new root systems and residue placement of cut juniper limbs. Young pines will be encouraged by strategic thinning and barrier protection from grazing.

This project will convert 90 acres of flood irrigated land to sprinkler irrigation in the Prairie Creek area of Wallowa County. Conversion to sprinkler irrigation from flood will improve irrigation efficiency from 40% for flood irrigation to 65% for sprinkler. The sprinkler irrigated land will require 30 inches of water versus 60 inches currently being used, resulting in 2700 inches of water saved. Conversion to sprinkler irrigation will require the installation of 3200 feet of buried pvc pipeline, with risers and 25 hp pump. 3 hand sprinklers will be installed to apply water to the land.

This project will improve riparian area conditions along 6800 feet of Prairie Creek. Reduce streambank erosion and amount of sediments entering Prairie Creek. Replace a irrigation diversion structure and barrier to fish passage with pumping plant.

This project consists of rehabilitating native Redband and Threatened Bull trout habitat by planting wetland type vegetation and installing micro-jet/drip irrigation systems on selected private land stream banks to re-establish riparian habitat on Malheur River tributaries. A portable pumping system will be used to service newly planted sites to provide available water, until the vegetation has established enough of a root system to maintain itself. Selected sites will also be fenced with electric wire (solar).

This project consists of construction of a pond (1/4 acre) to collect and filter sediment and accompanying nutrient runoff from crop and pasture land. This pond will also help to decompose residual chemical runoff of pesticides and herbicides, and reduce nitrogen/phosphorous effluent from fertilizers entering the Malheur River. As an additional benefit, the pond site will provide wildlife habitat for waterfowl, upland game birds, and small mammals. Vegetation plantings of sedges and rushes will be accomplished.

This is a conversion of an existing ditch, which loses high amounts of water, to a gravity fed, pressurized pipeline. Water savings from the conversion is estimated to be up to 75% savings from the conversion.

Building approximately 5500 feet of permanent let down fence on Little Crane Creek Fencing will improve water quality and potentially increase spawning success of bull trout (threatened species) within this area.  Approximately half of this fence is now completed.  Completion of fence will permit grazing with less administration needed to prevent damage to spawning areas.

A continuation of earlier successful work, this project will install 7 drop structures along Owsley Canyon Creek. In addition, riparian fencing will be built and plantings will be established along this reach of stream.

Project Name: Wolf Creek Riparian Enhancement and Irrigation Consolidation
Project Summary: This is Phase I of a multi-phase project on a 2 mile section of Wolf Creek that will involve riparian fencing, riparian plantings, installing a fish screen, building two ponds and a wetland area, and installing mainline pipe to replace three ditches.

This project will provide cost share assistance to install automated headgates on 2 ditches in the Lostine River system.  Automatic headgates will limit irrigation and stockwater withdrawals to values set by the ditch company, open and close the gate with diurnal stream fluctuations.  The device will also record diversion amounts on a daily, monthly and annual basis.

This proposal is a continuation of water conservation, water quality, and water temperature efforts recently implemented by the landowner on this property.  The objective of this project is to reduce water usage by converting flood irrigation to low pressure sprinkler irrigation on 151.8 acres in the Ladd Creek drainage.  Priority dates of 1868 and 1870.  By changing the method of applying the water, water usage will be reduced by 1.75 cfs.  As a result the enhanced stream flows will improve habitat and population health for aquatic plants and wildlife that are part of this ecosystem.  Ladd Creek supports spring chinook salmon, summer steelhead, and bull trout; all ESA listed salmonid species.
Oregon State University proposes to use grant funds to support training for watershed council technical advisory teams and to provide graduate students trained in watershed sciences.

The Watermaster District 11 office operates 40 stream gauging stations in the Upper Deschutes basin.  Many of the uppermost gauges are situated on the lower east slope of the Cascade mountains and are bound by snow from December to April every winter.  In addition to the gauges, the office operates several high elevation total precipitation gauges that require service during the winter.  The Snowcat will enable the office to operate and service these gauges at all times during the year.

A full time Watershed Conservationist with expertise in fish biology and/or hydrology would be jointly employed by the Siuslaw Watershed Council and Siuslaw SWDC.  The Watershed Conservationist would provide needed technical assistance and project management for Council and District watershed enhancement projects, landowner requested technical assistance, support for NRCSs CREP program (and other Farm Bill programs), landowner ESA and CWA compliance requests, and community educational outreach.

Project Name: Skipanon Slough Tide Gate Engineering Project
Project Summary: The Project will hire an engineer to design 3 plans for the removal, relocation and improved fish passage design of the Skipanon Slough Tide Gate, and priority barrier to rearing salmonid habitat in the lower Skipanon River.  Additionally, the Northcoast technical review team will help decide the best tide gate design for the project.

A demonstration project will be planned and designed to address over-widened channels that contribute to high water temperatures, low dissolved oxygen levels, and loss of critical fish habitats.  Strategic plantings of gravel bars with native riparian vegetation will help to narrow and shape active stream channels, resulting in water quality and fish habitat enhancement.

Project Name: MidCoast Fish Passage Restoration Prioritization and Design
Project Summary: Fund staff time (0.6FTE) to identify, prioritize and design fish passage projects in middle coast watershed.  Multiple agencies and groups will cooperate to develop a solid fish passage restoration program.  Program will be modeled after the Rogue Basin Fish Passage team.  Fish passage staff will design ten restorations and submit for funding at least five priority passage projects.

This funding will assist with developing a project which will consolidate five unscreened irrigation diversions into one screened diversion.  Two diversions on Griffin Creek and three diversions on Jackson Creek will be eliminated by constructing a new fish friendly diversion.  Over 2000 feet of open ditch system will be replaced with pressure pipe. This project addresses water conservation, fish protection and migration for Summer Steelhead.

Geotechnic, geomorphic and restoration analysis, planning and design for private lands not included in Bureau of Reclamation's Bank Stabilization and Restoration Project of the Tyler Creek Wasteway is proposed.  A 2.5-mile stretch of a tributary to Bear Creek suffered severe erosion damage when used to transport irrigation water in 1993 and unless restored, will contributed to phosphorus, turbidity and sediment problems for years to come.  Stabilization and restoration will permit continued BPR use within guidelines.

Siuslaw Watershed council proposes to provide technical assistance for restoration project development in the upper Siuslaw River and Lorane Valley sub-basin and has initiated outreach meetings with the community.  However, the Council does not have personnel to offer on the ground technical assistance which the community has requested.  Therefore, there is a critical need for technical assistance at this time.  The council will engage a conservation planner to contact cooperators and assist them in designing restoration work.  At least four such projects will be developed with applications for implementation funding to be submitted to OWEB and/or other organizations.

This project will develop detailed plans and designs for restoring a tributary of Coyote Creek.  Currently this tributary is diverted through a tile drain and routed along landowner's driveway.  Restoration planning will include a topographic survey, planting plan, hydrologic analysis, hydraulic analysis, and channel design and drawings.

This project will create a GIS layer that integrates land ownership with existing watershed assessment and restoration prioritization data layers.  Ten sub-basins maps will be created and show detailed land ownership to match the Council's other sub-basin maps. A contact information data base will be linked to these layers.

Project Name: Southern Willamette Near Stream Management Project
Project Summary: The East Lane SWCD and McKenzie, Middle Fork, Coast Fork, Long Tom WSC expect a large workload over the next year helping landowners address near-stream management issues and the local Agricultural Water Quality Managemnet Area Plan and Rules in the McKenzie, Middle Fork, Coast Fork and Long Tome Watersheds.

This project will focus on implementation of recommendations developed in the Tualatin River watershed analysis process.  Staff will provide technical assistance to individual landowners to develop voluntary water quality farm plans and develop project designs for restoration projects.  This process will further implement the Tualatin River Sub-basin Agricultural Water Quality Management area Plan and the Tualatin River Watershed Council Action Plan.

Project Name: West Fork of Pringle Creek Stream Enhancement Project
Project Summary: The West Fork of Pringle Creek is an urban stream that has been subjected to channelization, increased stormwater flows, and a reduction in native riparian vegetation.  A 2000 foot stretch of creek flows through public property (i.e. Judson Middle School and Woodmansee City Park).  The Pringle Creek Watershed Council, Salem-Keizer School District and the City of Salem are seeking funds to hire a consultant to conduct a hydrologic assessment, develop a stream enhancement plan, and obtain all necessary permits.

Project Name: Wildlife Habitat Planning for Yamhill County Parks
Project Summary: A Wildlife habitat plan will be prepared for ten developed county park locations and five undeveloped sites by a wildlife biologist.  These areas are spread geographically throughout Yamhill County and total close to 160 acres.  Various management options identified for each site will be prioritized by the Park Board for implementation and portions will be included in the Park master Plan.  Sites will be evaluated for stream and riparian condition, current vegetation, and existing and potential habitat for common species found in the watershed.  Yamhill Basin Council, Yamhill SWCD, and Yamhill County parks Board will seek funding and volunteer sponsors for projects.

Project Name: Wasco County SWCD Technical Assistance and Planning Staff
Project Summary: Two Conservation Technician/Certified Planners will provide planning and design assistance to landowners, irrigation districts and other entities enrolling in CREP or other SWCD/NRCS programs.

Project Name: Sherman County Resource Management System Planning
Project Summary: Technical/Planner will assist in development of 20+ resource management system plans including Endangered Species Act consultation and NEPA compliance.  Technical/Planner will receive on-the-job training from existing planning staff.

Project Name: Riparian Buffers in the Upper Deschutes Sub-basin
Project Summary: A technical assistance project to fund a Riparian Ecosystem Planner to develop conservation plans to better utilize USDA Conservation Reserve Programs (Conservation Reserve Enhancement Program & Continous Conservation Reserve Program) to restore riparian ecosystems in the Upper Deschutes Sub-basin (Crook, Deschutes and Jefferson Counties).  When implemented 67 stream miles and approximately 605 riparian ecosystems will be restored by 2004.  Not eligible as submitted

Project Name: North Fork John Day Technical Assistance Project
Project Summary: This project will implement more conservation project development, with the Monument SWCD and North Fork John Day Watershed Council.  As of right now this basin has a highly extensive monitoring program, as a result of this program, we need more conservation projects to be developed.  The outcome of developing and completing any conservation type projects, would be helpful for determining if projects such as Juniper Cover reduction and Riparian improvements have positive aspects for water quality parameters.

Oregon Water Trust will lease consumptive water rights from two landowners on Evans Creek, a priority watershed within the Rogue Basin, and convert those to instream water rights for the 2001 irrigation season. Total instream flow created through these leases will be almost one cfs.

Project Name: Williams Creek Watershed Council Support Project
Project Summary: Since our inception in 1996 we have existed as a volunteer organization, working closely with other groups such as ARWC to improve conditions in our watershed. We have recently completed our watershed assessment and action plan and are ready to implement projects that were identified and prioritized in these documents. We need a paid coordinator to facilitate these efforts and to organize the increasingly complex operations of the Council.

Since1994, the Tryon Creek Watershed Council has been operated and run by volunteers. The watershed assessment is in process, the area is experiencing dynamic growth, and a real opportunity exists for the Council to assist efforts for water quality improvements. There is a high potential for salmon recovery in this urban watershed. Significant coordination work is needed as a complex process is underway with several jurisdictions and resource management entities involved in planning, outreach, education, restoration and recreation questions and projects. A dedicated watershed coordinator is essential to provide needed support for the council, thereby increasing its effectiveness and benefiting the preservation and enhancement of the area's natural resources and enhancing community livability.
Grant will fund one FTE to coordinate five watershed council in Wasco County. Coordinator will receive technical and fiscal support from SWCD staff, as well as other watershed council partners.

Projects will fund a coordinator to help the resources management of local landowners, State and Federal agencies and public interest groups. Implement the Bully Creek Watershed Assessment and Strategy, implement a water quality monitoring assessment, perform outreach for public awareness of watershed issues, pursue funding for projects, facilitate meetings between federal land management agencies and users.

Lincoln Soil and Water would like to continue taking the Stream Demonstration Models to the schools.  The demand for the models exceeds the original expectations.  We have had a great response from the teachers and students and would like to be able to expand this effort.

Project Name: Tillamook Bay Salmon Life Cycle Monitoring
Project Summary: This project, ongoing since 1998, monitors fish populations, chiefly salmonids, in the Little North Fork Wilson River and the Little South Fork Kilchis River. Statistically rigorous methods provide weekly and annual estimates of fish numbers by species, age and/or size class.  This information can assess annual variability in population strength, and also could be useful in evaluating effects of land use and management actions on these populations.

This project will collect quantitative biological data for the salmonid resource in Grant Cr.  The data will be collected by the landowner's family and will provide management agencies with the ability to assess juvenile, adult and water quality trends in a primary spawning and rearing tributary of the Yaquina.  This information is currently unavailable because of a loss of access to agency staff to private property for monitoring activities.

Project Name: Long-term monitoring strategy for Clatsop Co. Watershed Coun
Project Summary: The watershed councils of Clatsop County propose to have a RARE program participant implement a long-term monitoring strategy, by filling data gaps found in the recently completed assessments, compiling new data, and creating a user-friendly data base for interested parties to continue monitoring.  The monitoring will follow approved protocols and allow agencies and interested parties the opportunity to utilize the data to meet their goals and meet the objectives of the councils.

Project Name: Beaver Habitat Monitoring in the Alsea Watershed
Project Summary: The goal is to monitor the abundance and distribution of beaver populations, and to measure the resulting changes in channel morphology, temperature, and habitat profiles in Buck/Crab/Green R. subbasins before and after the incorporation of full spanning log complexes.  This project addresses a critical assessment data gap for coastal watersheds, and creates a workforce training and employment program for Alsea workers. The applicant will also explore ways that beaver habitat can be enhanced to save stream restoration costs.

Project Name: Habitat Assessment of the Lower Columbia River
Project Summary: The project will develop a high definition, geographically accurate data set and GIS maps of the lower Columbia River aquatic and wetland habitat structure using a combination of satellite and airborne remote sensing imagery, field data and existing GIS data.  The data and maps will greatly improve our ability to make scientifically defensible decisions about the protection and restoration of critical habitat and the support of an aggressive, critical habitat protection and restoration program.

Project Name: Reconstruct. Of historic floodplain habitat of the LCR
Project Summary: Using historic literature and maps, the resettlement floodplain habitat of the lower Columbia River will be reconstructed from Bonneville Dam downstream to the Pacific Ocean.  GIS historic data base and maps will be developed that provide baseline information for contrasting historic conditions with current conditions and identifying habitat critical to native species.  The information will assist in the identification of critical habitat for protection and restoration and assessing changes in habitat over time.

The Siuslaw National Forest and Rosboro Lumber Company are discussing a land exchange which has the potential to put into Federal ownership contiguous land bases in key watersheds with important coho and late-succession habitat and offer better protection for the Yachats municipal watershed.  Due to extensive staff and budget cuts in the Siuslaw National Forest, additional funding is being sought for the site appraisals and environmental analysis needed as the first step in the land exchange process.

Project Name: Assessment of Riparian and W.Q. Cond. Below Powerlines
Project Summary: The project entails the collection of field data at Blachly Lane Electric Coop powerline crossings over riparian areas in order to determine the level to which each site for a Phase Two restoration.  This project will effect more than three miles of riparian areas in Deadwood, Lake Creek, Wildcat Creek subbasins within the Siuslaw Watershed.  Both Deadwood Creek and Lake Creek are 303(d) listed.

Remove fish passage/stream function problem crossing at School Fork Creek and replace with a bridge.  The 2000 acre watershed above this crossing contains over 2 miles of high quality Coho spawning and rearing habitat.  Other options at this site have been assessed and a bridge is the correct solution for this crossing.  This project is put forth in partnership between Lincoln SWCD, ODFW, MidCoast Watersheds, USFS, National Audubon Society, and Lincoln County Public Works.

This project continues TCSWCD'S successful program of streamside fencing, development of off-stream watering facilities, and riparian zone planting.  Continuation of this project supports on-going implementation of local conservation management plans, including: resource management plans, water quality plans, watershed council action plans, and the Tillamook Bay Comprehensive Conservation Management Plan.  Historically, this project has improved salmonid habitat, slowed erosion rates, and restored riparian areas.

This project will improve both juvenile and adult salmonid passage on an important tributary of Beaver Creek, located low in the Yaquina watershed.  Four culverts will be replaced that impede temperature dependant upstream migrations of juveniles.  Juvenile inventories indicate a barrier exists at two of these sites.  A minimum of 1 mile of high quality rearing habitat will become accessible as a result of this effort.  Off channel watering for livestock will be developed to reduce impacts on water quality within this tributary.

Gearhart Bog is the largest contiguous wetland of its kind remaining on the Oregon coast and the most significant of wetlands on the Clatsop Plains.  Because of the unique ecological values of this natural area, we need to carefully plan restoration projects based on a thorough evaluation of potential outcomes.  This project will evaluate Gearhart Bog's hydrology and water quality in order to: (1) quantify threats to the bog's wetlands posed by septic systems, cranberry bogs and other agricultural uses, (2) assess the effects of remnant drainage ditches on water flow, and (3) develop a restoration plan to guide the removal of existing logging roads within the bog in order to restore natural hydrologic conditions.

Project Name: Unname Creek No. 2 (Green Creek) Culvert and Stream Restor.
Project Summary: Improvements will be made to the culvert crossing streambed on Honey Grove Road at Milepost 1.87 by replacing the existing culvert with an oversized arch culvert and restoring the streambed that has been scoured below the existing culvert.  A small concrete dam located below the culvert crossing will also be removed.  The project area will be replanted with native or other suitable vegetation to enhance the restoration of this area.  This will provide fish passage to excellent habitat upstream.

The project proposes to plant the riparian area of about 1 mile of lower Drift Cr., Siletz and Anderson Cr., tributary to Drift Cr.  On Drift Cr., willow would be planted from the high water line to the top of the bank and a mix of conifer would be planted at the top of the bank and extend 50 to 100 feet from the stream.  Anderson Creek would be planted exclusively with willow.

The project proposes to add large wood at 15 sites on Oxbow Creek.  Project sites were selected based on locations where woody debris would naturally accumulate.  Cooperators in this project include Roseburg Forest Products, Siuslaw Watershed Council, Siuslaw SWCD and the Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife.

The project involves the South Slough NERR's acquisition of the project sites using federal funds (currently under way) and the subsequent restoration (primarily levee removal and tide channel restoration/construction) supported with OWEB and other organizations' contributed funds and inkind services.  Combined with adjacent protected tidal wetlands (Cox and Duncan Islands), the project will contribute over 500 acres of critical juvenile salmonid habitat along a five mile portion of the lower Siuslaw Estuary.

The applicant proposes to improve fish passage on Samson Creek by using a scour chain above the culvert, boulders placed within, and weirs created below.  The culvert is an intermittent barrier depending on rainfall and flow.  Fish presence surveys show coho, Chinook, chum, steelhead and cutthroat use in Samson Creek.  Partners include Tilamook County Public Works, ODFW and NRCS engineers to meet fish passage criteria for 50-year flow events will open 1 mile of habitat to salmonids.  July1-Sept. 15 in-water work period will be utilized.

Project Name: Clatskanie river/Anunde Island Shallow Water Hab. Rest.
Project Summary: Removal of a land bridge between the Clatskanie River and Kinnunen Cut/Beeson Slough on east end of anunde Island to improve shallow water habitat access for salmonids.

The project calls for fecal coliform testing at a local lab on samples that will also be tested for DNA genetic markers.  OSU will do the genetic marker study to identify human, bovine, feline, canine, and other sources.  This will help guide in prioritizing implementation actions for fishery habitat improvement projects directly related to salmonid survival.  Fecal coliform numbers will help identify areas that concentrated efforts.

This project focuses on an injection of wood complexity to a significant spawning and rearing tributary of the mainstem Yaquina.  The wood will serve to boost habitat complexity for juvenile salmonids and provide both summer and winter rearing habitats for threatened stocks of Coastal Coho.  The project follows a riparian recovery project implemented by 319 funding from DEQ.

Project Name: Acquisition of a Conser. Ease. To Pro. Vernal Pools
Project Summary: The Nature Conservancy proposes to acquire a conservation easement over a 155.43 acre parcel containing a key vernal pool wetland system in Upper Rogue Watershed.  Vernal pool wetland systems furnish watershed benefits including 1) improving water quality  2) providing natural flood control, and 3) protecting declining habitat for the vernal pool fairy shrimp, a federally listed threatened species, large flowered wooly meadowfoam, proposed for federal listing as an endangered species, and 16 additional at-risk species.

Project Name: Spirit of the Rogue Nature Center - Interim Prog. Del. Con.
Project Summary: This project will allow continuation of a yearly program delivery to over 2000 youth on-site, over 1,100 students in schools, and 30,000 site visitors.  This project is part of the overall program of Spirit of the Rogue Nature Center, and identified in the URAW's work plan as high priority.  The applicant proposes to hire a full time project director to implement the Master Plan, a part-time Natural Resource Education Coordinator and Administrative Assistant.  Remainder of funds for site operation during development of marketing and fundraising.

Project Name: Watershed Education and Management Planning Project
Project Summary: This project will educate high school students and teachers in agriculture, biology, earth science, water chemistry, and other related classes about watershed health and water quality.  It will introduce the students and teachers to the agencies and their local representatives.  The audience (class and teachers) at each location will learn by hearing a series of presentations as well as completing a management plan for a piece of rural property in their area.  A coordinator will be used to mange the projects.

Project Name: Lets Celebrate Salmon!! K-3 Salmon Education
Project Summary: Lets Celebrate Salmon! is a watershed and salmon education project for grade levels K-3.  It incorporates volunteers to lead children in salmon and watershed related classroom activities, to view salmon in the field and has a professional storytelling component that will reflect accurate natural history information.

This project proposes to secure a year of funding for the UBWC public information specialist to develop and coordinate education and outreach efforts for the council.  This proposal serves to facilitate specific educational efforts, including creation of a newsletter, web page, brochures, fact sheets, PSA's, slide shows and outside publishing.

This project will provide students and educators in the Bear Creek Watershed with increased opportunities to closely study and better understand their watershed.  RVCOG will accomplish this by sponsoring educator workshops, student symposiums, and by providing monitoring equipment, supplies, and technical expertise.  In addition, support will be provided for a Bear Creek Natural Resource Youth Corps Crew and the North Mountain Park Interpretive Area.

Project Name: J. Herbert Stone Nursery Constructed Wetland Ed
Project Summary: This project will provide Bear Creek students, educators, and the watershed community with increased opportunities to study wetland and riparian ecosystems and the impact these systems have on water quality and anadromous fisheries.  This will be accomplished by developing the J. Herbert Stone constructed wetland into an interactive educational site.  RVCOG will develop an interpretive trail system, interpretive materials (site guides, activities guide, study kit, study protocols), and coordinate workshops.

Project Name: Lower Umpqua Basin Water quality Monitoring Program
Project Summary: The Umpqua Soil and Water Conservation District proposes to initiate a water quality monitoring program to gather baseline data on waterbodies within district boundaries.  The data collected will be used to formulate a new set of reference conditions for use on agricultural lands and water bodies in the district that would eventually be adopted by DEQ (with their oversight and guidance).  This program will support 2 part-time technicians for 2 seasons.

Project Name: Coos and Curry County Ag. Lands Monitoring Program
Project Summary: This monitoring grant will complement the SB 1010 planning effort now occurring in both Coos and Curry counties.  The data collected is also being used to focus this project as a holistic approach to assess the current range of conditions on agricultural streams through baseline monitoring as an assessment tool.  Together, these will provide a strong understanding of current baseline conditions and allow assessment trends over time that result from the implementation of SB1010 plans.

This project seeks funding support for the UBWC field technician and a fisheries biologist to follow up on monitoring commitments made in previous grants.  In most grants, the ODFW was to provide inkind aquatic monitoring but recent budget cuts eliminated that service.  In others, no funding remains to allocate to monitoring.  It was applied to the on-the-ground project.  Without this funding, prior monitoring commitments are void.

Project Name: Little Butte Creek Stream Morphology Monitoring Program
Project Summary: This project will fund geomorphic analysis and monitoring of the Little Butte Creek by Southern Oregon State University students.

Project Name: Bear Creek Regional Storm Water Management Plan - Step 1
Project Summary: This project is Step 1 of a 3-step project to write and implement a regional stormwater management plan for the jurisdictions in the Bear Creek Watershed in order to reduce urban nonpoint source (NPS) pollution into Bear Creek.  Step 1 writes the regional approach aspect of the plan and prepares the jurisdictions to implement a regional plan by 1) informing jurisdictions about the sources and solutions to urban NPS run-off into Bear Creek; 2) researching, reviewing, summarizing, and presenting information on the benefits of a regional approach, implementation costs, associated regulatory requirements, and identification and pursuit of funding sources.  Final product will be agreement on a regional approach to stormwater management.

Project Name: Upper Rogue Watershed Assessment & Aerial Photo
Project Summary: Seven fifth-field watersheds will be included in a comprehensive watershed assessment.  Current data (97-00) will be gathered from multiple agencies & industry with USFS assisting to fill gaps.  The aerial survey of three key fish streams will produce a CD-ROM, videa and photos, and be used to educate landowners and stakeholders, to prioritize systematic restoration projects having no negative effects down or up stream, and for creation of a prioritized action plan.

Using ODFW and BLM protocols, this project will continue pre-project monitoring of fish counts, stream habitat, morphology and water flow/quality.  In their Aquatic Inventory, ODFW noted a lack of large riparian conifers for potential stream diversity.  Riparian vegetation management will be part of the overall watershed management plan. ODFW, UBWC and local land managers and owners will identify restoration and enhancement opportunities and then design appropriate structures.  These structures will create or deepen winter or summer habitat pools, increase sinuosity and slow water velocity, allowing potential spawning gravels to be deposited.  .  In conjunction with USFWS' Northwest Economic adjustment Initiative (Ecosystem Investment Projects), this project has the potential to train and employ local workers who have investments in the local culture and economy.  Set up post project monitoring program with paid and volunteer workers.

On Oldham Creek, adjacent to a similar project underway with OWEB funding, this project will construct 4,046 feet of riparian fence; install a hardened rock crossing; install a stock water system with 5 tank sites and plant riparian trees and shrubs.

On Morgan Creek, downstream from an OWEB funded weir project, construct 1,950 feet of riparian fence; install a hardened rock crossing; install a stock water system; and plant riparian trees and shrubs.

The purpose of this project is to develop a riparian planting program focusing on the mainstem of Bear Creek.  This project will implement actions suggested in the 1995 Bear Creek Watershed Assessment & Action Plan.  The project goal is to improve the creek's conditions through prescribed riparian plantings which will help to decrease water temperature, stabilize stream banks to decrease sedimentation and provide for greater habitat diversity.

Project Name: Rogue River Stakeholders Group River & Floodplain Mana. Plan
Project Summary: A consortium of landowners, local, state, and federal agencies have developed a river and floodplain management plan guided by a geomorphic study.  The plan provides channel adjustment opportunities within a geomorphically stable environment to reduce accelerated rates of erosion, channel degradation and impacts to fish habitat.  Seven acres of riparian vegetation will be re-established.  Fisheries enhancement and mitigation will be completed by connection of floodplain ponds to the mainstem.

Project Name: Griffin Creek Restoration and Irrigation Diversion Project
Project Summary: The Griffin Creek restoration and mitigation diversion will provide habitat, improve water quality, remove fish barriers and provide educational opportunities.  The creek has been channeled for irrigation conveyance and is deeply incised and lacks native riparian vegetation.  Restoration will reintroduce a meander and regrade and revegetate 1900 feet of creek banks.  The design will balance sediment and floodwater conveyance with improving critical aquatic habitat and water quality for Steelhead trout.

Project Name: Kerby Ditch Gravel Push-Up Dam Removal Project
Project Summary: Removal of a fish passage barrier (gravel push-up dam, restoration of hear gate, redirection of water flow from leaky gravel ditch to PVC pipe, resulting in a 30% water conservation and 90% reduction in erosion.)

Project Name: Illinois River Basin Riparian & Fish Habitat Improvement Pro
Project Summary: Restore proper function of streams, maintain and enhance riparian zone, improve sediment transport, reduce erosion, increase stream complexity and increase spawning and rearing habitat of Coho & Chinook Salmon, Steelhead and other resident trout.

The District will install a tree revetment to stabilize vertical slopes on an eroding bend of the N. Fork Smith River passing through open grazing pastureland.  This project will include willow facings, fencing, irrigation and riparian plantings.

This project will relocate a 1/4 mile section of Old Ferry Road that is 4-6 feet from the river to be 300 feet from the Rogue River.  The riparian area will be restored and nonpoint source pollution from this area will be eliminated.  Relocation will reduce turbidity and sediment caused by run-off, vehicle use, and flooding, and will improve water quality, spawning areas and habitat in this section of the river and affected areas downstream.  Restoration will be monitored for 5 years by the OFR Committee.

The Willamette/Molalla River Greenway project is an acquisition of 18 acres of Willamette riverfront property for the protection of riparian habitat including potential seasonal anadramous rearing areas, expansion of neighboring public land, and environmental educational opportunities within the critical migratory corridor of the upper Willamette Chinook salmon and steelhead runs.
