This project will prevent residential development at the heart of one of the last undeveloped stretches of riverfront in the Metro area. The City of Canby will own the property and will have joint management responsibilities with the Oregon Department of Parks and Recreation, Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife, and Clackamas County.

This acquisition application is the first phase of a multi phased project to acquire, restore, protect, manage, maintain, and enhance the functional values of wetlands, and for the conservation of natural values including fish and wildlife habitat, water quality improvement, flood water retention, groundwater recharge, open space, aesthetic values, and environmental education in the Willamette Valley Eco-region on approximately 306 acres of farmed, prior converted wetlands. Protection and restoration of seasonal emergent wetlands, bottomland forests, wet prairie and upland grassland, and oak savannah that mimic the habitat that once dominated the site will directly benefit endangered and threatened species, water quality and quantity, and biodiversity.  Acquired lands will be managed by a partnership between a non-profit organization, Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife, US Fish and Wildlife Service, and East Lane SWCD.

Three Rivers Land Conservancy requests 25% of the purchase price of 50 acres of native riparian vegetation and wetland  along Wilson Creek, a tributary of lower Tualatin River. This purchase is one phase of a long-term  natural area plan to protect approximately 300-acres of natural corridor along Wilson Creek in the lower reaches of the Tualatin Basin.  Acquisition and protection of this area will maintain native riparian vegetation along the stream, upland forest and open meadow habitat for songbirds and other animals that migrate along the stream corridor.  Acquired lands will be managed for its natural resource values.

The Marion, Polk, Yamhill and Washington SWCD will conduct an extensive outreach effort to landowners about the Conservation Reserve Enhancement Program, a riparian buffer incentive program.  The SWCDs will also prepare conservation plans for landowners that enroll in the program.  The goal of the project is to enroll 75 landowners in CREP and complete 75 conservation plans over a  two-year period.  The SWCDs will hire 2 FTE to complete the project.
This project will fund the update and publication of the Willamette Basin Atlas.

Project Name: The Oregon Garden Wetlands Education Program
Project Summary: The Oregon Garden Wetlands Project offers a unique opportunity to disseminate technical information about the importance of wetlands and sound watershed management in both a formal and informal manner to thousands of visitors.  This grant proposal along with other sources of income will fund interpretive signs strategically placed on the first sixty acres of Oregon's newest tourist attraction, an initial print run of 100,000 brochures in 2001, and 100,000 in 2002 that specifically address the importance of wetlands and how they function, and also assist in funding the visitor guides that provide the wetland tours and at least one education seminar.

Engaging Rural Community Watershed Restoration will build a community based, long-term restoration capacity in the rural areas of the Tualatin Basin.  Specific project components include: A) streamside slndowner outreach (peer-base leadership development), B) Rural Restoration Workshop Series and C) salmonid carcass placement.  This is phase two of a three year effort to implement priority restoration and monitoring projects designed to improve cold water fish habitat and water quality.

Project Name: West Eugene Wetlands 2001 Edu. Prog. Prep: (E-Prep Project)
Project Summary: Wetland Education Component includes design, development & evaluation of: A) education materials for teachers and volunteers in the West Eugene Wetlands Project; B) teacher and volunteer staff training; C) education and involvement of wetland restoration volunteers; and D) a comprehensive evaluation of all aspects of this project.

Project Name: The Effects of Water Control Structures on Native Reptiles
Project Summary: The project will support efforts to monitor turtles and amphibians to appraise the effects of four water control structures that will be introduced to the three study sites between 2001 and 2003.  The structures will be managed to extend spring flood periods to suppress exotic invasive species (e.g., unified, standardized monitoring program to track the dams' effects on turtles and amphibians).

The Tualatin Watershed Citizen Monitoring Initiative will 1) conduct ambient water quality monitoring to address known gaps in knowledge of watershed conditions (pH, temperature, turbidity, dissolved oxygen), 2) monitor restoration project effectiveness, and 3) expand citizen monitoring and create greater awareness of watershed land-use interactions.  This is a collaborative effort among OGI Saturday Academy's Student Watershed Research Project, Tualatin Riverkeepers, and Tualatin River Watershed Council.
Establishment of a monitoring program on a small watershed and integrating that monitoring into teacher education classes at the college level.

Implement a comprehensive monitoring program for the Molalla River.  The program would annually monitor macroinvertebrate communities, water quality, and physical habitat conditions at 6 established monitoring sites throughout the basin.  This OWEB grant would be used to implement and conduct the first year of this monitoring program with the cooperation of local entities and a contracted aquatic biologist.

Project Name: Lower Coast Fork Willamette Watershed Assessment
Project Summary: The Coast Fork Willamette Watershed Council proposes to complete an assessment of the Lower Coast Fork.  The proposed assessment will help the Council to fill data gaps by focusing on the lower 20% of the watershed, an area that is undergoing substantial development.  Floodplain and wetland communities in the lower reaches of the Coast Fork provide habitat for Oregon Chubb, Western Pond Turtle, Spring Chinook and other at-risk species.  The Council will employ an independent contractor to manage the project, and will follow the protocol outlined in the Oregon Watershed Assessment Manual.  The assessment process will require the organization of existing data from multiple sources and gathering new data from aerial photos and in-stream surveys.  Filling these gaps is necessary to complete an integrated assessment of the entire Coast Fork Willamette Basin.  Additional data collection, recommendations and action plan priorities will be based on the results of this assessment.

This grant proposal will assist local landowners, agencies, and the Yamhill Basin Council to begin and/or finish writing action plans for 6 fifth-field watersheds, and will fund the planning of stream bank restoration projects on two reaches of the Mill Watershed.  This proposal provides watershed groups in the Mill and Willamina watersheds with staff assistance to complete their watershed action plans.  This proposal also provides funds for the formation of watershed groups and the development of action plans in the Lower S. Yamhill, North Yamhill, Lower Yamhill and Chehalem Creek watersheds where assessments will be complete by June 30, 2001.

Project Name: Washington County Fish Passage Assessment & Prioritization
Project Summary: Develop a fish passage program and database for assessing and prioritizing fish passage status at road/stream crossings within Washington County by individual 5th field HUC basins.  The Dairy-McKay Creek Watershed will be the pilot basin for the analysis and prioritization plan.  Incorporate all current information into a consolidated database that accurately depicts opportunities for productive habitat recovery for threatened and endangered fish at County owned transportation facilities.

Project Name: Barriers Distribution & Movement Patterns of Marys River
Project Summary: The objective of the project is to track radio-tagged cutthroat trout to examine the degree to which structural barriers and temperature barriers influence movement, home ranges and habitat use patterns in the Mary's River Basin.  These data will be used to assess the degree to which cutthroat trout of the Mary's River Basin are dependent on habitat in the Willamette River proper, the patterns of seasonal use within the river and the degree to which barriers to fish movement exist.
This project will place a 20 foot section of riprap and three rock barbs on the McKenzie River.

Project Name: Washington County Fish Passage Improvement Projects
Project Summary: Replace undersized, impassable culverts to provide access to approximately seven (7) miles of habitat at two locations in the Tualatin River Watershed.  Provide fish passage improvements and habitat enhancements for these culvert replacement projects.  The applicant requests funds only for the environmental component of the project (larger culvert, more plantings, streambed simulation); costs for in-kind replacement of the existing culverts will be borne by the County.

Project Name: Arboretum Bank Education and Stabilization Project
Project Summary: The Friends of Delbert Hunter Arboretum, City of Dallas, and the Rickreall Watershed council are joining efforts to provide long-term stabilization of a 400' portion of the Rickreall Creek bank in the Delbert Hunter Arboretum Park.  This will be used as an educational tool for alternate methods of bank stabilization.  The project will slope the bank creating a natural flood zone.  Barbs will be used to stabilize the banks and increase aquatic complexity while creating a fish friendly habitat during high flows.

Project Name: Reed Canyon/Crystal Springs Headwaters Restor. Plan
Project Summary: This project would enhance fish habitat in Crystal Springs Creek  through the Reed College campus.

Project Name: W.F. Pringle Creek Log Placement and Vegetation Planting
Project Summary: Place 12 log structures within the channel for 1,600 feet of stream and plant willows along sections of stream exposed to sun.  This project will provide a substantial increase in the quality of fish habitat for this reach of W.F. Pringle Creek.

Project Name: MultCo: SE Division Dr. & Beaver Cr. Tributary Stream Passag
Project Summary: Replacement of a 4-foot diameter culvert on a tributary of Beaver Creek located at SE Division Drive.  ODFW has identified this pipe as a fish barrier for winter Steelhead and Cutthroat trout.  The new structure will be a 24-foot wide stream passage con-span.

Project Name: Brae Burn Creek Restoration and Enhancement
Project Summary: This project will 1) restore, maintain, and enhance the physical and biological integrity of a riparian zone of a headwater stream to Amazon Creek on private land, 2) add an urban land use demonstration project to the Long Tom Watershed demonstration projects, 3) include a water quality monitoring site, 4) provide education and public outreach and 5) show public and private partnership.
Provide assessment and follow-up workshops to landowners in selected areas in the Klamath Basin watershed.  Areas of focus will be identified by OSU Extension, watershed councils and working groups.

The project is described by the replacement of an existing open lateral (identified as the Fryrear Ditch) with a buried pipeline.  It provides irrigation water to approximately 475 acres.  Phase one of this project will consist of piping the first 17,453ft of ditch.  This section of the canal has a very high seepage rate, and loses water due to infiltration and evaporation.  This project will transfer 1.5 cfs of water to Squaw Creek permanently.

The project, which emphasizes juniper cutting, will enhance and restore native riparian and upland vegetation.  This will result in increased water infiltration and storage in critical areas of the 37,446 acre Chewaucan subwatershed project area, thereby reducing excessive surface runoff and soil erosion into the Chewaucan River and its tributaries.

Project Name: Agency Creek Dam Removal and Stream Restoration Project
Project Summary: The existing stream channel is dammed approximately 1,200 feet above its confluence with Crooked Creek.  As a result, approximately 1,600 feet of habitat upstream of the dam is not accessible to native fish.  In addition, as a result of the dam and impoundment, approximately 950 feet of stream habitat has been degraded or eliminated as a result of sedimentation.  The dam has also affected downstream habitats by altering hydrologic and geomorphologic regimes.
Restore 44 acres of wetlands along the Sprague River.
This project involves wetland restoration and enhancement of 86 acres adjacent to the Sprague River.

Project Name: Klamath Wildelife Area Miller Island Wetland Restoration
Project Summary: This project will prevent entrainment and incidental take of the endangered Lost River and shortnose suckers from operation of the main intake that brings water from the Klamath River to Unit C of the Klamath Wildlife Area's (WA's) Miller Island Unit.  It will improve habitat conditions for other wildlife, particularly waterfowl and other waterbirds, by enhancing about 500 acres of seasonal wetlands within Unit C.  This project will restore proper water management capabilities to these wetlands and thereby allow more efficient use of water and improve the quality of water within Unit C that is discharged into the Klamath river from the unit.  It will restore irrigation capabilities to about 150 acres of grain fields in Unit C and thereby increase forage production for fall and spring staging geese.

Project Name: Bartell Ranch Irrigation Water Recovery System
Project Summary: This project will provide a system to recycle irrigation water from 104 acres of pasture.  The system includes a toe ditch, pump, return ditch, and pipe.  The system will reduce nutrient loading, sedimentation and temperature in the water quality impaired Sprague River.

Restore 1,450 acres of Sprague River wetlands, riparian areas, and uplands and protect in a permanent WRP easement.  Improve water quality and fish and wildlife habitat in the Sprague River by decreasing sedimentation and temperature.

Project Name: Duncan Creek Channel Restoration and Stream Corridor Enhance
Project Summary: The Duncan Creek Channel Restoration and Stream Corridor Enhancement Project reconfigures existing irrigation diversions that are causing channel instability, restores stream channel form and function and fences and plants the riparian corridor to meet the project objectives.
This project would fund a sediment control facility on Hood River.

Project will implement best management practices (BMPs) and plant riparian vegetation in the Grass Valley Watershed.  Implementation will take place at four sites.  Practices to be cost shared include riparian restoration and cropland erosion control practices as elements of farm conservation plans.  A riparian restoration on the Sherman High School campus will provide a convenient educational resource, and will compliment the Sherman SWCD Conservation Nursery recently established on the high school campus.

The Chaparral Water Control District owns rights to 84 acres of water in the Swalley Irrigation District, delivered through a Central Oregon Irrigation District lateral.  Water is distributed through nearly 10,000 feet of open failing ditches.  The Chaparral District has requested assistance from the Deschutes SWCD to pipe the existing system.  Up to one cfs could be saved in this system, based on standard ditch losses.  Chaparral District will dedicate more than 50% of conserved water to instream use.

The Tumalo Water Conservation Project Group proposes to pipe open stretches of the Bend Feed Canal within the Tumalo Irrigation District.  The four-phase project will conserve approximately 20 cfs of water currently lost to percolation and evaporation.  The conserved water will transfer to instream water rights within Tumalo Creek, 5.8 cfs of senior water rights and 11.3 cfs of junior water rights.  This water will establish rights in Tumalo Creek where there has previously been none, permanently rewetting about 11 miles of channel and improving aquatic habitat in Tumalo Creek.  In addition to improving aquatic habitat, these flows will also help improve the water quality of the Middle Deschutes River.

The purchase of 92 acres of land easements and 1/4cfs of water rights will expand the Walla Walla River floodplain where it is currently constricted by 7 miles of levees and enhance stream flow.  This land and water acquisition project is one facet of a $1.6 million levee removal and riparian restoration program with the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers and the Umatilla Tribes.  If funded it will restore one and a quarter miles of riparian habitat along known steelhead and bull trout habitat.  Both species are ESA listed.

Acquisition of 1,836 acres immediately adjacent to Ladd Marsh by the Rocky Mountain Elk Foundation (848 acres) and a private partner (986 acres), with habitat beneficial to elk and other wildlife to be managed by the ODFW, or with a management agreement with private partner respectively.  The property is an east-facing slope which provides important upland habitat, including watershed headwaters, for fish and wildlife in the Grande Ronde Basin.

Project Name: Wallowa county Agrimet and Soil Moisture Monitoring
Project Summary: This project will provide a management tool for producers to calculate, by crop type, the amount of water depleted from their soils through evapotranspiration using Agrimet and soil moisture monitoring.

Project Name: Malheur Lake Drainage Basin Outreach Project
Project Summary: As the latest LMA for the SB1010 process, Harney SWCD is given the advantage of learning from others and the hardship of covering the most ground (over 700,00 acres) with the least resources, $1000/mo.  An outreach position in the southern sub-basins will greatly assist in our information, education and research needs as well as promote the possibilities of local watershed council involvement.

Project Name: Powder Basin Water Assessments #3 - North Powder River
Project Summary: Through contracting a writer, the Powder Basin Watershed Council intends to complete an assessment of the North Powder River Watershed (About 126 mi2).  This assessment will be number 3 in a series of 10 which are planned to cover the entire Powder Basin of 3,360 square miles.
Collect data on the Donner Und Blitzen watershed, write and publish a watershed assessment.

Project Name: Lostine River Ranch Water Quality Improvement
Project Summary: During the late 1960's a large pond was constructed in the upper Lostine River watershed area.  The pond is approximately 70 acres in size and is less than 10 feet in depth.  Outflow from the pond returns to the river approximately 1 mile downstream of the point of diversion.  Water temperature data shows the outflow from the pond is causing an approximate 2-degree Celsius increase in water temperature in the Lostine River.  This proposal would pipe the pond out flow to the westside ditch.

This project will improve riparian area vegetation, reduce sediments, and reduce streambank erosion along the Wallowa river.  This will be accomplished by installing a bridge to replace a ford used by vehicles and livestock and excluding livestock grazing along the stream corridor.

Improve riparian area conditions along 6800 feet of Prairie Creek.  Reduce streambank erosion and amount of sediments entering Prairie Creek.  Replace an irrigation diversion structure and barrier to fish passage with pumping plant.

This project will restore river and riparian form and function in a 1.3 mile reach to achieve goals of providing significant benefits to native fish species.  Specific benefits include: notching of two irrigation diversion dams to remove obstacles to fish passage; substantial improvement to salmonid spawning and rearing habitat; establishment of stable channel form; reduction of land loss; restoration of native riparian species; enhancement of floodplain function; retention of irrigation diversion capacity.

Project Name: Lorenzen Ranches Livestock Feeding Relocation Proj.
Project Summary: Lorenzen Ranches will relocate his feeding operation of Stage Gulch riparian area and move to an upland location more suitable for livestock feeding.  The new confinement area will be installed to a "no-discharge" standard.  The Stage Gulch riparian area will be restored with native shrubs and native grass.  In the second phase of the project Lorenzen Ranches will establish additional hay grass pastures, and develop a grazing management plan to establish a more intense pasture rotation.
Duplicate project same as z201-231

Project will include a 1.5 acre pond that incorporates shallow wetlands and deeper, open water habitat.  The area around the pond will be planted with native shrubs and trees to provide wildlife habitat.  The landowner is enrolling this area around the pond as well as the entire length of the Gekeler Slough through his property into the Conservation Reserve Enhancement Program.  The pond is close to the Gekeler Slough and will be a water as well as wildlife benefit.

The emphasis of this project will be the elimination of runoff from feedlots entering waters of the state.  The Yost Ranch currently feeds approximately 450 calves during the winter months.  The feedlots are located above and adjacent to the Farmers Ditch.  Runoff from the lots carries animal wastes to the ditch.  Treatment of the problem will include piping approximately 400 feet of the Farmers Ditch, construction of a new feeding area, consisting of fencing, and water development above the pipe section of ditch.

This project will plant a mix of six to eight foot native trees and shrubs along a ten mile reach of the John Day River.  A corridor fence is in place along this reach so livestock will have no access to the river or the newly planted trees.  The trees will only be planted along sections of the river where irrigation water is available.  The total length of these sections totals approximately five miles.

The landowner is enrolling more than a mile of Grande Ronde River riparian area into the Conservation Reserve Enhancement Program.  Along the CREP area there are two sites where the streambank is showing accelerated erosion.  This project would address that problem  Site one needs minor excavation, shaping, rocking and plantings.  Site 2 would involve installing log and rock barbs, deflectors, and plantings.

The field this project will address is subject to severe fill erosion, particularly in the lower half and is classified as by Natural Resources Conservation Service as HEL (highly erodible land).  A terrace system that consists of a combination of gradient terraces and WASCOBS (water and sediment control basins) will reduce the fill erosion.  Currently the runoff carries sediment directly into the Grande Ronde River.

This project is to cost-share on small conservation projects that landowners would like to implement to help improve water quality, quantity and range conditions (e.g. culvert, spot road rocking, mainlines for small acreage, spring/trough development etc.).  Often it is hard to get cost shares for small projects and the proposal process just to do a small project is usually lengthy.

This application seeks to address the closure of a water gap along the Silvies River, one of the County's major drainage systems.  The proposed solution includes a new well and trough system, fencing, bank stabilization and live stakes (willow plantings).  This 150 acre field is used for a seasonal animal feeding operation for a maximum of 250 head.

This project will be a comprehensive effort to improve the overall health of nearly 5 miles of fish bearing stream (including headwaters) and surrounding 3700 acre watershed.  Seven partnering entities will work in concert to accomplish 7 project phases over the next two years, including: 1) fish barrier removal, 2) in-stream large wood placement 3) riparian fencing, 4) road improvement & relocation, 5) spring development, 6) tree & shrub planting, and 7) critical area seeding.

This project proposes to construct one and three-quarter miles of riparian fencing along Indian Creek (tributary to Middle Fork John Day).  Current recovery of riparian vegetation condition will be protected and additional establishment of riparian vegetation will benefit bank stability, water quality, and fish and wildlife habitat.  Fence will be maintained by landowners and operator.  Monument SWCD will conduct water quality monitoring using DEQ protocols and compile, store, and report data.

This juniper abatement project covers approximately 85+ acres of sloping canyon walls.  Dense juniper stands are shading out the native pine seedlings and grasses.  Shallow soils made up of small pebbles move easily with spring run-off.  The project will promote a healthier balance through juniper control and grass seeding.  Soils will be stabilized with new root systems and residue placement of cut juniper limbs.  Young pines will be encouraged by strategic thinning and barrier protection from grazing.

Project Name: Inter Basin Education Outreach and Coord.
Project Summary: The purpose of this project is to increase the capacity of watershed councils and soil and water conservation districts to plan and implement watershed action plans by increasing their administrative, programmatic, and technical abilities.  Activities to be conducted include site visit reviews, consultations, training, dissemination of successful project "how to" descriptions, dissemination of model products, newsletters and other general information media.

This project will provide technical assistance and facilitate partnerships toward the conservation of Oregon's Greatest Wetlands.  TWC and PSU plan to do this by offering local watershed councils, soil and water conservation districts, land trusts, federal and state agencies, landowners and others information on the location, condition and biological and physiographic condition of the state's biologically important wetlands and watersheds.

The Oregon Plan Video Documentation Project received partial funding from OWEB last year.  One feature was produced and more are planned.  The purpose of this request is to develop an interactive distribution and dissemination of Video Documentation Project features and productions through local and regional broadcast, presentations to partner/stakeholder groups, K-12 and higher educational outlets and internet distribution.

Oregon Watershed Weeks was launched in 1999 to raise public understanding and stewardship of watershed health and to promote education efforts by watershed councils.  Watershed Weeks provides a statewide focus and venue for organizations to host watershed education and restoration activities during September and October.  A printed Event Guide is the cornerstone publicity tool, supplemented by a web site, media briefs, and other resources.  Watershed Weeks 2001 will continue and expand this effort.
A program to provide education directly to water users on the incentives and opportunities for conserving water available through federal, state, local or private programs.

Project Name: Juvenile Salmonid Survival Into and Through Oregon Estuaries
Project Summary: The goal of this study is to document the survival of smolts from upstream migration points into and through estuaries located along the entire Oregon coastline through the use of hydroacoustic telemetry.  This research will determine whether loss of smolts in the lower river or estuary, prior to ocean entry, is consistent between estuaries.  Estuaries with both high and low return rates will be chosen in order to determine if mortality prior to ocean entry correlates with adult return rates.

Project Name: North Central Oregon Streamflow Monitoring Data Work
Project Summary: The Oregon Water Resources Department is attempting to meet increasing public and agency demand for accurate streamflow data.  Staff shortages in the past have resulted in years of raw data becoming backlogged;  this information needs to undergo an intense validation procedure prior to public release.  Currently, OWRD hydrographers are informing interested parties that it might be several years to complete the data review process.  Funding is sought to contract with an outside specialist for a portion of the review to expedite the procedure.

Project Name: Juvenile Salmonid Survival in Specific Areas of The Nehalem
Project Summary: Through cooperation with the Lower Nehalem Watershed Council, local volunteers, and other researchers, and the use of affordable new technology, we will assess the condition and survival of steelhead in the Nehalem watershed in order to understand mortality in different stream reaches and if upper-watershed effects contribute to downstream or ocean mortality.  We can then develop prioritized management plans intended to increase the survival of salmonids in the Nehalem watershed, as mandated by the Oregon Plan.

This project seeks to increase public awareness of watershed health issues and encourage citizen participation in watershed health recovery efforts in the Upper Nehalem River basin using a variety of education and outreach activities.

The applicant proposes to hire a part-time Lorane sub-basin representative to learn about the resource values in the Lorane area watershed and to provide information to local landowners about opportunities for watershed restoration and funding for those activities.

This project will produce eight issues, over two years, of an eight-page quarterly newsletter that will be distributed throughout the Mid-Coast watersheds. The newsletter contains articles on watershed restoration projects, water quality, and watershed health and management issues.

This project would provide funding for one-third of the costs for an AmeriCorp member to work with the watershed councils of the North Coast (Nicolai Wickiup, Youngs Bay, Skipanon, Necanicum and Ecola Creek) to identify and fill data gaps in the assessments of the respective watersheds.

The applicant proposes to hire an aquatic biologist to conduct an assessment of macroinvertebrate communities, physical habitat and water quality in eight stream reaches distributed throughout the Necanicum River watershed.

Project Name: Lower Columbia River WSCl Action Plan Development
Project Summary: The applicant requests funding to pay a contractor to lead the Council through the development of an action plan based upon their newly completed watershed assessment.

Project Name: Habitat Assess of the L Columbia R w/ Hyperspectral Imagery
Project Summary: The applicant proposes to develop geographically accurate data and GIS maps of the Lower Columbia River aquatic and wetland habitat by using a combination of satellite and airborne remote sensing imagery.

This project would continue funding a manager for implementation of the Deadwood Creek Coordinated Resource Management Plan (CRMP).  Project plans include a major large wood placement project in partnership with the Siuslaw National Forest.
Two trained individuals will collect data through aquatic habitat inventory and spawning surveys and perform a variety of tasks in the Siuslaw River watershed.
This project continues work on a riparian fencing and planting crew project.  Projects will be completed on agricultural land located in several different watersheds in Tillamook County.

Project Name: Panther Creek Water District Groundwater Conversion
Project Summary: This project proposes to construct a well which will convert the primary source of domestic water for the community from Panther Creek to well water, thus allowing more water to remain in-stream.

This project will repair a large section of failing railroad-era road bed; replace an undersized and degraded culvert with a bridge; place an unspecified number of wood complexes into Trestle Creek, a tributary of Fishhawk Creek; and repair and stabilize a slide on another portion of the same road bed.

Project Name: Green Slough and Bug Hole Tide Gate Replacement Project
Project Summary: This project proposes to replace two deteriorated culverts and one poorly functioning and antiquated tidegate on Green Slough in the Youngs Bay watershed and would also replace another poorly functioning tidegate on Bug Hole in the Brownsmead area on the lower Columbia River.

Project Name: Lets Celebrate Salmon!! K-3 Salmon Education
Project Summary: This program will teach K-3 students about watershed and salmon issues.  It is implemented by volunteers leading children in classroom activities, salmon viewing in the field, and storytelling based on historic information.  It is a pilot project that will develop educational materials that could be used by other watershed groups.

This project proposes to integrate field work at "Wildlife Safari" into a curriculum that will be delivered in a coordinated series of lessons in both the field and classroom.  The project goal is to create an increased interest and enthusiasm in science and math and a better understanding of natural resource systems.
This project will develop a website for the Umpqua Basin Watershed Council for the purpose of public outreach.  A Public Information Specialist will create, publish, and maintain the website.

This program will provide students and educators with increased opportunities to closely study and better understand their watershed.  This will be accomplished by sponsoring educator workshops, student symposiums and by providing monitoring equipment, supplies and technical expertise.

Project Name: J Herbert Stone Nursery Constructed Wetland Education
Project Summary: This project will provide Bear Creek students, educators, and the watershed community with increased opportunities to study wetland and riparian ecosystems and the impact these systems have on water quality and anadromous fisheries. This will be done by developing the J Herbert Stone constructed wetland into an interactive educational site with an interpretive trail system.

Project Name: Nature's Treasures Science Fair and Water Fest
Project Summary: This project will continue sponsorship of a science fair and Water Fest for students from rural schools in the Upper Rogue.  The goal is to have participants gain knowledge about the environment and become more aware of their part in watershed stewardship.

Project Name: New Property Owner Outreach Pilot Project
Project Summary: This project will provide information through realtors to rural property buyers to help them understand state and local regulations affecting land management.

This project will establish baseline water quality and flow data for tributaries of the Rogue River. Data will be used to evaluate existing and potential future projects including restoration activities, compliance monitoring, storm water best management practices, and overall watershed health.

Project Name: Little Butte Creek Stream Morphology Monitoring Prgm
Project Summary: The project proposes to create a stream characterization and classification of the main stem of the South Fork Little Butte Creek.  This baseline information will determine seasonal changes in stream characteristics and assist in restoration project design.
This project proposes to replace and relocate two leaky restrooms in a heavily used park adjacent to Banner Creek, a tributary of the South Fork Coquille River.

The applicant will develop a riparian planting program focusing on the main stem of Bear Creek. Planting sites will be located on City of Medford and Jackson County properties.  The goal of the project is to improve the creek's condition through prescribed riparian plantings.

Project Name: Blackhorse Creek Fish Passage and Road Restoration Project
Project Summary: This project will renovate Blackhorse Creek Road by replacing an under-sized, bypassed culvert on the primary stream crossing with a fish passable, 100-year event squash pipe; repairing several other crossings and road washouts; and improving road drainage.

Project Name: Tualatin WS Nonpoint Source Pollution Education and Outreach
Project Summary: The applicants propose to implement a watershed wide effort by hiring a part-time Educator to implement a general public education program through 100 classroom and 30 community presentations over 18 months using the interactive nonpoint source watershed model and riparian kit.

Project Name: Yamhill County Park Wildlife Habitat Awareness
Project Summary: The project proposes to develop a wildlife habitat plan for the ten parks of the Yamhill County park system.  The wildlife habitat management plan would involve field site visits, a review of current literature, and mapping.

Project Name: Make A Ripple  Make A Wave
Project Summary: The program teaches about and advocates action that children can take for habitat protection, riparian zone definition, the importance of trees along streams, stormdrain pollution prevention, where city rain water goes, the lifecycle of salmon, and what is a watershed.

Project Name: Team Up "Green Team" and "Stream Team Captains"
Project Summary: The applicant has proposed to develop two additional components of its Team Up program, the training of 30 Stream Team Captains, and two Green Teams of high schools and community college students to work on watershed restoration projects in the Tualatin and Sandy watersheds. The end result will be two teams of students who will give 25 hours of work on a Team Up restoration site.

This program seeks to identify the sources of bacteria and temperature problems in the Mohawk subwatershed, acquire detailed data about two tributary streams in the lower McKenzie watershed, and learn more about temperature problems in the lower McKenzie River.

Project Name: The Effects of Water Control Structures on Native Reptiles
Project Summary: The applicants are seeking to implement a standardized biomonitoring program at the three-floodplain sites.  The proposal will establish a 3-year monitoring program that will facilitate post-project population data assessment for sensitive species including the western painted turtle and northern red-legged frog and the invasive exotic eastern bullfrog.

This proposal would provide partial funding for an additional year of the Citizen Monitoring Initiative to investigate long-term funding options, institutionalize volunteer photo point monitoring, and continue current project monitoring.

Project Name: South Santiam/Calapooia Water Quality Monitoring Program
Project Summary: The applicants propose hiring a water quality program manager to work with stakeholders to develop, implement and manage a water quality-monitoring program that expands on and refines the South Santiam Watershed Councils (SSWC) existing monitoring program.

Project Name: Washington County Fish Passage Assessment and Prioritization
Project Summary: The goal of the proposed project is to identify failing or deficient culverts in need of repair or replacement that block passage of steelhead and all fish species to high quality habitat.

Project Name: Fairview Creek Watershed Assessment and Management Program
Project Summary: The assessment will document the historical, current, and potential appearance, morphology, flora, fauna, and functional benefits of the creek.  The product of the project will be an integrated watershed assessment and restoration management program  with specific plans of what functions can and should be restored, how to restore the functionality of the creek, and how to ensure that the restoration succeeds through monitoring.

Project Name: Lower Coast Fork Willamette Watershed Assessment
Project Summary: The applicant proposes to complete an assessment of the Lower Coast Fork to provide historic and current perspectives of watershed conditions and formulate a future action plan and data collection priorities.

This project will utilize appropriate water control structures and ditch plugs to compensate for the off-site impacts to the hydrology caused by channelization, flood control and development on 40 acres of palustrine emergent and forested wetland habitat on private land within the Sauvie Island Wildlife Management Area.

Project Name: East Alton Baker Park Vegetation Restoration Plan
Project Summary: This project proposes to create and implement a Vegetation Restoration Plan for the Willamette River riparian area and the associated uplands of East Alton Baker Park.  The project is comprehensive and includes data collection, site planning and project implementation.

The proposed project will treat 80 miles of the highest priority roads, decommissioning 30 miles (removing the environmental effects of the road prism), while stormproofing an additional 50 miles (place roads in a hydrologically stable condition).

The project proposes to implement the City of Sherwood Weed Management Plan, which is a structured approach to weed management that is based on desired plant species rather than simply eliminating weeds.

This project proposes to replace the existing concrete culvert in the Frog Creek Tributary with an open bottom arch culvert.  The project will also involve grading the stream bank near the waters entrance to the culvert and replanting the area with native streamside vegetation.
This project proposes to reconnect Johnson Creek to its floodplain, restore 60 acres of salmonid habitat, and provide flood storage to reduce downstream flooding.

Project Name: Accelerate the Application of Riparian Buffers/Upper Deschu
Project Summary: This project would provide for a full time riparian planner to work with landowners to develop CRP and CREP plans in the Crook, Deschutes and Jefferson County areas.  The result of this planning process will be a conservation plan that addresses the needs of the resources in riparian ecosystems.

This project would oversee the collection of environmental, economic and social benchmark data and place it on a website to help inform the public and decision makers on the value and relevancy of environmental planning.
This project will help irrigators understand crop use, soil moisture and how to make irrigation adjustments in large and small systems based upon evapotranspiration (ET) rates.

Project Name: Keno Drainage District Water Qualitly Monitoring Project
Project Summary: This project would assess the non-point source load contribution to Lower Klamath River from Keno Drainage Districts irrigation canal operations.

Project Name: Upper Williamson Water Quality Monitoring Project
Project Summary: This project would monitor six sites in the upper 6 miles of the Upper Williamson River for one year.  Samples will be taken seasonally at four increments and will test: DO, pH, temperature, conductivity, turbidity, nutrients and total flow.

The project proposes to pump water carrying highway and agriculture runoff through a series of constructed ponds and emergent vegetation to uptake nutrients and filter sediments before it enters Upper Klamath Lake.

This project will restore historically drained wetlands, reconnect an oxbow with the river, restore the riparian area and develop wetland food plots of wild rice and barley adjacent to the Sprague River.

This project will restore historic water movement, reconnect oxbows to the river, and recreate swales to capture floodwater and spring flow in order to restore historic wetlands along the Sprague River.

Project Name: Agency Creek Dam Removal and Stream Restoration  Phase 2
Project Summary: This project involves the removal of the dam on Agency Creek and accumulated sediments, re-creation of a stream channel, restoration of 400 feet of channel below the impoundment and restoration of wetland fringe and riparian habitats.

This project proposes acquisition of 1,836 acres adjacent to Ladd Marsh by the Rocky Mountain Elk Foundation (848 acres) and a private partner (986 acres) containing habitat beneficial to elk and other wildlife.  The property acquisition will be managed as part of the Ladd Marsh Wildlife Area by ODFW.

This project proposes purchase of 73 acres of conservation easements and .25 cfs of water rights to allow expansion of the Walla Walla River in a stretch currently constricted by 7 miles of levees.  This land and water acquisition is one facet of a $1.6 million COE/CTUIR levee setback and riparian restoration project.  If funded, 1.5 miles of riparian habitat for steelhead and bull trout will be restored.  THIS APPLICATION WILL NOT BE CONSIDERED BY THE BOARD BECAUSE IT IS INCOMPLETE.

Project Name: Upper Butter Creek Channel Restoration Action Plan
Project Summary: The project proposes to complete an action plan which will allow the SWCD, landowners, EPA and Umatilla National Forest to move forward with an organized watershed approach to stream restoration.

The project will have the assessors plat maps digitized for a countywide geographic information system (GIS).  Through a cooperative effort with the Umatilla Basin Watershed Council, geographical information from projects will be available for educational/outreach purposes.

Project Name: Union County Transportation System Water Quality Assessment
Project Summary: The applicant proposes to evaluate water quality conditions of the county transportation system.

The applicant proposes to collect existing geological, hydrological, climate, stream, plant and wildlife data on the Donner Und Blitzen watershed.  The assessment will establish the status of the subbasin and identify priority areas and data gaps on both public and private lands.

Project Name: Spin & Marty-Butter Crk Range & Riparian Enhancement Project
Project Summary: This project would maintain and improve existing grass and shrubs stands for resident wildlife and cattle, improve upland habitat for big game in order to restore overall stream health to the upper Butter Creek basin by reducing erosion and overland flow.
The project proposes to relocate ranch corrals and a feedlot to a combined area approximately one mile from the Owyhee River in Rome.

The project proposes to remortar a historic hand-built dam constructed by Basques in 1917 and reconstruct a large hole in the front of the dam.  This will prevent further soil erosion and water loss to the Jordan Creek area near Arock.

This project proposes to break down obstacles to implementing voluntary reforms by educating water users on available opportunities and the benefits and trade-offs of implementing conservation practices.

The applicant proposes to fund a water-quality planner to supply marine industry operators located in selected Oregon Coast estuaries with information about estuary water quality programs and watershed restoration activities.

This project proposes to continue funding Oregon Department Fish and Wildlife fish habitat biologists and part-time Environmental Biology Aides to provide stream habitat restoration project planning and implementation services to landowners and watershed councils on the Oregon Coast, and in the Willamette and Sandy River basins.

This project would fund the continuation of a comprehensive watershed awareness and education program in the elementary, middle and selected classes in the high schools of Lincoln County.  OWEB funds would be used primarily to fund a 0.5 FTE education coordinator and for student and coordinator transportation costs.

This assessment/education project would occur in the Deadwood Creek sub-basin of the Siuslaw River watershed. The project would work with private landowners to assess the condition of their lands and then, if appropriate, develop management plans and restoration activities to resolve the problems. OWEB funds would be used to fund a portion of staff salary, project administration and GIS support.

Project Name: Upper Nehalem WSC WS Stewardship Citizen Outreach
Project Summary: This education project would focus on promoting public awareness of watershed health issues and citizen participation in restoration opportunities in the Nehalem River watershed.  The majority of the OWEB funds requested would be used for personnel and travel, with a much smaller percentage for supplies and production costs.

This project would fund the expansion of fish monitoring for one year in Knowles Creek, a tributary of the Siuslaw River.  A combination of smolt trapping, snorkel surveys and adult spawner survey activities would enable the 10 years of monitoring activities in Knowles Creek to be expanded into a complete life-cycle monitoring program in accordance with the recommendations of the IMST.  OWEB funds would be used primarily for personnel to conduct the spawning surveys and smolt trapping, administration, travel and miscellaneous supplies.

This proposal would continue a water quality monitoring program in the five major watersheds of Tillamook Bay (Miami, Kilchis, Wilson, Trask and Tillamook Rivers).  The parameters being measured are E.coli and total coliform from 35 different sites.  OWEB funds would be used to pay for coordination, lab supplies and analysis, volunteer travel and administration.

Project Name: Tillamook Bay Salmonid Life Cycle Monitoring
Project Summary: This proposal would continue a fish monitoring project on the Little North Fork Wilson River and the Little South Fork Kilchis River in the Tillamook Bay watershed.  The information is useful to determine population trends in these two rivers as well as to compare to similar studies conducted on other rivers.  OWEB funds would be used for wages and travel for 13 total employee-months (two-four positions).

This project seeks funding for an on-going water quality monitoring project on the Yachats River in southern Lincoln County.  The parameters to be measured are not provided in the application, nor is there discussion on the protocols to be used.  OWEB funds would be used for coordination and lab management/maintenance as well as supplies, equipment and report production.

Project Name: Beaver Habitat Monitoring in the Alsea Watershed
Project Summary: The two intertwined goals of this project are to monitor the abundance and distribution of beaver populations and measure the resulting changes in channel morphology, temperature and habitat profiles before and after the incorporation of full spanning log complexes in the Buck Creek, Crab Creek and Green River sub-basins of Five Rivers in the Alsea River watershed.  OWEB funds would be used for project coordination and field work as well as for supplies, production and administration.

Project Name: Siuslaw River Basin Estuarine Recovery Plan
Project Summary: This project would undertake a focused and detailed assessment of the Siuslaw River estuary and would identify and prioritize areas for protection, restoration, management and stewardship within the estuary.  The majority of the OWEB funds would be used for personnel with a small percentage for production and administration costs.

Project Name: Assessment of Riparian & WQ Conditions Beneath Powerlines
Project Summary: This project would collect data on powerline crossings over riparian areas in order to determine the level to which each site may contribute to deteriorated water quality. The field work would be done over more than 3 miles of riparian areas in the Deadwood Creek, Lake Creek and Wildcat Creek sub-basins of the Siuslaw River in Lane County.  OWEB funds would be used to pay for a field technician, travel, landowner permission contacts, a project manager and necessary field equipment.

This is a two-year project to plant 14,000  25,000 native trees and shrubs on private, non-industrial riparian land throughout the Siuslaw River watershed and the coastal lakes area near the community of Florence.  Well over half of the funds requested from OWEB would be used for trees and related supplies. The majority of the remainder would be used for wages and travel for the project manager.

This project would stabilize a large (18,000 cubic foot) railroad-era through-fill above Fishhawk Creek, replace an undersized culvert along this same railroad grade where it crosses Trestle Creek (a tributary of Fishhawk Creek) and repair and stabilize a slide on the same road.  OWEB funds would be used in all three project segments to pay for materials and contractors.

Project Name: Unnamed Creekl # 2(Green Creek) Culvert & Stream Restoration
Project Summary: This project would replace an undersized culvert on Green Creek (Alsea watershed) with an oversized arch culvert and restore the streambed that has been scoured below the existing culvert.  A small concrete dam located below the culvert crossing would also be removed. The project area would be replanted to enhance the restoration of the area.  OWEB funds would be used to pay for materials and the rental of equipment and labor outside the resources of Benton County Public Works Department.

This project would replace an undersized culvert on Sutter Creek, a small tributary of Honey Grove Creek in the upper Alsea watershed, with an oversized arch culvert and restore the streambed that has been scoured below the existing culvert.  The project area would be replanted to enhance the restoration of the area.  OWEB funds would be used to pay for materials and the rental of equipment outside the resources of Benton County Public Works Department.

Project Name: Acey/Little Rackheap Fish Passage Improvement Project
Project Summary: This project would restore fish passage at four culverts that currently are impassable at most flows and realign the channel and remove fill at another site where a culvert has washed out. The work would be done on Acey Creek and Little Rackheap Creek, two tributaries to the lower Nehalem River upstream of the community of Mohler.  OWEB funds would be used for materials, including two portable bridges ($66,375.00), heavy equipment time and operator wages.

Project Name: Applegate Communities Collaborative Fire Protection Strategy
Project Summary: This project is an effort to pull together all existing fire protection, suppression and fuel reduction plans into one comprehensive, prioritized strategy for the entire high-fire-risk watershed.

This project proposes to provide students and educators with increased opportunities to closely study and better understand their watershed. RVCOG will accomplish this through sponsoring educator workshops, student symposiums and by providing monitoring equipment, supplies, training and technical expertise.  In addition, support will be provided for a Bear Creek Natural Resource Youth Corps Crew and the North Mountain Park Interpretive Area.

Project Name: Umpqua Basin Manure Management & Composting Workshops
Project Summary: This project will plan, coordinate and conduct three, single evening workshops discussing the benefits of manure management and composting. The workshops will have a targeted attendance of 35 people each. Attendees will leave with a better understanding on the need to reduce the impacts of animal waste on water quality, on how to manage their animal waste and how a valuable product can be developed when processed properly.

Project Name: South Fork Coquille Steelhead Monitoring Project
Project Summary: This project will implement a monitoring program to determine the status and trends in adult and juvenile steelhead populations in the South Fork Coquille basin. The project will follow protocols developed by ODFW in the implementation of the Oregon Plan Coastal Monitoring Program. The project will also implement a nationwide fish habitat restoration and monitoring effort being undertaken by the USF&WS.

This project proposes to gather baseline data related to water quality and quantity issues in the Tenmile Lakes.  The data collected will also be used to support future studies on the Lake. The data will be available through the Lakeside web site and a report to be produced and provided to the community.

This project proposes to conduct a watershed assessment on the Coquille watershed following the protocols laid out in the OWEB Watershed Assessment Manual and result in an updated Action Plan for the Watershed.  The updated Plan will provide clear direction to the CWA as to where to focus restoration and enhancement efforts.

Project Name: Blackhorse Creek Fish Passage and Road Restoration Project
Project Summary: This project proposes to replace several undersized, plugged culverts and address ongoing stream bank and road surface erosion. The erosion problems will be addressed by returning the stream to its primary channel and the installation of armored; rolling dips in concert with out-sloping and road closures during the winter.  The project would benefit several fish species including coho.

The project proposes to develop a riparian planting program focusing on the main stem of Bear Creek. The immediate task will be to replant a wildfire burn, which destroyed a half-mile of both over and under story along the creek in Central Point. Other planting sites will target terraces in the riparian corridor that are void of confer species.  A workshop will also be held targeting local government agencies with information on the value of riparian areas, restoration methods, site monitoring and maintenance.

Project Name: Fishery Biologist Support to the Umpqua Basin
Project Summary: This project would continue support for a fisheries biologist position through ODFW to work with the Umpqua Basin Watershed Council. The position provides critical technical support through project design, on-the-ground project implementation and monitoring. The current position has been receiving support from OWEB since 1997.

Project Name: Tenmile Lakes WS Riparian Enhancemet/Upslope Erosion Control
Project Summary: This project proposes to enhance riparian areas on 16 stream reaches along six different tributaries to Tenmile Lakes.  The project will also implement Phase II of the Basin-wide Upland Erosion Control (seeding) Program.  Riparian areas will be planted with native western red alder, big leaf maple and myrtle.  Up-slope sites will be planted with a native grass erosion mix.  Prior to planting, site prescriptions and pre treatment efforts to reduce competition with planted species will be undertaken as necessary. Follow up monitoring will be used to determine project effectiveness.

Project Name: Tenmile Lakes WS Fish Passage/Sediment Abatement
Project Summary: This project proposes to remove seven fish passage and/or sediment problem structures within five sub-basins. The project will enhance and improve passage to approximately 20 miles of habitat. These sites have been identified as priority fixes through the Watershed Councils Assessment.

Cascade Pacific RC&D will continue on-site training during watershed council meetings for the staff and volunteers of the Marys, North Santiam, Calapooia, Middle Fork Willamette and Long Tom Watershed Councils and will offer training to the South Santiam and Luckiamute Watershed Councils. Topics to be covered include meeting facilitation, group process, creating and sustaining committees, improving organizational capacity, grassroots fundraising, consensus decision making, volunteer recruitment and retention, building conflict resolution skills, building and implementing action plans and organizing to implement projects.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted part-time personnel, mileage and supplies.

The Washington Co. SWCD proposes a focused outreach effort within the rural portions of the Dairy-McKay watershed to provide a substantial number of residents with a general knowledge of conservation practices, convey the message that conservation is compatible with a landowners economic and lifestyle objectives, and result in application of conservation practices and development/implementation of conservation plans.  OWEB funds are requested for part-time personnel, training, rent, web site costs, office supplies, postage, printing and administration.

The McGowan Watershed Outreach project aims to increase stakeholders knowledge of and interest in watershed conditions and enhancement; and to involve residents in educating others, setting goals for watershed improvement, planning enhancement activities, and developing a monitoring plan.  OWEB funds are requested for part-time personnel, travel, student transportation, watershed signs, materials and supplies, printing, film developing, postage and administration.

The Shed-Ed project provides opportunities for students to gain knowledge of natural resource principles and apply that knowledge to real-world problem solving, research and management.  Outside lecturers and field trips associated with the subject matter are scheduled twice a month.  This proposal for the second-year of the program would see the curriculum expanded to meet Certificate of Advanced Mastery (CAM) Level II and III requirements.  OWEB funds are requested for part-time personnel, teacher stipends, travel, lodging, training, student transportation, contracted resource professionals, field and classroom supplies, printing, postage, computer, monitoring and field equipment and administration.

Project Name: Oakridge Sch Dist Service Learning Partnership
Project Summary: This projects focus is to implement a sustaining program for rural community youth using community service learning as a strategy for environmental education.  Proposed activities include restoring the Buckhead Wildlife Area, maintaining Oregon Chub and western pond turtle habitat, identifying and removing noxious weeds, developing strategies to focus on storm water run-off and clean water issues, and presenting critical ideas to local government and agencies.  OWEB funds are requested for teacher and Forest Service personnel stipends, teacher training, bus transportation, supplies, printing, film developing, digital camera, and administration.

The focus of this project is water conservation education activities in three of the most water-restricted Yamhill County communities  Dayton, Lafayette and Sheridan.  Local contractors, student/teacher/parent groups, church groups, businesses and private homeowners will be invited to participate in learning about water-saving strategies through workshops and an ongoing demonstration project.  OWEB funds are requested for part-time personnel, travel, workshop supplies, display materials, printing, newspaper advertising and administration.

This project will develop, distribute and use educational materials geared toward teenage youth to address issues relating to healthy watersheds and how these issues relate to agricultural practices.  OWEB funds are requested for part-time personnel, production/printing costs, and administration.

Students from Mt. Hood Community Colleges Integrated Natural Resources Technology program and local middle and high school students will develop a restoration plan for about one mile of Beaver Creek on the college campus in Gresham, then will restore the area and undertake yearly monitoring and maintenance activities.  OWEB funds are requested for a part-time project coordinator, watershed council outreach staff, clerical support, travel, web page development, volunteer recruitment, field guide and data sheet production, postage, printing and administration.

This project will continue monitoring the 22 restoration sites established during the first year of the Tualatin Citizen Monitoring project and add 8 more restoration project sites, continue working with the current 60 volunteers, and train 15 new volunteers.  In addition, the project includes investigation of long-term funding options.  OWEB funds are requested for contracting with Tualatin Riverkeepers for volunteer management and for photo point supplies, copies and administration.

This project will support ongoing and additional monitoring measures at Thompsons Mills hydroelectric and hydro mechanical project on the Calapooia River.  The project includes: 1) characterizing run timing, especially as it relates to spring Chinook, relative to normal Mill operations; 2) conducting physical and biological surveys throughout the system; 3) conducting fish sampling to determine the relative abundance and distribution of various species through time throughout the system; and 4) collecting flow and temperature data to augment the biological data also being collected.  OWEB funds are requested for two part-time contracted positions, travel, supplies, station installation, laptop computer, pressure sensing probes, recorders, and gage houses.

Project Name: Assessment of Proposed Uban Development in Willamette Valley
Project Summary: The STREAM (Salmon and Trout Response to Environmental Alteration Model) Tool will be used to complete assessments of impacts from future land development in three urbanizing watersheds while also providing an opportunity to demonstrate and refine STREAM Tool procedures for data collection, analysis and reporting.  The three watersheds to be evaluated are Pringle Creek in Marion County,  Richardson Creek in Clackamas County and Bronson Creek in Washington County.  OWEB funds are requested for personnel, travel, supplies, communications, office equipment rental, report production and administration.

This proposal is to identify priorities and develop action proposals based on a completed watershed assessment and other studies.  OWEB funds are requested for part-time personnel, travel, GIS services, report production, report printing, cameras, film developing, GPS equipment and administration.

Project Name: Historic Coyote Cr Riparian Oak Savanna & Wet Prairie Restor
Project Summary: The project will restore riparian habitat along a historic branch of Coyote Cr. and restore an adjacent 33 acres of current farmland to upland and wet prairies.  The project is the second phase of a plan to restore 100 acres of farmland to upland and wet prairie.  OWEB funds are requested for travel, mowing, trees and shrubs, mulch, supplies, film developing, administration and monitoring.

This proposal is to restore and enhance approximately 230 acres of wetlands, riparian areas, and associated habitats along the Multnomah Channel approximately 12 miles north of Portland.  OWEB funds are requested for the fishway and water control structures, engineering design, construction management, biological design and permitting, monitoring, and administration.

This project will provide year-round rearing for salmonids.  Fifty-one acres of salmonid habitat will be restored at five sites.  Activities include:  removal of rock-lined wall from over 1,200-feet of stream bank and bank terracing to form a 40-foot wide benches that will be planted with riparian trees and plants; an existing pond will be reconnected to Johnson Creek to provide a backwater channel and egress for salmonids; excavation of a large open to create a wetland floodplain surface and reclamation of a backwater channel to connect the wetland to Johnson Creek; livestock exclusion fencing, invasive plant species removal, and a long-term vegetation management plan to protect an existing forested wetland;  removal of non-native grasses and blackberry and revegetation with native riparian trees and plants;  restoration of 5.63 acres of salmonid habitat by recreating original stream, wetland, side channel, and riparian conditions.  OWEB funds are requested for excavation/grading/fill, revegetation, bank stabilization, erosion control, large woody debris, and streambed gravel/substrate.

This project will restore 30 acres of seasonal wetlands, 29 acres of riparian forest buffer, and 90 acres of oak woodland/savannah on a site adjacent to the South Yamhill River that is currently being cultivated for annually-tilled row crops.  Work includes: planting oak woodland and savanna areas, seeding with native grasses, reconstructing seasonal stream channels, excavating and plugging the drain tile system, installing a water control structure, and intensive planting of native trees and shrubs to widen the existing riparian.  OWEB funding is requested for clearing and grubbing, compacted fill, shallow excavation, removal of drainage structures, oak savannah and riparian reforestation, native grass seeding, and administration.

Project Name: Pilot Project on WS Enhancement Thru Manure Management
Project Summary: This project will manage livestock manure on six properties in the South Santiam and Calapooia watersheds in an effort to address stream pollution, habitat loss, soil erosion, SB1010 requirements and DEQs 303(d) list.  A composing facility will be constructed to process agricultural wastes into salable compost.  OWEB funds are requested for technical staff, labor and materials for building manure storage facilities, a front end loader, a dump truck, four manure storage bins/drop boxes, and a drop box truck to pick up the bins, and administration.

Project Name: Noxious Weed Management Along Cedar Cr Stella Olsen Mem Park
Project Summary: This project will restore native plant communities along Cedar Creek within Stella Olsen Park by reducing the number of areas affected by noxious weeds through the implementation of an integrated weed management plan and by replacing them with native vegetation.  OWEB funds are requested for a project management, a seasonal worker, herbicide contractor, herbicide, EnviroCorps work team, plant materials and supplies, equipment, sign production, monitoring, and administration.

This project will restore 10 acres on the upland side of Beaver Creek, including the planting of native species.  OWEB funds are requested for a part-time project coordinator, outreach staff and clerical support, travel, site preparation, volunteer recruitment, graphic services, plants, tools, gloves/protective gear, postage, printing, and administration.

Project Name: Hammer Cr Pond Dam Project Develpmnt & Design For Fish Passa
Project Summary: This proposal is to draft preliminary engineering designs and estimate costs of providing fish passage around the 30-foot high earthen dam by conducting a topographic survey and endangered species assessment.  Endangered plant and animal species surveys will also be conducted.  Completion of fish passage around the dam would open a 3,000-acre watershed with over 6 miles of stream length to fluvial cutthroat trout and possibly juvenile Chinook salmon.  OWEB funds are requested for a topographic survey, wetland delineation, endangered species survey, design of the fish passage project, and administration.

This project will replace an undersized culvert crossing on Alexander Road at Milepost 0.25.  The project will open 1.1 miles of excellent stream habitat for Cutthroat Trout, Steelhead and juvenile Chinook within a drainage boundary of 900 acres upstream from the project. OWEB funds are requested for labor, purchase of materials, plants and seed, and the rental of equipment not presently owned by Benton County Public Works.

Project Name: Woods Cr Culvert Fish Passage Improvement
Project Summary: This project will improve a culvert crossing on Woods Creek Road at Milepost 1.10 by constructing three rock weirs at the outlet of the existing culvert and the addition of small, simulated rock baffles within the culvert.  This will provide fish passage upstream for cutthroat trout and steelhead to about 9 miles of excellent habitat within a drainage basin of 2,720 acres.  OWEB funds are requested for labor, purchase of materials, and the rental of equipment not presently owned by Benton County Public Works.

Project Name: Reese Cr Tributary Culvert Replacement & Stream Restoration
Project Summary: The project eliminates a fish passage barrier by replacing two undersized culverts and by planting of native species to aid stream restoration.  The project will open over 2 miles of good stream habitat for cutthroat trout, steelhead and juvenile Chinook within a drainage boundary of 359 acres upstream from the project.  OWEB funds are requested for labor, purchase of materials, plants and seed, and the rental of equipment not presently owned by Benton County Public Works.

Project Name: Woods Cr Tributary Culvert Replacement & Stream Restoration
Project Summary: The project will remove a fish passage problem by replacing the culvert crossing on Woods Creek Road at Milepost 3.04.  The project will open over 1.2 miles of excellent stream habitat for cutthroat trout, steelhead and juvenile Chinook within a drainage boundary of 359 acres upstream from the project.  OWEB funds are requested for labor, purchase of materials, plants and seed, and the rental of equipment not presently owned by Benton County Public Works.

This project will stabilize banks and enhance habitat along a 400-ft. reach of Rickreall Creek where it flows through the Delbert Hunter Arboretum in the City of Dallas.  Education is a primary objective of the arboretum, and this project provides an opportunity to demonstrate the use of engineered log jams within an urban environment to add stream complexity, trap sediment and develop fish habitat.  OWEB funds are requested for project coordination, engineering, mileage, equipment rental, materials and supplies and project administration.

An assessment and action plan have been completed for Why-chus (Squaw) Creek which lists over 30 action items.  This project would support a coordinator to do public outreach, facilitate work sessions, connect project proponents to resources and begin developing council led action projects.  A minimum of three action projects would be completed.  OWEB funds would be used for administration of the project, salaries for the Program Coordinator and Council Executive Director, travel, facilitation services, production costs and a computer.

Lakeside Farms is 400 agricultural acres adjacent to Hanks Marsh on the Upper Klamath Lake.  It drains to an area that also collects upslope agricultural and urban lands.  This project would  improve the quality of that runoff by creating a series of ponds with emergent vegetation that will maximize the uptake of nutrients to improve the water quality of water leaving the site and provide wildlife habitat.  This project will help address TMDLs in the Klamath Basin.  OWEB funds would be used for earthmoving and the pump necessary to remove the water from the final pond and lift it over the dike into Hanks Marsh (Upper Klamath Lake).

This project would assist 16 private landowners in buying soil moisture monitoring equipment.  The SWCD will assist in the installation of this equipment.  This project should guide these landowners and others in better water application conservation.  OWEB funds would be used to pay 75% of the cost of 149 sensors, 6 meters, 17 data loggers and 5 download accessory kits.

Project Name: Bartell Ranch Irrigation Water Recovery System
Project Summary: The 480 acres of hayfields and pastures are irrigated with a spreader ditch.  This project would create a toe ditch along the edge of the lowest field to collect irrigation water, a lift pump, pipe and return ditch to an upslope pond for storage and reuse.  This will conserve groundwater and eliminate the direct runoff potential of non-point source pollution into the Sprague River.  OWEB funds will be used for design work, cultural resource assessment, and the purchase of the supplies.

Project Name: WWRID Groundwater & Exchange Application & Economic Analysis
Project Summary: The Walla Walla River Irrigation District (WWRID) and 2 landowners within it will complete 2 well applications for fish-e and 2 applications to exchange water rights.  An economic analysis will be completed summarizing the cost of construction and pumping the well in lieu of surface water, allowing surface water rights to be protected for instream uses.  Once the exchange is completed, up to 7 cfs of water rights could be exchanged.  OWEB funds are requested for the engineering analysis to complete the applications and analysis.

The project will construct an off-stream lowland irrigation storage reservoir to provide winter surface water storage of approximately 60 acre-feet and result in increased instream flow (1+ cfs) during May-August irrigation period.  OWEB funds are requested for reservoir excavation, pipe, flow meter, bentonite, concrete and administration.

Project Name: Baker Irrigation Efficiency Walla Walla River
Project Summary: The project will convert 24.1 acres of flood-irrigated land to sprinkler .  The water saving will be protected as part of the OWRD Conserved Water Program.  An estimated .3 cfs instream will be created with 1865, 1890 and 1905 priority dates.  Project objectives include increased streamflow and improved irrigation efficiency.  OWEB funds are requested for irrigation efficiency materials.

This project involves the conversion of an open ditch, which loses high amounts of water, to a gravity-fed pressurized pipe.  Water savings from the conversion is estimated to be up to 75% savings from the conversion.  Project implementation will improve both water quality and quantity and follows the objectives of SB 1010 water quality management plans.  OWEB funds are requested for the pipe materials, installation and administration.

This project addresses the construction and weed management phases on portions of the Malheur Slough.  The project will assist movement of seasonal flows over flat terrain via shallow swales to historic channels, restore riparian areas and improve water quality and wildlife habitat.  The project seeks to restore a drainage system that comes fairly close to the natural system.  OWEB funds are requested for mileage, project manager, construction, culverts, seeding and administration.

The project will replace six miles of existing, deteriorating pipeline on a gravity system to better serve the needs of the consumers while saving electricity, conserving water, reducing erosion and conserving water for fisheries habitat.  Without this pipeline, the ditch company will be forced to revert to flood irrigation over a large expanse of developed property supplying water to nearly 1,000 acres of irrigated pasture and cropland.  OWEB funds are being requested for excavation, pipe, concrete and contingency.

A temporary portable bridge will be purchased to be used by loggers, landowners, Wallowa County, USFS and emergency services.  The project will provide temporary crossing of waterways with minimal disturbance, providing a low-cost alternative to fords, temporary culverts and/or soil crossings.  Implementation will reduce sediment transport and streambank stability.  OWEB funds are requested for 50% of the purchase of the bridge section.

This project will improve ecological conditions in this 220,000-acre allotment for the benefit of numerous wildlife populations and the local agricultural economy. Implementation incorporates range improvements that will facilitate livestock distribution and wildlife enhancement by installing 24 miles of 2.75" HDPE gravity-fed from two 30,000 gallon vertical storage tanks.  OWEB funds are requested for pipe installation, mobilization, pipe, tanks, generator, and administration.

The emphasis of this project is the implementation of several watershed restoration projects on 3 tributaries of the south Fork of the John Day River.  Project components include 7 spring developments, 4.4 miles of fencing, including riparian exclusion, riparian pastures and upland pasture; 60 acres of seedbed preparation and 295 acres of whitetop treatment.
