OWEB funds are requested for fencing, equipment rental, seedbed preparation, spring developments, permits, solar stock water systems, Escort and administration.

This project will improve riparian conditions and fish passage by removing a gravel push-up dam on the Middle Fork of the John Day River.  The push-up dam will be replaced with a permanent, fish friendly structure.  Project objectives include improved water quality, fish passage, improved irrigation water management and improved streambank conditions.  OWEB funds are requested for diversion materials, equipment rental and administration.

The project will reduce sediment inputs into Long Creek by curtailing headcuts in several places along the Creek.  Structural materials, rock riprap and juniper riprap, will be placed along individual cut-faces to stabilize the terrace and minimize the potential sediment sloughing during and after high flow.  OWEB funds are requested for riprap and juniper placement, site preparation, steel posts and administration.

Project Name: Imperial Ranch Grazing Demonstration Project Phase 1 of 2
Project Summary: The landowner is attempting to determine if high intensity/short duration livestock grazing will improve overall range conditions, livestock production and riparian area recovery.  This project would assist the landowner in paying for the costs of moving 500 head of cattle to a different 50 acre paddock per day on 20,000 acres.  Extensive monitoring would occur to determine the effects on the ecology and livestock.  The project would last five years in order to determine impacts with different years of moisture.  OWEB funds would be used for manpower, material, monitoring and administration.

Project Name: Oregon County's Natural Resource Planning Workshop
Project Summary: One workshop will be held in spring 2002 to give elected county officials a better understanding of their rights and roles in public land management and to show them how they can become effective partners with state and federal agencies in developing better management opportunities for the enhancement of local natural resources.  OWEB funds will be used to pay for printed materials used in the workshop ($2,500) and for a promotional outreach mailing.

The OEC will create and distribute 20,000 copies of a statewide version of its booklet 50 Ways To Love Your River.  The booklet provides homeowners with tips on how they can reduce their impact on water quality and on endangered fish.  Distribution will begin in the spring of 2002 through watershed councils, the Oregon Plan Hotline and website, and utilities (among others).  Most OWEB funds will support personnel costs ($21,000), with some funds also used for brochure production costs.

Project Name: CD-ROM on Salmonid Habitat Features & Their Restoration
Project Summary: The project will create a multi-media CD-ROM based educational program that will approach salmonid ecology, habitat, and principles of habitat enhancement and restoration from a watershed scale perspective.  500 CDs will be distributed free statewide by a means and to an audience that are both undisclosed in the application.  The largest OWEB expenses would be for CD-ROM design and technical development ($14,000), with other major expenses for CD-ROM production.

This project would enhance and sustain the Coastnet and Rivernet water quality monitoring networks by providing teachers with tools that make it easier for them to participate.  Specific products will include a water quality curriculum designed to meet Certificate of Initial Mastery (CIM) and Certificate of Advanced Mastery (CAM) requirements, additional sampling equipment, additional follow-up and communication with teachers, and funding for travel and substitute teachers.  The major OWEB expenditure would be for personnel ($90,000), with other major expenses for participant travel and monitoring equipment.

Project Name: Upper Nehalem WSC Citizen Outreach Education Participation
Project Summary: This education project would focus on promoting public awareness of watershed health issues and citizen participation in restoration opportunities in the Nehalem River watershed. Both adults and students would be targeted; adults through workshops and public forums and students through classroom activities and field trips. The majority of the OWEB funds requested would be used for personnel and travel, with a much smaller percentage for supplies and production costs.

This project will produce four issues of an eight-page quarterly newsletter featuring articles on the science of watersheds, local restoration projects, MidCoast watershed council news and how-to information on habitat restoration. The newsletter will be distributed throughout the watersheds of the mid-coast region to approximately 1000 recipients. OWEB funds will be used to pay for the research, writing and editing of the newsletter as well as the graphics, layout, printing and postage.

Project Name: Beaver Habitat Monitoring in the Alsea WS
Project Summary: The two intertwined goals of this project are to monitor the abundance and distribution of beaver populations and measure the resulting changes in channel morphology, temperature and habitat profiles before and after the incorporation of full spanning log complexes in the Buck Creek, Crab Creek and Green River sub-basins of Five Rivers in the Alsea River watershed. OWEB funds will be used for fieldwork as well as for supplies, production and administration.

This project will fund the expansion of fish monitoring for one year in Knowles Creek, a tributary of the Siuslaw River. A combination of smolt trapping, snorkel surveys and adult spawner survey activities will enable the 10 years of monitoring activities in Knowles Creek to be expanded into a complete life-cycle monitoring program in accordance with the recommendations of the IMST. OWEB funds will be used primarily for personnel to conduct the spawning surveys and smolt trapping, administration, travel and miscellaneous supplies.

This monitoring project will fund the first year of a long term program designed to monitor macroinvertebrates, water quality and habitat conditions at 10 different sites in the Necanicum River watershed. All protocols will follow DEQ approved practices. Almost 90% of the total OWEB funding will be used for personnel costs to conduct the monitoring.

This proposal seeks funding to continue a water quality monitoring program in the five major watersheds of Tillamook Bay (Miami, Kilchis, Wilson, Trask and Tillamook Rivers). The parameters being measured are E.coli and total coliform. Local volunteers using DEQ approved protocols collect the samples from 35 different sites. OWEB funds will be used to pay for coordination, lab supplies and analysis, volunteer travel and administration.

This proposal will fund an assessment of fish passage in 300 culverts in the Clatskanie River and the tributaries of Westport Slough, both tributaries of the lower Columbia River. The assessment will be done by a private contractor and will be done according to the ODFW culvert survey protocol. A prioritization of the culverts needing work will be a component of the finished product. OWEB funds will be used for contracted services, project coordination and administration.

Funding this project will replace seven culverts currently presenting barriers to fish passage in the Siuslaw River watershed and adjoining Siltcoos Lake area, opening 10 miles of stream and access to 38 acres of wetlands. 80% of the OWEB funds requested will be used for supplies and materials, while the remainder is budgeted for administration, monitoring and production costs.

This project will fund the fencing and planting of roughly 1500' of the riparian area on both sides of the Lewis & Clark River; the installation of off-stream watering devices in the pastures on both sides of the river and; improve the 2 livestock crossing areas. Almost 90% of the OWEB funds will be spent on those activities, with the remainder budgeted for administration, monitoring and signage.

Project Name: Sanchez Riparian Habitat Restoration & Enhancement Project
Project Summary: Funding this project would pay for the cutting, transport and subsequent planting of 1,250 willow posts and 2,500 willow whips on a gravel bar at RM 4.7 on the Trask River. The goal of the project is to stabilize the gravel bar, narrow the stream channel and recruit additional gravel and sediments so that future plantings of conifer and hardwoods could occur on the stabilized and aggraded bar. 80% of the funds requested from OWEB will be used to pay the labor of cutting and planting the willows. The remainder is budgeted for administration, production and monitoring.

Project Name: Fenk Riparian Habitat Restoration & Enhancement Project
Project Summary: The goal of this project is to stabilize a gravel bar at RM 5.5 on the Trask River by planting 720 willow posts and 1,440 willow whips. By stabilizing and aggrading the gravel bar, the project expects that the river channel width would decrease and that streambank erosion would be reduced. 80% of the requested OWEB funds would be used for the cutting, transport and planting of the willows.

Project Name: Education & Outreach Project Throughout Coos County
Project Summary: This project proposes to hire an Outreach Coordinator to facilitate and coordinate Northwest Steelheaders and STEP education and outreach projects in Coos County.   This includes programs involving students and three large educational facilities targeting community youth, educating them about the values of watershed restoration efforts.

This project proposes to demonstrate innovative natural water restoration technology (Lake Restorer TM) in a polluted pond and provide outreach and education opportunities through workshops targeting K-12, University students and the general public covering aquatic ecosystems, ecological design and watersheds. Sampling methods will also be taught along with data cataloging, microscope use and care. Interpretive signage will be placed to provide for long-term project demonstration and information.

This project proposes to create an interactive multimedia documentation of restoration efforts and watershed conditions. The interactive site will be available through a Web site. The objective of the proposal is to better involve the public and increase their awareness and understanding of restoration work that is being completed.

This project proposes to provide students and educators with increased opportunities to closely study and better understand their watershed. Rogue Valley Council of Governments will accomplish this through sponsoring educator workshops, student symposiums and by providing monitoring equipment, supplies, training and technical expertise.

Project Name: Watershed Assessment & Action Plan Phase III
Project Summary: This project proposes to develop watershed assessments and action plans for five additional fifth field watersheds in the Umpqua basin. These will compliment the seven fifth field watershed assessments currently in progress. The new watersheds will include Looking Glass/Olalla, West and Lower Cow Creek, Myrtle Creek and the South Umpqua River.

This project proposes to expand a previously funded project to include moving over 1,000' of steel and concrete pipeline out of the riparian area and replacing it with a buried PVC pipeline creating a 200 buffer strip. It will also help complete the removal of the current dam structure and replacement with a structure allowing fish passage along with bank stabilization both below and above the structure.

Project Name: Tenmile Lakes WS Riparian Enhancement & Upslope Erosion Cont
Project Summary: This project proposes to enhance riparian areas on seventeen stream reaches along six different tributaries to Tenmile Lakes. The project will also implement Phase II of the basin-wide upland erosion control (seeding) program. Riparian reaches and erosion sites have been identified through the first phase riparian/sediment assessment. Prior to planting, site prescriptions and pre- treatment efforts to reduce competition with planted species will be undertaken as necessary. Riparian areas will be planted with native western red alder, big leaf maple and myrtle.  Up-slope sites will be planted with a native grass erosion mix.

This project proposes to demonstrate how development along riparian corridors can serve as a vehicle for bringing about positive changes in riparian areas. The project will accomplish this through reintroducing stream meanders, removing fish passage barriers, providing instream  and riparian habitat to improve water quality and providing for educational opportunities.

Project Name: Little Applegate Road Sediment Reduction Project
Project Summary: This project proposes to reduce erosion and delivery of sediment to anadromous fish-bearing streams in the Applegate River watershed. Road rehabilitation, including drainage improvements, aggregate applications, stream crossing improvements and road decommissioning will reduce erosion at documented, priority sediment source areas in the Little Applegate River watershed.

This project will restore 30 acres of drained agricultural land to a wetland, wet meadow and upland habitat through drain pipe removal and plugging. Shallow water areas will be created, native vegetation will be reestablished and exclusion fence will be constructed.
This project proposes to install 1,600 of riparian fence, develop two off-channel stock watering systems and plant native trees and shrubs in open areas inside the fenced riparian habitat.

This project proposes to replace an existing culvert with a pipe arch, remove an irrigation dam and install a rock chute to preserve established habitat values. Cemented gabions will be replaced with rock weirs.

This project proposes to install riparian fences along 3,860 of the creek., install three cattleguards at key crossing points, design and replace a culvert crossing with a cattle guard and plant native riparian trees and shrubs behind the fenced riparian areas.

Amazon Creek Ranch, LLC, proposes to acquire a 160-acre conservation easement to provide long-term protection for a recently-completed wetland restoration site located between the William Finley Wildlife Refuge and Fern Ridge Wildlife Refuge.  The project would benefit 85 at-risk species of birds, reptiles, plants and invertebrates.  OWEB funds would be used solely for acquisition.

The Pudding River Watershed Council seeks support for a Watershed Fair at the Oregon Gardens.  Coupons to reduce the admission fee would be offered to local watershed residents and stipends would be provided to local watershed councils to enable them to exhibit and provide educational handouts at the fair.  Attendance at the fair is projected to be 5,000 to 7,000 people.  OWEB funds would be used to reduce admission fees and pay for producing handout materials.

Project Name: Middle Fork Willamette WS Education Program
Project Summary: The Middle Fork Willamette Watershed Council proposes expansion of an in-school watershed education program previously piloted by the Lost Creek Watershed Council.  The program includes field trips and service learning and incorporates the Stream Scene, Project WET and Aquatic Wild curricula.  OWEB funds would be used to hire a part-time educator, pay for student/educator travel, and purchase education supplies.

The Oregon Environmental Council proposes reducing mercury pollution in the lower Willamette by 10-lbs. per year by targeting 3 major pollution sources:  automotive switches, fluorescent lights, and thermostats.  OWEB funds would be used to hire a program director and provide travel, supplies, graphic design, printing, postage, and auto switches.

Cascade Pacific RC&D seeks continued funding of a program aimed at improving the effectiveness of targeted watershed councils by building organizational capacity and communication skills among council participants and staff.  OWEB funds would be used for contracted personnel, mileage and printing.

Project Name: On The Rivers Edge-Water Education For Small Towns
Project Summary: Yamhill SWCD proposes a public outreach program targeted to the residents of Lafayette, Dayton and Sheridan.  The program would focus on links between water user actions, water and energy conservation, and watershed health.  It would be delivered through water bill inserts, workshops, news media, displays, demonstrations and storm drain plaques.  OWEB funds would be used for project coordination, trailer rental, materials, plaques, advertising, printing and mailing.

The Luckiamute Watershed Council proposes creation of a display board describing the accomplishments of the council for use at public events.  OWEB funds would be used to purchase the board and create display materials.

Project Name: Middle Fork Willamette Water Quality Monitoring Coordination
Project Summary: The Middle Fork Willamette Watershed Council proposes to further develop, refine and implement a water quality monitoring program that initially focuses on bi-monthly sampling at 14 representative sites.  OWEB funds would be used to hire a monitoring coordinator and to cover travel, laboratory analysis, equipment purchases and program operations.

Project Name: Clackamas/Sandy Basin Water Quality Monitoring & Assessment
Project Summary: The Clackamas SWCD seeks funding for collection of baseline water quality data in a normal rainfall year for the tributaries in 9 sub-basins of the Clackamas and Sandy River watersheds.  OWEB funds would be used to hire a technician and cover mileage, pesticides analysis, laboratory analysis, and report printing.

The Foundation for Oregons Housing Future proposes refinement of the STREAM Assessment Tool following demonstration of its utility in 3 urbanizing watersheds in Marion, Clackamas and Tualatin Counties.  The Tool predicts the change in salmon and trout populations resulting from alternative proposals for land development.  OWEB funds would be used for personnel, travel, supplies, equipment rental and report production.

The Marys River Watershed Council proposes development of an Action Plan based on its Watershed Assessment.  The Action Plan will identify and prioritize specific actions to help protect, maintain and restore watershed function.  OWEB funds would be used for project coordination, consultants, mileage, and production costs.

Project Name: Corvallis Natural Features Inventory & Assessment Tiers 1&2
Project Summary: The City of Corvallis proposes an assessment and inventory of watershed conditions within the Corvallis UGB, including water quality, hydrology, fish habitat conditions, fish passage barriers, riparian conditions, upland habitat conditions and development levels.  OWEB funds would be used for contracted outreach, photo/map interpretation, field work, inventory/assessment preparation and data entry into the Citys GIS system.

Project Name: Development of Data Collection Procedures/Action Plans
Project Summary: The Marys River Watershed Council proposes development of an objective set of protocols with which to conduct field assessments and GIS database analyses for the purpose of identifying and prioritizing on-the-ground action items. Protocols, data sheets and training materials would be developed.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services, data assistance, travel, report printing and GPS equipment.

Project Name: Judson School Woodmansee Park Site Assessment
Project Summary: The Pringle Creek Watershed Council proposes assessment of the upper reaches of the West Fork of Pringle Creek within Salem city limits and generation of specific project concepts.  OWEB funds would be used to contract for a hydrologic assessment and development of project concepts.

The South Santiam Watershed Council seeks funding to develop an Action Plan based on its Watershed Assessment, and to fill key gaps in the assessment.  The Action Plan will identify and prioritize specific actions to help protect, maintain and restore watershed function.  OWEB funds would be used for contracted services, volunteer travel, supplies, report production, printing and GPS equipment.

The Calapooia Watershed Council proposes to conduct an assessment of the entire Calapooia watershed.  The assessment will integrate existing analysis, map floodplain vegetation, and describe historical and current conditions.  OWEB funds would be used for contracted services and report reproduction.

The Luckiamute Watershed Council proposes to conduct an assessment of the entire Luckiamute watershed.  The assessment will illustrate data gaps and help the council prioritize future projects.  OWEB funds would be used to contract with a resource consultant.

Project Name: Clackamas Co Fish Passage & Habitat Enhancement Project
Project Summary: The Clackamas County SWCD proposes a county-wide effort to maximize benefits derived from county fish passage projects by adding on-the-ground habitat enhancements to adjacent private lands.  OWEB funds would be used for project coordination, travel, and monitoring.

The Tualatin River Watershed Council proposes to develop a funding model for sustainable photo point monitoring of restoration projects in the Tualatin Watershed.  During the pilot year of the project, 22 restoration sites were monitored.  OWEB funds would be used for training sessions, volunteer management, data management, supplies and copies.

Ducks Unlimited, Inc. seeks funding for restoration of floodplain connectivity among three properties.  Fishways and water control structures will allow for adaptive management to promote habitat recovery for threatened, endangered, and other wetland-dependent species.  OWEB funds would be used for permitting, engineering, construction, supplies, and monitoring.

Washington County SWCD seeks funding for the planning and implementation of agricultural resource management systems within the McFee Creek watershed to achieve TMDLs while improving habitat for steelhead trout.  OWEB funds would be used for personnel, monitoring, incentives, supplies, phone, soil tests and meetings.

Watersheds Unlimited proposes to install fencing to exclose grazing and haying activities around several small tributaries to Oak Creek and to plant native trees to improve riparian cover.  OWEB funds would be used for project supervision, fencing, outreach supplies and monitoring.

Northwest Habitat Institute seeks funding to restore 30 acres of farmed wetland to a mosaic of wetland and wet prairie.  The project includes creating a stream course to move water through a series of connected pools and planting of native wet prairie vegetation.  OWEB funds would be used for project coordination, seasonal staff, equipment rental, herbicide application, supplies and monitoring.

Project Name: Deer Creek Park Yamhill Co Wet Prairie Restoration
Project Summary: The Friends of Deer Creek Park and Northwest Habitat Institute seek funding to restore 23 acres of old pasture/farmland to wet prairie to benefit wildlife and serve as a pilot project within the Yamhill County parks system.  OWEB funds would be used for project management, seasonal employees, equipment rental, herbicide application, and supplies.

Clackamas County Service District No. 1 proposes removal of an earthen dam that is a fish passage barrier and removal of the associated reservoir that creates water quality problems due to heat sink and sediment accumulation.  OWEB funding would be used for mobilization, traffic direction, erosion control, de-watering, removal of structures, clearing, excavation, rock, geotextile, adjusting cable manholes, soil preparation, seed, LWD and trees.

Project Name: Vincent Culvert Replacement & Stream Restoration Project
Project Summary: Benton County Public Works proposes to remove and replace a culvert that is currently a fish passage barrier to open 1.1 miles of stream habitat for salmonids within a drainage boundary of 972 acres upstream from the project.  OWEB funds would be used for purchase of materials, the culvert, plants and seed, equipment rental and labor.

The City of Salem seeks funding to enhance fish passage on Pringle Creek by installing a fish ladder and a small check dam to spread flows and lower velocities, and a series of check dams to stabilize the stream bed elevation.  OWEB funds would be used for construction of the fish ladder, weirs, and channel improvements.

Seven FFA and 4H and environmental science instructors will involve approximately 250 students in field monitoring changes in land management practices on private lands by working with participants in the Living on a Few Acres workshops occurring in Deschutes, Jefferson and Crook counties.  Irrigation, grazing, and water quality specialists will provide on-site prescriptions for landowners and the students will monitor existing and changed conditions.

Rather than irrigating by the calendar, this project will use soil moisture measuring equipment in four orchards (two of new trees and two of fruit bearing age) to dictate irrigation applications and to measure the difference from historical practices.  Fruit quality will be measured.  OWEB funds will be used for equipment and a half- time research assistant.

This project would provide cost share funds to seven farmers over three years to help with construction of  sediment control basins and the cost of converting to direct-seed, minimal tillage on highly erodable wheat lands.  OWEB funds would provide $15/acre for two years to help with the increased cost of this farming technology.

Project Name: Conservation Improvements on 11 Farms in Pine Hollow
Project Summary: This proposal lists 11 different landowners properties in Sherman County. They would include offstream livestock water development, 4 miles of riparian fencing, range seedings, terracing and construction of sediment control basins.  These watersheds flow into the John Day River.  OWEB funds would be used to fund roughly half the cost of each of these management practices.

Project Name: Conservation Improvemnents on 5 Farms in Grass Valley
Project Summary: Five landowners would do 480 acres of brush control, 56,000 feet of new terraces, 3,200 feet of grass waterway and 28 sediment control basins to improve infiltration and reduce runoff and erosion.  OWEB funds would pay for half of the cost of constructing these improvements.

Project Name: Deschutes - John Day Feral Swine Eradication Project
Project Summary: This project would shoot concentrations of feral pigs from a fixed wing plane or helicopter when they are reported by landowners in the middle Deschutes and lower John Day river basins.  It would occur over a two year period and 1,000 acres of damage areas would be reseeded.

This project would help bring the waste management of an 80 year old dairy into compliance with todays standards by placing a tank for collection of liquid waste and a concrete pad to collect drainage from the manure storage.  Currently, drainage has contact with the Lost River.

Project Name: K & K Ranch Tailwater Treatment Wetland/ Wood River Riparian
Project Summary: This project is the design and survey phase of a project that would construct wetland pods to improve the quality of irrigation tailwater and fish and wildlife habitat on a cattle ranch along the Wood River.  Plans for removing dikes to restore connection to the floodplain, sinuosity and riparian function will be part of the project design.

Project Name: Clover Flat/Valley Falls Winter Feeding Area Improvements
Project Summary: The landowner has purchased land for winter cattle feeding which removes cattle from having to be confined to the current site where Green Creek flows.  This project would make some water and fencing improvements on the summer and fall pastures and pay for the livestock pens and feeding bunks and livestock handling facilities on the new wintering site near Valley Falls in Lake County.

Project Name: So Fork Walla Walla Land & Water Acquisiton Project
Project Summary: The Confederated Tribes of the Umatilla Indian Reservation (CTUIR) is seeking funds for a fee simple purchase of 46 acres.  The primary goal is to protect the property from future development and to transfer a 13-acre, .48 cfs senior irrigation water right, a legally protectable instream flow right.  These actions will have direct benefit on the Walla Walla River which contains federally listed summer steelhead, bull trout and spring chinook salmon.  OWEB funds (100%) are requested for land and water purchase price.

Project Name: Malheur/Owyhee Soil & Nutrient Loading Assessment Project
Project Summary: This project will fund a study to measure and record field runoff and loading to ascertain actual erosion rates from various row-crop irrigated fields.  Forthcoming TMDL loading targets for the Snake River call for an 81% reduction in total phosphorous and sediment, having a major impact on irrigation practices and agricultural cropland practices.  OWEB funds are requested for a technician and student aide wages and travel (66%), materials/equipment (20%), rent (4%) and administration.

A rangeland technician will be funded to help the resource management by local landowners, state and federal agencies and various public interest groups.  The technician will oversee range projects, documenting changes in riparian vegetation and streambank conditions on public and private lands while pulling partners together to improve the watershed and water quality.  Work will be concentrated in the Bully Creek subbasin.  OWEB funds are requested for salary (82%), mileage (4%), and administration/expenses.

Project Name: Biomonitoring of the Upper So Fork John Day River WS
Project Summary: Funds are sought for the third year of a comprehensive monitoring program of macroinvertebrate communities, physical habitat and water chemistry in the upper South Fork of the John Day basin to assess and monitor the effectiveness of watershed restoration efforts and best management practices.  ABR will be contracted to conduct the field work, analyze and interpret the data and report the results to the interested parties.  The project augments several existing and future data sets.  OWEB funds are requested for salaries (74%); travel, mileage (6%), water chemistry analysis,supplies, equipment lease (15%) and administration,expenses (5%).

The Owyhee Watershed Council is seeking funds for a contractor to complete a local assessment of 3 subbasins which comprise 2,633,237 acres.  Existing information pertaining to these subbasins will be collected and compiled.  Fieldwork will be initiated based on the identification of data gaps in existing information.  OWEB funds are requested for an assessment contractor (89%), mileage, mailing and administration.

The project proposes to excavate a small shallow wetland pond in an area that is fed by perennial springs and install an enclosure fence around the 6-acre wetland.  The wetland pond will act as a filter for irrigation tailwater from the terrace above the wetland area.  The riparian area will be enrolled in continuous CRP.  OWEB funds are requested for excavation (61%), culvert installation (18%), technical assistance (6%) and administration and monitoring.

The project seeks to correct bank failure on the Grande Ronde River by using a combination of a willow trench with a vegetated mat and a rock toe.  The project is approximately 650' downstream from the confluence of the State Ditch and Catherine Creek where the outside river back is eroding and threatening an unimproved road. The area adjacent to the river will be enrolled in CREP with livestock exclusion.   OWEB funds are sought for base rock and placement (37%), excavation and backfill (24%), willows, seed and geotextile blanket (31%) and administration.

Three culverts on Pine Creek were identified as fish-passage barriers.  A previous OWEB project funded the cost and design analysis of replacement culverts.  When completed, the new culverts will provide an additional 10 miles of spawning habitat for anadromous and resident fisheries.  OWEB funds are requested for precast concrete culverts and installation (87%), engineering oversight (6%) and administration.

This project will rehabilitate 2,000 acres of overgrazed and erodable lands in the Shirttail Creek watershed near Durkee.  An 11-mile fence will exclude livestock grazing for 3 years on 4 miles of Shirttail Creek and its tributaries.  After 3 years, any resumption of livestock grazing will be done only with a written plan approved by ODFW.  OWEB funds are sought for fencing (100%).

The project proposes to install a 2.8 million-gallon bilge (irrigation pond) for irrigation efficiency.  It is anticipated that 357.5 gallons per minute (.79 cfs) will be put into the Walla Walla River.  This will allow for reduced water rate delivered to the farm and conserved water to be left instream.  OWEB funds are requested for pond liner, pumps and pipe (96%) and administration.

The project addresses the construction and weed management phases of project 99-579.  The assessment finding for this area includes over 40 landowners who are willing to cooperate in restoring a DEQ-listed sensitive aquifer to a natural drainage covering 18 miles of Harney Countys central basin.  The project seeks to restore the slough back to its historical drainage system.  OWEB funds are requested for construction (71%), coordinator (6%), seeding (3%), engineering (3%), culverts (7%), mileage (3%) and administration.

The project will restore 5 miles of the West Fork of the Silvies River, which was ditched, diked and straightened, back  to a naturally functioning river and floodplain.  The entire project includes approximately 2,250 acres of restored wetlands, riparian habitat and upland buffer.  The project also includes a carp-control function that will enhance the entire watershed.  OWEB funds are requested for river channel excavation & berm removal (100%).

Project Name: Sumpter Valley Dredge Tailings Rehabilitation Project
Project Summary: Returning 40 acres of dredge tailings to a more natural hydrologic state and establishing and maintaining desirable groundcover is this projects goal.  The spoils will be contoured, seeded and fenced; then cattle will be fed and possibly grazed at the site.  OWEB funds are requested for equipment rental (53%), fencing (9%), seed (16%) and project management, administration, monitoring (22%).

Project Name: Walla Walla Water Quality Monitoring & TMDL Implementation
Project Summary: This water quality monitoring program will support both the current DEQ TMDL implementation and monitoring process and seeks to quantify improvements in water quality conditions.  Parameters measured include temperature, streamflow, pH, dissolved oxygen, conductivity, turbidity and macroinvertebrate sampling.  OWEB funds are requested for monitoring coordinator salary/training/mileage (87%), reagents/printing (3%) and administration (10%)

Project Name: Richartz Canal Piping Walla Walla River Conservation
Project Summary: This project seeks cost-share funding for piping almost 3 miles of open canal with 16 users, 1,111 acres and return and protect 4 cfs to the river using the Conserved Water Program.  The completed project will restore summer flows for 4 miles of habitat.  OWEB funds are requested for pipe and materials (97%0 and administration (3%).

Project Name: Demonstration of Split Season Use Instream Leasing
Project Summary: This project will demonstrate, document, and evaluate the effectiveness of the Split Season Use Instream Leasing Program through the acquisition of approximately 10 split season leases in 2002.  Acquisitions will be targeted in the John Day, Umpqua, and Rogue basins.  OWEB funds will be used to pay 80% of the lease payments to willing landowners.

The proposed project will provide a private sector contact and educator for Oregon farmers and ranchers on nonpoint source water quality and pesticide issues.  The project will last 3 years and will develop educational materials for farmers and ranchers.  OWEB funds will be used for personnel and consultation services (78%), travel (12%), supplies, printing, and equipment.

This project has three components:  preparing materials, building relationships with constituencies, and disseminating information about instream water rights.  Oregon Water Trust and For the Sake of the Salmon will partner on producing brochures, websites, articles, workshops and information packets to raise awareness of landowners and others in streamflow restoration priority areas.  OWEB funds will be used for personnel costs (71%), travel, administration, and material production costs (18%).

Project Name: Summer WS Education Workshop: Water in the Desert?
Project Summary: The proposed project would sponsor a 4-day summer workshop for K-8 teachers interested in applying environmental education curricula to local watershed issues for classroom application.  Follow-up student field trips are also provided for the 25 teachers.  OWEB funds will be used for an education program manager and teacher stipends (38%) and travel costs for the workshop and student field trips (42%).

Project Name: Increasing WSC Capacity to Address Aquatic Invasive Species
Project Summary: This project will develop guidelines, educational materials, and related training programs to help watershed councils address aquatic non-native species (ANS).  The products of this project will be research-based, correlated with the ANS Management plan, peer reviewed, and coordinated with state and federal agencies.  65% of OWEB funds will be used for graduate research assistants, 8% for travel and per diem, and 14% for pilot ANS assessments.

Project Name: Outdoor Science School WS Field Study
Project Summary: This project would develop and implement a Watershed Field Study at the NW Regional Education Service District's Outdoor Science School for elementary students.  The end product would be a full day field study including lesson plans, background materials, posters, and equipment that can be replicated in other programs.  OWEB funds would support personnel costs (63%) to develop and implement the program, teaching materials, and travel.

Project Name: CD-ROM on Salmonid Biology Habitat & Restoration
Project Summary: The project would develop and distribute an interactive educational tool (CD-Rom) on the biology and habitat of salmonids and the principles of fish habitat enhancement and restoration.  The target audiences are high school and community college students, watershed council members and landowners.  OWEB funds would be used for the CD-Rom programming 53%), CD production and distribution (32%), and travel.

This project would produce a 30 minute documentary film showcasing the stories of several Oregon families and tribes who have chosen to change their farming methods to reclaim wetlands, streams and rivers.  The film will be broadly distributed and meets the needs of classroom and public presentations.  Funds would be used to pay for the contracted labor (47%), supplies, and production costs (35%) associated with the film.
Culvert replacements on Gerber Road
OWEB Small Grant Program
OWEB Small Grant Program

Project Name: Weyerhaeuser Springfield False Brome EDRR/Treatment/Containment Program
Project Summary: Weyehaueser Springfield Tree Farm covers approximately 215,000 acres in Linn and Lane Counties east of Springfield, OR. Willamette NF and Eugene District BLM lands border and checkerboard with Weyerhaueser ownership. There are four major watershed areas on the Tree Farm - the Mckenzie, the Mohawk; the Calapooya; and the Middle Fork Willamette. Cooperative projects for invasive species control exist with the Willamette and Calapooya watersheds.    False brome on our Tree Farm originates from valley fringe areas in the SW and NW portions of ownership (Map Zone A). In a remainder of the Tree Farm (Map Zone B), new satellite populations typically occur on roadside shoulders, pull-outs, and turn-arounds, where seed is introduced buy vehicular traffic. Isolated populations of meadow knapweed have been detected and treated in similar locations in 2010 and 2011.    The proposed project would include a combination of surveying an treating any new false brome and knapweed locations; monitoring success and re-treating any seed-thru or fringe survivors  in previously identified/treated isolated weed populations; and re-treating the travel corridors within core epicenter (Map Zone A) areas. Travel corridors in the epicenters were initially treated by Glenn Miller, ODA in 2009/2010. Satellite population have had initial treatments in 2010 and 2011.    The early detection sites will be treated by a 1-2 person back pack crew. The crew will verify the weed presence, map the site, and maintain treatment records. The vehicular travel areas of the epicenter will be treated by truck mounted spray equipment. Chemical treatment will be gyphosate and sulfmeturon methyl with surfactant in a water carrier. Aminopyralid will be used for knotweed.

Grantee: Lake County Cooperative Weed Management Area
Lower Burnt River Weed Management Area (LBRWMA)

Project Name: Mill Creek - Four Sisters Weed Control

Grantee: Friends of Buford Park & Mt Pisgah
Project Name: Buford Park False Brome Control & EDRR
Mirror Lake Yellow Flag Iris Control Project
Deschutes Basin Rock and Gravel pits
Whychus Creek Corridor Native Plant Restoration
Spurge laurel and Japanese knotweed control-2014

Grantee: Friends of Buford Park & Mt Pisgah
Project Name: Buford Park False Brome Control & Prevention

Grantee: Lake County Cooperative Weed Management Area
Project Summary: The Goose Lake Basin lies between the Fremont and Modoc National Forest. All surface water from the basin drains into Goose Lake. The Southern half of the basin is in California creating great pressure from noxious weed travel across the border into Oregon and the northern stretch of the Goose Lake Basin. Just south of the border lies large infestations of Yellow starthistle, medusahead rye, mediterrenean sage, Scotch and musk thistle and of course Dyer's woad. In 2013 through our OSWB County Grant we treated many county properties and it became apparent to the LCCWMA that Dyer's woad was really beginning to spread throughout the town of Lakeview and the Goose Lake Basin, as well as, one site spreading into the Warner Weed Prevention Ares. Dyer's woad produces large amounts of seed and can be very hard to control once established.  The timing to for treatment is narrow.  Therefore, we plan to advertise and involve the community in locating unknown infestations, pinning treatment down to the most optimal time.

Project Name: Lincoln County Wetland  & Riparian Weed Control Project
McKenzie River RD Power Line Invasives
Union County Yellow Starthistle Survey & Control
Hypericum Removal in Oregon's Old Cascades
Wheeler Yellow Starthistle Prevention and Containment
Molalla River Confluence Priority Invasives Control
Lower Crooked River Noxious Weed Coordination
Spurge laurel and Japanese knotweed Control- 2015
Weed Survey and Treatment after Wildfire
Central Coastal Range Meadow Habitat Restoration
Threatened Checkermallow: Coast Range Meadow Restoration

Grantee: Lake County Cooperative Weed Management Area
Project Name: Lake County Property Noxious Weed Contol
Lincoln County Yellow Flag Iris Control Project
Ludwigia and parrot's feather control in Columbia Slough
Desolation Creek Weed Management- Phase I
The Whychus Floodplain Knapweed Control Project
Hells Canyon Yellow Flag Iris Control

Grantee: Upper South Fork John Day WC
Project Name: South Fork John Day Whitetop Control
Yamhill County Knotweed / Spurge Laurel Control

Project Summary: This proposal would continue fecal coliform bacteria, precipitation, stream temperature and stream discharge monitoring for two years on Beaver Creek, a tributary of the Tillamook River, in order to complete the statistical analyses to quantify the extent of improvements to water quality occurring as a result of on-the-ground activities conducted under a previous OWEB funded project. OWEB funds will be used for sampling costs, laboratory analyses, travel, supplies, data analysis, reporting and administration.

Project Name: Riparian Buffer Effectiveness on Bacteria Removal
Project Summary: This project will monitor an experimental demonstration system constructed to determine the efficiency of riparian buffer zones of varying size and configuration in removing fecal coliform bacteria from runoff water. The work will be done in the Tillamook Bay watershed. OWEB funds will be used for sampling costs, laboratory analyses, supplies, data analysis and report costs incurred by the study contractor.

This restoration project will plant approximately 10,000 native trees and shrubs on the riparian property of 13 different landowners in the Lewis and Clark, Necanicum and North Fork Nehalem Rivers in Clatsop County. OWEB funds will be used to pay for project management, travel, materials, monitoring and administration.

This project would plant trees and shrubs in the riparian zones of three property owners in the Yachats River basin and one landowner in the Beaver Creek basin, a direct ocean tributary in the mid-coast area. Fencing to exclude livestock where necessary and fence enclosures and other devices to protect the plantings from wildlife damage would be constructed as well. OWEB funds will be used for project management, labor and materials to build the fences and protective devices, administration and monitoring.

Bacteria and turbidity levels will be checked at 30 locations through out the Douglas County portions of the Umpqua Watershed potentially affected by agricultural operations. The project will help livestock owners better identify and understand their potential impacts on water quality in a non-regulatory manner. OWEB funds requested would be used for costs related to sampling labor, lab analysis. Mileage, report writing, project management and administration.

The project will fund a project implementation technician to work with private landowners, in Coos County, to apply voluntary practices and implement voluntary conservation farm plans using USDA cost-share programs. OWEB funds would be used for field technician salary, field supplies and a wing-back pull spray for weed control on pasture land.

The project proposes to conduct project effectiveness monitoring on all Coquille Watershed Association (CWA) Projects. Each project will be measured against its primary project objectives.  Project funds requested would be used for a monitoring specialist, a monitoring assistant, a surveyor, 12 vemco temperature devices, survey gear, associated supplies and administrative costs.

The project would initiate a reclaimed water reuse program that will benefit water quality and quantity in the South Umpqua River. The program will incorporate water quality trading, which is being promoted by Oregon DEQ and the US EPA.  Project funds requested would be used for design and construction of reuse conveyance system, outreach and fiscal administration.

This project proposes to install riparian 1,600 of fence, develop two off-channel stock watering systems and plant native trees and shrubs in open areas inside of the fenced riparian habitat.  Project funds requested would be used for a field technician, fencing installation, seedlings and fiscal administration.

The project will fund a field technician to promote and implement the Conservation Reserve Enhancement Program (CREP) in Douglas County. Ten landowners will be enrolled in CREP. This is a continuation of the program initiated last year. Project funds requested would be used for technician salary, travel and fiscal administration.

This project would complete maintenance on approximately one hundred and thirty mile of riparian enhancement projects completed in the Coquille watershed by the Coquille Watershed Association. These projects consist primarily of livestock exclusion fencing and riparian planting. Project funds requested would be used for salaries for a 3-person restoration crew, inmate crew leader, travel, inmate crew costs, trees, fencing materials, tools, chain saws, four-wheeler and fiscal administration costs.

Project Name: Cow Cr Riparian Restoration & Habitat Enhancement
Project Summary: Project activities will focus on riparian area enhancement, habitat improvement and sediment reduction on Starveout and Cow Creek at the confluence with Starveout Creek in South Umpqua River watershed. Large wood will be placed in the stream to narrow Cow Creek to facilitate bedload accumulation causing severe degradation to the riparian area habitats at the mouth of Starveout Creek.  Project funds requested would be used for planning/design, construction materials, contracted services, plants, monitoring, travel and fiscal administration.

This project will acquire a permanent conservation easement on Norwood Island, which is approximately 54 acres in size and is situated at the confluence of the Willamette River and the Long Tom River.  The landowner currently has a CREP contract.  The proposed conservation easement by Benton County Parks would extend the CREP 15 year easement to a perpetual easement by paying the landowner 30% of the CREP contracts value (a formula developed in other states).  OWEB funds are requested to pay 22.5% of the value of the CREP contract.  The remaining 7.5% will come from Benton Countys Title III funds.

Western Rivers Conservancy is requesting funds for the Sandy River Conservation Project to acquire and protect 124 acres of riparian and upland habitat along the Sandy River.  The City of Sandy will hold title to the property and will manage the land under two goals: 1) preservation and enhancement of the land; and, 2) limited and low-impact public access to the Sandy River.  OWEB funds are requested for approximately 42% of the purchase price with match funding from the City of Sandy and OR Parks and Recreation.

Project Name: Willamette River Gallery Forest Protection Phase II
Project Summary: Western Rivers Conservancy is requesting funds for the purchase of 85 additional acres in the Luckiamute conservation unit, adjacent to the 500 acre State Park Natural Area at Luckiamute Landing and containing more than a mile of Luckiamute Riverbank.  Oregon Parks and Recreation Department would hold title to the property proposed by the acquisition and will manage the property.  OWEB funds would be used for 75% of the purchase price.

Project Name: Monitoring Phase II to Develop Restoration Plans
Project Summary: This proposal is for implementation of Phase 2 of a 2-part water quality monitoring project in the Marys R. watershed.  The project will pinpoint the source of potential water quality problems in the vicinity of two sites identified in Phase 1.  OWEB funds are requested for personnel, travel, lab services, consultant, equipment and administration.

This proposal is for the second year of a 5-year project that combines intensive baseline water quality sampling and analysis with extensive education, outreach, and implementation of BMPs.  OWEB funds are requested for personnel, travel, laboratory analysis, report printing/CD production-distribution, and administration.

Project Name: Middle Fork Willamette Water Quality Monitoring
Project Summary: This proposal is to further refine, develop and subsequently implement the beginning phases of a water quality monitoring program that initially focuses on bi-monthly sampling of key parameters at 14 representative sites.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services, travel, lab analysis, operations, equipment and administration.

This proposal is for an assessment that integrates existing data and includes field data collection and verification following the OWEB Assessment Manual protocols.  The assessment would cover two 5th-field watersheds totally 101,952 acres.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services, production costs and administration.

This proposal is for Phase 2 of a program previously funded by OWEB.  It includes identification of additional fish passage barriers, compilation of available data on barriers and habitat inventories, and will use the combined data to prioritize future improvements.  Benton County covers 677 square miles.  OWEB funds are requested for personnel, travel, production, operations and administration.

This proposal is to restore 30 acres of high-value wetland and riparian habitat in the Dairy Creek sub-basin of the Tualatin River watershed on land recently purchased by Metro.  OWEB funds are requested for personnel, travel, contracted labor, seed, tubing, production costs, administration and 5-years of vegetation monitoring.

Under this proposal, surplus hatchery salmon carcasses will be distributed by helicopter and ground crews to 5 tributaries of the Sandy and Clackamas Rivers to enhance levels of marine-derived nutrients.  OWEB funds are requested for personnel, travel, contracted helicopter and labor, equipment, administration, overhead, and monitoring.

This proposal is for planning and implementation of agricultural resource management systems within the 9,700-acre McFee Creek watershed to achieve TMDLs for temperature, DO, phosphorus and bacteria while improving habitat for steelhead trout.  OWEB funds are requested for personnel, travel, monitoring/analysis, incentives, supplies, production costs, rent and administration.

Project Name: Upper Willamette Basin Aquatic Species Passage Solutions
Project Summary: This is a collaborative project involving 4 watershed councils and 2 sub-watershed groups.  It proposes removal and replacement of 6 culverts in high priority areas and compilation of fish passage information throughout the Upper Willamette Basin.  OWEB funds are requested for personnel, contracted engineering, design, permits, GIS services and labor, construction materials and administration.

This project proposes organization of four Grate Mate pilot projects within the Columbia Slough watershed to demonstrate storm-drain filtering as a viable retrofit solution for reducing storm water pollution.  OWEB funds are requested for personnel, travel, contracted labor, materials, printing and administration.

Project Name: Scappoose Bay WS Priority Fish Passage Correction
Project Summary: This project proposes correction of 7 high priority fish passage barriers in the Scappoose Bay watershed.  OWEB funds are requested for personnel, travel, contracted design, permitting and labor, construction materials and administration.

Project Name: Delta-Ponds Willamette River Side Channel & Floodplain
Project Summary: This proposal is for restoration of critical side channel and floodplain habitat on the Willamette River.  The project includes connecting the Delta Ponds and side channels to the Willamette River and interconnecting the ponds, restoring riparian habitat, and providing public access, recreation and educational opportunities.  OWEB funds are requested for construction related to a bridge, culverts, gates and vaults.

This proposal encompasses components of three main elements of the Mohawk Partnerships restoration and protection effort in the McGowan sub-basin:  community and stakeholder engagement, scientific assessment and prioritization, and science-based near-term and long-term monitoring.  OWEB funds are requested for personnel, travel, signs, supplies, printing, postage and administration.

Project Name: Middle Fork Willamette Watershed Education Program
Project Summary: This proposal is for expansion of an in-school watershed education program previously piloted by the Lost Creek Watershed Council.  The program includes field trips and service learning and incorporates the Stream Scene, Project WET and Aquatic Wild curricula.  OWEB funds are requested for personnel, travel, phone, curricula, office supplies, printing, mailing and administration.

This proposal is for implementation of a restoration plan on 10 acres of riparian and upland sites adjacent to Beaver Creek on Mount Hood CC property.  The project includes watershed education through applied experiences in weed control, native species planting, monitoring, research and community outreach.  OWEB funds are requested for personnel, travel, contracted services, supplies, printing, signs, equipment and administration.

Project Name: Outdoor Science School WS Field Study
Project Summary: This proposal is to develop and implement a Watershed Field Study at the NW Regional ESDs Outdoor Science School for elementary students.  The end product would be a full-day field study including lesson plans, background materials, posters and equipment.  OWEB funds are requested for personnel, travel, production costs, equipment and administration.

This proposal is to implement a program that would reduce mercury pollution in the lower Willamette by 10-lbs. per year by targeting 3 major pollution sources:  automotive switches, fluorescent lights, and thermostats.  OWEB funds are requested for personnel, travel, supplies, graphic design, printing, postage, auto switches and administration.

This project would establish an interactive restoration data reporting system to be used by all of the federal, state, tribal and private entities investing in watershed restoration projects in the Deschutes Basin.  It would provide opportunities for spreadsheets, maps, photos, budgets and identification of cumulative impacts.  It would be accessible for designing projects and partnerships and focusing on priority projects by those engaged in watershed restoration.

Project Name: Threespine Stickleback in the Upper Deschutes
Project Summary: This project would study the introduced threespine stickleback and the parasite Schistocephalus solidus in the Upper Deschutes Basin to characterize environmental parameters associated with outbreaks in order to clarify risk of infection to fish and wildlife and to understand food web impacts on native salmonids. OWEB funds would be used for research personnel, travel, equipment, publication and OSU in direct costs.

This project would conduct an OWEB based watershed assessment of two 5th field watersheds: Sprague River Valley and the Sprague River above the confluence with the Sycan River, all in the Upper Klamath Basin. OWEB funds would be used for contracted services, production costs and administration.

The Landscape Management System (LMS) will be used to measure and evaluate the Montreal Process for Sustainable Forestry on two properties in the Drews Creek watershed in Lake County.  The assessment will be done on 3,500 acres of private land and 6,000 acres of national forest lands. OWEB funds would be used for project management, contracted services and administration.

Grass Valley Creek in Sherman County is currently on the DEQ 303(d) list as water quality impaired for temperature.   Runoff and the resulting erosion is a major contributor of sediment and floodway damage to riparian areas.  This project would construct and repair 10.5 miles of terraces, build 28 sediment control basins and  480 acres of brush control and reseeding.  OWEB funds would be used for personnel, travel, contracted services, administration and monitoring.

Project Name: Fulton & Gordon Canyon WS Enhancement/4 Farms
Project Summary: The project will address runoff and sediment transport issues in north Sherman County by constructing 77 water and sediment catchment basins and over eight miles of terraces in dryland wheat agriculture areas.   OWEB funds will be used for personnel, contracted services, administration and monitoring.

The project site is a spring adjacent to the Sprague River and it is an important spawning spring for endangered suckers and redband trout.  The outlet channel is degraded and blocked by river sediments.  This project would restore habitat features, stabilize the spring channel outlet and reconfigure the channel to create spawning structures that retain gravel in pool tailouts. OWEB funds would be used for contracted services, supplies in the form of vegetation and grant administration.

This project consists of channel restoration on a half-mile of spring fed Miller Creek, which is adjacent to the Sprague River, and restoration of a 6 to 10 acre wetland.  The deeper, narrower, more sinuous channel will provide optimal spawning, rearing and over-wintering habitat for redband trout and endangered suckers. OWEB funds will be used for contracted services and materials.

This project on the Sycan River, just above where it enters the Sprague River, would re-establish native vegetation along the river banks, narrow the width and deepen the channel and reconnect oxbows to benefit spawning and rearing areas for redband trout and listed sucker fish. OWEB funds would be used for construction only.

Brown Springs flows in the Sycan River about 2 river miles above the confluence with the Sprague River.  Currently the temperature of the water can raise 17 degrees in less than one mile due to three earthen dam ponds and lack of vegetation.  This project would restore the channel out of the ponds, fence livestock away from the stream and revegetate the streambanks. OWEB funds would be used construction only.

Feral pigs are expanding their range in the area between the Lower Deschutes and John Day rivers.  Many streams are designated as critical habitat for summer steelhead.  Springs and riparian areas are being damaged by the pigs.  This project would support helicopter and fixed wing gunning to reduce the population followed by reseeding of the damaged areas. OWEB funds would be used for contracted services, materials (seed and ammunition) and grant administration.

This project would enlist the help of The Wetlands Conservancy to evaluate wetland conditions and assess the potential to use market based enterprises, including wetlands mitigation banking to help finance the restoration and protection of these key habitats. OWEB funds will be used for travel, contracted services and grant administration.

The 600 acre ranch borders the Wood River in the Klamath Basin.  The landowner is seeking ways to enhance the compatibility of the ranch with the fish and wildlife resources in the adjoining wetlands, riparian and aquatic environments.  This project will design and construct 3 wetlands of 4, 12 and 5 acres and install fencing to exclude livestock. OWEB funds will be used for contracted services, monitoring equipment purchasing, grant administration and monitoring.

This project will develop an effective and inexpensive method for assessing and monitoring health of stream reaches and effectiveness of restoration projects in the Umatilla and Willow Creek subbasins by using aquatic macroinvertebrates.  It will also provide educational opportunities to the public on the importance of invertebrates in river food webs and as biomonitoring tools.  OWEB funds are requested for salaries (89%), printing (1%) and administration (10%).

This project will input existing invasive weed data into a new database designed to record weed occurrence (site) across the landscape regardless of ownership.  The state-of-the-art database can be used to assess vegetation conditions, document treatment needs, track changes over time and provide a usable weed layer for future watershed assessments.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services for data input (90%) and administration (10%).

The Union SWCD is requesting partial funding for engineering support to design and implement conservation and habitat improvement projects.  In the last 2 years, engineering support provided engineering for more than 60 projects.  OWEB funds are requested engineering (73%), mileage (8%), supplies/materials (13%) and administration (6%).

Project Name: Malheur River Basin Habitat & WS Restoration
Project Summary: The project will complete a water-recovery system; establish a 6,000' wildlife habitat border; plant 20 acres to corn or sorghum to provide a wildlife food plot; rock 5,560' of native-surface road and prepare educational brochures describing the work.  Objectives include improving water quality/quantity, wildlife habitat and provide an educational opportunity for landowners to learn about the benefits of managing for wildlife habitat.  OWEB funds are requested for power supply (36%), road rocking (11%), food plots (40%), pamphlets (2%) and administration/monitoring (11%).

The project will restore 5 miles of the West Fork of the Silvies River, which was ditched, diked and straightened, back to a naturally functioning river and floodplain.  The entire project includes approximately 2,250 acres of restored wetlands, riparian habitat and upland buffer.  The project also includes a carp-control function that will enhance the entire watershed.  OWEB funds are requested for river channel excavation & berm removal (100%).

The applicant is proposing to install a more efficient irrigation system on 105 acres and install several bulges in the system to allow for more efficient water management and a reduced water delivery rate to the farm.  In addition, some stretches of the Little Walla Walla will be piped where seepage has been a problem.  This project will provide approximately 2 CFS of conserved water left instream.  OWEB funds are requested for sprinkler conversion (47%), pond liners (49%) and pipe (4%).

Project Name: Monument & Middle John Day Technical Asst.
Project Summary: The applicant is seeking funds for technical assistance to implement fish-friendly projects in areas served by the Monument and Wheeler SWCDs as projects have been increasing in these locations over the last few years.  OWEB technical assistance has been secured by Grant SWCD and those resources shared with Monument District.  However, current levels of support are inadequate to meet demand.  This proposal seeks to retain a person with a technical background who will prioritize restoration projects in Wheeler and Monument areas.  OWEB funds are requested for salary (60%), mileage (13%), office equipment (10%), rent (7%) and administration (10%).

This project would consolidate and move the point-of-diversion for the Milton Ditch downstream several miles, leaving 8 cfs to flow in the main channel the additional distance. It will eliminate the need for a gravel push-up dam at the Milton Ditch diversion, allowing for improved fish passage into Couse Creek and improve irrigation delivery, allowing for an instream right of approximately 3.5 to 4.5 CFS, pre-1900 water right.  OWEB funds are requested for conveyance piping (96%) and administration (4%).

This project will rehabilitate approximately 200 feet of river bank located on the outside bank of a 900 bend on Catherine Creek.  Project components include a rocked toe and base, side sloped at a 2.5:1 ratio; install 450 sq ft of filter fabric; plant 350 cottonwood & willow posts; install 2 root wads and seeded with native grasses.  OWEB funds are requested for mobilization (6%), equipment rental (56%), plant materials (14%), filter fabric (8%) and administration/monitoring and technical assistance (15%).

Project Name: John Courtney Small Pond & Nutrient Management
Project Summary: This project will build a small swale to capture livestock runoff, build a small pond, develop 2 springs, provide livestock water and install 1,120' of cross-fencing.  The pond is solely for wildlife habitat.  To capture livestock runoff, a small swale will be built above the pond, where sediment and nutrient-contaminated water can evaporate and infiltrate before reaching the pond.  OWEB funds are requested for mobilization (5%), equipment rental (45%), fencing (8%), spring development and watering materials (27%), technical assistance/monitoring/administration (15%).

Project Name: CD-ROM on Salmonid Biology Habitat & Restoration
Project Summary: OSU Extension seeks funding to develop an interactive educational tool on the biology and habitat of salmonids that also introduces principles of stream and fish habitat restoration. OWEB funds will be used to cover the costs of a programming contractor and of integrating the educational material, burning the CD, designing and printing the jewel case, and distributing the CD to secondary schools, colleges and universities, and watershed councils across the state.

The Hatfield Marine Science Center proposes revitalizing its Rivernet water-quality monitoring network, which has been operating for the past six years. OWEB funds will be used to support an additional part-time coordinator, provide additional equipment to meet DEQ standards, provide schools with travel funds to field sites, and provide schools with substitute teacher funds to allow for additional adult supervision at field sites.

Project Name: The Cannon Beach Elementary Sch WS Gardening Project
Project Summary: A part-time teacher would work with the Cannon Beach Elementary School students (K-5) to provide information on how a healthy watershed functions and the role of humans within the wateshed. The lessons will be conveyed by means of studying the local Ecola Creek watershed and by planting a native plant garden at the school. The students will explore the critical elements that support the plants and wildlife in the watershed to understand what is needed to make their garden successful. 100% of the OWEB funds will be used for the teachers wages.

Project Name: Fish Barrier Removal On Miller Page Creeks
Project Summary: Implementation of this project would remove four barriers to fish passage on two major tributaries (Miller and Page Creeks) to the Clatskanie River in Columbia County. The elimination of the barriers will open 8.25 miles of high quality spawning and rearing habitat for coho, chinook, steelhead and cutthroat trout. The majority of the requested OWEB funds would be used for construction costs with minor amounts budgeted for project management, travel and production costs.

Project Name: Karnowsky Cr Fishery Habitat Enhancement Project Phase II
Project Summary: This is Phase Two of the Karnowsky Creek project. Phase One recreated a meandering stream out of a diked and straightened ditch. Phase Two will place, by helicopter, approximately 100 whole conifer trees (28-36 DBH) and 20 logs along the newly restored area to enhance fish and wildlife habitat. Over 85% of the requested OWEB funds will be used for helicopter move-in and flying time. The remainder is for administration (10%) and a project manager (5%).

A variety of restoration activities will occur as a result of this project on one landowners property on Roache Creek a tributary of Siltcoos Lake on the central Oregon coast. Stream sinuosity would be restored along 1,425 feet which is currently ditched; 3.85 acres of wetland would be enhanced; 15.4 acres of riparian area would be planted with a variety of native trees and shrubs and one undersized fish passage barrier culvert would be removed and replaced with a railcar bridge. Maintenance of the native trees and shrubs would occur until they are free-to-grow. OWEB funds will be used for project management, site preparation, bridge installation, planting maintenance and monitoring.

Project Name: Fenk Riparian Habitat Restoration & Enhancement Project
Project Summary: The goal of this project is to plant willow posts and whips on a gravel bar at River Mile 5.5 on the Trask River in Tillamook County to stabilize the bar, decrease the channel width, reduce streambank erosion and increase shading. The bulk of the requested OWEB funds would be used to pay the wages and travel expenses of the crew to cut, store and plant the willows.

Project Name: Sanchez Riparian Habitat Restoration & Enhancement Project
Project Summary: This project would plant willow posts and whips on a gravel bar at River Mile 4.7 on the Trask River to stabilize the bar, decrease the channel width, reduce streambank erosion and increase shading. The bulk of the requested OWEB funds would be used to pay the wages and travel expenses of the crew to cut, store and plant the willows.

Project Name: Siuslaw Basin Habitat Enhancement Design Project
Project Summary: The application has been pulled from this round of review. It is a design and planning project better suited for the upcoming Technical Assistance round of funding.

Project Name: Bear Cr WS Monitoring & Enhancement Education Program
Project Summary: This project proposes to provide students and educators in the Bear Creek Watershed with increased opportunities to closely stud their watershed and improve its conditions. The Bear Creek Watershed Education Partners (BCWEP) will accomplish this by sponsoring educator workshops, student symposiums and by providing monitoring equipment, supplies and technical expertise. Funds will support watershed enhancement activities.

This project proposes to establish a Salmon-Safe Applegate, an extension of the successful regional agricultural certification program to the Applegate watershed. Salmon-Safe Applegate will recognize farmers practicing stream-friendly agriculture and provide them with marketing assistance as well as technical assistance in implementing activities on their lands. The project will promote water quality and wildlife habitat protection to both the conventional and organic farming communities in the Applegate.

This project proposes to develop an after school education program that trains high school students in DEQ water quality monitoring protocols.  The program will educate youth in these protocols and enhance science and math education in the classroom.  Instructors will also develop a quality assurance/quality control (QA/QC) program that supports the testing protocols of the Umpqua Basin Watershed Council.  The QA/QC is intended to support adult volunteer monitoring programs for the watershed council.

This project proposes to continue smolt trapping in six Rogue Basin streams  in order to estimate the production of coho, chinook and steelhead smolts. The project began in 1998. Streams where the trapping will be undertaken include Little Butte creek, Bear Creek, Elk Creek, Slate Creek, Little Applegate River and the West Fork of Evans Creek. At the end of each trapping season, a report summarizing the results of the study will be written and distributed to agency partners, watershed councils and other appropriate entities. Sampling protocol to be followed was developed by ODFW. The project provides baseline fish population data and if continued will provide long-term trend information on these populations.

This project proposes to address poor instream habitat complexity within Pheasant Creek. Boulder weirs and logs will be placed to address inadequate pool depths and gravel amounts and poor instream habitat complexity conditions as identified in an ODFW habitat survey. An additional project component will see fencing to exclude livestock from the stream and non-native vegetation removed.

This project proposes to limit livestock access to Coles Valley Creek, distribute alternative stock water, enhance riparian vegetation, improve crossing points and stop erosion in a down cutting drainage. The project location is adjacent and upstream from  landowners that have already completed riparian fencing and plantings.

Project Name: Headwaters & Talent Irrigation Dist Collaboration Phase II
Project Summary: This project proposes to build and install two large self-cleaning moss racks at intersections of Coleman Creek and Wagner Creek along the Talent Canal. The project will protect water quality in natural streams and improve water quality in the irrigation conveyance system by refining manual/mechanical aquatic weed management methods as a long-term alternative to chemical methods. an irrigation workshop will also be held  to increase irrigation management skills and will be that is tailored to local crops and systems.

Roseburg Urban Sanitary Authority (RUSA) proposes to apply reclaimed water from the Roseburg Regional Waste Water Treatment Facility (WWTF) to a poplar and grass plantation, and at approximately a dozen urban irrigation sites.  The urban sites will then lease or transfer their surface water rights from the South Umpqua River to instream flows.
The application has been pulled from this round of review. It is a design and planning project better suited for the upcoming Technical Assistance round of funding.

The Childrens Festival is an academy-styled event related to water resources, watershed management and community participation in maintaining watershed health.  More than 1,600 4th-6th graders attend for free, 300 middle and high school students attend as presenters, and 75 community representatives participate.  OWEB funds would be used primarily for personnel, contracted services and outreach materials and production.

Project Name: Middle Fork Willamette WS Education Program
Project Summary: This resubmitted proposal is for expansion of an in-school watershed education program previously piloted by the Lost Creek Watershed Council.  The program includes field trips and service learning and incorporates The Stream Scene, Project WET and Aquatic Wild curricula.  OWEB funds would be used primarily for personnel, travel, phone, curriculum materials, printing and mailing.

This resubmitted project proposes organization of four Grate Mate pilot projects within the Columbia Slough watershed to demonstrate storm-drain filtering as a viable retrofit solution for reducing storm water pollution.  OWEB funds would be primarily used for personnel, travel, contracted labor, materials and printing.

Project Name: Establishment of a Volunteer-Based Monitoring Program
Project Summary: This project would address Metros priorities of monitoring and involving the public in natural resource stewardship by establishing a volunteer monitoring program focusing on collecting photopoint and datalogger data.  The project would be used to standardize data collection in the region.  OWEB funds would be used primarily for personnel and equipment.

Project Name: Monitoring of Fish Species & Aquatic Habitat In Streams
Project Summary: The City of Wilsonville proposed to hire ODFW to evaluate the abundance and distribution of fish species in the steams of Wilsonville and to conduct an aquatic habitat survey to indicate where habitat should be protected or restored.  OWEB funds would be used for personnel.

This project will restore and enhance degraded habitat along a 1,700-foot segment of the 40-mile loop trail that borders the northern portion of Smith Lake in the City of Portland.  The work includes removing approximately 26,000 sq. ft. of impervious roadway and enhancing forested habitat along the area.  OWEB funds would be used primarily for engineering design, permits, contracted services and materials.

Located at the headwaters of Tryon Creek in the City of Portland, this project will remove 450 feet of existing 36-inch culvert and replace the piped portion of the creek with an open channel.  The associated urban storm drain system in the 67 acre drainage basin will be redirected to constructed wetland facilities before re-entering the creek.  OWEB funds would be used primarily for construction, design, permits and project management.

Located at the Resort of the Mountain in Welches, this project will re-establish 2 side channels within the Salmon River, restore fish passage to Wee Burn Creek, increase salmonid spawning and rearing conditions, decease the chance of sewer line failure in the event of a flood and provide conservation education opportunities.
