OWEB funds would be used primarily for contracted services, labor, materials and production of education/outreach materials.

Project Name: Clackamas Co 2003 Fish Passage Improvement Projects
Project Summary: Located in the Molalla and Newland Creek watersheds in Clackamas County, this project consists of culvert replacement at 3 sites to open 27 stream miles to anadromous fish passage.  OWEB funds would be used primarily for construction, materials and supplies, design, permits and equipment rental.

This 376 acre parcel of land lies between the national forest land and the Klamath National Wildlife Refuge. It contains Crystal Creek, a spring fed stream,  that provides habitat for the Endangered Shortnose and Lost River Sucker fish, Bull Trout and the State/USFWS Sensitive Redband Trout.  Nearly two miles of Crystal Creek and adjacent wetlands are on this property.

Project Name: Irrigation Effiieincy Training in Hood River Pear Orchards
Project Summary: The Hood River Valley is one of the largest pear growing areas in the United States.  This project would provide, through additional weather stations and soil moisture monitoring, real-time estimates of evapotranspiration and watering needs to better manage the application of irrigation water, thus reducing the demand and the effectiveness of the irrigation.  This would not only save water, money and energy; it would improve water quality in the basin and thus benefit listed steelhead and bull trout.

This project would undertake the completion of a watershed assessment of the Sprague River in Klamath County.  While portions of the watershed have been inventoried, a comprehensive assessment has not been done that would include all existing inventories with the participation and guidance from the local communities.  This assessment would utilize the OWEB Watershed Assessment Manual approach.

The project would improve and protect three springs that have been damaged by livestock and elk.  Livestock and elk watering provisions will be made and two miles of fencing will better control livestock.  These improvements will increase flow and improve water quality to the Cedar Lake wetlands east of Lakeview in Lake County.

This project consists of channel restoration on a half-mile of spring fed Miller Creek, which is adjacent to the Sprague River, and restoration of a 6 to 10 acre wetland.  The deeper, narrower, more sinuous channel will provide optimal spawning, rearing and over-wintering habitat for redband trout and endangered sucker fish.

Project Name: Rocky Ridge Ranch Stored Water System
Project Summary: NOT AN ELIGIBLE PROJECT, SEE ors 541.375(8).
This project would plant conifer trees on 1,000 acres of private non-industrial forest lands damaged by the 12,465 acre Sheldon Ridge fire west of The Dalles.

Project Name: Wetland Protection & Feral Pig Control Project
Project Summary: Feral pigs are expanding their range in the area between the Lower Deschutes and John Day rivers.  Many streams are designated as critical habitat for summer steelhead.  Springs and riparian areas are being damaged by the pigs.  This project would support helicopter and fixed wing gunning to reduce the population followed by reseeding of the damaged areas.

Wallowa SWCD is proposing to improve application of water for irrigation on 70 acres.  Planned practices include a 2,800 GPM intake box in both the West Side and Poley-Allen ditches.  A total of 7,560' of PVC pipeline will be installed, with 3 wheel lines, a center pivot and flow-measuring devices.  Watershed benefits include improved water quality and quantity.  OWEB funds are requested for 50% of the cost of pivot and wheel lines (99%) and administration (1%).  Other cost-share partners include NRCS and the landowner.

This project will rehabilitate approximately 200 feet of river bank located on the outside bank of a 900 bend on Catherine Creek.  Project components include a rocked toe and base, side sloped at a 2.5:1 ratio; install 450 sq ft of filter fabric; plant 350 cottonwood & willow posts; install 2 root wads and seed with native grasses.  Project implementation will result in water quality benefits.  OWEB funds are requested for mobilization (6%), equipment rental (56%), plant materials (14%), filter fabric (8%) and administration/monitoring and technical assistance (15%).  Cost-share partners include the landowner, BOR and NRCS.

Project Name: Butte Cr Diversion & Irrigation Improvement Project
Project Summary: This project will install an ODFW-approved fish screen and diversion weir;  4,300' of PVC to replace earthen ditches and provide livestock watering access along the new pipeline.  Watershed benefits include improved water quality, reduced sediment, improved fish passage and improved water quantity.  OWEB funds are requested for engineering (24%), PVC pipe and supplies (65%) and administration/monitoring (11%).  Cost-share partners include USFWS, ODFW, NRCS, OWRD and the landowner.

The project proposes to excavate a small shallow wetland pond in an area that is fed by perennial springs and install an enclosure fence around the 6 acre wetland.  The wetland pond will act as a filter for irrigation tailwater from the terrace above the wetland area.  The riparian area will be enrolled in continuous CRP.  Project objectives include reduced sediment and nutrient loading and improved water quality.  OWEB funds are requested for excavation (61%), culvert installation (18%), technical assistance (6%) and administration and monitoring.

Project Name: McKenzie Ranch Windbreaks & Water Diversion Project
Project Summary: A comprehensive land improvement project is proposed.  Project components include culvert installation, 3 headgates, 1,320' of PVC, planting a windbreak (with drip irrigation) and livestock watering troughs.  Watershed benefits include water quality and quantity improvements.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted labor (11%), windbreak (25%), fencing (8%), stock tanks (28%), pipeline/gates (26%) and administration (2%).   Other cost-share partners include NRCS, BVSWCD and the landowners.

This project would consolidate and move the point-of-diversion for the Milton Ditch downstream several miles, leaving 8 cfs to flow in the main channel the additional distance.   It will eliminate a gravel push-up dam at the Milton Ditch diversion, allowing for improved fish passage into Couse Creek and improve irrigation delivery allowing for an instream right of approximately 3.5 to 4.5 CFS, pre-1900 water right.  OWEB funds are requested for conveyance piping (97%) and administration (4%).  Cost-share partners include BPA, Walla Walla River Irrigation District and CTUIR.

The project is proposing to remove 10,000 yards of waste-rock material from the riparian area, reestablish riparian vegetation, and construct an overflow pond for mine drainage water.  Red Boy is an historic underground hard-rock gold mine located near Granite, which was last operated prior to 1916.  Granite and Clear Creeks are significant spawning and rearing streams for spring chinook and summer steelhead, and also serve as habitat for several species of resident fish.  Watershed benefits include improved water quality, removal of a large accumulation of waste rock, reestablishing a functioning floodplain and improved fish passage.  OWEB funds are requested for removal of waste rock (100%).  Cost-share partners include DEQ Orphan-Site Account and the landowners.

Project Name: Upper So Fork John Day River WS Restoration
Project Summary: The project is seeking funds to improve watershed conditions on both private and public lands within the Upper South Fork John Day Basin.  Project elements include 2,720 acres of juniper removal, 2,309 acres of herbicide application, 35 acres of aspen-stand treatment, culvert installation and log weir repair.  Watershed benefits include improved aspen stands, decreased sediment, releasing sequestered water from junipers and enhanced riparian growth.  OWEB funds are requested for juniper control (72%), aspen stand treatment (4%), equipment rental and mobilization (7%), culvert (1%), herbicide (6%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners include Malheur National Forest, Title II Funds and Grant Weed Control District.

Project Name: Umatilla & Walla Walla Basin Engineering Assistance
Project Summary: The Umatilla SWCD is requesting funds for engineering and technical assistance to design and implement conservation and fish habitat improvement projects in Umatilla County for both the Walla Walla and the Umatilla basins.  Funding will be used to solicit services from professional engineers or private technicians for design and project management which will lead to improved water quality and increased summer flows.  OWEB funds are requested for technical consultation (90%) and administration (10%).  Cost-share partners include Umatilla SWCD, Umatilla Basin Watershed Council and the Walla Wall Basin Watershed Council.

The Oregon Environmental Council seeks funding to develop and distribute a statewide version of its regional booklet, 50 Ways to Love Your River", which provides homeowners with tips on how to reduce their impacts on water quality and endangered fish. OWEB funds will primarily support personnel costs associated with distributing the booklet, most of which will be facilitated by low-cost partnerships and in-kind contributions.

Sageworks Media seeks funding to develop Edens Highway, a public education and community building multi-media project that addresses sustainable watershed development and wild salmon conservation. Signed stewardship contracts with 250,000 participants will commit citizens to change their behavior in support of watersheds and endangered salmon, and will also serve as the primary means for evaluating project success. OWEB funds will be used in part to support development, outreach, production, and post-production costs.

The Center for Natural Lands Management seeks funds to provide stewardship planning information at 10 Oregon sites in an effort to improve long-term resource maintenance and response to changing environmental conditions. Existing mitigation and preserve sites will be evaluated for project inclusion, and submitted to watershed councils for comment. OWEB funds will be used primarily for personnel costs associated with researching Oregon sites.

Project Name: Water Forum/Published Forum Targeting Policy Makers &
Project Summary: Oregons Future seeks funds to publish a 40-50 page water forum to educate policymakers and citizens about water issues and their impact on local communities. The forum proposes to involve OWEB in the content and to distribute the forum to watershed councils, soil and water conservation districts, and others. Following distribution of the forum, Oregons Future will host a public panel involving several of the authors. OWEB funds will be used for personnel and production costs.

The Bonneville Environmental Foundation proposes to partner with watershed councils statewide to oversee and implement long-term monitoring and evaluation programs in select Oregon 5th and 6th-field watersheds. Results will be shared through the Internet, public presentations, publications, and direct mailings. OWEB funds will be used primarily for personnel costs and secondarily for travel, supplies and materials, contracted services, and production costs.

The Oregon Natural Heritage Information Center (ORNHIC) seeks funds to update existing data sets on historic and existing vegetation and protected areas. All data will be made available to watershed councils to assist them with watershed assessments. The project will indirectly benefit local economies by helping to reduce potential conflicts in land management planning and development. OWEB funds will be used primarily for personnel costs and secondarily for travel, contracted services, and supplies and materials.

Project Name: Douglas SWCD/Umpqua Basin WC Tech Support
Kelley Cr Fish Passage Water Quality/Habitat Improvement
Benton Co Fish Habitat Quality Inventory

Project Summary: Ineligible for OWEB funding consideration

Project Name: Upper Willamette Basin Aquatic Species Passage Plan
Green Island Restoration: Hydrologic & Botanical Analysis
Engineering Designs Badger Ditch Piping & Mill Cr Floodplain
Umatilla & Walla Walla Basin Technical Assistance
Database for Pine Cr WS Powder Basin

Project Summary: Summer 2002 burned lands emergency re-seeding
Unallocated Riparian Inventory
Unallocated Research RFP Coordination
2003-05 Council Support for Luckiamute WSC

Project Name: GIS Workshop for Nestucca Neskowin WSC
Project Summary: This education project would fund a workshop for Nestucca Neskowin Watershed Council members and others, the purpose of which would be to teach the participants how to use GIS software and to think spatially and conceptualize using GIS in order to integrate GIS into the councils monitoring, restoration, data management, education and outreach planning efforts. OWEB funds would be used for the instructor as well as for rental of equipment and a classroom.

Project Name: GIS Workshop for Lower Columbia River WSC
Project Summary: This education project would fund a workshop for Lower Columbia River Watershed Council members and others, the purpose of which would be to teach the participants how to use GIS software and to think spatially and conceptualize using GIS in order to integrate GIS into the councils monitoring, restoration, data management, education and outreach planning. OWEB funds would be used for the instructor as well as for rental of equipment and a classroom.

A self-guided, wheelchair-accessible riparian plant tour-path would be built adjacent to the existing handicap accessible fishing platform at the North Fork Nehalem Hatchery if this education proposal were implemented. The purpose of the tour path would be to provide public education on the types and roles of native plants in the riparian zone. The bulk of the requested OWEB funds would be used for production of display panels and the construction of a concrete pathway. Lesser amounts are budgeted for project management, travel, equipment and administration.

Ducks Unlimited, Inc. would enhance approximately 200 acres of seasonal wetlands, several miles of sloughs and 30 acres of native riparian forest on private land currently operated as a hybrid poplar plantation near Clatskanie, Oregon if this proposal were funded. Enhancement activities include shallow excavation, installation of water control features in drainage ditches, barrier fence removal and planting native riparian trees and shrubs. The requested OWEB funds would be used for contracted services to implement the enhancement activities.

This project would replace a culvert to provide year-round passage for juvenile and consistent passage for adult salmonids on Crooked Creek in the Lobster Creek/Five Rivers basin in the Alsea River system. Six log structures would also be placed to further enhance the habitat. OWEB funds will be used to finalize the project design, pay for materials and supplies and to implement the replacement and large wood placements.

20 log structures would be placed into a one-half mile section of Shady Creek, a tributary to Chickahomony Creek in the Siuslaw River system. The upper half of the stream reach is in BLM ownership and the lower half is owned by a private entity. OWEB funds will be used for equipment time to place the structures, purchase of some of the materials and project management.

This project proposes to establish a Salmon-Safe Applegate, an extension of the successful regional agricultural certification program to the Applegate watershed. Salmon-Safe Applegate will recognize farmers practicing stream-friendly agriculture and provide them with marketing assistance as well as technical assistance in implementing activities on their lands. The project will promote water quality and wildlife habitat protection to both the conventional and organic farming communities in the Applegate.

This project proposes continue the project funded under OWEB grant # 201-302. The project works with teachers and high school students. To date, 143 high school students have participated in the current program. With continued funding an additional 240 would be reached over the next two years. The information presented is not part of regular class curriculum and strongly emphasizes natural resources. Students participate in classroom discussions on a suite of resource management and agricultural issues and then apply what they have learned in the field in the development of management plans for participating landowners.

Project Name: Illinois Valley Water Quality & Quantity Monitoring
Project Summary: This project proposes to continue the water monitoring activities of the Illinois Valley Watershed Council, ongoing since 1996. Currently 17 established sites are being actively monitored for water quality parameters. The project will also help the council to analyze previously collected data and to develop an action plan for the monitoring program. Additionally, the effects of irrigation return flow will on stream temperatures and flows will be monitored to establish if late season stream flows are being augmented and if temperature is decreasing.

This project proposes to continue smolt trapping in six Rogue Basin streams  in order to estimate the production of coho, chinook and steelhead smolts. The project began in 1998. Streams where the trapping will be undertaken include Little Butte creek, Bear Creek, Elk Creek, Slate Creek, Little Applegate River and the West Fork of Evans Creek. At the end of each trapping season, a report summarizing the results of the study will be written and distributed to agency partners, watershed councils and other appropriate entities. Sampling protocol to be followed was developed by ODFW. The project provides baseline fish population data and if continued will provide long-term trend information on these populations.

This project proposes to continue watershed project effectiveness monitoring for the Tenmile Basin Partnership. Activities to be monitored include riparian and fencing projects, instream habitat improvement activities, fish passage improvement, water quality and stream crossing projects. Information collected will assist the Partnership in design and implementation of future projects. Baseline monitoring will also be conducted in areas where projects are currently being planned.

Project Name: Fisheries Habitat Analysis of the Umpqua Estuary
Project Summary: This project proposes to support habitat mapping of the Smith and Umpqua River estuaries. This work will include: a bathymetric map using SONAR/DGPS methodology, substrate composition, water quality (mixing areas, ect.) and fisheries work. Information gathered will provide baseline habitat data, which will provide further studies along with habitat protection and enhancement opportunities.

This project proposes to use the Proper Functioning Condition (PFC) methodology to assess low-elevation, tributaries, which are on privately owned property. The information that this assessment will provide is necessary to fill a data gap regarding the health of these systems and will be used in the development of the Lower Rogue Watershed Council Action Plan.

This project proposes to use bioengineering techniques to protect a rapidly eroding streambank and allow the revegetation of an approximately 100 foot riparian buffer. Rootwad and log structures combined with native shrub and tree plantings are intended to increase pool habitat and maintain both the old main channel and the new side channel as functioning habitat. Reduced sediment inputs and solar loading will improve water quality both over the short and long term.

This project proposes to reintroduce meanders, remove fish barriers and improve habitat and water quality and provide educational opportunities in an urban setting. The creek has been channelized for irrigation conveyance and has become deeply incised and devoid of native vegetations. Restoration will reintroduce meander and regrade the banks and reintroduce native vegetations to 1900 feet of streambank. The design will balance sediment and floodwater conveyance while improving critical aquatic habitat and water quality for steelhead. The project is part of a 230-acre master planned development named Twin Creeks.

This project proposed to continue the riparian enhancement program of the Coquille watershed association. Under this proposal approximately 15 miles of riparian area would be enhanced. This would be accomplished through livestock exclusion fencing, off channel watering development and planting of native riparian trees and shrubs.

This project proposes to limit livestock access to Coles Valley Creek, distribute alternative stock water, enhance riparian vegetation, improve crossing points and stop erosion in a down cutting drainage.  Over 6 acres will be protected including 2.700 feet of stream. The project location is adjacent and upstream from  landowners that have already completed riparian fencing and plantings.

This project proposes to develop and implement a large-scale management effort on gorse control on both public and private lands. The effort is a multi-state and federal agency and local stakeholder effort. It will consist of planning, documentation, on-the-ground control and maintenance/restoration/monitoring.

This project proposes to enhance a 98-acre property currently managed for livestock and hay production. Project components consist of riparian fencing and planting on over 1940 feet of stream, Christmas tree reventments, stock water development and hardened stream crossings and upland plantings.

This project proposes to enhance riparian and instream habitats through three adjacent properties. The project will also enable the landowners to more effectively manage their resources. Enhancement will be accomplished through riparian fencing and native species plantings, off channel stock watering development, hardened stream crossings, Christmas tree revetment, upland plantings, bridge installation instream structure placement and existing well development.

This project proposes to continue the Umpqua Basin Watershed Councils riparian restoration program. To date over 50 miles of riparian fencing have been completed. The council typically provides the fence materials and the participating landowners provide the labor to construct the fences.

This project proposes to construct 1,800 feet of riparian fencing to exclude livestock, develop off channel watering remove noxious weeds and replace with native species and construct a bridge to keep livestock and equipment crossing over the stream.

Project Name: Big Tom Folley Rd & Culvert Phase II
Project Summary: The project proposes to install log and boulder combinations at 46 sites in mainstem Big Tom Folley and North Big Tom Folley creeks. In addition four culverts will be replaced throughout the basin opening 4.79 miles of fish habitat and road decommissioning will occur on 2.08 miles of roads.

This project will take information compiled by the Pacific NW Ecosystem Research Consortium, including the Willamette River Basin Planning Atlas and the Habitat Conservation and Restoration Opportunities Map, and make it accessible to landowners, watershed councils, SWCDs, agencies and others as they implement conservation strategies.  OWEB funds would be used primarily for personnel.

Project Name: Coast & Mid Fork Willamette Collaborative WS Outreach
Project Summary: This project is between the East Lane SWCD and Coast and Middle Fork Willamette Watershed Councils and other local organization.  It is designed to increase dialogue and activities between residents and watershed councils regarding watershed health and ecosystem protection and restoration.  OWEB funds would be used primarily for personnel, supplies, materials and production costs.

The City of Wilsonville proposes to hire ODFW to evaluate the abundance and distribution of fish species in the streams of Wilsonville and to conduct an aquatic habitat survey to indicate where habitat should be protected or restored.  OWEB funds would be used primarily for personnel.

This proposal is for Phase 2 of a 2-part water quality monitoring project in the Marys River watershed.  The project seeks to determine the sources of water quality problems in the vicinity of two of the three Phase 1 sites where potential problems were found previously.  OWEB funds would be used primarily for contracted services.

Project Name: Monitoring & Mapping Water Quality in the Oak Cr WS
Project Summary: This project is to provide additional water quality data and recommend management improvements in the Oak Creek watershed and will further develop the watershed as a teaching tool for both the local community and OSU.  OWEB funds will be used primarily for personnel and lab supplies.

Located on a tributary of Amazon Creek in the City of Eugene, this project will restore, enhance and maintain the creeks physical and biological integrity, develop and maintain a water quality monitoring site, and provide education and outreach.  OWEB funds would be used primarily for contracted services, materials, engineering, design, and outreach.

In a partnership between the City of Salem and the Glenn and Gibson Creeks Watershed council, this project aims to re-establish native Willamette Valley prairie/oak savannah on a 12-acre site in West Salem owned by the City of Salem.  OWEB funds would be used primarily for contracted services and materials.

Project Name: Pringle Cr Restoration at Loose Ends
Project Summary: This proposal is to widen Pringle Creek in the City of Salem at several locations.  The goal is to provide space and refuge habitat for native fish.  The widened areas near the stream and adjoining slopes will be planted with riparian vegetation.  OWEB funds would be used primarily for contracted services, materials, design, permits and video production.

Project Name: Willamette Floodplain Restoration Project Dyksterhuis Site
Project Summary: This project is a continuation of the Willamette Floodplain Restoration Project to restore floodplain function, riparian forest buffer, and fish and wildlife habitat on the main-stem Willamette between Harrisburg and Corvallis.  The project will re-establish a riparian buffer utilizing CREP in combination with bank stabilization structures.  OWEB funds would be used primarily for project management and construction.

Project Name: Scappoose Bay Watershed Priority Fish Passage Correction
Project Summary: This proposal is to correct seven high priority fish passage barriers in the Scappoose Bay watershed.  The barriers have been identified and prioritized in the councils Barrier Assessment.  OWEB funds would be used primarily for personnel, designs, permitting, construction and materials.

Project Name: Monitor Plant Survival in Riparian Buffers
Project Summary: In the last 15 years, Wasco County has assisted landowners in protecting 91 miles of streamside vegetation.  Pending applications include another 51 miles of stream buffers. This project would hire a part time person to monitor aquatic habitat conditions, survival of plantings, maintenance and water quality on at least 10 miles of treated stream.  OWEB funds would be used to pay for 16 months of labor, travel mileage and a digital camera.

This project would continue funding for a water quality monitoring coordinator in the Upper and Little Deschutes sub-basins for two years.  This is an interagency regional effort to monitor and improve water quality, increase community awareness and assist n the implementation of TMDLs on 1,800 miles of steam.  The position will focus on TMDL monitoring and implementation, water quality monitoring and the training of volunteers to conduct water quality monitoring. OWEB funds would be used to help support the personnel costs, travel/training, office support needs and administration of the project.

This project would replace the existing dam outlet, re-configure the spillway channel and modify the dam on Lost Creek (tributary to the Crooked River) to improve the ability to maintain lake levels and outflow in a manner that enhances fish passage and habitat for native redband trout. The current configuration of the dam has essentially blocked fish passage since the 1940s. The dam will be modified to address safety concerns.  The spillway will be widened and the slope changed to more closely match the stream characteristics therefore allowing fish passage up and downstream during average high water events.  A new outlet pipe and controls will be installed to better manage lake levels for water quality and fish passage concerns. OWEB funds will be used for dam and outlet pipe modifications.

Project Name: McKay Cr Stream Restoration & Natural Channel Est
Project Summary: This project will re-establish the gradient and sinuosity of approximately 4 miles of McKay Creek, a tributary to the Crooked River.  It will also place structures to improve fish habitat and provide fencing to protect the area for several years prior to grazing under a revised management strategy. Historically, the stream was an important summer steelhead spawning stream and it may be again with the planned re-introduction of anadromous fish above the Pelton/Round Butte Dam complex.  After the channel reconfiguration and instream habitat structure placement, the riparian areas will be planted with willows, alder and other native plants. OWEB funds will be used for equipment, plantings and materials (fencing, woody material, rock and planting stock).

Project Name: Tamarack Cr Stream  Bank Stabilization/Gradient Control
Project Summary: This project would place approximately 60 rock grade control structures in the lower two miles of Tamarack Creek and another 60 rock structures in a one mile stretch of the East Fork Beaver Creek in the upper end of the Crooked River watershed.  The structures will allow the stream to re-connect to the floodplain, raise the water table and the water storage in the substrate and eliminate downcutting of the stream channel. The structures will be built to allow fish passage and placed in a manner to restore the pool/riffle ratio and thereby benefit the native redband trout. OWEB funds would be used for construction and administration.

This project would repair approximately 30 miles of terraces and construct and repair 35 sediment control basins in the dry land wheat growing country between Hay Canyon and Rock Creek in Gilliam County.  These sub-watersheds contribute sediment into the lower John Day River and they support steelhead spawning.  Hay Creek is water quality impaired due to sediment.  It is now necessary to rebuild some of the terraces and other sediment control structures  because they have captured sediments to the extent that their function is restricted.  OWEB funds will be used for heavy equipment leasing and administration.

Brown Springs is the source of a half mile of stream which flows into the Sycan River.  This project would restore the original channel, eliminate the three ponds which cause the stream to increase in temperature and restore upstream and downstream fish passage for native fish, including the federally listed Lost River and Shortnose sucker fish.  Fencing would restrict livestock use of the stream.  Fish passage would be restored with a fish ladder and grade controls and riparian vegetation would be planted.  This stream historically provided cool water refuge for fish in the Sycan and Sprague River systems.  OWEB funds would be used construction labor and equipment, permits and administration.

This project would eliminate standing juniper from 400 acres of land along Pine Creek, a tributary to the Crooked River.  It would also develop a spring to improve livestock management and for wildlife benefit.  This treatment is consistent with the management plan for the property and the juniper clearing already done by the landowner.  The areas to be treated will be replanted with native grass seed.  An improved understory/groundcover will aid in infiltration and reduce runoff and erosion.  OWEB funds would be used spring development and reseeding.

This project would develop/repair three springs and a wetland berm to restore hydrologic function to Crane Lake Wetlands, a high elevation wet meadow complex east of Lakeview.  This area has been overgrazed by livestock and elk.  The spring development should improve the flows and create small wetland areas for wildlife.  Additional fencing will be installed to protect the stream feeding the wetland and riparian planting will occur.  These work elements are part of an overall ranch management plan.  OWEB funds will be used for field supervision of the work, travel, mobilization, fencing, photo documentation and administration.

Project Name: Silver Lake Juniper & Stream/Wet Meadow Restoration
Project Summary: This project would clear juniper from 437 acres in order to enhance spring and stream flows, restore native grasses and reduce erosion along Bridge Creek and Buck Creek in the Silver Lake watershed.  In addition, juniper would be placed in the streams to increase habitat complexity and increase the water table in wet meadow areas.  The woody material placed in stream would be keyed into the banks using DOF guidelines.  The additional storage of water in the soil profile should achieve more consistent flows.  OWEB funds would be used to fell and remove juniper and for administration.

Project Name: Improving Range Health With A Range Drill
Project Summary: The Wasco County Soil and Water Conservation District would purchase a rangeland drill for reseeding native grasses that will be rented out to landowners to restore rangeland health, reduce erosion and provide wildlife habitat.  They will target at least 200 acres per year for treatment. A rangeland drill is a heavy duty seeder that can be pulled over rough ground and existing grass stands without seedbed preparation.  Most ranchers do not own this piece of equipment.  The drill will be made available with its own trailer.  A rental fee of $7.50 per acre will be charged for the use of it which will be used to keep it maintained.  Landowners will contribute their time and the cost of seed.  While some of the sites may receive livestock grazing, the drill may also be used on lands under CREP or continuous CRP.  OWEB funds will be used for a maintenance technician, purchase and administration.

This project in Wasco County would construct a demonstration agricultural chemical handling structure consisting of a roof and a concrete pad with a sump for collecting spillage when spray tanks are filled. The 8,544 acres of orchards and vineyards in Wasco County are sprayed nine times a year.  With a 400 gallon spray tank covering about two acres, this amounts to 38,447 pesticide fillings per year.  Some of these chemicals are very lethal to fish, and some have been detected in the Hood River watershed to the west.  This project would demonstrate a safer condition for handling these chemicals by capturing and safely disposing of spilled chemicals in hopes that similar structures would become a standard part of orchard management. OWEB funds would be used for project construction oversight, construction and administration and monitoring.

The Wasco County Soil and Water Conservation District proposes to demonstrate the value of stump grinding to orchardist (in lieu of piling and burning) so the chips can be used as mulch thereby reducing the amount of herbicide necessary and the amount of potential runoff into fish bearing streams.  This project would bring in a stump grinder to renovate 15 acres of orchard with the mulch being applied to some but not all of the new rows so cost and treatment methods can be compared.  Tours of the site will be held by the OSU Extension Service and articles about results will appear in the Wasco Co. SWCD newsletter and the OSU Hort News. OWEB funds would be used for labor to spread the mulch, the stump grinder mobilization and hourly fee, administration and monitoring.

Project Name: Improving Grass Stand Health With A Flail Mower
Project Summary: This project would purchase a flail mower to help restore the vigor of Conservation Reserve Program grass stands to benefit wildlife and potentially livestock.  There are over 100,000 acres enrolled in CRP in Wasco and Sherman counties.  The SWCDs would rent the mower out at a rate of $2.50 per acre which should cover the replacement costs of the mower.  It is anticipated that about 500 acres could be treated annually.  While CRP is the best way to control erosion, the stands become over-grown with dead plant material and their forage value and vitality are severely diminished.  The mower would leave the material on site to add tilth to the soil but the plants would produce more green forage for birds and wildlife.  The CRP areas can be burned but this is not safe in many areas. OWEB funds would be used to purchase the mower and trailer, administration and monitoring.

Project Name: Buck Hollow WS Enhancement Implementation Phase 8
Project Summary: This project would implement the 8th phase of restoration work in the Buck Hollow watershed, a tributary to the Deschutes River.  Since 1991 there have been significant improvements to the water quality, a decrease in peak flows and increased spawning activity of the federally listed summer steelhead.  There continues to be water temperature issues in Buck Hollow Creek. This project would undertake various conservation practices including terracing, water and sediment control structures, spring developments, brush control and range seeding.  This is the last on-the-ground restoration work planned in the watershed.  All of the restoration activities have been part of individual farm plans.  Restoration work started at the top of the watershed and has progressed to the lower reaches of the watershed.  OWEB funds would be used for project management, project construction, purchase of a digital camera, administration and monitoring.

The project will measure and record field runoff and sediment loading to determine actual erosion rates from different crops & slopes.  Forthcoming TMDL loading targets for the Snake River call for an 81% reduction in total phosphorus and sediment.  OWEB funds are requested project management (50%), travel (5%), summer aides (16%), samples (7%), equipment/meters (14%), administration (9%).  Cost-share partners include the Malheur SWCD, NRCS, landowners, Owyhee WSC, Malheur WSC, OSU Experiment Station and ARS Research Lab.

Project Name: Big Sheep Cr Aquatic Habitat Inventories
Project Summary: The Nez Perce Tribe Fisheries Division is proposing to conduct aquatic habitat inventories (R6, Level II survey methodology) within the Big Sheep Creek subwatershed near Joseph.  OWEB funds are requested for fish biologists (42%), travel/training (18%), technical consultant fees (30%), gear (3%), film/printing/cameras (2%) and administration (6%).  Cost-share partners include the Wallowa-Whitman National Forest.

A proper functioning condition (PFC) assessment will be conducted on all streams within the Buhler Ranch ownership near Joseph.  The Buhler Ranch consists of 10,000 acres with approximately 10 miles of streams to be assessed.  Blue Mountain Natural Resource Consulting will administer and assist with the PFC assessment.  OWEB funds are requested for PFC assessment (35%), GIS compilation (55%) and administration (10%).  Cost-share partners include the Buhler Ranch Partnership.

Project Name: Community Planning Process L Joseph Cr WS Assn
Project Summary: The applicant is proposing to do an assessment of current conditions in lower Joseph Creek watershed (162,807 acres) to develop priorities for watershed restoration.  Assessments of forest, range and range conditions will occur as well as road and recreational-use analysis and wildlife issues.  OWEB funds are requested for forest assessment (64%), riparian assessment (30%) and administration (6%).  Cost-share partners include The Nature Conservancy, USFS, Ford Foundation/Wallowa Resources, Wallowa County NRAC, Grande Ronde Model Watershed.

The project proposes to improve water quality and irrigation efficiency through the installation of 11,980" of PVC and 1,500' of gated pipe to convert the field from furrow to border irrigation.   A settling pond & buffer strip will be installed to filter sediment/nutrients from the area farms tailwater and spawning habitat for rainbow trout will be established.  OWEB funds are requested for engineering/technical assistance/design (5%), laser field leveling (34%), construction of trout stream (14%), pipe installation (12%), PVC pipe (25%), plant materials (5%) administration (5%).  Cost-share partners include Geertson Seed Farm, Owyhee Watershed Council, Malheur SWCD, ODFW and NRCS.

Redband trout habitat will be rehabilitated and water quality improved by planting 540 wetland-type plants and 900 trees/shrubs and installing micro-jet/drip irrigation on Clover Creek near Westfall.  A portable pumping system will be used to provide available water until vegetation establishes sufficient root systems.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (45%), transportation to project site (4%), vegetation (9%), tree shelters/stakes/fertilizer (13%), Hydro-ram pump (7%), lines/emitters (7%), administration (8%) and maintenance (7%).  Cost-share partners include Malheur SWCD, landowners, NRCS, ODA, ODFW, local schools and Boy Scouts.

This project proposes to remove juniper trees on 1,000 acres; develop 3 springs to provide off-site water; improve livestock distribution; allow existing riparian vegetation, native grasses and forbs to reseed, thereby improving upland vegetation and wildlife habitat.  Water storage capacity will improve, soil erosion decrease, streamflows increase to Willow Creek near Ironside.  OWEB funds are requested for well drilling & hookup (24%), spring excavation/materials (47%), fencing materials (19%) and administration (10%).  Cost-share partners include the landowners.

The project will integrate crop-water use, soil-water potential and soil-water content measurements into irrigation scheduling, management and control system.  It continues innovation, demonstration and educational efforts to make drip irrigation a viable alternative solution for various crops.  OWEB funds are requested for technical oversight (48%), irrigation equipment (39%), administration (9%), and outreach/reports (4%).  Other cost-share partners include the landowner-KLG Farms and Reid Saito and Malheur Experiment Station.

A bridge will replace an undersized culvert on Spring Creek which provides water for ODFWs Enterprise fish hatchery.  During high-flows, the culvert washes out the adjacent bank, runs over the road and deposits excess sediment back in Spring Creek.  The project will help to improve water quality.  OWEB funds are requested for welding (4%), bridge sections/steel piling rock (72%), engineering (9%) and permitting (19%).  Cost-share partners include Wallowa County Public Works.

The project seeks to improve water quality by reducing sediment and improve fish passage and spawning and rearing habitat for ESA-listed fall/spring chinook and summer steelhead.  Project elements include moving the existing road 30', constructing new abutments; install a rock barb and stabilize the bank on Courtney Creek, close to the Grande Ronde River near Troy.  OWEB funds are sought for road relocation/overflow relief dip (24%), abutments (43%), railroad car bridge (13%), rock barb (11%), mobilization (8%), administration (1%).  Cost-share partners are ODF and the landowner.

The project will improve irrigation efficiency on 230 acres of flood-irrigated hayland near Lostine. Flood irrigation will be converted to sprinklers.  Components include installation of 7,000' of buried PVC, 1 water-control structure, 3 wheellines (4,040') center pivot (1,183') and flow-measuring gauges.  Watershed benefits include improved water quality, improved water distribution and a reduction in the amount of water diverted from the Lostine. OWEB funds are requested for the pivot (52%), electrical (7%) wheellines (39%) and administration (1%).  Cost-share partners include EQIP, NRCS and the landowner.

Oregon Sea Grant seeks funds to support continuing production and distribution of Restoration, an advertising-free, quarterly newsletter about salmon, watersheds, and people. The newsletter is distributed for free to approximately 1400 watershed groups, agency personnel, landowners, and academics. OWEB funds will be used to cover the cost of the contract editor, a freelance writer, and printing and distribution of the newsletter for one year.

The Resource Assistance for Rural Environments (RARE) Program seeks continuing funds to support the placement of eight technical assistants in watersheds across Oregon. Based at the University of Oregon the program will place these graduate-level participants in rural communities to provide planning, assessment, education and outreach, and research services to enhance watersheds and to implement the Oregon Plan. Training will be provided, and a staff of professional planners will provide technical support. OWEB funds will be used to place the eight technical assistants in Oregon watersheds. Funds will also be used for related travel, contract assistance, outreach materials, and field equipment.

Project Name: Development of Biodiversity Data Protected Areas Info
Project Summary: The Oregon Natural Heritage Information Center (ONHIC) seeks funds to develop an update GIS data layer at a fine scale with an associated relational database on protected areas. All data will be made available to watershed councils to assist them with watershed assessments. These include parks, natural areas, wilderness areas, and the sites the watershed groups and state and federal agencies are protecting and restoring throughout Oregon. The dataset will be posted at the Oregon GeoSpatial Clearinghouse, and will be included in a number of on-line searches developed for the Institute of Natural Resources. The dataset is key to improving and facilitating assessments throughout Oregon, and to assisting the Progress Board in measuring the success of many Oregon Plan activities. OWEB funds will be used to fund all parts of the project, including salaries.

Project Name: Development of Biodiversity Data Historic Vegetation Info
Project Summary: The Oregon Natural Heritage Information Center (ONHIC) seeks funds to develop new data for historic vegetation in areas of the state not already included in existing coverage. ONHIC will develop a 1:24,000 coverage of historic vegetation for the Grande Ronde Basin, lower Columbia River between Astoria and Rainier, and inland portions of the Coquille River. Historical data help watershed groups determine what restoration is appropriate for a given area, and which habitats have suffered the greatest declines. OWEB funds will be used to fund all parts of the project, including salaries.

Project Name: Mapleton Schools' Natural Resource Ed Program III
Project Summary: This project would fund the continuation of an independent natural resource education program in the Mapleton School system that has utilized classroom studies, guest technical specialist speakers, videos, field trips and hands-on activities to bring salmon restoration and watershed health issues to students from the 5th through 12th grades. The school system is seeking to institutionalize the program through the development of a Natural Resource Certificate of Mastery (CAM) for the Mapleton schools. The majority of the funds would be for personnel (78%), travel (7%-school bus rental for field trips) and administration (7%).

Both juvenile salmonid abundance and distribution snorkel surveys and stream channel and riparian habitat assessments would be conducted for 86 miles of the Upper Nehalem River watershed with funds from this proposal. Both surveys types would be done during the winter months and the snorkel surveys would focus on coho and be done at night. The information generated would be utilized to identify priority areas for restoration projects. 78% of the proposed budget is for the survey crew, while 6% each is allocated for travel and supplies.

Project Name: Effective Monitoring for Completed/Future Tidal Restoration
Project Summary: The Clatsop County watershed councils are applying for funds to conduct a monitoring project to begin an evaluation of the effectiveness of tidal restoration projects. Three completed restoration projects and six future restoration projects are included in the monitoring plan. Parameters to be measured include temperature, DO, turbidity and salinity. Personnel and travel account for 68% of the budget while supplies and equipment account for another 21%.

Both juvenile salmonid abundance/distribution snorkel surveys and aquatic habitat inventories would be conducted in the Young's Bay watershed with funds from this proposal. Both surveys types would be done during the winter months and the snorkel surveys would focus on coho and be done at night. The information generated would be utilized to identify priority areas for restoration projects. 78% of the proposed budget is for the survey crew, while 6% is allocated for crew travel and 7% for supplies.

A watershed assessment and action plan will be developed for the 15,900 acre Sand Lake watershed in Tillamook County if this project is funded. This small estuarine system is one of the few remaining coastal areas without an assessment. Almost 90% of the budget is allocated for contracted services.

This project would analyze estuarine wetland sites within the Siuslaw River basin to determine where restoration activities are necessary; establish the type of activity necessary at each site; and prioritize the sites for potential action. The process will be based on observable, scientifically valid data related to tidal wetland functions. 91% of the budget is allocated for contracted services to conduct the analysis and prioritization process.

This project proposes to continue the project funded under OWEB grant # 201-302. The project works with teachers and high school students. To date, 143 high school students have participated in the current program. With continued funding an additional 120 students would be reached over the next year. The information presented is not part of regular class curriculum and strongly emphasizes natural resources. Students participate in classroom discussions on a suite of resource management and agricultural issues and then apply what they have learned in the field in the development of management plans for participating landowners.

The project proposal would continue the watershed monitoring program shared by the Lower Rogue and South Coast Watershed Councils. Under this project, effectiveness monitoring would occur on the councils 600 restoration projects.  Baseline and storm related water quality data in all the Counties major watersheds would continue to be collected. Additionally 45 miles of private road would be surveyed for sources of sediment. The information collected helps the council play an active role in the development of local TMDLs and WQMPs.

This project proposes to continue watershed project effectiveness monitoring for the Tenmile Basin Partnership. Activities to be monitored include riparian and fencing projects, instream habitat improvement activities, fish passage improvement, water quality and stream crossing projects. Information collected will assist the Partnership in design and implementation of future projects. Baseline monitoring will also be conducted in areas where projects are currently being planned.

Project Name: Watershed Assessment & Action Plan Phase IV
Project Summary: The project would fund the final Phase of the Umpqua Basin Watershed Councils watershed assessment process. Watershed assessments and action plans will identify and prioritize key project locations and watershed improvement methods to improve fish habitat and water quality conditions for five areas comprising over 516,400 acres.

The project would move the Applegate River Watershed Councils assessment and action planning process to the next geographic focus area identified in their draft strategic plan. The traditional OWEB assessment methodology will be combined with analysis/identification of the areas most catastrophic wildfire risk. Landowners will be engaged through neighborhood meetings held in local homes. This will help with outreach, issue identification and action plan development.

This project proposes to develop and implement a large-scale management effort on gorse control on both public and private lands. The effort is a multi-state and federal agency and local stakeholder effort. It will consist of planning, documentation, on-the-ground control and maintenance, restoration and monitoring.

The project proposes to replace three fish passage barrier culverts with passage friendly structures. The project ties into other activities being undertaken by the landowner aimed at improving water quality and stream habitats. These activities include rocking of all roads on the property, fencing through the CREP program, creating of off-channel watering and the planting of 94 acres.

Raindrops to Refuge seeks funding to conduct education and outreach to the citizens of Sherwood about watershed health in their community. The program is supported by the Tualatin River Watershed Council. OWEB funds will be used to contract with an AmeriCorps volunteer, cover honorariums for two workshops, purchase a tabletop display, cover the costs of booth fees, print watershed guidebooks and other education materials. This is a new submission.

The Coast Fork Willamette Watershed Council seeks funding to sample macroinvertebrates at 30 locations throughout the basin for taxonomy and possible metals contamination. Xerces Society advisors will be on site with council staff and volunteers. OWEB funds will be used for laboratory analysis of samples, project management, and fiscal management. This is a new submission.

The Pudding River Watershed Council seeks funding to assess all the subbasins in the Pudding River watershed. The assessment will compile all known sources of information on watershed conditions. OWEB funds will be used for providing a single half-time employee as project manager, reimbursing mileage, copying and printing, contracting to consultants or interns. This is a new submission.

The WRI seeks funding to create a new watershed/habitat priorities map for the basin using a consensus-based process to consolidate and refine emerging priorities. This product builds on the foundation of subbasin planning as well as on the Willamette Restoration Strategy and the Willamette Basin Supplement to the Oregon Plan. OWEB funds will be used to convene a group of experts to refine and consolidate prioritization information into a GIS-based map; evaluate commonalities and disparities in approach; identify scientifically credible methods for consolidating and displaying priorities; and funding the costs of data and information generation through use of established protocols. This is a new submission.

The McKenzie Watershed Council seeks funding to restore habitat for at-risk spotted frogs, which were formerly widely distributed throughout the valley. The project proposes to translocate eggs or adults into fishless habitats following an inventory of frogs and fish. OWEB funds will be used to cover the salary of a McKenzie-area zoologist with experience in spotted frog population monitoring. This is a new submission.

Project Name: Pringle Cr Restoration at Loose Ends
Project Summary: Oregon Watershed seeks funding to widen Pringle Creek at several location and to recreate refuge areas for native fish. The widened areas near the stream and adjoining slopes will be planted with native riparian vegetation. This project is a resubmission. The February 2003 review team valued the fact that the project is landowner-initiated and appreciated the concept of restoring channel complexity. The team, however, expressed reservations about the project design and recommended that ODFW be consulted on the project. OWEB funds will be used for excavation, permit fees and applications, project management and design.

This 376 acre parcel of land lies between the national forest land the Klamath National Wildlife Refuge.  It contains Crystal Creek, a spring fed stream which provides habitat for the endangered Shortnose and Lost River Sucker fish, Bull Trout and the State/USFWS Sensitive Redband Trout.  Nearly two miles of Crystal Creek and adjacent wetland are on this property.

Project Name: Automated Water Quality Monitoring & Public Outreach
Project Summary: This project would fund the purchase and installation of water quality monitoring equipment for two site on Mill Creek and two sites on Threemile Creek in Wasco County.  The stations would monitor water temperature, turbidity and flow.  The creeks support steelhead and coho.

Project Name: Camp Cr Paired WS Juniper Control Water Quantity Monitoring
Project Summary: The purpose of this project is to develop an understanding of the impacts of western juniper harvest on water quantity and timing of flow.  The paired watersheds are located 60 miles southeast of Prineville.  They have been monitored annually since 1994 for precipitation, vegetation composition and cover, erosion rates, changes in streambed morphology and surface flows.

Thirtymile Creek is 40 miles long and is one of the most pressured streams in the region for land use, steelhead and water.  It flows into the John Day River in southern Gilliam County.  A watershed assessment would be done using OWEB Assessment Manual protocol.

Project Name: Transcription of General Land Office Survey Notes/U Klamath
Project Summary: The original survey notes from 1860-1912 of section lines provide the first quantitative descriptions of watershed form and function and will aid in the assessment of current conditions in the Klamath Basin.  The project would transcribe those notes and place them on GIS topographic maps.

Project Name: L Crooked & M Deschutes Wild & Scenic River Flow Assessment
Project Summary: The assessment would conduct an instream flow assessment to document the relationship between ground and surface water influences so minimum flows can be established to protect the Lower Crooked And Middle Deschutes Wild and Scenic Rivers.

Project Name: Bakeoven Watershed Assessment/Wasco Co Watershed Action Plan
Project Summary: This project would follow the OWEB assessment manual protocol to complete a watershed assessment of the Bakeoven watershed.  Bakeoven Creek flows into the Deschutes River at the City of Maupin.

While an assessment has been completed for the Crooked River watershed, it did not contain the level of detail necessary to prioritize restoration needs and opportunities.  This project would follow the OWEB assessment manual and complete an action plan prioritizing possible restoration projects.

Project Name: Agrichemical Handling Facility/Sprayer Fill/Rinse Station De
Project Summary: Wasco County had 8,544 acres of orchards which receive nine pesticide applications each year.  This project will establish a demonstration chemical handling facility consisting of shaped concrete pad with sump under roofed pole shed for containment of chemical spilled during filling of orchard sprayers and rinsate from filling and washing sprayers.

The adoption of no-till practices in the Columbia Plateau area of north central Oregon has led to chemical-fallowing treatments to control weeds vs. mechanical working of the soil.  New air propelled spraying equipment can result in a 33% reduction in the amount of chemical used.  This project would pay for the purchase of the new equipment and demonstration of its use on 1,000 acres of land along the White River and Deschutes River, both designated Wild and Scenic Rivers.

This project would install one half mile of fencing to exclude livestock from wetlands along the Sprague River just north of Beatty.  Cattle grazing would be allowed in mid to late summer after waterfowl nesting and will be removed before damage is done to the desired vegetation.

This project would construct 20 and repair four existing water and sediment control structures over 6,000 acres of cropland.  The two sites where this would occur are located in Lamerson Canyon and Rock Creek, both of which are listed as water quality impaired and both support steelhead spawning.

Feral pigs are expanding their range in the area between the Lower Deschutes and John Day Rivers.  Many stream are designated as critical habitat for summer steelhead.  Springs and riparian areas are being damaged by the pigs.  This project would support helicopter and fixed wing gunning to reduce the population and it would re-seed the damaged areas.

The project will continue to provide assistance to teachers in designing and conducting natural resource-based learning activities with an emphasis on watershed learning.  Students will be involved with plant propagation; natural science measurements; use of math in water and irrigation systems; water quality and ecosystem; wastewater treatment plant; various field days as well as other activities.  OWEB funds are requested for coordinator salary (71%), supplies/postage (9%), travel & training (4%), equipment (8%) and administration (8%).   Cost-share partners are the Milton-Freewater USD, Boeing Company Charitable Trust, Wildhorse Foundation and other sources.

This effort will expand implementation of CREP on all applicable sites according to administrative capabilities and landowner interest.  Emphasis will be placed on education/outreach, technical assistance and coordination between various agencies and participants.  Streams in the basin are water-quality limited due to temperature and flow and a significant amount of acreage is currently eligible for CREP.  OWEB funds are requested for mileage (5%), education coordinator (80%), mailing (3%), monitoring (2%) administration (10%).  Other cost-share partners include Walla Walla Basin WSC, Umatilla SWCD and Walla Walla County Conservation District.

Project Name: Wallowa County Stream Flow Gaging Stations
Project Summary: The project will continue the operation of seven mainstem stream gages - three in the Lostine, two in Bear Creek and two in the Wallowa River.  These gages are intended to assist irrigation water management, fisheries management, long-term flow and trend analysis.  Also, DEQ WQ management planning, subbasin planning and will provide essential information to facilitate a proposed exchange for stored water in Wallowa Lake with surface water in the Lostine River and Bear Creek.  OWEB funds are requested for personnel (USGS, OWRD and GRMWP (74%), contracted services (15%), supplies (2%) and administration (10%).  Cost-share partners include the Grande Ronde Model Watershed Program and Nez Perce Tribe.

Ongoing hydrologic and hydrogeologic assessment monitoring will be continued.  The project is designed to answer critical water budget and supply questions for the Walla Walla basin and will provide support for the Walla Walla River USFWS-irrigation district agreement and the CTUIR-USACE Feasibility projects currently underway.  Components include installing and maintaining 22 semi-permanent stations; seepage assessment; shallow aquifer well-level monitoring; diversion inventory; surface-groundwater modeling and water budget.  OWEB funds are requested for project manager (33%), travel (2%), contracted services (51%), supplies/printing and equipment (4%) and administration (10%).  Cost-share partners include OSU, OWRD, CTUIR, Hudson Bay District Improvement, Walla Walla River Irrigation District and WWBWSC.

The water quality monitoring coordinator will continue to manage the implementation of the long-term monitoring as identified in the Umatilla River Basin TMDL and WQ Management Plan.  Monitoring will continue to focus on climate, flow, temperature, sediment and geomorphic assessment for the calendar years of 2004 and 2005.  OWEB funds are requested for coordinator (80%), training (3%), phone (3%), equipment (4%) and administration (10%).  Cost-share partners include the DEQ, WRD, ODA, ARS, USFS, City of Pendleton and Umatilla SWCD.

Project Name: Water Quality Monitoring for the Grande Ronde River Basin
Project Summary: The project will continue assessment of current water quality conditions, trends and restoration/conservation project effectiveness.  It will coordinate and improve data collection programs in the basin and will continue to inform landowners, operators, and natural resource conservationist of water quality conditions and trends and educate them in issues related to water quality.  OWEB funds are requested for water quality technician (93%), travel (1%) and administration (6%).  Cost-share partners include the BOR, Union SWCD,  NRCS, DEQ 319 funds.

Project Name: Database for Strategic Planning in the Pine Cr Watershed
Project Summary: The applicant is proposing to develop a stream diversion database for the Pine Creek Watershed subbasin which is a starting point for strategic watershed planning.  The project will provide a database that can be readily updated, develop GIS maps, identify where headgates, fish screens and measuring devices are currently in place and identify areas where improvements are needed.  This database will augment the assessment, inventory and action planning of the watershed council and NWPPC.   OWEB funds are requested for database manager (95%) and administration (5%).  Cost-share partners include Baker County and USFS.

Project Name: Alvord Lakes Guano Thousand Virgin WS Assessment
Project Summary: The project proposes to prepare a watershed assessment on three subbasins which total 3.2 million acres, each comprises of several closed basins with similar geologic factors.  Existing geological, hydrologic, climatic, stream, plant and wildlife data will be compiled.  Field work will be initiated on the identification of data gaps.  Landowner collaboration will be encouraged.   OWEB funds are requested for project manager (11%), assessment contractor (79%) and administration (9%). Cost-share partners include ODFW, BLM. Harney County Court and Harney County WSC.

The assessment will characterize historical and current watershed conditions in Butte Creek basin comprising 120,000 acres.  The assessment will identify specific opportunities and priorities for watershed restoration efforts and will be conducted by a contracted consultant with a technical advisory team representing various agencies providing oversight and information.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (10%), contracted services (66%), publication(3%), equipment/supplies (5%) and administration (7%).  Other cost-share partners include NRCS, ODFW, Wheeler SWCD, WRD, ODF, Wheeler County Court, City of Fossil, and landowners.

Project Name: Old Bird Hunters Border Strip & Pipeline Restoration
Project Summary: Planting/seeding 16 acres of food and cover borders will provide nesting and brood-rearing opportunities for upland game birds and small mammals.  Gated pipe (560') will be installed to irrigate food plots for upland game birds.   Plant materials include forage kochia, coyote willow, wood rose and other native species.  A pump-back irrigation system will be used to water the filter strips/food plots which will reduce the amount of irrigation water used.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (20%), plants and seed (59%), administration (9%) and monitoring (12%).  Cost-share partners include ODFW, USFWS, Malheur SWCD, Pheasant Forever, Malheur Watershed Council and the landowners.

12.5 miles of blocked steelhead and redband trout habitat will be restored by removing and replacing five culverts in the Joseph Creek watershed with bridges.  The current culverts are undersized or have inappropriate gradients with perches and were rated as high or very high for replacement in the Culvert Fish Passage Rating & Prioritization Report by the USFS.  OWEB funds are requested for bridges (54%), abutment pairs (15%), excavation & installation (17%),  administration(5%) and interpretive signs (9%).  Cost-share partners include The Nature Conservancy, GRMWP, USFS, Wallowa Resources and Auburn University.

The project seeks to improve water quality by reducing sediment inputs to Little Courtney Creek and the Grande Ronde River, rearing and spawning habitat for ESA-listed fall/spring chinook and summer steelhead.  Project components include 3,000' of new road construction, rock 3.75 miles of road, install three culverts and 11 drain dips and one ford.  The project implements the Wallowa County/Nez Perce Tribe Salmon Recovery Plan by following road management recommendations.  OWEB funds are sought for road rocking (70%), drain dips/ford (5%), CMPs (2%), rock pit development (22%) and administration (1%).  Cost-share partners are ODF and the landowner.

The proposal addresses restoring steelhead and redband trout habitat along lower Bologna Creek, a tributary to the mainstem John Day.  Project components include riparian fencing, planting and beaver reintroduction to restore streamflows, instream and riparian habitat; and an intense monitoring plan to measure the effectiveness of the use of beaver for restoration.   OWEB funds are requested for personnel (12%), fencing (22%), planting (5%), relocate beaver (2%), administration (5%) and monitoring (54%).  Cost-share partners include BLM, USFS, EPA, CTWS, ODFW, landowners, Wildlife 2000 and Northwest Watershed Institute.

Project Name: Watershed Weeks: We All Live in a Watershed
Project Summary: For Sake of the Salmon will continue and expand efforts by Oregon State University Sea Grant to assist watershed councils in raising public understanding and stewardship of watershed health and education. Oregon Watershed Weeks provides a statewide focus and venue for organizations to host watershed education and restoration activities in fall 2004 and 2005. OWEB funds will be used to cover personnel costs, contracted services and production costs, and program administration. This project has been previously funded by OWEB.

The Oregon Association of Conservation Districts seeks funding to increase the capacity of conservation districts and watershed councils to carry out their functions. Such capacity building entails director and staff training, development of progress-reporting mechanisms, improved communication, and preparation of training materials. OWEB funds will be used to cover personnel costs, contracted services, printing and mailing, office supplies, and travel and lodging. This project has been previously funded by OWEB.

Project Name: Make A Ripple Make A Wave
Project Summary: Creative Information, Transformation Education, or CITE, seeks funding to provide watershed protection education and to inspire positive action for 12,000 K-5 students in 42 elementary schools in urban and rural Oregon. OWEB funds will be used to cover the costs associated with 33 of the 42 scheduled programs (contracted services, travel and lodging, and supplies and materials. The cost per student is about $1.50. This project has been previously funded by OWEB.

The University of Oregon seeks funds to support the placement of eight technical assistants in watersheds across Oregon. Technical assistants will help build capacity in districts and councils by providing planning, assessment, education and outreach, and research services. Among watershed councils, the program will target those councils that fell in the lower half of recent OWEB council support allocations. OWEB funds will be used to support members and to facilitate placement. No OWEB funds will be used to support University of Oregon staff salaries or benefits. This project has been previously funded by OWEB.

PSMFC seeks funding to develop and deliver three separate and complimentary products to raise the level of invasive weed awareness in Oregon. The products -- noxious weed identification guides, fact sheets, and a general brochure -- will be part of a larger strategy currently under development. The project has targeted a number of different audiences across the state. OWEB funds will be used to print all three products. This is a new submission.

Project Name: NW Oregon Invasive Weed Management Partnership
Project Summary: Cascade Pacific RC&D seeks funds to conduct a fall 2003 pilot and three spring 2004 invasive weed identification and treatment workshops for a number of different audiences across the state. OWEB funds will be used to cover the costs of a contractor to plan and organize the workshops, the development and printing of manuals, and travel. This is a new submission.

OWHF is seeking funds to purchase and house stockpiles or riparian fencing materials that will be housed at ODFW Fish District offices. ODFW will negotiate riparian fencing agreements with landowners across the state interested in protecting riparian areas on their property. ODFW will work with local councils to identify targets for riparian restoration. OWEB funds will be used to purchase fencing materials. This is a new submission.

This project proposes to complete a watershed assessment and action plan for the 15,900 acre Sand Lake watershed in Tillamook County. This small estuarine system is one of the few remaining coastal areas without an assessment. The proposal will integrate work completed by the Forest Service. The proposal has identified the need to develop restoration priorities and what recent information is available to assist the assessment. Almost 90% of the budget is allocated for contracted services.

Project Name: Salmon Anchor Habitat Implementation in Tillamook & Nehalem
Project Summary: This project repeats (for a third year) snorkel surveys for juvenile salmonid abundance and distribution on all stream reaches in Oregon Department of Forestry (ODF) salmon anchor habitats within Tillamook Bay and the lower Nehalem River watersheds.  The project will also conduct a pre- and post harvest assessment of physical habitat parameters within salmon anchor habitats.  OWEB funds will be used for wages, equipment, and travel for the snorkel survey crew; and geographic information systems mapping (85%), for travel expenses and participation in the ODF salmon anchor habitat work group (15%).

This project evaluates forty stream reaches on federal lands in the coast range portion of the lower Umpqua River basin for potential and surveyed  riparian vegetation to determine if species composition of riparian vegetation (including non-native species) different between managed (disturbed) and unmanaged (reference) sites?  OWEB funds will be used primarily for wages, benefits, travel, supplies, digital camera and graduate student tuition.

Project Name: Elk Creek WS Bacteria Source Tracking Study
Project Summary: This projects seeks to identify origins of coliform bacteria through water quality sampling and DNA fingerprinting.  OWEB funds are requested for contractor staff, sample collection, and analysis.

Project Name: Southwest Oregon Foothill Permeability Restoration Demo
Project Summary: This project addresses the ecological impact of annual grasses and forbs at the landscape scale.   The effects of vegetation type on infiltration rates, overland flow, soil loss, and fish habitat will be monitored.  OWEB funds will support OSU staff (55%), supplies and equipment (35%), and production costs (10%).

Project Name: Smith River WS Bacteria Source Tracking Study
Project Summary: This projects seeks to identify origins of coliform bacteria through water quality sampling and DNA fingerprinting.  OWEB funds are requested for contractor staff, sample collection, and analysis.

While an assessment has been completed for the Crooked River watershed, it did not contain the level of detail necessary to prioritize restoration needs and opportunities. This project would follow the OWEB assessment manual and complete an action plan prioritizing possible restoration projects. The Crook County SWCD and the Crooked River Watershed Council occupy the same office. They will work closely together to contract most of the work necessary to complete the assessment. While there has been land management changes occurring in the Camp Creek watershed, this assessment is necessary to identify and prioritize future changes in management and the investment of restoration funds. OWEB funds would be used to pay for contracted technical assistance in gathering the data and writing the assessment as well as printing costs. Other partners in the project include the Crook County SWCD, the Crooked River Watershed Council, NRCS, BLM, USFW, OSU Extension and ODFW.

Project Name: Automated Water Quality/Public Outreach through the Internet
Project Summary: This proposal funds water quality monitoring for two streams listed for temperature and chemical contamination on the 303(d) list.  This information will help to develope an action plan for pesticide use for orchards and other pollutant sources in the watershed.  OWEB funds are primarily for monitoring equipment (25%) and web-enabled reporting (65%).

Project Name: Upper Powder River Watershed Action Plan
Project Summary: The proposed project will develop a restoration plan for a 3,000 acre dredge tailings area in the Sumpter Valley and develop an action plan for the assessment area completed in 2001. The project will rely on public input for priorities and support.  OWEB funds are for consulting services.

This proposal, submitted by the Oregon Wildlife Heritage Foundation, requests $61,826 from OWEB to assist ODFW in it's state mandated task of gathering disparate and incomplete inventories of artificial fish passage barriers into one statewide inventory.  The requested funds will specifically be used to support one of three information systems specialists working on the project.   The resulting database will be joined to a GIS  incorporating current and historic fish distributions, a 1:24k stream layer, and information on habitat quality above the barriers to aid in prioritizing passage improvements.  Once completed, the data base and prioritization tool will be made available on the internet.

This project would provide private landowners in the Siuslaw River basin with assistance releasing new riparian plantings. A three-person crew would treat roughly 105 acres of riparian plantings, or 21,000 trees. OWEB funds would be used for purchase of three clearing saws, various seedling protection materials (stakes, tree tubes, etc.), and travel costs.

A variety of restoration activities, including replacing a culvert with a bridge, livestock exclusion fencing and riparian plantings would occur on three contiguous properties along Rock Creek, a tributary to Devils Lake in the Lincoln City area of the central Oregon coast. Rock Creek is one of the high priority coho streams in the mid-coast area. OWEB funds would be used for: bridge purchase and installation; fence materials and installation; trees and planting activities; and project management costs.

Project Name: Keystone Cr Culvert to Bridge Replacement
Project Summary: With funds from this proposal, a 40-foot bridge would be installed in place of two undersized, shotgun-style culverts currently limiting fish passage on Keystone Creek.
