Keystone Creek is a tributary of the Clatskanie River in the lower Columbia River basin. OWEB funds would pay for the culvert removal and bridge placement.

Ducks Unlimited Inc. would replace two of four iron tidegates that currently block tidal exchange between Tide and Merrill Creeks and Deer Island Slough with the lower Columbia River with funds from this proposal. Tidal connection would be restored to 2.5 miles of lower Tide and Merrill creeks with the installation of new tidegates. OWEB funds would be used for purchase and installation of two 72 self-regulating tidegates.

The City of Vernonia proposes to replace an undersized and deteriorating culvert at the junction of Bear Creek and Adams St. within the city limits. Bear Creek is a small (870 acre) tributary of the upper Nehalem River. OWEB funds would be used for purchase and installation of the culvert, engineering and road resurfacing.

This project proposes to conduct a variety of restoration activities, very near the town of Florence, on two small tributaries of South Inlet, a tributary of the lower Siuslaw River.  A segment of 3150 linear feet of stream would be fenced and 1880 linear feet of stream bank would be planted with a variety of native tree and shrub species. Two culverts would also be placed to provide fish passage and allow livestock and machinery the ability to cross over the creeks without going through them. OWEB funds would be used for: purchase and installation of the culverts; fencing materials and installation; trees and shrubs; and noxious weed removal.

Project Name: Dahlin Cr Fish Passage & Riparian Restoration Project
Project Summary: This project would replace an undersized culvert at the mouth of Dahlin Creek, a 460-acre tributary of Mercer Lake located just north of the city of Florence.  Several four acre sections of the valley bottom would be planted with native trees as well. OWEB funds would be used for: purchase of the culvert and a small portion of the installation costs; trees, shrubs and tree protection devices; and project management costs.

Large wood debris jams would be placed in 26 sites along 1.5 miles of Eames Creek utilizing a track type excavator. Eames Creek is a tributary of Wolf Creek in the Siuslaw River basin. OWEB funds would be used for excavator time to place the debris jams and for use of a self-loading log truck.

This is a two-year project to plant and maintain native trees and shrubs on private non-industrial riparian lands throughout the Siuslaw River watershed. OWEB funds would be used for tree release labor, project management, purchase of trees, shrubs and tree protective devices, travel, and monitoring.

This project, involving two landowners, would fund the site preparation and planting of a combined 2,100 linear feet of the riparian area along Mill Creek, a tributary of the Trask River in the Tillamook Bay watershed.  On the property of one of the landowners, 1300 feet of livestock exclusion fencing with a 20-ft setback will be installed.  OWEB funds will be used for the costs of site preparation, fencing supplies and installation, tree release for two years, project management, and tree protection devices and supplies.

This proposal would replace two undersized and perched culverts in the Youngs Bay watershed with bridges, reestablishing fish passage to a total of 5.5 miles of habitat and provide for the natural transport of sediment and debris. One of the sites is located on the North Fork Klaskanine River and the other is on the South Fork of the Lewis & Clark River. OWEB funds are requested for 50% of the costs for purchase of the prefabricated bridges and their installation.

Project Name: Port of Tillamook Bay Dairy Digester Project
Project Summary: The Port of Tillamook Bay is requesting funds to purchase two Caterpillar engine/generator sets, each designed to produce 1.3MW of electricity to the public grid, for use in their biogas plant. The plant is designed to utilize manure from the areas dairy farms, thereby reducing the amount of waste applied to the fields and subsequently at risk of entering the rivers and waterways. OWEB funds would be used for the purchase of the two engines/generator sets.

This is a combined erosion control and fish habitat enhancement project to be accomplished on the mainstem Necanicum River several miles upstream of the City of Seaside. A combination of large wood structure placement and bio-engineered stream bank stabilization activities will be implemented on the property of a single private landowner. OWEB funds would be used for: equipment and labor involved in the large wood structure placement and labor and materials for the bio-engineered stabilization activities.

This project proposes to remove two fish passage-blocking culverts and replace them with more passage friendly designs. The barriers also pose sediment delivery risks and are located near the mouths of Deadline and Iron creeks. The creeks are both located in critical reaches of Lobster Creek where several anadromous species spawn and rear in high densities.

The project proposes to enhance instream habitats for anadromous species in Walker Creek and Dutch John Creek, both mainstem Coquille tributaries. Five wood structures would be placed in Walker Creek and Dutch John Creek and existing rock structure designed to create an off channel habitat pond would be repaired.

The project proposes to place eight combination boulder and log weir structures in Salmon Creek, a tributary of the South Fork Coquille. Instream habitats were greatly simplified in the one-mile reach due to historic splash damming.
This project proposes to enhance approximately 15 miles of riparian area within the Coquille Watershed through constructing fencing and planting native tree and plant species.

This project proposes to enhance instream habitats in South Sisters and Bum Creeks. Approximately 50 sites will have log and boulder structures placed. Project work will improve 2.5 miles of spawning and rearing habitats in the two streams.

This project proposes to install, maintain and monitor urban catch basin filtration systems to remove sediment, trash and other contamination from street runoff before it enters Sutherlin Creek. The Creek is a tributary of the North Fork Umpqua River.

The project proposes to enhance a two acre wet area. Project funds would be used to implement Phase II which consists of planting native species and monitoring. The project would take place in the Sutherlin Creek subbasin of the North Umpqua watershed.

The project proposes to install 1.3 miles of riparian fencing. The riparian area will be planted with native species. Off channel stock watering will be developed as well as hardened livestock crossings. The project will take place on Marsh Creek in the South Fork Umpqua River watershed.

The project proposes to enhance instream habitat along a two mile section of the North Fork Coquille by adding large wood and boulders to the stream channel. The stream was historically splash-dammed resulting in a simplified instream habitat.

The project proposes to place instream habitat structures consisting of boulders and logs along a three quarter mile stretch of stream. The project would benefit salmonid spawning and rearing habitats. The project would take place in the South Fork of Myrtle Creek in the South Umpqua River.

The project proposes to build on five successful years of an invasive weed control project. Project funding is requested for weed control on private and public lands; education and outreach activities; GIS mapping of weed populations; and restoration and planting activities. Project activities will take place in the Illinois River watershed in the Rogue Basin.

The project proposes to relocate Jackson Creek to reduce the undermining of Grant Road, while reducing erosion and establishing native riparian species. The project is attempting to use more environmentally friendly techniques versus traditional riprap approaches.  Jackson Creek is located in the Bear Creek subbasin of the Rogue River.

Project Name: E Fork Williams Cr Salmonid Habitat Restoration
Project Summary: The project proposes to enhance native salmonid habitats through placement of large wood and boulders in the East Fork of Williams Creek over a two-year period. The project is located in Williams Creek in the Applegate subbasin of the Rogue River.

The project proposes to place boulders and log structures in Pheasant Creek to improve gravel recruitment and retention. The riparian area will also be fenced to exclude livestock. The project is located in the Elk Creek subbasin of the Umpqua River Watershed.

The Friends of Tryon Creek are requesting $150,000 in OWEB funding to purchase and preserve the 8.5 acre Englewood Trail property adjacent to Tryon Creek State Natural Area, Multnomah County. The acquisition of the property would complete the forested edge of the park and aide in protecting water quality and fish habitat for steelhead trout and resident cutthroat trout in a portion of a Tryon Creek headwater stream by preventing four estate-style home developments. The Oregon Parks and Recreation Department will be both the owner and manager of the land. The total purchase price is $1,285,000.

Project Name: Scappoose Bay WS Priority Fish Passage Correction
Project Summary: This resubmitted application proposes to correct six high priority fish passage barriers to meet ODFW design guidelines for passage of juvenile and adult salomonids and flow capacity. The correction of these barriers would open approximately eight miles of potential habitat identified as refugia in the Watershed Assessment.  OWEB funds would be used primarily for contracted services including design, permitting and construction, for three high priority barriers on private land, to hire a Fish Passage Project Coordinator and provide administrative costs.

The Institute for Applied Ecology is requesting project funding for the control of false-brome, an exotic grass which forms dense carpets in intact or disturbed habitats ranging from wet to dry forests, meadows and riparian zones. The first phase of the project would 1) restore habitat by controlling false-brome in sensitive ecosystems and outlying populations, 2) implement preventive measures to slow its spread, and 3) contribute to determining the species distribution in Oregon to develop a pro-active management plan. OWEB funds would be used for all elements of the project including personnel, contracted services, supplies/materials, administration, and monitoring.

Project Name: Boeckman Cr Fish Passage & Stream Restoration
Project Summary: The City of Wilsonville is requesting project funding for the removal of a 48 corrugated metal culvert and associated fill, restoration of the stream and riparian area, and the installation of a wood pedestrian bridge. The primary goals of the project are to improve fish passage and restore the stream corridor throughout the project area. Boeckman Creek is a tributary of the Willamette River and removing the culvert would potentially open 0.5 miles of anadromous and resident fish habitat. OWEB funds would be used for portions of contracted services, supplies, and materials.

Project Name: Spring Valley Cr Upper WS Restoration
Project Summary: The Oregon 4-H Foundation has submitted a proposal to improve fish passage and restore upland and watershed function in a perennial tributary to Spring Valley Creek by replacing two undersized culverts and constructing a bypass channel around an existing pond with a dam.  A rail car bridge will be installed across the bypass channel.  Approximately 1.5 miles of resident cutthroat trout habitat would be reestablished. The project includes both upslope and riparian plantings.  OWEB funds would be used for contracted services, supplies/materials, production costs and equipment.

Project Name: Bylund/OR St Parks Willamette River Restoration
Project Summary: This project would create a continuous 4,000 foot long riparian buffer along the Willamette River by restoring and enhancing floodplain function and fish and wildlife habitat. The project will provide additional riverfront property to Oregon State Parks Greenway and promote the concept of a meander belt along the Willamette River. A land exchange between Richard Byland and OSP will give OSP ownership of the riverfront property. OWEB funds would be used for contracted services and supplies and materials for construction of the stream stabilization structures.

Project Name: Sandy River Delta Riparian Forest Restoration
Project Summary: This project proposes to restore 150 acres of abandoned pastureland, within the Sandy River delta, by planting native hardwood riparian species. This project is part of a long-term effort to restore 1,500 acres of the Sandy River delta. This project has regional significance and is supported by federal, state and local partners who desire to restore unique wildlife habitats and native hardwood forest at minimal costs. OWEB funding would be used for personnel, contracted services, supplies/materials, administration, and monitoring.

This project proposes removing invasive plant species and 50 years of garbage and debris from isolated wetlands near Johnson Creek and reestablishing native plant communities. The project plans to restore six small wetland areas in the Johnson Creek floodplain along the Springwater corridor by removing invasive plant species and garbage, then reestablishing native vegetative communities through planting. OWEB funds would be used for personnel, contracted services, supplies/materials, and administration.

Project Name: Pringle Cr Restoration at Loose Ends
Project Summary: This resubmitted project will reclaim some of the original floodplain along a 250 ft. reach by excavating along the east bank of Pringle Creek at three locations in order to create wide spots in the channel. These terraces will provide zones of slower water for fish during periods of high flow and allow for the establishment of riparian vegetation within areas that are frequently inundated. The widened areas near the stream and adjoining slopes will be planted with native riparian vegetation. OWEB funds would be used for contracted services, supplies/materials, production costs, administration, and monitoring.

This project would restore channel stability in 2.2 miles of Tumalo Creek west of Bend where it has continued to degrade after a 4,300-acre forest fire in 1979.  The design would reduce velocities, stabilize the streambanks and riparian vegetation and increase fish habitat for native redband trout.

This project would rehydrate a 28-acre brown moss fen located ten miles west of Sisters.  Drainage ditches would be blocked with 35 woody structures and a control program for reed canary grass will be initiated.

Hay Creek is a tributary to the John Day River.  This project would build ten miles of new terraces and re-build ten miles of terracing that has outlived their functional lives.  It would also construct 20 sediment catchment basins.  All of this work is aimed at reducing erosion and sediment deposition in Hay Creek and the John Day River.

Crooked Creek flows into the Wood River Marsh and Agency Lake in Klamath County.  The project would narrow the channel and increase instream habitat for native trout on a quarter of a mile of the creek.

This project would deepen the stream, provide additional habitat structures, add channel length to a 600-foot reach of stream near the headwaters.  It would also provide fish passage and habitat by restoring a 600 foot meander that has been cutoff so that it would provide some backwater rearing habitat for native redband and endangered sucker fish in the Klamath basin.

This project includes spring development and solar powered pumping, 14 sediment control basins, a mile of new terracing and the repair of over eight miles of existing terraces on four farms.  The project would reduce erosion and sediment discharge into tributary streams and the John Day River.

This project would develop 17 springs and install two solar pumps on existing wells for livestock water.  These improvements will facilitate better livestock distribution, taking the pressure off of riparian areas on 11,000 acres.  The watershed is a subwatershed to the John Day River.

Project Name: Upland Water & Holistic Range Management in Bakeoven WS
Project Summary: This project would drill a well to provide livestock water in the uplands of Upper Coon Creek and Sparks Gulch (tributaries to Bakeoven Creek [a tributary to the Deschutes River]) to take pressure off of the riparian areas.  Warnock Ranches, covers 23,000 acres, one quarter of the watershed, and has been utilizing an aggressive livestock management system of low duration but high intensity grazing.  This additional water would allow better management not dependent on the ephemeral streams and riparian areas.

Bill Tsiatsos Ponds  The project proposes to construct two ponds in the upper Grande Ronde basin near Starkey. The ponds will help to improve upland conditions and water quality by attracting livestock away from riparian area as well as provide late-season water for fire fighting. OWEB funds are requested for technical support (2%), equipment rental (88%), administration (9%), and monitoring (1%). The landowner will provide cash cost-share.

Dick Snow Ponds  The project proposes to construct two ponds in the upper Grande Ronde basin near Starkey. The ponds would help improve upland conditions and water quality by attracting livestock away from riparian area as well as provide late-season water for fire fighting. OWEB funds are requested for technical support (2%), equipment rental (88%), administration (9%), and monitoring (1%). The landowner will provide cash cost-share.

Carl Hopp Pond  The project proposes to construct one pond in the Bear Creek drainage of the upper Grande Ronde basin. The pond would help improve upland conditions and water quality by attracting livestock away from riparian area as well as provide late-season water for fire fighting. OWEB funds are requested for technical support (2%), equipment rental (88%), administration (9%), and monitoring (1%). The landowner will provide cash cost-share.

Bob Correa Ponds  The project proposes to construct two ponds in the Marley Creek drainage of the upper Grande Ronde basin near Starkey. The ponds would help improve upland conditions and water quality by attracting livestock away from riparian area as well as provide late-season water for fire fighting. OWEB funds are requested for technical support (2%), equipment rental (88%), administration (9%), and monitoring (1%).  The landowner will provide cash cost-share.

Dean Stone Ponds  The project proposes to construct one pond west of Bear Creek in the upper Grande Ronde basin. The ponds would help improve upland conditions and water quality by attracting livestock away from riparian area as well as provide late-season water for fire fighting. OWEB funds are requested for technical support (2%), equipment rental (88%), administration (9%), and monitoring (1%). The landowner will provide cash cost-share.

The applicant proposes to improve irrigation efficiency and water application on 280 acres near Lostine by converting flood to sprinkler irrigation to improve late-season flows to the Lostine and Wallowa Rivers. Components include an intake box in the Poley-Allen Ditch, buried PVC, flow meter, three wheel lines and a center pivot. OWEB funds are requested for center pivot (96%), administration (3%), and monitoring (1%). Cost-share partners include Wallowa SWCD and the landowners. EQIP already provided funding for some components.

This project would develop offstream water for livestock by drilling a groundwater well and installing five troughs away from the riparian area in the Willow Creek drainage of Morrow County. Installation would improve upland conditions for this high-use wildlife area and improve water quality. OWEB funds are requested for well drilling (25%), bury pipe (26%), materials (26%), solar pump (17%), and administration (6%). Cost-share partners include the landowner and Morrow SWCD.

The project is to build a less costly cross-slot no-till drill focusing on water vapor for germination. The drill would be available for use by Morrow County producers to enhance soil organic matter and reduce erosion. OWEB funds are requested for accumulator, valves & monitor system (15%), cross-slot openers (76%), freight (4%), and administration (5%). Cost-share partners include Starvation Farms and Morrow SWCD.

The project proposes to restore one-half mile of South Cottonwood Creek near Milton-Freewater to increase the production of ESA-listed steelhead.  Project components include seven cross-vanes, three J-hook vanes, one-half mile of six-strand high-tensile smooth-wire fencing, native cuttings, channel shaping and livestock watering.  Watershed benefits include improved fish habitat and water quality. OWEB funds are requested for contracted labor (53%), materials (30%), permits/engineering (8%), and administration (9%). Other cost-share partners include BPA/CTUIR, ODFW, landowner and Walla Walla Basin Watershed Council.

This project proposes to move corrals to eliminate livestock access to the Gekeler Ditch system near La Grande. Currently, the operator keeps bulls in the corrals with the ditch, which carries a large amount of perennial spring water, adversely impacting water quality. Watershed benefits include improved water quality, reduced sediment and bacteria. OWEB funds are requested for technical assistance (5%), well drilling/power (38%), pipe and troughs (47%), and administration/monitoring (10%). Cost-share partners include the operator.

The project would significantly improve water quality in the Willow Creek drainage west of Vale. Project components include designing a waste-contamination facility to reduce the 9.5 tons/acre/year of soil loss, 12,000' cross-fencing, two animal waste ponds, wildlife pond and four troughs. OWEB funds are requested for engineering/technical assistance (5%), contracted labor for fencing, pipe and ponds (37%), materials (48%), and administration (9%). Cost-share partners include EQIP, Malheur SWCD and the landowners.

The project would replace flood irrigation with a sprinkler system to improve irrigation efficiency on 244 acres in the Lostine River watershed near Wallowa. Irrigation efficiency would reduce irrigation withdrawal demand from the Lostine, potentially increasing instream flow, and improve water quality. Components include 5,900' PVC, five wheel lines, one center pivot, two pumping plants and two flow meters.  OWEB funds are requested for the center pivot (67%), wheel lines (29%), and administration/design (4%). Cost-share partners include EQIP, Wolfe Ranch and Wallowa SWCD.

The project is designed to improve water quality, instream habitat and the riparian corridor for ESA-listed steelhead in Swamp Creek near Enterprise. Project components include five miles of riparian pasture fence, plant and cage 1,000 hardwoods, cage 50 existing shrubs, harden five water gaps, spot-rock seven miles of draw-bottom road and inventory of uplands. OWEB funds are requested for personnel (23%), pond construction (11%), upland spring developments (37%), improve fish passage (20%), and administration (9%). Cost-share partners include USFS, Wallowa Resources, Bella Vista Foundation, Title II and BPA.

The project seeks funding to restore degraded riparian and floodplain habitat, improve instream habitat diversity and water quality for ESA-listed adult and juvenile steelhead and spring chinook salmon near Lostine. Project components include reestablishing one-half mile of meandering stream channel, six revetments, six J hooks, eight grade-control structures, 12 acres of revegetation, two stock tanks, two water gaps and pond construction. OWEB funds are requested for channel reconstruction (43%), instream structures (45%), vegetation (7%), and administration (5%). Cost-share partners include BPA, NRCS, ODFW, landowner, Wallowa Resources, various foundations and volunteers.

Two separate sources of irrigation return flow would be used to create new and enhance approximately 35 acres of wetlands. Water quality is limited in both return flows and will be improved by filtering this water though wetlands for nutrient removal while reducing temperature prior to entering the Wallowa River near Wallowa. OWEB funds are requested for personnel (11%), contracted services (30%), supplies/materials (36%), engineering (13%), supplies (1%), and administration (9%). Cost-share partners include NOAA, Grande Ronde Model Watershed, DU and volunteers.

A 4,725' portion of a seasonal stream which carries heavy spring runoff would be improved by bank shaping, installing a log-grade drop structure, 32 rock checks, four hardened crossings and seeding near Elgin. Reshaping will reduce erosion potential and facilitate woody vegetation establishment. The area would be enrolled in CCRP after project installation. Watershed benefits include improved water quality. OWEB funds are requested for contracted services (69%), supplies/materials (18%), seed (4%), and administration/monitoring (9%). Cost-share partners include the landowner.

This project would install a water-conveyance pipeline and center-pivot irrigation system and remove over one mile of earthen ditch in the Prairie Creek drainage near Enterprise. Watershed benefits include improved water quality by  reducing sediment and nutrient-laden irrigation tail-water return. OWEB funds are requested for pipeline (39%), irrigation components (54%), and administration (7%). Cost-share partners include EQIP, Birkmaier Ranch, BOR and Wallowa SWCD.

Project Name: Kern Cr & Willow Cr Water Quality Enhancement
Project Summary: One hundred ninety-six acres of flood-irrigated field would be converted to sprinklers near Vale.  Implementation would eliminate water flow through the silage pit, improve water quality, reduce sediment transport and will tie into the irrigation lateral project recently approved by OWEB.  Follows Malheur AWQMP.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services, equipment rental (19%), materials (77%) and administration, engineering, monitoring (4%). Cost-share partners include NRCS, Malheur SWCD and the landowner.

One hundred twenty-nine acres of flood-irrigated field would be converted to sprinklers near Vale. Implementation would reduce significant soil loss and protect an existing riparian zone from grazing and sediment intake. Project components include a bubbler and 2,700' mainline conveyance pipe from the Owyhee main canal. OWEB funds are requested for materials (pipe/bubbler) (82%), equipment (7%) and administration (9%), and monitoring (2%). Cost-share partners include Owyhee Irrigation District, NRCS, Malheur SWCD and the landowner.

Project Name: Lower South Fork Riparian Restoration Phase 1 & 2
Project Summary: The project proposes to provide outreach and education to riparian landowners on the Lower South Fork Coquille River concerning the need for reach-based riparian restoration. The goal is to enroll landowners in the program and then develop reach-based restoration plans resulting in a funding proposal to implement those plans.

Project Name: Riparian Restoration & Fish Passage Improvement Community Ed
Project Summary: The project proposes to develop and implement an intensive 12-month program that will educate target landowners about the needs, alternatives, benefits, and resources for restoring riparian areas and improving fish passage. The program will encourage landowners to critically evaluate their current land management activities and make informed decisions about their future actions.

In partnership with key stakeholders, the Oregon Environmental Council will lead a voluntary, year long planning process in the Rogue River basin to develop strategies for increasing water availability for all beneficial uses, including threatened salmon.

Project Name: Clackamas River Basin Council Outreach & Education
Project Summary: This project will allow the CRBC to implement the strategic outreach and education components of its Basin Action Plan and subwatershed action plans in Rock, Richardson, Clear, Foster, Deep and Goose creeks. It will support delivery of targeted education and outreach activities, demonstration projects and specific products designed to enhance community awareness and understanding of watershed values. It will involve students, landowners, community groups, agencies and jurisdictions. OWEB funds would be used for personnel, supplies/materials, production costs, contracted services, and administration.

The Willamette Riverlands project will address two objectives: 1) developing public awareness of floodplain restoration benefits in terms of endangered species recovery, clean water, and downstream flood protection; and 2) enhancing communication and collaboration among land managers and owners, and communities in the growing number of floodplain activities along the Willamette River and its major tributaries. OWEB funds would be used primarily for personnel costs (Program Coordinator, Executive Director) and administration.

This Project will support the Technical Assistance Directory (TSD) with website enhancements and additional recruitment and outreach of technical assistance providers in underrepresented areas of the state.  These improvements are designed to help watershed councils and soil and water conservation districts have better access to and develop better long-term working relationships with technical assistance sources.

Project Name: Williams Cr WS Fish Access Improvement Project
UBWS TA for Engineering & Field Technician
L Columbia Slough Large Wood Complex Design
Gerking Canyon TA for Enhancing WQ
Harney SWCD & Malheur WSC NR Specialist

Project Summary: OWEB 2003-05 Small Grant Program

Project Name: Watershed Council audit and bonding reserve
Project Summary: Watershed council audit reserve
Restoration project effectiveness Board Restoration project effectiveness validation monitoring position

Funds from this proposal would be used to enhance approximately 100 acres of wetlands and 50 acres of riparian forest on private land along the lower Columbia River near Clatskanie. Planned enhancement activities include shallow excavation; ditch grading/filling, increasing topographic diversity; planting native trees and shrubs; and removal of wildlife barrier fencing. Columbia Whitetail deer are the species targeted but many other wildlife species will also benefit from the proposed activities. 49% of the requested OWEB funds are budgeted for planting activities, 42% budgeted for earth moving/excavation and 9% for administration.

This application seeks two years of funding for an on-going riparian planting project in the Siuslaw watershed. The additional two years of funding will provide 20,000 native trees and shrubs to private, non-industrial landowners for planting in the riparian zones of the Siuslaw basin and the adjoining coastal lakes region. Basic tree establishment activities (tree release) are also included in the planned activities. The bulk of the requested OWEB funds will be used for tree release ($22,000); trees and planting supplies ($13,600), project management and travel ($12,400).

The Upper Nehalem Watershed Council is applying for funds to repair a fish passage barrier on Cedar Creek, a tributary of the upper Nehalem River. The council will replace the currently undersized and perched culvert, located very near the confluence with the Nehalem, with a railcar bridge. The bulk of the OWEB funds requested will be used for bridge and materials purchase ($40,650) and the actual culvert removal/bridge installation process ($8,670).

This project would establish conifers along a two-mile stretch, currently dominated by 20+-year old alders, of the upper Necanicum River. The alders would be felled and a mixture of conifers planted in 8 pre-selected 0.5-acre patches along the 2-mile reach. 6-ft tall protective fencing would be installed around each patch to eliminate elk and deer damage. Labor for falling, fencing, planting and follow-up maintenance is budgeted at $18,400 and project management at $11,200. Supplies and materials purchased with OWEB funds would be $12,400.

The project proposes to place boulders and log structures in Pheasant Creek to improve gravel recruitment and retention.  The riparian area will also be fenced to exclude livestock.  The project is located in the Elk Creek sub-basin of the Umpqua River Watershed.

This first phase of a two phase project on Cottonwood Creek, a tributary of the Klamath River in Jackson County, will complete a topographic map and final design for the entire site, replace the Colestin Road culvert to allow fish passage and treat the West Gully area of the project.

The project proposes to enhance a two acre wet area.  Project funds would be used to implement Phase II which consists of planting native species and monitoring.  The project would take place in the Sutherlin Creek sub-basin of the North Umpqua watershed.

The project proposes to install 1.3 miles of riparian fencing.  The riparian area will be planted with native species. Off channel stock watering will be developed as well as hardened livestock crossings.  The project will take place on Marsh Creek in the South Fork Umpqua River watershed.

The Greenbelt Land Trust is requesting OWEB funding to purchase permanent conservation easements on approximately 120 acres of this 183 acre farm along the Luckiamute River in Benton County.  The property contains approximately one mile of stream, riparian, and floodplain habitats along the Luckiamute River and one-half mile of the lower reach of Price Creek.  The permanent easements will be purchased on 100 acres that are also signed up under the Conservation Reserve Enhancement Program (CREP) administered by the Farm Services Agency.  The additional 20 acres that contain important habitat values but do not qualify under the CREP program guidelines will be placed under the easement.

Project Name: Fitton Green Cr Fish Passage & Habitat Restoration
Project Summary: This project proposes to improve two culvert crossings, an abandoned bridge crossing and two debris jams on Fitton Green Creek, tributary to Marys River.  This stream is located within a natural resource conservation area.  The existing perched culverts will be removed and replaced with bridges and an existing debris jam that currently blocks fish passage will be removed.  A new bridge will replace the abandoned, failing log bridge that is currently a passage barrier debris jam.  OWEB funds would be used for personnel (engineer, surveyors, supervisor, and laborers), contracted services, supplies/materials and administration.

The proposed work is needed to fine tune the water control structure recently installed at Smith and Bybee Lakes Wildlife Area to make it function better.  The refinements will protect the structure and simplify operation and maintenance.  The structure will require active management for many decades and these refinements will ensure that operations are safe and efficient.  OWEB funds would be used for personnel (engineering), contracted services (permits, fabricate and install trash racks and access steps), and administration.

Marys River Park, a 28-acre natural area and main open space asset for the City of Philomath will be restored by removing invasive plants, replacing them with natives, and the trail system will be enhanced to reduce environmental impact and to accommodate increased use.  The interpretive trail will be revived and serve as a public restoration demonstration site.  The park will become part of Benton County Parks Canoe and Land Trails system complete with installation of a safe boat launch.  OWEB funds would be used for personnel, contracted services, supplies/materials, production costs and administration.

Project Name: Spring Valley Cr U WS Restoration
Project Summary: The Oregon 4-H Foundation has submitted a proposal to improve fish passage and restore upland and watershed function in a perennial tributary to Spring Valley Creek by replacing 2 undersized culverts and constructing a bypass channel around an existing pond with a dam.  A rail car bridge will be installed across the bypass channel.  Approximately 1.5 miles of resident cutthroat trout habitat would be reestablished.  The project includes both upslope and riparian plantings.  OWEB funds would be used for contracted services, supplies/materials, production costs and equipment.

Project Name: Sandy River Delta Riparian Forest Restoration
Project Summary: This project proposes to restore 90 acres of native hardwood riparian forest and twenty acres of seasonally wet slough within the Sandy River delta, by planting native hardwood riparian species.  This project is part of a long-term effort to restore 1,500 acres of the Sandy River delta.  This project has regional significance and is supported by federal, state and local partners who desire to restore unique wildlife habitats and native hardwood forest at minimal costs.  Site reforestation will benefit adjacent waterways, and provide shade and in-stream structure along rivers with anadromous fish populations.  The slough will provide off-channel refuge for fish during high water events.  OWEB funding would be used for personnel, contracted services, supplies/materials, equipment, administration and monitoring.

This project will improve winter refugia and rearing habitat for juvenile salmonids, water quality, floodwater storage and wildlife habitat.  Key objectives: 1) implement permitted floodplain restoration plan to add a five (5) acre seasonal backwater habitat and increase side channel complexity; 2) propagate and plant genetically local native forbs, shrubs and trees; 3) irrigate approximately 15,000 trees/shrubs/grasses planted in 2004-2005; 4) monitor wildlife and restored channel behavior; 5) contol exotic weeds; 6) build interpretive floodplain forest trail, and 7) lead educational tours and work.  OWEB funding would be used for personnel, mileage, contracted services, supplies, equipment, monitoring and administration.

This project would restore connectivity into Sycan Marsh and the Sycan River in an effort to re-establish access for ESA listed bull trout now residing in Long Creek.  It would also screen irrigation diversions in Sycan Marsh in the upper Klamath Basin.

This project, northwest of Klamath Lake, would restore .75 mile of stream and riparian habitat along Crane Creek which has been taken out of its original channel and put into an irrigation ditch.  This habitat would help support multiple fish species including redband trout, and endangered fish including bull trout, shortnose suckers and Lost River suckers

This project would provide continuing OWEB support for a Weed Coordinator to implement a integrated weed management strategy in Crook County.  Several streams are listed for water quality problems of temperature and sediment and part of the cause is due to weeds which out-compete native plant materials more effective in capturing rainfall and stabilizing streambanks.

This project on the lower Sycan River consists of design, engineering and restoration to put the river back into its historic channel.  This would re-connect it to its floodplain and reduce nutrient loading, stream velocities, streambank failure and restore riparian vegetation.

Willow Creek in drains 181 square miles and flows through the City of Madras.  This project would replace an undersized 48" culvert with a 96 culvert to improve passage for redband trout and to reduce sediment from seeded fields when flows go around the pipe.

This project would install micro-sprinkler systems on four orchard tracts in the Mosier Watershed.  Water savings are expected to be from 25% to 65%.  The groundwater aquifers have been declining and springs that normally added water to Mosier Creek are now taking water from the creek.  Mosier Creek provides habitat to several fish species with salmon and the ESA listed Steelhead restricted to the lower reaches by natural barriers.

This project would be Phase I of a two phase project to pipe three miles of the Orchard Ridge Ditch, a water conveyance on upper Fifteenmile Creek in Wasco County.  The ditch carries 9 cfs of water and loses up to 1.1 million gallons/day (1.5cfs).

This project would replace a 9 by 7 by 60 long culvert with a bridge over Eightmile Creek on the Endersby Cut-Off Road in Wasco County.  The culvert does not allow steelhead adult or juvenile fish passage at all flows.

Copperfield Draw is incised, disconnected from its floodplain and contributing fine sediments to the Sprague River.  This project would re-establish the stream historical dimension, pattern and profile by physically construction a new channel and re-routing the stream, leaving portions of the existing channel to serve as side channels.

Located near Ladd Marsh by La Grande, project components include 11,000' of exclusion fencing; develop a livestock watering system, install 7 troughs, construct a containment swale, plant 2 windbreak/shelterbelts and install a drip irrigation system for the shelterbelt.  Watershed benefits include improved water quality, reduced sediment, reduced nutrient loading, improved wildlife habitat and improved riparian function.  OWEB funds are requested for technical support (1%), contracted services (52%), supplies/materials (38%) and administration (9%).  The landowner will provide cash and in-kind cost-share.

An area adjacent to Conley Creek near La Grande enrolled in CREP, will also be enhanced with 4,816' of cross-fence, plant a shelterbelt, develop a livestock well and deliver water to different paddocks.  Implemented projects will help to improve riparian and upland conditions, wildlife cover and water quality.  OWEB funds are requested for technical support (2%), contracted services (43%), materials - fencing, plants, drip system, troughs- (45%), administration (9%) and monitoring (1%).  Cost-share partners include the landowner and FSA.

This project will develop 5 off-site water developments in 3 grazing allotments and construct 2.2 miles of fence for a riparian exclosure to provide protection to 1.1 miles of Balm Creek in the Powder River drainage near Medical Springs.  Watershed benefits include improved vegetative conditions, improved riparian shade and bank stability.  OWEB funds are requested for spring development (18%), fence construction (72%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners include USFS and permittees.

Located east of Cove, this project will protect a spring and wet meadow by constructing a 10' x 12' buck-and-pole enclosure around Mt. Fanny spring; constructing .38 mile of a buck-and-pole fence across a meadow to block vehicle access, and decommissioning and rehabilitating approximately .5 mile of a compacted 4-WD road.  Watershed benefits include improved ability of these wet meadows to capture, store and release water and reduce the sediment production from a dirt road.  OWEB funds are requested for fencing (91%) and administration (9%).  The USFS is the cost-share partner.

This project continues a successful effort by Union SWCD to provide a cost-share incentive for producers to convert to direct seeding on approximately 6,400 acres.  Direct seeding is a proven method to reduce soil and wind erosion, reduce field burning and improve carbon sequestration.  More expensive equipment and reduced yields for the first 5-7 years requires an economic incentive to convert to direct seeding.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (7%), direct-seed equipment rental (84%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners include the landowners and EPA.

The project proposes to construct 8 ponds on 5 different landowners properties in the upper Grande Ronde Basin near Starkey.  The ponds will help to improve upland conditions and water quality by attracting livestock away from riparian area as well as provide late-season water for fire fighting.  OWEB funds are requested for technical support (2%), equipment rental (88%), administration (9%) and monitoring (1%).  The landowners will provide cash cost-share.

Project Name: Reducing Environmental Impact Through Precision Agriculture
Project Summary: This project will offer an incentive to growers in Umatilla County to use technology that promotes more efficient use of agricultural fertilizers while reducing environmental impacts.   This precision agriculture includes soil condition mapping, zonal soil sampling and application of fertilizer using variable rate applicators.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (7%), travel (2%), grower incentive (79%), outreach/computer program (3%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners include NRCS, OSU Extension, Columbia Basin Ag Research Center and growers.

Project components include 2 solar pumps installed in 2 wells, a spring development, pipeline and troughs, fenced collection ponds in Willow Creek drainage near Ironside.  These wells provide livestock and wildlife water on 3,000 acres.  Watershed benefits include improved water quality, upland vegetation and wildlife water sources for elk, deer and sage grouse.  OWEB funds are requested for SWCD personnel/engineering (26%), solar pumps/panels (40%), fence materials (6%), pipe/tanks/trough (13%), administration (11%) and monitoring (4%).  Cost-share partners include NRCS, ODFW, USFWS and the landowner.

This is the 1st phase of a 2-phase project to provide alternative livestock water to 3 pastures on a 50,000 acre private and BLM allotment in western Malheur County. Components includes well drilling to supply water to 3 troughs, 3,960' of pipe and a 10,000-gallon storage tank.  Watershed benefits include improved uplands, wildlife habitat and improved riparian areas.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (4%), well drilling (32%), tanks/pump (54%), administration (10%) and monitoring (1%).  Cost-share partners include McEwen Ranch and Malheur SWCD.

A 2-pond pumpback system will collect and transport tailwater to be reused on 4 fields treating 42 acres to reduce E. coli levels within Willow Creek.  Irrigation ditches will be converted from open dirt to gated-pipe.  Watershed benefits include reduced erosion, improved water quality and lower E. coli levels.   OWEB funds are requested for project management (6%), engineering (5%), pump-back construction (18%), materials (62%), administration (9%) and monitoring (1%).  Other cost-share partners include USFWS and the landowner.

A sediment pond to provide water storage will be constructed and riparian vegetation and seed planted to create wildlife habitat on 260-acres of cropland and 1,500-acres of open rangeland in Willow Creek. Watershed benefits include improved water quality, reduced sediment and bacteria and improved vegetative conditions.  OWEB funds are requested for technical assistance/engineering (15%), sediment pond (19%), fencing (7%), plantings (45%) and administration/monitoring (14%).  Cost-share partners include the NRCS, ODFW and the landowner.

Five ponds in 3 drainageways will filter and clean drainwater on 155 acres near Adrian.  Vegetation will be planted near the ponds and filter strips will help to improve water quality.  OWEB funds are requested for project management/engineering (10%), well drilling (16%), solar pump (37%), pipe (13%), plants (8%), fencing (4%) and administration/monitoring (12%).  Cost-share partners include USFWS, WHIP, ODFW, LO and NRCS.

A low-efficiency irrigation system will be replaced with 2 high-efficiency, low-pressure pivot irrigation systems.  A push-up dam will be replaced with a pump station.  Water savings are estimated at 2,800 gpm.  OWEB funds are requested for project management/engineering (6%), contracted services (80%), supplies/materials (8%) and administration/monitoring (6%).  Cost-share partners include NRCS, FSA, landowner and USFWS.

Located in the Succor Creek Basin, this project will convert 6,600' of earthen ditch to pipe, reduce irrigation-induced erosion on 268 acres and allow 3 farms to convert from flood irrigation to sprinklers.  Watershed benefits include improved water quality, improved water management and reduced erosion.  OWEB funds are requested for engineering/management (7%), pipe/inlets (84%), and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners include South Board of Control, OWC, NRCS, BOR and the landowners.

A CREP project to install 2 miles (both sides) of fencing along Birch Creek south of Pendleton will be enhanced by planting 35,000 plants, mulch and tree protectors on 36 acres.  Improved riparian conditions will help to restore the function of Birch Creek, provide aquatic and wildlife habitat, moderate stream temperatures and improve water quality.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (6%), site prep (17%), maintenance (23%), plants/grass seed (18%), mulch (20%), administration (8%) and monitoring (8%).  Cost-share partners include CREP, CTUIR, ODFW and the landowner.

The project will convert 4,260' of open ditch to a buried high-pressure PVC.  Water use from McKay Reservoir will be reduced by 40-60%, which equates to 58-73 acre-feet/year. Implementation will reduce sediment loads, improve water quality and quantity and minimize return flows.  OWEB funds are requested for pipe/appurtenances (54%), top soil/grass seed (13%), trenching (27%), permits (1%) and administration (5%).  Cost-share partners include Elder Ditch irrigators and NRCS.

2.5 miles of Black Mountain Lane will be reconstructed by installing rock, gravel, and proper drainage.  Watershed benefits include reduction of current and potential soil erosion and sedimentation caused by improper drainage into Willow Creek, reducing impacts to fish in Willow Creek.  OWEB funds are requested for personnel supervision (6%), contracted services (57%), rock/culvert (30%) and administration/monitoring (7%).  Cost-share partners include ODF, Bruce Young Logging, Morrow County Road Department and Wilkinson Ranches.

Project Name: Wheeler & Morrow Co Fuels Treatment & Forest Restoration
Project Summary: Pre-commercial thinning and slash abatement on 220 acres are proposed for portions of Wheeler and Morrow counties.  Treatment will reduce potential for catastrophic wildfire, improve forest health, reduce potential for insect and disease infestations and improve watershed health and function.  OWEB funds are requested for pre-commercial thinning (45%), slash treatment (51%), administration (2%) and monitoring (2%).  Cost-share partners include ODF and the landowners.

A 2' drop at the downstream end of the culvert is impeding fish passage on Wallupa Creek near Troy.  The culvert will be replaced with a bridge.  Project implementation will decrease bank erosion, improve fish passage and habitat and improve water quality.  OWEB funds are requested for prefabricated bridge (76%) and permits/project design (24%).  The cost-share partner is Wallowa County Public Works.

This project will improve 157 acres near four fish-bearing streams that drain into Pine Creek.   Project components include removing a portion of densely vegetated pockets of hawthorn and treating the slash; planting 2,000 native conifers and hardwoods, grass seeding of exposed soils and controlling livestock grazing.  Watershed benefits include improved fish and wildlife habitat, increased streamside shading and reduced risk of catastrophic fire.  OWEB funds are excavator rental (83%), plant materials (5%), slash burning (3%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners include ODFW, ODF, Eagle Valley SWCD and Pine Valley Ranch.

Project Name: L Middle Fork & Bear Allotment Improvement
Project Summary: The project proposes to install 10 miles of riparian and cross fencing; install five cattleguards;  install a new upland water source and rebuild 14 exclosures burned during the Summit Fire.  Watershed benefits include improved riparian and upland vegetation, improved rotational grazing and upland water storage. OWEB funds are requested for project management (2%), fence construction (89%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners include Malheur National Forest, USFS Title II and permittees.

Project Name: Cedar Hill Farm Wetland Enhancement-Wallowa & Lostine Rivers
Project Summary: Spring Branch Creek, near Wallowa, heavily augmented by irrigation return flows will be used to enhance and enlarge existing wetlands.  Water quality is limited in both return flows and will be improved by filtering this water though 13 acres of wetlands for nutrient removal while reducing water temperature.  OWEB funds are requested for water management (2%), water quality analysis (3%), contracted services (51%), design/construction management (32%), equipment/permits (3%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners include BPA and the landowners.

Project Name: Siuslaw Basin Whole-Basin Juvenile Salmon Survey (RBA II)
Project Summary: This application proposes to conduct a juvenile salmonid snorkel survey over the course of the late spring and summer throughout the Siuslaw River basin using a rapid bioassessment technique developed for the Oregon coast. OWEB funds would be used in all aspects of the project with the bulk of the costs allocated to wages for the training, supervision and daily work of the snorkel crews.

The upper Nehalem watershed council proposes to conduct a watershed analysis of the Rock Creek sub-basin. The analysis will support development of the City of Vernonia municipal water supply source protection plan and the Upper Nehalem Watershed Council action plan upgrade. OWEB funds would be used primarily for personnel to collect the necessary information and conduct the analysis.

This assessment project would be the first comprehensive survey of the physical habitat, water quality and juvenile salmonid abundance and distribution in the Neacoxie sub-watershed, a major tributary of the Necanicum River. The primary purposes of the survey would be to: 1) identify key areas of use by coho in all life stages; 2) assess the riparian conditions; and 3) develop a list of sites suitable for large wood placement. OWEB funds would be used primarily for the habitat and fish utilization surveys.

This application proposes to conduct project effectiveness monitoring on all Coquille Watershed Assocation (CWA) projects continuing its monitoring program as a basic tool for determining the effectiveness of its project implementation work. The monitoring feedback helps direct the focus of design, development and implementation of future projects.

Project Name: Evans Cr Temperature/ Dissolved Oxygen Monitoring
Project Summary: This project proposes to continuously monitor temperature and dissolved oxygen content in Evans Creek located in the Rogue River watershed. Data collected would be used to evaluate the spatial and temporal variations of these two parameters over an annual cycle. The results will be compared to fish size and population data collected by ODFW.

Project Name: Bear Cr Enhancement at Medford Sports Park
Project Summary: The project proposes to assist with the analysis of natural resource characteristics and conditions at the new Medford Sports Park complex. Instream, riparian, wetland and upland characteristics will be surveyed and analyzed to assist with the design of fish habitat enhancements and integrated stormwater facilities.

Project Name: Elk Cr WS Bacteria Source Tracking (BST) Study
Project Summary: This project proposes to identify the origins and loads of coliform bacteria so that effective BMPs can be implemented to meet TMDL goals in Elk Creek located in the Umpqua River Watershed.

This project would assess riparian and channel conditions for private lands of the mainstem Coquille River from the confluence with the North Fork to the estuary. This will be the final phase of the riparian assessment work needed to complete the entire watershed.

Project Name: Life History & Genetics of Spring & Fall Chinook
Project Summary: This project proposes two objectives. The first is to conduct research that will determine the proportion of spring and fall run sub-yearling Chinook salmon rearing in three seasonal floodplain wetland sites in the lower Willamette River with sub-yearling Chinook salmon at three sites located on the mainstem Willamette River below Willamette Falls.  The second objective is to compare growth rates, condition and diet of sub-yearling Chinook salmon at up to eight wetland sites on the lower Willamette River with five mainstem sites in the lower Willamette River.  OWEB funds will be used for contracted services (consultation, analysis), travel, supplies/materials, production costs, equipment and administrative costs.

The City of Salem is requesting funding for the certification of Salem parks system by the nonprofit organization Salmon-Safe.  The evaluation process features an in-depth assessment of the park systems overall management policies and operations related to the protection and restoration of water quality and fish habitat.  This evaluation is augmented by a field level assessment of a sub-sample of individual parks.  Both system-wide and park evaluations are conducted using a set of standards to evaluate whether the management of candidate parks is consistent with best management practices for avoiding harm to stream ecosystems.  Restoration and enhancement projects on parklands are also assessed in the field to determine if significant progress is occurring, system-wide, to address existing habitat deficiencies.  OWEB funds will be used for contracted services.

Project Name: Action Plan & Habitat Inventory for the Luckiamute WS
Project Summary: The Luckiamute Watershed Council will create an action plan to identify high priority restoration opportunities along with a fish passage and aquatic habitat inventory in selected drainages in the Luckiamute watershed identified as having the highest potential for steelhead trout productivity.  Objectives of the action plan include: evaluating barriers to fish passage and habitat conditions in sub-watersheds that have the greatest potential for steelhead production, identifying and assessing improvement opportunities for other fish and wildlife at a site specific scale, and identifying other watershed concerns such as wetland restoration, sedimentation, control of non-native plant species and actions to improve water quality and quantity.  OWEB funds will be used for contracted services (stream inventory, GIS, technical writing and project management), production costs and administration.

This project will develop a plan for setting up three demonstration farms in Benton, Linn and Lane Counties to illustrate Best Management Practices to use for the protection of ground and surface water, comply with SB 1010 and prepare a farm for receiving incentive payments for good conservation under the Conservation Security Program (CSP).  It will also develop a monitoring program to measure results.  The farms will be used for education/outreach as models to raise the awareness of farmers in preparation for CSP.  OWEB funds will be used for travel, contracted services, supplies/materials, production costs and administration.
Mosier Valley aquifers are declining.  This project would monitor groundwater levels and behavior to develop a water budget and hydrologic model of the aquifers.

This project would monitor bull trout in the upper Hood River basin.  The study will address key questions regarding the life history, population size and trends and the effectiveness of current management practices.

This project will evaluate the effectiveness of riparian stands as drift barriers for pesticide sprays used in orchard management in Wasco County.  The study will evaluate alternative planting options for spray drift barriers taking into account species and densities.

Rock Creek Gauging Station in Baker County, used as a management station for distribution of flows since June 1976, will be relocated downstream to an approved site with suitable control already in place. The cost of setting up the new station will be minimal and physical intrusion to the stream will be limited.  Repairing the existing structure is cost-prohibitive.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services (9%), materials (5%), equipment (77%) and administration (8%).  Cost-share partners include the Baker County Water Resources Department and Baker Valley SWCD.

The applicant proposes to develop a multivariate model of stream reach condition based on macroinvertebrate community structure for use in the Umatilla and Willow Creek subbasin.  Macroinvertebrates are ideal organisms for assessing stream conditions, but models must be developed for specific geographical locations.  No appropriate models currently exist for these basins.  OWEB funds are requested for salaries (87%), supplies (1%), equipment (2%), and administration (9%).  Cost-share partner are OSU, Morrow and Umatilla SWCDs, ODFW and Confederated Tribes of Umatilla Indian Reservation (CTUIR).

Project Name: Ecological Assessment of Riparian Restoration Projects
Project Summary: The applicant will evaluate the effectiveness of riparian restoration projects by comparing year-round bird communities and available resources- food, shelter and nest-site availability - in restored, semi-restored and unrestored riparian areas in the Malheur Basin.  Functioning riparian communities provide suitable nesting structure and shelter from weather and predators (primarily woody vegetation).  Avian surveys will be conducted at each of the six sites during the four seasons.  OWEB funds are requested for salaries (77%), mileage (4%), housing rental (1%),sampling analysis (4%), supplies (2%), equipment (3%) and administration (9%).   Cost-share partners are OSU and ODA.

Project Name: Understanding P Sources in the Malheur WS
Project Summary: The Malheur River watershed delivers water averaging 350-450 ppb total phosphorous (P) to the Snake River.  Phosphorous losses are influenced by human activities, especially irrigation-induced erosion near the mouth of the river.  This project proposes comprehensive sampling at 1 km interval, with 70 soil samples and 70 rock samples taken from each zone.  This assessment will help to ascertain sources of naturally occurring P.  OWEB funds are labor (31%), analysis (59%)  and administration (10%).  The BLM is a cost-share partner.

Project Name: Wilson-Trask Delta Salt Marsh Restoration & Salmonid Habitat
Project Summary: This proposal would fund a number of activities on a parcel of land in the delta between the Task and Wilson Rivers in Tillamook Bay. Activities would include: removing a plug and tidegates to reconnect Blind and Hall Sloughs; re-grading 0.15 miles of a road levee; installing six new culverts with tidegates; removing gravel and sand borrow pits along the southern shore of the Wilson River; and recontouring 7,200 cubic yards of the north bank of the Wilson River. OWEB funds are proposed for all those activities.

This project would fence and plant 4,900 feet of Vaughn Creek, a tributary of Tillamook Bay. Both sides of the creek would be treated for a total of 9,800 feet of riparian area. The setback will average 12 feet. OWEB funds are budgeted primarily for wages for fencing and planting labor with smaller amounts for project management and three years of tree release.

Approximately 17 acres of a combination of riparian and uplands would be planted with a mix of native conifers and woody plants on the property of a private landowner on the Little Nestucca River as a result of this proposal. Two years of tree release is also budgeted. The majority of OWEB funds are planned for tree release labor, followed by site preparation, animal (beavers, elk and deer) control device installation on the new trees and monitoring.

This proposal would replace two culverts currently impeding fish passage and remove a third on Pugh Creek, a tributary of the Siuslaw River. In conjunction with the culvert removal/replacements, six sites along a _ mile reach of Pugh Creek would have large wood complexes added to increase stream complexity and trap and sort gravels. OWEB funds would fund use of various heavy pieces of equipment and operator time, culverts and fill material.

Project Name: Bear Cr - Coho Salmon Habitat/Access Improvement
Project Summary: This proposal is designed to improve salmon access and habitat on Bear Creek, a tributary to Rock Creek in the upper Nehalem River basin. Project activities include replacement of a culvert, upstream large wood placements and riparian planting. The culvert project site is located at the mouth of Bear Creek, on Adams Avenue adjacent to Anderson Park in downtown Vernonia. OWEB funds would be used for: purchase and installation of the culvert and repaving the section of Adams Avenue affected; logs for instream placement, planting materials and construction of three educational kiosks.

Project Name: Wildcat Basin 8 Culverts Fish Passage Enhancement
Project Summary: The Siuslaw Watershed Council proposes to replace eight culverts in the Wildcat Creek sub-basin of the Siuslaw River watershed. The culverts have been prioritized for replacement via a watershed-wide review and would address the top eight of 19 problem culverts in the sub-basin. OWEB funds will be used for virtually all aspects of culvert replacement work. The large budget items (over $50,000) include excavation, culvert components, aggregate and concrete (footings, wing walls and headers).

This proposal would replace two culverts,  place 60 pieces of large wood into 6 sites and spot plant 18 acres of riparian land in Cedar Creek, a tributary to the upper Nehalem River. The culvert in the mainstem Cedar Creek would be replaced with a railcar bridge while the culvert in the tributary to Cedar Creek would be replaced with a larger culvert designed to allow fish passage. The bulk of the requested OWEB funds will be used for the purchase of the railcar bridge and culvert while most of the remainder of the funds will be used for installation costs.

This project proposes to improve anadromous fish access to approximately five miles of cold water refugia, spawning and rearing habitat in the Coquille River watershed by replacing two undersized culverts with an appropriately sized culvert and a railcar bridge. An additional project benefit will be the decrease current and potential sediment inputs into the stream channels.

This project proposes to implement instream structure placement projects in the Umpqua River watershed on Little Tom Foley Creek, South Fork Deer Creek, Upper Cow Creek, Martin Creek and House Creek. Project activities include log and boulder structure placement, some tree felling into Little Tom Foley Creek and the re-watering of a historic side-channel on South Fork Deer Creek.

This project proposes to continue a project partnership between ODFW and the UBWC to provide riparian fencing materials to landowners to fence riparian areas in order to improve and protect instream and riparian habitats. To date, over fifty miles have been fenced under this program.

Project Name: U Umpqua WS Road Restoration Phase 1
Project Summary: This project proposes to improve approximately 20 miles of roads within the Hubbard Creek Drainage, located in the Umpqua River watershed, to reduce the amount of fine sediment flowing into the creek system. Project activities would take place across multiple ownership boundaries.

The city of Keizer in partnership with Marion County is requesting OWEB funding to acquire a 34-acre parcel of land along the Willamette River.  The proposed acquisition is adjacent to an 85-acre parcel, known as Beardsley Bar State Park, managed by ORPD.    The acquisition of this property is necessary to link the Park with existing infrastructure and to provide adequate access for creating the Keizer Rapids Regional Community Park.  This acquisition has the potential to benefit several species including the Western pond turtle and the red-legged frog.  Management will follow ecological guidelines for OPRD leased property and Marion County National Heritage Parks.  This acquisition will allow for regional low-impact and pedestrian access to the Willamette River while simultaneously preserving open space, riparian forests and wetlands.

Project Name: Fitton Green Cr Fish Passage & Habitat Restoration
Project Summary: This project proposes to improve two culvert crossings, as well as an abandoned bridge crossing, on Fitton Green Creek, a tributary to Marys River.  This stream is located within a natural resource conservation area.  Currently, both culverts are barriers to fish passage and the low water ford stream crossing is causing accelerated erosion and sediment delivery to the stream. The existing perched culverts will be removed and replaced with bridges and an existing debris jam that currently blocks fish passage will be removed.  A new bridge will replace the low water, stream crossing ford.  This project will create about 2 miles of good quality upstream tributary fish habitat.  OWEB funds would be used for personnel (engineer, surveyors, supervisor, and laborers), contracted services, supplies/materials and administration.

This application proposes to remove culverts from identified high priority streams and decommission approximately 15 miles of forest roads within the Bull Run Watershed, the City of Portlands Municipal Watershed.  This will improve water quality by eliminating long-term chronic road surface erosion sediment delivery and eliminate the risk of catastrophic culvert and road fill failure, by restoring natural drainage patterns.  Additionally, culvert removal will eliminate current fish barriers, opening about 16 miles of upstream fish habitat.  OWEB funds will be used for contracted services (culvert removal, road decommissioning, and revegetation).

This project proposal has several goals for the lower Clackamas River, including improving water quality, stabilizing eroding stream banks, promoting a functioning riparian area, restoring stream channel shade, addressing future LWD recruitment on approximately 26 acres of side channel and riparian habitat.  This riparian improvement will involve the community in an important restoration project.  The three main activities to accomplish the above goals include the removal of invasive species, planting of native vegetation and monitoring and maintenance of the native vegetation.  OWEB funds will be used for personnel, travel, contracted services, supplies/materials, production costs, equipment and administration.

This project proposes to improve fish passage at three different sites on Potter Creek.  At the first site, an existing 48 diameter culvert with a 2' drop at the outlet will be replaced with a 8 (span) x 6 (rise) pipe-arch culvert.  At the second site an existing 24 diameter culvert and 18 overflow culvert will be replaced with an 8 (span) x 6 (rise) pipe-arch.  At site three, an existing dam will be removed and replaced with a series of rock grade-control, step-pool structures as well as placing a screen and gate valve on an existing 18 culvert that diverts stream flow to an existing pond.  This project will open approximately .54 miles of upstream habitat.  OWEB funds will be used for contracted services.

This project proposes to remove two existing side by side 48 diameter culverts and replace them with a 12 (span) x 8 (rise) pipe-arch culvert.  The existing culvert installation is undersized for peak flows and is constricting the stream channel causing excessive flow velocities which impede fish passage.  This project will open approximately 0.5 miles of high quality, upstream spawning and rearing habitat for both resident and anadromous salmonids in Potter Creek.  OWEB funds will be used for contracted services.

Project Name: Ramsey Wetland Complex Off-Channel Habitat Design & Res
Project Summary: This project proposes to restore access to historic off-channel habitat for juvenile salmon in the lower Columbia Slough, while simultaneously restoring tidal connections and improving water quality and habitat for aquatic and terrestrial wildlife in a forested wetland.  Approximately 6000 cubic yards of material will be removed to reconnect about 1.3 acres of off-channel rearing habitat for over wintering and refuge for juvenile salmon.  Additionally, about 3 acres of riparian, floodplain and wetland habitat will be improved by planting native wetland, scrub-shrub and forested wetland species.  OWEB funds will be used for personnel, contracted services (excavation), supplies/materials, production costs and administration.

Project Name: Sprague River Channel Reconstruction & Wetland Enhancement
Project Summary: The project site is on the Sprague River just downstream of the confluence with the Sycan River near Beatty.  The main river channel has cut down due to overgrazing and lack of bank stabilizing riparian vegetation.  Two cutoff channels accelerate the velocity of the river by shortening its length and thus the river does not have access to its floodplain to dissipate flood flow energies.  This project would plug those channels and restore natural sinuosity.  This river system is home to the endangered Lost River and Shortnose sucker fish.

Irving Creek joins Jackson Creek, which, historically flowed into the Upper Williamson River above Klamath Marsh National Wildlife Refuge.  In recent times Jackson Creek is diverted for irrigation and there is no longer a channel that connects it to the Williamson.  This project would reconstruct the historical channel and restore connectivity for the redband trout and other aquatic and terrestrial species.

This project proposes to restore riparian areas on private lands by planting native vegetation.  The project will enroll up to 1,600 acres within the Lower Crooked River, the Deschutes River, Trout Creek and Three-Mile Creek areas in the Deschutes Basin in this riparian enhancement and carbon sequestration project.

Project Name: Grass Valley/Pine Hollow/Jackknife & N Sh WS Conservation
Project Summary: This project would continue to address erosion processes on dryland wheat farming areas in Sherman County.  It would also fund improvements to livestock operations and thus decrease grazing pressures on riparian areas.

This project consists of five sites; three on the Deschutes River, one on Squaw Creek and one on Paulina Creek.  Each of the sites will be designed to address streambank stability, habitat and shading to improve water quality and fish habitat.

This project would replace an existing 9 foot by 7 foot by 60 foot long culvert with a larger open arch culvert to span the stream and solve the steelhead passage barrier problem on Eightmile Creek, a tributary to Fifteenmile Creek, home of the eastern most run of listed wild winter steelhead.  The project is in Wasco County.

Walla Walla River Irrigation District (WWRID) proposes to pipe, rehabilitate and automate the first 4,150' of Powell/Pleasantview Ditch near Milton-Freewater, convert 104 acres from flood-to-sprinkler, install water-measuring devices and on-farm piping.  Expected water savings are 2-4 cfs.   Watershed benefits are water quality and  quantity improvement.  OWEB funds are requested for personnel (2%), pipeline installation (11%), pipe (63%) on-farm efficiency (15%) and administration (8%) and monitoring (1%).  Cost-share partners include BPA, WWRID, Oregon Water Trust, NRCS and landowners.

Project Name: Baker Valley Horizontal Flat-Plate Fish Screen
Project Summary: The project seeks funds for a horizontal-flat screen on the Powder River.  The fish screen is needed to protect a recently installed OWEB project, 99-090.  Funds were approved previously for this project by ODFW, but were later withdrawn due to over expenditure.  Project implementation will benefit fisheries.  OWEB funds are requested for fish screen (91%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners Baker Valley Irrigation District (BVID), Baker SWCD, NRCS and BOR.

This project will facilitate juniper removal of 1,156 acres near Fossil using either trackhoe, chainsaw or piling.  The treated areas will then be reseeded with an appropriate rangeland mix.  Watershed benefits include improved groundwater, decreased erosion, improved rangeland health and wildlife habitat.  OWEB funds are requested for project managementt/engineering (3%), juniper removal (87%), administration (9%) and monitoring (1%).  Cost-share partners include various landowners and NRCS.

This project continues a successful effort by Union SWCD to provide a cost-share incentive for producers to convert to direct seeding on approximately 6,400 acres.  Direct seeding is a proven method to reduce soil and wind erosion, reduce field burning and improve carbon sequestration.  More expensive equipment and reduced yields for the first 5-7 years requires an economic incentive to convert to direct seeding.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (7%), direct-seed equipment rental (84%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners include the landowners and EPA.

Project Name: Little Willow Irrigation Return Flow Elimination
Project Summary: This project will facilitate converting 98 acres of row crops from flood irrigation to sprinkler by installing a center pivot, fencing to eliminate livestock access to Willow Creek near Vale, installing buried main lines, two troughs for off-stream water and 700 willow plantings along the creek.  Project implementation follows SB 1010 and will improve water quality, reduce phosphorous and improve riparian conditions.  OWEB funds are requested for project management/engineering (8%), contracted services (17%), materials (71%) and administration (4%).  The landowner is the cost-share partner.

The project will stabilize approximately 125 lineal feet and 20 vertical feet on the Lostine River bank by installing a bankfull bench, three log jams and one rock vane.  The site is directly upstream of the most productive chinook spawning area on the entire Lostine.  The sediment and fines are actively deposited into the system annually.  OWEB funds are requested for personnel (20%),  engineering (18%), equipment rental (37%), materials (12%), administration (9%) and monitoring (4%).  Cost-share partners include Nez Perce Tribe, Wallowa School District and Dave Lundquist.

Located near Butter Creek, 500' of an irrigation ditch has washed so deep that a side ditch is non-functioning.  The washouts are creating substantial erosion.  The applicant wants to line the ditch with concrete blocks and place drop structures throughout the 500' to slow the water velocity. Watershed benefits include improved water quality.  OWEB funds are requested for materials (91%) and administration/monitoring (9%).

Funding is requested to complete 6,400' of fencing and plant 1,000 trees on a previously funded OWEB project.  Project accomplishments to date include restoring three meanders of the Powder River through levee removal and three wetlands.  Watershed benefits include improved water quality, riparian vegetation and improve instream fish habitat.  OWEB funds are requested for tree planting labor (19%), fencing (66%), plant materials (6%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners include Ducks Unlimited.

Project Name: Highline Canal Piping - Walla Walla River Conservation
