Project Summary: The Walla Walla WSC is seeking funds to pipe 1.4 miles of open canal which has 24 users and serves 1,294 acres.  Project will return and protect approximately 11 cfs using Conserved Water Statute.  Watershed benefits include restoring spring passage and summer flows for 19 miles of steelhead and bull trout habitat.  OWEB funds are requested for management (3%), pipe/fittings (92%) and administration (5%).  Cost-share partners include Hudson Bay District, NRCS and BPA.

This is the firstt phase of a two-phase project to provide alternative livestock water to three pastures on a 50,000 acre private and BLM allotment in western Malheur County south of Juntura.   Components includes well drilling to supply water to three3 troughs, 3,960' of pipe and a 10,000-gallon storage tank.  Watershed benefits include improved uplands, wildlife habitat and  riparian areas.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (4%), well drilling (32%), tanks/pump (54%), administration (10%) and monitoring (1%).  Cost-share partners include the McEwen Ranch and Malheur SWCD.

Ponds to filter water from agricultural field will be constructed in three drainage ways to filter and clean drainwater on 155 acres near Adrian.  Wildlife food cover plots of grasses and forbs will be planted near the ponds and the filter strips will help improve water quality.  OWEB funds are requested for project management/engineering (10%), well drilling (16%), solar pump (37%), pipe (13%), plants (8%), fencing (4%) and administration/monitoring (12%).  Cost-share partners include USFWS, Watershed Habitat Incentive Program (WHIP), ODFW, LO and NRCS.

A gravel push-up dam will be replaced with a permanent, controllable structure to provide fish passage and irrigation water control near Baker City.  The ditch serves 800 acres.   Watershed benefits include improved water quality, reduce channel degradation, improve stability and reduce risk of embankment failure.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (1%),engineering (26%), equipment rental (15%), materials (49%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners include Burnt River SWCD, Burnt River Irrigation District, NRCS and ditch users.

A two-pond pumpback system will collect and transport tailwater to be reused on four fields treating 42 acres to reduce E. coli levels within Willow Creek near Vale.  Irrigation ditches will be converted from open dirt to gated-pipe.  Watershed benefits include reduced erosion, improved water quality and lower E. coli levels.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (5%), engineering (4%), pump-back construction (18%), materials (63%), administration (9%) and monitoring (1%).  Cost-share partners include USFWS and the landowner.

Project Name: Compensating Conservation: Direct Seed Incentive Program
Project Summary: The Umatilla SWCD is proposing to enroll 20,000 acres into a direct seed incentive program, compensating landowners at $10/acre.  The seed will be drilled into the previous crop residue but requires either purchase or rental of direct seeding equipment.  Watershed benefits are reduced erosion, improved water quality and improved wildlife habitat.  OWEB funds are requested for project manager (6%), direct seed (84%), administration (9%) and monitoring (1%).  Cost-share partners include landowners, OSU Extension, Umatilla SWCD, NRCS and Agriculture Research Service (ARS).

This project will install an irrigation system (1.0 mile) and food/cover lots to improve wildlife habitat conditions on 60 acres.  The food plots will be seeded to a mixture of forbs and grasses to provide season-long cover/food for upland game birds.  Sedges, rushes and riparian vegetation will be planted around the pond.  OWEB funds are requested for project manager/engineering (9%), pipe (73%), seed (6%), administration (10%) and monitoring (2%).  Cost-share partners include USFWS, WHIP, ODFW, the landowner and NRCS.

Historic dredge tailings, which constrict and cut off a channel of Clear Creek, will be  redistributed  to connect it to its historic floodplain.  Approximately 220,000 cubic yards will be moved to improve water quality and fisheries habitat.  OWEB funds are requested for personnel (10%), travel (3%), equipment rental (83%) and administration (4%).  Cost-share partners are the USFS, CTUIR, NOAA, BPA and ODFW.

The proposed project, located near Baker, will replace a gravel push-up dam with a permanent, controllable structure that provides fish passage and improved water control on the Packwood ditch which serves 450 acres.   Watershed benefits include improved water quality, reduced erosion and improved fish habitat.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (3%), engineering (30%), equipment rental (24%), materials (35%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners include Burnt River SWCD, Burnt River Irrigation District, NRCS and the ditch users.

This joint cooperative project between Malheur SWCD, BLM and the landowner near Westfall proposes to remove juniper on 1,040 acres, plant perennial grasses and develop three springs .  Watershed benefits include improved upland vegetation & wildlife habitat, reduced erosion and improved water infiltration and streamflows.  OWEB funds are requested for personnel (4%), juniper removal (55%), seeding (9%), spring development (20%), fencing (2%) and administration (10%).  Cost-share partners are the landowner, USFWS, ODFW and NRCS.

Morrow County, traditionally a small-grain producing area, typically follows winter wheat/summer fallow rotation.  The applicant is seeking an $8.50/acre incentive to implement new chlorophyll-sensor equipped sprayers to reduce the amount of pesticide used in a small grain, direct-seed system.  Watershed benefits are improved water quality and reduced erosion.  OWEB funds are requested for equipment rental (90%) and administration (10%).  Costshare partners are OSU Extension and participating growers.

Located near Enterprise, this project proposes to develop nine upland water sources, treat 25 chronic sediment sources, cage 50 residual native shrubs and modify 41 instream structures.  Watershed benefits include improved water quality, instream habitat, riparian condition and fish passage for threatened steelhead.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (9%), spring developments (22%), fencing (7%), sediment reduction/instream structures (46%), administration (8%) and monitoring (8%).

Located near Twickenham, this project will improve irrigation efficiency through the installation of a pivot and the installation of 4,760' mainline, leasing .3 cfs back into the John Day.  Tree planting will occur along the riparian area.  Water quality, quantity and riparian habitat will improve.  OWEB funds are requested for engineering (34%), plant materials (21%), pipe (30%), pivot pad (4%) and administration (10%). Cost-share partners are EQIP and the landowner.

A low-efficiency irrigation system will be replaced with two high-efficiency low-pressure pivot irrigation systems, resulting in significant water savings to the John Day.  A pump structure will replaced a push-dam diversion.  Watershed benefits include improved water quality, quantity and fish habitat.  OWEB funds are requested for engineering/project management (10%), pipe installation (81%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners include EQIP, CREP and the landowner.

Project Name: Reducing Environmental Impact Through Precision Agriculture
Project Summary: This project will offer an incentive to growers in Umatilla County to use technology that promotes more efficient use of agricultural fertilizers while reducing environmental impacts.   This precision agriculture includes soil condition mapping, zonal soil sampling and application of fertilizer using variable rate applicators.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (9%), grower incentive (80%), outreach/computer program (2%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners include NRCS, OSU Extension, Columbia Basin Ag Research Center and growers.

Project components include two solar pumps installed in two wells, development of a spring,  pipeline and  troughs and fenced collection ponds in Willow Creek drainage near Ironside.  These wells provide livestock and wildlife water on 3,000 acres.  Watershed benefits include improved water quality, upland vegetation and wildlife water sources for elk, deer and sage grouse.  OWEB funds are requested for SWCD personnel/engineering (21%), solar pumps/panels (50%), fence materials (6%), pipe/tanks/trough (17%), administration (2%) and monitoring (4%).  Cost-share partners include NRCS, ODFW, USFWS and the landowner.

This project proposes to install six barbs, slope the bank and plant 150 plants along Bully Creek to stabilize the bank and reduce streambank erosion.  Grade-control structures will be installed to control three headcuts occurring at the irrigation return-flow sites and off-stream water will be provided to reduce impacts to the riparian area.  OWEB funds are requested for engineering/project management (10%), stream work (46%), off-stream water (27%), headgate (6%), seed (2%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners include the landowners, Malheur SWCD and NRCS.

Approximately 400 acres of juniper will be selectively removed and riparian vegetation and native grasses will reseed naturally on this project located in upper Willow Creek drainage.  Watershed benefits include improved riparian vegetation, reduced soil erosion and improved wildlife habitat.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (4%), juniper removal (85%) and administration (10%).  The landowner is the cost-share partner.

Located near Stanfield, the goal of this project is to convert two parcels (39 total acres) from flood irrigation to sprinkler.  Watershed benefits include improved water quality, reduced erosion and overland flow and improved water quantity.  OWEB funds are requested for personnel (2%), electrical (26%), pump station (20%), PVC mainline (25%), handline/wheelines (18%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners are the landowners and Umatilla SWCD.

This project proposes to install 12 barbs within .5 miles of Jordan Creek, install a 2,200' exclosure fence and to plant 850 trees/shrubs.  Planting will be done by Jordan Valley High School and local residents and will include wildlife and riparian vegetation. Watershed benefits are decreased erosion and sediment loading, improved riparian conditions and improved wildlife habitat.  OWEB funds are requested for project management/engineering (11%), rock work/barbs (51%), bank sloping (28%) and administration/sign (10%).  Cost-share partners are local residents, NRCS, Malheur SWCD, USFWS and Jordan Valley High School.

Project Name: Williams Dairy Heifer Raising Partial Relocation
Project Summary: Located in the Walla Walla basin, this project will relocate 7 CAFO pens away from Little Mud Creek, install fencing and a water supply system and restore 75 acres and 1 mile of riparian and wetland habitat.  The pens are located along a fish-sensitive tributary.  Watershed benefits are improved water quality and fish, riparian, wetland and instream habitat.  OWEB funds are requested for personnel (2%), concrete pad (41%), feeding berm (3%), fencing (36%), water supply system (9%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners are landowners, Umatilla SWCD and NRCS.

Located in the Powder basin near North Powder, three ponds will be constructed to provide clean water, improve livestock distribution, provide fire-fighting water and offstream water for livestock.  Watershed benefits include decreased erosion, improved upland vegetation and wildlife cover.  OWEB funds are requested for equipment rental (62%), materials (33%) and administration (5%).  Cost-share partners are National Wild Turkey Federation, ODFW and the landowners.

A 10-acre wetland will be constructed using water from the Allendale collection drain, which flows directly into the Snake River.  The wetland will decompose residual chemical runoff laden with pesticides, nitrogen and phosphorous and reduce E. coli transport.  Watershed benefits include improved water quality and will provide waterfowl and upland gamebird habitat.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (2%), pond construction (36%), plantings (21%), waterwheel/pipeline (31%), administration (9%) and monitoring (1%).  Cost-share partners are ODFW, BOR, Malheur SWCD, landowners and USFWS.

Project Name: Natural Resources WS Education Through Science Inquiry
Project Summary: The project proposes to continue and expand the natural resource education program for the 2005/2006 academic year. Eighty on-site delivery days will be provided to local schools. The curriculum is delivered through a mobile classroom and encompasses both the physical and life sciences in its approach.

This project proposes to develop an outdoor classroom facility in Palmerton Park along Evans Creek in the Rogue Basin. Story boards will be installed that discuss the importance of watersheds and the watershed approach. The facility would be used by the Seven Basins Watershed Council, the Rogue River School District and the general public.

Project Name: Reducing Non-Point Pollution from Charity Car Washes
Project Summary: The Oregon Environmental Council is seeking funding to partner with local jurisdictions and charity carwash organizers to develop and implement preferred best management practices to reduce non-point source pollution from charity carwash events.  The projected environmental outcome is a reduction in suspended sediments and phosphorous, as well as other pollutants, discharged into the lower Willamette from summertime charity carwashes.  OWEB funds will be used for personnel (program director), travel, supplies/materials, production costs, equipment and administration.

Project Name: After-School WS Education (W3 & Restoration Wed. Programs)
Project Summary: This proposal requests funding for an after-school watershed education (Wildlife, Watersheds and What-Not), a 90-hour, 2-terms per year course for 7-12th grade students taught by natural resource professionals.  The intent and focus of the program is to engage 7-12th grade youth in hands-on and contextual learning related to forestry, watershed, and other natural resource education opportunities not available through traditional secondary education, through the enrichment and/or establishment of after school natural resource science and watershed related programs. OWEB funds will be used for personnel, travel, contracted services, supplies/materials, production costs, equipment, and administration.

Project Name: Cartakers of the Enviornment International Conference Legacy
Project Summary: This proposal requests funding to allow approximately 300-400 student delegates from the YES '05  International Conference to participate in a conference legacy planting project.  About 3000 native plants, trees and shrubs will be planted on 3 acres in the greater Salem area.  OWEB funds will be used for personnel, travel, contracted services, and supplies/materials.

Project Name: Evaluation & Demonstration of Drip Irrigation in Orchards
Project Summary: This project would demonstrate water savings and reduced contamination of nitrogen loading of streams affected by 10,000 acres of orchards in the Hood River basin.  Stream flow enhancement is identified as a need to improve salmonids during rearing and other life-stages in the 1999 Hood River Watershed Assessment.

While there has been progress in educating people about why conservation and backyard habitat are important, there seems to be a lack of practical application.  This project proposes to conduct three 2 hour workshops on mapping, designing and planting a basic conservation landscape in the southern and northern portions of Wasco County.

This project in Klamath County will continue to offer classes in the Master Watershed Stewards Program, conduct educator workshops on existing watershed function curriculums, coordinate watershed/wetland field days for elementary students and continue contributions to the OSU Extension monthly newsletter.

The Northwest Youth Corps is proposing to initiate a Watershed Enhancement Youth Corps (WEYC) modeled on its State Parks Corps. The WEYC program incorporates service learning and hands-on conservation work. The project will directly support the operation of a WEYC crew for 15 weeks as they complete restoration projects in each of OWEB's five regions from April to October 2005. OWEB funds are requested for wages, vehicle usage, taxes, insurance, monitoring travel costs, and administration.

The application requests funds to acquire 10 acres adjacent to an existing city park along South Depoe Bay Creek at the southeast corner of Depoe Bay harbor.  The property contains a _ mile of stream and benefits the following priorities: floodplain lowland riparian, lowland riparian woodland and shrubland, and tidally influenced freshwater wetlands.

The project would remove four undersized culverts which currently pass Conyers Creek under a street in the City of Clatskanie, and replace them with a 64-foot long bridge. The majority of OWEB funds (82%) would be used for bridge materials and construction costs.

This project would plant 1,300 conifers and several hundred native shrubs on four separate landowners properties. The four properties lie along four different streams in Clatsop County. The majority of OWEB funds are budgeted for project management (26%), site preparation and two years of tree release (22%), plants and supplies (18%) and two years of monitoring (18%).

Ivy would be removed from 15 acres of remnant estuarine spruce forest in the Neawanna system if this project were implemented, and infestations of Scotch Broom and Himalayan Blackberry in the same area would also be removed. The area would be replanted with native conifer and shrubs and tree release activities would occur for two years. The majority of OWEB funds (65%) would be used for clearing and planting activities while 8% is budgeted for materials and another 8% for equipment.
This project proposes to exclude livestock from 1.2 miles of North Myrtle Creek and restore native riparian vegetation. Bank erosion will be addressed at six sites using bioengineering techniques.
This project proposes to replace two fish passage blocking culverts and will open up one mile of habitat for coho, steelhead and resident trout species.

Project Name: W Fork Trail Cr Culver Replacement For Fish Passage
Project Summary: This project proposes to replace an undersized culvert with a bridge. The project will improve fish passage for six miles for coho and nine miles for steelhead.

Project Name: W Fork Williams Cr Salmonid Habitat Restoration
Project Summary: The project proposes to place large woody debris instream to improve habitat complexities and rearing habitats for coho, chinook and steelhead.
The project proposes to revegetate 450 acres of riparian habitat that experienced high intensity fire in 2002. The area supports coho, steelhead and resident trout species.

Project Name: Fitton Green Cr Fish Passage & Habitat Restoration
Project Summary: This project proposes to improve two culvert crossings, as well as an abandoned bridge crossing, on Fitton Green Creek, a tributary to Marys River.  This stream is located within a natural resource conservation area.  Currently, both culverts are barriers to fish passage and the low water ford stream crossing is causing accelerated erosion and sediment delivery to the stream. The existing perched culverts will be removed and replaced with bridges and the stream channel will be relocated to its original, historic location.  A new bridge will replace the low water, stream crossing ford.  This project will create about two miles of good quality upstream tributary fish habitat.  OWEB funds would be used for personnel (engineer, surveyors, supervisor, and laborers), contracted services, supplies/materials and administration.

This application proposes to implement a two-year riparian restoration project in the Molalla River riparian corridor.  The restoration will significantly improve the riparian area and adjacent upland conditions, benefiting fish and wildlife habitat and water quality.  Projects will focus on controlling accelerated erosion and sediment delivery, reducing nonpoint source pollution, improving stream bank stability through riparian planting and invasive species control.  OWEB funds will be used for pre-implementation costs (design, permits), personnel, travel, contracted services, education/outreach, administration, and monitoring.

This project proposes to enhance in-stream structures and channel complexity, and plant native trees and shrubs for enhancing water quality and fish and wildlife habitat on 16 acres including approximately 6,000 lineal feet on Crystal Springs Creek.  Crystal Springs is an important spring fed tributary to the lower Johnson Creek.  Crystal Springs Creek is identified as a priority restoration area in the Johnson Creek Watershed Action Plan, and is important as cool water refuge for juvenile salmonid rearing and productivity.  OWEB funds will be used for personnel, contracted services, supplies/materials, and education/outreach.

Project Name: Coos County Roads Sediment Risk Inventory
Coos Lowland and Heads-of Tide Project Development
Alsea WS Fish Passage Inventory & Assessment
Middle Stephens Cr Riparian Habitat Restoration
Project Summary: This project proposes to restore 11 acres of riparian area along the mainstem of Stephens Creek.  Stephens Creek is a small tributary to the Lower Willamette River.  Project objectives include the removal of invasive non-native vegetation and replanting with native herbaceous grass and forbs, followed by native trees and shrubs to increase riparian function and provide for additional stream shade.  OWEB funds will be used for contracted services, supplies/materials, and education/outreach.

Project Name: Woods Cr Basin Fish Passage Rstoration
Project Summary: This project proposes to correct impaired fish passage at 8 stream crossings in the Woods Creek subwatershed.  The existing culverts will be replaced with oversized, countersunk pipe-arch culverts providing access to over 5.3 miles of good, cutthroat trout habitat.  The Woods Creek subwatershed has been identified by ODFW as one of their highest priority basins for cutthroat.  OWEB funds will be used for pre-implementation costs, personnel (project manager, outreach coordinator), travel, contracted services, supplies/materials, education/outreach and administration.

Project Name: Urban Riparian & Wetland Restoration at Fulton Park
Project Summary: This project proposes to restore 4.5 acres of urban riparian area and wetlands in a public park managed by the City of Portland, along a tributary to Stephens Creek.  The project focuses on removing non-native invasive plant species and restoring native tree and shrub communities that enhance both water quality and wildlife habitat.   OWEB funds will be used for contracted services, supplies/materials and education/outreach.

Project Name: Watkins Sprague River Channel & Wetland Restoration
Project Summary: This project just downriver from the community of Sprague River, would plug two cut-off channels that are threatening to capture the main flow of the Sprague River and thus cut off two meanders, shortening the river and increasing velocities and streambank erosion.  Funds from OWEB make up 40% of the project.

Project Name: Winding Sprague River Channel & Wetland Restoration
Project Summary: This project would plug two cut-off channels that divert 750 cfs from the main channels of the Sprague River that prevent bankfull flows from accessing the floodplain.  Without the ability to dissipate the energy of bankfull flows, banks are eroded, water quality is impaired and fish habitat is reduced.  OWEB funds constitute 24% of the project and would be used for heavy equipment operation to shape streambanks and block the cut-off channels.

Project Name: Mike Love Sprague River Channel & Wetland Restoration
Project Summary: This project would block two cut-off channels that threaten to take all the water from the existing meandering channel which would result in higher velocities, increase bank erosion, lower water quality and less habitat for the listed Lost River and shortnose sucker fish.  OWEB funds would be used for heavy equipment operation and constitute 27% of the overall project costs.

This project would restore fish passage, screen two diversions, improve water management and restore upland pasture as part of a project to protect riparian areas on one half mile of Cottonwood Creek, a tributary to Thomas Creek in the Goose Lake Basin.  There are several state listed sensitive fish species in the creek.  The OWEB funds requested make up 75% of the project costs and would be used for materials and construction.

This project proposes to replace 58 irrigation diversion structures located throughout the 13.5 mile main ditch system to reduce irrigation demands on the upper Williamson River in the Klamath Basin.  This should increase flows by 2.86 cfs.  OWEB funds comprise 39% of the total project costs.

This project would purchase and install a 24 inch diameter pipeline 6,960 feet to operate a fish ladder and screen on the Lost and Boulder District Improvement Company diversion.  The project would save 5 cfs of water currently being lost through seepage in a diversion ditch and use 1 cfs to operate the fish screen and ladder and the remaining conserved water would add to the irrigation district flows.  OWEB funds would be used for 75% of the project costs.

This is a three year project where irrigation practices and crop needs will be monitored the first year in the Ochoco Irrigation District (Crook County), the second year scientific irrigation scheduling and system efficiencies will be utilized, and the third year willing producers will voluntarily enter into a water-market lease consistent with irrigation district, state and federal policy.  OWEB funds represent 15% of the project costs.

The Grande Ronde River near La Grande will have improved habitat and fish passage through streambank and channel improvements.  Project components include seven rock cross-vane weirs, nine J-hook structures, 18 rock-vanes, 57 bank protection revetments, 2,200 feet of channel reshaping, 3,400 feet of bank lay-back and extensive revegetation.  Overall project implementation will lead to improved water quality, fish passage and watershed health.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services (96%) and monitoring (4%).  Cost-share partners include Army Corps of Engineers and DEQ.

The project protects the grasslands of Hells Canyon including the Snake, Imnaha, and Lower Grande Ronde rivers from invasion and degradation by noxious weeds using integrated pest management.  Proposed treatment includes 125 acres of high priority treatment, 20 acres of revegetation, 20 sites for bio-control releases, biological control monitoring and education materials.  Watershed benefits include improved upland conditions and improved water quality.  OWEB funds are requested for personnel/travel (10%), survey (16%), restoration/ground treatment (50%), educationa/outreach (7%), backcountry travel (3%), administration (9%), monitoring (5%).  Cost-share partners are Vale District BLM and WallaWalla Ranger District.

Project Name: Dry Gulch Off-Stream Watering & WQ Improvement
Project Summary: This project will improve water quality by removing access for 350 head of cattle by installing 7,920 feet of mainline, 13,200 feet of fencing, 11 troughs and 15 acres of riparian planting.  Watershed benefits included improved water quality, improved vegetation, wildlife habitat and stream shading.  OWEB funds are requested for project management/engineering (24%), excavation (26%), fencing (10%), pipe (24%), troughs (11%) and administration (4%).  Cost-share partners include NRCS and the landowners.

Project Name: Baker Valley Early Intervention Juniper Control
Project Summary: Watershed conditions on upland rangelands and riparian areas will be improved by treating 550 acres of juniper, seeding 550 acres and developing two springs. Watershed benefits include improved vegetative conditions, increased soil conditions and improved water quality. OWEB funds are requested for project management/engineering (7%), juniper control (52%), fencing (7%), seed (20%), spring development (6%) and administration (7%). Landowners are the cost share partner.

Located near Baker City, this wildlife habitat restoration project will consist of both wetland and upland plant communities designed to provide optimum habitat for a variety of wildlife.   A 10.6 acre pond will be fenced; bitterbrush, the uplands will be planted with sagebrush and rabbitbrush and seeded with native species such as bluebunch wheatgrass, Idaho fescue and Great Basin wildrye.  Watershed benefits are improved wildlife habitat and water quality.  OWEB funds are requested for engineering (12%), equipment mobilization and rental (76%), seeding and planting (8%) and administration (4%).  The landowner are cost share partner.

Located southwest of Boardman, this project proposes to install 6,300 feet of pipe to replace an outdated leaking irrigation system.  Watershed benefits include decreased water use in Willow Creek and conserving energy in the Willow Creek watershed.  Implementation follows the Willow Creek Agriculture Water Quality Management Plan (AWQMP).  OWEB funds are requested for electrical (10%), materials including pipe, pump station, water box, pump and pivots (80%) and administration/monitoring (10%).  Willow Farms LLC is the cost-share partner.

Project Name: Installing AgriMet in Southern Umatilla Co
Project Summary: The project proposes to purchase, install and manage an agricultural weather station in Birch and McKay creeks.  The purpose of monitoring climate, precipitation and soil conditions is an effort to maximize irrigation efficiency and minimize negative impact to water quality and quantity.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (20%), AgriMet Station (50%), education/outreach (9%), administration (9%) and monitoring (12%).  Cost-share partners include OSU Extension Service and the landowner.

Located near Milton-Freewater, _ mile of Cottonwood Creek will be improved to increase the production of ESA-listed summer steelhead and redband trout. Project components include 5 cross-vanes, 4 large woody debris jams, 2 rootwad revetments, riparian planting, stream channel reconstruction, 2 off-stream water developments and riparian fencing.  Watershed benefits include reduced erosion, improved water quality, and fish habitat and increased fish production.  OWEB funds are requested for equipment rental (34%), materials (57%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners include CTUIR, ODFW, and the landowner.

Located near Hermiston, this project proposes to utilize the Westland Irrigation District canal during periods of excess winter and spring flows on the Umatilla River.  Water will be supplied to an existing aggregate pit to recharge the shallow alluvial aquifer.  Watershed benefits include restoring natural functioning processes, cooling the Umatilla River with cool groundwater and provide refugia for migratory and resident fish.  OWEB funds are requested for stream measurements (17%), drilling (7%), lab analysis (6%), water delivery (39%), equipment (3%), monitoring (28%).  Cost-share partners include Umatilla County,  the consultant and laboratory testing.

Located near Keating, the Big Creek Ditch will abandon and fill 10,200 feet of earthen ditch and install 7,400 feet of 12-inch pipeline and appurtenances to provide service to the users.  Watershed benefits include improved water quality, enhanced vegetative growth, and reduced erosion.  OWEB funds are requested for engineering (7%), equipment rental/installation (17%), materials- pipe, outlet, fill (73%) and administration (3%).  Cost-share partner is the Big Creek Ditch Company.

This project proposes to install six barbs, three weirs, slope the bank and plant 200 plants along Bully Creek to stabilize the bank and reduce streambank erosion.  Grade-control structures will be installed to control three headcuts occurring at the return-flow sites and off-stream water will be provided to reduce impacts to the riparian area.  OWEB funds are requested for engineering/project management (16%), equipment rental and installation (44%), materials (31%)  and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners include the landowners and NRCS.

Located near Adrian, the project proposes to install 25,500 feet of PVC in two irrigation laterals and four settling ponds.  The laterals serve five local farms on 460 acres.  Watershed benefits include improved water quality, reduce chemical and sediment inputs and improve wildlife habitat.  OWEB funds are requested for SWCD personnel/engineering (5%), PVC (61%), materials (21%), flow meters (8%) and administration (3%).  Cost-share partners include BOR, South Board of Control, and Malheur SWCD.

The Lower Columbia River Watershed Council requests $24,150 for the planning, design and engineering involved in the replacement of 4 undersized culverts with a modular bridge system in the city of Clatskanie; at a single site on Conyers Creek, a tributary of the Clatskanie River. OWEB funds will be used for project management (4%), geotechnical engineering (37%), survey (12%) and design (41%).

Project Name: Engineering Design for Re-establishment of Reneke Cr Channel
Project Summary: The Nestucca Neskowin Watershed Council would use $24,200 of OWEB funds to pay for the production of permit-ready designs for two culvert replacements and the reconstruction of Reneke Creeks historic channel. Of the requested OWEB funds, 90% would be used to produce those plans and designs. A small amount would be used for project management and $700 would be spent on brush clearing to enable the initial surveys to occur.

Project Name: Jumpoff Joe Cr Bio-Engineering Technical Design
Project Summary: Under this proposal the services of a certified civil engineer will be retained for the development and drafting of a working bio-technical design for stream bank erosion control and channel modification along Jumpoff Joe Creek.

Project Name: Roberts Cr & S Fork Deer Cr Conservation Planning
Project Summary: The project proposes to design Grazing Management Plans for several large acreage ranches. Included will be riparian buffer restoration prescriptions, stock watering systems, weed management, fencing plans and stream bank protection designs.

Project Name: Willow Cr Confluence Restoration Scoping & Budgeting
Project Summary: This proposal will contract with an accredited water resources firm to analyze the benefits and develop a conceptual design and budget for restoring the historic channels of the west and east forks of Willow Creek.  The scope of work includes all anticipated submittal requirements, a review of the historic and existing hydrologic and hydraulic parameters, a fluvial geomorphic investigation, identification of all potential project elements and data gaps, a summary of the necessary legal requirements (NEPA, permits), assembly of possible alternatives, evaluation of the costs/benefits of alternatives, as well as the value and function of restoring the system.  OWEB funds will be used for contracted services and administration.

This project proposes to develop a hydrologic and hydraulic model of the drainages within the Sauvie Island Drainage Improvement Company territory, including alternative evaluations to improve hydraulics, improve water quality and wildlife habitat, leading to potential wetland and riparian restoration sites.  OWEB funds will be used for contracted services and administration.

Project Name: Luckiamute WS Winter Steelhead Fish Passage Survey
Project Summary: This proposal will identify high priority restoration opportunities through a fish passage, habitat inventory, and fish population survey within five sub-basins in the Luckiamute watershed.  A technical team will prioritize the fish passage barriers in 42 miles of stream and produce a list of the highest priority restoration projects, along with cost estimates and property owners.  OWEB funds will be used for contracted services, travel, production costs and administration.

Project Name: Upper McKay Cr Flow Study & Restoration Design
Project Summary: McKay Creek in Crook County is the priority area for habitat improvement for the re-introduction of steelhead in the Crooked River sub-basin.  This project would determine stream flows and water needs for instream and consumptive uses to assess streamflow restoration opportunities.

Project Name: USFS Road 4600-930, Chesnimnus Cr Crossing Design
Project Summary: Technical assistance is requested to design a bridge or open-bottom arch culvert to replace the present culvert where a USFS road crosses Chesnimnus Creek.  The existing culvert is perched during late-season flows and blocks passage of juvenile steelhead.  Funds are requested for project management (10%), design engineering (83%), design printing (3%) and administration (3%).  The USFS is the other funding partner.

Project Name: Wallowa Lake Dam Replacement - Final Engineering
Project Summary: Technical assistance is requested to complete the engineering evaluation and design to support a fish trapping facility at the base of Wallowa Lake dam, screen the intake tower and develop design details of the future hydropower facility at a future date.  The Nez Perce Tribe has future plans to trap migrating salmon at the base of the dam.  OWEB funds are requested for final engineering (96%) and administration (4%).  The Associated Ditch Company is the cost-share partner.

The project will direct outreach to landowners in the Lower South Fork Coos River area with the goal of providing knowledge and participation in strategic restoration programs. Outreach will be delivered through a series of community coffee-klatches regarding current sub-basin conditions and restoration opportunities.

Project Name: Youth Natural Science Program, OSU Extention Jackson County
Project Summary: The project proposes to partner with over 20 local agencies and organizations to increase awareness of local natural resources and the interconnectedness of watershed ecosystems through after-school activities, educator trainings, special events and watershed educations kits. The program is intended to reach over 3,500 rural and urban youth with an emphasis on drawing Latino participants.

Spawning Watershed Education III is a landowner, student and teacher education program within the McKenzie watershed designed to improve watershed health.  This program focuses on key concerns of riparian function, water quality and fish and wildlife habitat.  This program is in its third year and strives to improve knowledge of its stakeholders through multiple education strategies including teacher workshops, classroom presentations/field trips, restoration tours and community presentations.  OWEB funds will be used for personnel, travel, supplies/materials, administration, production costs, equipment, and monitoring.

Project Name: Magness Memorial Tree Farm Forestry/WS Ed Program
Project Summary: This project proposes to offer a hands-on environmental education program at a demonstration tree farm near Wilsonville.  Water quality and watershed health are major concepts in the program, with thousands of students every year learning about the connection between forest health and the stream system. OWEB funds will be used for personnel, travel, contracted services, supplies/materials and production costs.

The goal of this project is to improve teacher knowledge about pressing urban watershed issues and expose them to partnership resources they can leverage to take this knowledge into the classrooms.  Teacher workshops are a means to improve teacher knowledge about issues that impact their schools, students and the community at large.  OWEB funds will be used for contracted services and production costs.

Project Name: Building Cultural Diversity for Future WS Workforce
Project Summary: This project will target high school students from diverse cultural backgrounds to participate in vocational opportunities within Portlands six watersheds. Portland Parks staff will mentor students in work situations that focus on watershed education, ecological restoration, planning, native plant production and community stewardship events with the purpose of exposing diverse work responsibilities for students future employment considerations. OWEB funds would be used for personnel.

This project proposes a series of three day workshops in the Luckiamute and Ash Creek watersheds that teach adult stakeholders to write personal essays that focus on their present and past experiences in the watershed.  The essays will be published in a book and workshop curriculum will be developed that can be used in other watersheds.  OWEB funds will be used for travel, contracted services, supplies/materials, production costs, equipment and administration.

This program will increase the knowledge and skills of college and high school students by providing technical and educational coordination and support to teachers involved in long-term base line monitoring and watershed education in the Portland metropolitan area.  The goal is to enable these students to develop an awareness of watershed and stream health, knowledge of stream ecosystems and their relationship to the larger watershed, and skills in water quality analysis, data analysis and interpretation of then results.  OWEB funds will be used for personnel, travel, contracted services, supplies/materials, production costs and administration.

Project Name: Tri-County Japanese Knotweek Outreach & Ed Program
Project Summary: This project proposes to fund a contractor to conduct Japanese knotweed education and outreach on a basin-wide landscape level that will lead to landowners treating knotweed on their property and restoring native riparian vegetation, in the Calapooia, North and South Santiam watersheds.  OWEB funds will be used for travel, production costs, equipment and administration.

This education program is a partnership of the Rickreall and Glenn-Gibson watershed councils and the Polk SWCD to increase knowledge and understanding of basic watershed principles and the practices and behaviors that will help protect, enhance and restore watershed function.  OWEB funds will be used for travel, contracted services, production costs, equipment and administration.

This project will lead to workshop training for landowners on riparian silviculture, fish passage and screening, off-stream watering, spring management and juniper management.  Two watershed education workshops per year using widely accepted curricula will be conducted along with teacher trainings and classroom presentations.

Project Name: Waste Water to Wetlands Interpretive Signage
Project Summary: Once the constructed wetland adjacent to Lake Billy Chinook in Jefferson County is in operation, this project would construct and install five interpretive signs along a trail to inform visitors how the wetland functions.

This project would make use of current technology to demonstrate maximum irrigation efficiencies to individual landowners who collectively irrigate 150,000 acres in the Upper Deschutes River basin.  Current efficiencies average about 55 - 65%.  The project is designed to lead to production savings and reduced water usage with the potential to increase instream flows.

Project Name: Creating a Sustainable Future for Fish, Water, & People
Project Summary: This project would train the trainers in consensus seeking and collaborative problem solving.  Community leaders, agency representatives and business leaders will learn using the economic, social and environmental issues facing the Hood and Deschutes River Basins.

Project Name: Evalation/Demonstration of Drip Irrigation in Orchard Crops
Project Summary: This project will demonstrate that drip irrigation can substantially reduce water consumption by orchard trees, lower nutrient and pesticide leaching from orchards down to groundwater and improve tree fruit yield and quality.  To be conducted in the Hood River basin, the results will be distributed throughout the Northwest.

Project Name: U Grande Ronde Pond Development Demonstration & Promotion
Project Summary: Union SWCD is proposing to conduct a demonstration project to promote using ponds to help to improve livestock distribution.  The target audience is ranchers in far eastern Oregon.   Instructional goals are to improve riparian grazing management and streambank vegetation.  OWEB funds are requested for watershed technician (47%), brochures (29%), tours (19%) and administration (5%).  ODA is the cost-share partner.

Project Name: Building Knowledge in Watershed Restoration Principals
Project Summary: In partnership with the Oregon Commission for Voluntary Action and Service, The Nature Conservancy proposes to recruit 30 interns over three years to enhance their knowledge of watershed restoration principles. Cross-training will focus on three areas: 1) watershed restoration planning and administration,  2) research and monitoring, and 3) field methods. All interns will be placed in regional offices of The Nature Conservancy to work directly on watershed assessment and restoration projects. Interns will work under the direction of local professionals and will be linked with staff in partner organizations. Objectives are to 1) Increase public engagement in local stewardship activities, 2) increase local and state decision maker support for watershed stewardship activities, and 3) build knowledge and strengthen group problem solving and support.

The Network of Oregon Watershed Councils proposes to increase public, decision maker, and watershed council knowledge using two broad approaches:  1) Provide specific information about watershed function, councils, and watershed restoration to the public and decision makers to increase their participation in and support for restoration efforts throughout the state; and 2) Provide training opportunities for council personnel and members through a combination of formal curriculum, training manual, peer mentorship, and donated in-kind capacity building.

This application proposes to monitor the effectiveness of fish passage through tide gates, both newly installed and older gates, concentrating on juvenile salmonid passage. The majority of the requested OWEB funds are budgeted for two personnel to conduct the netting, collection, measurements and data compilation (84%).
This proposal would set up a baseline GIS database for monitoring of weed control projects within Coos County.

This project would continue the water quality monitoring program in the Lower Umpqua watershed area. The project focus has been primarily on private agricultural/rural lands and has included an emphasis on conservation management practices and restoration effectiveness monitoring.

Project Name: Best Practices Guidelines for Wetland Restoration Projects
Project Summary: This monitoring project is intended to inform restoration practitioners, fish and wildlife managers and regulatory personnel of compatible project design and management of wetland restoration projects with respect to juvenile salmon use and passage capability/opportunity using recently collected data.  OWEB funds will be used for contracted services and administration.

Project Name: S Fork Mill Cr Steelhead Video Count
Project Summary: Migrating steelhead will be digitally video recorded and counted as they pass up the fish ladder of the Wicks Water Treatment Plant on Mill Creek.  Mill Creek flows northeast about 16 miles from the foothills of the Cascade Mountains to the Columbia River at the city of The Dalles.

Project Name: Groundwater Budget & Model for Mosier Valley
Project Summary: This project would provide support to allow the US Geological Survey and local SWCD personnel to continue monitoring water use and movement in the Mosier aquifer.  The aquifer water levels have been dropping since the 1970s.  Mosier Creek is now losing water as it flows through the area where it previously gained water from springs.

Oregon Water Trust (OWT) would like to install seven continuous recorders to monitor streamflow to see if instream flows are being met in OWTs priority basins.  OWEB funds are requested for personnel/travel (38%), stilling wells (3%), equipment (49%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners include OWT, Columbia Basin Water Transaction and National Fish & Wildlife Foundation.

Project Name: North & Middle Forks Research, Monitoring & Evaluation
Project Summary: The applicant proposes to provide a venue where regional and local monitoring efforts can be integrated and progress made toward a John Day basin-wide monitoring strategy to answer population-level questions and continue and expand water quality status and trend monitoring within the basin at sites identified by basin partners.  OWEB funds are requested for personnel (86%), travel (2%), supplies (3%) and administration (9%).   Other cost-share partners include Monument SWCD, NFJD WSC and NMFS.

Project Name: Grande Ronde Basin Gauging Station Monitoring Water Y 06-07
Project Summary: Five permanent, continuous recording stream gauging stations will be operated and maintained for the 2006-2007 water years.  The stations are strategically located throughout the upper Grande Ronde Subbasin on USFS lands.  These stations are being monitoring and the annual report developed by the watermaster using USGS specifications.  OWEB funds are requested for gauging station monitoring (91%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners include USFS, CTUIR and Grande Ronde Model Watershed Program (GRMWP).

This monitoring project consists of monthly field collection of water samples to be sent to an approved lab for analysis on 10 separate parameters.  Previous monitoring was done at six locations.  Parameters to be analyzed include E. coli, nitrates, phosphates, ammonia, chlorophyll-a, suspended solids, temperature, conductivity, TKN and turbidity.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (3%), sampling contractor (91%) and administration (6%).  Cost-share partners include BOR, Malheur WSC, ODA and OSU Malheur Experiment Station.

The application requests funds for the applicant to acquire a 253 acre parcel within the Columbia River estuary between Astoria and Knappa.  This project addresses the following priority ecological systems:  Freshwater emergent marsh, Freshwater mudflats, Intertidal freshwater wetlands, and Lowland riparian woodland and shrubland.  This area of the estuary is known to provide critical rearing and refugia habitat for juvenile salmonids.

This multi-component restoration project would place a minimum of 9 large wood structures along a 2,000 foot stream reach, pull two shotgun style undersized culverts, plant a variety of native species of trees and shrubs in 1.5 acres of riparian corridor and 0.25 acres of wetland in a tributary sub-basin of Gods Valley Creek. Roughly 75% of the requested OWEB funds are budgeted for heavy equipment and planting and brushing activities.

Roughly 30 large wood structures would be placed into a 3,260 foot reach of a key tributary (Trib A) of Gods Valley Creek with this project. Of the requested OWEB funds 76% are budgeted for labor and equipment to place the logs.

This proposal would partially fund two years of work to control or eradicate knotweed, an invasive species threatening to dominate the riparian zones, in five key tributaries of the Siuslaw River and two tribs of the Coastal Lakes basin. Of the requested OWEB funds 51% are budgeted for a licensed herbicide applicator and another 30% is budgeted for project management.

This application proposes to replace an existing bridge that marginally spans a slough in Tillamook Bay with a longer one, thereby elevating the bridge above the level of extreme high tides and floodwaters. Cattle and farm equipment use the bridge to access an island. The bridge also supports a manure pipeline out to the island. Of the requested OWEB funds 87% are budgeted for preparation and installation of the bridge.

The project would remove four undersized culverts located at one site, which currently pass Conyers Creek under a street in the City of Clatskanie, and replace them with a 64-foot long bridge. Of the OWEB funds 38% would be used for bridge materials, 28% for construction costs and 25% on design/engineering and surveys.
The project proposes to replace two partial fish barriers with culverts and help restore instream habitat complexity through placement of rock and log structures and wetland restoration.
The project proposes to enhance Fitzpatrick Creek and the Umpqua River through riparian fencing, planting of native conifers and shrubs, noxious weed control and two off channel stock watering sites.
The project proposes to improve fish passage for coho and steelhead at two culvert locations along Jones Creek. Improving fish passage at these two locations will open up one mile of habitat.

The application request funds to purchase a 1.02 acre parcel near the confluence of Johnson Creek and Crystal Springs in southeast Portland.  The project addresses the following priority ecological systems:  freshwater aquatic beds, oak woodland, riparian forests and shrublands, and Western Oregon upland prairie and oak savanna.  The project will allow for restoration of the site and access from the Springwater Corridor Trail to Johnson Creek Park.

Project Name: Lower Willamette River Riparian & Wetland Enhancement
Project Summary: This project will enhance Willamette River shoreline habitat and improve rearing and off-channel refuge habitat for ESA-listed juvenile chinook, coho and steelhead native to the Willamette and Columbia River basins by enhancing riparian and wetland habitat through invasive species removal and revegetation and placement of large woody debris.  OWEB funds will be used for pre-implementation, contracted services, supplies/materials and education/outreach.

This project proposes to enhance in-stream structures and channel complexity, and plant native trees and shrubs for enhancing water quality and fish and wildlife habitat on 16 acres including approximately 6,000 lineal feet on Crystal Springs Creek.  Crystal Springs is an important spring fed tributary to the lower Johnson Creek.  Crystal Springs Creek is identified as a priority restoration area in the Johnson Creek Watershed Action plan, and is important as cool water refuge for juvenile salmonid rearing and productivity.  OWEB funds will be used for personnel, contracted services, supplies/materials, and education/outreach.

This project will stabilize 600 feet of eroding streambank along the mainstem Willamette River using bioengineering, woody debris structures and planting with native vegetation.  Additionally, 27 acres of bottomland riparian habitat will be enhanced by the removal of non-native invasives and replanted with native species and log placement in a 2.5 acre pond to enhance western pond turtle habitat.  OWEB funds will be used for personnel, travel, contracted services, supplies/materials administration and monitoring.

Project Name: Johnson & Errol Cr Confluence Fish Habitat Restoration
Project Summary: This project will create and restore approximately 550 feet of tributary habitat and enhance one acre of surrounding riparian and floodplain habitat at the Errol Creek confluence area by removing two fish passage barriers, increasing instream complexity and site restoration. The project activities will increase the amount and quality of rearing and refuge habitat in Johnson Creek for listed juvenile chinook, steelhead and coho.   OWEB funds will be used for personnel, contracted services, supplies/materials and monitoring.

This project includes restoring and enhancing five acres of riparian area at Johnson Creek Park.  The project includes the placement of large woody debris, removal of invasive plants, installation of native plants and planting maintanence.  OWEB funds will be used for contracted services, supplies/materials, education/outreach and monitoring.

Project Name: Lookout Point Ranch Oak Habitats Restoration & WQ Improvemen
Project Summary: This project requests funding for the restoration of oak savannah, oak-pine and prairie habitat restoration, and improving an improperly constructed power line access road with undersized culverts.  Additionally, a spring area will be restored by removing a diversion structure, excluding cattle and providing an alternative water source for livestock management.  OWEB funds will be used for pre-implementation, personnel, contracted services, supplies/materials, administration and monitoring.

This project would make improvements to reduce erosion in the area near Bullard Creek east of Lakeview.  Uncontrolled access has damaged springs, culverts and unimproved roads leading to water quality degradation in the creek.

This project will work with eight different landowners adjacent to the Sprague or Williamson Rivers to fence off riparian areas, improve armored livestock crossings, develop off-stream watering and plant riparian areas with native woody species.

Project Name: Upper Klamath River Weed Management Area
Project Summary: This project would create the Upper Klamath River Weed Management Area.  The goal is to help irrigation districts and landowners with surveying, mapping, controlling and monitoring noxious weeds along the Klamath Straits Drain and Upper Klamath River systems.

Project Name: North Fork Mill Cr Culvert Removal
Project Summary: This project would remove a culvert fish passage barrier and replace it with a concrete bridge to open up nearly six miles of high quality spawning habitat in the North Fork Mill Creek.  This is part of the threatened Mid-Columbia ESU wild winter steelhead run.

This project would replace the open Badger Irrigation ditch used to divert up to 41cfs with three miles of 30 inch pipe that can only carry 32cfs thus allowing more instream flow in Badger Creek and reducing the risk of ditch failure and sediment dumps into the creek.  The ditch is located in the Badger Creek Wilderness, Mt. Hood National Forest.

Project Name: Solar/Wind Hybrid Off-Stream Stock Water Development
Project Summary: This project would install three solar/wind powered stock water systems at existing wells to provide water for cattle.  This will eliminate the need for cattle to access the riparian areas of Buck Hollow and Grass Valley Creeks in Sherman County.

Located near La Grande, this project will construct two terraces on a field in a wheat/fallow rotation to reduce rill erosion and two spring developments will be constructed to improve livestock distribution.  Watershed benefits include reduced sediment and nutrient transport, reduced soil erosion, improved water infiltration and improve riparian conditions in Mill Creek.  OWEB funds are requested for survey/design (4%), equipment rental (80%), troughs/waterline (8%) and administration (9%).  The landowner is the cost-share partner.

The Malheur National Forest plans to replace four culverts to restore fish passage along 7.8 miles of Butte and Beaver Creeks, which flow into the Middle Fork John Day River on the Oxbow Conservation Area, managed by Confederated Tribes of the Warm Springs Reservation of Oregon (CTWSRO).  The culverts were selected due to the linkage with ongoing habitat work on the John Day.  OWEB funds are requested for materials and contracted services (91%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners include USFS.

Project Name: Combating Leafy Spurge in the Walla Walla Basin
Project Summary: Leafy spurge (Euphorbia esula) is currently spreading in this basin.  This project proposes to pinpoint areas of heaviest infestation; control these sites either chemically or biologically and plant grass seed after the treatments.  Watershed benefits are improved upland vegetation and infiltration.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (27%); contracted services (18%), chemical and seed (42%), advertising (3%), administration (9%) and monitoring (1%).  Cost-share partners include Umatilla County Weed Board, OSU Extension, the landowners and Umatilla SWCD.

Located near Hermiston, this project proposes to divert 45 CFS of excess winter and spring Umatilla River flows to an existing gravel pit to recharge the shallow aquifer.  The elevated water levels in the aquifer will augment late-season flows and the cooler groundwater will reduce river temperatures.  OWEB funds are requested for baseline measurement (16%), drilling monitoring wells (8%), lab analysis (6%), water delivery (39%), equipment (3%) and monitoring (28%).  Cost-share partners include Umatilla County, Westland Irrigation District and the consultant.

Located north of Enterprise this project replaces a culvert at Summit Creek which is a barrier to juvenile steelhead with a open-bottom arch to open 1.2 miles of habitat.  At Doe Creek, the current will be removed and replaced with an open-bottom arch and the gabion structures below will be removed.  Watershed benefits include improved fish habitat and passage.  OWEB funds are requested for engineering/project management (3%), excavation and construction (95%) and administration (2%).  Cost-share partners include BPA and NOAA/American Rivers.

Located on Service Creek approximately 3.3 miles upstream from its confluence with the John Day, this project replaces a double culvert, which is prone to failure and is a fish-passage barrier with a modular steel bridge. The culverts create a partial fish passage barrier during most flows and the erosion behind the culverts creates a jump barrier. This is the last fish-passage barrier on the salmonid reaches of Service Creek.  Watershed benefits include improved fish passage and habitat and water quality.  OWEB funds are requested for engineering/project management (11%), equipment rental (23%), bridge components (58%), and administration and monitoring (8%).  Cost-share partners are USFWS and the landowners.

Located near Adrian, this project will create a 15 acre constructed wetland to filter 3-4 CFS of agricultural drainwater that drains directly into the Snake River.  The first pond will cover 2.1 acres designed to filter nitrates and sediment; the second pond is 5.9 acres and will clean out phosphates as well as provide wildlife habitat and the third pond will be 5.9 acres and complete the treatment of phosphates. OWEB funds are requested for engineering/project management (5%), contracted services for pond construction and structures (70%), materials (plants structures) (20%) and administration (5%).  Cost-share partners are the landowners, NRCS, Malheur SWCD, ODFW, USFWS, BOR and Snake River Correction Institute Inmate Planting.

This project proposes to install 12 barbs and three rootwads within .5 miles of Jordan Creek, install 2,200 foot exclosure fence and plant 850 trees/shrubs by Jordan Valley High School students and local residents for wildlife and riparian vegetation. Watershed benefits are decreased erosion and sediment loading, improved riparian conditions and improved wildlife habitat.  OWEB funds are requested for project management/engineering (19%), contracted services (planting, rock work/barbs) (71%), fencing materials (2%) and administration (8%).  Cost-share partners are local residents, NRCS, City of Jordan Valley, Malheur SWCD, USFWS and Jordan Valley High School.

Project Name: Beyond Words Juniper Removal Phase I
Project Summary: Beyond Words Youth Ministries near Westfall is a non-profit organization that employs troubled youth.  These youth will remove 829 acres of juniper on private land and 200 acres on BLM in an effort to teach work skills and conservation.  Watershed benefits include improved water quality, infiltration and upland vegetation.  OWEB funds are requested for juniper removal (80%), project management (9%), administration (9%) and monitoring (2%).  Cost-share partners include Westfall Ranches and Beyond Words Ministry.

Project Name: Grassland Restoration at the Boardman Conservation Area
Project Summary: The Nature Conservancy is seeking to restore 90 degraded areas within the Boardman Grasslands including a former cattle-holding pasture and watering areas.  Grass, forbs and shrub seed will be collected on-site and planted using a rangeland drill or by hand-broadcasting.  OWEB costs are requested for personnel (24%) herbicide/seed (37%), ATV seed stripper (6%), administration (9%) and monitoring (26%).  Cost-share partners include TNC, ODFW and USFWS.

Project Name: Antelope Peak Habitat Enhancement Phase I
Project Summary: Located near North Powder, this project will take 10 acres of low-elevation historical wetlands, now in row crops, and return it to wetlands and expand two existing ponds.  Project components include 1,320 feet of a permanent wildlife friendly fence, seeding and planting.  Watershed benefits include improved water quality, improved wildlife habitat and reduced erosion.  OWEB funds are requested for engineering (19%), mobilization (7%), earthwork (68%) and administration (6%).  Cost-share partners are the landowner, ODFW and Baker Valley SWCD.

Project Name: Dry Gulch Off-Stream Watering & Water Quality Improvement
Project Summary: This project will improve water quality by removing stream access for 350 head of cattle by installing 7,920 feet of mainline, 13,200 feet of fencing, 11 troughs and 15 acres of riparian planting.  Watershed benefits included improved water quality, improved vegetation, wildlife habitat and stream shading.  OWEB funds are requested for project management/engineering (11%), excavation (22%), fencing (8%), pipe (45%), troughs (10%), plants (1%) and administration (3%).  Cost-share partners include SWCD and the landowners.

Located near Umapine, this project will relocate seven CAFO pens away from Little Mud Creek and restore over 21 acres of riparian habitat.  The pens are located directly along a fish-sensitive tributary of the Walla Walla.  Watershed benefits include improved water quality, reduced sediment and nutrient transport.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (6%), berms (42%), fencing/gates (32%), water facilities (6%), riparian restoration (4%), administration (9%) and monitoring (1%).  The landowner is the cost-share partner.

Project Name: Small Wood Marketing & Fuel Reduction Initiative
Hedges Cr Student & Business Outreach Restoration Design
TMDL Compliance as Funding Source for Ongoing Restoration
Verde Native Plant Nursery & Restoration Services
Ochoco Irrigation District Water Efficiency Optimization
Hands on Land WS Stewardship Work Program
Contract for macroinvertebrete sampling for water quality
Project Summary: included as part of DEQ 206-807
Wateshed Council Support umbrella reserve

This Technical Assistance Type III proposal would allow the Siuslaw SWCD to reach out to approximately 60 landowners on the N. Fork Siuslaw with the goal of enrolling willing landowners in the WRP, WHIP & EQIP programs; establishing conservation plans for their farmland; and implementing best management practices with the goal of improving water quality and watershed health. OWEB funds would be used for the Siuslaw SWCD Watershed Conservationist, travel, consultation and some minor production costs.

Project Name: Landowner Recruitment to Implement Practices for Improving WQ & WS Health
Project Summary: This Technical Assistance Type III proposal would allow the Lincoln SWCD to contact approximately 100 landowners and recruit them to take action to implement practices on their property that improve watershed health, water quality and listed fish recovery. OWEB funds would be used for personnel and travel.

Project Name: Design of the Buchanan Riparian Corridor
Project Summary: The project proposes to provide technical assistance to develop a management plan which will lead to the implementation of regional-scale best management practices (BMPs) to address storm water, wetland, and other riparian issues in in the growing City of Eagle Point centered on the Buchanan drainage in the Little Butte Creek located with in the Rogue River basin.

Project Name: South Slough Reserve Action Plan for WS Managment, Restoration & Research
Project Summary: The project proposes to develop a phased action plan for a new watershed scale forest management, restoration and research program for the reserve.  The SSNERR is a 5,000 acre area protected within the South Slough watershed in Coos Bay that includes 4,000 acres of coastal upland and riparian habitats.

Project Name: Roberts Cr & Deer Cr Restoration Project Planning & Design Project
Project Summary: The project proposes to develop best management practices and project proposals for several large acre landowners in the South Deer Creek and Roberts Creek watersheds within the Umpqua River basin. Managing livestock in these sub-basins is critical to the restoration of degraded riparian areas and streams. Riparian fencing with corresponding grazing plans and other best management practices identified in the action plans to be developed with the land owners will help accelerate recovery in these two areas.

Project Name: Applegate Terrestrial Restoration Action Plan; Placed Based Planning for Applied Restoration
Project Summary: The project proposes to develop site specific terrestrial restoration action plans for private non-industrial landowners in the Applegate River watershed. Technical planning will involve the synthesis of comprehensive site characteristics and regional factors into site specific action plans.

In the last century the Corps of Engineers channelized the Long Tom R. from Fern Ridge reservoir to the mouth.  Stroda Dam is one of three drop structures which are passage barriers for native fish, including cutthroat trout and spring chinook. This grant would fund analyses of technical solutions to this problem.

Project Name: Project Planning & Managment Plan Development for Cardwell Hills Landowners
Project Summary: This grant would fund management and project specific restoration plans for 20 landowners in the Marys River watershed, thus addressing  the loss of upland and wetland habitats as part of a area-wide regional restoration effort.

Project Name: Sauvie Island Drainage & Irrigation Canal WQ, Functions, Plant & Wildlife Improvement
Project Summary: Sauvie Island has been heavily ditched and drained to support agricultural uses.  Those canals have been deteriorating over the past sixty years with negative results for water quality.  The irrigation district and the soil and water conservation district are partners in a comprehensive approach to enable landowner habitat restoration. This grant would fund the services of a hydrologic engineer who will model the system and propose design options to improve the operations of the Sauvie Island Drainage Improvement Company, which serves 12,000 acres of farmland.

Project Name: Crystal Springs Stream Design & Permit Project at Eastmoreland Golf Course
Project Summary: In cooperation with ODFW and the Corps of Engineers, this project would fund the design of restoration features that would enhance wildlife habitat and water quality in the Crystal Springs area in Eastmoreland within the city of Portland.  The Portland Watershed Management Plan identifies this area as one with high potential for significant watershed benefits if restored to a more naturally functioning state.

Three culverts on Beaver Creek, a tributary to the Sandy River near the city of Troutdale, block fish passage and access to 4.6 miles of habitat. Lower Columbia coho salmon and Lower Columbia Chinook salmon and steelhead are some of the fish species present. This grant would fund the design of a set of improvements for all three culverts, which are all within right-of-ways owned by Multnomah County.

Project Name: Lower Beaver Cr Pre-Design & Conceptual Planning
Project Summary: This grant would fund an action plan to restore sections of lower Beaver Creek, a tributary of the Sandy River. Within the Portland Metro area, this is one of the few relatively intact riparian corridors, but excessive sedimentation, elevated temperatures, lack of woody debris, impaired hydraulic function, and non-native vegetation are limiting wildlife habitat and aquatic productivity. The action plan would build on and link up with land acquisition and habitat restoration projects usptream and downstream of the project area.

Project Name: City of Scappoose Greenway Action Plan
Project Summary: Two miles of South Scappoose Creek flow through the City of Scappoose, and this urban interface has limited the natural function and habitat values of the creek.  This grant would be used to examine the hydrology and fluvial geomorphology of a 2-3 mile stretch of the creek, propose engineering solutions, and develop site restoration plans for key properties. This will result in a Greenway Action Plan.

Project Name: Willow Cr Confluence Restoration Scoping & Budgeting
Project Summary: The lower section of willow Creek was channelized in the 1970's, affecting native vegetation and wetland functions. This project area is within the West Eugene Wetlands, and restoring the natural stream course in a stretch of Willow Creek would restore habitat for plant species dependent upon native wet prairie. The grant is sought to fund a conceptual design for carrying out hydrologic and hydraulic studies, do a fluvial geomorphic analysis, and propose bioengineering solutions.  This will serve the overall goal of reversing habitat loss in the Willamette Valley.

Project Name: Mid-Willamette Tributaries Floodplain Workshops & Landowner Project Planning
Project Summary: This is a project to recruit landowners in the North Santiam, South Santiam, and Calapooia watersheds to work with watershed councils towards the development of whole farm management plans with conservation goals. Best management practices of existing agricultural conservation programs would be emphasized in workshops held throughout the region, and the soil and water conservation district planners would work with the watershed councils to provide technical assistance to landowners.

Project Name: Stream Channel Restoration Design at Rimrock Ranch (Whychus Cr)
Project Summary: This TA grant would develop a comprehensive plan for the restoration of existing and historical significant instream habitat for 1.6 miles of Whychus Creek (formerly Squaw Creek).  The project, on Rimrock Ranch northeast of Sisters, is part of the recovery efforts to reintroduce ESA listed steelhead above the Pelton/Round Butte Hydroelectric Project.

This TA project would develop an Action Plan for this watershed.  The need for the plan has been identified in both the John Day Subbasin Plan and the Hay Creek/Scott Canyon Watershed Assessment.  The area, in Gilliam County, is identified as having fish passage, fish habitat, rangeland, noxious weed and erosion issues.  The Action Plan would identify and prioritize specific watershed restoration projects.

Project Name: Sprague River Tailwater Wetlands Initiative - Phase I: Site Prioritization
Project Summary: This TA project would implement the Hatfield Working Group Science Teams 5-year restoration plan by inventorying irrigation surface tailwater flows, prioritizing sites, and developing conceptual designs for treatment wetlands in the Sprague River sub-basin in the Klamath Basin.

Project Name: Powder River Basin Water & Stream Health Analysis
Project Summary: Baker County is seeking funds to investigate additional water storage for multiple beneficial uses in the Powder Basin.  Without completing the Powder River Basin Water & Stream Health Analysis, they will be unable to move forward with the sequential steps of the projects, such as identifying data gaps.  OWEB funds are requested for research, mapping & partnerships (93%), travel (3%) and supplies (4%). Cost-share partners are BOR, Baker County, SWCDs, BRID, Powder Valley Control District, ODA, OWRD.

18.5 acres of privately owned property, including 6 acres of riparian land, in the Little Nestucca River watershed will be brushed and replanted with conifers, two small culverts would be removed and a third replaced if this application was funded. The majority of the requested funds (75%) are budgeted for contract services (site prep, seedling protection, tree planting, herbicide application and project management). 20% is budgeted for supplies (trees and seedling protection materials).

Project Name: Twin Cr Riparian Restoration & Urban Stormwater Treatment Project
Project Summary: The Twin Creeks Transit Oriented Development is proposing a project which would incorporate several stream restoration projects and storm water treatment best management practices into their design of a 235-acre development in an urban watershed within the Griffin Creek and Jackson Creek sub basins of Bear Creek watershed located within the Rogue River Basin.  The work could provide significant improvement to fish habitat, water quality and provides a highly visible open showcase to other communities and watersheds.

Project Name: Buchanan Riparian Corridor Urban WS Restoration Project
Project Summary: The project will incorporate stormwater treatment, flood control, protection of mitigated wetlands, educational opportunities, pedestrian trails and riparian viewing areas, and streambank protection in a drainage area that is currently degraded and unkept.  The resultant improvements will include an interconnected corridor of wetlands, riparian habitat, and a BioLab.  It could affect 485 acres of urban watershed that is currently planned for development.

The project proposes to Placement of three cross-vane rock structures and two log jams in middle and upper South Umpqua River to improve spring chinook spawning habitat.  The structures will be located near several older (mid 1980s) restoration projects that will be used as controls to evaluate the new structures.

The project proposes on-the-ground watershed restoration activities on Tribal lands in the Jordan Creek drainage as a result of the recently conducted watershed assessment. Jordan Creek is located in the South Umpqua River drainage. Activities would include riparian planting; instream structure placement; construction of settling ponds and an acclimation pond

The project proposes to place approximately sixty to seventy large logs and thirty tons of boulders in one and a half miles of buck Creek, located in the Elk Creek watershed in the Umpqua River basin. Project activities will aggrade spawning gravels and create habitat complexes for coho, steelhead and cutthroat trout. The project will also replace a failing culvert with a bridge and construct an off-channel alcove for over-wintering coho. A riparian area overrun with blackberries with native trees and shrubs.

Project Name: Middle Rogue WSC Noxious Weed Managment Partnership Program
Project Summary: The project proposes to develop a Middle Rogue watershed wide noxious weed management program which will involve the enrollment of landowners in a voluntary noxious weed eradication program. State listed noxious weeds will be identified, managed and eradicated to improve watershed health.

Project Name: Middle Rogue Forest Health Initiative II
