Project Summary: The project proposes to continue the Middle Rogue Forest Health Initiative began in 2000. The project provides technical assistance, landowner outreach and forestry stewardship to promote healthier forest conditions and reduce the severity of wildfires in the Middle Rogue watershed in the Rogue River basin.

The project proposes to provide a bridge crossing of Battle Creek, located in the Evans Creek watershed in the Rogue River basin, allowing for five miles of road improvement activities including re-establishing road grades, establishing ditch lines and installation of water bars on approximately five miles of existing roads and the decommissioning of .75 miles of road to reduce sediment inputs into Battle Creek. The activities will also lead to future fuel reduction projects.

The project proposes to promote the re-establishment of coho salmon to the 130 acre Garrison Lake in the South Coast. This will be accomplished through re-locate the outlet to Garrison Lake back to one of its historic channels. This new meandering channel will be inland from the current artificial outlet which is constantly pummeled by ocean surf, subject to dune and sand movements which periodically closes the outlet, causing lake flooding. The new proposed outlet would be designed to pass fish twelve months of the year and will create a more stable lake level.
The project proposes to address three fiash passage barriers in Coles Valley Creek within the Umpqua River watershed. The project will also involve wetland and riparian restoration activities.

The project proposes to enhance 12.8 acres of riparian area on a 211 acre property on Roberts Creek within the South Umpqua River watershed. Restoration activities include riparian fencing, riparian planting, streambank stabilization, stockwater development and two stream crossings.

The project proposes to restore 175 acres of oak woodland, oak savanna, riparian forest and 1.8 miles of stream habitat to benefit several plant, wildlife and fish species. The work would take place in the Calapooya watershed located within the Umpqua River basin. The project will also serve as a demonstration site for outreach education of student and community groups for the restoration of oak and riparian habitats.

This is a grant to acquire 50 acres of off-channel riparian forest habitat (via conservation easement and fee simple) near river mile 22.5 on the lower McKenzie River to the east of Springfield. The oxbow area supports Chinook salmon, bull trout, cutthroat trout, lowland salamanders, western pond turtles, red-legged frogs;  provides habitat for birds (including shorebirds, bald eagles, and waterfowl); and is used for feeding and migration by river otter, mink, and beaver. ODFW has identified this site as one of the few left in the Lower McKenzie that exhibits natural, unconstrained hydrology.

Round Lake is currently agricultural land drained by tiles, but historically was wetland.  This grant would fund the recreation of approximately 100 acres of wetland by recontouring the land, removing a deep drainage ditch, removing tiles, and putting in a water control structure and levee.

Green Island, Big Island, and Roberts Island are all properties owned by the MacKenzie River trust.  They are in the lower MacKenzie River, the last bastion of Upper Willamette spring Chinook, and have been in agricultural use for several decades.  This grant would be used to return approximately 300 acres to riparian habitat over a two year period.

Project Name: Northern Tributaries of Calapooia River Fish Passage Project
Project Summary: Johnson Creek is a tributary of the Calapooia watershed.  Two fish passage projects would improve migration corridors for steelhead, cutthroat trout, and Chinook salmon, opening up approximately 10 miles of stream.

The McKenzie River watershed council requests $131,760 to implement a series of floodplain/riparian restoration projects on private land in the Mohawk River area, which flows into the McKenzie just upstream from its confluence with the Willamette River. In the past, the Mohawk River supported a run of Upper Willamette spring Chinook salmon, but that run went extinct in 1910. At present, the river provides habitat for the strongest remaining population of fluvial (migratory) cutthroat trout in the Willamette basin. Work will include invasive weed removal, livestock exclusion fencing, and fish passage improvements to improve riparian and instream conditions.

Ducks Unlimited requests $168,682 to restore 51 acres of degraded riparian/forest habitat on the Tualatin River National Wildlife Refuge.  Clearing and draining of the land for agricultural purposes has eliminated many of the wetlands in the basin. The land was recently acquired from a private owner, and remediation has already begun. Non-native plants from a nursery operation will be removed and the area replanted with native trees. The natural spring flooding regime will provide off-channel rearing and resting habitat for native fish, as well as habitat for native waterfowl.

Scappoose Bay watershed council requests $84,370 to restore 30 acres of habitat in the Scappoose Bay bottomlands, and to enhance 70 acres of wetlands. The site is near the confluence of the Multnomah Channel and  the Columbia River, where development has taken its toll on the natural function of the wetlands/bottomlands; this project would restore seasonal wetlands by repairing or replacing failing water control structures.

Project Name: Holomb Cr & Arrah Wanna Side Channel Bridges
Project Summary: This project would address fish passage problems on Holcomb Creek (east of Oregon City in the lower Willamette basin)and on the Sandy River (tributary to the Sandy River, near Wemme).  Culverts on private property would be replaced with bridges, improving habitat for native fish, including salmon and lamprey.

Project Name: North Fork Sprague Channel Stability Project
Project Summary: This project would construct 2.2 miles of permanent fence along Five Mile Creek where it joins the North Fork Sprague River and repair several headcuts, construct hardened cattle crossings and water gaps and provide off-stream watering for livestock.  The purpose is to re-establish healthy riparian areas and instream habitat for Redband trout and Marbled Sculpin and it will help provide high quality perennial stream flows downstream for ESA listed Shortnose and Lost River suckers.

Project Name: Upper Sprague Riparian Enhancement Initiative: Livestock Access Mgt Phase
Project Summary: This project builds on the last two years of agency/landowner relationship building in the Sprague River.  Approximately eight miles of fencing would be purchased and installed to protect and restore riparian areas by better managing livestock access to the river.  Grazing management plans would be developed and off-stream livestock watering would be integrated, where necessary, in the improvements to maximize the benefit to this riparian protection program and participating landowners.

This project would aid 24 landowners in four watersheds in Sherman County with construction of water and sediment control basins, level terraces, gradient terraces and grassed waterways in order to reduce soil erosion into fish bearing streams.

This project seeks to improve an area frequently used by locals for recreation by eliminating off-road mudding just upslope and upstream of Lakeview in Bullard Creek.  Restoration includes improvements to damaged springs, creek crossings and culverts with seasonal road closures and an explanatory kiosk.

This project, in Clover Flat about 10 miles north of Lakeview, would place small rock check structures in Willow Creek to stop down-cutting and head-cutting occurring on the site and below the site.  The project includes fencing the area from livestock grazing and planting of willows to help stabilize the banks and provide shade.

Project Name: Irrigation Water Mgt to Restore Stream Flow
Project Summary: This project proposes to work with landowners within the area of the Middle Deschutes and WyChus Creek (formerly Squaw Creek) to reduce their irrigation water needs to result in a total of 1 cfs instream waterright conversion.  Both of these stream sections are water quality limited due to low summertime flows.

Project Name: Farmers Irrigation District''s Lowline Water Conservation Project
Project Summary: The project, Phase I, will pipe 3,000 feet of a 7,000 foot open ditch  the Lowline canal of the Farmers Irrigation District serving the Hood River basin.  This will decrease water needs by 20 to 40% and reduce the likelihood of canal failure which occur frequently  adding sediment to the West Fork of the Hood River.

This project would replace a 1987 water diversion and fish passage structure on Coe Creek, a tributary to the Middle Fork of Hood River.  A new structure would allow for the removal of glacial silt from the 30cfs diversion and it would upstream and downstream fish passage for ESA listed Bull trout and Winter Steelhead as well as redband and cutthroat trout.

This project would pay to lease a D-8 Caterpillar to clean out and restore up to 68 miles of terraces and sediment basins on 25,000 acres of dryland wheat agricultural lands in Gilliam County.  One operator, over a five year period, would work to bring these structures into compliance with NRCS standards as time allows.

Project Name: Watkins Sprague River Channel & Wetland Restoration
Project Summary: This project would stabilize an avulsion channel in the Sprague River to improve channel-floodplain connectivity, floodplain water storage and water quality.  The project would enhance two backwater wetlands and restore riparian habitat and add woody debris to the channel to improve habitat for ESA listed larval Lost River and Shortnose suckers and redband trout and migratory birds.

This project would install a solar water pump at an existing well to provide drinking water for livestock to take the pressure off of  the West Fork of Dry Creek to reduce streambank damage and sedimentation into Rock Creek  a steelhead spawning stream in Gilliam County.

Located north of Enterprise this project replaces a culvert at Summit Creek, which is a barrier to juvenile steelhead, with a open-bottom arch to open 1.2 miles of  habitat.  At Doe Creek, the existing culvert will be removed and replaced with an open-bottom arch and the gabion structures below will be removed.  Watershed benefits include improved fish habitat and passage.  OWEB funds are requested for engineering/project management (3%), excavation & construction (95%) and administration (2%).  Cost-share partners include BPA, Wallowa Resources and USFS.

Project Name: Four Co Medusahead Containment & Strategic Treatment
Project Summary: This well-defined cooperative effort in Wheeler, Morrow, Grant and Gilliam Counties will assist landowners to contain the spread of medusahead rye in uninfested landscapes.  Tools include satellite patches and priority sites, herbicides treatments on 5,000 acres, small-scale reseeding (100 acres) for heavily infested areas and continued education and mapping support.  OWEB funds are requested for mapping (1%), project management (16%), treatments (39%), herbicides (30%), seed (2%), administration (9%) and monitoring (3%)..  Cost-share partners include Wheeler, Monument, Morrow SWCDs; Gilliam-East John Day WSC; NRCS; Gilliam, Wheeler, and Grant Counties Weed Control; ARS and landowners.

The proposed project near Pendleton will provde streambank erosion control on 700 feet of Lower McKay Creek.  Streambank erosion is contributing sediment and threatening a cottonwood galley.  Project components include 6 rock barbs, 5 willow rows, 2,600 willow cuttings, 50 of toe rock and 8 root wads. Watershed benefits include improved habitat complexity, vegetation and water quality.  OWEB funds are requested for engineering (17%), rock, root wads & vegetation (70%), sign (2%), administration (9%)and monitoring (2%).  Lower McKay Water Control is the cost-share partner.

Project Name: Mountain Cr Ditch Conversion Phase II
Project Summary: Located east of Mitchell, phase II will convert 8,200 of open ditch to PVC mainline on the north side of the Mountain Creek and will complement phase 1 which replaced the open ditch on the south side. The project complements  several other OWEB efforts on Mountain Creek.  Watershed benefits include improved water quality, decreased erosion and provide an opportunity for irrigation efficiency.  OWEB funds are requested for project management/engineering (7%), equipment rental (9%), pipe and materials (78%), administration (5%) and monitoring (1%).  Cost-share partners include NRCS and the landowner.

Project Name: Marching Down the Malheur - 3 Miles of Malheur River Restoration
Project Summary: A community effort involving 4 landowners with 4,420 acres proposes to improve fish habitat and reduce excessive bank erosion on over 4 miles of the Middle Fork of the Malheur in the Drewsey Valley. Project components include bank benching, barbs, rootwad revetments, willow planting and sod mats.  Watershed benefits include improved riparian conditions, water quality and reduced sediment transport.  OWEB funds are requested for permitting (2%), engineering/survey (48%), bioengineering (35%), off-channel water developments (%), mobilization (3%) and administration (5%).  Cost-share partners include FSA, USFWS, landowners, Harney SWCD, ODA, Agency Technical Steering Committee.

Located in Baker County, this project will improve rangeland and watershed conditions by treating 370 acres of juniper, developing 2 springs and 7,920 cross-fence, seeding 340 acres and treating 200 acres of leafy spurge. Watershed benefits include improved water quality, improved vegetation and improved soil conditions.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (3%), juniper control (28%), cross-fence  (7%), spring development (4%), seed (20%), chemical (32%) and administration (4%).  Cost-share partners include landowners, Baker County Weed Department and Burnt SWCD.

This project proposes to seed 109.3-acres of rangeland; develop 1 spring and 2 watering facilities; install 2,600 of pipeline and 4,000 cross-fence in the Butter Creek watershed in Umatilla County.  Watershed benefits include improved rangeland vegetation, water quality and improve rangeland health.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (11%), spring development (37%) fencing (28%), sign (2%), seed (13%), administration (9%) and monitoring (1%).  Cost-share partners include NRCS and the landowner.

Project Name: Variable Rate Fertilizer Application in Umatilla County
Project Summary: This project proposes to increase accessibility of variable-rate fertilizer application in Umatilla County. An incentive payment of $20/acre for $2,000 acres which will reduce the potential contact of fertilizers with surface/groundwater, encourage direct-seed cropping system and improve soil health and tilth. OWEB funds are requested for project management (10%), incentive cost-share (80%), administration (9%) and monitoring (1%). Cost-share partners include NRCS, OSU Extension and landowners.

Located near Vale, this project addresses excessive soil erosion and bacteria-laden runoff from flood-irrigated pastures that enter the Malheur River.  The applicant is proposing to convert 89 acres from flood to sprinkler irrigation using 1 center pivot and 3 wheel lines.  Project components include 6,600 of buried PVC, 2 flow meters, 2 pumps, 6 troughs, 14,00 cross-fencing and 10.5 acres of wildlife planting. OWEB funds are requested for project management (2%), PVC, flowmeters & headgates (82%), troughs & power (20%) and administration (5%).  Cost-share partners include Malheur Watershed Council. Landowner, EQIP and Vale Oregon Irrigation District.

Project Name: Pacific Shrimp Co Water Conservation Project
Project Summary: The applicant is proposing to inventory water used by Pacific Shrimp Company in one season for each of the plants top three water intensive processes, create a water management plan, implement the plan to reduce the plants water use by 25% for each process, maintain 10.25 million gallons of water savings per summer in the Siletz River, and conduct worker education.  OWEB funds are requested for personnel (plant quality control officer), project manager, education materials, monitoring, best available technology equipment, and administration.

Project Name: Applied Forest Restoration, Milling and Manufacturing from private lands
Project Summary: The applicant is proposing to complete baseline forest stand inventories, develop site-based silvicultural prescriptions, implement forest restoration treatments, haul materials to a small mill, process the materials to finished products, and complete a study to determine the extent to which sales of finished products can offset costs of restoration.  OWEB funds are requested for project management, travel, forest restoration, hauling, milling and processing, market analysis, education, and administration.

The applicant is proposing to assign youth teams to riparian sites on Johnson Creek for the annual Watershed Wide event and have the Teams commit to at least four on-site work party experiences over the course of the academic year.  Work could include refuse and invasive plant removal, native shrub and tree planting, mulching, stream bank restoration, and educational outreach.  OWEB funds are requested for a stewardship coordinator, outreach coordinators, bus transportation, mileage, classroom substitutes, youth crew, native trees and shrubs, water quality test kits, newsletter printing, meetings, equipment, monitoring and administration.

Project Name: Lower Columbia Slough Habitat Restoration and Education Project
Project Summary: The applicant is proposing to replace two 50-year old culverts on flood control conveyance ditches at the Columbia Childrens Arboretum with pedestrian bridges and an accessible trail system, restoration of native vegetation, and installation of two interpretive trailhead signs at the east and west public access points.  OWEB funds are requested for project management, engineering, graphic designer, earthwork and culvert removal costs, bridge installation, plants and mulch, and administration.

Project Name: Zenger Farm - Upland Habitat Restoration and Water Quality Project
Project Summary: The applicant, in partnership with Verde Native Plant Nursery, will prepare, install and insure establishment of a bioswale, landscape buffer, vegetative filter strip, and planter box on the upland portion of the farm.  Zenger Farms is located in the Johnson Creek watershed and is one of few working urban farms in the Portland city limits.  OWEB funds are requested for bioswale and landscape installation, native plant and seed materials, training, monitoring and administration

The applicant, in partnership with Verde Native Plant Nursery, is proposing to restore two remaining Columbia sedge meadows at Smith and Bybee Wetlands Natural Area by installing Columbia sedge on the perimeter of the existing meadows to reconnect the two adjacent meadows.  The project will also include control of invasive plants through mechanical and chemical means.  OWEB funds are requested for nursery employees, mileage, plants, planting supplies, training, outreach, monitoring and maintenance, and administration.

Project Name: Juntura Malheur River Stream Protection Project
Project Summary: The applicants are proposing to eliminate a human waste problem along the Malheur River by installing a restroom facility in Juntura along Highway 20.  OWEB funds are requested for project management, travel, rest area construction, well drilling, septic installation, parking lot installation, electric hook-up, hardware, educational kiosk, monitoring and administration.

The applicants are proposing to construct a berm and settling pond to channel run-off from the north end of the fairgrounds (site of the rodeo arena and year-round stables) to an existing drain that will be connected by pipe to a settling pond.  The pond will be fenced off and appropriately lined to prevent seepage and allow evaporation of the run-off.  The goal is to prevent contaminated run-off from entering the storm drain system and the Snake River.  OWEB funds are requested for engineering, project management, fence installation, pipe, bentonite, fence materials, and administration.

Project Name: The Alsea and Marys Watersheds Passage Barrier Survey and Action Plan
Project Summary: The Benton SWCD Fish Passage Improvement Program (BFPIP) proposes to conduct a survey of fish passage barriers in four yet to be identified 7th-field sub watersheds in the Alsea and Marys River basins and develop a list of restoration opportunities from the results. Funds will be used primarily to fund BFPIP staff to compile and organize the survey results.
The project proposes to hire an engineer to design solutions to address erosion control of an eroding bank on the North Coquille River.

Project Name: Rogue Basin Fish Passage Action Planning
Project Summary: The project proposes to develop an action plan to strategically address fish passage improvement basin-wide through a prioritized approach which will be implemented over the next ten years.

Project Name: Isthmus Slough Road Sediment Reduction Project
Project Summary: The project proposes to conduct road surveys, analyze data and prepare restoration designs for road improvement projects aimed to improve fish passage and reduce sediment inputs in the Coos River watershed.
The project proposes to support land owner recruitment efforts for the Applegate River Watershed Councils riparian restoration program.

Project Name: Upper Poodle Creek Fish Passage Analysis and Design
Project Summary: A seriously perched culvert on a tributary to Upper Poodle Creek in Lane County disconnects 1.5 miles of upstream habitat for resident cutthroat trout, causes severe channel and bank erosion downstream, and disrupts the natural transport of streambed and woody material. This technical design (TA#1)project will result in a fish passage design to replace the culvert with a bridge. Partners include the BLM. OWEB funds will be used principally to pay for contracted design and related survey/CAD work.

Project Name: Klein Point Fish Habitat Improvement Design
Project Summary: This technical design (TA#1)project will consist of a geomorphic analysis, hydraulic modeling, and engineering designs for instream habitat structures, functional riparian areas, and floodplain connectivity at Klien Point at the confluence of Johnson Creek and the Willamette River.  Partners include the City of Milwaukie. OWEB funds will be used principally to pay for contracted design and related survey/CAD work.

Project Name: North Santiam Spawning Gravel Enhancement Design Study
Project Summary: This technical design (TA#2) will address a limiting factor to ESA-listed fish species recovery at Big Cliff Dam, just downstream of Detroit Dam. It proposes to develop an action plan for addressing spawning gravel that is trapped behind Big Cliff Dam. The results of the plan will assist the North Santiam Council in getting federal funding earmarked for enrollment into the Army Corps Section 1135 program, which provides authority to modify existing Corps projects to restore the environment. Partners include USACE, USFWS, NOAA, ODFW, and Detroit Lake. OWEB funds will be used principally to contract for engineering services to complete the study for Section 1135 enrollment.

Project Name: Santiam Basin Fish Passage Improvement Project
Project Summary: The North and South Santiam watershed councils propose to partner with OSU to prioritize fish passage barriers in the Santiam Basin. This technical assistance (TA#@) project will involve performing field surveys performed according to ODFW protocols with the result to be incorporated into ODFW's statewide fish passage barrier database. OWEB funds will be used principally to support an OSU engineering graduate student research assistant position.

This technical assistance (TA#2) project will use OWEB funds principally to contract for the adaptation of an existing limiting factors protocol for use with steelhead, identification of factors limiting steelhead productivity in Pedee Creek, and design of a comprehensive restoration project to address the limiting factors. Partners include ODF, ODFW, OSU Extension, BLM, and Benton SWCD.

Project Name: Upper Willamette Landowner Recruitment and Floodplain Restoration Design
Project Summary: This technical assistance (TA#3) project will use OWEB funds to contract for the recruitment of floodplain landowners in the Middle and Coast Fork Willamette watershed to participate in floodplain restoration projects. Partners include USACE, Willamette Riverkeeper, City of Springfield, McKenzie River Trust, and the University of Oregon.

This project would result in a stream restoration design for Willow Creek just east of Madras.  The creek was channelized and straightened and it has downcut with steep banks that are eroding with no vegetation to hold the banks together.

Project Name: Lower Grass Valley Canyon Creek Restoration Action Plan
Project Summary: This project would do a stream survey and habitat analysis on the lower seven miles of Grass Valley Creek in Sherman County.  The end product would be an action plan prioritizing actions necessary to restore steelhead spawning in this reach.

Project Name: The Hay Creek/Scott Canyon Watershed Action Plan
Project Summary: A watershed assessment for Hay Creek/Scott Canyon in Gilliam County in 2003.  This project would hire a consultant to help the landowners and agencies complete an action plan to identify and prioritize specific restoration actions.  This is an area of critical steelhead habitat.

Project Name: The Thirtymile Creek Watershed Action Plan
Project Summary: This project would retain a resource consultant to work with a resource management technical team to develop an action plan for restoration projects on Thirtymile Creek in Gilliam County.  A watershed assessment for this 174,000 acre, 5th field watershed was completed in 2006.

Funds are sought for the survey and design for the Umatilla River at Horseshoe Curve at RM 38.  A wide shallow channel has an eroding left cutbank with little vegetation and inadequate riparian habitat along the reach. Tentative design includes rootwad revetments, footer log structures, bank sloping and riparian vegetation.  Funds are requested for survey and design (80%), project manager (11%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners are CTUIR, ODFW, UBWC and the landowner.

Technical assistance for the design, engineering and restoration of 4.5 miles for a severely degraded portion of Eagle Creek near Halfway is being sought by Eagle Valley SWCD.  Funds are sought for base mapping, design for a fish friendly diversion at the historic Nash diversion and for streambank restoration  directly above the push-up dam.  Funds are requested for project management (3%), mapping (37%), design engineering (54%) and administration (6%).  Cost-share partners are Eagle Valley SWCD, Westside Irrigation District and the landowners

The applicant is proposing to complete a topographical survey of 200 acres of former native grassland, emergent/wet meadow and riparian habitat adjacent to Willow Creek north of Summerville. Following completion of the topographic survey, recommendations for habitat improvement will be made and a restoration design completed.  Funds are requested for survey and design (100%).  Ducks Unlimited is the cost-share partner.

An existing 3-bay bridge on Pine Creek near Halfway is contributing to channel constriction and forcing spring high flows to flood adjacent homes and agricultural lands.  Pine Creek, a tributary of the Snake River, experienced severe flooding in the spring of 2006 resulting in a massive amount of streambank erosion and deposition of gravels. OWEB funds are requested for engineering (92%) and administration (8%).  Partners include City of Halfway, ODOT, ODA, ODFW, DEQ, USFWS, BOR and the Halfway community.

The Malheur River is experiencing significant bank erosion at 5 locations adjacent to the City of Ontarios wastewater treatment facilities.  This erosion deposits increasing amount of soil into the river annually.  The absence of vegetation is increasing water temperature and erosion.  Designs are needed for a topographic survey of the area, bank stabilization and for a permanent fish-friendly facility.  OWEB funds are requested for survey (19%), design (66%), permit & production assistance (10%) and administration (4%).  Partners include the Malheur Watershed Council and City of Ontario.  Technical review will be provided by BOR, ODFW and ODA.

Project Name: Kirkway Collaborative Project for Powder River Restoration
Project Summary: The applicant is seeking technical assistance for landowner recruitment and stream and riparian assessment for an area of town where significant bank sloughing is occurring.  Approximately _ mile of the Powder River needs to be treated near Baker City with 24 adjacent landowners along this stretch.  Collaboration of these landowners is essential to restoration implementation. OWEB funds are requested for outreach coordination (81%), supplies/production (10%) and administration (9%).  Partners include BOR, landowners and contractors..

The Siuslaw Institute seeks funding to produce an attractive book (50 pages, 300 copies) that would tell the story of the Deadwood Creek Enhancement Project, an eight-year effort to implement a variety of restoration activities on the properties of eighteen different landowners in the Deadwood Creek sub-basin of the Siuslaw River watershed. Using surveys and interviews to elicit participating landowners comments, the book would be designed to provide guidance for landowners and restoration professionals in recruiting, managing and rewarding landowners participation in ecosystem and community recovery. The majority of the funds (73%) would be used for staff to conduct interviews, photograph and write the book.

Project Name: Full Circle Schools Restoration Ecology Program Partnership
Project Summary: The project proposes to support Lomakatsi Restoration projects Full Circle Schools Restoration Ecology Program which offers a collaborative community-based approach to watershed education.

The project proposes to fund a two year education program that will produce six journal publications targeting the Upper Rogue watershed area which will provide education information and resources on watershed and natural resource issues such as fuel management and water quality.

This is a series of activities that will result in watershed council members, stakeholders, and volunteers writing and publishing a book or personal essays about the Luckiamute and Ash creek watershed. The goals are to increase communication skills and understanding about what motivates stewardship. OWEB funds will be used principally to support project management and to print the book.

OWEB funds will be used to support the McKenzie Watershed Council's Spawning Education Program, which involves a diverse community of stakeholders in restoring the watershed and K-12 students in learning about spring chinook salmon life history needs. Partners include EWEB and Spirit Mountain.

Project Name: Calapooia and Santiam Joint Education Project - Phase II
Project Summary: Phase I of the Calapooia and Santiam Joint Education Project focused on increasing knowledge of council members, citizens, and students about watershed principles. Phase II, the subject of this application, will provide an interactive education program for consituents that demonstrates the importance of developing restoration action skills for ensuring watershed health. Partners include the two councils and local community partners. OWEB funds will pay for a contractor, supplies, and events.

Project Name: Demonstration of Drip Irrigation in Orchard Crops
Project Summary: This project would enable an already established field trial for drip irrigation in orchards to continue in the Hood River Basin.  Education materials will be produced and tours will be held to share production and water saving results.

This project with the Upper Deschutes Watershed Council brings volunteers together to do hands-on restoration projects while learning about the ecology and restoration opportunities in the riparian corridor.  The Community Rivers Program engages new landowners in reducing the impacts of development affecting riparian areas by involving them in site specific restoration projects.

Project Name: The Four W Strategy for Watershed Enhancement
Project Summary: This project would provide workshops, neighborhood meetings and land management classes to rural residents in Deschutes County on land management - Water, Weeds, Wildfire and Wildlife.

The proposal would create interest among high school teachers to develop Resources & People (RAP) Camps throughout Oregon based on a current model operating in Klamath Falls. The current RAP Camp serves 60 students, but receives 175-200 applications per year. OWEB funds will be used to develop, publish and distribute conservation education outreach tools and materials. The materials will be used in Oregon high schools to encourage formation of RAP Camps. Products will include two 15-minute videos and brochures (English & Spanish).

The proposal would create the Oregon Watershed Education Consortiuma partnership of government, watershed councils, non-profits, schools, teachers, universities and businesses from around the state. OWEC will coordinate and implement watershed teacher education using existing program models and curriculum. OWEB funds will be used for watershed education workshop implementation, program follow-up, educator support, Creeks and Kids workshop involvement for 72 teachers, and an annual watershed education conference.

In this proposal, Oregon Trout would partner with watershed councils, soil and water conservation districts and other organizations in four diverse watersheds to create a scalable, community-driven model for improving science education and engaging students in the health of their home waters. The proposal builds on experience gained in the Healthy Waters Institute, launched in 2005 in four watersheds. OWEB funds would be used to implement the program and to prepare to expand to additional watersheds.

Project Name: Invertebrate and Diatom Communities-Hoffman and Karnowsky Creeks
Project Summary: The Siuslaw Watershed Council requests funding to conduct an assessment of the invertebrates and diatoms in two adjacent tributaries to the lower Siuslaw River; one (Hoffman) a creek heavily impacted by logging and livestock grazing and the other (Karnowsky) a creek thats had significant restoration work accomplished within the last three years. The purpose of the assessment is to attempt to determine the effectiveness of restoration activities on the food web and trophic level interactions in ways beneficial to salmonids. OWEB funds will be used for field collection and lab processing of invertebrate and diatom samples, database development and report writing.

Project Name: Rogue Basin Stream Flow Monitoring Project
Project Summary: The project proposes to continue stream flow monitoring in the Rogue River watershed in 48 high priority water availability basins during low flow summer months and fall months.

Project Name: Lower Umpqua Basin WQ Monitoring Program
Project Summary: The project proposes to continue the Umpqua SWCDs efforts to collect baseline water quality information in the Lower Umpqua Riverwatershed to help evaluate the effectiveness of installed conservation practices.

No resource exists for river enthusiasts to get information about bacteria levels at their favorite recreation area on the Willamette River and its adjacent tributaries. Many areas also are not currently monitored for bacteria. This project proposes to monitor bacteria levels at popular sites and present the information bi-monthly online. Partners include DEQ. OWEB funds will be used principally for staff, supplies, and outreach.
This project would develop and implement a long term water quality monitoring program in the Crooked River Watershed.  It would guide the development of TMDL's and in their implementation.

The project proposes to fund a two year education program that will produce six journal publications targeting the Upper Rogue watershed area which will provide education information and resources on watershed and natural resource issues such as fuel management and water quality.

Project Name: The Molalla River Rehabilitation Action Plan
Project Summary: This project proposes to use OWEB funds to contract to perform an Aquatic Habitat Inventory (AHI)using ODFW protocols; a Bank Erosion Hazard Index, topographic survey, and a level III geomorphic assessment in the Molalla River Watershed. The information will inform the development of a restoration/rehabilitation plan of prioritized projects. Partners include ODFW, NFWF, Clackamas SWCD, and Molalla River Improvement District.

The Columbia River Estuary Study Taskforce (CREST) is seeking funding to replace a tidegated culvert with a bridge in a 45-acre property alongside South Clatsop Slough in the Youngs Bay estuary. OWEB funds would be used for the bridge purchase and placement (82%), geotechnical analysis (5%) and monitoring (6%).

The project proposes to continue the monitoring of Larson Creek tide gate located in the lower Coos River watershed. Further coho life-cycle monitoring will further test the value of improving the design and function of tide gates.
The project proposes to improve anadromous fish passage at two locations on mainstem Little Butte Creek located in the Rogue River watershed, through the removal of a concrete dam and a push up dam.

The project proposes to continue the successful riparian restoration program in the Applegate River watershed. Native tree and vegetation species will be planted along riparian areas with 303(d) temperature listings and salmonid rearing locations being the focus areas.
The project proposes to improve instream habitat complexity in Brummit Creek and Karl Creek in the Coquille River watershed by placing 150 logs along three and a half miles of creek.

The project proposes to improve anadromous fish passage and reduce sediment inputs into Johnson Creek located in the Coquille River watershed by replacing three undersized culverts with properly sized and installed culverts.
The project proposes to replace three tide gates on Beaver Creek in the Coquille River watershed with more fish friendly designs in order to improve water quality and improve fish passage.

The project proposes to improve fish passage and reduce sediment inputs at three sites within the Coquille River watershed. Two culverts on Fat Elk Creek and one culvert on Water Tank Creek will be replaced with properly sized and placed culverts.

Project Name: Elkhead Oak Woodland and Riparian Restoration
Project Summary: The project proposes to  restore twenty acres of oak woodland, five acres of riparian forest and .3 miles of stream habitat through invasive specie removal, thinning, replanting areas with native vegetations and the placement of five instream structures and three tree revetments and associated willow plantings. The project is located in the Umpqua River watershed in the Calapooya Creek drainage.

Grantee: Marys Peak Natural Resources Interp Ctr
Project Summary: Mary's Peak Natural Resource Interpretive Center is requesting 1,500,000 (total project cost of $2,531,000) to purchase 124 acres of wetland and upland along Newton Creek.  The project is located in Philomath.

This project proposes to implement the restoration of 100 acres of Wapato willow wetlands in the Round Lake shallow basin in Columbia County. The project will provide water quality improvements as a result of eliminating annual agricultural practices on site. A final engineering design has been completed and Ducks Unlimited is in the final stages of purchasing a perpetual conservation easement on the property. Partners include NAWCA. OWEB funds will be used principally for site constructions (ditch fill and swale creation) and reseeding and planting of native vegetation.

This project proposes to reconnect the floodplain between Green and Big islands. Large wood will be placed in the floodplain and instream. Invasives will be controlled on three islands and their interiors will be reforested. Partners include USFWS, ODFW, and McKenzie River Trust. OWEB funds will be used principally for hydrologic modeling (for future levee breaching), project management, log hauling and placement, invasives management, and tree planting.

This project proposes to address a number of fish passage barrier issues (undersized culverts, lack of spawning gravel and large wood, scour pools, and bank erosion) on Holcomb and Bear Creeks and a side channel to the Salmon River in Clackamas County. Partners include Clackamas County SWCD, Sandy Basin Watershed Council, NRCS, BLM, USFS, and ODFW. OWEB funds will be used principally to purchase and install three bridges at the three sites and to control erosion through streamside plantings.

The project would cut juniper trees on 200 acres near the Chewaucan River in Lake County.  Juniper has encroached into former bunchgrass/sagebrush plant communities and become so dense as to out-complete these plants, creating a condition where there are no understory plants to hold back overland flow, aid in infiltration and stop erosion.

Project Name: Herbicide Use Reduction Program for Dryland Crop
Project Summary: This project would provide cost-share incentives to dryland wheat growers in Wasco County to use "Weedseeker" technology to treat invasive weeds.  This infra-red spray technology uses 40% or less of the pesticides normally used.  The technology would be used on 8,000 acres.

An existing feedlot in Vansycle Canyon, a tributary of the Walla Walla, is a source of contamination from sediments and nutrients.  Relocating the animal feeding operation to an upland site and enrolling the area into CREP will improve water quality and improve wildlife habitat.  OWEB funds are requested for relocation (76%), concrete (16%), troughs/pipe (2%) and administration (6%).  Cost-share partners include NRCS, Umatilla SWCD and the landowners.

An animal feeding area will be moved from the Bear Creek riparian area south of Pilot Rock to a more suitable upland location.  The area will be reseeded and planted to appropriate species.  Water will be piped from Bridge Creek to 6 troughs and 2,640 feet of riparian fence installed to eliminate access to Bear Creek.  Water quality and upland vegetation will be improved.  OWEB funds are requested for facility (85%), concrete (3%), fencing (3%), troughs/pipeline (3%) and administration (6%).  Cost-share partners include NRCS and the landowner.

Located north of Burns on the Malheur Forest, a 300-acre Eagle Roost area is being threatened from overstocking of understory trees.  The applicant proposes to thin and hand-pile slash on 287 acres to 5 to 10' crown spacing and grapple pile 23 acres.  The fuels reduction will break up fuel continuity vertically and horizontally to maintain the integrity of the Eagle Roost.  Watershed benefits are improved forest health and protection of an important eagle roost.  OWEB funds are requested for thinning & hand piling (91%) and administration (9%).  Title II and USFSA are cost-share partners.

Monument SWCD proposes to address the medusahead infestation on 20 landowners encompassing approximately 1,200 acres in northern Grant County. Continued spread of medusahead is a very significant threat to the ecological integrity of upland ecosystems as it eliminates plant diversity and reduces wildlife habitat.  The applicant will identify, treat and monitor potential sites.  OWEB funds are requested for mapping (2%), project management (16%), treatment (40%), herbicide (28%), seed (3%), administration (9%) and monitoring (2%).  Cost-share partners include landowners, EOARS, NRCS and Monument SWCD.

Rudio Creek, near Monument, is a significant steelhead-spawning creek with the project site a primary access for livestock and wildlife to the creek.  This project will treat 200 acres of juniper, develop 2 springs, install 2 troughs, seed 80 acres, treat 180 acres of medusahead and install 2,500 of fencing.  Watershed benefits include improved riparian and wildlife habitat, water quality and upland vegetation.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (10%), juniper treatment (32%), spring development (26%) herbicide (20%), administration (9%) and monitoring (3%).  Cost-share partners include landowners and Monument SWCD.

Invasive junipers have impaired the habitat and water quality on the 1,100-acre Milk Ranch.  The proposed project will complete the final brush eradication plan.  Monument SWCD proposes to remove 157 acres of juniper and develop 1 spring.  Watershed benefits include improved water quality and upland vegetative habitat.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (1%), juniper removal (67%), spring development (20%), administration (9%) and monitoring (3%).  Cost-share partners include the landowners.

Project Name: Ridley Creek Improvement and Spring Development
Project Summary: Unrestricted access to Ridley Creek near Keating has created degraded riparian conditions.  Keating SWCD is proposing to install 1,100' of 5-strand fence along Ridley Creek, plant willow, red-osier dogwood and wild rose, install a 10,00-gallon cistern and 3 troughs.  Watershed benefits are improved riparian vegetation.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (6%), technical design (16%), pipe/installation (30%), trough/cistern (42%) and administration (6%).  Cost-share partners include Keating SWCD and the landowner.

Project Name: Five Point Ditch Diversion Improvement Project
Project Summary: A permanent diversion structure will be constructed near Halfway.  Currently, 10.5 cfs is diverted from East Pine Creek from May to October using a push-up dam, which can result in blocked passage for redband and bull trout (located upstream).  The diversion lacks water-handling structures that impact water quantity and temperature. OWEB funds are requested for project management (13%), permits (1%), contracted services (22%), materials (52%), administration (9%) and monitoring (3%).  Cost-share partners include USFS, USFWS, ODFW and 5-Point Ditch Company.

Project Name: Wheeler County Medusahead Containment & Strategic Treatment
Project Summary: The Wheeler County Medusahead Working Group will work to contain the spread of medusahead into uninfested landscapes by implementing a comprehensive weed prevention strategy.  Project components including herbicide treatment on 2,000 acres, mapping 25 sites and native seed application on 100 acres.  In addition, field trials to identify best treatment scenarios and continued mapping and monitoring will occur.  Watershed benefits include improved upland vegetation, water quality and infiltration.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (6%), mapping (5%), treatment (77%), administration (8%) and monitoring (4%).  Cost-share partners include Wheeler County Weed Department, SWCD, EOARC.

Project Name: Medicine Creek Bank and Headcut Stablization
Project Summary: Medicine Creek flows into Gordon Creek near Elgin.  A substantial headcut is creating excessive erosion and significant erosion.  This project will stabilize the streambed by shaping and grading banks to a 3:1 slope and installing 5 rock barbs for grade control.  The area will then be enrolled in CREP.  Watershed benefits include improve water quality and streambank stability.  OWEB funds are requested for survey/permitting (16%), contracted services (70%), project management (2%), materials (2%) administration (8%) and monitoring (2%).  The landowners are the cost-share partners and NRCS after CREP enrollment.

Located near Adrian, this project will help to convert 122 acres of furrow-irrigated agriculture into sprinkler irrigation to improve water quality and irrigation efficiency.  Project components include 6,152' of pipe, bubbler and flow meter.  Furrow irrigation results in high levels of irrigated-induced erosion causing increased sediment loading in irrigation drains that run into the nearby Snake River.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (2%), contracted services- pipe installation (10%), pipe 77%), administration (9%) and monitoring (2%).  Cost-share partners are the landowners, NRCS, Owyhee Watershed Council and South Board of Control.

This project is the second phase of a previously funded stream barb project completed in 2003 and proposes to treat 1,200' of Malheur River streambank near Harper.  Project components include 6 rock barbs/vanes and bioengineering including willows, currants, chokecherry and elder berry proposed for streambank revegetation.  Watershed benefits include improved water  quality, infiltration and upland vegetation.  OWEB funds are requested for engineering (22%), project management (7%), contracted services (24%), barbs (35%), plants (3%), administration (8%) and monitoring (1%).  Cost-share partners include landowners, NRCS and USFWS.

The Ecola Creek Watershed Council requests funding for the survey and engineering aspects of Phase 1 of the Highway 101 Recharge Restoration project that will restore tidally influenced wetlands to functional habitat for coastal coho and cutthroat trout within tidewater on City of Cannon Beach property. OWEB funds will be used for surveying; site and data analysis; design; permitting; construction oversight; project management; travel; and pre-construction monitoring.

This project would produce a fine-scale topographical map (as close as a 1 contour level) of the Salmon River Estuary by means of a Laser Imaging Detection and Ranging (LIDAR) survey. The fine scale topographical data is necessary for a number of purposes: determination of areas that will be tidally inundated following dike removal; determination of the types of vegetation that will grow at different levels in the estuarine environment; flood risk analysis on adjoining highways (101 and 18) and; determination of the effects of culvert installation under Hwy 101. OWEB funds will be used for the survey and analysis.

Lincoln County Public Works requests $1.2 million to help in the raising/restoration of the Devils Lake Road in Lincoln City. The project would raise the road out of the Rock Creek/Devils Lake floodplain, lengthen two bridges and restore the riparian community in the affected Rock Creek and Seid Creek sub-basins. OWEB funds would be used to share the costs of construction.

The Siuslaw SWCD, in partnership with the USFS/Siuslaw National Forest, Ecotrust and the Umpqua SWCD, requests funding to help in the development of a whole basin restoration plan, and start the NEPA process, for Fivemile/Bell Creek, the largest tributary of Tahkenitch Lake. The Forest Service has recently acquired a 640-acre former cattle ranch/industrial timberland operation which, when added to their existing 1,800 acres within the basin, provides an opportunity to plan, design and implement a whole basin restoration action. OWEB funds will be used for field surveys, data collection and analysis by a number of professional from disciplines including forestry, hydrology, fisheries, wildlife, botany, archaeology, and recreation.

Project Name: Clatskanie River Cooperative Resource Management Plan
Project Summary: The Columbia SWCD requests funds to hire a qualified environmental consulting firm to help with a detailed assessment and evaluation of the Clatskanie River basin and to help the Coordinated Resource Management (CRM) technical team develop a restoration plan for specific reaches of the river. The OWEB funds would be used for the consulting/engineering firm to provide cross section surveys; develop alternatives and review options with the technical team and; prepare final designs based upon options selected by the committee.

The Loomis Wetland project site is a 249-acre parcel that has been significantly altered from its original condition by diking, livestock grazing and channelization of three streams that cross the property. While other restoration work has already occurred on the property, this project proposes to focus on restoring native trees, shrubs and grasses to the property. The requested OWEB funds will be used for purchase of trees and shrubs, fencing and planting materials, labor, and project management.

Project Name: Coastal Windthrow Tree Salvage and Transport
Project Summary: The Oregon Wildlife Heritage Foundation (OWHF), in partnership with the ODFW Western Oregon Stream Restoration Program, is requesting $240,000 for a coast-wide project designed to fund the costs involved with the loading and hauling of donated logs and trees. The trees and logs become available opportunistically as a result of windstorms, roadwork, and development or land use changes. Projects similar in practice but smaller in scope have been funded previously in several different coastal watersheds. OWEB funds would be used for direct loading and hauling costs.

Project Name: Farmers Irrigation District Instream Leasing Program
Project Summary: The Oregon Water Trust requests $7,375 for a five year instream lease in parnership with Farmers Irrigation District.  The goals of the project are to establish a district leasing program to improve streamflow in the Hood River.

Project Name: Stewardship is Citizenship: the Deadwood Creek Restoration Story
Project Summary: In this resubmitted application, the Siuslaw Institute seeks funding to produce an attractive book (50 pages, 300 copies) that would tell the story of the Deadwood Creek Enhancement Project, an eight-year effort to implement a variety of restoration activities on the properties of eighteen different landowners in the Deadwood creek sub-basin of the Siuslaw River watershed. Using surveys and interviews to record and elicit participating landowners comments, the book would be designed to provide guidance for landowners and restoration professionals in recruiting, managing and rewarding landowners participation in ecosystem and community recovery. The majority of the funds (73%) would be used for staff to conduct interviews, photograph and write the book.

The Tillamook Estuaries Partnership, in cooperation with the Neskowin Regional Water District, ODFW and the Nestucca Neskowin Watershed Council, is requesting $142,808 from OWEB to address a fish passage problem on Hawk Creek, a tributary to Neskowin Creek in southern Tillamook County. A rock weir at the Water Districts point of diversion currently impedes adult salmonid passage and blocks juvenile passage to 1.5 miles of spawning and rearing habitat. The project would replace the rock weir with a series of 16 notched concrete weirs overlain with large wood. OWEB funds are budgeted for construction costs (71%) and the supplies necessary for the construction (26%).

Project Name: Building Citizen Stewardship in Local Watersheds
Project Summary: The Scappoose Bay Watershed Council proposes an Education project designed to raise the awareness level of local citizens about the need to protect local natural resources. The project would include four workshops on subjects such as water-wise gardening and landscaping, best management practices for small acreages, backyard conservation and invasive species management, and for developers: working around wetlands and floodplains. A series of trainings are proposed to complement the workshops, including sessions on native plant propagation, planting native trees, and making presentations to local government and/or community groups. Brochures developed around the workshop topics would also be created as outreach tools. The majority of OWEB funds (72%) would be used for project management, coordination and workshop development.

Project Name: North Fork Cascade Creek Road Decommissioning
Project Summary: The Alsea Watershed Council, in partnership with the Siuslaw National Forest, is requesting $80,838 to conduct a culvert removal and road-decommissioning project on Cascade Creek, one of the major tributaries of Fiver Rivers, itself the major trib to the Alsea River. One large culvert on the N. Fk of Cascade Creek, a total passage barrier to juvenile salmonids, will be removed as would seven other smaller culverts over 0.7 miles of forest road. 89% of the requested OWEB funds are budgeted for equipment time and labor for culvert removal and road decommissioning.

Project Name: Private Property Protection and Repair-Gnos Dike/Salmon Creek Marsh Restoration
Project Summary: The Salmon Drift Creek Watershed Council, in partnership with the Siuslaw National Forest, is submitting two proposals for two different restoration options on the same site in the Salmon River estuary. This proposal (Option One) would reconstruct a historic stream channel for Salmon Creek on the west side of Hwy 101 and north of the Salmon River; fill a number of drainage ditches remaining in the marsh by hard compaction; and rebuild a dike and install two tidegates for the protection of a private landowner. The failed dike was a component of an earlier Forest Service marsh restoration project implemented in 1996 and was a component of that projects agreement with the private landowner. OWEB funds would be used for construction of the dike and installation of the tidegates and the filling and compaction of the drainage ditches.

Project Name: Private Property Protection and Repair-High Marsh Restoration
Project Summary: The Salmon Drift Creek Watershed Council, in partnership with the Siuslaw National Forest, is submitting two proposals for two different restoration options on the same site in the Salmon River estuary. This proposal (Option Two) would place and spread approximately 10,000 yards of fill on 6.68-acres of private property immediately adjacent to the Forest Service 70-acre parcel of restored marsh just west of Hwy 101 and north of the Salmon River. The purpose of the fill would be to raise the elevation of the subsided private land to the level of that of a reference high marsh in the estuary that has never been diked and has not subsided. This filling effort is being proposed in lieu of reconstructing a failed dike on the private land that was installed by the Forest Service as part of an agreement to conduct a marsh restoration project implemented in 1996. This project will also fill the remaining drainage ditches in the adjacent Forest Service property and reconstruct a historic stream channel for the remnant arm of Salmon Creek. OWEB funds will be used for filling and grading on the private land (65%) and for monitoring of the reconstruction of the high marsh habitat (28%).

The Deschutes River Conservancy requests $863,534.00 of OWEB funds to acquire a short-tern instream water lease (10 year)in the upper Deschutes basin. The project proposes to lease 60-70 cfs or 18-25,000 acre feet annually, from seven (7) irrigation Disricts.  The ecological benefits of the project include decreased stream temperatures, improved riparian habitat and function and increased channel complexity.  Species benefiting from this proposal include redband trout, Bull trout, rainbow trout (Steelhead), chiselmouth, largescale sucker, Columbia spotted frog and the American beaver.  This proposed instream lease will benefit areas identified as high priorities in the Oregon Plan Streamflow Restoration Priorities document.  Partners include the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation, Portland general Electric, Avion Water Company, local irrigation districts, landowners, Oregon Water Resources Department and the local watershed councils.

The Nestucca Neskowin Watershed Council, in partnership with the Siuslaw National Forest, requests $44,185 to implement a large wood placement project in the Little Nestucca River basin. A heavy-lift helicopter would be utilized to place 35 large logs (average 110 ft long, 32 DBH) in 11 locations in a 0.7-mile reach of the mainstem Little Nestucca. An additional 5 similar logs would be placed in two locations in the lower 0.3-mile reach of Stillwell Creek, a tributary to the Little Nestucca in that reach. 91% of the OWEB funds are budgeted for helicopter move-in and flight time.

The Nestucca Neskowin Watershed Council is proposing to replace an undersized culvert on private land on Horn Creek, one of two significant Chum salmon streams in the Nestucca River basin. Horn Creek enters the mainstem at RM 3, just above Pacific City. OWEB funds are budgeted for Contracted Services (29%) and Supplies/Materials (67% - culvert & streambed simulation rock).

Project Name: North Beaver Creek Tributary Restoration Project
Project Summary: The Lincoln SWCD requests $40,172 to implement a multi-component project on a private property in Beaver Creek, a direct-to-the-ocean watershed, located about 7 miles south of Newport in the central coast. Beaver Creek is an extremely important coho stream and also supports chinook, steelhead and cutthroat trout. Restoration actions planned for the site include culvert replacement, channel reconstruction, livestock exclusion fencing and riparian planting. OWEB funds are budgeted for contracted services for all those activities (47%), supplies (21%), project management and staff (15%)

Project Name: North Beaver Creek Restoration Design Project
Project Summary: The Lincoln SWCD is working with private landowners in the North Beaver Creek basin, located roughly 7 miles south of Newport, to develop restoration treatments for a 2.5-mile stream reach. Technical Assistance funds are sought for the development of a topographic survey and hydrologic model of the reach in order to develop restoration actions/projects to discuss with the landowners and subsequently develop detailed restoration project designs and cost estimates. 84% of the requested OWEB funds are budgeted for a combination of surveys; model creation; restoration designs and drawings; and permit assistance. The remainder is budgeted for administration and project management.

Project Name: Kosydar Farm Riparian and Wetland Enhancement Project
Project Summary: The Lincoln SWCD is proposing to implement a multiple component restoration project on a private landowners property on the lower mainstem Siletz River. Restoration actions would include construction of 4,600 ft of livestock exclusion fencing; stream bank sloping with large wood, rootwads, rock and willow plantings to address a 650 ft stretch of eroding bank; riparian plantings of native trees and shrubs; and the protection and enhancement of 1.5 acres of wetlands. The majority of the requested OWEB funds will be budgeted for equipment time and labor (37%); supplies and materials (30%); equipment (8%); and personnel (10%).

The Coffer Ranch conservation easement is the first phase of a conservation program that will protect the outstanding natural and agricultural values of the Mill Creek valley from the continuing development pressure in Crook County, Oregon's second fastest-growing county from 2000-2006. The Deschutes Land Basin proposes to use $475,000 in OWEB funds to help purchase a $950,000 conservation easement on 330 acres, including one mile of Mill Creek, four large spring areas with 10- 18 acres of associated wetlands, 167 acres of prime agricultural soils, and other natural resources. The riparian and wetland communities are conservation priorities. This and subsequent easements will protect the significant restoration investments OWEB and others have already made in Mill Creek.

The Wetlands Conservancy is proposing a Technical Assistance project for the Yaquina River estuary and lower watershed. The goal of the project is to develop an integrated restoration plan for 8,000 acres of Yaquina River basin estuarine, wetlands and upland habitats. Tasks involved will be to collect and synthesize information; identify and prioritize conservation targets; finalize a conservation and restoration plan and; work with local landowners and other local partners in implementing the plan. OWEB funds are budgeted for in-house personnel (41% - information collection and mapping), contracted services (35%) (analysis, planning and prioritization), travel (10%) and administration (10%).

Project Name: Salmon River Fish Passage Barrier Assessment

Project Summary: The Greenbelt Land Trust is proposing acquisition of a conservation easement on approximately 76 acres of property at the confluence of Maxfield Creek and the Luckiamute River in Benton County, Oregon. This project is adjacent to the 145 acre Thomas Paine Farms conservation easement, located to the south, that was acquired by the Greenbelt Land Trust and funded by OWEB in January 2006. The Luckiamute Maxfield Creek easement will conserve 3/4 of a mile of river frontage along Luckiamute River and 1/2 mile of streamside habitat along Maxfield Creek. 71 acres of the easement area include a mix of habitat types including riparian, wetlands, oak woodlands, grasslands and potential upland prairie sites. These habitats are all identified as high priority habitat types in the Willamette Valley. A portion of the property, 28 acres, will stay in agricultural production with a mix of hayfields and pasture lands. Most of the 76 acres was enrolled in the Conservation Reserve Enhancement Program (CREP) in 2001. The landowner has installed a number of additional habitat enhancements on the property. A 5 acre portion of the property that contains a house and farm buildings will not be utilized for habitat conservation. Conservation goals are restoration and enhancement of the identified habitat types.  Estimated cost of the project is $275,000 with $200,000 provided by OWEB to cover the purchase price of the easement.

The Wetlands Conservancy proposes to acquire a conservation interest in approximately 61.5 acres of wetlands in the Poole and McCaffery Slough area of Yaquina Bay.   Fee title will be acquired for 11.75 acres and conservation easements will be acquired for two parcels totaling 49.6 acres.  The conservation acquisitions add to a previously funded acquisition of approximately 245 acres.

The project proposes to continue the successful riparian restoration program in the Applegate River watershed. Native tree and vegetation species will be planted along riparian areas with 303(d) temperature listings and salmonid rearing locations being the focus areas.

Project Name: Coquille Watershed Innovation Irrigation Efficiency Project
Project Summary: This project proposes to partner with five landowners to improve irrigation management and efficiency on their lands in Coos County. Conservation plans with on-the-ground-components and BMPs that specifically address limiting factors to reduce temperature, dissolved oxygen, sediment, bacteria and nutrients, as well as other resource concerns, will be developed.

Project Name: Tilbury Family Ranch Habitat Assessment & Ecosystem Restoration Plan
Project Summary: This project proposes to fund a habitat assessment and design a restoration plan for the Tilbury ownership, a 2,144 acre property in Northern Douglas County. A conservation easement is being donated by the owners to the Mckenzie river Trust. This plan will guide and encourage habitat restoration priorities to be included in the easement focusing on prairie and oak plant communities.

This project proposes to restore riparian functions along Anderson Creek, a tributary to Bear Creek, located in Phoenix, Oregon.  Activities include stabilizing the creek bank and restoring riparian habitat. Bank stabilization includes reshaping the eroded creek bank, installing coir wraps, and planting native vegetation following developed planting prescriptions.

Project Name: Jumpoff Joe "Ellison Watson Reach" Technical Design
Project Summary: This project proposes develop construction plans for a 300 ft. section Jumpoff Joe Creek, a tributary of the Rogue River, for the improvement of fish habitat and riparian forest development.  Designs will focus on stabilizing an eroding bank and reshaping the channel to restore flood plains and a stable meander pattern.

This project proposes to work with Jackson SWCD to recruit landowners along Reese Creek located in the Upper Rogue Watershed. Reese Creek is listed for high bacteria levels on the DEQ 303(d) list. Project work would focus on education about non-point source pollution sources and negotiating workable solutions to improve water quality.
This project proposes to develop an implementation plan to address water quantity issues on Trail Creek located in the Upper Rogue Watershed.

Project Name: RCC Urban Run-Off Water Quality Project 1) Assessment
Project Summary: This project proposes to fund data collection/testing for contaminants and development of an evaluation report for Rogue Community Colleges Grants Pass campus.

Project Name: Rogue Basin Fish Passage Action Planning
Project Summary: The project proposes to develop an action plan to strategically address fish passage improvement basin-wide through a prioritized approach which will be implemented over the next ten years.
The project proposes to support land owner recruitment efforts for the Applegate River Watershed Councils riparian restoration program.
The project proposes to replace three tide gates on Beaver Creek in the Coquille River watershed with more fish friendly designs in order to improve water quality and improve fish passage.

The project proposes to work with four private land owners to construct 6 miles of riparian fencing to exclude livestock from the streams and install off-channel livestock watering systems in Bear Creek on the North Fork Coquille River. The fenced off areas will be planted with a mixture of native trees and shrubs.

The project proposes to restore 175 acres of oak woodland, oak savanna, riparian forest and 1.8 miles of stream habitat to benefit several plant, wildlife and fish species. The work would take place in the Calapooya watershed located within the Umpqua River basin. The project will also serve as a demonstration site for outreach education of student and community groups for the restoration of oak and riparian habitats.

The project proposes to enhance 12.8 acres of riparian area on a 211 acre property on Roberts Creek within the South Umpqua River watershed. Restoration activities include riparian fencing, riparian planting, streambank stabilization, stockwater development and two stream crossings.

Project Name: Partnership for the Umpqua River Design & Engineering Support 2007-2009
Project Summary: The project would support design work for future restoration projects including instream restoration, culvert replacement, wetland restoration, riparian ad livestock projects and flow modification projects.

Jumpoff Joe Creek is a tributary to the Rogue River. It currently lacks large wood and other structural elements.  It has downcut and sidecut significantly in the past ten years, causing extensive erosion and sedimentation.  A 6,200 foot section of stream was analyzed under OWEB TA grant 207-011 to create a design to begin to address these problems.  The addition of large wood and boulders, combined with bank pullbacks and riparian plantings, are used in combination at four sites.

Project Name: Field Guide to Shrubs of SW Oregon
Project Summary: The project proposes to develop and publish and distribute a field geared exclusively to the identification of native shrubs in the Klamath Mountains eco-region. Despite the regions significance as a hotbed of biological diversity there is currently no such guide.

This project is a resubmit (208-2005). This project proposes to partner with five landowners on the lower mainstem Coquille River. The work would improve irrigation management and efficiency on their lands.  The systems will be designed to implemement BMPs resulting in reduced non-point source pollution and better habitat for aquatic species.

Project Name: Monitoring OR Coastal Marine Habitats to Examine Linkages to Watersheds & Upstream Land Use
Project Summary: The project proposes to monitor five Oregon coast watersheds and the adjacent marine systems at the watershed mouths to examine connectivity between watershed quality and intertidal marine systems.

The Applegator is an outreach tool of the Applegate Partnership and Watershed Council, promoting community and ecosystem health and diversity. It has had over 13 years of successful, community based-operations. It is distributed bi-monthly via bulk-mail ton7,600 rural households in the two-county Applegate Watershed.

The proposal will fund the second year of the Salmon Safe Applegate Cultivating Healthy Watersheds School Program in the Applegate River watershed. The number of participating schools will be expanded from four to five with additional grades being served. Salmon-Safe is an established regional agricultural certification program that emphasizes water conservation, soil conservation, minimizing the use of chemicals, livestock management, riparian restoration and the conservation of biodiversity. The Applegate has been a pilot program for the Salmon-Safe certification program.

Project Name: Upper Little Applegate Stream Crossing Restoration
Project Summary: The project would take place on the Little Applegate River system, a tributary to the Applegate River located in the Rogue River Watershed. Roads constructed in the upper watershed by previous owners in steep and highly erodible soils. The erosion. Primarily through mass wasting events, is contributing and has the potential to contribute large pulses of fine sediment to the watershed. The roads will be upgraded and road-stream crossings that have failed or are likely to fail due to undersized culverts will be replaced along with installing improved crossings, stabilizing adjacent slopes and providing adeqwuate drainage to ensure a functioning hillslope hydrology.

This project proposes to restore riparian functions along Anderson Creek, a tributary to Bear Creek, located in Phoenix, Oregon.  Streambank confinement and loss of vegetation from urbanization and residential development has greatly altered the riparian corridor.  The stream needs channel armoring, bank restoration, and planting to restore the natural function of the stream and provide habitat for fish and wildlife species.

The Watts-Topping Dam is a full spanning 4.5 foot high concrete dam that diverts water from lower Williams creek, a tributary to the Applegate River in the Rogue River Watershed. The dam diverts water into two ditches for the oldest water right on Williams creek and is a major fish passage barrier for adult fall chinook and all juvenile salmon year round.  It impedes passage for coho, steelhead, cutthroat and Pacific Lamprey. The proposed solution is to retrofit the diversion with a fish ladder, The design is being provided by Bureau of reclamation. The work is the result of OWEB TA grant #207-155.

Project Name: WCWC/BLM Joint Bill Creek Restoration Project
Project Summary: Bills Creek is a tributary of Williams Creek which is located in the Applegate river watershed in the Rogue River basin. The lower reaches of Bill creek in the Williams Creek Watershed are devoid of quality salmon spawning and rearing habitats due to past land use practices. The stream is considered essential habitat for coho. The project would place over 80 large logs into the stream at fifteen sites along a 0.4 mile reach.

Project Name: Ashland Forest Resiliency, City of Ashland Technical Assistance
Project Summary: The City of Ashland, contractors, volunteers, and concerned stakeholders would gain funding to collaborate with the Rogue-Siskiyou National Forest, to determine basic stand and site characteristics necessary to delineate units, write unit specific prescriptions, and for each unit determine optimal operational approaches, on site mitigation, and mark trees to be thinned as part of timber sales or stewardship contracts to implement the proposed Ashland Forest Resiliency Project across 8100 to 8900 acres in the Ashland watershed located in the Rogue River basin.

Bishop Creek is a tributary to Forest Creek which flows into the Applegate River, a main tributary of the Rogue Rover. Bishop Creek divides two pastures of the Hunter Ranch. This forces cattle to cross through the streambed when moving between the two pastures.To eliminate impacts from livestock activities to the stream, the project proposes to install a culvert crossing, move a fence and plant the resulting enlarged riparian buffer, fence and plant an upland area where pasture runoff collects before emptying into Bishop Creek, and develop off-channel watering sources

Project Name: Increasing Public Awareness and Knowledge in the Coos WS
Project Summary: The project proposes to place a RARE volunteer to initiate an outreach strategy in conjunction with the newly forming friends of the Coos Watershed group. The RARE volunteer will coordinate the delivery of a series of six general interest workshops on watershed restoration, lead at least three tours of restoration sites, participate in the coffee klatch program and prepare outreach materials. Four brochures on restoration success stories will also be prepared.

The project will take place on Deer Creek, a tributary to the Illinois River in the Rogue River basin.     The current channel is highly unstable, characterized by lack of a defined channel, radical shifts in alignment and an extremely braided nature. The Ranchs current water right delivery system  decreases the instream summer flow conditions.    The project proposes solution is to develop a downstream alternate point of diversion and water delivery system to increase the length of stream with water left in, gravel deposits will be reshaped into a meandered channel configuration with point bars, riffle/pool features and side-channels and large wood and boulders will be placed to stabilize and maintain the restored channel. Instream work will cover a two-mile reach of stream implemented through a three phase approach.

The project proposes to replace a culvert on a perennial salmon and steelhead bearing tributary to Grayback Creek a tributary to the Illinois River in the Rogue River watershed. The culvert prevents access to 0.3 miles of spawning and rearing habitat for coho. The current culvert (48 inch CMP) will be replaced with a 72 inch open bottom box culvert

Project Name: Jackson County Surface Water Monitoring Program
Project Summary: The project proposes to assist an ongoing project involving a real-time surface water monitoring network on high priority streams within the Rogue River basin. This project would provide water resource managers and the general public with the ability to monitor stream flow and water quality parameters on a near real-time basis via the internet.

Project Name: Myrtle Creek North Fork Stream Enhancement
Project Summary: Due to past management practices such as splash dams and stream cleaning efforts, the North Fork Coquille River lack the structure and complexity needed to retain gravel within the system. This project would construct 2 boulder weirs and 4 boulder clusters to begin to trap gravel and increase stream complexity within the reach.
