Rock Creek is a tributary to the South Fork Coquille River. The project reach is lacking in large wood, pool habitat, spawning gravels and has been over widened due to past management activities.  Twenty log and boulder structures are proposed at Rock Creek to increase stream complexity, connectivity to the floodplain and pool habitat.

The project proposes to construct four miles of riparian fencing on four private landowners properties within the North Fork Coquille and Bear Creek watersheds located within the Coquille River watershed. Additionally off-channel livestock watering sites would be developed and a mixture of native tree and shrubs would be planted in these protected riparian areas.

Grantee: Joe Merchep Umpqua River Foundation, Inc (JMURF)
Project Summary: Diamond Lake was treated with the fish toxicant rotenone in September 2006 to eradicate tui chub and restore the lakes water quality and trout fishery. The project proposes to fund a two day symposium at Diamond Lake to bring together experts related to the restoration of Diamond Lake and other water bodies to share data summaries, analysis and discussion.

Project Name: Umpqua Basin Fish Barrier Identification and Removal
Project Summary: The project proposes to move sites identified as fish passage issues through the Umpqua Basin Fish Access Team (UBFAT) process towards on the ground projects to improve fish passage.

The project proposes to funs the implementation of a native free tree program for landowners on coho bearing streams in the lower South Umpqua and Lower North Umpqua fifth field watersheds which include the greater Roseburg area. In the project area there are approximately 2,000 privately owned parcels that border 135 miles of coho salmon bearing streams.

The project proposes to enhance 12.8 acres of riparian area on a 211 acre property on Roberts Creek within the South Umpqua River watershed. Restoration activities include riparian fencing, riparian planting, stream bank stabilization, stock water development and two stream crossings.

Project Name: Diamond Lake Restoration Project Post-Treatment Monitoring
Project Summary: The project proposes to fund year two of the post-treatment monitoring of Diamond Lake. Since the treatment, the water quality recovery of the lake has been monitored to   document the impacts of the treatment.

Project Name: South Fork Deer Creek Restoration Phase II
Project Summary: The project proposes to install 25 fish habitat structures on 1.76 miles of stream in the South and the Middle Fork of Deer Creek tributaries of the Umpqua River watershed.
The project proposes to focus Partnership of the Umpqua Rivers (PUR) instream and riparian restoration efforts in the South Fork Umpqua River on multiple priority tributaries.

Coho, steelhead, and Chinook habitat is severely degraded in Lutsinger Creek, a tribury to the  mainstem Umpqua River. Most of the instream structure was removed by historic stream cleaning. The project proposes to place large wood and boulders back into over 2 miles of stream to increase the summer rearing and winter refuge habitats.

Project Name: Elk Creek Bacterial DNA Source Tracking
Project Summary: This project proposes to collect monthly water samples at various designated locations within the Elk Creek watershed, located in the Umpqua River basin. Samples will be analyzed using bacterial DNA source tracking methods (BST) to determine the species of origin.

Project Name: Post-Knotweed Control Riparian Restoration in the Coos Bay Heads-of-Tide

Project Summary: Urban storm water runoff has degraded Clark Creek, a former salmon-bearing stream running through Salems Bushs Pasture Park. The City of Salem proposes to retrofit a parking area and adjacent park with bio-swales, daylight a section of the creek, and restore instream habitat and the riparian area. The Pringle Creek Watershed Council will help to maintain the site over time. OWEB funds will be used primarily for contracted services and supplies and materials.

Grantee: Friends of Buford Park & Mt Pisgah
Project Summary: Friends of Buford Park and Mt. Pisgah seek technical assistance funding for developing a GIS database, processing and analyzing data generated through habitat assessment and inventory, supporting education and outreach, and prioritizing enhancement projects for the Howard Buford Recreation Area (TA2). OWEB funds will be used primarily for contracted services and project management.

Grantee: Friends of Buford Park & Mt Pisgah
Project Name: South Meadow Floodplain Enhancement Project Phase 3 (2008)
Project Summary: South Meadow is an approximately 200-acre floodplain site in Lane Countys Buford Recreation Area at the confluence of Willamette River and Coast Fork Willamette River. Modification of this floodplain habitat has been extensive. Friends of Buford Park and Mt. Pisgah propose to implement the third and final phase of hydrologic modifications in the area by 1) excavating a quarter-acre alcove, a half-acre inlet, and a one-acre side channel; and 2) revegetating 12 acres with native grasses, shrubs, and trees. These modifications are expected to improve winter refugia and rearing habitat for juvenile salmonids, water quality, floodwater storage, and wildlife habitat. OWEB funds will be used primarily for contracted services, supplies and materials, and effectiveness monitoring.

Clackamas River Basin Council seeks technical assistance funding for recruiting (TA3) landowners for future restoration projects along Deep Creek. The goal is to recruit 3-5 property owners where fish passage barriers are known to exist, and 10 landowners willing to participate in riparian protection/restoration projects. OWEB funds will be used primarily for contracted services and in-house personnel.

The once-abundant Columbia sedge meadows of the Smith and Bybee Wetlands Natural Area in Multnomah County are listed as critically imperiled by the Oregon Natural Heritage Information Center. This project builds on an existing restoration project previously funded by OWEB where Verde Native Plant Nursery crew members have removed invasive teasel and reed canarygrass and installed 8,000 Columbia sedge plugs. Verde proposes to treat an additional two acres in the same manner, using 5,000 Columbia sedge plugs one land cleared of invasives. OWEB funds will be used primarily for project management, in-house personnel, and supplies and materials.

Willamette Riverkeeper seeks technical assistance funding for assessing the physical and hydrologic structure of Norwood Island at the confluence of the Long Tom and Willamette rivers. The area is characterized by lack of shade, streambank erosion, and lack of channel complexity. The overall goal is to provide alternatives for restoration at the island and surrounding area. OWEB funds will be used primarily for contracted services and project management.

The Cardwell Hills area in the upper Marys Watershed has historically harbored high-quality native riparian communities of Fenders blue butterfly and its host, Kincaids lupine. However, the riparian area is increasingly infested with invasive plant species.  Marys Watershed Council has previously removed stream barriers to upstream use by cutthroat trout, and is now working to provide cooler conditions for these salmonids as they rear and spawn. The council proposes to control invasives and restore historic native plant populations on seven contiguous properties along Reed Creek and portions of the mainstem Marys. OWEB funds will be used primarily for project management, contracted services, and supplies and materials.

An existing eight-foot-high logjam behind six concrete pilings from a former railroad bridge 18 miles upstream of Ritner Creeks confluence with the Luckiamute River is a barrier to winter steelhead. The Luckiamute Watershed Council seeks technical assistance funding to assess and design the modification or removal of the pilings (TA1). OWEB funds will be used primarily for contracted services and project management.

Project Name: Salmon River Side Channel Fish Passage Improvement
Project Summary: The Salmon River has a limited number of side channels available for Pacific lamprey, spring chinook, winter steelhead, and coho salmon rearing and spawning. A box culvert on the privately owned Arrah Wanna side channel is a barrier to fish passage due to its narrow width and flat concrete bottom. The Sandy River Basin Council proposes to remove the culvert and replace it with a 20-foot-span bridge matching the widest portion of the stream. This project is a resubmission, this time under the auspices of the council instead of the contractor. The Arrah Wanna Homeowners Association supports the project and has provided cash/in-kind match. OWEB funds will be used primarily for pre-implementation, contracted services, and supplies and materials.

Project Name: Oaks Bottom Wildlife Refuge Fish Passage & Habitat Restoration Project Phase I
Project Summary: Willamette Riverkeepers and the City of Portland seek to provide fish access to resting and rearing sites along the lower Willamette River at Oaks Bottom Wildlife Refuge. Phase 1 implements a fish passage, floodplain reconnection/restoration and public stewardship project. Specifically, the applicant proposes to remove and replace a failed culvert with an open-bottom concrete box culvert, reclaim 4,000 linear feet of tidal slough channels north of the culvert, and restore 15 acres of wetland/emergent wetland habitat with native vegetation.  As an urban location, the refuge provides opportunity to educate the public about restoration activities. Eight outreach events are planned for school children. OWEB funds will be used for pre-implementation design work, project management, contracted services, supplies and materials, and post-project effectiveness monitoring.

Project Name: The Middle Molalla River Rehabilitation Phase I
Project Summary: The middle 10 miles of the mainstem Molalla River have elevated bacteria levels and temperatures, reduced riparian channel complexity, and high width-to-depth ratios throughout the system. Molalla River Watch seeks technical assistance funding for a systematic evaluation (TA2) of the middle reach of the river to determine prioritized sites for future restoration. OWEB funds will be used primarily for contracted services and project management.

Project Name: The Lower Molalla River Rehabilitation Phase I
Project Summary: The lower 13 miles of the mainstem Molalla River have the poorest salmonid habitat of the entire river. The lower reach suffers from excessive sedimentation from the upper two reaches of the system. There is a high width-to-depth ratio and streambank erosion. Pool/riffle sequences are missing, large woody debris seldom is retained, water temperatures are too high, and macroinvertebrate populations are low. The Molalla River Improvement District seeks technical assistance funding for a systematic evaluation (TA2) of the lower reach of the river to determine prioritized sites for future restoration. OWEB funds will be used primarily for contracted services and project management.

SOLV and community partners seek to develop and implement a riparian habitat restoration project on lower Beaver Creek in Troutdale from the historic Columbia River Highway bridge to the confluence with the Sandy River. Specifically, the project proposes to re-establish the native riparian plant community along 1,146 linear feet of Beaver Creek that is currently overgrown with blackberry. The applicant also proposes to increase stream complexity and canopy cover by adding conifers and native trees for future woody debris recruitment. The project is a continuation of a previously funded OWEB project, immediately upstream of the proposed new project location.  OWEB funds will be used primarily for contracted services and supplies and materials.

Project Name: Sauvie Island Drainage & Irrigation Canal Water Quality, Functions, Plant & Wildlife Improvement
Project Summary: West Multnomah SWCD seeks technical assistance funding to develop a hydrologic and hydraulic model of the drainages within the main levees of Sauvie Island Drainage Improvement Company; to improve water quality; and to better manage operations for weed control, sedimentation, and erosion. The goal is to have an action plan (TA2) for re-engineering drainage canals, reducing erosion, and creating as a result 15-25 acres of new wildlife habitat. OWEB funds will be used primarily for contracted services.

Project Name: Lower Willamette River Off-Channel Habitat Restoration
Project Summary: This project, at the confluence of Stephens Creek and the Willamette River, seeks to restore floodplain connectivity, habitat diversity, shoreline complexity, and off-channel habitat in a 3.5-acre area. Specifically, the applicant proposes to reconnect the site to floodplain wetland by removing a 280-foot decommissioned concrete pipe, re-grading the bank, and establishing native riparian plantings; to restore wetland and riparian habitat by removing invasives and revegetating with native plants; and to restore shoreline complexity and create off-channel habitat by installing about 95 logs divided into several complexes of 3-13 logs each. OWEB funds will be used for contracted services, supplies and materials, and some education and outreach.

The Slough School Education Program engages K-12 students throughout the Columbia Slough watershed in science education and service-learning projects.  The activities raise awareness of watershed issues while empowering youth as engaged citizens and tomorrows watershed stewards. Since 2002, over 23,000 students have participated in related classroom activities, field trips, and watershed projects.  The past successes of the Slough School program will inform the work in this project term, which will increase available educational opportunities, evaluate current practices and build sustainable future funding.  With this grant, the applicant proposes to support one teacher workshop and to engage 4,000 students from 25 different schools.  Metro Regional Government and the Cities of Portland, Gresham, and Fairview are partners in this project. OWEB funds will help assess the success of the first six years and build sustainability. OWEB monies will be used for: personnel, travel, production, and materials.

The Multnomah Education Service District (MESD) Outdoor School program provides a learning experience to over 7,000 sixth graders every year. Each class spends a week at one of the MESDs residential forest sites, immersed in hands-on science exploration and discovery in the natural environment of the Pacific Northwest. Youth learn about plants, animals, water, and soil by engaging with the world around them. The program partners with five local camps across two counties.  OWEB funds will be used to purchase water-study supplies needed by these sites: water turbidity kits, watershed maps, and laminated study photos of water invertebrates.

Project Name: Harmful Algal Bloom Monitoring in Western Oregon Watersheds
Project Summary: Freshwater algal blooms caused by cyanobacteria (blue-green algae) occur throughout the summer and are associated with anoxia and fish kills. Blooms are expected to worsen with global warming, and recent years, major blooms in western Oregon water bodies have triggered public health advisories against water contact. Apart from potential harm to stream ecology, blooms result in decreased water-based recreation and significant local economic loss. The applicant proposes a pilot baseline monitoring project in collaboration with federal lake managers (USFS, USACE) to begin assembling the first genetic (DNA-based) description of the major bloom components in western Oregon watersheds. This will enable (1) more accurate bloom identification; (2) discrimination between benign or potentially toxic bloom strains; (3) information on the relatedness and potential dissemination routes of cyanobacterial blooms in western Oregon. OWEB funds will be used principally for in-house personnel (post-doctoral researcher and a graduate research assistant).

Grantee: Friends of Buford Park & Mt Pisgah
Project Summary: With this resubmission, the project, located in Lane Countys Howard Buford Recreation Area along the Coast Fork of the Willamette River, seeks to restore nearly 40 acres of floodplain function. This will be accomplished by increasing the frequency of flows to a _-mile-long side channel, thereby allowing more frequent mainstem-side channel interaction. In addition, the applicant proposes to re-vegetate 4.5 riparian acres, restore prairie habitat on 10 acres, plant a native herbaceous understory on 16 acres in floodplain reforestation areas, and control invasives along eight acres of the side channel. OWEB funds will principally be used for contracted services, supplies and materials, and some post-project effectiveness monitoring to measure for, among other things, the presence, elevation, and duration of side channel flows; fish and bird presence/absence; and plant survival.

Project Name: Crystal Springs Culvert Replacement and Volunteer Restoration Project
Project Summary: With this resubmission, the project proposes to remove three culverts that are impassable for juvenile salmonids, restore 18.4 acres of riparian/wetland habitat, and recreate instream complexity along Crystal Springs, a major tributary to Johnson Creek and the Willamette River. Local citizens will restore native plant species by removing concrete blocks along the creek bed and invasive plants, and installing bareroot plants during eight volunteer events. OWEB funds will be used principally for contracted services.

This project, immediately adjacent to the Willamette River in Eugene, seeks to improve instream and riparian habitat for a wide variety of species, including Chinook salmon, western pond turtle, and neo-tropical migratory birds. A remnant of an aggregate mining operation, this ecosystem of ponds, channels, uplands, and wetland is owned by the City of Eugene, which over the past several years, has been working with numerous partners to improve the system. This project proposes to re-establish critical hydrologic connections between the ponds and the Willamette Rive, to control invasives, and to restore 46 acres of riparian and wetland habitats. OWEB funds will be used principally for contracted services.

Project Name: Middle Fork Willamette WSC Watershed Rangers Project
Project Summary: In 2006, the MFWWC Education and Outreach Committee developed a vision for providing watershed knowledge, awareness, and skills to rural elementary schools in the watershed. Watershed Rangers (the watershed education curriculum) is currently taught in one grade level in three communities. The curriculum is complemented by field trips focused on species and their habitats and building positive land stewardship through hands-on activities at select restoration sites. In 2008-2010, the applicant proposes to expand the program to approximately 400 students in grades 3-6 at the watersheds three elementary schools. Project partners include Lowell School District, City of Oakridge, BLM, USFS, US Army Corps, Springfield Utility Board and teachers/principals of Oakridge, Lowell, and Pleasant Hill schools. OWEB funds will be used for contracted services, project and fiscal management, supplies and mileage.

Project Name: Upper Willamette Landowner Recruitment and Floodplain Restoration Design
Project Summary: This joint TA#3 project in the Middle and Coast Fork Willamette watersheds will provide floodplain landowners and with professional facilitators and technical experts to develop and design floodplain restoration projects in the lower portions of the two watersheds. Project partners include the USACE, Willamette Riverkeeper, City of Springfield, McKenzie River Trust, and others. OWEB funds will be used principally for contracted services (landscape architect, geomorphologist) and project management.

This TA#2 project proposes to conduct hydrological engineering and biological assessment for the purpose of preserving, restoring, and protecting natural waterways, wetlands, riparian areas, and fish habitat within Tangent city limits and downstream. Tangent needs to protect the water it receives from the middle and upper Calapooia watershed and properly manage its runoff discharges into Lake and Oak creeks, which drain into the Calapooia.  The project will be built upon a foundation study The City of Tangent Local Wetland and Riparian Area Inventories Assessments Report of Findingsfunded by DSL for the City of Tangent.  Partners include Linn County SWCD, Calapooia Watershed Council, and ODOT. OWEB funds will be used principally for contracted services.

Project Name: Stout Creek Stream Restoration Project Plan and Design
Project Summary: This TA#2 project proposes to develop a restoration strategy for Stout Creek in the North Santiam Watershed, an essential salmonid habitat and 303(d)-listed stream. Stout Creek is also identified in the Draft ESA Recovery Plan for Salmon and Steelhead for restoration action. Channel incising has disconnected the stream from flood benches, and noxious weeds have disconnected it from meanders. There is a lack of wood in the riparian buffer for habitat complexity and stream shading. The completed product will create an opportunity to restore 2-3 stream miles, and to connect the creek with adjacent restored areas and existing high-quality habitat. Partners include NFWF, eight landowners (who are actively recruiting other neighbors), and various technical advisors.  OWEB funds will be used principally for contracted services.

Project Name: Snake-Deford Stream and Floodplain Restoration - Phase 2
Project Summary: This TA#2 project proposes to develop a restoration strategy for Snake-Deford Creek in the North Santiam Watershed. The project will build on restoration efforts under way on this essential salmonid habitat. Snake-Deford Creek is one of a few streams downstream of Detroit Dam with enough year-round flow to support a naturally rearing steelhead population. There is opportunity to add large wood for habitat complexity, connect the floodplain with the stream, restore and protect native riparian vegetation to provide shade, and integrate the watershed enhancement with the Mill City Storm Drainage System Management Plan. Partners include Mill City, Cascade Pacific RC&D, and 4 landowners (who are actively recruiting neighbors). OWEB funds will be used principally for contracted services.

Historical land use practices associated with agriculture and urban development have created a deeply incised channel bordered invasive plants and lacking a tree canopy along Ash Creek, a tributary to the Willamette River near Independence. Used by winter steelhead and spring Chinook as winter rearing habitat, Ash Creek lacks off-channel features and complexity. High summer water temperatures limit cutthroat trout productivity. In partnership with adjacent public and private landowners and ODFW, the applicant will reconnect the stream to its floodplain, create a third-mile of salmonid habitat, and establish a native riparian canopy on four acres. OWEB funds will be used primarily for pre-implementation and contracted services.

Use of a dry-season ford through Price Creek near its confluence with the Luckiamute River has adversely impacted fish passage, spawning and rearing habitat, channel form and function, and water quality. The project proposes to replace the ford with a full-spanning bridge. Partners include FSA and the landowner. OWEB funds will be used for contracted services and supplies and materials.

Project Name: Jordan Creek Fish Passage and Water Quality Improvement
Project Summary: This project proposes to replace or remove five fish passage barriers on Jordan Creek, a major tributary to Coyote Creek in the Long Tom Watershed. One culvert will be removed altogether, another replaced with a rocked crossing, and the remaining two replaced with appropriately sized culverts. The final barrier  an irrigation dam  will be replaced with an off-channel irrigation reservoir. The adjacent pasture will be renovated and cross-fenced. Project partners include NRCS and the landowner. OWEB funds will be used principally for contracted services, supplies and materials, and education and outreach. The project is a continuation of a previously funded OWEB project (#206-095), which was designed to restore fish passage on Owens, Coyote, and Bear creeks, increase instream habitat complexity and off-channel winter rearing habitat, riparian restoration and wetland enhancement, and restore a 123-acre upland prairie.

Project Name: McFadden Water Quality and Riparian Enhancement
Project Summary: The project proposes to enhance over a half-mile of Owens Creek and a seasonal tributary. Owens Creek is a major tributary to Bear Creek, which joins the Long Tom River downstream of Fern Ridge Reservoir near Eugene. Owens and Bear creeks are water quality limited with high levels of E. coli and high summer temperatures. The applicant proposes to install fencing, establish off-channel water, eradicate blackberry, and increase shade through riparian plantings. Partners include the BLM and the landowner. OWEB funds will be used principally for supplies and materials and education and outreach.

This grant will support one regional, one statewide, and two county-wide programs. The county programs include working with Benton County Public Works to develop a plan to meet water quality (TMDL) standards by expanding a vegetation management education program to all county residents. Regionally, the grant will support efforts funded by a secured DEQ 319 grant to develop landowner workshops, tours, and a video on best management practices for improving water quality. An existing Keepers of the Creek guide will be printed and distributed statewide via the OSU Extension 4-H Wildlife Stewards network and Benton SWCDs Making Ripples Program. OWEB funds will be used for personnel, development of education kits, printing materials, video production, and travel support for workshops and tours.

This project is a continuation of a previously funded OWEB technical assistance project (#207-162) to develop a design to re-open a historic side channel at the confluence of Gooseneck and Mill creeks in Polk County. The main problem lies with the main channel of Gooseneck Creek, which has eroded to bedrock. The applicant proposes to reactivate a historic secondary channel and to add structural elements (log crib structures, trees with root wads, boulders) along 480 feet of the main channel and along 400 feet of the secondary channel.  This will reduce velocities in the main channel and encourage deposition of coarse bed load, development of pool riffles and off-channel habitat for at-risk species, including winter steelhead, cutthroat trout, Pacific lamprey, western pond turtle, and red legged frogs. Partners include ODFW, BLM, Polk SWCD, and the landowners. OWEB funds will be used principally for pre-implementation, contracted services, and supplies and materials.

This TA#2 project proposes to develop a watershed restoration action plan for the Luckiamute Watershed Council. The action plan will detail a prioritized list of subwatershed, stream reach, and site-specific restoration priorities. OWEB funds will help pay for contracting with a multi-disciplinary environmental planning firm experienced in Willamette Basin restoration projects and actions plans; an outreach specialist who will conduct stakeholders meetings; and a project manager to ensure timely sharing of information between the parties involved and delivery of the various phases of the project. OWEB funds will be used principally for contracted services.

Project Name: Landowner Recruitment for Maxfield Creek Restoration
Project Summary: This TA#3 project proposes to recruit landowners for future restoration projects in the Maxfield Creek basin (6th field HUC) of the Luckiamute Watershed. The goal is to recruit 10-15 willing landowners to participate in riparian and/or stream restoration projects. The recruitment effort will be done in cooperation and with support from the Benton SWCD. OWEB funds will primarily be used to hire contracted services for the recruitment effort and to plan and design the individual restoration projects.

This 375-acre site in the Tualatin River Watershed was diked, drained, and tiled for crop production in the 1950s. ONeil Creek and an unnamed seasonal creek were relocated and channelized. As a transitional area between riverine and upland systems, a restored site has the potential to serve as a functional riparian corridor with substantial benefit to wildlife and to decrease sedimentation. Located just upstream of the Metro-Lovejoy wetland restoration project and within the proposed boundaries of the Tualatin River NWR, the site offers unique restoration opportunities. The USDA-NRCS purchased a permanent easement on the site using WRP funding. The applicant proposes to disrupt the tiling and plant nearly 12 acres of high-density riparian forest buffer and nearly 95 acres of low-density forest riparian buffer. Partners include NRCS, USFWS, Clean Water Services, and the City of Hillsboro (landowner). OWEB funds will be used principally for contracted services (weed control) and supplies and material (seed).

Project Name: The Middle Molalla River Rehabilitation Plan - Phase I
Project Summary: This TA#2 project, a resubmission (208-3021), proposes to conduct an Aquatic Habitat Inventory and Geomorphic Analysis to: 1) develop an understanding of the hydrologic dynamics of the middle Molalla River and how it is changing over time; 2) identify design options and restoration opportunities for stream corridor rehabilitation and floodplain reconnection; and 3) involve local citizens and other partners in creating a restoration plan for the middle 13 miles of the Molalla River. Project partners include: Molalla River Watch, ODFW, Clackamas SWCD, BLM, and the Molalla River Improvement District. OWEB funds will be used for contracted services, project management, and landowner outreach.

Project Name: The Lower Molalla River Rehabilitation Plan - Phase I
Project Summary: This TA#2 project, a resubmission (208-3022), proposes to conduct an Aquatic Habitat Inventory and Geomorphic Analysis to: 1) develop an understanding of the hydrologic dynamics of the lower Molalla River and how it is changing over time; 2) identify design options and restoration opportunities for stream corridor rehabilitation and floodplain reconnection; and 3) involve local citizens and other partners in creating a restoration plan for the lower 14 miles of the Molalla River. Project partners include: Molalla River Watch, ODFW, Clackamas SWCD, BLM, and the Molalla River Improvement District. OWEB funds will be used for contracted services, project management, and landowner outreach.

This TA#1 project will enable engineered solutions to fish passage blockages in the high-priority subbasin of Deep Creek. OWEB funds will allow four closely located passage barriers to be surveyed and engineering designs to be developed for the purpose of removing or altering barriers to salmonid fish passage for all life stages. Oversight and design collaboration will be provided by the ODFW, and the Clackamas River Basin Council staff and project oversight team. Concurrent coordination with diverse landowners, including state and county agencies, private businesses, and individuals will prepare for implementation of designs upon completion. Restoration projects resulting from the technical assistance grant will open miles of the Deep Creek north fork to federally listed Coho, steelhead, and Chinook. OWEB funds will be used principally for in-house personnel and contracted services.

Project Name: Clackamas River Basin Council Outreach & Education
Project Summary: The applicant seeks funding for continued support for two successful, broad-based programs in the Clackamas River Basin  Clean River Campaign and Stream Team-Stream Stewards. These two programs have engaged thousands of citizens in a range of popular hands-on water quality activities. The Clean River Campaign has included the annual Clackamas River clean up; the Stash the Trash program, which provides trash bags at key locations near the river; a childrens water festival (WET Day); a WET teachers workshop; a two-day Earth Day celebration; and Damascus Day Celebration. The Stream Team-Stream Stewards Program has included the Get Involved program, which teaches residents about the functions and values of a healthy watershed and engages them in various hands-on stewardship activities at restoration sites in the watershed. Such activities have included water quality, lichen, and macroinvertebrate monitoring; carcass nutrient enrichment; sustainable development workshops; and bioswale maintenance. OWEB funds will be used principally for project management.

Community Development Corporations (CDCs) sponsor affordable housing in every watershed throughout the Willamette Basin. The applicant proposes a one-year watershed education program that heightens watershed awareness among CDC resident communities through one-on-one conversations, flyers, photos, and other media; builds watershed knowledge among resident youth through a Classroom Watershed Curriculum; and builds watershed skills among crew members of the Verde Native Plant Nursery through weekly classroom training. Partners include Hacienda and Rose CDCs; Community Partners for Affordable Housing; Columbia Slough, Johnson Creek, and Tualatin River watershed councils, SOLV, and Portland Clean Rivers Education Program. OWEB funds will be used principally for project management and personnel to conduct outreach activities.

Agricultural conversion of wetlands and riparian habitats has impacted the Tualatin River, contributing to reduced function and processes important to water quality and fish and wildlife. Among many regional efforts to remedy these losses, Metro has purchased farmland that historically functioned as wetland and riparian habitat. The applicant is proposing to use OWEB funds to match secured NRCS and VEGBACC funds and pending funding from DSL. Specifically, OWEB funds will be used to restore 40 acres of native riparian forest along one mile of Tualatin River riparian corridor. Match funds will pay for removal of agricultural tiles, recovery of wetland function, and restoration of wet prairie/wetland vegetation on an additional 30 acres.

This TA#2 project, a resubmission (208-3010), proposes to conduct a hydraulic model of Norwood Island and a topographic survey. It will then use data from this exercise to develop some restoration options for the site in conjunction with several project partners.  Norwood is a large floodplain island that can provide multiple benefits for the Willamette River, seizing on opportunities elucidated by the Willamette River Basin Planning Atlas in this stretch of river.  OWEB funds will be used principally for contracted services.

This project on Fifteenmile Creek would construct engineered rock and log structures to reduce lateral migration of the creek and provide fish habitat. Fifteenmile is water quality impaired for temperature and sediment and it is has the easternmost run of ESA listed winter steelhead.

Project Name: Herbicide Use Reduction Program for Dryland Crop
Project Summary: This project would provide a cost share to dryland wheat farmers to use Weedseeker technology for herbicide application on 4,000 acres.  It should reduce overall chemical use on this land by over 3,000 pounds and serve as a demonstration to other operators in the Fifteenmile Watershed.

Fifteenmile Creek in Wasco County is the easternmost home to ESA listed winter steelhead.  This project would install five upstream facing rock control structures, and two engineered log structures to reduce erosion and provide fish habitat.

This would be a demonstration project in Mosier where there has been groundwater declines since the 1970s.  It would adapt existing plant nursery structures to catch and store rainwater, thus reducing groundwater usage by 40,000 gallons per year.

This project would restore 500 feet of McKay Creek north of Prineville.  The stream has been channelized and it has downcut  leaving 15 foot vertical streambanks that are continuing to erode.  The streambanks will be sloped back with a new meander bend and upstream facing vains that will alter the direction of the stream energy will be constructed.

This project would replace two of the existing four diversion weirs that provide fish passage barriers on the Crooked River just upstream of Prineville.  Spring Chinook and Summer Steelhead are due to be re-introduced into the Crooked River beginning in 2008.  The projects will provide upstream and downstream fish passage and screening of the irrigation diversions at these structures.

Irrigation tailwater from 3600 acres of farmland drains through the Cove Palisades State Park.  The water contains sediment and nutrients which enter the Crooked River arm of Lake Billy Chinook.  This project would construct wetlands, filter strips and ponds with a goal of reducing the sediment and nutrients by 90%.

This project would replace a 3,087 foot open ditch with a buried plastic pipeline that will replace two other points of diversion to provide controlled and efficient water delivery to 60 irrigated acres off Jack Creek, a tributary of the Metolius River.  This will enable the landowner to change from flood irrigation to pressurized sprinkler and stop the water from being diverted in the non-irrigation season.

This project would purchase a center pivot irrigation system and install 4,720 feet of  buried mainline to accept flow from a water supply developed by the landowner which would eliminate the need for irrigation tailwater to flood irrigate the owners 62 acres.  The tailwater from these pasture lands currently flows to Gate Creek and then the White River to the Deschutes River.

Project Name: Indian Creek Juniper and Grazing Management
Project Summary: This project on Indian Creek in the southern portion of Wasco County would take out 1,000 acres of post-European settlement juniper encroachment in order to restore the understory of perennial grasses.  The landowner would then start a post-treatment fire regime with a 10 year return interval to control future juniper expansion.

Project Name: Improve Grass Stands for Watershed Health
Project Summary: This project in the Bakeoven Watershed, a tributary to the Deschutes River, would help offset the cost of grazing CRP (Conservation Reserve Program) lands in order to demonstrate the increase in production that is anticipated from grazing these decadent native grass stands.  The subsidy the landowners receive for not tilling these highly erodible lands is reduced when the lands are grazed but the reduction is more than the revenue received from the grazing.

In connection with the removal of the Chiloquin Dam on the Sprague River and the construction of a new pumping station, the Modoc Irrigation District recognizes a need to improve its irrigation efficiencies.   This project would install upgraded water gates, culverts, flow meters and drain pumps to improve water delivery and eliminate discharge of nutrient rich tailwater into Upper Klamath Lake.

This project on Shitike Creek on the Warm Springs Confederated Tribes Reservation, needs restoration.  This project would create a new meander and stream function in an area now occupied by two former wastewater sludge ponds.  The ponds will be removed and the sludge removed as part of this project.

Grantee: Inland Empire Action Coalition - Klamath Falls
Project Summary: This project on the Sprague River would provide a low weir to re-water an abandoned oxbow for an off-channel rearing area for ESA listed Shortnose and Lost River sucker fish.  In addition, an area at the bottom end of the oxbow would be opened up to allow flow through the off-channel area.  Rootwad structures would be installed to reduce bank erosion and provide fish habitat and 14,000 willow and cottonwood trees will be planted to provide bank stabilization.

Project Name: Juniper Hills Preserve Old Field Restoration
Project Summary: This project would treat invasive species on 225 acres, and reseed the area to native perennial grasses to create a meadow habitat near the upper Crooked River.  The area was farmed but the water was taken off the area and now requires management to restore its value as a grassland.
This technical assistance project would investigate the feasibility of a wetland enhancement project to reduce nutrient loading of tailwater before it is pumped back into Upper Klamath Lake.

This project would add to the work already done to restore fish passage and wetlands at the lower end of Drews Creek near Goose Lake in Lake County.  The project would help complete the 7,000 feet of new stream channel that bypasses the earthen dam to provide passage during high flows.
This project outside of Lonerock in south Gilliam County would mechanically remove 435 acres of juniper on several different sites on four different land ownerships.

This project would treat an erosion problem coming from 125 acres in Gilliam County that is farmed for dryland wheat.  It would construct 12 terraces and rock check structures in the gullies to slow down overland flow, allowing sediment to drop out so it doesnt discharge into the John Day River about one and half miles downstream.

This project would remove a 9 foot diameter culvert that is causing channel widening on Lake Creek, a tributary to the Metolius River.  The road will be obliterated and the stream channel section restored.  Lake Creek is an historically significant spring Chinook and Sockeye salmon spawning and rearing stream.

This project in the Fifteenmile Watershed of 220,000 acres would engage technological methods of applying herbicides that have been shown to reduce application rates by and average of 66%.  The Wasco County SWCD has been successful in achieving a 90% conversion on the 100,000 acres of dryland wheat production to direct seed/no-till farming practice within the watershed to control sediment runoff.  This increases the need for effective weed management.  This project would demonstrate these farming practices on four farms totaling 4,000 acres.

This project by the Wasco County SWCD at the east edge of The Dalles, between the Columbia River and Interstate 84, would treat 10 acres of wetland to control and eliminate invasive plant species. Through the use of a flail mower and follow-up selective herbicide treatment, Himalayan Blackberry, thornless honey locust, Russian olive and reed canary grass will be removed.

Project Name: Herbicide Drift Reduction to Sustain No-till Farming
Project Summary: This project in Wasco County, proposed by the Wasco County SWCD, would install six telemetry weather stations so growers know the best time and conditions to apply herbicides so they dont drift into sensitive orchard or vineyard crops.  The adoption of minimum tillage practices to reduce sediment transport increases the need for chemically controlling noxious weeds.

Funding is being requested to publish 3,000 rural living handbooks for the Wasco County SWCD.  The handbook will cover such issues as water supplies, wildfire defense measures and other aspects of living in a mixed residential and agricultural area.  The objective is to inform landowners, particularly people just moving into the area, and protect rural lands and resources.

Project Name: Juniper Flat Water Conveyance Efficiency Investigation
Project Summary: The Juniper Flat District Improvement Company, south of The Dallas, has 35 miles of open ditch that loses 1,427 acre feet per year to seepage and evaporation.  This project would enable monitoring of water flow at different locations to determine the areas of greatest system losses so a mitigation plan can be developed to deal with the worst losses in a short time and within a reasonable price.  The Wasco County SWCD is coordinating this project.

Project Name: Lower Fifteenmile Instream Pool Habitat Establishment
Project Summary: This project east of The Dalles would improve floodplain connectivity and pool/riffle ratios in lower Fifteenmile Creek.  It hosts the easternmost run of winter steelhead.  Five V-weirs in a quarter mile of stream and two engineered log structures in this slow moving section of stream would improve spawning and rearing habitat.  The project is sponsored by the Wasco County SWCD but the USFS and ODFW are contributing time and materials.

Project Name: Off-Stream Stockwater & Riparian Protection (Upper Klamath Basin)
Project Summary: This project, above Upper Klamath Lake, involves two properties, one on Sevenmile Creek and one on Crooked Creek, that currently have to provide livestock access to streams for water.  Two new wells are proposed with piping to a total of five water troughs together with .5 miles of new fencing to restrict livestock access from Crooked Creek.  Sevenmile Creek is fenced but the gates have to be left open for the livestock.  The landowners, JaCox Ranch and Agency Ranch are working with the Klamath Basin Rangeland Trust on this project.  A total of 410 acres will be served.

The Klamath Basin Rangeland Trust has been working to implement land and water management changes in the Upper Klamath Basin for the past five years.  This project would support an outreach specialist who would conduct community meetings, grazing and riparian workshops, school field trips and a lot of one-on-one meetings with landowners to further the objective of improved resource management.  The OWEB funds would be used for personnel.

Project Name: Restoration of Native Fish in the Upper Sycan Watershed
Project Summary: This project would provide funding to develop an Implementation Plan to enhance the abundance and distribution of native fish populations in the 240,000 acre Upper Sycan Watershed.  There are several resource agencies and The Nature Conservancy attempting to restore the Bull Trout populations and control the non-native Brook Trout populations.  The TNC is taking the lead on this project.

Efforts to reach out to landowners in the Sprague River have been very successful in the last three years.  This model will be continued in the Sprague River watershed and duplicated in the Upper Klamath Lake area with this grant. Meetings are hosted by a landowner with lunch materials provided by the program and agency staff are invited to discuss resource issues and opportunities.  OWEB funds would be used for personnel and meals.

This project just east of Chiloquin would install 1.5 miles of riparian fencing and four water troughs and 2,000 feet of 1 pipe and a solar pump to provide off-stream watering.  The riparian buffer will vary between 50 and 200 feet.  The Klamath Basin Ecosystem Foundation will implement the project in order to reduce streambank degradation and improve water quality in the Sprague River and Upper Klamath Lake.

In connection with the removal of the Chiloquin Dam on the Sprague River and the construction of a new pumping station, the 5,000 acre Modoc Irrigation District recognizes a need to improve its irrigation efficiencies.   This project by the Klamath Basin Ecosystem Foundation would install upgraded water gates, culverts, flow meters and drain pumps to improve water delivery and efficiency.  The new irrigation diversion will be functioning in the spring of 2008 and the Chiloquin Dam will be removed in the summer of 2008.

Project Name: Ferel Swine Eradication in North Central Oregon
Project Summary: This project would use corral trapping, remote camera monitoring and aerial gunning to remove 500 to 700 feral swine from Wasco, Sherman, Wheeler, Jefferson and Crook Counties by the year 2010.  The Wasco County SWCD is leading this multi-agency effort to deal with riparian area damage problems in the target area.  Approximately 100 acres of damaged areas would be reseeded following eradication.

This project would trade water from Ochoco Irrigation District in Crook County with live stream flow in McKay Creek to convert 6.9cfs to an instream waterright.  McKay Creek is important to the re-introduction of steelhead to the Crooked River and, due to irrigation withdrawals, it normally has very low or intermittent streamflow during critical steelhead and redband trout life cycle periods.  This project will pay for final engineering, piping and a pump station.  Five diversion dams will no longer be necessary to divert irrigation water so they will be removed.

This project of the Upper Deschutes Watershed Council would engage 150 local students in six on-the-ground riparian restoration projects on Whychus Creek.  This will help, besides the restoration benefits, people to understand the importance of the stream ecosystem and the re-introduction of salmon and steelhead.  The area continues to experience growth with new landowners moving into the area and this project and the media coverage will increase landowner awareness of watershed management issues.  OWEB funds would be used for personnel and operating expenses.

The Upper Deschutes Watershed Council has hosted Riverfest for nine years.  A week of activities centered (hikes, tours, riparian plantings, river clean-up) around understanding and restoring the rivers and streams in the Upper Deschutes.  This project would provide continued support for this event while supporting 40 high quality watershed education opportunities during the 2008 and 2009 Riverfests.   OWEB funds would be used personnel, operating expenses and production information materials.

Juniper Canyon, a tributary to the Columbia River, has concentrated and scattered infestations of rush skeltetonweed and yellow starthistle.  These weeds pose a threat to the remaining native rangeland biodiversity.  Umatilla SWCD is proposing to treat 1,000 acres and introduce biological controls where feasible.  Watershed benefits include improved water quality and rangeland health.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (9%), treatment/application (47%), herbicide (36%) and administration (9%) and monitoring (1%).  The Umatilla County Weed Department, BLM,, BPA, Umatilla SWCD and landowners cost-share partners.

In the spring of 2006, a flood on Succor Creek near Rockville caused massive sedimentation and erosion, moving significant amounts of cobble and gravel.  The Succor Creek Irrigation District developed a plan to improve fish passage, channel and bank stability on 17 push-up dams. Projects components include ditch consolidation on 6 facilities; removal of 2 push-up dams; 15,840 feet of riparian fencing and bank stabilization. Watershed benefits are improved water quality, fish passage and channel stability. OWEB funds are requested for project management (2%), engineering (17%), contracted services (6%), materials-rock/pipe (70%) and administration (5%).  Cost-share partners include Malheur SWCD and Succor Creek Irrigation District.

Located near Arock, Malheur SWCD proposes to address water loss and impaired water quality by piping 6,640 of 2 irrigation ditches and converting from furrow irrigation to 3 pivots.  Project implementation addresses water quality improvement as outlined in the Owyhee AQMP.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (1%), survey (3%), materials (90%) and administration (6%).   Cost-share partners include NRCS and the landowner.

Wetland conditions will be improved along Succor Creek.  Project components include reconnecting Succor Creek to its historic channel; installing 6 rock weirs downstream of the diversion; engineered log jams and 10 rock barbs.  Watershed benefits include improved floodplain connectivity, water quality and riparian conditions.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (2%), engineering (29%), installation (20%), materials (41%) and administration (8%). The landowner is the cost-share partner.

Lack of upland water sources has significantly impaired the riparian conditions on the East Fork of Deer Creek. Monument SWCD is proposing to develop 3 springs; install a 1,200-gallon storage tank and 3 troughs; and juniper removal and follow-up seeding on 38 acres. Watershed benefits are improved riparian and upland vegetation.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (2%), contracted services (60%), materials (28%) and administration (10%).  Cost-share partners include NRCS and the landowner.

Invasive junipers have impaired the habitat and water quality on the 1,100-acre Milk Creek Ranch.  Monument SWCD proposes to remove 150 acres of juniper and develop 2 springs and includes rotational grazing system.  Watershed benefits include improved water quality and upland vegetative habitat.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (2%), contracted services (87%), pipe (2%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners include the landowner, ODF and NRCS

The lack of upland water and historical overgrazing decreased wildlife habitat near Monument. Project components include developing 4 springs and 1 pond; installing 5,280 of cross fence and juniper removal and seeding on 10 acres.  Watershed benefits include improved upland habitat and diversity and water quality.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (1%), spring development (44%), juniper removal (3%), fence installation (31%), pond construction (8%), field trip (1%) and administration (10%).  Cost-share partners include NRCS, Monument SWCD and the landowner.

Located at the headwaters of Rock Creek near Lone Rock, this project proposes to improve upland and riparian vegetation and habitat by installing 20.5 miles of fence, riparian planting and 16 water developments. Watershed benefits are improve riparian conditions, habitat and water quality.  OWEB funds are requested for riparian fencing (6%), plantings (79%), water developments (6%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners include NRCS, BPA and ODFW.

Project Name: Clear Creek Fish Passage & Riparian Enhancement
Project Summary: The 2006 flood on Pine Creek in Halfway caused excessive erosion and sedimentation in Clear Creek. The applicant is seeking funds for various diversions, fencing, planting and engineering. Watershed benefits include improved water quality, streambank erosion and riparian area enhancement.  OWEB funds are requested for rock (33%), engineering (18%), materials/contracted services (49%).  The landowners are cost-share partners.

A 4.5-mile stretch of the high-gradient Eagle Creek near Richland has been severely degraded from previous diking, periodic flooding, push-up dams and high amounts of deposition.  The applicant proposes to replace 3 push-up dams and 1 log dam to allow fish passage and restore streambank health and vegetation.  Watershed benefits include improved water quality and riparian vegetation.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (8%), contracted services (51%), materials (39%) and administration (2%).  Cost-share partners are USFWS, NRCS, CTUIR, WRD, ODFW, OSU Extension, Eagle Valley SWCD and West Eagle Valley Control District.

The project will complete a final design for a pipeline system allowing more efficient floor irrigation and eliminating 11 diversions on Wolf Creek near North Powder.   Future project implementation will result in fish passage, water conservation and improved return flow to Wolf Creek.  The new system will have the capability to floor irrigate during high spring flows allowing for significant groundwater recharge. OWEB funds are requested for project coordination (12%), survey & design (76%), travel (3%) and administration (9%).  Partners include Powder Valley Water Control District, NRCS and Union SWCD.

The North Fork John Day WSC is working with USFS permittees to exclude livestock access on Meadowbrook Creek along US 395.  Project components include 6.5 mile of fence and 2 water developments.  Watershed benefits include improved riparian habitat, streambank stability and water quality.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (6%), contracted services- fencing & water development (70%), administration (9%) and monitoring (15%).  Cost-share partners are the Umatilla National Forest, ODFW, permittees and NFJD WSC.

Project Name: Irrigon Relocation Lateral Two Pipeline & Pump Station Project
Project Summary: The existing lateral consists of 5,850 feet of open ditch and buried concrete.  The open ditch sections are conveyances of adverse water quality, seepage and evaporative loss.  The applicant proposes to replace the ditch with a buried PVC and also install a variable-frequency drive pump station at the head of the pipe to deliver pressurized water to 40 landowners. Watershed benefits are improved water quality and quantity.  OWEB funds are requested for project management/administration (15%) gravel  (15%), engineering (3%), pipe/fittings (65%).  Cost-share partners are the West Extension Irrigation District and landowners.

Project Name: Spring Creek Water Quality Protection Project
Project Summary: Located near Halfway, this _ mile section of Spring Creek, a tributary to Pine Creek will be enhanced.  The applicant proposes to install 2,640 of 5-strand barbed-wire fencing, riparian planting, 1 trough and replace and old wooden push-up diversion structure with a concrete diversion and fish screen Watershed benefits include improved water quality, fisheries habitat and fish passage.  OWEB funds are requested for engineering (30%), contracted services (11%), materials (58%) and administration (1%). The landowner is the cost-share partner.

Union SWCD is working with a landowner near La Grande to install 3 terraces in a wheat/fallow rotation to reduce rill erosion on a 30-acre HEL parcel. The riparian area will be improved by installing 300 of fencing to exclude livestock access and constructing a fenced pond with a trough for off-stream water. Watershed benefits include reduced sediment and nutrient transport, improved water quality, infiltration and riparian vegetation. OWEB funds are requested for survey/design (13%), equipment rental (73%), pipe (3%), administration (9%) and monitoring (2%).  Cost-share partners include Union SWCD and the landowner

Engineering services are sought to survey and design the conversion of 7,000 feet of open ditch to 5,000' of gravity-flow pipe near La Grande. Engineering expertise is needed to specify pipe size and material that will support heavy loads of street traffic. The new alignment will allow for the gravity-flow system.  OWEB funds are requested for education coordinator (80%), travel (8%), supplies (47%), brochures (29%), tours (19%) and administration (5%).  Cost-share partners are Irrigations Canal Company, City of La Grande and Union SWCD.

The landowner is proposing to fence a recently purchased property in the upper Grande Ronde to limit road access for day-trippers and hunters and to remove livestock access to McCoy Creek and unnamed tributary.  Project components include 11,000 of high-tensile fence.  Watershed benefits include improved riparian vegetation, reduced sedimentation caused by road use and the improved upland vegetative health. OWEB costs are requested for project inspection (3%) fence installation (21%), fence materials (69%), administration (6%) and monitoring (1%).  The landowner is the cost-share partner.

Project Name: USFS Road 4600-930, Chesnimnus Creek Crossing Design
Project Summary: Design and engineering is sought for a bridge or open-bottom culvert arch to replace an existing culvert where the USFS road crosses Chesnimnus Creek north of Enterprise.  The existing culvert is perched during late-season flows, blocking the passage of juvenile steelhead.   Funds will be used to coordinate designs with USFS engineering staff and use these designs to develop a bid package.  OWEB funds are sought for project management (8%), design (83%) and administration (8%).  Cost-share partners are USFS and Nez Perce Tribe.

Project Name: Drewsey Reclamation Ditch Fish-Friendly Diversion Structure
Project Summary: An existing check dam that blocks fish passage will be replaced with a fish-friendly diversion structure in the upper Malheur River, which supports bull trout and redband. ODFW will install a fish screen to ensure fish passage.  Watershed benefits included improved water quality and fish passage.  OWEB funds are requested for permitting/personnel (2%), contracted services (65%),  concrete  (25%), revegetation (5%), administration (2%) and monitoring (1%).  Cost-share partners are FREMA, USFWS, NRCS, Drewsey Reclamation Ditch Company and Harney SWCD.

A 28-acre parcel is one of the larger intact parcels near Ontario and will be enrolled in CREP.  The applicant proposes to bury 950 of pipe to convey water to a new diversion box; remove 1,000 non-native Russian-olive; install 7,500 of riparian and cross-fencing and 2 troughs; plant various grasses, wetland and riparian plants and install a way-station for migratory Monarch butterflies.  Watershed benefits are improved riparian, wetland and upland vegetation and improved wildlife habitat. OWEB funds are requested for project management (5%), contracted services (47%), materials (44%) and administration (4%).  Cost-share partners are NRCS, CREP, Malheur WSC and the landowners.

The 29-acre property sits on a flat bench above the Snake has severe erosion from flood irrigation, lack of windbreaks and soil types.  The applicant proposes to install 21,040 of pipe to facilitate the in stallion of solid-set sprinklers.  The landowner will also replant the alfalfa field and install a pumping station. Project components include 820 of buried 4 pipe.   Watershed benefits are improved water quality and reduced erosion.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (2%), pipe (94%) and administration (4%). The landowner is the cost-share partner.

The applicant is proposing to complete a topographical survey of 200 acres of former native grassland, emergent/wet meadow and riparian habitat adjacent to Willow Creek north of Summerville. Following completion of the topographic survey, recommendations for habitat improvement will be made and a restoration design completed. Engineering designs will be developed to ensure project feasibility and accurate cost estimates.  Funds are requested for survey and design (100%).  Ducks Unlimited is the cost-share partner.

Funds to inventory fish passage barriers in the Willow Creek watershed in Morrow County are requested.  When completed, the applicant will develop an implementation plan to remove them in a strategic and prioritized manner. Removing these barriers is necessary to restore summer steelhead access to historic spawning habitat and will improve access and movement for resident redband trout.  OWEB funds are sought for project management (4%), contracted services (85%), supplies (2%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners are Inland Empire Coalition, Morrow SWCD and ODFW.

Several partners are working to improve fish passage on lower Willow Creek in Morrow County to improve fish passage for steelhead and resident redband trout.   Project components include installing 9 full-spanning cross-vanes downstream of an existing concrete diversion dam to facilitate fish passage. Watershed benefits include fish passage.  OWEB funds are requested for design/permits (13%), project management (11%), cross-vane construction (62%), travel (2%), administration (9%) and monitoring (3%).  Cost-share partners are the ODFW, IEAC, Morrow SWCD and volunteers.

Juniper is encroaching the fenced riparian area of Fox Creek (west of Fox)and invading the uplands, changing the hydrologic and nutrient cycles; drying 2 intermittent streams and 3 springs.  The applicant will remove 400 acres of juniper and seed 380 acres in the uplands and 20 acres in the riparian area. Watershed benefits include improved water quality; improved riparian and upland plant communities.  OWEB funds are requested for project consulting (2%), juniper removal (73%), seed (10%), effectiveness monitoring (7%) and administration (9%). Cost-share partners are Hugh Barrett, NRCS, Vaughan Ranches and NFJD WSC.

The Oregon Aspen Project (OAP) is a new program seeking funding to recruit central and eastern Oregon landowners to commit to improving the condition and function of aspen habitats.  OAP proposes to recruit landowners by holding 4 stewardship workshops and conducting on-site consultations for interested landowners.  Project partners are Forest Restoration Partnership, OSU Extension, ODF, Oregon Rangeland Trust, NRCS and various WSCs.  OWEB funds are requested for project management/personnel (68%), workshop materials (5%), travel (17%), printing (3%) and administration (7%).  Cost-share partners include Forest Restoration Partnership and OSU Forestry Extensions.

Project Name: Remove Pushup Dams on North Fork John Day
Project Summary: Push-up dams are significant fish-passage barriers and a limiting factor for steelhead and Chinook production on the North Fork John Day River. This project will replace 2 PU dams with concrete pump stations.  Watershed benefits include improved water quality resulting from elimination of heavy equipment in the river; improved fish passage and improved streambed cobbles.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (4%), pipe/pump materials/fittings (86%), monitoring (1%) and administration (9%). Cost-share partners are Wheeler SWCD, ODFW, USFWS, NFJD WSC and the landowners.

Project Name: Clear Creek Fish Passage and Riparian Enhancement
Project Summary: The 2006 flood on Pine Creek in Halfway caused excessive erosion and sedimentation in the lower 3.2 miles of Clear Creek. This project addresses critical habitat for bull trout. Funds are sought for pre-cast concrete sill diversions, fencing, planting and engineering to be implemented along this stretch. Watershed benefits include improved water quality, streambank erosion and riparian area enhancement.  OWEB funds are requested for the diversion installation (99%) and administration (1%).  The landowners are cost-share partners.

In the spring of 2006, a flood on Succor Creek near Rockville caused massive sedimentation and erosion, moving significant amounts of cobble and gravel.  The Succor Creek Irrigation District developed a plan to improve fish passage, channel and bank stability. Projects components include ditch consolidation on 6 facilities, removal of 2 of 4 push-up dams. Watershed benefits are improved water quality, fish passage, riparian habitat and channel stability. OWEB funds are requested for engineering (40%), contracted services (11%), materials-rock/pipe (46%) and administration (3%).  The Succor Creek Irrigation District is the cost-share partner.

Wetland conditions along Succor Creek will be improved and sediment transport reduced  through streambank stabilization.  Project components include reconnecting Succor Creek to its historic channel; installing 6 rock weirs downstream of the a fish-friendly diversion; engineered log jams and 10 rock barbs.  Watershed benefits include improved floodplain connectivity, water quality and riparian conditions.  OWEB funds are requested for engineering (29%), contracted service (50%), materials (17%) and administration (4%). The landowner is the cost-share partner.

Project Name: Powder River Water Quality Enhancement Project - Phase #4
Project Summary: Cattle have unrestricted access to this part of the Powder River and the Baldock Slough near Baker City.  The applicant proposes to install 2.6 miles of fencing, 88,000 of 10 mainline, 19,200 of 3-foot PVC for laterals, 32 troughs and riparian planting.  Watershed benefits are improved riparian vegetation, streambank stabilization and water quality. OWEB funds are requested for project management (13%), engineering (12%) materials (67%) and administration (8%).  Cost-share partners include EQIP, DEQ 319, North Powder High School, Burnt SWCD and the landowner.

Grantee: Confed Tribes Warm Springs - Prairie City
Project Summary: CTWS is proposing to treat 1,250 acres of juniper to release sequestered water in the upland part of the John Day watershed.  Juniper will be hand-felled on multiple sites selected in accordance with restoration objectives and strategies of the NWPCC John Day Subbasin Plan, which identifies imperiled and priority watersheds at the 5th-field level.  All but the oldest age classes will be cut. Where appropriate, 2-6 mature juniper/acre will be left for wildlife. OWEB funds are requested for contracted juniper felling (100%).  Cost-share partners include CTWS and the landowners.

Funds are sought for the design of a bridge to cross North Pine Creek near Halfway.  Cattle are transported across the creek several times a year to access a USFS allotment.  The site was adversely impacted by the 2006 high flood event and deposition.  Funds are requested for design (100%).  The landowner is the cost-share partner.

The North Fork John Day WSC is working with USFS permittees to exclude livestock access on Meadowbrook Creek.  Project components include 6.5 miles of fence and 2 water developments.  Watershed benefits include improved riparian habitat, streambank stability and water quality.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (3%), construction labor (77%), materials (10%), administration (9%) and monitoring (1%).  Cost-share partners are the Umatilla National Forest, ODFW, permittees and NFD WSC.

A 2-year monitoring program is proposed for the 195,800-acre Pine Creek watershed near Halfway in Baker County.  Baseline data will be collected on instream habitat, noxious weeds, pH, DO, temperature, turbidity and riparian vegetation. Data collected will enable managers to prioritize projects and actions in 3 distinct reaches of Pine Creek, which has ESA-listed bull trout. OWEB funds are requested for project management (6%), mileage (1), contracted services (85%) and administration (7%).  Cost-share partners include Baker County, Powder Basin WSC, and USFS.

Located near Troy, the landowner is proposing enhance the riparian area along 6 miles of Mud and Buck Creek by constructing 7 miles of 4-wire fence 50 to 200' from the riparian area.  Other components include installing 4 watergaps, controlling weeds and planting native seed on 8 acres. The project is located on very steep, deep canyons, which have high potential to increase sediment loading and have large areas of non-native annuals.  Watershed benefits are improved riparian condition, upland vegetation and water quality. OWEB funds are requested for project management (3%), contracted services (83%) and administration (7%).  Cost-share partners include GRMWP and the landowner.

Located within the Indian Creek allotment in Grant County on the North Fork John Day Ranger District, this project will create a 110-acre upland riparian enclosure.  A 3-strand high-tensile, smooth-wire fence will be constructed on  Kelsay Creek, spawning and rearing habitat for ESA-threatened steelhead, Chinook salmon and bull trout.   OWEB funds are requested for project management (6%), fencing (82%) and administration/monitoring (12%).  Cost-share partners include the CTUIR and Umatilla National Forest.

Inadequate late-season flows are addressed by installing a conveyance system to pipe water from a reservoir to leaving water in Rudio Creek that would have been diverted in late summer. Rudio Creek is the largest tributary of the NF John Day and an important spawning and rearing habitat for spring Chinook.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (2%), contracted services (39%),  materials (34%), pump (16%) and administration (9%).

Located near Monument, this ranch has insufficient upland water and degraded upland vegetation resulting from historical overgrazing. The new landowner is proposing to improve watershed conditions by developing 4 springs and 1 pond; installing 5 troughs; installing 5,280 of cross fence; removing 9.5 acres of juniper and reseeding.  Watershed benefits include improved upland habitat, vegetation and diversity and improved water quality.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (2%), contracted services (64%), materials (23%), field trip (1%) and administration/monitoring (10%).  Cost-share partners include NRCS, Monument SWCD and the landowner.

Lack of upland water sources has significantly impaired the riparian conditions on the East Fork of Deer Creek. Monument SWCD is proposing to develop 3 springs; install a 1,200-gallon storage tank and 3 troughs; and juniper removal and follow-up seeding on 38 acres. Watershed benefits are improved riparian and upland vegetation, decreased soil erosion and improved water quality. OWEB funds are requested for contracted services (50%), materials (40%) and administration/monitoring (10%).  Cost-share partners include NRCS, Monument SWCD and the landowner.

Located south of Monument, an upland project proposes to install 8,900 of riparian fence, 8,510 of pipeline, develop 1 spring, install 4 700-gallon troughs and one 1,500 gallon trough.   This upland enhancement project will complement a recently completed OWEB small grant that created 3 usable pastures.  Watershed benefits include improved upland vegetation, infiltration and water quality. OWEB funds are requested for contracted services (61%), materials (30%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners are NRCS and the landowner.

Malheur County has 142,00 acres of heavily tilled row crops which require several passes using ground-disturbance equipment.  Funds are sought to develop 2-year field trials to do side-by-side demonstration of the conventional tillage and no-till methods; an economic analysis; directed multiple tours and education classes on the use of strip tillage.  The applicants propose to conduct 5 workshops; reach 300 landowners, 2 schools and develop 4 papers. OSU Extension and the SWCD propose to purchase a strip-till drill and a no-till grain drill for various demonstrations. OWEB funds are sought for travel (4%), tours (2%), equipment (93%) and administration (3%).  Partners include the OSU Extension, Malheur SWCD and landowners.

Located near Arock, Malheur SWCD proposes to address water loss and impaired water quality by installing 3,460 of 8 mainline to a pivot and a concrete pad. Changing from flood irrigation to sprinkler will substantially improve water quality. In addition, ODFW will study the effects of improved irrigation after converting from flood to sprinkler irrigation to ascertain if there are any impacts on mosquitoes.  A reduction in the mosquito population should have a positive impact on the sage grouse population by reducing the threat of the West Nile virus.  Project implementation addresses water quality improvement.

Project Name: Walla Walla Basin Photo Point Monitoring
Project Summary: The Walla Walla WSC is proposing to analyze 15 miles of stream habitat with permanent photopoints to document changes due to active or passive restoration activity.   In addition, 5 sites in Dry Creek will be seasonally visited to measure the effects of constructed ponds and 4 sites will be established along the Walla Walla. OWEB funds are requested for personnel (76%), supplies/equipment (9%), travel (6%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners are the WWBWSC, BPA and EPA.

Project Name: Medicine Creek Bank and Headcut Stablization
Project Summary: Medicine Creek flows into Gordon Creek near Elgin.  A substantial headcut is creating excessive erosion and significant erosion.  This project will stabilize the streambed by shaping and grading banks to a 3:1 slope and installing 5 roughened channel structures for grade control.  The area will then be enrolled in CREP.  Watershed benefits include improve water quality and streambank stability.  OWEB funds are requested for survey/permitting (16%), contracted services (70%), project management (2%), materials (2%) administration (8%) and monitoring (2%).  The landowners are the cost-share partners.

The Malheur Experiment Station is proposing to reach 250+ landowners with workshops that focus on the increased use of drip irrigation to reduce irrigation-induced erosion.  In addition, other topics will include practical guidelines for irrigation scheduling; the negative effects of phosphorous on water quality and increased plant and riparian knowledge.  Outcomes include workshops, field days, papers and presentations.  OWEB funds are requested for salaries (68%), supplies (19%), travel (4%) and administration (9%).  Partners include Malheur Experiment Station.

This project addresses water quality by converting 90 acres of sloped ground from flood to sprinkler irrigation.  Sediment is carried to the main lateral from 30 year-old cement ditches that are degraded, inefficient and frequently damaged, resulting in substantial water loss.  Project components include 7,360 of pipe, 2 bubblers, 3 wheel lines and a 15 hp pump.  Watershed benefits include improved water quality.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services (21%), materials (76%) and administration (3%).  Cost-share partners are EQIP and the landowners.

Project Name: Westfall Malheur River Water Quality Improvement
Project Summary: Malheur WSC is proposing to pipe 2,200 of open earthen conveyance ditch that carries water from irrigation districts main canal to an 88-acre parcel near Harper.  There is a natural spring at the base of the property that catches runoff and deposits sediment into the Malheur River 1,000 away.  In addition, 2,600 of fencing will be installed to accommodate a half-circle pivot.  Watershed benefits include improved water quality.  OWEB funds are requested for engineering (3%), contracted services (21%), materials (72%) and administration (4%).  Cost-share partners are EQIP and the landowners.

The Burns-Paiute Tribes is proposing to plant 372 acres, that was chemically treated in September 2007, of the Malheur River Wildlife Mitigation Site located near Vale. The proposed seed mix includes bluebunch wheatgrass, Sandberg's bluegrass and Idaho fescue to replace non-native species of medusahead rye and annual cheatgrass.  A no-drill will site-prep the area and a technician will spend 2 months seeding from an ATV at a rate of 15#/acres.  Watershed benefits are improved water quality, infiltration and habitat for the petitioned sage grouse.  OWEB funds are requested for seed (95%) and administration (5%).  The Tribes is the cost-share partner.

Project Name: Meeting Climate's Challenges, John Day Basin
Project Summary: The Oregon Paleo Lands Institute (OPLI) proposes to hold workshops to help OPLI understand regional threats, challenges and opportunities as a result of climate change, which is a major threat to watershed health as it increases populations of detrimental forest insects, disease and wildland fire risk.  Proposed tools include development of 10,000 pamphlets, 2 field trips, 8 workshops, a DVD film and interpretive display kiosk at the OPLI center.  OWEB funds are requested for project management/personnel (27%), travel (5%), productions (62%) and administration (6%).  Cost-share partners are OMSI, Wheeler SWCD, Wild Salmon Center, Sonoran Institute and the John Day Fossil Beds National Monument.

The applicant is proposing to install 3 pivots and modify a 4th.
