Project components include installing a permanent pumping station and flow meter; installing 2,360 of 12 pipe to transfer water from a diversion to a bulge; transferring late-season water rights and enrolling 45 acres into CREP.  Watershed benefits include improved water quantity, improved fish habitat, reduced erosive stream velocities and promote vegetative recovery.  OWEB funds are requested for personnel (4%), contracted services  (9%), materials-including pivots (77%), administration (9%) and monitoring (1%).   Cost-share partners are OWT, FSA, EQIP and LO.

Wallowa Resources proposes to remove 11 culverts; decommission 2 road beds; decompact, outslope, narrow and contour and harden 2 pond overflows.  There is high sediment potential from these unmaintained roads, which parallel Summit and Poison Creeks and a loss of floodplain connectivity. Watershed benefits are improved water quality and reduced erosion.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (12%), contracted services (79%) and administration (9%).   Costshare partners are Nez Perce Tribes, National Forest Foundation and USFS.

Project Name: Wal' a wa -Tamkaliks Side Channel Engineering
Project Summary: Engineering is sought on 1.5 km for the creation of a new side channel on the Wallowa River. The proposed project will divert a portion of the total flow into a new channel to create a more complex habitat.  Funds will also be used to complete the required permit applications and complete the final design.  OWEB funds are requested for engineering (91%) and cultural resource survey (9%).  The Nez Perce Tribes and the Wallowa Band-Nez Perce Trail Interpretative Center are the cost-share partners.

Project Name: Pre- & Post-RestorationMonitoring of 2 Headwater Projects in the Middle Fork of the John Day River
Project Summary: Extensive before-and-after monitoring of stream temperature dynamics using fiber-optic  temperature sensing and physically-based modeling will occur on the Middle Fork of the John Day.   Collected data - including presence/absence, instream habitat, riparian vegetation, water quality and quantity - will assess the efficacy of restoration projects in achieving reduced peak temperatures.  This efforts complements other monitoring funded by BPA.  OWEB funds are requested for personnel (48%), travel (15%), supplies (20%), equipment (8%) and administration (9%). CTWS and OSU are cost-share partners.

A fish passage barrier exists near Summerville on property owned by Union County and another landowner.  Discarded asphalt, rock and logs were placed in Dry Creek to maintain an historic irrigation POD.  Project components include removing the debris and installing 4 grade-control structures, 2 rootwads revetments, live-stake cottonwoods and seeding native species.  OWEB funds are requested for construction (92%), engineering (3%) and administration (5%).  Cost-share partners are GRMWP.

Bridge Creek WSC is proposing to remove juniper on 170 acres; reseed 110 acres; control weeds on 64 acres; develop 1 spring and prepare a grazing plan in the uplands of Thompson Creek near Mitchell. An extensive bitterbrush plant community is dying out from meadusahead rye encroachment.  Implementation addresses improved wildlife habitat, plant diversity, water quality and irrigation efficiency. OWEB funds are requested for  project management (3%), juniper removal (43%), seed (36%), spring development (8%), administration (9%) and monitoring (1%).

An undersized open-bottom culvert on Deer Creek, which drains into the Wallowa River near Minam, is a fish passage barrier.  A 3-foot waterfall over a log weir 15 downstream passes only adults.  GRMWP is proposing to replace the arch with a 23-span, 7 rise and 40 bottomless concrete box with wing walls.  The log weir will be removed and 248 of stream channel reconstructed with 13 rock steps throughout the channel.  Watershed benefits are improved habitat complexity and fish passage.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (2%), mobilization  (23%), bottomless box (66%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners are GRMWP, BPA and USFS.

A 3-foot rock-and-plywood diversion with no jump pool on Mountain Creek, near Mitchell, is a barrier to all stages of salmonids.  Wheeler SWCD is proposing to replace the diversion with driven a sheet-piling/rock-weir diversion and convert 500 of open-conveyance ditch to pipe.  ODFW will screen the diversion. OWEB cost-share is requested for engineering (20%), contracted services (25%), materials (46%), administration(9%).  Partners include BPA, ODFW, LO and Wheeler SWCD.

The current undersized squashed culvert on Bridge Creek is 14 wide by 10 high and has a 3-foot jump which is difficult for adults and impossible for juveniles.  Wheeler SWCD is proposing a 22' wide x 9' high culvert that will provide fish passage and will also add streambed simulation- rock weirs, root wads and tree planting.  Bridge Creek is the largest steelhead-producing stream in this part of the John Day subbasin.  OWEB funds are requested for engineering (2%), contracted services (88%), materials (1%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners are Wheeler County Road Department, BPA, CTWS (BPA), ODFW and Wheeler SWCD.

The property is located in the headwaters of Rock Creek in the John Day Basin, which is habitat for ESA-listed steelhead. Low stream flows, sediment and poor water quality will be addressed by project implementation.  Watershed benefits include improved water quality, upland and riparian vegetation and habitat by installing 18.5 miles of fence, extensive riparian planting and 16 water developments. OWEB funds are requested for riparian fencing (6%), plantings (79%), water developments (6%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners include NRCS, BPA and ODFW.

Project Name: Navigating the Dam Removal Permittting Process: A Guidance Document
Project Summary: This application proposes to develop a state-wide technical guidance document for assisting WSC, agencies, private landowners and other groups navigate the regulatory requirements for small dam removal in Oregon.  The technical document will be organized by regulatory agencies and will include a checklist and decision tree for dam removal.  Partners include Oregon State University.  OWEB funds will be used for project management, in-house personnel and travel.

Project Name: Evaluating the Role of Dam Removal For Salmon & Sucker Recovery in Oregon
Project Summary: This research will occur in both the Rogue and Sprague basins and will evaluate the physical and biological responses of these systems to dam removal.  The objectives of this research are 1) Determine the reliability of bio-indicators for detecting responses that are relevant to small dam removal;  2) Implement protocols to document the rate, magnitude, and spatial extent of dominant geomorphic processes; and  3)  Inform and link the science, practice, and monitoring of dam removal regionally within Oregon.  This work will result in an effectiveness monitoring document for dam removal.

The Wetlands Conservancy is resubmitting a proposal to develop a coordinated landscape scale ecological framework and plan to assist in prioritizing projects and defining restoration goals, strategies and performance standards for estuarine, wetland and upland habitats of the lower Yaquina River basin. The vast majority of OWEB funds (85%) will be used to pay for personnel, including a GIS analyst and mapmaker, a project manager, a hydrologist, forest and fisheries specialists, a conservation planner, and Wetland Conservancy staff.

In this Type II Technical Assistance project, Tillamook County is proposing to hire a consulting firm to formulate alternatives, model and evaluate those alternatives, and prepare pre-designs for three identified project components, in order to improve ecological function and reduce flooding in the Tillamook Bay watershed. Properties along the Wilson and Trask River floodplains would be affected. Partners in the project include the Oregon Solutions Project ($40,000 cash), Tillamook County, and David Evans and Associates (both in-kind support).

The MidCoast Watersheds Council is proposing a multi-component restoration project on 6 properties on Bummer Creek, a tributary of the South Fork Alsea River, located just south of the community of Alsea. Restoration activities would include fencing, planting, construction of large wood in-stream structures, construction of off-channel ponds and the replacement of two culverts. OWEB funds will be used for labor and materials for fencing (17%), planting (22%), large wood structures (8%), off-channel ponds (25%) and culvert replacement (8%). Partners include BLM (cash & in-kind), USFS (in-kind technical assistance), 5 private landowners (in-kind labor) and Farm Services Administration (CREP cash).

Ducks Unlimited (DU) is proposing to complete a hydrologic modeling, soils analysis, topographical survey and mapping, and partner/stakeholder coordination project with the future goal to restore 100-acres of former tidal marsh on Kerry Island in the lower Columbia River. Partners in this Type I Technical Assistance project include DU and USFWS. Ninety-four percent of the requested OWEB funding would be used for DU in-house personnel.

The Nestucca Neskowin Watershed Council is proposing a Type II Technical Assistance project that would produce a Limiting Factors Analysis for the Sand Lake watershed. The requested OWEB funds will be used for project management, collection and analysis of aquatic habitat data, evaluation of culverts encountered, development of GIS layers, and to prepare a report identifying factors limiting production of coho and other salmonids. Two restoration grant applications will also be developed as a deliverable. Partners in the project include Tillamook Estuaries Partnership ($2,000 cash), USFS ($1,000 cash), Demeter Design ($650 cash), OSU Extension, and ODFW.

The Necanicum Watershed Council, Weyerhaeuser Company, and ODFW are proposing a Type II Technical Assistance project to evaluate the effects of the windstorm of December 2007 on the Necanicum watershed. Aquatic habitat inventories done in 2003 and 2005 would be repeated to assess the changes to the system and re-evaluate the need for different types of restoration projects. OWEB funds would be used primarily (88%) for the costs of accomplishing the surveys and managing the project.

This Type I Technical Assistance project would design a restoration project to remove the existing dikes and utilize the resulting spoils to fill an excavation once intended to be another section of the Siletz Keys development. Technical expertise is necessary to determine elevations of dike grading and ditch filling with associated fill amounts. OWEB funds would be used for contracted services (91%) and administration (9%).

The Lower Nehalem Community Trust, working with the Upper and Lower Nehalem Watershed Councils and The Nature Conservancy (TNC), would use funds from this Type II Technical Assistance project to develop a Comprehensive Conservation Action Plan, following TNCs Conservation Action Planning process, for the entire Nehalem River basin. Restoration efforts previously accomplished in the basin have focused on fish habitat and have not generally addressed the needs of other species. OWEB funds would be used for project management (36%), facilitation (26%), a GIS specialist (13%), administration (9%), travel (4%), production (4%), equipment (Arcview GIS 9.3  4%) and meeting supplies (3%).

Project Name: North Coast Watershed Education and Outreach Program
Project Summary: The North Coast Watershed Association proposes to hire a 0.5 FTE position for two years to accomplish a variety of education and outreach tasks in their region. Tasks proposed to accomplish include: development of a native plant program based out of Lewis & Clark National Historic Park; establish native plant nursery plots at three local schools; maintain a volunteer water quality monitoring program and assess potential for another similar program; and produce five workshops that address local resource concerns for local landowners. OWEB funds are requested for personnel (64%), travel (12%), production (12%), project management (3%) and administration (9%).

This project will result in the removal of invasive shrub and brush species and replanting of native riparian vegetation on City of Seaside property along 0.5-miles of Necanicum Drive bordering the Necanicum River. At least another 12 sites along the Neawanna River totaling roughly 2.5 acres would also be cleared of invasive species and replanted with native riparian trees and shrubs. An interpretive sign designed to educate tourists and residents about estuary processes and functions and the benefits associated with riparian restoration would be developed and placed on Necanicum Drive at a highly visible location. OWEB funds are budgeted for project management and labor (57%), materials (16%), educational signage (11%) and administration (10%).

The Necanicum Watershed Council requests funding to implement a seven-year project that would monitor both the physical and biological attributes of three adjacent artificially constructed alcoves on the mainstem Necanicum River. The intent of the project is to evaluate the benefits of alcoves to salmonids relative to construction cost and to quantify longevity of the alcoves relative to accessibility to the mainstem and alterations in rearing surface areas as a function of time. OWEB funds would be used for contracted services (summer & winter snorkel surveys, summer & winter electro-fishing, physical site survey, flow monitoring - 84%), project management (7%) and administration (9%).

The City of Eugene requests $1,900,000 to purchase a 39.9 acre undeveloped parcel located on the west flank of the South Hills that include three streams, riparian forest, broad-leaf forested wetland, and upland mixed-fir forest.  Acquisition of the property will benefit multiple functions, including passive recreation, preservation of water quality, storm water retention, and habitat preservation.

Four restoration actions would occur on Boykin Creek, a tributary of the N. Fork Nehalem River, with funding from this Lower Nehalem Watershed Council proposal. Restoration activities included are: 100 key pieces of wood placed instream within the lower sections of the project reach; a fish-passage barrier culvert on a small tributary stream replaced at the confluence with Boykin Creek; a fish passage barrier created by a collapsed log stringer bridge on mainstem Boykin Creek would be removed and; invasive species of vegetation removed and native species of trees and shrubs replanted over roughly 11.4 acres of riparian area. OWEB funds are budgeted for contracted services (63%), materials (17%), project management (10%) and administration (7%).

The Siuslaw Watershed Council is proposing four restoration activities for a reach of Swamp Creek in the Lake Creek sub-basin of the Siuslaw River. Four undersized barrier culverts would be removed; 120 logs would be placed to create 18 in-stream structures; a wildlife friendly fence would be built around three pastures to manage and exclude livestock from the riparian areas and; 600 native conifers would be planted and maintained along the riparian buffer. OWEB funds will be used for contracted services (49% - equipment costs and fence building labor), materials (30%), project management (10%) and administration (9%).

The Tillamook Watershed Council proposes an Education project involving four middle school and six high school teachers and 280 9th and 10th grade Tillamook school students that will provide hands-on experience in the use of Global Positioning System (GPS) and Geographic Information System (GIS) tools and technology through the monitoring of estuarine wetlands and watershed restoration. OWEB funds are budgeted for supplies (56% including 10 GPS units, 12 pairs of waders 18 HACH Reagents tests, Petri film, etc.), equipment (18% including an oxygen probe and turbidometer), education coordinator (11%) and administration.

Project Name: NF Beaver Creek Tributary Restoration Design
Project Summary: The Lincoln SWCD requests funds to conduct a Type I Technical Assistance project to address problems in a severely manipulated and fragmented tributary of North Folk Beaver Creek, a direct-to-ocean tributary in Lincoln County. The proposed technical assistance provider would perform a thorough site survey and hydraulic modeling to develop a stream channel and crossing design to provide fish access and natural stream and wetland functions. OWEB funds will be used for contracted services (86%), administration (9%) and project management (2%).

This proposal would fund an on-going 10-year watershed education effort in schools in the region covered by the MidCoast watershed council. The focus of this program is classroom work and in-field work on stream reaches local to each of the schools. Classroom work is on basic watershed awareness while the in-field work covers a multitude of activities. OWEB funds are budgeted for salaries (83%), supplies (4%), travel (4%) and administration.

Four years of spawning surveys focused on coho and chum salmon in the Netarts Bay watershed are proposed in this application. The Nestucca Neskowin Watershed Council would hire a consultant to accomplish the surveys and involve Tillamook High School students in the activity. OWEB funds are budgeted for contracted services (surveys, landowner outreach, analysis & reporting  88%), project management (6%) and administration (5%).

Western Horizons Conservation Society (WHCS) requests $500,000 for the purchase a 7,820-acre cattle ranch, in Wallowa County, near Imnaha.  The ranch contains approximately eight miles of Imnaha River frontage.  Conservation acquisition will prevent all commercial development and restrict the use of the property to its current uses, which the application states are agricultural and recreational activities.  The application states that the acquisition will benefit Chinook salmon, steelhead, and bull trout.

Project Name: Elk River & Rock Creek Land Acquisition
Project Summary: Western Rivers Conservancy (WRC) requests $200,000 to repay loans it took to purchase a 170-acre property in the Elk River watershed, near Port Orford, in Curry County.  The application states that the property contains 80 acres of lowland riparian woodland and shrubland, 0.5 miles of Rock Creek (both banks), and approximately 300 feet of Elk River frontage.  WRC was required to act quickly to purchase the property because the land was on the verge of conversion to a rural home site.  Protection of the property will benefit OWEB priority species such as coho salmon and foothill yellow-legged frog.

The City of Albany requests $2.4 million to purchase 24.2 acres of undeveloped land in a residential area of North Albany.  The property is part of a remnant oxbow of the Willamette River.  The proposed acquisition contains OWEB priority ecological systems, including 4.25 acres of aquatic beds and freshwater emergent marsh, and 3.7 acres of riparian forest and shrublands.  The remainder of the property (16.25 acres) consists of a fallow farm field, which the application characterizes as eventual Western Oregon upland prairie and oak savanna.  The City of Albany will hold title to the property and manage it for multiple purposes, including wildlife habitat and education-oriented park space.  The project will benefit OWEB priority species such as western painted turtle and western pond turtle.

Three Rivers Land Conservancy (TRLC) requests $500,000 to purchase an 87-acre property southeast of Damascus, in Clackamas County.  TRLC intends to partner with Metro, which will contribute $112,000 to the purchase of the property.  The application states that the primary habitat of concern on the property is a 32-acre cliff, cave, and talus system.  Most of the rest of the property contains mixed hardwood-conifer forest.  Metro will hold title to, and manage, half of the acquired acreage; TRLC will own and manage the rest of the property.  The project will benefit OWEB priority species such as American kestrel and Townsends big-eared bat.

Project Name: Jumpoff Joe "Ellison Watson Reach" Technical Design
Project Summary: This project proposes develop a habitat restoration plan for a 2,700 foot section of Jumpoff Joe Creek, a tributary of the Rogue River. The project's goals are to improve habitat and promote riparian forest development.  Designs will focus on restoring stable flood plains, meander pattern and riparian vegetation.  The project will utilize bioengineering, riparian plantings, root wads, wood complexes, debris rakes, boulders, pointbar shaping, and bank sloping.

Project Name: Landowner Recruitment for Middle Rogue WSC Restoration Projects
Project Summary: The project seeks technical assistance funding for recruitment of landowners for future watershed restoration projects in the Middle Rogue River watershed. The focus areas are the priority sub-watersheds of Grave Creek, Galice Creek and Jumpoff Joe Creek.

Bills Creek is a tributary of Williams Creek which is located in the Applegate river watershed in the Rogue River basin. The lower reaches of Bill creek in the Williams Creek Watershed are devoid of quality salmon spawning and rearing habitats due to past land use practices. The stream is considered "essential habitat" for coho. The project would place over 80 large logs into the stream at fifteen sites along a 0.4 mile reach.

The project seeks funding for the development of  instream restoration project designs and obtaining permits for a project site on Kelly Creek, a tributary to the East Fork Illinois River located in the Rogue River watershed.

Project Name: Upper Little Applegate Restoration - Phase II
Project Summary: The project would take place within the Little Applegate River system, a tributary to the Applegate River located in the Rogue River Watershed. Roads constructed in the upper watershed by previous owners in steep and highly erodible soils. The erosion, primarily through mass wasting events, is contributing and has the potential to contribute, large pulses of fine sediment to the watershed. The roads will be upgraded and road-stream crossings that have failed or are likely to fail due to undersized culverts will be replaced along with installing improved crossings, stabilizing adjacent slopes and providing adequate drainage to ensure a functioning hillslope hydrology.

Project Name: Williams Creek 10 year Assessment & Action Plan Revision
Project Summary: The proposed Williams Creek Watershed Council (WCWC) Williams Creek 10 year Assessment & Action Plan Revision is an update of their current Assessment. The WCWC feels the current assessment is now outdated and  would like to revise the original document because some watershed conditions have changed in the past decade and many projects outlined in the Action Plan have been completed.

Project Name: Williams River Quarry Fish Passage Improvement
Project Summary: The project proposes to improve fish passage conditions at the Williams River Five Mile Rock Quarry which has been a long-running concern of local fisheries biologists and land managers. The Williams River is a main fork of the Coos River.

The project will take place on Deer Creek, a tributary to the Illinois River in the Rogue River basin. The project proposes to develop a downstream alternate point of diversion and water delivery system to increase the length of stream with water left in, gravel deposits will be reshaped into a meandered channel configuration with point bars, riffle/pool features and side-channels and large wood and boulders will be placed to stabilize and maintain the restored channel. Instream work will cover a two-mile reach of stream implemented through a three phase approach.

Project Name: Quartz Creek Fish Restoration Pilot Project
Project Summary: The project proposes to fund design work for in-stream fish habitat enhancement, riparian zone enhancement and water quality improvement in a 750' reach of Quartz Creek.  Quartz Creek is a tributary to Jump-0ff Joe Creek located in the Middle Rogue River watershed.

Project Name: Elk Creek Watershed Assessment and Action Plan
Project Summary: This project proposes to complete an assessment that will include all the land within the 187,000 acres of the Elk Creek fifth-field watershed, and to develop an action plan to prioritize the restoration actions of the Elk Creek Watershed Council.

Project Name: Williams River Watershed Fine Sediment Reduction
Project Summary: The applicant proposes to install 110 additional cross-drain culverts, replace 23 broken culverts, and upgrade six damaged or undersized stream crossings, including the construction of a 95-foot, full-spanning bridge at one site.  The project will address identified negative impacts of fine sediments on water quality and salmonid habitat from forest roads.

The project proposes to continue the "UR Watershed News" newsletter in the Upper Rogue Independent (URI) newspaper. The Upper Rogue Watershed Association (URWA) feels that  this method of information delivery is the most effective means of  communicating watershed issues. With over 14,000 papers mailed monthly, the URI reaches the most citizens in the Upper Rogue River watershed.

Project Name: Illinois Valley Riparian Tree Planting Project (two year project)
Project Summary: The proposed project will take place in the Illinois River valley located in the Rogue River watershed and will be overseen by the Forestry Action Committee (FAC). This tree planting project has been ongoing for the last 17 years and has provided 289,760 native seedlings for riparian and associated upland areas on private property. The project involves approximately 80 landowners a year. The FAC will develop a site prescriptions and assist in planting activities.

A Professional Engineer with hydrology background will be contracted to evaluate 1,500 feet of pasture-side riverbank on the Sixes River and to design fish habitat practices to improve habitat, reduce bank erosion, and promote reestablishment of riparian forest where erosion is destroying an existing CREP project.

The project proposes to develop solutions to loss of riparian vegetation and in-channel complexity throughout a more than 0.5 mile reach of Pleasant Creek, tributary to Evans Creek, located in the Rogue River watershed.

An unnamed tributary to Hill Creek, in the upper reaches of the Bear Creek Watershed above Emigrant Lake, is progressively eroding to the point where banks are incised up to 20 feet in places. Technical assistance is needed to survey the incised creek and determine the rate and reasons for stream incision as well as to design a restoration plan for this creek.

The project proposes to develop an outreach program aimed at the adult residents of the Williams Creek Watershed. Williams Creek is a tributary to the Applegate River, located in the Rogue River watershed.  This program will provide long-term  education and outreach tools such as an updated webpage; a portable display and brochure; 4 direct mailings; monthly newspaper articles (24 over two years), a 20-minute reproducible DVD on issues relating to the Williams Creek Watershed; and hands-on learning opportunities including 8 workshops/speaker's forums, 6 restoration site tours, 4 watershed tours. These efforts will help residents increase their knowledge and participation in addressing watershed-related issues.

This project proposes to conduct pre and post project effectiveness monitoring on the instream, riparian and fish passage projects implemented by the Coquille Watershed Association, to determine if the short term and long term objectives of the biological and physical aspects are being achieved.

The project proposes to replace a culver located at the mouth of Williams Creek, a tributary to the North Fork Umpqua River. This culvert is located at milepost 37 on State highway 138, east of Roseburg. The existing concrete box culvert at Williams Creek was constructed in 1960 and is near its 50-year design life. Pre-project monitoring indicates the culvert is a partial barrier to adult anadromous fish at low flows and does not pass juvenile fish upstream. If the culvert were corrected, an additional 4.37 miles of habitat would be made accessible to Oregon coastal coho, chinook, steelhead and coastal cutthroat trout.

Hall Creek and Hoot-n-Holler Creek are tributaries to South Fork Deer Creek in the Umpqua River watershed. Both streams lack habitat complexity, are incised, flow is intermittent, and very few complex pools are present. The proposed solution to this problem is the addition of boulders and full trees with rootwads attached along a one-half mile reach of each stream.

Project Name: West Fork Windy Creek Fish Passage
Project Summary: West Fork Windy Creek is a tributary of Middle Cow Creek located in the Umpqua River watershed. The project proposes to replace two culverts which block fish passage. The habitat opened up by this project is high quality and the work will provide an additional two miles of spawning, winter refuge and summer rearing habitat.

The purpose of this project is to keep three USGS stream gages located on important salmon and steelhead streams in the Umpqua River basin active for two more years. The gages play an important role in monitoring the effects of high streamflows and floods on existing instream projects within the vicinity of the gages.

The project proposes to remove two culverts and add large wood to help restore instream habitat functions on Billy Creek, a tributary to Elk Creek in the Umpqua River basin. The project will improve fish access and help restore complex habitat for juvenile coho, steelhead, and cutthroat trout.

Project Name: Coho Life History in Tide Gated Coastal Lowland Streams
Project Summary: The proposed effort is a continuation of a long-term monitoring study initiated in 2004 by the Coos Watershed Association to describe coho survival and production in two tide gated coastal lowland streams.  Coho abundance, distribution and movement will be monitored in each stream to identify freshwater and marine survival of each coho population, describe seasonal habitat use in each basin, and to describe potential differences in coho movement and passage patterns in the two streams.

The project proposes to fund the Coos Watershed Technical Science Education Training (WTSET) program. The project intends, through a process  of outreach and needs assessment, to deliver a program of landowner meetings, teacher training workshops, summer camps, and an education outreach event that the applicant will use to expand awareness and facilitate improved stewardship of the Coos watershed.

The Applegate Partnership and Watershed Council proposes to plant native trees and shrubs along those streams listed for excessive temperature within the Applegate River watershed. This project will continue their ongoing riparian restoration program.

Project Name: Salemtowne Fish Passage and Water Quality Improvement Project
Project Summary: This TA#1 project proposes to conduct a feasibility study on two-three options for improving fish passage and water quality on lower Gibson Creek in the Salemtowne community. A small dam and deteriorating fish way are impassable. The stream is designated migration and rearing habitat for winter steelhead and is used by a variety of other native fish. The options under consideration are: 1) Remove the existing dam and non-functional fish way and restore a wetland and sinuous stream channel; 2) Retrofit or replace the existing fish way to restore passage and enhance the riparian area; and  3) Construct a step-pool bypass channel that creates passage around the existing area and enhance the riparian area. The council will work with landowners and project partners to determine the preferred option, and the engineering firm will design the selected option. OWEB funds will be used to contract with an environmental engineering firm to do the feasibility study. Partners include: ODFW, NFWF, Salemtowne Association, and the City of Salem.

Pringle Creek, from its confluence with the Willamette River to the upstream side of the Commercial Street culvert, has suffered much degradation to fish habitat. This TA#1 project proposes to review previous restoration designs and provide new site-specific designs where none now exist, to address all fish habitat/passage/stormwater issues along this five-mile length of stream. Partners include City of Salem Public Works and Fernwood Environmental Services. OWEB funds will primarily be used to contract for environmental engineering services.

The Conservation Reserve Enhancement Program (CREP) Technical Assistant Project being proposed will work toward restoration and enhancement of riparian habitats within four watersheds of the Upper Willamette Basin. These watersheds all exceed state water quality standards for temperatures due to inadequate riparian shade and stream channel widening. Erosion, sedimentation, nutrient infiltration, and presence of fecal coliform and invasive/noxious weeds, are all known limiting factors within these watersheds. The applicant proposes to enroll landowners in CREP by distributing CREP newsletters and conducting landowner workshops. Partners include: NRCS, ODF, EWEB, and FSA. OWEB funds will principally be used to pay for the applicant's time to administer the effort through 2010.

Lack of access to suitable spawning and rearing habitat is a major limiting factor in the population success of federally listed Coho, Chinook, and steelhead in the Clackamas River Basin. The applicant has identified three fish barriers in the Deep Creek subwatershed: a concrete weir, a culvert, and a dam with spillboards. Due to their complexity, all three require engineered solutions. OWEB funds will primarily be used to contract for a site survey, sediment analysis, an examination of alternatives, permitting, and the final design process to remove the fish barriers. Opening this area will allow additional habitat for numerous Coho spawning and rearing in the stream. Partners include Clackamas County Water and Environmental Services and ODFW.

Riparian shade and structure is lacking in many significant parts of the Clackamas River Basin. Deep Creek, a large producer of Coho and other salmonids, lacks riparian cover in many locations. The applicant will recruit landowners to allow riparian tree planting on approximately one mile of streamside properties to provide shade to Deep Creek. Native trees and shrubs will be planted and their survival monitored. OWEB funds will allow expansion of a current program planting in two sub-watersheds within the Urban Growth Boundary, and will match support for crew and plant materials.

Grantee: Friends of Buford Park & Mt Pisgah
Project Name: South Meadow Floodplain Enhancement Phase III
Project Summary: With this resubmission (208-3006 and 208-3042), the project, located in Lane County's Howard Buford Recreation Area along the Coast Fork of the Willamette River, seeks to restore nearly 40 acres of floodplain function. This will be accomplished by increasing the frequency of flows to a _-mile-long side channel, thereby allowing more frequent mainstem-side channel interaction. In addition, the applicant proposes to re-vegetate 4.5 riparian acres, restore prairie habitat on 10 acres, plant a native herbaceous understory on 16 acres in floodplain reforestation areas, and control invasives along eight acres of the side channel. OWEB funds will principally be used for contracted services, supplies and materials, and some post-project effectiveness monitoring to measure for, among other things, the presence, elevation, and duration of side channel flows; fish and bird presence/absence; and plant survival.

Project Name: School District Recruitment, Restoration Design, and Stormwater Management
Project Summary: This TA#2 project proposes to develop habitat enhancement and stormwater management plans for two secondary schools in Eugene. The applicant will recruit the local school districts to manage open space on the campuses as habitat and to implement stormwater best management practices to reduce adverse impacts to downstream water quality. OWEB funds will primarily be used for contracted services to conduct various assessments and action plan.

Project Name: Jordan Creek Fish Passage and Off-Channel Irrigation Design
Project Summary: Four existing culverts and an irrigation dam currently block fish passage on Jordan Creek, a tributary to Coyote Creek. This TA#1 project proposes to 1) develop designs and specifications for passable crossings at three locations and for culvert removal at one location; and 2) develop a passage design and off-channel irrigation solution for the existing instream irrigation impoundment. OWEB funds will primarily be used for contracted services to develop the designs.

Mosby Creek is a high-priority, undammed tributary of the Row River/Coast Fork Willamette, with a documented lack of complexity, suitable spawning, and early rearing habitat for salmonids. This TA#1 Project proposes to develop designs for instream habitat structures to increase overall instream complexity and to recruit spawning gravels along 4.5 miles of Mosby Creek. OWEB funds will primarily be used for contracted services to develop the designs.

The Coast Fork Fish Passage Technical Group seeks to develop a prioritized database of fish passage barriers throughout the Coast Fork Willamette Watershed, excluding BLM and USFS lands. The objectives of this TA#2 are to:  1) prioritize fish habitat above potential passage barriers,  2) evaluate on-site the top 25 potential barriers,  3) create an accessible database format,  4) create GIS maps that illustrate the barriers and their priority rankings, and  5) make recommendations for replacement and correction. OWEB funds will primarily be used for contracted services to develop the assessment and action plan.

Project Name: Monitoring Heavy Metal Exposure in the Willamette River Basin Using Freshwater Mussel Shells
Project Summary: Heavy metal contaminants threaten fish, human, and ecosystem health, and are considered a source of water quality impairment in the Willamette River Basin.  Studies linking bio-indicator species with spatial and temporal trends have not been well documented.  The western pearl mussel (Margaritifera falcata) is long-lived and can tolerate heavy metal concentrations at low levels.  Their role as bio-monitors of past exposure and future restoration success is under utilized.  This proposal will develop a monitoring technique using M. falcata shells in assessing historical and prospective levels of heavy metal exposure at five study sites in the Willamette Basin.  Partners include Oregon State University and U.S. Geological Survey.  OWEB funds will be used for staff time, monitoring equipment, and sample processing.

This TA #1 project will evaluate and design fish passage to the upper reaches of Forestry Creek, a tributary to Rickreall Creek in Dallas.  Forestry Creek has been straightened and altered from its historic alignment, and the current alignment poses a total barrier to fish passage at the creeks confluence with Rickreall Creek.  The historic channel and alignment of Forestry Creek is still present; however, several road-stream interfaces present barriers to fish migration in the historic channel.  An analysis of several passage alternatives will aid in the development of a final design for the passage.  Partners include the City of Dallas and the Rickreall Watershed Foundation. OWEB funds will be used for engineering survey and design and project management.

This project, located on Blair Creek in the lower Greasy Creek subbasin of the Marys River Watershed, will remedy in-stream habitat connectivity limitations within Blair Creek by replacing culverts within a 1.3 mile reach.  Restoration of fish passage within this creek was initiated by the Benton Soil and Water Conservation Districts Fish Passage Improvement Program surveys of culverts in 2007.  In spring 2008, OWEB funded the replacement of two culverts in the subbasin.  This investment was followed by Oregon Trout funding the development of engineering designs for eight private culverts and removal of three additional barriers.  Major partners include Oregon Trout, Benton County Public Works, and Benton Soil and Water Conservation District. OWEB funds will be used principally for project management, contracted services, and supplies and materials.

This project will enhance approximately 700 feet of stream channel and habitat along Abernathy and Park Place creeks in Clackamas Countys Abernethy Subbasin, near Oregon City.  The project will re-shape the eroding banks and create fish habitat by placing boulders and large wood instream and creating an off-channel alcove. The project is consistent with the draft Lower Columbia River Recovery Plan, which seeks to reduce sediment loads, reduce erosion to stream banks, increase channel complexity, increase riparian tree canopy, and improve habitat for threatened and endangered species.  Major partners include Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife and Oregon City Public Works. OWEB funds will be used principally for project management, contracted services and supplies and materials.

This TA#1 project will design large wood placement and an alcove on lower Beaver Creek near its confluence with the Sandy River in Troutdale.  Lower Beaver Creek is limited by water quality issues, lack of large wood, reduced off-channel habitat, and a riparian corridor dominated by invasive species.  There is a lack of complex habitat for Chinook salmon as well as Coho, steelhead, and cutthroat trout.  Partners include City of Troutdale, Sandy River Watershed Council, ODFW, Reynolds Natural Resource Academy and the landowners. OWEB funds will be used to secure design expertise to analyze stream flow data, the force exerted upon the wood, and the amount of earth or boulders required to keep the wood in place.  The drawings and analysis will be used to obtain permits for implementation.

Grantee: Friends of Tryon Creek State Park
Project Summary: This project is designed to enhance awareness and improve knowledge of 2,500 program participants and develop skills to improve 100 home sites within the Tryon Creek watershed.  The project will develop audience-specific programming to reach community groups, restoration project volunteers, and motivated landowners; and it will measure the program results.  Programs will be delivered to 24 community groups, 1,600 restoration volunteers, and 200 Landscaping for Conservation participants during the two-year project.  OWEB funds will be used for salaries and materials. Partners include the Tryon Creek Watershed Council, West Multnomah Soil and Water Conservation District, Oregon Parks and Recreation, and Portland Bureau of Environmental Services.

With its headwaters located in the McDonald-Dunn Forest, Frazier Creek flows through rural residential areas, farmland, Jackson-Frazier Wetland (a Benton County green space and public park), and urban residential areas before it reaches its confluence with the Willamette River near Albany.  During the early 1980s, the Soil Conservation Service  worked with private landowners to construct a freshwater recreational pond by creating a 10-foot earthen dam in the creek.  Today, the dam is silted in and has formed a forested wetland. As a result, it prevents fish access to almost a mile of good quality habitat upstream.  The project will reroute Frazier Creek around the pond and wetland area to open up access to spawning and rearing habitat upstream.  An engineered stream channel will be constructed with large woody debris and vegetated soil lifts.  An old emergency spillway will be the new location for the stream channel and will be vegetated with Oregon ash and other suitable riparian vegetation.  The old water control structure on the dam will be filled and abandoned.  OWEB funds will be used principally for final design and construction.

The Clackamas Watershed lacks accessible, comprehensive monitoring information. Existing data are unpublished and scattered among academic and agency groups; and important data remain to be collected to provide context for existing data. This project will collect existing data, display them on the applicants website, and collect inexpensive but important contextual data through bio-monitoring and spot water-quality monitoring. Partners include the U.S. Geological Survey, the Oregon Department of Agriculture, Department of Environmental Quality, the Student Watershed Research Project, and Clackamas County SWCD. OWEB funds will be used to support data collection, display, analysis, and reporting.

Project Name: Clackamas Side Channel at Shoe Island
Project Summary: This TA#1 project proposes to contract for the development of engineering designs for reconnecting a side channel on the Clackamas River at Shoe Island. The Clackamas River is still a stronghold for salmon species, even though it lacks qualities that would support expanded runs.  Lack of side-channel habitat has been identified as a key limiting factor in the lower Clackamas River.  Restoration of side channels is a high priority to ODFW, which is a partner in this effort.  To expand salmon populations and ensure viability, this technical assistance activity would provide permit-ready plans and specifications for reconnecting a side channel.  OWEB funds will be used primarily for contracted services  to survey the site, conduct hydraulic modeling, and draw the designs.  Potential funding partners include the Oregon Governors Fund for the Environment and the Ecotrust Whole Watershed Initiative.

This project will improve coniferous and hardwood forest habitat in Forest Park, a 5,000-acre forest located on the west side of the Willamette River in the City of Portland.  Invasive species will be removed from approximately 160 acres and native species will be planted on 25 acres.  Up to 100 conifers encroaching into Oregon white oak habitat along the perimeter of the park will be thinned.  The project will reduce wildfire hazard conditions, as well as enhance critical Oregon oak habitat.  Partners include City of Portland Bureau of Environmental Services, West Multnomah SWCD, PGE, and FEMA.  OWEB funds will be used principally for contracted services and secondarily for neighborhood association education and outreach.

Present day and historical land use patterns in the Camp Creek Basinincluding forestry, agriculture, and rural residentialhave had direct and indirect effects on water quality and fish and wildlife habitat. The Camp Creek Basin Study is designed to examine the relationship between land use patterns and watershed conditions through implementation of a long-term monitoring and restoration program. Student teams will collect 2- 4 years of baseline water quality, and aquatic and riparian habitat and macroinvertebrate data, which will be analyzed and used to help identify, prioritize, and implement restoration projects. Partners include Springfield Public Schools, Springfield Utility Board, and Eugene Water and Electric Board. OWEB funds will be used for salaries, contracted services, equipment, travel, and administration.

This project will implement a volunteer-based education/outreach program for Coast Fork Willamette Watershed residents. Specifically, it will link residents with the school-based STREAM Education program and a variety of partners and restoration actions in the Upper Willamette.  The program will address lack of knowledge about watersheds and confusion about the role/existence of the watershed council.  The STREAM Educational Program will receive funding for field trips (busing, staff time and equipment), which provide valuable kinesthetic learning for at-risk youth.  The project will help reduce barriers by bringing community members together across age/class/knowledge boundaries.  Funding will be used for staff time to develop the program and set up workshops, and to coordinate two programs.  Partners include OPRD, Walama Restoration Project, The Nature Conservancy, and OSU Extension Service.

Project Name: Middle Fork Willamette Watershed Rangers Project
Project Summary: This project will offer rural teachers and their elementary school students in grades 3-6 a natural resources curriculum with field trip opportunities.  The applicant with work with 12-15 teachers who will present the curriculum and provide hands-on learning experiences to their students.  250-350 students will work on Watershed Rangers activities such as water quality testing, stream surveys, invasive species removal, and wildlife tracking. OWEB funds will be used principally to cover the costs of the outreach coordinator.  Funding partners include the Bureau of Land Management, USDA Forest Service, US Army Corps of Engineers, University of Oregon Environmental Leadership Program, and Lundy Elementary School.

This TA#1 project will provide a necessary site survey, fish passage solution (models), and permit preparation needed to replace a long-deteriorated corrugated pipe on Wagner Creek within the Lost Creek subbasin.  Fish passage and excessive sedimentation are limiting factors to salmonid viability in the Middle Fork Willamette Watershed.  OWEB funds will be used primarily to contract with a professional engineer to develop the technical design for project implementation.  Project partners include the landowners ODFW, and Giustina Land and Timber.

This TA#2 project, a resubmission, seeks technical assistance for an aquatic habitat inventory and geomorphic analysis to: 1) develop an understanding of geomorphic processes of the Molalla River and how it is changing over time; 2) identify restoration opportunities and design options for stream corridor rehabilitation and floodplain reconnection; and 3) involve citizens and partners in creating an integrated strategic restoration plan with prioritized site-specific projects for the lower 13 miles of the Molalla River and first mile of Milk Creek. The Molalla is an undammed river that supports dwindling populations of Chinook salmon and winter steelhead.  The lower reach suffers from the effects of excessive sediment. Project partners include Molalla River Watch, ODFW, Clackamas SWCD, BLM, and Molalla River Improvement District. OWEB funds will be used for some project management and primarily for contracted services.

Project Name: Sauvie Island Private Land Wetland Restoration
Project Summary: This TA#1 project seeks funding to complete topographic survey work and a soils analysis to assist the applicant in restoring approximately 465 acres of marsh and forested/scrub shrub wetlands on two private parcels on Sauvie Island in the Sturgeon Lake basin.  Construction of a large dike in the 1930s fragmented the southern portion of Sturgeon Lake, severing its connectivity with the remainder of the tidally influenced body of water.  Pre-restoration work will address the loss of the seasonal-emergent and forested/scrub shrub wetlands in the remnant southern portion of the lake basin.  OWEB funds will also be used for project permitting and coordinating local partner involvement.  Project partners include the private landowners, USFWS, ODFW, West Multnomah SWCD, and Sauvie Island Drainage Company.

Project Name: Sturgeon Lake Restoration Action Plan Development
Project Summary: This TA#1 project seeks to develop restoration design alternatives as part of an action plan emphasizing sediment reduction, debris management, and restoration of flows from the Columbia River into Dairy Creek and the 3,200-acre Sturgeon Lake.  The lake has historically provided significant seasonal over-wintering and rearing habitat for juvenile salmonids and lamprey, in addition to supporting the majority of the wintering waterfowl on Sauvie Island.  The primary objective is to develop a design that will reduce the continuing sedimentation problem that is impairing water circulation to and within Sturgeon Lake.  Partners include West Multnomah SWCD, ODFW, Oregon DEQ, Ducks Unlimited, Multnomah County, U.S. Army Corp of Engineers, NRCS, NW Oregon Resource Conservation and Development Council, NOAA Fisheries, USFWS and adjacent private landowners. OWEB funds will be used exclusively for a contractor to conduct the hydrologic modeling.

This project is an expanded version of a successful pilot project conducted by the Luckiamute Watershed Council in 2007-2008.  Funds requested will be used for six workshops and two tours in the Luckiamute and Marys watersheds. The purpose will be to train 30 adult watershed residents, councilors, or board members to communicate about their respective watersheds.  The workshops will lead to the publication of two books of personal essays and pictures about the watersheds. The books will be sold to raise money for other watershed projects. The project trains volunteers to write effectively and then to market their works and watersheds.  OWEB funds will be used for staff, travel, administration, and supplies.  In-kind and cash donations will come from local sponsors and the two participating watershed councils and boards to pay for printing the book.  Results will be measured in participation, book sales, and publicity; and will be reported to each watershed councils oversight committee.

This TA#1 project proposes to develop a riparian vegetation planting plan with full designs for the City of Springfields Mill Race, a waterway planned for salmon habitat and water quality enhancements.  An upstream section of the mill race, a side channel connecting the Middle Fork Willamette and main stem McKenzie River in Springfield, is part of an Army Corps of Engineers Section 206 project.  Designs will be prepared by a professional restoration design team and will be developed through use and integration of site vegetation and planting conditions assessments, consideration of the channel restoration master plan, riparian shading model output, and land ownership and partnership agreements.  The plan will result in appropriately phased project implementation for noxious vegetation control, soil and bank preparation, and native riparian planting and establishment over the entire 3.5-mile length of the Springfield Mill Race, with emphasis on the lower 0.5-mile reach of the waterway. OWEB funds will be used exclusively for contracted services.

Project Name: Willamette River and Johnson Creek Confluence Salmon Habitat Improvement
Project Summary: The Lower Willamette River suffers from lack of habitat complexity and floodplain interaction, which limits rearing, migrating, and spawning salmonids.  This project will address these limiting factors through the strategic placement of large wood structures and boulder clusters along Johnson Creek at its confluence with the Willamette River. This will provide cover and refuge habitat, as well as help retain gravels and potentially promote scour pool development.  Additionally, a series of three alcove areas are being proposed to provide off-channel rearing and refuge habitat during high-flow events.  Effectiveness monitoring will evaluate channel morphology, substrate, woody debris structures, habitat unit frequency, and canopy cover for at least three years post implementation. OWEB funded the project designs to a 30% level for this project (208-3000).  OWEB funds will be used principally for contracted services.

Project Name: Building a Foundation to Implement a Willamette Basin Nutria Management Plan
Project Summary: This TA#2 project will collect and document data on nutria damage in waterways in Polk County to build the foundation for developing the first Regional Nutria Management Plan in the Pacific Northwest.  In Oregon, nutria are non-native invasive species that pollute water; displace native wildlife; damage dikes, crops, and riparian vegetation; and potentially transmit disease to pets, livestock, and humans.  OWEB funds will be used to educate the public about nutria, create a standardized data collection form, document nutria damage, test nutria for disease, evaluate nutria control methods, and work with landowners to record various features of captured nutria.  The data collected from this project will be used to seek future funding to address nutria populations and their effects on water quality, native fish, and riparian health.  Partners include Polk SWCD, NRCS, OSU College of Veterinary Medicine, Ash Creek Water Control Board, and ODF.

Project Name: Jespersen Groundwater Conservation and Wetland Project
Project Summary: This project east of Klamath Falls near Swan Lake would install 10,420 feet of buried mainline to connect an existing pump with several existing central pivot irrigation systems in order to separate the irrigation water from live surface flow.  A length of 6,000 feet of ditch will continue to serve the 3,000 acres recently enrolled in the Wetland Reserve Program (WRP), 1,600 acres of which was irrigated farmland.

This project in Lake County, between Valley Falls and Warner Lakes, would enable juniper treatment on 1,200 acres of private land in conjunction with treatment occurring on 6,000 acres of surrounding Bureau of Land Management and US Forest Service lands.  The project would cut young invasive juniper in order to restore the sagebrush-steppe plant communities important to restore watershed function and benefit candidate species of the Greater Sage Grouse and the ESA listed Warner Sucker fish.

This project in Wasco County west of Maupin will use chainsaws to cut invasive young juniper on 240 acres.  The large material will be used for firewood and the small material will be piled to provide wildlife habitat.  The old growth juniper will not be cut.  The treated area will be over-seeded with native bunchgrasses.

This project in the Deschutes National Forest west of Lake Billy Chinook would thin and remove timber on 4,300 acres to prevent a stand-replacement fire, decommission 3 miles of roads and treat 200 acres of spotted knapweed.  Fly Creek is a tributary of the Metolius arm of Lake Billy Chinook and it is Mule Deer winter range.

Project Name: Establishment of a Water Transaction Program for the Upper Klamath Basin
Project Summary: This project would take advantage of a seven year history the applicant has in working with the Bureau of Reclamation, the Natural Resources Conservation Service and private landowners to convert a temporary water leasing program to a permanent water transactions program that works to secure permanent instream water transactions in the Upper Klamath Basin.

This project north of Sisters and along Indian Ford Creek is part of a 1200 acre Glaze Meadow Riparian Restoration Project on US Forest Service lands.  Conifers in the stream corridor would be thinned to promote large trees and reduce the competition with stagnant aspen groves and meadows, fire would be re-introduced and two miles of road would be decommissioned.  The stream is DEQ 303(d) listed for temperature and supports native redband trout.

Project Name: Evans Creek - Hutson Drive Culvert Replacement
Project Summary: This project on Evans Creek, a tributary to the East Fork Hood River, would replace two existing culverts with a 28 foot long bottom-less arch culvert with a 23 foot span.  The current culverts are a partial fish passage barrier for winter steelhead (ESA listed in 1998), cutthroat trout and coho salmon.  The project would provide access to 1.3 miles of additional spawning habitat.

This project consists of planting riparian buffers, fencing and off-stream water along almost 16 miles of the Sprague River in Klamath County.  In locations where previous projects or this project complete riparian fencing, vegetative buffers of trees, shrubs and native grasses will be planted within the riparian areas.  The OWEB portion of the project would install one mile of fencing, construct one shallow well for livestock water 1500 feet from the river, purchase and install 2,640 trees, 5,280 shrubs and 112 pounds of native grasses in the riparian buffers on four of the 14 sites.

This project located about seven miles southwest of Klamath Falls and west of Highway 97 seeks to restore connectivity between a 1700 acre emergent wetland and the Klamath River by creating several small channels to provide water movement through the marsh.  The marsh has experienced a decline in habitat quality and its ability to help purify nutrient rich waters from Upper Klamath Lake since the Klamath River was diked and riprapped in 1946.  The owners of the Tule Smoke Hunt Club denied access for this work and therefore this remains an important part of the marsh habitat.  Seventy five percent of the marshes have been drained and converted to agriculture.

Project Name: Precision Farming Applications for Improved Nutrient Management
Project Summary: This project would help agricultural producers in Sherman County conduct site productivity analysis and require the use of high technology fertilizer application rates with the purpose of documenting a reduction in fertilizer use without a reduction in the yield productivity of the site.  Since 1993 well testing documented high level of nitrates in the groundwater in approximately 30% of the wells tested.

Project Name: Upper Lytle Creek Whole Watershed Restoration
Project Summary: This project would remove 1540 acres of invasive juniper, treat medusahead  and repair roads to reduce sedimentation into Lytle Creek, an intermittent tributary to the Crooked River below Prineville.  This project will treat these issues in the entire sub-watershed.  The juniper treatment will focus on spring areas to enhance flow and reduce the competition in aspen stands.  Treatment of medusahead and reseeding of 450 acres will take place and two miles of road improvements will take place to reduce sediment.

This project north of Sisters and along Indian Ford Creek is part of a 1200 acre Glaze Meadow Riparian Restoration Project on US Forest Service lands.  Conifers in the stream corridor would be thinned to promote large trees and reduce the competition with stagnant aspen groves and meadows, fire would be re-introduced and two miles of road would be decommissioned.  The stream is DEQ 303(d) listed for temperature and supports native redband trout.

This project would sponsor two workshops for teachers in environmental education, conduct two  four day summer workshops for up to 30 kids about Klamath watershed related subjects and it will work with two schools (teachers and students) to create two schoolyard habitats that will be used for life science lessons.  Existing ecology curriculums will be used.

This project would provide support for the continuation of RAP Camp (Resources and People).  It is a one week camp high school students make application to attend from the Northwest.  Topics cover a variety of ecological sciences.  At the end of the week, students have to assume the role of a resource manager, farmer, business person, rancher, etc. and work together to develop a management plan for a designated area.  There are several field trips and presentations by land and resource managers.

This project would engage 800 middle and high school students from Sisters in active watershed stewardship of Whychus Creek.  Project components include streamside learning in ecology, hydrology, biology and writing.  In addition, the students will be involved in habitat restoration projects to help with the success of reintroduction efforts to restore anadromous fish to Whychus Creek.

This project would reconfigure and reconnect Badger Spring to the Sprague River east of Beatty in Klamath County.  The spring connection was straightened and now connects to the river by a gated culvert and there is no clearly defined channel between the spring and the Sprague River.  A new creek would be built that would mimic the original meandering connection over 1,070 feet.  It would be a narrow channel with pool-riffles for fish passage at a grade to connect to the river.  Willows will be planted for stream stabilization.  In addition, two small adjacent seasonal backwater wetlands will be enhanced and connected to the Sprague River to provide larval and juvenile fish rearing habitat.

This project just north of the town of Beatty in Klamath County would reconnect several springs to the Sprague River allowing for fish passage and providing larval and juvenile fish rearing habitat for the ESA listed Lost River and Shortnose sucker fish.  The Frog Springs complex is diverted via culvert to the Sycan River without fish passage and this will be re-directed south to the Sprague River.  A total of 5,000 feet of narrow sinuous channel will be constructed and planted with willows and gravel will be added in riffle areas.  Adjacent wetlands that have been deepened to reduce their size and for livestock use will be contoured to increase their perimeter and restructured to be emergent wetlands.  The land is permanently enrolled in the Wetland Reserve Program.

This project would place 14 log structures (8-10 logs per structure) and enhance 17 acres of wetlands in and adjacent to the Wood River above Upper Klamath Lake.  These projects will increase habitat for native redband trout and help stabilize streambanks on a _ mile reach of the river.  The wetlands will help treat irrigation tail-water and provide backwater rearing habitat for larval and juvenile Lost River and Shortnose sucker fish.

This project on the John Day River just north of the Cottonwood Bridge between Wasco and Condon would address several restoration needs on the Murtha Ranch, recently acquired by the Western Rivers Conservancy.  The lower 2.8 miles of Hay Creek will be treated for invasive species (41 acres), sculpted to restore floodplain connectivity, and planted with riparian species.  The entire section, a total of 5.6 miles, will be fenced to exclude livestock.  Another 161 acres of invasive species will be treated on eight sites using both chemical and bio-control agents.  All of the treated areas will be replanted with native grass, forb and woody plant species.

This project on Hay Creek east of Madras would replace an 18,600 foot long irrigation ditch with 17,200 feet of 15 inch PVC mainline pipe.  Currently, the ditch carries water  to a pond where it is pumped out for irrigation with the overflow water going into Hay Creek, adding both sediment and warm water from the pond.  Hay Creek is a tributary of Trout Creek which is an important ESA listed steelhead spawning stream for the eastside Deschutes steelhead population.  Once piped, there would no longer be overflow going into Hay Creek and there may be a reduced amount of water diverted due to irrigation efficiencies gained.

This project just east of Chiloquin would install 1.75 miles of riparian fencing to protect 14.5 acres of riparian area and purchase and install one off-stream watering system with a solar pump to supply four water troughs.  The riparian buffer will vary between 50 and 200 feet.  The project will reduce streambank degradation and improve water quality in the Sprague River and Upper Klamath Lake.

Project Name: Klamath Basin Volunteer Water Quality Monitoring Program
Project Summary: This project would support a Monitoring Coordinator position for one year in the Upper Klamath Basin.  The coordinator would recruit, train and oversee volunteers as they collect and evaluate water quality monitoring samples on the Sprague and Williamson Rivers.  The project will focus on filling data gaps in these areas during the 2010 field season.

Project Name: Klamath Working Group Education and Outreach Project
Project Summary: This project would hold several local workshops for landowners to explain watershed processes and restoration techniques in the Upper Klamath Basin.  Specialist will present talks on resource issues in the basin and the types of things that can be done to address water quality, quantity and fish recovery efforts.  In turn, the Klamath Watershed Partnership will listen to landowners concerns.  The workshops will be followed-up with one-on-one consultations about potential projects.

Project Name: The Crooked River Student Proposal Project
Project Summary: This proposal would join the Crooked River High School and the Crooked River Watershed Council in working with watershed processes and local issue related to the Crooked River watershed.  Students will identify field projects, make an application for a small amount of money to implement the project, collect data, write a report and make a presentation about the project.

This project near Lonerock in Gilliam County would treat 2661 acres of juniper on six privately owned sites.  Landowners will replant 900 acres of grassland infested with medusahead as well as lands disturbed during the juniper removal project.  Four springs will be developed and 2.5 miles of cross fencing will be installed to aid in pasture management.  The basin has been identified by the ODFW as important to ESA listed steelhead for spawning and rearing.

Project Name: TTDC Point of Diversion Feasibility Analysis
Project Summary: This project would look at alternatives to the existing point of diversion from the Deschutes River that serves the Tumalo Town Ditch Company.  Currently the diverted water is carried in an open canal adjacent to the Deschutes and then in a pipeline that is in danger of being captured by the river, and then in an open ditch from which individual landowners divert water for lawn and gardens within the community of Tumalo.

This project, about 20 miles east of Chiloquin on the Sprague River would build 1.5 miles of exclusion fencing around an existing 28 acre wetland that currently contributes sediment to the Sprague River during snow melt and runoff periods because it is part of a pasture and is heavily grazed.  The project would also construct one mile of fence adjacent to the Sprague River to exclude trespass livestock from the river.  Both the wetland and the riparian area have exposed banks without vegetation due to livestock use.

This project southeast of Bonanza in Klamath County would thin 60 acres of juniper on the toe of a southwest facing slope above cultivated agricultural land.  The treatment is proposed in order to increase water infiltration and perennial grasses.  The restored understory should arrest overland flow and store more water in the soil profile.

Grantee: Inland Empire Action Coalition - Klamath Falls
Project Summary: This project would install 6,000 feet of livestock exclusion fencing along the Sprague River and adjoining wetlands at a site about 22 miles east of Chiloquin.  It would also install off-stream livestock water by burying 2,500 feet of 1-1/4 PVC pipe to two 700 gallon stock water tanks.  Two thousand willow cuttings will be planted with tree protectors to protect them from livestock, beaver and muskrats.  A total of 30 acres will be fenced off and planted.  The area will be managed as a riparian pasture for the restoration of the riparian areas.

Project Name: Backwater Habitat Restoration Along the Sprague River at Dusty Lane
Project Summary: This project adjacent to the Sprague River about 15 miles east of Chiloquin would improve an off-channel seasonal backwater wetland on 11 acres.  Bioengineering techniques including the placement of large wood and boulders, together with plantings, will increase surface roughness during high flow events.  The side channel is eroding and much of the wetland hydrology is being lost.  This reduces the effectiveness of the  floodplain and the value of the area as backwater habitat for juvenile and larval fish.  The Sprague River is important habitat for the ESA listed Lost River and Shortnose sucker fish.

This project would enable a planning team of US Fish and Wildlife Service scientist, City of Klamath Falls personnel and bioengineering consultants to develop a plan to protect and restore wetland fringe habitats on Lake Ewauna.  The wetland fringe habitat provides rearing habitat for the ESA listed Shortnose and Lost River sucker fish.  The plans will enable the project team to obtain permits and determine material and construction costs for implementing the plan.

Project Name: Water Quality of Northern Great Basin Vernal Pools
Project Summary: This monitoring project would develop baseline water quality data for reference condition of unaltered and altered vernal pools in the Northern Great Basin.  The vernal pools are formed by a shallow claypan and are associated with the presence of silver sagebrush.  Grazing in and near vernal pools is a concern for microbiological effects on water quality.  The study will provide some measure against which to gauge the impact of altering a vernal pool by excavation (dugout) versus the hydrology and water quality of unaltered wetlands.

This project located about seven miles southwest of Klamath Falls and west of Highway 97 seeks to restore connectivity between a 1700 acre emergent wetland and the Klamath River by creating several small channels to provide water movement through the marsh.  The marsh has experienced a decline in habitat quality and its ability to help purify nutrient rich waters from Upper Klamath Lake since the Klamath River was diked and riprapped in 1946.  The owners of the Tule Smoke Hunt Club denied access for this work and therefore this remains an important part of the marsh habitat.  Seventy five percent of the marshes in the Klamath Basin have been drained and converted to agriculture.

This project would engage the Deschutes Basin Land Trust, the Deschutes River Conservancy and the Upper Deschutes Watershed Council in working with thirty teenagers on activities in the basin that have environmental significance.  Participants will learn about watershed processes and local management issues and create watershed education exhibits and other outreach programs to be used by local schools, libraries and the community partner locations.

This project in the Deschutes National Forest west of Lake Billy Chinook would thin and remove timber on 4,300 acres to prevent a stand-replacement fire, decommission 3 miles of roads and treat 200 acres of spotted knapweed.  Fly Creek is a tributary of the Metolius arm of Lake Billy Chinook and it is mule deer winter range.

Located in Morrow County, south of Heppner, the project proposes to reconstruct 2.5 miles of the Black Mountain Lane by installing pit-run rock, gravel and proper drainage.  Project components include installation of 7 rolling dips, 6 culverts. Black Mountain Lane is a 2.5 mile earthen road with minimal rock and is parallel to a small tributary of Willow Creek, a fish-bearing stream.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services (42%), rock and culverts (47%), oversight (5%) and administration (5%).  Cost-share partners are the landowner for rock and equipment, ODF for technical assistance and Morrow County Road Department for equipment use.

Project Name: Little Muddy Creek Range & Habitat Restoration
Project Summary: This project is located in Little Muddy Creek, a tributary of Pine Creek, which flows into the Malheur River, northeast of Burns.  The upper Malheur River is bull trout-rearing habitat and redband habitat from the headwaters to Warm Springs Reservoir.  Project components include 700 acres of juniper cutting, piling and slash pile burning; 2 miles of 4-strand barbed-wire fence to divide the ranch into 3 pastures for rotational grazing; drill  a 220 well; install 2 tanks; seed 72 acres and prepare a range plan. OWEB funds are requested for layout (6%), project management (3%), contracted services (73%), materials (8%), equipment (5%) and administration (5%). The landowners will supply significant cash and in-kind.

Malheur WSC is proposing to pipe 2,200 of open earthen conveyance ditch that carries water from irrigation districts main canal to an 88-acre parcel near Vale.  There is a natural spring at the base of the property that catches runoff and deposits sediment into the Malheur River 1000 away.  In addition, 2,600 of fencing will be installed to accommodate a half-circle pivot.  Watershed benefits include improved water quality.  OWEB funds are quested for project management (2%), contracted services (21%), fencing/pipe/materials (68%) and administration (9%).  The landowner will provide the pivot and some installation.

Project Name: Rose Creek Irish Spring Fire Fencing Project
Project Summary: Location west of Ironside on Highway 26, this project proposes to install 6.0 miles of 4-strand-barbed-wire fence around 1,300-acre parcel.  In 2007, a fire went through this entire area, which had a OWEB project completed in 2006 that thinned juniper and enhanced aspen along the riparian areas. The 1,300-acres was seeded after the fire and needs to be protected from adjacent grazing.   OWEB funds are requested for fencing (94%) and administration (6%). The landowner will provide cash and in-kind.

Juniper now occupies historic sagebrush-steppe on 1,254 acres in Grant and Malheur Counties north of Juntura.  Sage grouse leks were identified in this watershed.  Project components include juniper cutting on 1,254 acres and seeding on 300 acres.  The landowner will implement a prescribed burn in the next 6-7 years to control juniper regeneration.  A grazing plan, including temporary rest and deferment, will be implemented.  OWEB funds are requested for juniper removal (62%) personnel (8%), seed (18%), mileage (2%)administration (9%) and monitoring (1%). The landowner will provide labor, reseeding and fencing. Cost-share is provided by ODFW for technical assistance and NRCS a grazing plan.

Located near Arock, Malheur SWCD proposes to address water loss and impaired water quality by piping 3,920 of a drain ditch with 24 PVC.  Historically, large agricultural tracts in this part of Malheur County have traditionally used furrow irrigation, which is difficult to control, leading to significant erosion. Water quality is often threatened as drain ditches collect water from multiple users with high levels of nutrients or fertilizers.  Project implementation addresses water quality improvement. OWEB funds are requested for engineering (6%), installation (19%), materials (69%) and administration/monitoring (6%).  The landowner will provide some in-kind installation.

A groundwater management area was declared in 1990 in the lower Umatilla basin (LUBGWMA).  The Umatilla SWCD is seeking technical assistance to hire a person to plan, organize, hold workshops, conduct meetings and help to implement groundwater projects.  Success will be measured with 3 completed surveys; assessing the amount of irrigated acreage using BMPs; survey livestock-feeding operations; outreach and education activities and also hold several meetings.  The Clean Water Neighborhood (CWN) will provide residents with resources and BMPs to address potential contamination of the groundwater.  OWEB funds are requested for personnel (100%).  Cost-share partners are the ODA, SWCD, OWRD and GEOD, who will provide technical assistance.

Funds are sought for engineering and design of a bridge to cross North Pine Creek near Halfway.  Cattle are transported across the creek several times a year to access a USFS allotment.  The site was adversely impacted by the 2006 high-flood event and deposition, making the riparian area quite wide and complicating the design.
