There is also severe bank failing on the streambanks opposite the riparian area.  Funds are requested for design (96%) and administration ($4,000).  The landowner and other (unspecified) funding sources are the cost-share partners.

The Powder Valley Agriscience class designed this project.  The school is proposing to restore a severe undercut and headcut banks, which are causing stream dysfunction and vegetative problems.  Proposed components include 18 bevel V-notch weirs, 120 cabled juniper for rip rap, high-intensity grazing management and 5,280 fencing.  The bank will be reshaped to a 2:1 slope.   Riparian vegetation will be planted at 5-foot interval along 9,285 feet of Wolf Creek.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services (32%), materials- juniper, vegetation, clamps (46%), equipment (14%) and administration (8%).  Powder Valley High School, ODA and the landowner are cost-share partners.

The 2006 flood on Pine Creek in Halfway caused excessive erosion and sedimentation in the lower 3.2 miles of Clear Creek. This project addresses critical habitat for ESA-listed bull trout. Funds are sought replace 6 push-up dams and install water-measuring devices.  Due to diminished flow in late summer and early fall, the current structures do not allow fish passage. Watershed benefits include improved water quality, streambank erosion and riparian area enhancement.  OWEB funds are requested for the diversion installation (96%) and administration (4%).  The landowners are cost-share partners.

Project Name: Determining Status of Native fish as a Restoration Tool
Project Summary: The applicant proposes to implement a monitoring regime that identifies the distribution of both native and non-native fish so future restoration efforts can target the assemblage level and offer increase benefits to listed fish. OWEB funds are requested for 3 training sessions with the protocol and the associated database to Oregon stakeholders.  The information developed at these sessions will help stakeholders plan and evaluate future restoration efforts. EMAP will be applied to 10 sites on the Owyhee and Rogue Rivers and 20 sites on the John Day with sites selected in cooperation with stakeholders of these regions.  OWEB funds are sought for personnel (73%), mileage (10%), travel (4%) and supplies (13%).  Partners include OSU, National Fish and Wildlife Foundation and EPA.

The Confederated Tribes of the Umatilla Indian Reservation (CTUIR) and the USFS are collaborating to address compromised fish passage on three crossings in the Desolation Creek watershed and one crossing on Granite Creek, south of Ukiah.  These crossings are passage barriers for various life stages of anadromous fish. Granite Creek and Desolation Creek are used by ESA-listed Mid-Columbia steelhead and bull trout and also spring Chinook salmon.  Four precise concrete bridges will replace the undersized culverts on Howard, Sponge, Battle and Granite Creeks.  OWEB funds are requested for the pre-cast bridge (33%), contracted services, mobilization and contingency (58%) and administration (9%).  Umatilla National Forest will provide design and oversight. CTUIR will provide design and monitoring. The Pacific Coast Salmon Recovery Funds (PCSRF) and EcoTrust will provide implementation funds.

Grantee: Confed Tribes Warm Springs - Prairie City
Project Name: Oxbow Conservation Area Instream Habitat Project
Project Summary: Natural river function will be restored to apportion of the Middle Fork of the John Day (MFJD). In the 1970s, riprap and rock barbs were installed to stabilize eroding banks, which prevented the channel from natural adjustments over time, leading to a gradual disconnect with the floodplain. Confederated Tribes of the Warm Springs  (CTWS) is proposing to remove 33 rock features consisting of large rock barbs and one riprap wall; harvest 78 whole trees with rootwads; install 14 large wood structures and reinitiate flow into an old meander.  Project implementation will restore floodplain connectivity, lateral migration, and sinuosity and habitat complexity. OWEB funds are requested for contracted services (87%), staff overnight travel (1%), effectiveness monitoring (3%), and administration (9%). Cost-share partners are BPA for construction cost, BOR for design oversight, NOAA IMW effectiveness monitoring; Wild Salmon Center and USFWS for construction.

Project Name: Upper Wallowa River Stream Bank Stabilization
Project Summary: Due to debris slides, storm events and channelization, an 8,000-foot stretch of the upper Wallowa River, upstream of Wallowa Lake near Joseph, has severe channel instability and streambank erosion.  Historic stream channelization and bank stabilization over the years has modified instream and riparian habitat for kokanee and bull trout and has disrupted natural  floodplain processes. The proposed technical assistance will allow design of preliminary alternatives and final design for this section.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (5%), in-house personnel (4%) and survey/engineering (91%).  Partners includes ODFW, Oregon Parks and Recreation (OPRD), USFWS, adjacent private landowners and Wallowa County.

The property is located in the headwaters of Rock Creek, which is major tributary for ESA-listed steelhead,in the John Day Basin. Low streamflow, sediment and poor water quality will be addressed by project implementation. Trees and vegetation are sparse and noxious weeds are encroaching. The project will be implemented on 10,500 acres.  Watershed benefits include improved water quality, upland and riparian vegetation and habitat by installing 18.5 miles of fence, extensive riparian planting and 16 water developments. OWEB funds are requested for riparian fencing (6%), plantings (79%), water developments (6%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners include NRCS, BPA, CTUIR, Columbia Land and Timber and ODFW.

This project is located on Gable Creek, a tributary of Bridge Creek near Mitchell, and addresses fish passage by replacing two diversions with one driven-sheet piling diversion.  The lower of the two diversions is an undersized culvert that the landowner blocks to divert water.  The culvert is scheduled for replacement.  Consolidating the diversion will help facilitate this replacement by removing the needs for the landowner to divert water from this location.  The project also addresses flows in Gable Creek by converting 11,000 of open-ditch conveyance to a pressurized pipeline system. Watershed benefits are improved fish passage, habitat and connectivity and water quality. OWEB funds are requested for engineering (9%), installation (7%), pipe and fittings (75%) and administration (9%).  The landowner will provide labor for installation and pipe.

Located 4.5 miles south of Monument, an upland project proposes to install 9,644 of riparian fence, 7,586 of 2 pipeline, develop 1 seep, install 4, 700-gallon troughs and 1 10,000-gallon storage tank.   This upland enhancement project will complement a recently completed OWEB small grant that created 3 usable pastures.  Watershed benefits include improved upland vegetation, infiltration and water quality. OWEB funds are requested for project installation (73%), pipe, trough and tank (18%) and administration (9%).  The landowner will provide in-kind installation and some pipe. NRCS will provide technical assistance.

Technical assistance is requested for a geomorphological assessment on river miles 28.0 to 36.5 on Fox Creek and 2,000 feet of Wiley Creek, located south of Long Creek.  Stream reaches were straightened or cultivated and numerous diversion channels constructed to transport water to individual pastures and hay fields, resulting in an altered hydrologic function.  The applicant wants to identify existing channel characteristics for a Level II Rosgen survey to measure physical attributes including pool frequency, instream wood, native riparian vegetation and instream fish cover. Funds are requested for project management (26%), contracted services- data collection and engineering (63%), mileage (2%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners are North Fork John Day Watershed Council, Anderson-Perry, landowners and Confederated Tribes of the Umatilla Indian Reservation (CTUIR).

Project Name: Willow Creek Landowners Water Quality Restoration - Phase II
Project Summary: The Willow Creek Working Group (WCWG) is continuing its effort to address irrigation-induced erosion and high bacterial counts in the Willow Creek drainage, which encompasses about 500,000 acres. WCWG estimates that due to implementation of previous projects, 4,000 to 16,000 tons of soil and millions of E. coli colonies were prevented from entering Willow Creek.  This application continues WCWGs previous efforts and proposes to bury 10 miles of mainlines; convert 2 miles from ditch to pipe; install 4 pivots (cost-shared); install 9 pumpback systems to eliminate return flow from 770 acres; install 1 mile of riparian fencing, 2.5 miles of cross-fencing and pipe 2.2 miles of drain ditches along feedlots to prevent animal waste from entering Willow Creek.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (4%), contracted services (5%) materials/equipment (88%) and administration.  Cost-share partners are 20 participating landowners who will over $841,500 in both cash and in-kind contributions.

A technical assistance project was previously approved, resulting in a design for a streambank stabilization project along the Powder River.  There are 29 landowners along this stretch, which is managed as a conveyance ditch for authorized water rights to the landowners downstream. Proposed project alternatives include:  1. seeding with a coir-matting soil wrap; 2. brush layering with coir-matting soil wrap and 3. live-staking with coir- matting wrap.  In addition, 2 concrete irrigation structures will be removed, 3 cross vanes and 1 J hook will be installed.  OWEB funds are requested for engineering (5%),  project management (2%), contracted services (91%) and administration (2%).  Partners providing in-kind cost-share include City of Baker City, the landowners, PBWC, BOR, Baker SWCD, NRCS and Eagle Scouts.

The Umatilla Basin Watershed Council (UBWC) is proposing to prepare a comprehensive restoration design for 7 miles of the Umatilla River, from rivermile 26 to 33, near Echo.  Anthropogenic actions created habitat alternations, which have adversely affected habitat and bank stability.  The UBWC requests geoengineering assistance to analyze current river conditions and propose floodplain restoration options.  The final product will be a comprehensive restoration plan that includes appropriately designed individual projects, which can be reviewed by the regulatory agencies, to reduce the likelihood of project failures. OWEB funds are requested for project management (3%), contracted services (87%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners are the Umatilla basin technical team.

Location west of Ironside on Highway 26, this project proposes to install 2.0 miles of 4-strand-barbed-wire fence around a 1,300-acre parcel. The 1,300-acre was seeded after the fire and needs to be protected from adjacent grazing. The landowners will fence 4 miles and are requesting cost-share from OWEB for 2 miles. OWEB funds are requested for fencing (94%) and administration (6%). The landowner will provide cash and in-kind.

Juniper now occupies historic sagebrush-steppe on 1,250 acres in Grant and Malheur Counties north of Juntura. Project components include juniper cutting on 1,250 acres and seeding on 400 acres.  Juniper removal will include 890 acres by chainsaw and 360 acres by dozer with machine piling.  Native grasses and forbs will reseeded.  OWEB funds are requested for juniper removal (63%) personnel (4%), seed (22%), mileage (2%) and administration (9%). The landowner will provide labor, reseeding, fencing and cash; ODFW- technical assistance; SWCD - outreach publications and NRCS - grazing plan.

This project is located north of Beulah Reservoir in the same general vicinity as project 209-5065. Project components include juniper removal on 400 acres and seeding on 200 acres.  Juniper removal will be by chainsaw, followed by lop and scatter for slash abatement.  Funds are requested for cutting (63%), seeding 20%), mileage (2%), project management and layout (7%) and administration (9%). The landowner will provide labor, ODFW and NRCS will provide technical assistance and Malheur SWCD will provide outreach.

The Bunker Water Quality project is located in Malheur County approximately 8 miles southwest of Nyssa.  A waterway draining more than 1,000 acres of mainly flood-irrigated farmland bisects the property, adversely affecting water quality. This project proposes that a series of 3 - _-acre sediment/nutrient ponds be constructed along the uppermost portion of the waterway to capture runoff prior to entering the wildlife area and a proposed 4th pond.   OWEB funds are requested for pre-implementation (4%), contracted services (51%), effectiveness monitoring (3%), equipment (including pivots) (31%) and administration (9%).   The landowner will provide cash and inkind.  EQIP (pending) will provide cash.

Bingham Restoration project is located in southern Union County near North Powder.  The project targets 2 waterways:  the Davis-Kelsey waterway bordering the southern property along North Powder Road and the Wilson waterway bordering the eastern property. The applicant is proposing to install 1.3 miles of 4-strand barbed-wire fence along the waterways to prevent livestock access and install 6 stockwater systems.  In addition, they propose to fence cottonwood galleries and plant willow and shrub cuttings.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services- excavation, supplies and labor (91%) and administration (9%).  The landowner will plant shrubs, install fence and monitor the project.    RRT.

The Lower Powder Irrigation District (LPID) in Baker City is seeking technical assistance to gather data from agency partners. LPID wants to map all structures, headgates and existing ditches that are part of the irrigation system from the Thief Valley Reservoir to the junction of Highway 86 and the Powder River.  Collected data will include existing conditions on irrigation systems, structures, watershed characteristics and hydraulic function.  LPID wants to develop a long-term plan that will be a tool used to cooperatively improve agricultural and irrigation water management (IRM).  OWEB funds are requested for design and survey (91%) and administration (9%).  LPID, Keating Valley Water Users and ODA are cost-share partners and will provide in-kind survey, stakeholder meetings and coordination.

Funds are sought to survey and design a more natural restoration on Cusick Creek.  Located east of North Powder in Union County near Thief Valley reservoir, Cusick Creeks stream channel was straightened, resulting in hydrologic change, increased stream width, vertical-cut banks, sedimentation and loss of hydrophilic vegetation. The applicant seeks a design that will reconnect 49 acres of floodplain, realign 3,477 feet of stream, restore 1.4 miles of native plant community and restore fish passage to and from Thief Valley reservoir.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (4%), in-house personnel (4%), engineering/surveying (88%) and administration (4%).  Cost-share partners include the Keating SWCD, BOR, landowners, ODFW and Union County.

Locate north of Durkee in Baker County, this project proposes to treat habitat and species as cited in the Oregon Conservation Strategy.  The total project encompasses approximately 720 acres of juniper removal in a stand density to 150 to 200 trees per acre (TPA).  Leafy spurge, back hennabane and knapweed are noxious weeds that have invaded the area and are spreading.  The project will treat 100 acres of leafy spurge and apply native seed after spraing and also treat 10 acres of knapweed. OWEB funds are requested for project management (1%), contracted services- juniper treatment  (84%), materials- seeding (7%), and administration (7).  Landowners will provide in-kind labor and equipment; NRCS through the Wildlife Habitat Incentive Program (WHIP) will provide cash and in-kind, Tri-County Weed Management will provide weed funds for spurge treatment and Burnt River SWCD will provide in-kind assistance.

A point of diversion (POD) for the Dry Gulch Ditch is located on the main stem of Eagle Creek approximately 7 miles upstream of Richland. The ditch currently has a measuring device that is .75 miles downstream of the POD. Eagle Valley SWCD is proposing to install a ramp flume measuring device located at the POD to improve flow measurements and insure appropriate flow and withdrawal.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (18%), water measuring device (73%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners include Eagle Valley SWCD, Dry Gulch Improvement district and OWRD.

Project Name: West Camp Creek Push Up Dam Removal
Project Summary: Located 6 miles south of the Unity Reservoir, this project addresses 7 push-up dams on Camp Creek. Project components include installing 7 concrete sill and sheet-pile structures; 7 headgates and water-measuring devices and riparian plantings.   Watershed benefits include improved fish passage, water quality, water quantity and riparian health. OWEB funds are requested for engineering and permitting (28%), project management (4%) technical support (2%), contracted services (12%), materials (47%) and administration (7%).  The landowner will provide in-kind labor and the SWCD education/outreach for the project once implemented.

Project Name: Lostine River Fish Passage Improvement Project
Project Summary: The City of Lostines water diversions existing concrete fish ladder is failing and no longer meets fish passage. Project components include:  remove the barrier; reconstruct 150 feet of channel and install 12 rock grade-control vortex weirs 13.8 feet apart with less than 1 foot rise between each weir to accommodate fish passage. In addition, the applicant proposes to broadcast seed with native seed mix, plant 100 trees; plant willows whips and use a stinger to reclaim existing trees and shrubs.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services (99%) and an interpretive sign (1%).  ODFW will provide cash and in-kind; GRMWP cash for the project (pending), PSC Southern funds cash (pending) and the Nez Perce Tribe in-kind.

The project is located in the Battle Mountain area in Willow Springs and Owings Creek, which flows into Birch Creek.  Due to lack of water in the uplands, livestock and elk concentrate in the drainages, causing streambank degradation, sedimentation and potential nitrate inputs, thus underutilizing the prime grazing uplands.  Project components include:  drill a 400-foot well, install two 1,200-gallon cisterns, install 6,280 feet of pipeline, pump, install 5,000-watt generator and 3 400-gallon troughs.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (3%), contracted services  installation and well drilling (71%), materials- pipe and cistern (17%) and administration (9%). The landowner will provide cash and in-kind labor; NRCS and Umatilla SWCD will provide in-kind assistance.

The 2,000-acre Kee Ranch is located in the Bologna Basin in Grant County west of Monument.   The applicant is proposing to develop 3 off-channel water sites, install 4 groundwater wells and thin 60 acres of juniper.  Proposed project components include develop 3 seeps; install 463 feet of pipe; install three 600-gallom troughs; remove 12 acres of juniper by hand-felling and 48 acres by excavator.  The juniper slash will be used to create a 200-foot brush fence along the East Fork of Bologna Creek.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (2%), contracted services  equipment and labor (77%), materials (11%), administration (9%) and monitoring (1%).   The landowner and OSU are cost-share partners.

Located east of Monument, this project identifies a continuing priority for the Monument SWCD by developing upland off-channel watering sources.  Project components include:  developing 4 springs; installing one 800-gallon trough; one 600-gallon trough; 8,204 feet of cross fence; thin 40 acres of juniper, including the area above the spring sites and seed the area where juniper was removed. OWEB funds are requested for contracted services  spring development, fencing, juniper removal -  (79%), materials  pipe and troughs (12%) administration (9%) and monitoring (1%).  The two landowners will provide cash and in-kind contributions.

The property is located in the headwaters of Rock Creek in the John Day Basin, which is major tributary for ESA-listed steelhead.   Streams have been heavily impacted by unlimited use and have little vegetation.   Watershed benefits include improved water quality, upland and riparian vegetation and habitat by installing 1.9 miles of fence and 5 water developments. OWEB funds are requested for fencing (61%) and water developments (39%).  Cost-share partners include NRCS, BPA, CTUIR, USFWS and ODFW.

Project Name: Moon Hill RX-North Steens Ecosystem Restoration Project Phase II
Project Summary: The Burns BLM, Diamond Valley Ranch, Riddle Ranch and Thompson Ranch are collaborating to implement the Moon Hill Restoration project near Diamond.  It is another landscape-level effort and is Phase II of the North Steens Ecosystem Restoration Project that plans to treat 336,000 acres of public and private land that has 75% juniper encroachment. Components include 9,260 acres of juniper removal, 7,860 acres of  broadcast burn, 400 acres machine piling, 500 acres of jackpot burn and temporary forage of 1,500 AUMs.  The riparian area will be selectively cut and 140 acres of mountain-mahogany protected.   OWEB funds are requested for contracted services- juniper removal (83%); temporary forage (4%), administration (9%) and monitoring (4%).  BLM will provide cash and in-kind.  Riddle Ranch, Thompson Ranch and Diamond Valley Ranch will all provide in-kind match.

Project Name: Harney Basin Groundwater Study Phase II
Project Summary: Harney WSC is seeking funds for a multi-phased groundwater study project.  OWRD has agreed that more information is needed within the study area to answer questions regarding the variability of the aquifers across the basin.  The first phase is the landowner outreach, which will educate the public on the need for a database and collect data to ascertain specific monitoring needs.  The second phase is data collection. The water table in the basin has decreased as the number of wells has increased.  Harney WSC wants to collect data on the 2,000 wells in the 350,000-acre study area. OWEB funds are requested for consultant (91%) and administration (9%).  Harney WSC, OWRD, NRCS, DEQ and private fund raising  are cost-share partners.

Project Name: A Rigorous Statewide Assessment of OWEB's Restoration Projects
Project Summary: The applicant will complete a statistically and ecologically rigorous statewide assessment based on known and tested EMAP designs, sampling methods, and indicators. The goal is to determine the degree to which indicator, project type, regional location, or project age affects our assessment of effectiveness. They will also illustrate the value and feasibility of a statewide effectiveness monitoring program for assessing restoration projects and ecological status and trends. To do this, they will randomly select 50 sites from OWEB's restoration project database and compare them with 50 unrestored sites on the same streams. At each site they will sample fish and benthos assemblages, physical and chemical habitat, and selected landscape indicators. They will also sample 10 sites assessed by other institutions to compare alternative methods and indicators in assessing effectiveness.

Project Name: Oregon Civic Science Educational Project - Phase II
Project Summary: The Oregon Watersheds and Websites project will directly involve residents in 2 scientific studies. The first study examines 3 different management methods of late-successional forest after a major fire. These methods are: dead tree salvage harvest, limited harvest of some dead-trees, and finally, limited harvest along with planting of fire-resistant pines and prescribed burns. The second study looks at 3 different forest management practices in the five-rivers watershed east of Waldport. Proposed are 3, 5-hour field trips, 3, 2-hour workshops, 2 publications, 8 instructional video clips, and updated websites.

The applicant will conduct critical analyses of monitoring results for 54,000 acres of forested watersheds.  Also, lower the cost per unit area of effective watershed and landscape monitoring by developing lidar-based methods that minimize costs while maximizing efficiency for a variety of questions.  Partners include Oregon Watersheds and Websites Project Inc., Forest Service Research, Siuslaw and Rogue River - Siskiyou National Forests, Regional Ecology Program, The Nature Conservancy, and others.

Project Name: South Fork Siletz River (Valsetz) Log Crib Removal Impact Assessment
Project Summary: In this Technical Assistance project, the Oregon Wildlife Heritage Foundation (OWHF) is partnering with ODFW and Forest Capital Partners to assess the amount of sediment trapped behind the remaining dam and the potential downstream effects of releasing the sediment if the remaining dam structure were removed. OWEB funds would be used to hire a stream hydrologist/engineer to perform a hydraulic study to determine the effects of removing the remaining log crib structure.

Project Name: Clatskanie River Hydraulic and Hydrologic Analysis
Project Summary: In this Technical Assistance project, the Lower Columbia River Watershed Council is working with NRCS, the Columbia SWCD, the City of Clatskanie,  ODOT and the members of the Clatskanie River Coordinated Resource Planning Partners to implement a hydraulic and hydrologic analysis of 8.7 miles of the lower Clatskanie River system. A hydraulic model would be developed with the capability to model fish passage, channel bank stabilization, sedimentation, flood and restoration analyses and model the tidal influence of the Columbia River on the study reach. Over 90% of the requested OWEB funds are budgeted for the survey, analysis, development and calibration of the model.

Project Name: Limiting Factors Project Development (5 Rivers/Upper Yaquina)
Project Summary: In this proposal, the MidCoast Watershed Council is proposing to hire a consulting firm to design a number of restoration projects on high intrinsic potential reaches in the upper Yaquina and the Five Rivers (Alsea) sub-basins. Multiple properties are involved and the effort will require an extensive outreach effort to identify willing landowners and design projects specific to their properties. Partners with the Council in this effort are the Freshwater Trust ($10,000 cash), the USFS Siuslaw National Forest ($5,120 in-kind), the Alsea Stewardship Group ($1,500 cash) and the Lincoln SWCD ($900 in-kind). The huge majority of OWEB funds are budgeted for contracted services for landowner outreach and site-specific restoration project designs (88%).

Project Name: Nehalem - Riparian Restoration - Jewell Meadows - Phase IV
Project Summary: With this project, the Council would complete the fourth and final phase of a planting project on Fishhawk Creek in the Jewell Meadows Wildlife Area, once again partnering with ODFW, DEQ and the BLM nursery to address temperature and future large wood recruitment issues by the planting of a minimum of 700, 3-ft or taller, native conifers and hundreds of native shrubs along a 2,000 ft reach of Beneke Creek and an 800 ft reach of Fishhawk Creek. As with the previous planting efforts in the JMWA, 350-400 wooden structures will be built to protect groups of trees and shrubs from browsing, trampling or horning by elk and/or deer. The majority of OWEB funds are budgeted for planting and fencing activities (45%), tree protection (fencing) materials (28%) and project management (11%).

This application would continue the fencing and planting program in the upper Nehalem, with a focus on the E. Fork Nehalem, by outreach to additional landowners and the development of new cooperator agreements and riparian planting project designs. The project aims to develop 20 Cooperator agreements, with 16 of those involving landowners in the E. Fork sub-basin. Partners in the project will include the Upper Nehalem Watershed Council and DEQ. The majorities of the requested OWEB funds are budgeted for an Outreach contractor (74%) and project management (14%).

The Central Coast Land Conservancy requests $53,450 to purchase an 18-acre conservation easement on a property adjacent to the Miami River in Tillamook County, approximately 0.5 miles upriver from Tillamook Bay.  The property contains floodplain wetlands, inter-tidal marsh, and channel habitats.  The conservation easement is intended to protect the propertys existing habitat values and the outcomes of a large restoration project that is scheduled to begin in 2010.  The application states that the project will benefit priority species such as Chinook salmon, chum salmon, coho salmon, and steelhead.

The Alsea Watershed Council is working with a private landowner, the Siuslaw National Forest and ODFW on this Technical Assistance project. The project would hire a consulting firm to study the hydraulics of the Canal Creek sub-basin for the purpose of designing large wood placements on two properties, owned by the same entity, in the sub-basin. OWEB funds are budgeted for the hydraulic modeling and design on the lower property (55%) and the design work on the upper property (32%).

In this application, the Alsea Watershed Council is working with Benton County Public Works, BLM, ODFW and Weyerhaeuser to replace 5 undersized and poorly designed culverts in Trout Creek, a tributary of the S. Fork Alsea River, with new culverts properly sized and placed to allow total passage to all life stages of salmonids and other aquatic organisms. Three sites below culvert #1 would also receive large wood structures as would one site between culvert #1 and 3. Approximately 4,500 willows would also be planted downstream of culvert #1. OWEB funds are budgeted for culvert purchase and materials (52%), equipment and labor for installation of the culverts and placement of some large wood structures (37%) and project management (6%).

In this Technical Assistance application, the Lower Nehalem Watershed Council is partnering with ODFW, the Tillamook Estuaries Partnership and Tillamook County  to complete topographic and hydrologic surveys of the floodplain area and infrastructure of Trib C from upstream of Gods Valley Road downstream to Gods Valley Creek; to then process the survey data and develop preliminary design concepts for channel reconstruction, culvert crossing improvements and riparian and in-stream enhancements. Once the concepts are developed and reviewed by the project partners, final designs will be created and applications for permits for implementation will be submitted. OWEB funds will be used for contracted services (88%), project management and travel.

This project would address both the lack of native vegetation on the lower reaches of the Necanicum and Neawanna Rivers and also help educate tourists and residents to watershed and estuary health issues. It would do so by removing invasive plant species along 0.5 miles of Necanicum Drive on City property in downtown Seaside and replanting that stretch with appropriate native vegetation. The same activities would occur on another 2.5 acres along the lower Neawanna River. Educational interpretive signage on estuary and riparian habitats and values would be created and placed in highly visible areas on Necanicum Drive. OWEB funds are budgeted for project management (38%), planting labor (22%), materials (16%), educational signage & outreach (14%) and administration (8%).

In this application, the Lower Nehalem Watershed Council is partnering with ODF, BLM, the Fire Mountain School and ODFW to conduct an invasive species removal and conifer planting project along roughly six miles of mainstem Cook Creek, a tributary of the lower Nehalem River. 12 designated camping sites would be treated for invasive species removal (Scotch Broom and Blackberry) and selectively replanted with conifers. Six miles of mainstem riparian area would be planted with 20,000 native conifers (Sitka Spruce, Western Red Cedar, Western Hemlock and Douglas Fir) and 1,000,000 hemlock seeds would be manually dispersed. OWEB funds are budgeted for planting and invasive species removal labor (49%), project management (27%) and tree protection supplies (14%).

In this application, the City of Cannon Beach is proposing a multi component project to restore the Little Pompey Wetland, a historic estuarine marsh within the city limits by: replacing three existing, non-functioning tidegates with one properly sized, fully operational gate to restore hydraulic connection and provide salmonid access; treating stormwater to remove pollutants before allowing it back into the wetland and; excavating and re-opening tidal channels within the wetland. 67% of the requested OWEB funds are budgeted for the purchase and installation of the Flow-Through Stormwater Filtration System and the tidegate and culvert. Another 25% is requested for a variety of activities including tidal channel excavation, the reconnection of a historic tributary to the wetland, surveying and staking, invasive plant removal, erosion control and planting. Project management is budgeted for 8%.

Project Name: Upper Miami River Restoration Project Phase I
Project Summary: In this application, the Tillamook Watershed Council proposes a multi-component restoration project to address all of the priority limiting factors over a five-mile reach of the upper Miami mainstem and the lower reaches of a couple of the tributaries in that 5-mile reach of mainstem. The project would place 206 key pieces of large wood and 103 secondary pieces in structures at roughly 40 sites in the five-mile reach. 50 boulders will be incorporated, most in clusters in the mainstem Miami while a few are proposed for use as ballast in some of the large wood structures. In addition, a one-mile section of road along one of the tributaries will be decommissioned and 10-acres of riparian habitat are proposed to be underplanted with a mixture of hemlock and fir. OWEB funds are budgeted for contracted services (69% - equipment & labor to haul and place logs and boulders, decommission the road and plant trees), supplies/materials (23% - purchase of logs and boulders), project management (3%) and administration (4%).

In this application, the Siuslaw Watershed Council is working with Roseburg Resource Company and ODFW in middle and upper Swamp Creek high in the Siuslaw River basin to replace two undersized fish barrier culverts and place large wood structures in 15 sites in roughly 2 miles of Swamp Creek. OWEB funds are budgeted for contracted services (54% equipment and operator time), supplies/materials (36% culverts and logs) and administration (9%).

Project Name: Forest to the Sea Outdoor Schools and Habitat Comparison Studies
Project Summary: In this application the MidCoast Watershed Council is proposing a further expansion of its Education program by focusing efforts on 4th-5th and 6th grade students with the goal to get youth outside, learning and enjoying the environment. The proposed new program component would include day-trip field experiences conducting comparison studies on two streams near the students schools, and for 6th grade students, five 5-day Outdoor School camps with 450 total student participants. The requested OWEB funds are budgeted for project management staff (75%), stipends for additional time for school teachers (15%) and administration.

Oregon Rangeland Trust (ORT) proposes to purchase a 3,514-acre conservation easement on a working cattle ranch in Lake County, near Lakeview.  The application states that the ranch contains high-demand home sites, and that an easement is necessary to protect the property from rampant real estate development.  The property contains portions of Bauers, Spring, Synder, Antone, Cox, and Camp creeks, which join Thomas Creek downstream of the property.  Currently, the ranchs nine linear miles of stream are unfenced and accessible by livestock.  The application states that riparian fencing and habitat restoration will occur on the property, benefiting redband trout, Goose Lake lamprey, Goose Lake sucker, and other species.  This project was first submitted to OWEB during the October 2008 grant cycle (application 209-108), but was withdrawn from that grant cycle by ORT.

The project proposes the placement of 20 log habitat enhancement structures in approximately 0.75 miles of Russell Creek, in the Smith River watershed. The structures will reconnect the stream channel with the flood plain, trap gravel and woody debris to create spawning beds, complex pools and additional winter refuge opportunities.

The project will address five fish passage barriers and sediment sources in two tributaries to South Tenmile Lake. Under this proposal, project partners will correct fish passage and sediment input issues at five stream crossings to improve salmonid and wildlife access to approximately 16 miles of high priority native salmonid rearing habitat as well as permanently remove approximately 570 cubic yards of perched sediment from these high priority stream crossings.

Project Name: Big Creek Fish Passage and Sediment Abatement
Project Summary: The project proposes to implement approximately 13,000 feet of exclusion fence,  five bank stabilization sites, improve 3 off-channel watering sources, upgrade 11 ditch relief pipes on field roads and correct 15 improperly functioning stream crossings in Big Creek, a tributary to North Tenmile Lake.

The project proposes to implement 11,000 feet of exclusion fencing,  8 bank stabilization fixes,  improve 3 off-channel watering sources,  upgrade 4 ditch relief pipes on agricultural roads and correct 2 improperly functioning stream crossings on Johnson Creek, a tributary to Tenmile Lakes.

The requested funding will enable the Governor's Oregon Solutions effort, the Applegate Sustainable Aggregate Project (ASAP), to proceed through its next phase of development of scientifically sound solutions for sustainable gravel mining in the Applegate valley, located in the Rogue River basin. The ASAP team is comprised of Jackson and Josephine Counties, the Applegate Partnership and Watershed Council (APWC), state and federal agencies, and a variety of other stakeholders that share a common interest in the health of the watershed.

Project Name: Jackson Creek Fish Passage Design at Hanley Road
Project Summary: This project proposes to fund the required property and stream surveys to assist in the development of solutions to stabilize the channel throughout the project reach which will benefit landowner's properties, improve instream habitat, and allow fish passage past a barrier located on Jackson Creek, a tributary to Bear Creek, located in the Rogue River watershed.

The project activities under this proposal include the removal of dense non-native vegetation and replanting with a diverse selection of native trees and shrubs over approximately 11.5 acres. The project is located at the confluence of Ashland and Bear creeks, in the Rogue River watershed, which support several species of anadromous and resident native fish. These streams are impaired for temperature, bank stability, and lack of large woody debris.

A variety of native species including conifers, deciduous trees and shrubs will be planted based on site prescriptions along three miles of Bear Creek and its tributaries within the City of Medford. Bear Creek is a sub-basin in the Rogue River watershed.

The project proposes to develop a riparian design plan to remove non-native species along a 1,000 foot section of bank on the Little Butte Creek, a tributary to the Rogue River. The design plan will also include an engineered approach to reshape and stabilize the streambank for replanting with native species.

The project proposes to develop a comprehensive plan for the eventual return of beavers to the waterways of Williams Creek valley. Williams Creek is a tributary to the Applegate River located in the Rogue River watershed.

Project Name: Main Stem Williams Creek Restoration Analysis
Project Summary: The project will fund technical assistance support to help identify appropriate locations and designs for instream wood placements on private lands along salmon bearing reaches of the mainstem of Williams Creek. Williams Creek is a tributary to the Applegate River located in the Rogue River watershed.

Project Name: Bioswale Wetland Filtration and Stream Restoration
Project Summary: The project proposes the placement of over 80 large logs into the creek at 12 sites along a 0.4-mile reach creating multiple log and boulder jams in a major tributary to Upper Williams Creek, located in the Applegate River watershed in the Rogue River basin.

Elk Creek is a tributary to the Rogue River above the City of Shady Cove.  Under this proposal stream surveys will be conducted in this watershed with an emphasis on beavers and beaver habitats.    Work activities will concentrate on surveying for potential log placement sites and beaver survival areas in the Elk Creek and its tributaries.

Project Name: Sucker Creek Channel and Floodplain Restoration - Phase 2
Project Summary: This project will restore a natural meander pattern to a mile section of stream that has been straightened and altered from historic conditions. The project is located in Sucker Creek, a major fish-producing tributary to the Illinois River located in the Rogue River basin.

Project Name: East Fork Illinois River: Reach-scale Analysis & Restoration Design
Project Summary: This project proposes to assess and develop solutions to a severely degrading reach of the East Fork Illinois River, a tributary to the Illinois River in the Rogue River watershed. This system is a designated Salmon Stronghold, but is limited by factors including degraded riparian habitat, loss of channel complexity, high summer water temperatures and lack of in-stream structure.

Project Name: White-Deer Creek Habitat and Channel Enhancement Design
Project Summary: The proposed activity is a stream reconnaissance and assessment to develop a restoration strategy and rehabilitation design for a highly disturbed reach of Deer Creek, a critical stream for several species of anadromous fish including coho salmon. Deer Creek is a tributary to the Illinois River, located in the Rogue River watershed.

The project proposes to construct 1.25 miles of riparian fencing along Catching Creek, a tributary to the South Fork Coquille approximately one mile upstream from the City of Myrtle Point,  to exclude livestock from the stream, remove invasive plants and replant the riparian area with a mixture of native tree and shrub species appropriate for these sites.

The project proposes to construct 1,700 feet of riparian fencing to exclude livestock along the East fork Coquille River and remove invasive plants and replant the riparian area with a mixture of native tree and shrub species.

This project proposes to place approximately 400 pieces of large wood over approximately 5 miles of stream to restore instream cover, pool and riffle diversity.  The proposed instream restoration project is located in Elk Creek a 6 field watershed within East Fork Coquille River, approximately 10 miles northeast of Myrtle Point.

Building on the Coos Watershed Association's established riparian restoration program, the project will employ a 3 person riparian crew with a crew leader for two years to maintain riparian restoration projects by controlling weeds and insuring plant protection is in place.

Project Name: Williams River Watershed Habitat Improvement Phase I
Project Summary: This project would install 110 cross-drain culverts, replace 23 broken culverts, and upgrade 6 damaged or undersized stream crossings, including the construction of a 95 foot, full spanning, bridge at one site.  The project is located in the Williams River Watershed, about 20 miles west of Roseburg and 30 miles east of Coos Bay in the Oregon Coast Range.

The project proposes to help restore a reach of Ross Slough through riparian plantings of conifers, hardwoods and shrubs on 1.2 acres and the installation of 2,500 feet of fence. Ross Slough is a historical tidal wetland and tributary stream to the west of Catching Slough which connects directly to Coos Bay.

Project Name: North Slough Creek Riparian Restoration Project
Project Summary: The project proposes to control noxious weeds, eliminate livestock access, and establish a riparian buffer on 3.5 acres of streambank as part of a long-term CREP contract on the mainstem and tributary stream reaches of North Slough Creek, a tributary to Coos Bay.  The project will also replace an undersized 48 inch culvert and place large wood instream.

Abstract:   The project will improve habitat and restore instream processes in approximately three quarters of a mile of Cox Creek. Under this proposal, secondary channels and expanded wetland areas will be created at three sites. Cox Creek is a tributary to Elk Creek in the Umpqua River basin.

The project will improve habitat in approximately three quarters of a mile of Andrews Creek. Large wood structures will be placed at twenty sites, incorporating approximately 100 large logs, to reconnect the stream to the floodplain and create complex pool habitat. Andrews Creek is located in the Billy Creek watershed, a tributary to Elk Creek in the Umpqua River basin.
The project proposes to remove two culverts and add large wood to help restore instream habitat functions. Billy Creek is a tributary to the Elk Creek watershed, a tributary to the Umpqua River.

This project will improve Cook Creek's fish habitat and water quality by reestablishing 25-foot riparian buffers along the stream channel, placing 54 log structures within the stream, increasing the stream length by 147 feet by constructing meanders within the most constrained and incised section of stream and building a 710-foot bioswale adjacent to Highway 138E to filter contaminated road run-off.   The project will occur along a 0.65 mile of Cook Creek, a tributary to Calapooya Creek that flows through the City of Sutherlin and along Highway 138E and empties into the Umpqua River.

The project in Lobster creek would reconstruct a gravel bar using material from an existing mid-channel gravel bar, supplemented with native material and large wood.  Above and below the bar boulder/log complexes would be installed and the area would be planted with willows and cottonwoods, in the lower riparian area and cedar and Douglas fir higher up n the stream banks.
The project proposes to develop designs for replacement of five culvert sets along a 1.3 mile stretch of Redlick Creek, a tributary to the Rogue River below the City of Shady Cove.

Project Name: Knapp-Kamph New River Habitat Improvement Plan
Project Summary: The project proposes to develop an implementation plan for two New River ranches, totaling over 1900 acres in size. Five restoration priorities: instream habitat, sediment sources, pasture runoff, riparian restoration, and wetlands; will be evaluated for project opportunities that address limiting factors to water quality and instream habitat.

Project Name: Fate and Days Creeks Stream Restoration
Project Summary: This project seeks to build instream habitat structures with 100 logs and 500 boulders, clear five acres of riparian blackberry, and replant with native species to improve the quality of habitat over one mile of Fate Creek and Days Creek, tributaries to the South Umpqua River.

This project seeks funds to restore riparian and instream habitats along one mile of instream and riparian habitat in Morgan Creek near Canyonville. Morgan Creek is a tributary to the South Umpqua River.

The project proposes to implement 11,000 feet of exclusion fencing,  8 bank stabilization fixes,  improve 3 off-channel watering sources,  upgrade 4 ditch relief pipes on agricultural roads and correct 2 improperly functioning stream crossings on Johnson Creek, a tributary to Tenmile Lakes.

This riparian enhancement project continues ongoing efforts by Bear Creek Watershed Council to improve riparian function. The project focuses on three miles of Bear Creek and its tributaries within the City of Medford. Bear Creek is a sub-basin in the Rogue River watershed.

The proposed project will take place in the Illinois River valley located in the Rogue River watershed and will be overseen by the Forestry Action Committee (FAC). This tree planting project has been ongoing for the last 17 years and has provided 289,760 native seedlings for riparian and associated upland areas on private property. The project involves approximately 80 landowners a year. The FAC will develop site prescriptions and assist in planting activities.

The project proposes to provide a restoration plan for a 1,000 foot section of Lone Pine Creek and a 0.25 acre adjacent wetland. Lone Pine Creek is a tributary of Bear Creek in the Rogue River watershed.

Quartz Creek is a tributary to Jump off Joe Creek, a tributary to the Rogue River located near Merlin, Oregon. The project proposes to improve instream habitats in Quartz Creek. Under this proposal, 20-25 large wood and rock complexes will be created along 1,800 feet of Quartz Creek. The project will increase the quality and quantity of rearing and spawning habitat and riparian cover on private lands for coho and steelhead.

Project Name: Ni-les'tun Tidal Wetland Restoration Effectiveness Monitoring
Project Summary: The 418 acre Ni-les'tun Unit of Bandon Marsh NWR is the largest tidal wetland restoration project in Oregon. The proposed 5 year monitoring project proposes to document the effectiveness of this restoration investment.

The applicant proposes to decommission a failing fifty-four foot railcar bridge crossing on Hubbard Creek and replace it in another location with a bridge located out of the historic floodplain. Additionally, sixty large pieces of wood and one-hundred boulders would be placed in Luval Creek a tributary to Hubbard Creek. Hubbard Creek is a tributary to the Umpqua River, located near Umpqua, Oregon.

The proposed project would target K-12 students living in the Bear Creek watershed. The Bear Creek Education Partners (BCWEP) aims to promote community watershed stewardship ethic by cultivating a sense of place among local students. The anticipated barrier to learning is the lack of exposure that modern students have to their surrounding environment. BCWEP will address this challenge through workshops, student and community events, a watershed symposium, field experiences, classroom programs and school equipment supplementation.

Project Name: Coquille Fish Trap Creek Riparian Fencing 2010
Project Summary: The applicant proposes to construct 1.42 miles of electric riparian fencing to exclude livestock from the stream, install an off-channel watering system, remove invasive plant species, replant riparian areas with native tree species and install a small bridge on Fish Trap Creek, a tributary to the Coquille River.

Project Name: North Fork/East Fork Coquille Watershed Restoration Project Development
Project Summary: The project proposes to target the North and East Forks of the Coquille River for engaging local citizens and landowners in identifying and developing restoration priorities and projects.

Project Name: Coquille Catching Creek Creek Riparian Fencing 2010
Project Summary: The project proposes to construct 1.25 miles of riparian fencing along Catching Creek, a tributary to the South Fork Coquille approximately one mile upstream from the City of Myrtle Point. The project's goals are to restore the riparian zone by excluding livestock from the stream, removing invasive plants and replanting the riparian area with a mixture of native tree and shrub species appropriate for the site.

The applicant proposes to implement a riparian improvement project on the main stem Little Butte Creek near Lake Creek. Little Butte Creek is located in the Rogue River watershed. 700 lineal feet of four strand barbed wire fencing will be constructed, invasive species (Himalayan blackberry) will be removed and 0.75 acres will be planted with native tree and shrub species.

The applicant proposes to undertake instream habitat work on 16 private landowner properties on the West Fork Williams Creek. Williams Creek is a tributary to the Applegate River in the Rogue River watershed. The project would create 45 large wood and boulder clusters along two miles of stream.

The applicant proposes to address stream segments in the Applegate River watershed that are on the 303(d) list for exceeding summer stream water temperature standards through riparian restoration and protection activities. 60 acres will be planted covering over 5 miles of stream bank and sites with livestock concerns will be fenced.

This TA#1 resubmission will design large wood placement on lower Beaver Creek near its confluence with the Sandy River in Troutdale. Lower Beaver Creek is limited by water quality issues, lack of large wood, reduced off-channel habitat, and a riparian corridor dominated by invasive species. There is a lack of complex habitat for Chinook salmon as well as Coho, steelhead, and cutthroat trout. A steep hillside on the west side of the project site and private property on the north side limit the kind of projects that can be undertaken. Still, there is opportunity to improve instream complexity by adding large wood. To that end, The applicant proposes to hire a contractor to determine the most effective means of installing large wood in the stream. Ultimately, large woody debris placed in lower Beaver Creek is expected to be pinned in a rigid matrix and anchored with boulders. Partners include the Bill Healy Foundation, Jackson Foundation, and ODFW. OWEB funds will be used principally for contracted services and travel to the site.

This project will enhance approximately 700 feet of stream channel and habitat along Abernathy and Park Place creeks in Clackamas Countys Abernethy Subbasin, near Oregon City.  The watershed priorities include reducing sediment loads, reducing erosion to streambanks, increasing channel complexity, increasing riparian tree canopy, and improving habitat for threatened and endangered species. Proposed modifications will enhance approximately 0.6 acres of stream channel and habitat. The conceptual design contains three significant components to restore natural stream processes and increase stream complexity to enhance habitat:  1) bank re-shaping and excavation,  2) installation of LWD Structures and placement of boulders, and 3) installation of bioengineering treatments along the streambank. Partners include volunteers, Weyerheauser, Metro Nature in Neighborhoods, Oregon City and ODFW. OWEB funds will be used primarily for project management, contracted services, supplies and materials, and travel.

The Springfield Mill Race is a diversion off the lower Middle Fork Willamette River at approximately RM 191 near Lane Countys Clearwater Park. The Mill Race flows for approximately 4 miles and rejoins the mainstem Willamette River near downtown Springfield. The Mill Race follows a meandering northwesterly course through natural and agricultural lands, past rural residential urban and industrial areas, and into a 30-acre Mill Pond about three miles downstream of its inlet. The pond is impounded by the Booth-Kelly dam and presents water quality and habitat limitations. The dam is about 15 feet high with a spillway and ineffective fish ladder, making it a major deterrent to fish passage. Removal of the dam is a key element of the Springfield Mill Race Restoration project, which is a comprehensive effort planned with the Army Corps of Engineers to address fish passage, water flow, and habitat and water quality issues. In addition to the Corps, partners include the City of Springfield Public Works, Bonneville Environmental Foundation, Bullitt Foundation, Public Works and Economic Development Program, and NOAA. OWEB funds will be used to pay for a portion of the Corps cost to remove the dam and restore the channel area around the dam.

This project, located on Blair Creek in the lower Greasy Creek subbasin of the Marys River Watershed, will remedy in-stream habitat connectivity limitations by replacing culverts along a 1.3-mile reach of Blair Creek. Land use within this area is primarily rural residential. Restoration of fish passage within this creek was initiated in 2007 by Benton SWCD Fish Passage Improvement Program culvert surveys. OWEB funded the restoration of the Highway 34 crossing at the mouth of Blair Creek in 2008. This investment was followed later that year by Oregon Trout (now, The Freshwater Trust) funding engineered designs for eight private culverts and the removal of three more fish passage barriers. Partners include Benton County, Benton SWCD, and The Freshwater Trust. OWEB funds will be used for pre-implementation design, project management, contracted services, supplies and materials, and education and outreach.

With this proposal, Marys River Watershed Council's restoration efforts will continue to build on strategic outreach efforts for landowner recruitment and project development in five priority subbasins in the Marys River Watershed. Over the past 3.5 years, landowner outreach efforts have resulted in more than 100 landowners participating in restoration or conservation actions, including 40 landowners in the Blakesley Creek (Cardwell Hill) subbasin, 35 landowners in the Woods Creek subbasin, and 14 landowners in the Greasy Creek subbasin. This proposal seeks to recruit 30 new landowners within two additional subbasins (Tum Tum and Upper Marys River) to participate in planning and implementing restoration that addresses limiting factors of stream temperatures, habitat connectivity and habitat complexity. Partners include The Freshwater Trust, Benton SWCD, and USFWS. OWEB funds will be used primarily for contracted services to support landowner outreach activities.

Approximately 65% of historically accessible stream miles in the Glenn and Gibson creeks watershed have been lost due to fish passage barriers. On lower Gibson Creek in the Salemtowne community, a small dam creates a pond on the edge of a golf course. An older fish way on the dam is impassable. As the lowest barrier on Gibson Creek, its removal is a high priority for the City of Salem. The lower reach of the stream is designated migration and rearing habitat for winter steelhead and several additional miles are used by a variety of other native fish. The applicant proposes to contract with an environmental engineering firm to design and oversee the restoration of fish passage at the site. Partners include: Salemtowne Civic Association, Polk SWCD and City of Salem, NFWF, and ODFW. OWEB funds will be used primarily for contracted services.

Project Name: Gales Creek Rippling Wates Restoration Project
Project Summary: Chronic inputs of sediment from bank erosion and lack of main- and off-channel habitat for native fish and amphibians affect much of lower Gales Creek. An enhancement plan developed for the lower creek placed a high priority on projects that improve aquatic habitat through riparian planting, introduction of large wood, and enhancement of off-channel habitat. The proposed project was identified to meet all of these high-priority objectives by enhancing 1000 feet of degraded secondary channel, constructing several engineered log jams on the mainstem, protecting an eroding bank using bioengineering techniques, and revegetating 1.2 acres of streambank and floodplain. Partners include the landowners, Washington County, and ODFW. OWEB monies will be used primarily for project management, contracted services, supplies and materials, and permits.

Peckenpaugh Drainage Ditch traverses 5.7 miles of Linn County farmland before emptying into Muddy Creek. The seasonal ditch is characterized by an overall lack of vegetation and steep, eroding banks, resulting in high sediment transport to Muddy Creek. Where vegetation does exist, it tends to be thickets of reed canary grass. Nutria present a growing problem. The applicant seeks technical assistance funding to engineer and design for grade stabilization, using a bioengineered approach to create a functioning grassed waterway. Partners include OSU Extension and ODA. OWEB funds will be used primarily for project management and contracted services.

This project takes place at two sites in the Columbia Slough Watershed owned by Portland Parks & Recreation: Whitaker Ponds Nature Park and Johnson Lake Natural Area. Whitaker Ponds is a popular urban, open-air learning center and both sites are important wildlife links in a chain of water bodies, including Smith and Bybee Wetlands Natural Area. The sites were privately held until 1995, when Metro purchased them. Metro invested heavily in clearing the sites of invasive plant species and developing the office and environmental center for the Columbia Slough Watershed Council at Whitaker Ponds. While the current stewardship of both sites is effective, the level is inadequate to fully restore the natural riparian communities. The applicant proposes to remove invasives and re-plant approximately 22 acres. Given the projects location, it has significant educational opportunities, as well as job training opportunities for low-income people. Partners include the Columbia Slough Watershed Council and Portland Parks and Recreation. OWEB funds will be used primarily for project management, contracted services, supplies and materials, and education and outreach.

A perennial, unnamed tributary to Tickle Creek in Clackamas County supports Coho, winter steelhead, and cutthroat trout. Two culverts on private property on this tributary are velocity barriers to juvenile Coho. The applicant proposes to replace the culverts with one, 20-foot span pre-cast modular concrete bridge. Replacing the culverts will allow unrestricted fish passage of nearly three miles of spawning and rearing habitat. Partners include the landowner and ODFW. OWEB funds will be used primarily for pre-implementation designs, project management, and supplies and materials.

Remove an existing 48-foot metal culvert on Holcomb Creek, a tributary to Abernethy Creek to the Lower Willamette River. Holcomb Creek supports federally listed Coho and winter steelhead, cutthroat trout, and Pacific and Brook lamprey. The existing culvert is perched and undersized, causing a velocity and debris barrier. The stream tops the road every few years, causing erosion. The applicant proposes to replace the culvert with one, 20-foot span pre-cast modular concrete bridge.  Replacing the culvert will allow unrestricted fish passage nearly three miles of spawning and rearing habitat. Partners include the landowners, Clackamas SWCD, ODFW, and the Fish America Foundation. OWEB funds will be used primarily for pre-implementation design and permitting, project management, and supplies and materials.

This project is focused on a sustainable desired future condition for habitat, vegetation and water quality in Portlands 5,000-acre Forest Park?a mixed conifer and hardwood forest on the western flank of the Willamette River. This project will improve coniferous and hardwood forest habitat.  Invasive species will be removed from approximately 160 acres and native species will be planted on 25 acres.  Up to 100 conifers encroaching into Oregon white oak habitat along the perimeter of the park will be thinned.  The project will reduce wildfire hazard conditions, as well as enhance critical Oregon oak habitat.  Ecologically, the project also addresses watershed function by providing an improved nutrient cycling system and anchor habitat for flora and fauna. Partners include Linnton Neighborhood Association, City of Portland Bureau of Environmental Services, West Multnomah SWCD, PGE, and FEMA.  OWEB funds will be used primarily for project management, contracted services, and supplies and materials.

Project Name: Scappoose Bay Watershed Limiting Factors Analysis
Project Summary: The applicant seeks to conduct a Limiting Factors Analysis of high-priority Coho and other salmonid habitat for three 6th-field Hydrologic Units (HUCs)?South Scappoose, North Scappoose, and Milton creeks. Using existing GIS data, snorkel surveys of juvenile salmonids, Aquatic Habitat Inventories, and additional data collected in the analysis, the end product will identify habitat conditions that limit the success of salmonids within the three HUCs and will determine priority restoration prescriptions that address the habitat limitations and improve salmonids productivity. Partners include BLM and ODFW. OWEB funds will be used principally for contracted services.

A dual culvert system along Wolf Creek, a tributary to Mill Creek in the Mohawk River watershed, is undersized and acts as a barrier to cutthroat and rainbow trout. The project will replace the culverts with one 21-foot span, 7-foot rise open-bottom pipe arch culvert. The project will restore a natural substrate and debris migration pattern to the stream and open up four miles of important tributary habitat to aquatic passage. The project is located on a Lane County road and adjacent lands are owned by Weyerhaeuser. Partners include ODFW, Lane County Public Works, and Weyerhaeuser, which will contribute in-kind resources to the project. OWEB funds will be used for the purchase of the pipe arch culvert, contracted services, and project management.

Project Name: Clackamas Side Channel at Shoe Island
Project Summary: Although the Clackamas River is a stronghold for salmon species, it still lacks many of the qualities that would support expanded runs. The Clackamas River Basin Action Plan identifies lack of side channel habitat as a key limiting factor in the lower river. The applicant seeks technical assistance support to develop permit-ready plans and specifications for reconnecting the Shoe Island side channel to the Clackamas River. Partners include ODFW and The Nature Conservancy. OWEB funds will be used principally for contracted services.

Project Name: BRING Recycling Water Quality Demonstration Project
Project Summary: BRING recycling, located near the main stem Willamette River between Eugene and Springfield, is one of the earliest recycle/reuse facilities in the nation. Over 35,000 people visit the facility each year, making it an ideal education and demonstration site. Water quality is a major concern in this area due to the light industrial zoning, lack of stormwater infrastructure, large amounts of impervious surfaces, and the close proximity to the river. The potential for untreated run-off entering the river is high. BRING has identified this concern and proposes to address it by developing a green technology demonstration project that uses sustainable on-site stormwater practices to capture and treat or make use of 100 percent of the sites stormwater. OWEB funds will be used for pre-implementation design and contracted services to install a bio-swale and retention pond (to collect and bio-filtrate runoff from the sites impervious surfaces), install permeable pavers to allow for infiltration of runoff on a portion of the site, roof runoff cisterns for the collection of rainwater (to be used for irrigation of a native interpretive garden), and installation of a green roof to reduce roof runoff from the facilitys main public building. The project will also include interpretive signage for public education. Partners include BRING, Upper Willamette SWCD, and several local businesses.

Project Name: Oak Creek Landowner Recruitment for Restoration
Project Summary: This project will target 57 landowners in the Oak Creek Watershed in Benton Co. for riparian restoration. Resulting projects will address 303(d)-listed water quality parameters, including temperature, mercury, and bacteria. Project partners include ODFW, City of Corvallis, Benton SWCD, Marys River Watershed Council, OSU Extension, and Oregon Department of Environmental Quality.

Existing culverts in Harris Creek, a tributary to the upper Luckiamute River, are fish passage barriers. The culverts are perched, too small to effectively pass bank full flows, and the upper crossing is causing extreme channel and bank erosion. The project proposes to replace the lower culvert with a bottomless pipe arch. The paired 6-foot diameter upper culverts will be replaced with a counter-sunk pipe arch. The new culverts will meet or exceed ODOT/USFS stream simulation criteria. Additionally, two sets of concrete bridge pilings remain from the old Valley and Siletz Railroad line on the upper Luckiamute River. The pilings have accumulated massive log jams on a bedrock substrate that serve as partial barriers to upstream migration of native steelhead and cutthroat trout. The obstructions have caused a widening of the channel and bank erosion, potentially endangering private property. The Upper Luckiamute is in one of the conservation opportunity areas identified in the Oregon Conservation Strategy. Partners include the landowners, ODFW, ODF, and National Fish and Wildlife Foundation. OWEB funds will be used for pre-implementation design, supplies and materials, and contracted services.

The Portland Metro region lacks a guiding vision that defines regional goals for conserving and restoring species and habitat diversity. Such a vision is needed for context on how local protection and restoration efforts can interconnect to provide viable breeding, foraging, and migratory systems and to maintain intact populations of native fish and wildlife. The lack of such a plan means local efforts within the Portland Metro region often fail to address adequately how their efforts connect to the larger Puget Trough/Willamette Valley Eco-Region. The applicant is requesting funds for technical assistance to develop maps and models to support Metros current development of a regional conservation framework. Partners in the development of the framework are Metro Columbia Land Trust, Audubon Society of Portland, Urban Greenspaces Institute, USFWS, Trust for Public Lands and the Intertwine Alliance. OWEB funds will be used primarily for contracted services to develop the maps and models.

The Willamette Watershed Stewardship Project will provide through three community paddling events in the lower Willamette River watershed education and involvement opportunities to 700 youths and adults. This will include 24, fourth-sixthgrade teachers and their classes as well as local community members. Each class will receive four classroom lessons and one unique watershed field trip that includes a service learning element and an on-river paddling experience. An experienced staff of environmental educators will use successfully tested curricula. Participants will learn about their local watershed, watershed issues, and develop an increased appreciation of their local watershed through project activities. Participant interviews, surveys, tests, and extent of participation will determine project success. Partners include Portland Public Schools. OWEB funds will be used primarily for salaries, supplies, and travel.

Grantee: Friends of Buford Park & Mt Pisgah
Project Summary: Lane Countys 2300-acre Buford Park, located on the edge of Eugene-Springfield, is a valuable biological reserve of native Willamette Valley plant communities. Buford Park contains about 1500 acres of globally endangered plant communities (oak woodland, savanna, upland, and wetland prairies). Increased supplies of genetically-local native plant materials are needed to conserve these communities and support expanding habitat restoration activities throughout the southern Willamette Valley. The applicant proposes to expand its native plant nursery, which currently fills a critical role of propagating otherwise unavailable native plants in intermediate quantities. The applicant plans to add 30 new propagation beds, doubling the area in seed production and doubling the seed yield over time. Species mixes will be diversified, adding 16 new species to the 60 species currently producing seed. Partners include Lane County, Bonneville Power Administration, ODA, Norcross Foundation, and ODFW. OWEB funds will be used primarily for in-house personnel and contracted services.

Project Name: Lower Springfield Mill Race Restoration Plan
Project Summary: The Springfield Mill Race ? a 3.5 mile side channel of Middle Fork Willamette River ? is undergoing restoration for fish habitat on the upper three miles, ending at the point of a 15-foot dam removal. This leaves the lower half-mile reach as the final element of enhancement to the entire waterway. This section is heavily urbanized and requires a well-conceived restoration plan, considering bank and channel improvements, stormwater outfall management, noxious weed control and riparian planting, property owner agreements and/or land acquisition, and integration of educational/recreational opportunities. Partners include Willamalane Park and Recreation District and ODFW. OWEB funds will be used for professional design services to assist the City of Springfield with a restoration plan for this half-mile stretch.

An existing portion of the Peckenpaugh seasonal waterway has degraded with steep bank erosion. The proposed action for this resubmission is to design a means for stabilizing an approximately 4000 lineal foot section of the drainage, from its confluence with Muddy Creek to the crossing at Peckenpaugh Road. Partners include ODA, OSU Extension, Linn SWCD and Linn County Road Department. OWEB funds will be used primarily for contracted services to complete an engineering design.

Project Name: Assessing Riparian Habitat, Aquatic Habitat and Water Quality in the Chehalem Valley Watershed
Project Summary: Riparian habitat, aquatic habitat, and stream water-quality in the Chehalem Valley watershed are affected by urbanization, agriculture, and climate change. Riparian and aquatic habitat and most water quality parameters for the watershed have not been updated since 2001. There are scattered sites in the basin with data on E.Coli, dissolved oxygen and temperature, but those sites were last monitored in 2004. The applicant proposes to collect water-quality data and measure discharge at 16 sites in the watershed. In addition, the applicant will document the riparian and aquatic habitat at seven sites for one year. Using these data, the applicant will prioritize restoration projects to (1) increase the number and length of continuous cold-water refuge miles, and (2) improve water quality in the watershed. Project partners include Department of Agriculture, Oregon DEQ, Yamhill SWCD, and Yamhill Basin Council. OWEB funds will be used primarily project management, in-house personnel, and contracted services.

Currently two metal culverts on Delph Creek are barriers to fish passage due to a shallow downstream pool, the slope of pipes, and a two-foot perch at the outlets. This proposal is to replace the culverts with a pre-cast concrete modular bridge. This will open approximately 4.5 miles of high-quality spawning and rearing stream habitat to winter steelhead, Chinook and coho salmon. The bridge will be designed to pass a 100-year storm event. The applicant (Clackamas County Department of Transportation and Development) is proposing to fund 48 percent of the total cost and has submitted letters of support from Clackamas River Basin Council, and ODFW. OWEB funds will be used primarily for contracted services and supplies and materials.

Project Name: North Fork Molalla River Habitat Enhancement
Project Summary: The North Fork Molalla, a significant tributary to the Molalla River, needs structure to create rearing and spawning areas for Willamette ESU ESA-listed Chinook salmon and winter steelhead. The developed reach between Dead Horse Canyon and Lukens Creek is the appropriate gradient and flow for spawning and rearing; however, there is virtually no structure to capture and sort spawning gravel and create pools for rearing habitats. Currently the reach is not used for spawning and is used very little for rearing by either species. The proposed solution is to place large wood of adequate length and diameter along 5,500 feet of steam, anchored by boulders and secured by existing adjacent riparian trees. Effectiveness monitoring will be done through spawning surveys, snorkel surveys, and evaluation of gravel retention. Partners include the Native Fish Society (NFS), ODFW, and Weyerhaeuser Co. OWEB funds will be used primarily for contracted services and supplies materials.

Project Name: N and S Scappoose Creek Confluence Restoration
Project Summary: This project is located at the confluence of North and South Scappoose creeks in the Scappoose Bay Watershed, near the confluence of Multnomah Channel and the Columbia River. The primary objective of the project is to restore the function of the alluvial fan and improve habitat at the confluence of these two important salmon habitat creeks. The applicant proposes to address degrading creek conditions and disconnection of the creeks from the floodplain. Specifically, the project seeks to enhance the connection with an existing network of secondary channels through strategically engineered log jam placements; provide fish habitat through placement of large wood and backwater habitat enhancement; manage sediment inputs into the creek; and reestablish five acres of a healthy riparian forest. Baseline monitoring will document basic conditions at the site before and after implementation. Partners include National Fish and Wildlife Foundation, Lower Columbia River Estuary Program, Columbia SWCD, and ODFW. OWEB funds will be used primarily for contracted services and supplies materials.

Project Name: Jordan Creek Fish Passage and Water Quality Improvement
Project Summary: This project will replace or remove five fish passage barriers on Jordan Creek, a major tributary to Coyote Creek, which is a target sub-watershed of the Long Tom Watershed Council's Model Watershed Program. One culvert will be removed, another replaced with a rocked crossing, and two will be replaced with appropriately sized culverts. The fifth passage barrier is an irrigation dam/instream impoundment, which will be removed and replaced with a rock vane for instream grade control and an off-channel irrigation reservoir supplied by a 12-inch gravity-fed pipe with a screened head gate to prevent fish from entering the diversion. All structures will be designed for year-round fish passage. Adjacent pasture will be renovated and cross-fenced to improve water quality. Project partners include the landowner, NRCS, and Oregon Country Fair. OWEB funds will be used for project management, engineering oversight, permits, equipment rentals, supplies materials for multiple project elements, and effectiveness monitoring.

Project Name: Jordan Creek Fish Passage and Water Quality Improvement - Effectiveness Monitoring
