Project Summary: This 38-acre wetlands enhancement project is located near the headwaters of Upper Camas Swale Creek, nine miles west of the creeks confluence with the Coast Fork Willamette River. Here, where wet prairie and ash forest give way to steeper forested slopes, an extensive system of functional wetlands with good native plant community exists. Previous agricultural practices ditched the stream and plowed under parts of the native prairie, resulting in the loss of hydrologic function, native plant biodiversity, and wetland habitat for endemic species. The ditch has not downcut to shallow bedrock. The dredged material was placed in a berm next to the ditch, further restricting channel overflow to the surrounding wetland. This project proposes restoration on 23 acres and invasives control on an additional 15 acres. Partners include USFWS and the landowner. OWEB funds will be used primarily contracted services (targeted spraying of invasive species, thinning overstocked ash trees, log placement, planting and watering) and for supplies and materials (native seed and container stock).

Project Name: Mid Willamette Landowner Recruitment and Restoration Design
Project Summary: This project proposes to recruit landowners to participate in restoration projects for three priority sites in the Mill, Pringle, and Claggett creek watersheds. Selection of these sites is based on limiting factors, project availability, and habitat improvement. The applicant will recruit willing landowners to participate in the designs of restoration plans for their properties. . The goal is to contact 150 landowners in each of the three watersheds through informational meetings, tours of restoration sites, and media announcements. The applicant will contract with an engineer to develop restoration plans for up to 10 sites. Partners include the City of Salem, City of Keizer, and Marion Soil and Water Conservation District. OWEB funds will be used primarily for project management, including landowner outreach, and contracted services (designing the 10 plans).

Project Name: Oak Creek Landowner Recruitment for Riparian Restoration
Project Summary: Significant riparian restoration has been completed in the Oak Creek Watershed. However, the bulk of the restoration has occurred on Oregon State University lands, leaving opportunity and need for riparian restoration on privately owned lands. This project will target 57 landowners in the Oak Creek Watershed for riparian restoration. Resulting projects will address 303(d)-listed water quality parameters, including temperature, mercury, and bacteria. Landowners will be recruited through mailings, phone calls, neighborhood meetings, workshops, and tours of successful riparian restoration in the watershed. Project partners include ODFW, City of Corvallis, Marys River Watershed Council, and OSU Extension. OWEB funds will be used primarily for in-house personnel to recruit landowners.

Project Name: Willamette River and Johnson Creek Confluence Salmon Habitat Enhancements
Project Summary: The Lower Willamette River (defined as the 22 river miles between the Clackamas River input and the Multnomah Channel) suffers from lack of habitat complexity and floodplain interaction which is critical for rearing, migrating, and spawning salmonids. This project is located at the confluence of the Willamette River and Johnson Creek in Clackamas County. The project reach is defined as the quarter-mile stretch from the 17th Avenue Bridge crossing over Johnson Creek downstream to the creeks confluence with the Willamette River. The project will provide increased habitat complexity for numerous species, including federally listed coho salmon, steelhead trout, and spring Chinook salmon. All of the fish produced in the upper and mid-Willamette River basin migrate past the confluence with Johnson Creek and will benefit from improved cover and resting habitat resulting from the project. An effectiveness monitoring program will conduct spawning surveys and evaluate channel morphology, substrate, woody debris structures, and canopy cover for at least five years post implementation. OWEB funded initial project design to a 30 percent level for this project. Project design is now 90 percent complete. Partners include the Oregon Governors Fund, Jubitz Family Foundation, City of Portland, and PGE. OWEB funds will be used primarily for contracted services and project management.

Due to extensive alterations, Gales Creek has been identified as a high-priority stream by The Nature Conservancy, Metro, Clean Water Services, and the Tualatin River Watershed Council. This project will restore channel complexity, riparian forest, and access to off-channel habitat along nearly one mile of Lower Gales Creek. The project proposes to restore 10 acres of wet prairie and eight acres of riparian forest, improve water quality on Roderick Creek and fish passage in general, and conserve water. The OWEB portion of this multi-partner project seeks to construct an alcove off the creek and to improve 800 hundred feet of riparian area across and downstream of the alcove. The project has been identified as the first pilot project under the Willamette Partnerships Counting on the Environment  a system for quantifying and tracking flows of ecosystem services over time. The project demonstrates how interested landowners, detailed watershed priorities, and multiple funding sources can come together to increase the pace, scope, and effectiveness of restoration. Partners include the Willamette Partnership, Oregon Department of State Lands, Clean Water Services, Natural Resources Conservation Service, ODFW, and landowners. OWEB funds will be used primarily for contracted services and project management.

Project Name: Continuous Pesticide Monitoring in the Pudding Watershed
Project Summary: Pesticide use in Oregon watersheds, particularly those watersheds that provide salmon habitat, is of increasing concern. Monitoring studies in the Pudding watershed conducted by DEQ, USGS, and others suggest that pesticides in surface water may pose a risk to aquatic life, including ESA-listed salmonids. The Marion Soil and Water Conservation District, with technical support from Oregon State University, will employ new monitoring techniques to better define pesticide surface water loading in the Pudding Watershed. Using a passive sampling device, surface water concentrations of multiple pesticides will be monitored continuously at several locations in the Pudding watershed. Monitoring results will be used to parameterize a GIS-based environmental fate model (i.e., a model showing the environmental effects of specific pesticides). The model will be used in the evaluation of alternative best management practices and mitigation measures to reduce pesticide stream loading at the watershed scale. The main partner is OSU Extension. OWEB funds will be used primarily for the collection and analysis of monitoring samples.

The project is located on private property on McTimmonds Creek, a major tributary to the Luckiamute River. An existing concrete in-fill roadway and perched culvert is a barrier to fish passage, and is also causing stream bed and bank erosion. The barrier is located approximately 1.7 miles upstream of the creeks confluence with the Luckiamute River. The proposed solution is to remove the concrete road and culvert barrier and replace with a free-spanning bridge. Removal of this barrier will restore natural open channel stream flow, thereby reopening approximately 1.2 miles of the upstream sections of McTimmonds Creek to access for spawning and rearing habitat for native coho, Chinook, steelhead and cutthroat trout. The project complements the Luckiamute Watershed Rapid Bio-Assessment, conducted in 2008. The landowner is the sole project partner and the Luckiamute Watershed Council has provided a letter of support. OWEB funds will be used primarily for contracted services.

The Calapooia Watershed Noxious Weed Control project will take place in riparian areas along the mainstem Calapooia River in Linn County. The project addresses the problem of unhealthy riparian buffers by controlling Japanese knotweed and false brome infestations that are spreading through the Watershed's sensitive riparian habitats. The Calapooia Watershed Council proposes to expand its successful Knotweed Control Program to treat all known knotweed sites along 50 miles of the Calapooia River from above Holley to the Calapooia-Willamette confluence in Albany. The Council proposes to treat approximately 35 acres of false brome along headwaters tributaries and the Calapooia River, spread over 46 stream miles. Partners include USFS, BLM, Weyerhaeuser, Cascade Timber Consulting, Inc., and Linn County Road Department. OWEB funding will be used to treat riparian knotweed and false brome infestations, and to reseed and replant treatment sites with native vegetation.

Grantee: Lake County Cooperative Weed Management Area
Project Name: Warner Valley Noxious Weed Mapping Project
Project Summary: This project in Warner Valley, northeast of Lakeview, would inventory and map weed infestations such as pepperweed, hoary cress, Russian knapweed and Scotch thistle on over 124,000 acres.  The proposal is to use a helicopter mapping contractor using Digital Aerial Sketch Mapping.  The area covered includes over 30 different private landowners in addition to public lands.

This project would analyze the hydrology and stream condition of Hay Creek, a wet meadow system, a tributary to Drews Creek in the Goose Lake Watershed in Lake County.  The stream is downcut due to historical grazing practices and there are headcuts in a seasonally wet meadow that, if left untreated, will continue up the meadow.  The assessment will characterize the stream corridor and prioritize stream rehabilitation actions.

Project Name: Indian Creek Restoration Project - Markham Phase
Project Summary: This proposal in the Hood River Basin is to pipe 6,600 feet of irrigation canal that will eliminate eight diversions from Indian Creek, including two seasonal push-up dams which are partial fish passage barriers.  It is anticipated that .25 cfs of water loss will be eliminated which will remain in Indian Creek.  Farmers Irrigation District has been actively piping part of their system since the 1980s, several sections are still in open canals that collect runoff and contribute water quality problems to the Hood River, home to ESA listed salmon, bull trout and steelhead.

Project Name: Jack Creek Ponderosa Pine Savannah and Wetland Restoration
Project Summary: This proposal would remove encroaching conifer stands and restore wetland/wet meadow hydrology on nearly 800 acres on three sites within the Chemult Ranger District.   The project would repair four and install six new ditch plugs to restore 70 acres of wetland in an area drained for pasture.  One of the areas is part of a 250 acre meadow that was ditched and drained in the 1970s but acquired by the USFS through a land exchange in the early 1990s.

Project Name: Maury Mountains Ponderosa Pine Parkland and Sage/Shrubland Steppe Restoration
Project Summary: This proposal would thin juniper on 453 acres and both juniper and ponderosa pine on 319 acres to enhance and restore sagebrush steppe lands in the Maury Mountains east of Prineville.  The treatments will take place on four sites; North Hamer, South Hamer and North Shotgun and South Shotgun sub-basins to the Crooked River in the Ochoco National Forest.

This project would reconfigure and reconnect Badger Spring to the Sprague River west of Beatty in Klamath County.  The spring connection was straightened and now connects to the river by a gated culvert and there is no clearly defined channel between the spring and the Sprague River.  A new creek would be built that would mimic the original meandering connection over 1,070 feet.

Project Name: Upper Lytle Creek Whole Watershed Restoration
Project Summary: This project would remove 1540 acres of invasive juniper, treat medusahead and repair roads to reduce sedimentation into Lytle Creek, an intermittent tributary to the Crooked River below Prineville.  This project will treat these issues in the entire sub-watershed.  The juniper treatment will focus on spring areas to enhance flow and reduce the competition in aspen stands.  Treatment of medusahead and reseeding of 450 acres will take place and two miles of road improvements will take place to reduce sediment into the reservoir.

Project Name: Deep Creek Mouth and Vicinity Restoration Project
Project Summary: This project proposes to install 22,000 feet of fencing to create a riparian pasture of 470 acres, together with riparian plantings and stream channel habitat complexity work on Deep Creek, a tributary to the North Fork Crooked River east of Prineville.  Deep Creek is known as a genetic stronghold for redband trout due to lack of stocking, historically.

Project Name: Aquifer Recovery Planning for Streamflow Restoration
Project Summary: This project in the area of Mosier will use recently collected USGS data on the impact of cross-connected wells to prioritize wells for repair that would slow or reverse aquifer declines by fixing leaks in the groundwater system that are believed to reduce surface water flows in Mosier Creek and Lower Rock Creek by at least 20 percent.  The project will conduct further analysis of existing wells to document inter-aquifer flow.

Project Name: Juniper Flat Water Conveyance Efficiency - Section B
Project Summary: This project would help with several irrigation ditch repairs identified as necessary by a field crew last year looking for areas of major ditch loss.  The Juniper Flat District Improvement Company currently loses 50% more water than they divert because of ditch losses.  The water is diverted from Clear Lake Reservoir and the 9 cfs of water saved by the ditch repairs would benefit the district water users.

This project would recruit landowners to explore opportunities to engage local conservation groups and agencies in restoration projects on their lands in the upper Klamath Basin.  The majority of resource impacts to water quality and water quantity occur on private lands.  Through a series of workshops, field trips and individual consultations, resource issues will be discussed and individual projects will be targeted for design and partnership recruitment.

This project just east of Chiloquin on the Sprague River would install 1.75 miles of riparian fencing to protect 14.5 acres of riparian area and purchase and install three nose-pump livestock watering systems.  The riparian buffer will vary between 50 and 150 feet wide and will be managed to ensure recovery of the riparian area.  The project will reduce streambank degradation and improve water quality in the Sprague River and Upper Klamath Lake.

This project southeast of Bonanza in Klamath County would thin 180 acres of juniper on the toe of a southwest facing slope, above cultivated agricultural land.  The treatment is proposed in order to increase water infiltration and perennial grasses.  The restored understory should arrest overland flow and store more water in the soil profile.  The primary resource objective is to restore the understory of brush, forbs and bunchgrasses to benefit big game winter range, including deer, elk and antelope.

This project would construct 1.5 miles of fencing to protect the riparian zone along the inside of a curve on the Williamson River about a mile downstream of Chiloquin.  The riparian zone is in pretty good shape because livestock have been excluded historically by a major irrigation canal.  With the removal of Chiloquin Dam and a change in the point of diversion, the canal in the area is no longer being used.

This project on the North Fork Sprague River in Klamath County would replace an 84 foot long, 13 feet round culvert that, due to gradient and velocity, does not meet ODFW fish passage criteria and replace it with a free spanning bridge.  This will ensure access to 40 miles of perennial fish habitat for redband trout, Upper Klamath Lake lamprey and Pit-Klamath brook lamprey.

Project Name: TID - Tumalo Feed Canal Piping Phase 2
Project Summary: This proposal is to help fund Phase II of a multi-phase project to pipe the Tumalo Irrigation Districts Tumalo Feed Canal.  This phase would pipe 2.7 miles and result in permanent instream transfer of 4.6 cfs in Tumalo Creek and 3.5 cfs of winter storage releases to Crescent Creek, the Little Deschutes and the Deschutes River.  The project is just northwest of the City of Bend.

Project Name: Aquifer Recovery Planning for Streamflow Restoration
Project Summary: This project in the area of Mosier will use recently collected USGS data on the impact of cross-connected wells to prioritize wells for repair.  The goal of the repairs is to slow or reverse aquifer declines by fixing leaks in the groundwater system that are believed to reduce surface water flows in Mosier Creek and Lower Rock Creek by at least 20 percent.  The project will conduct further analysis of existing wells to document inter-aquifer flow.

Project Name: Seeds to Streambanks Native Plant Education
Project Summary: This project would involve incarcerated youth, elementary schools and homeowners with riparian habitat in propagating, planting and monitoring the success of riparian plants for streambank restoration within The Dalles.  The Northern Oregon Regional Correctional Facility (NORCOR) has a large greenhouse and they are looking for hands-on learning opportunities and science lessons for their 12 to 18 year old detainees.

This project would support the updating and printing of a Wasco County Rural Living Handbook.  It will help awareness of natural resource management issues that they may affect on their lands and it provides information on who to contact for assistance.  Through a wide variety of venues, the handbook will be available to all rural residents.

Project Name: Woody Species Planting Guide and Workshop
Project Summary: This project would convey proper riparian planting techniques to restoration agencies and conservation groups in the Upper Klamath Basin.  Through two workshops, a brochure and site visits, the participants will learn how to select the proper size and species of plants, where to plant them, how to plant them, protect them and maintain them long enough to ensure a high percentage of survival.
This project on the west edge of the Deschutes River nine miles south of Bend in the Deschutes National Forest would remove a third of a mile of levy and restore 70 acres of wetlands.

This project would engage up to 800 middle and high school students in restoration activities on six projects on the Deschutes River and Whychus Creek.  The students will receive classroom introductions to river and watershed processes, streamside tours of different types of stream habitat conditions and then be engaged in developing restoration plans and implementing those plans on the six priority restoration sites.

Project Name: Middle Fork Hood River Instream Flow Assessment
Project Summary: This project would look at different flow management alternatives to benefit ESA listed bull trout, Chinook and coho salmon and steelhead for the various points of diversion and water storage under the control of the Middle Fork Irrigation District (MFID) in the Hood River basin.  The MFID services 43% of the irrigation acres in the basin and operates three hydroelectric powerhouses integrated into the irrigation system.

Project Name: MFID Clear Branch Dam Fish Passage Feasibility Assessment
Project Summary: This project will evaluate the feasibility of using an upstream laddered and downstream screened bypass at Clear Branch Dam on the Middle Fork Hood River to enable fish passage.  This is the reach of stream in the Hood River basin that supports the last two remaining populations of bull trout, an ESA listed species.

Project Name: McGee Creek In-channel and Floodplain Restoration
Project Summary: This project would place large wood on 1.8 miles of McGee Creek, a tributary of the West Fork Hood River in order to create more diversified habitat and recruit spawning gravels.  This area is the primary producer of spring Chinook in the Hood River Basin, an ESA listed species.

Project Name: Horse Heaven Creek Watershed Restoration Project
Project Summary: This proposal is for juniper management, off-stream water development, seeding and weed treatments on 12,000 acres in the Horse Heaven Creek watershed, about 20 miles southeast of Prineville.  This would build on landowners efforts to reduce the negative impacts of juniper expanding its historic range and, in many instances, dominating sites that were once sage/bunchgrass plant communities.

This project would provide support to treat noxious invasive weeds (primarily Himalayan blackberries) on three publicly owned recreation sites in The Dalles.  Two of the three parcels are part of the River Trail along the Columbia River and the third site, along Mill Creek, is proposed to have access to the River Trail.  The areas are all highly visible and receive public use.

Project Name: Urban Homesteading for Healthy Communities and Watersheds
Project Summary: This project would work with approximately 20 adults in The Dalles, over a two year period through a series of nine workshops about garden layout, composting, food growing and preservation, watershed health, integrated pest management, soil quality and conservation.

This project would promote awareness among Deschutes, Crook and Jefferson County residents on the impact invasive species have on riparian areas and lakes in the tri-county area.  Through public service announcements, newspaper articles, radio and television interviews and special events this effort will attempt to reach newcomers and land managers.  There are numerous invasive species in the area that affect wetlands and riparian areas and with education, resources and tools it is hoped that the species will be identified and treated in an effective manner.

Project Name: Teaching Core Biology to Save Salmon
Project Summary: This project will engage 150 to 200 high school students from five high schools in the Klamath Basin to learn about salmon life cycles and water quality issues.  The five high school biology teachers will teach a two week salmon/cell biology/inquiry unit in October 2010 and a three week water quality inquiry/cell biology/ecology unit in May of 2011.

This project would recruit landowners to explore opportunities to engage local conservation groups and agencies in restoration projects on their lands in the Upper Klamath Basin.  The majority of resource impacts to water quality and water quantity occur on private lands.  Through a series of workshops, field trips and individual consultations, resource issues will be discussed and individual projects will be targeted for design and partnership recruitment.

Klamath Outdoor Science School holds field camps for students throughout Oregon in field and classroom ecology/land management curriculums at their field station along the Wood River in the Upper Klamath Basin.  The multiple-day camp will host approximately 1100 students and 100 adults during this grant period.  This school has been operating for approximately three years.

Project Name: McEwen Diversion Replacement & Fish Passage Restoration
Project Summary: An existing push-up dam on the Powder River located near Sumpter is a seasonal fish-passage.  The barrier will require fish passage improvement for long-term bull trout recovery.  The proposed solution is to install a permanent sill-and-sheetpile diversion, include ODFW-approved fish passage and install several weirs downstream of the structure to gradually step up the river gradient to the diversion height.    Watershed benefits include improved water quality, fish passage and streambank conditions.  An engineering firm in La Grande provided preliminary designs.  OWEB funds are requested for engineering (21%), project management  (14%), in-house personnel (2%), contracted services (58%) and administration (4%) . Cost-share partners include the ditch landowners, ODFW and Baker Valley SWCD.

Project Name: North Powder River Push Up Dam Removal
Project Summary: Located near the town of North Powder, one of the last push-up dams on the North Powder River is proposed for replacement. Project components include a lay-flat stanchion structure with fish passage provided by an Alaska steeppass fishway.  In addition, a headgate, water-control structure, flashboards and a measuring device will be installed.  Watershed benefits include improved water quality, decreased sediment, improved streambank conditions and improved fish passage and habitat.  OWEB funds are requested for engineering (13%), project management (4%), contracted services (75%), and administration (8%).  The landowner and Baker Valley SWCD are cost-share partners.

Located 14 miles north of Burns, this project addresses headcutting and excessive erosion in 2 areas.  NRCS provided funding for the completed engineered drawings.  Proposed actions include installing juniper riprap, rootwads, brush-and-rock weirs and whole trees with root wads.  A total of 87 trees will be installed with several trees in a single bundle.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (6%), in-house personnel (5%), contracted services (72%), travel (4%), administration (5%) and monitoring (3%).  The landowner and NRCS are cost-share partners.

Project Name: Not Dry Gulch Offstream Watering Project
Project Summary: Located in Baker County 2.5 miles east of Richland, Dry Gulch is an extensive perennial stream nearly 5.5 miles long that runs throughout the year. Eagle Valley SWCD is proposing to keep livestock off the gulch, listed by DEQ for habitat modification, sediment and temperature.  Project components include develop 1 spring; install 4, 220 feet of pipe for watering troughs and 270 feet of in the corral area; install 7 troughs and 1,000 feet of 4-strand barbed-wire fencing. OWEB funds are requested for project management (5%), contracted services (29%), supplies/materials  (60%) and administration (6%).  Cost-share partners include the landowners and Eagle Valley SWCD.

Owyhee Watershed Council (WSC) in partnership with the South Board Irrigation District proposes to address irrigation-induced erosion by installing 1,400 feet of 27 pipe for a lateral located along the slope of highly erodible land with 2% to 12% slopes. Other project components include installation of an 8-foot by 200-foot sediment and headwall at the head of the 27 pipe.  Watershed benefits include decrease sediment transport, phosphorus, nutrient, bacteria and turbidity and more efficient water usage. OWEB funds are requested for project management  (2%), supplies/materials (94%) and administration (4%).  Cost-share partners are the landowner and South Board Irrigation District.

Design is sought for the final phase of an existing wetland located near Ontario.  It will complete the project by constructing a drain meander that would create a large marsh area, approximately 20 acres, for additional cleaning of a drain not included in the original design.  The project requires an engineer with constructed wetland experience to design the meander.  OWEB funds are sought for project management (9)%, engineering  (66%), technical assistance (9%), travel (5%), production (1%) and administration (9%).

Ducks Unlimited proposes to address the loss of seasonal-emergent wetlands in the North Powder drainage near North Powder.  Restoration objectives include restoring 12.3 acres of palustrine-emergent wetland; 40 acres of riparian-lowland, forest-shrub community; restore 60 acres of uplands and 35 acres of wet meadow.  Project components include constructing 3,165 feet of berm; installing 11,500 feet of exclusion fencing; planting hawthorn, chokecherry, birch, alder, willow and woods rose; develop a management plan for grazing. Watershed benefits include improved fisheries, avian and upland habitat and wetlands.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (7%), in-house personnel (7%), contracted services (65%), materials (11%) and administration (9%). Cost-share partners include ODFW Gamebird stamp, NRCS- WHIP, Ducks Unlimited and the landowner.

A low-gradient reach of Owsley Creek, near La Grande, is a barrier to fish passage due to a four-foot overfall that has been created.  Previously, upstream banks, lacking riparian vegetation due to excessive grazing, created a sediment load that drops out in the flat area and created the 4-foot overall.  Proposed components include restoring 650 feet of stream channel to pass a 10-year event; concentrate 1 cfs for fish passage; install 1,200 feet of 4-strand, smooth-wire fence 25 feet from the top of the bank; reseed the disturbed area and install sediment trap 80-feet long at the upper end of the project.

Project Name: Medicine Creek Bank and Headcut Stabilization
Project Summary: Medicine Creek has a substantial headcut  that is creating excessive erosion and significant bank instability.  This project will stabilize the streambed by shaping and grading 1,800 lineal feet of streambank to a 3:1 slope.  Disturbed areas up to 100 feet from the channel will be seeded with various grass species and legumes. A series of 4 structures designed and constructed to meet ODFW fish-passage criteria will be installed along the 1,800 channel section for grade control.  Instream work needs to be completed before enrolling the area into CREP. Watershed benefits include improve water quality, riparian habitat and streambank stability.

Project Name: Foothill Return Flow Elimination & Drain Restoration
Project Summary: Located near Vale, this project addresses 180 acres of pasture and cropland that are flood-irrigated.  There is a 3,200-feet long, 15-feet deep and 20-feet wide open earthen drain ditch that captures all the irrigation runoff as well as runoff from storm events and snowmelt, which flow directly into the Malheur River.  Livestock have access to this ditch, year-round in some fields, and use it as a water source during the irrigation season. Project components include installing 3,200 feet of 10-inch perforated pipe at the bottom of the drainage ditch; install 2,520 feet of 10-inch mainline from pivot site to the irrigation source and install a pivot.   OWEB funds are requested for project management (3%), contracted services (26%), pipe and electrical (67%) and administration (4%).  The landowner is the cost-share partner.

The Malheur Watershed Council is working with two landowners in the Drewsey area of Harney County to address watershed concerns on approximately 300 acres. Two existing earthen ditches totaling almost 2 miles have a common point of diversion from Cottonwood Creek. Piping these ditches would conserve water and improve the quality of the excess water that flows back to Cottonwood Creek.  Several hundred head of cattle have access to the ditch during irrigation season contributing to poor water quality.  Project components include installing 8,950 feet of 18 100# pipe; 820 feet of 24 100# pipe and flow meters at the beginning of each pipe segment.  Measuring the water would likely contribute to water conservation.  OWEB funds are requested for engineering (1%), project management  (4%), pipe and flow meters (92%) and administration (3%).

Wheaton Creek is located in a remote part of northwestern Malheur County.  They will install 1,800 feet of 1.25 PVC to the original system that flows to a 12,000-gallon tank; 2,300 feet of 1.25 pipe to a new trough; 2 standpipes at existing troughs equipped with a wildlife escape ramp and a 12-panel solar system on 2 stands to power a centrifugal surface pump.  Livestock will be pulled out of the creek bottoms and distributed more evenly in the upland area to achieve even livestock forage utilization.  Watershed benefits include improved riparian vegetation, upland vegetation and water quality.   OWEB funds are requested for project management (16%), travel (3%), supplies  (74%) and administration (7%).  Cost share partners are the landowners.

The Bunker Water Quality project is located in Malheur County approximately 8 miles southwest of Nyssa.  A waterway draining more than 1,000 acres of mainly flood-irrigated farmland bisects the property, adversely affecting water quality. The project proposes that a series of 3 _-acre sediment/nutrient ponds be constructed along the uppermost portion of the waterway to capture runoff prior to entering the wildlife area and a proposed 4th pond.   Implementation addresses sedimentation, nutrient transport and bank erosion and will also improve habitat for migratory birds.  OWEB funds are requested for permitting (8%), project management (3%), excavation (55%), culverts (25%), administration (8%) and administration (%).   The landowner will provide cash and inkind.  EQIP (pending) will provide cash.

Project Name: Closed Lakes Basin Historic Wetland Mapping and Restoration Tool
Project Summary: The Wetland Conservancy (TWC) is seeking technical assistance to develop a wetland conservation, restoration opportunity and prioritization strategy in the Closed Lakes Basin.  Closed basin wetlands provide critical habitat for a large diversity of avian, plant and amphibian species. TWC will transcribe General Land Office (GLO) original survey notes into a database and map historical vegetation at a 1:24,000-scale, using 7.5 USGS maps as a base. OWEB funds would be used for in-house personnel (62%), contracted services (29%) and administration (9%).   Partners include the EPA with grants to YWC, EPA grant to OSU and ODFW.

Project Name: Graham Blvd Water Quality Improvement Project (Lateral 216)
Project Summary: Malheur SWCD and the Vale Oregon Irrigation District (VOID) are proposing to replace an earthen lateral measuring 10,550 feet with a pressurized pipe.  The project is located 2.5 miles west of Vale.  The current lateral is an earthen ditch approximately 4 to 5 feet-wide that flows approximately 5-7 cfs.  Lateral 216 serves 415 irrigated acres comprising alfalfa, corns, grains and permanent pasture.Malheur SWCD is proposing to install and bed 3,560 feet of 8-inch, 4,120 feet of 15-inch; 2,120 feet of 18-inch and 750 feet of 10-inch pipe.  In addition there will be 14 turnouts and the project involves 20 farmers, OWEB funds are requested for project management (1%), contracted services engineering (2%), materials- pipe and fittings (90%), administration (6%) and monitoring (1%).  VOID will install and bed the pipe at a cash value of $98,432 or $9.33/foot installed.

Wheaton Creek is located in a remote part of northwestern Malheur County.  Two landowners rotate approximately 550 head of cattle through fenced pastures on more than 10,000 acres south of Ironside.  In 1995, an extensive system was installed to pump water from Wheaton Creek through 4 miles of pipeline into 4 water toughs in 3 separate pastures.The applicant is proposing to utilize an already developed a 10- to 12- gallon per minute (gpm) fenced spring and gravity-flow water to the proposed pump site on Wheaton Creek into a storage tank.  They will install 1,800 feet of 1.25-inch PVC to the original system that flows into a 12,000-gallon tank; install 2,300 feet 1.25-inch pipe to a new trough; 2 standpipes at existing troughs equipped with a wildlife escape ramp and install a 12-panel solar system on 2 stands to power a centrifugal surface pump.  Livestock will be pulled out of the creek bottoms and distributed more evenly in the upland areas to achieve even livestock forage utilization.  Watershed benefits include improved riparian vegetation, upland vegetation and water quality.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (14%), travel (3%), contracted services -solar pump installation (5%) supplies/materials  (68%) and administration (7%) and monitoring (3%).  Cost-share partners are the landowners who will install the pipe, fittings  troughs and standpipe.

The Malheur Watershed Council is working with three landowners in the Drewsey area of Harney County to address watershed concerns on approximately 300 acres.  The project is located in the Otis Valley irrigation district seven miles northeast of Drewsey.  One landowners field is adjacent to the diversion and requires a very short ditch (100 feet).  The other two landowners share a common ditch for the first 5,540 feet, then the ditch splits to serve each landowner.  The first ditch is 1,420 feet and the second is 2,870 feet.  Combined length of the three ditches is 9,740 feet.  Project components include installing 100 feet of 21-inch 100-pound pipe; 8,220 feet of 18-inch,100-pound pipe; 1,420 feet of 10-inch 100# PVC, 2 butterfly valves; 2 flow meters and a concrete structure and inlet.   Measuring the water would likely contribute to water conservation.  The upper reaches of Cottonwood Creek are redband trout habitat.   Project implementation addresses adverse water quality due to sediment transport, erosion, banks stabiliy and E coli transport as well as ditch loss due to seepage and evaporation. OWEB funds are requested for engineering (1%), project management (3%), pipe and flow meters (89%) and administration (6%) monitoring (1%).  The two landowners with the longest length of ditch are providing in-kind and cash cost-share for project implementation engineering.

Project Name: A Rigorous Assessment of Restoration Projects with Greater Grande Ronde Watershed
Project Summary: The Grande Ronde watershed has been the focus of a many restoration projects.  However, despite substantial funding and effort, a clear assessment is lacking on the effectiveness of those investments.  Oregon State University (OSU) Department of Fisheries and Wildlife proposes a statistically and ecologically rigorous watershed assessment based on known and tested EMAP  (environmental monitoring and assessment program) designs, sampling methods and indicators.  The goal is to determine the effectiveness of rehabilitation and fish-passage projects and also the degree which regional location and project age affect the overall effectiveness of the various projects.  Twenty sites will randomly selected within the Grande Ronde Watershed from instream, riparian and fish passage projects found in OWEBs, ODFWs and NMFSs databases. Paired sites will be evaluated over a two-year period, sampling fish assemblages, salmonids and physical habitat.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (10%), in-house personnel (9%), contracted services (74%), travel (6%) and supplies (1%). Project partners include EPA, National Marine Fisheries Services (NMFS), Pacific States Marine Fisheries Council, USFWS, Amnis Opes Institute and Western Land Trust.

The Wetland Conservancy (TWC) is seeking technical assistance to develop a wetland conservation, restoration opportunity and prioritization strategy in the Harney Basin.  Wetlands in this area are under stress from invasive species, an aging water management infrastructure and competing needs for limited-water supply.  A changing climate may further reduce local water supply.  Closed-basin wetlands provide critical habitat for a large diversity of avian, plant and amphibian species.  As a critical component of a coordinated wetland conservation and prioritization plan for the basin, TWC is requesting technical assistance to map the historical location, extent and condition of wetland and stream channels in 57 townships in the Silvies River, Blitzen River and Silver Creek drainages.  The data source will be the historic public land surveys of the General Land Office (GLO) conducted primarily between 1873 and 1889.  Land survey data will be transcribed into an Access database and historic stream channels and vegetation will be mapped a 1:24,000-scale, using 7.5-minute USGS maps as a base. OWEB funds are sought for the wetland ecologist services (61%), the Oregon Corrections for quad maps (29%), supplies and administration (10%).  Cost share partners are the EPA through Wetlands Program Grants (cash).  Other listed partners with unspecified contributions include OSU, U.S. Fish &Wildlife Service (USFWS) and The Nature Conservancy (TNC).

Project Name: Not Dry Gulch Offstream Watering Project
Project Summary: Located in Baker County 2.5 miles east of Richland, Dry Gulch is an extensive perennial stream nearly 5.5 miles long that flows year-round.  This area receives 15 inches of rain annually.  Dry Gulch drains 2,466 acres and flows through the pastures of his projects two landowners.  Project components include developing 1 spring; installing 4,220 feet of 2-inch and 4-inch pipe for watering troughs; installing 1 hardened crossing in the corral area; installing 7 troughs and 1,300 feet of 4-strand barbed-wire fencing on the east side of Dry Gulch.  In addition, disturbed areas will be seeded. Troughs will be located outside of the riparian area and supply water to each individual pasture. Watershed benefits include improved water quality, plant diversity, upland vegetation and wildlife habitat and stabilize at-risk streambanks.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (6%), contracted services (29%), supplies/materials(60%) and administration (6%). Cost-share partners include the landowners and Eagle Valley SWCD.

An existing push-up dam on the Powder River located near Sumpter is a major seasonal fish-passage barrier.  The upper Powder is identified as important bull trout habitat.  The proposed solution is to install a permanent concrete sill-and-sheetpile diversion with ODFW-approved fish passage.  A two-step pool system will be installed downstream of the structure to gradually step up the river gradient to the diversion height with engineered and graded rip-rap. Watershed benefits include improved water quality, fish passage and streambank conditions. OWEB funds are requested for engineering (16%), project management  (10%), in-house personnel (1%), contracted services (68%) and administration (5%). Cost-share partners include the ditch landowners, ODFW, Baker Valley SWCD and Baker County Weed Control.

Malheur SWCD and the landowners on Fletcher Gulch are proposing to replace an earthen lateral measuring 15,000 feet located 5 miles northwest of Adrian.  The current lateral is an earthen ditch approximately 4- to 5-feet wide and is widening from higher flows.   Fletcher Gulch serves 1,000 acres agricultural producers raising mostly corn but also grains, beans potatoes and sugar beets on fairly steep slopes, which results in very significant erosion.  Tailwater flows into the Old Owyhee drain and then into the Malheur River. alheur SWCD proposes to pipe 15,000 feet pipe (various sizes) of lateral and provide a gravity-flow system. Other project components include 178 various valves, flanges and reducers; 6,320 feet of mainline for on-farm projects; 15 flow meters; 2 rotating screens and other miscellaneous materials. 257 acres would be immediately converted to sprinkler with two pivots and one linear system installed to eliminate furrow irrigation.  Pivots use at least 25% less water annually saving 64 acre-feet. Also, 650 feet of pipe to existing pivots and flow meters will be installed.   OWEB funds are requested for project management/engineering (2%), contracted services  installation (28%), materials- pipe and fittings (68%) and administration (2%).  Partners include the landowners, Malheur SWCD, NRCS and the Owyhee Irrigation District.

Clover Creek Ranch is located north of Harper and Westfall in the Bully Creek drainage.  The applicant is proposing to treat 300 acres of juniper which occupies much of the historic Malheur High Plateau Sagebrush-Steppe. Sage grouse leks were identified in this watershed.  Fledging sage grouse survive on a diet of grass and forb seeds. Proposed project components include juniper cutting on 300 acres and seeding on 100 acres.  Juniper will be removed using a chainsaw, piled and/or lopped and scattered.  Native grasses and forbs should naturally reseed.  NRCS will assist with a grazing plan and on the certified native plant and vegetation mix for areas where reseeding is slow.  The landowner will implement a prescribed burn in the next 6-7 years to control juniper regeneration.  A grazing plan, including temporary rest and deferment, will be implemented.  Watershed benefits include improved upland vegetation, decreased soil erosion and stream sedimentation; improved water quality, infiltration and wildlife habitat. OWEB funds are requested for project management/layout (10%), in-house personnel (7%), juniper removal, lop and scatter (60%), seed (18%), mileage (1%) and administration (9%). The landowner will provide labor for juniper removal and reseeding; ODFW- technical assistance on seeding of areas near the sage grouse leks; SWCD - outreach publications and NRCS  assistance on grazing plan.

Westfall Ranches is located north of Harper and Westfall in the Bully Creek drainage.  The applicant is proposing to treat 625 acres of juniper which occupies much of the historic Malheur High Plateau Sagebrush-Steppe.    Project components include juniper cutting on 625 acres and seeding on 155 acres.  Juniper will be removed using a chainsaw, piled and/or lopped and scattered.  Native grasses and forbs should naturally reseed.  NRCS will assist with a grazing plan and on the certified native plant and vegetation mix for areas where reseeding is slow.  A prescribed burn will follow in 6-7 years to control juniper regeneration.  A grazing plan, including temporary rest and deferment, will be implemented.  Livestock grazing after treatment will include temporary exclusion (rest) or deferment and the identification of alternative feed sources.  Watershed benefits include will improve upland vegetation, decreased soil erosion and stream sedimentation; improved water quality, infiltration and wildlife habitat.  Riparian vegetation along the Indian Creek will improve.  ODFW supports removing juniper for enhancing wildlife habitat, especially the western sage grouse.  OWEB funds are requested for project management/layout (7%), juniper removal, lop and scatter (67%), seed (16%), mileage (1%) and administration (9%). The landowner will provide labor for juniper removal and reseeding; ODFW- technical assistance on seeding of areas near the sage grouse leks; SWCD - outreach publications and NRCS  assistance on grazing plan.

Cottonwood Creek runs through the Belknap Ranch in the northwestern corner of Malheur County.   Juniper encroachment has led to a decrease in watershed health with the destruction of understory vegetation leading to overland flow, soil erosion, increased stream sedimentation and decreased stream flows. Project components include juniper cutting using a chainsaw on 1,000 acres and seeding on 200 acres.  Juniper expressing old-growth characteristics will not be cut.  Native grasses and forbs should naturally reseed.  NRCS will assist with a grazing plan and selecting the certified native plant and vegetation mix for areas where reseeding is slow.

Owyhee Watershed Council (WSC) in partnership with the South Board Irrigation District proposes to address irrigation-induced erosion by replacing a 1,400- foot earthen lateral with a pipe. Project components include installing 1,400 feet of 27 pipe; an 8-foot by 200-foot sediment pond between Napton Road culvert and the pipeline and installing a headwall between sediment pond and head of the 27 pipe.  The sediment pond will catch sediment and slow water before is enters the pipe. Watershed benefits include decrease sediment transport, phosphorus, nutrient, bacteria and turbidity and more efficient water usage.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (2%), engineering (3%), supplies/materials- pipe and headwall (85%) and administration (9%).  The South Board Irrigation District will install the pipe and sediment pond.

Located northwest of Adrian, Owyhee WSC is proposing to convert 104 acres from furrow-flood irrigation to sprinkler-pivot.   Project components include pipe 3,727 feet of  earthen drain ditch to provide a pressurized gravity flow; install 1,890 feet of 10-inch mainline to service pivot; 300 feet of 6-inch mainline from first to second pivot; 1,357-foot pivot to irrigate 69 acres;  946-foot pivot to irrigate 35 acres and flow meters to each pivot.  Pivots will use 25% less water than the current furrow irrigation.  Two sediment ponds will be installed one at 150 x 50 12 and other 300 x 100 x 16 - installed at the mouth of each drain flowing through the farm before reaching the Old Owyhee Canal.  Watershed benefits include improve quality by reducing sediment and nutrient transport; improving irrigation efficiency by installing pivots and improving water quantity; decreased sediment, phosphorus, nutrients inputs and improved water efficiency. OWEB funds are requested for project management (4%), contracted services (37%), materials- pipe, bubblers, pumps (49%) and administration (9%).  The lessee is the cost-share partner.

The project is located 19 miles north of Burns in forested uplands close to a drainage and spring that is tributary to the Silvies River.  The project addresses overstocked ponderosa pine and encroaching juniper on significant stands of curl-leaf mountain-mahogany which provides food and cover for deer and elk. A sage grouse lek, historic strutting grounds, is located three miles west in the Hay Creek Complex, which is comprise of two separate leks.  A reduction in stand density will protect and improve habitat for existing sage-grouse populations.  Reducing the stand density will also increase the size of existing pine for future snag recruitments, improve the health and vigor of the current stand and reduce the risk from mountain pine beetle and the pine engraver beetle. Project components include remove all juniper except those that have old-growth characteristics or appear to be important wildlife trees; space ponderosa under 9 inches dbh (diameter at breast height) to an 18-foot spacing.; pile slash with an excavator; protect all mountain-mahogany and seed 12 acres with intermediate wheatgrass, Ladak alfalfa and slender wheatgrass.

Located 14 miles north of Burns, Harney SWCD proposes to address headcuts in 2 areas.  The box canyon, focuses on 350 feet of stream channel. Design for this reach concentrates on providing grade control to increase the elevation and also woody debris to encourage sediment deposition and a rebuilding of the channel bed.  Site 2 focuses on 650 feet of straightened channel upstream and 100 feet down stream of the confluence.  The west channel has experienced considerable erosion and head cutting, such that the banks are approximately 12 feet high in some areas.     Project components include:  1. place 18 inch-minus rock in the stream channel to provide articifial riffles.  2.  Place brush - juniper trees, limbs and rootwads - anchored in place with large boulder or whole tree to provde bank stabilziaiton and sediment trapping.  NRCS provided EQIP funding for the completed engineered drawings.  Proposed actions include installing juniper riprap, rootwads, brush-and-rock weirs and whole trees with root wads.  OWEB funds are requested for in-house personnel (5%), contracted services (77%), travel (3%), administration (8%) and monitoring (6%).  Cost-share partners include NRCS, Harney SWCD and the landowners.

Project Name: Stinkingwater Habitat Enhancement and Grazing Management Phase II
Project Summary: Located in the upper Malheur River basin east of Burns in the Drewsey Valley, this project proposes to treat two channels of Stinkingwater Creek subject to severe channel downcutting, bank instability, loss of floodplain connectivity and decreased riparian vegetation.  Project components include installing 3 hardening crossings and a siphon. The streambank at the siphon with be reshaped from a vertical cut to a 2:1 slope.  The siphon will be used to provide additional water for livestock and wildlife.  In addition, 3 Rosgen-style J-hooks will be installed instream to divert flow away from the streambank and  reduce sediment input.  Watershed benefits include improved water quality, fisheries habitat, streambank stability and riparian habitat for sage grouse. OWEB funds are requested for engineering (16%), installation (53%), materials (16%), monitoring (6%) and administration (9%).  The landowner will provide in-kind contribution.  Harney SWCD will provide some technical assistance and monitoring.

The project is located near Summerville and proposes provide off-stream livestock water in the Willow Creek drainage. The first pond is located near Dry Creek, a seasonal stream with no summer flow.   The second pond is located near Spring Creek which has perennial and seasonal springs providing a limited water source. Ponds will eliminate access to the creek of livestock which will improve water quality and riparian vegetation.  The ponds will be fences and piped to troughs.  After the construction of the first pond, the landowner will enroll that portion of the stream into CREP.   OWEB funds are requested for project management (8%), contracted services (66%), materials pipe and troughs (16%), administration (9%) and administration (1%).

The project is located 1.5 west of Union on Catherine Creek.  Currently, 430 feet of streambank is eroding at an increasing rate, releasing sediment into the system and inhibiting riparian vegetation establishment.  Proposed project components sloping the banks to a 2:1 ratio; place rock 12-inch to 28-inch rock at the toe of the streambank; install 860 feet (2 rows at 430 feet) of logs at the base of the streamside slopes above the toe rock;  install 32 rootwad deflectors with ballast rock 21 inch to 42 inches in diameter; install 1,000 yards of coconut-mesh groundcover; and plant 700 cottonwood and willow posts and 600 willow whips.  Watershed benefits include decreased sediment input, improved bank stabilization and water quality, riparian vegetation and fisheries habitat.OWEB funds are requested for project management (4%), contracted services  earthwork, rock placement and mobilization (40%), materials (48%) and administration (7%).  Cost-share partners include landowners on both sides of Catherine Creek.

Wallowa County has an extensive weed program in the canyon areas and on federal lands, but other areas have weed infestations that are increasing in size.  The Wallowa County Weed Department is proposing to treat noxious weeds on the A list and T list that are over _ acre in size. OWEB funds are requested to pay for 50% of the initial spraying and the seeding costs.  Watershed benefits include improved native vegetation, upland and riparian habitat and infiltration as native plants provide more complex root structure. Project components include contract spraying (47%), herbicide and seed (47%) and administration (6%).  Cost-share partners include the participating landowners, Wallowa County Weed Department and Wallowa SWCD.

Located in Morrow County, south of Heppner, this project proposes to reconstruct 2.5 miles of the Black Mountain Lane by installing pit-run rock, gravel and proper drainage. Project components include installing 6 culverts, 7 rolling dips and grading and re-shaping the road. This road is a public access crossing private land; not County-deeded and thus not maintained by the County Road Department. Black Mountain Lane is an earthen road with minimal rock and is parallel to an unnamed tributary of Willow Creek, a fish-bearing stream. OWEB funds are requested for pre-implementation (1%), project management (1%), contracted services (46%), travel (.1%), supplies and materials (51%), fiscal administration (1%). Partners provide 26% match funding.

This project is located on the Lower John Day River in the Gilliam County. The project objectives serve to restore habitat on the lower three miles of Hay Creek and on the mainstem of the John Day River between river miles 35 and 41. Project components include treating 41 acres on 2.8 miles of Hay Creek for invasive weeds, then planting and maintaining native riparian vegetation, fencing the sections of Hay Creek that are open to livestock grazing, and treating 161 acres of noxious weed along the mainstem John Day River. The watershed benefits include increased riparian vegetative health which will in turn aid in holding back sediment, aggrading the incised channels, lowering stream temperatures, stabilizing banks and increasing the levels of year-round flows. Funding is requested from OWEB to pay for project management (2%), contracted services (54%), supplies and materials (34%), fiscal administration (9%), post-implementation status reporting (1%). Match from partners comes to 29% of total project cost.

Project Name: Joliff Barrier and Stream Restoration Project
Project Summary: Eliminating an abandoned irrigation dam on river mile 10 of East Birch Creek would open up an additional 21 miles of fish passage on East Birch Creek, an important summer steelhead spawning and rearing tributary of the Umatilla River. The project would remove the dam, recreate the natural gradient of the stream channel, reshape the banks and meander geometry, install four cross-vane and six J-hook structures, restrict livestock access to the stream channel, and revegetate the banks and floodplains impacted by the construction. OWEB funds are requested for pre-implementation (1%), in-house personnel (2%), contracted services (84%), supplies & materials (2%), capital equipment (2%) and fiscal administration (9%). Minimal amounts are also requested for post-implementation status reporting and travel (<.1%). The Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife, as partner on this project, has secured 35% of the total project cost.

Project Name: Clean Water Neighborhood B4 Irrigation Line Conversion
Project Summary: This project is located in the Lower Umatilla Basin Groundwater Management Area (LUBGMA), eight miles northeast of Hermiston. The project would convert 2,860 feet of open irrigation ditch to pipe, reconnecting the B line with the B4 lines. By piping this section, the watershed benefits realized include reducing sediment and potential nutrient runoff, improving ground water quality and increasing conveyance efficiency. OWEB funds would be spent on project management (2%), supplies and materials (89%), and fiscal administration (9%). Hermiston Irrigation District is the partner on this project and has committed to covering 62% of the total cost.

Project Name: Clean Water Neighborhood (CWN) Feed Canal Project
Project Summary: Located in the city of Echo in Umatilla County, this project would line 900 feet of a leaky section of the Feed Canal, an irrigation system established in 1907 to divert water from the Umatilla River near the City of Echo to the Cold Springs Reservoir. This section of the canal is seeping onto Echos school athletic field. This project lies within the boundaries of the Lower Umatilla Basin Groundwater Management Area (LUBGMA) and also reflects directives of the Umatilla Subbasin 2050 Water Management Plan. OWEB funds are requested for program management (4%), travel (<1%), supplies and materials (85%), non-cap education/outreach (1%), and fiscal administration (9%). Partners provide 53% match funding.

Project Name: Walla Walla Basin Aquifer Replenishment and Stream Restoration Program Phase I
Project Summary: The Walla Walla River subbasin is the focus for this program which flows into this bi-state valley and becomes a distributary river system of historic river branches, spring-creeks and in the last century, irrigation systems. This proposal is a continuation of aquifer recharge projects starting with an OWEB funded technical assistance grant in 2002. It is designed to significantly increase the volume of water being restored to the aquifer-spring system.  Monitoring and analysis will be expanded to specifically address the fundamental questions regarding recharge influence on restoring the aquifer, surface flow and improving water quality.  The application states that watershed benefits realized by this project include improved late-season flow, reduced stream temperature and improved fish habitat. OWEB funds are requested for pre-implementation (8%), project management (11%), in-house personnel (7%), contracted services (23%), travel (.5%), supplies and materials (26%), effectiveness monitoring (16%), educational/outreach (1%), fiscal administration (7%) and post-implementation status reporting (.5%). Partners include BPA, Washington Department of Ecology, Bureau of Reclamation and Oregon Department of Transportation and would provide 56% match funding.

The project centers in headwaters of Bologna Creek, a tributary of the mainstem John Day River. Objectives of the project include improving hydrologic function of the uplands where the juniper is crowding out native grasses and shrub component and developing upland water sources for wildlife and livestock. Watershed benefits include improving hydrologic function, water quantity and quality, increasing recruitment of native grasses and forbs and improving upland conditions. The proposed components of the project include hand-falling 60 acres of dense stands of juniper, mechanical piling of large juniper to create brush fence exclusion along East Bologna Creek, reseeding native grasses on any disturbed ground in treatment areas, and developing three off-channel water developments. The project aligns with NWPCC John Day Subbasin plan (2005) restoration strategies and is located in an area listed as very high priority for flow restoration. OWEB funds are requested for program management (4%), contracted services (75%), supplies and materials (10%), fiscal administration (9%), and post-implementation status reporting (2%). Partners include the landowner, NRCS, OSU and ODF.

This project is located on lands that drain into Rudio Creek, a tributary of the North Fork John Day River in Grant County. The components of the project include drilling a well and installing a solar pump system; retrofitting an under-producing solar system on an existing second well, developing and piping 2 springs, and installing 2 guzzlers to provide water on dry ridge lines. OWEB funds were requested for project management (6%), contracted services (13%), travel (<1%), supplies and materials (71%), and fiscal administration (9%). Match of 35% would be provided from the landowner and potentially from a USDA Rural Development Fund grant.

Project Name: Sherman County Area Watersheds Upland Erosion Control
Project Summary: This project encompasses land located in Sherman County in north central Oregon. Partners include the Sherman County Area Watershed Council, Sherman Soil & Water Conservation District, six landowners and the Natural Resource Conservation Service. The application proposes to construct 20,740 feet of cropland terraces, 11 cropland water and sediment control basins (WASCBs), 4 rangeland WASCBs and one acre of grassed waterways. OWEB funds were requested for 1% project management, 4% in-house personnel, 82% contracted services, 1% travel and supplies/materials, 9% fiscal administration and 3% post-implementation status reporting.

Project Name: Hermiston Irrigation District B4 Ditch Conversion Project
Project Summary: The project site lies 8 miles northeast of Hermiston, in the Cold Springs drainage area and within the Lower Umatilla Basin Groundwater Management Area. The Umatilla Soil & Water Conservation District partnered with the Hermiston Irrigation District in this proposal to pipe 4,000 feet of the open B4 line irrigation ditch, connecting it back to the main B-line. OWEB funds were requested for 3% in-house personnel, 87% supplies/materials, 9% fiscal administration, and 1% travel and post-implementation status reporting.

The Umatilla Soil & Water Conservation District partnered with the Stanfield Irrigation District and the Natural Resource Conservation Service in this proposal to pipe 5,200 feet of the C-line irrigation ditch, install a rotating trash screen and three pumps systems to convert from flood to sprinkler delivery system. The project site is located east of the town of Stanfield in Umatilla County. OWEB dollars were requested for 2% in-house personnel, 1% contracted services, 87% supplies/materials, 9% fiscal administration, and 1% travel and post-implementation status reporting.

Project Name: Rudio Creek Ranch Habitat Restoration Project
Project Summary: The Freshwater Trust, partnering with the landowner and the Bonneville Power Administration, proposes to put 2.4 miles of Rudio Creek back into its historic channel, reconnect the floodplain, increase pool habitat and riparian vegetation on 103 acres. Rudio Creek is an ecologically significant tributary to the North Fork John Day River in Grant County. OWEB funds were requested for 14% pre-implementation, 7% project management, 1% in-house personnel, 49% contracted services, 3% travel, 21% supplies/materials, 4% fiscal administration and 1% post-implementation status reporting.

The project site is located on private land in the Rudio Creek watershed, draining into the North Fork John Day River in Grant County. Submitted by the North Fork John Day Watershed Council and partnering with the landowner and the USDA Rural Development Fund, the project proposes to cut 240 acres of juniper, reseed perennial grass where warranted on treatment sites, develop one upland spring, install one solar pump and two guzzlers to increase water sources in the uplands on the dry, eastside of the ranch. OWEB funds were requested for 2% project management, 35% contracted services, 53% supplies/materials, 9% fiscal administration and 1% travel, education/outreach and post-implementation status reporting.

The project site is located on Rock Creek, a major tributary to the lower John Day River in Gilliam County. Partnering on the project with the Gilliam East John Day Watershed Council are the Gilliam Soil & Water Conservation District and the Oregon Department of Fish & Wildlife. The project proposes to build a concrete step-pool fishway on the west side of an existing diversion dam, opening up passage to quality habitat upstream to all life stages of salmonids. OWEB funds were requested for 50% project management, 41% contracted services, 8% fiscal administration and 1% travel and post-implementation status reporting.

Project Name: Technical Evaluation of Aquatic Conservation Options at Bates Pond
Project Summary: The Native Fish Society requested funds to evaluate implications and efficiencies of three alternative approaches addressing the effects of Bates Pond on Bridge Creek, a tributary of the Middle Fork John Day River in Grant County. OWEB funds were requested for 6% project management, 73% contracted services, 12% travel and 9% fiscal administration.

Project Name: Love Your River Education and Outreach Campaign

Project Summary: The Westwind Stewardship Group (WSG) requests technical assistance to conduct a thorough survey of the Westwind property in the Salmon River estuary to inventory and map the location of invasive species and produce an action plan identifying priority species, areas and key strategies for control and prevention. OWEB funds would be used to obtain survey equipment (GPS) and supplies, and to help hire a contractor to conduct the surveys.

The Columbia SWCD is requesting technical assistance to gather hydrologic and geomorphologic data on 8 miles of the mainstem Clatskanie River. The 8 mile reach of mainstem would be roughly in the middle of the basin. Data would be collected from field studies as well as from existing sources. The data would be analyzed and synthesized, models developed and a strategic plan developed, which would include specific restoration and enhancement project opportunities. In addition, 3 conceptual designs will be developed for the restoration projects most highly ranked. The requested OWEB fund will be used for staff and contractors to collect and analyze the data, with very minor amounts budgeted for supplies and equipment.

In this application, the Siuslaw Watershed Council, in partnership with the International Port of Coos Bay, is seeking OWEB funds to address a priority problem culvert in the Siltcoos Lake watershed. The project would design a railroad bridge crossing for Schrum Creek, remove the failing wooden box culvert and install the new bridge, thereby opening 2 miles of creek to unimpeded fish passage and improved wetland function. The OWEB funds would be used for engineering (36%, including survey & design), culvert removal and bridge installation (41%) and the bridge itself (19%).

Project Name: Tillamook County Landowner Recruitment for Restoration Project
Project Summary: With technical assistance funding from this application, the Tillamook Bay, Lower Nehalem and Nestucca-Neskowin watershed councils would partner to hire a contractor to conduct landowner outreach activities in the three watersheds. The contractor would focus on priority basins in the three council areas, including the N. Fork Nehalem (Lower Nehalem), the Miami River (Tillamook Bay) and throughout the Nestucca-Neskowin watershed. Project funds would be used to pay the outreach contractor, contractor mileage, outreach materials and project management costs for the three councils.

Project Name: Tillamook-Nestucca Estuaries Tidal Wetland Strategic Planning
Project Summary: In the project of which this application is only a part, the Tillamook Estuaries Partnership will contract with Laura Brophy of GreenPoint Consulting to identify and characterize tidal wetlands in Tillamook and Nestucca bays and prioritize them for conservation and restoration through the protocols of the Estuary Assessment component (chapter 10) of the Oregon Watershed Assessment Manual. All of the requested OWEB technical assistance funds would be used to develop the subsequent strategic plan on how to approach restoration and conservation for the tidal wetlands; the end product of the larger effort.

In this Technical Assistance proposal, the Columbia SWCD requests funds to hire a contractor to collect data (topographic surveying, streambank stability analyses, stream sediment monitoring, channel characterization and flow), on 6,000 feet of mid Merrill Creek, a tributary of Tide Creek in the lower Columbia River. After the data is collected, it would be analyzed and restoration project types and sites then identified and prioritized. A plan would then be developed to strategically approach restoration in the basin. The contracting firm would then select three high priority projects for design based on the amount of stream reach restored, benefit to fisheries, and degree of ecological function restored. Designs for restoration work to occur at three sites would be produced to 65% completion and would be expected to restore a minimum of 2,500 linear feet of stream. OWEB funds will be used to pay the consulting contractor for the survey, analysis and design work; project management and administration.

Tillamook Estuaries Partnership (TEP), in partnership with Tillamook County Public Works Department, which owns and manages over 3,000 culverts in the county, is proposing a Technical Assistance project to prioritize culverts throughout the Tillamook Bay watershed for repair or replacement based primarily on their potential to impede fish passage. TEP would hire three, two-person, field crews to conduct site visits at each crossing identified through a GIS effort. The field crews would visit each site and collect a variety of data on the stream channel and crossing structure identified as a fish culvert during the visit. Field data would then be analyzed using existing Barrier Determination and Prioritization models, and then combined with data on fish presence and upstream habitat quality and quantity to rank culverts in terms of priority for replacement. OWEB funds are budgeted for field crew wages (93%) and field crew travel (7%).

The City of Portland, in partnership with the Trust for Public Land, requests $1,500,000 from OWEB for the purchase of a 146-acre property that is part of River View Cemetery in Multnomah County.  The property contains riparian and upland forests.  It also contains 2.2 miles of intermittent and perennial streams that are direct tributaries of the Willamette River.  The application states that the property is a wildlife corridor that connects Forest Park to Tryon Creek State Natural Area.  The application also states that red-legged frog and western gray squirrel, both OWEB priority species, will benefit from protection of the property  The total project cost is $14,000,000.

In this project, the MidCoast Watershed Council is proposing to replace a poorly functioning fishway on mainstem Fiver Rivers in the Alsea River basin with a new structure designed to provide passage to adult and juvenile salmonids at all anticipated flows. As part of the project, the Siuslaw National Forest will fix two culverts further upstream, one a box culvert on the mainstem that is currently a partial barrier to fish passage at low flows and the second a tributary culvert that is a total passage barrier preventing access to over a mile of low gradient habitat. Partners in the project include the Siuslaw National Forest. 91% of the requested OWEB funds are budgeted for removal of the existing fishway and construction of the new structure while project management and administration will each account for 4%.

Project Name: Bear Creek Beaver Protection and Enhancement
Project Summary: In this Technical Assistance project, the Salmon Drift Creek Watershed Council will hire a contractor to work with landowners to identify and develop projects that will improve beaver populations in Bear Creek, a tributary of the Salmon River watershed. One of the project deliverables will be the development of at least three projects designed to increase beaver in the basin, either by reducing beaver/people conflicts or by encouraging beaver through habitat improvements.  Partners include landowners, the Council and Lincoln SWCD. OWEB funds are budgeted for contracted services (landowner recruitment, outreach, project design and development  52%), project management (35%) and administration (9%).

Project Name: Tumalo Feed Canal Water Conservation Project ( Phase 2 )
Project Summary: DRC requests $581,000 to fund a permanent instream water rights transfer from Tumalo Creek and Crescent Lake tributary to the Deschutes River in Deschutes County.  The water rights total 0.44 cubic feet per second (CFS) and 158.01 acre-feet (AF).  The application states that the project will help address low summer flow and temperature in the lower Tumalo Creek and middle Deschutes below Bend.  The acquisition is priced as the costs necessary to complete the piping that will conserve a total of 2.49 cfs. that is otherwise fully funded.  Failure to fund this portion will reduce the conserved water by 0.44 cfs.    Following the submittal OWEB was notified that they had additional funding and had reduced the request to $439,428 and for that would reserve 0.36 cfs.

Project Name: Applegate River Landslide Stabilization and Restoration
Project Summary: The project proposes to stabilize a landslide on the lower Applegate River next to Southside Road near Murphy, Oregon. The landslide is composed of at least three different slumps that have slipped into the Applegate River, blocked the river from its normal path and produced a large fault scarp of bare soil and rock 100 feet high. This proposal includes stabilization techniques to be applied to the slide deposits,instream structures added to maintain stable channel configuration, and restoration and riparian planting programs to help reduce the potential of sediment mobilization, as well as restoration plans to develop greater chinook, coho and steelhead spawning, rearing and side-channel refugia.

This project development proposal will consist of intensive outreach to specific landowners and development of project designs, permits and funding proposals for on-the-ground restoration projects in the Catching Slough basin that drains into the Coos River estuary. One-on-one outreach will be targeted to landowners in pre-determined high priority areas as indicated in the 2008 Catching Slough Sub-basin Watershed Assessment.  The projects planned for implementation as a result of this grant will be largely riparian planting, bio-engineered bank stabilization structures and culvert replacements.

Project Name: Elk Creek Bacteria Source Tracking Design
Project Summary: The Elk Creek Bacteria Source Tracking Design project will enlist the services of a qualified water quality consultant to develop a monitoring program and analysis plan that will determine the source of coliform bacteria in the Elk Creek Watershed, located in the Umpqua River basin.

The project proposes to improve instream habitat along one half mile of Elk Creek, located in the Umpqua River watershed. The project will construct five full-spanning rock weirs to trap gravels, and create pool habitat along with increasing hyporheic flow and reducing summer water temperatures. The project will help create additional pool habitats for juvenile coho and other salmonids

Project Name: Wasson Watershed Ridge-Top to Estuary Restoration
Project Summary: The project proposes to implement a ridge-top to ridge-top to estuary management approach based on the premise that the whole watershed contributes to the restoration of essential fish habitat in the South Slough National Estuarine Research Reserve (SSNERR), a 4,800-acre protected area located in the western arm of the Coos River estuary. The project will create one and a half kilometers of stream channel with large wood placements, recreating stream meanders and improving stream connectivity. Approximately five acres of invasive vegetation in tidal and non-tidal wetlands will be converted to native wetland forb, grass and woody vegetation communities. Approximately five acres of forested swamp will be returned to the valley bottom. Over 20 acres of degraded upland and riparian habitat will be treated to improve long-term watershed processes that support aquatic habitats in the project area.

Grantee: National Center for Conservation Science & Policy
Project Summary: The work proposed will continue technical assistance activities which began under OWEB Technical Assistance Grant 209-2031.The proposed technical assistance activities will support the recruitment of landowners along the former pool area of the former Savage Rapids Dam which was located on the mainstem Rogue River near the city of Grants Pass, into a riparian revegetation program. The project will assist in the design of riparian planting site plans for each landowner. Revegetation will focus on establishing native trees and shrubs to reduce erosion, increase shade, and increase streambank roughness.

The project proposes to treat address high and medium priority sediment risks on three ranch and two forestry road networks and a series of pasture gullies. The project will reduce chronic sedimentation and help the treated areas to withstand large storm events. Roads will receive drainage improvement work including drainage feature and road drainage culvert improvements.  Pasture gullies will be stabilized using rock grade control structures.

Project Name: South Sister Creek and Jeff Creek Riparian Restoration Project
