OWEB funds were requested for in-house personnel, travel and PISR (1%), supplies/materials (90%), and fiscal administration (9%.)

Project Name: Promoting Stewardship of Umatilla's Natural Resources
Project Summary: This application proposed to increase community stewardship and educate residents on how to restore and preserve healthy watersheds in Umatilla Basin by providing the best tools, resources and information to encourage individuals to adopt best management practices through workshops, tours, events and presentations. This would be accomplished by two programs, the Clean Water Neighborhood (CWN) and Preserving Umatillas Resource through Education (PURE). OWEB funds were requested for in-house personnel (82%), travel (1%), production (8%) and fiscal administration (9%.)

Project Name: Birch Creek Instream Flow and Fish Barrier Outreach
Project Summary: This proposal would recruit landowners along Birch Creek, a priority stream in the Umatilla basin, and encourage them to participate in restoration projects to remove fish passage barriers, improve irrigation efficiencies, explore in-stream flow/leases, and enroll in federal/state programs to offset funding of such improvements. OWEB funds were requested for in-house personnel (86%), travel (3%), supplies/materials and production (1%), equipment (1%), and fiscal administration (9%.)

This project, located on Berry Creek, a tributary to Canyon Creek in Grant County, would replace two existing culverts that currently impede fish passage, are undersized and prone to failure. By correcting these culverts, over 3.75 miles of habitat will be opened up for all life stages of salmonids. OWEB funds were requested for pre-implementation (2%), project management (2%), contracted services (55%), supplies/materials (26%), and fiscal administration (9%.)

Project Name: Preparing Watersheds for Climate Change Training Program

Project Summary: 2011-2013 Biennium Watershed Council Support
2011-2013 Biennium Watershed Council Support
2011-2013 Biennium Watershed Council Support
2011-2013 Biennium Watershed Council Support

CTGR requests $1,000,000 to purchase 1,225 acres of grazing and forestry lands in Dupee Valley, in the South Fork Yamhill River watershed in Yamhill County.  The property is one holding, held by a single owner.  The application describes the property as a rare opportunity for hilltop-to-hilltop restoration and protection of fish and wildlife resources.  CTGR wishes to purchase the property to restore it to riparian forest, wet prairie, and oak habitats for the benefit of priority species such as coastal cutthroat trout, acorn woodpecker, Fenders blue butterfly, Kincaids lupine, and Nelsons checkermallow

In this Technical Assistance application, Tillamook Estuaries Partnership is proposing to contract for the development of designs for four new stream crossings on Hobson Creek, a tributary of the lower Miami River. The new culverts would be designed to meet active channel widths and ODFW fish passage requirements at each of the four sites. Partners in the project could include the landowners, TEP, ODOT, ODFW, USFWS, the Collins Foundation, FishAmerica Foundation and the Mead Foundation.

Project Name: Wolf Creek Tributary/10C Road Culvert Replacement
Project Summary: The Siuslaw Watershed Council, in partnership with Roseburg Forest Products and BLM, is proposing to remove an existing barrier culvert on an un-named tributary to Wolf Creek in the Siuslaw River basin and replace it with a culvert sized to comply with fish passage requirements. The new culvert will be oriented correctly for the stream channel and placed correctly to grade. Five log structures will also be placed instream, some below the culvert site, some above, to help maintain stream grade as the stream adjusts, and to supply stream habitat complexity. The majority of OWEB funds are requested for culvert purchase and placement activities for the culvert and large wood structures with minor amounts for project management, travel and administration.

In this Restoration application the Lower Nehalem Watershed Council, in partnership with the city of Rockaway, is applying for OWEB funds to implement multi-faceted fish passage project. Jetty Creeks original stream channel will be restored in the reach influenced by the Citys Water Treatment Plant (WTP), allowing unimpeded fish access to 1.8 miles of habitat upstream of the WTP; the citys off-channel impoundment will be improved; the Citys diversion will be upgraded with a fish screen and stream flow gauge designed to facilitate water rights management; and the existing fish ladder and dam structure will be modified to ensure fish utilize the restored stream channel and not attempt to gain access to the citys impoundment pond.

In this application, the Columbia River Estuary Study Taskforce, in partnership with BPA and National Parks Service, is proposing to combine three techniques to maximize habitat restoration potential in all areas of the Colewort Creek site. Project actions include: 1) enhancement of the existing tidal marsh through channel shaping and large wood placement; 2) restoration of filled historical wetlands by removing fill and recreating tidal channels and; 3) reconnection of isolated wetlands with tidal hydrology through culvert replacement. 90% of the requested OWEB funds would be used for construction activities (erosion control, surveying, dewatering and stream diversion, tidal channel excavation, and marsh plain lowering), with the remainder budgeted for administration and project management.

This MidCoast Watershed Council proposal is designed to address the water temperature limitation in the upper Yaquina River sub basin by implementing a multi-faceted plan to restore a functional riparian canopy on the properties of three of the largest livestock operators in the area. Activities planned for those three properties include fencing to exclude all livestock from 4 miles of mainstem upper Yaquina, planting the newly fenced riparian area and, for three years, maintaining the riparian plantings. A bridge will be installed on one of the properties to end the negative impacts of regular equipment fording of the mainstem. Two other properties (4.1 acres) will also be planted and the two most important upper mainstem Yaquina salmon anchor sites will be treated by helicopter with full spanning large wood. Two tributaries will also be treated with excavator placements of large wood. Partners in the project include the landowners, USFWS, BLM and ODF. OWEB funds are budgeted for contracted services (42%), materials (41%), project management (7%), plant establishment (6%) and administration (3%).

In this application, the Lincoln SWCD is partnering with the Lincoln County Public Works Department, ODFW, ODF and several landowners to address 10 problematic culverts, spread across 6 tributaries and the upper mainstem of Spout Creek, a tributary of the Big Elk in the Yaquina River basin. The work would increase fish access to at least 9.7 miles of habitat. The project would also improve stream complexity by placement of instream wood structures over 2.75 stream miles and would enhance basking habitat of the only documented population of Western Pond Turtles in Lincoln County by placing 16 logs into the old Harlan mill pond. OWEB funds are requested for materials (59%), contracted services ((36%), administration (3%) and project management (2%).

In this proposal, the Lower Nehalem Watershed Council (Council) is working with the SF Nehalem Dairy Company to plant 6,000 native conifers and 2,000 native shrubs along roughly 3 miles of the lower Nehalem River. The BLM Native Plant Nursery will donate the native plant stock. OWEB funds are budgeted for tree planting labor (35%), three years of tree release labor (12%), project management (28%), materials (15%) travel (4%) and administration (6%).

Project Name: Mabel Creek Floodplain Restoration and Cutthroat Trout Passage
Project Summary: The Youngs Bay Watershed Council, working in partnership with the Campbell Group, USFWS, Trout Unlimited, Western Native Trout Initiative, ODFW, DEQ and North Coast Watershed Association volunteers, proposes to obliterate the _ mile section of the Mabel Creek mainline forest road that runs immediately alongside Mabel Creek, a tributary of the upper Youngs River, fully remove four culverts to restore floodplain function, replace two culverts on other roads to restore fish passage to over one mile of Mabel Creek and place 80 key pieces of large wood instream along with 190 filler pieces. OWEB funds would be used to fund road obliteration, floodplain restoration, large wood placement, one fish passage culvert replacement and erosion control materials and labor.

In this Restoration project, the Columbia SWCD, in partnership with BLM, ODFW and two landowners, is proposing to restore 2,000 linear feet of incised streambank on Merrill Creek, a tributary to the lower Columbia, by excavating a new active floodplain, reducing bank angles, planting native vegetation in the riparian area, creating new off-channel habitat and increasing stream complexity through the use of logs and boulders. OWEB funds would be used for project design, construction, riparian restoration, plant establishment, project management and administration.

Project Name: Upper North Fork Siuslaw Integrated Watershed Restoration
Project Summary: In this application, the Siuslaw Watershed Council and the Siuslaw National Forest are partnering with Plum Creek Timber and several other private landowners to implement a multiple component restoration project in the upper N. Fork Siuslaw and three of its tributaries (McLeod, Porter and Sams) to address: 1) lack of large wood instream; 2) sediment issues from a forest road running alongside Porter Creek; and 3) a variety of WQ issues involved with 5 different dispersed campsites. OWEB funds will be used for helicopter and excavator contract time; landowner outreach; contract and materials for the road decommissioning and dispersed campsite modifications; project management and administration.

Project Name: Walker Creek Phase II-Riparian Enhancement Project
Project Summary: The Upper Nehalem Watershed Council in partnerships with Hampton Affiliates (landowner) and BLM to conduct a riparian planting project along 6.4 miles of Walker Creek, tributary to Beneke Creek in the upper Nehalem River basin, focusing on areas of alder domination. 6,000 trees native conifers will be planted and some girdling of alders will occur to open the existing canopy for sunlight to the newly planted trees. OWEB funds would be used for planting materials and labor, purchase and installation of tree protective devices, project management and administration.

This proposal would continue and expand upon a MidCoast Watershed Council project that has been successful in the region over the course of the last twelve years. The project entails taking advantage of opportunities to collect whole trees, logs and other materials for restoration activities, free of charge from public and private properties, made available through storm events and land management activities (road building and/or land clearing). In addition, the project includes the ability to use a portion of the funds for the purchase of large logs from the regions timber companies, logs that the timber companies would otherwise chip for pulp material instead of use as lumber. The price of the purchased logs is comparatively low due to their size and condition (species, number of branches/knots, size and age) and the fact that the companies do not have the normal transport costs involved in logs of this type. Partners in the project include ODFW, ODF, Plum Creek Timber, Forest Capital Partners Inc, and private landowners.

In this TA application, The Nature Conservancy is requesting funding to hire a consultant to design a restoration project to address factors limiting production of salmonids in a reach of Big Creek on property it has recently acquired. Big Creek is a direct-to-ocean tributary on the central Oregon coast, roughly 10 miles south of Yachats and 13 miles north of Florence. Deliverables would include bid-ready engineering drawings and a companion report outlining project goals, methods, analysis, implementation elements, and a cost estimate. Partners include Oregon Parks & Recreation Department, ODFW, ODOT, USFS, USFWS, Audubon and the MidCoast Watershed Council.

Project Name: Lambert Slough Fish and Wildlife Acquisition
Project Summary: CTGR requests $750,000 to purchase a 183-acre property on the north bank of the Willamette River, approximately 5 miles southeast of Dayton, in Yamhill County.  The application states that 59 acres of the property are currently protected by an NRCS floodplain easement.  The remainder of the property is being farmed.  CTRG wishes to acquire the property to stop erosion and restore floodplain function.  The application states that the project will benefit priority species such as Chinook salmon, Pacific lamprey, coastal cutthroat trout, and steelhead.

Project Name: East Thornton Lake Natural Area & Kalapuya Interpretive Ctr
Project Summary: The City of Albany requests $250,000 in reimbursement for its purchase of 26.72 acres of wetland, riparian forest and shrublands, and former oak savanna in north Albany.  This application is a resubmission of application #209-111, submitted in October 2008.  The application states that the property contains 4 acres of aquatic beds and freshwater emergent marsh, and 3 acres of riparian forest and shrublands (for a total of 26.2% of the acreage proposed for acquisition).  The remainder of the property (19.7 acres) consists of a fallow farm field, which the application characterizes as eventual Western Oregon upland prairie and oak savanna (13 acres) or eventual riparian forests and shrublands (3 acres).  A public park is planned for the property, and will contain a play area, interpretive facility, interpretive trails, wildlife viewing stations, and picnic tables.

Columbia Land Trust (CLT) requests $260,000 to purchase 115 acres of white oak and ponderosa pine woodlands near The Dalles.  The purchase is of the first phase of CLTs efforts to protect the entire corridor along the Ridge from the Columbia River Gorge to the Mt Hood National Forest, which the application states is highly threatened by residential development.  The property is located in the Wasco Oaks Conservation Opportunity Area, identified in the Oregon Conservation Strategy.  The project will benefit OWEB priority species such as Lewis woodpecker and Western gray squirrel.

The Elk River Land Trust proposes acquiring the McGribble Tract as a fee title acquisition of 217 acres located in the Elk River watershed in Curry county. The property contains 1.5 miles of productive fish habitat adjoined by steep second growth native forest. The property is used for nesting by marbled murrelets and adjoins Forest Service land that is heavily used by murrelets. The conservation need is to protect Coho and Chinook salmon habitat from landslides, debris torrents and sedimentation while protecting marbled murrelet nesting trees and preventing fragmentation of murrelet habitat.

Oregon Rangeland Trust (ORT) requests to purchase a 3,514-acre conservation easement on a working cattle ranch in Lake County, near Lakeview.  ORT first submitted an application for this project in October 2008, but withdrew the application. A primary goal of the project is to sustain ranching operations.  The application commits the landowner to largely discontinuing grazing in riparian areas, installing riparian fencing, and implementing habitat restoration projects.  The property contains Oregon Valley Land tracts.  These are 10-acre parcels, remnants of a large tract that was subdivided in 1908.  The application states that the parcels are high-demand home sites, and that an easement is necessary to protect the ranch from disruption of ecological communities caused by rampant real estate development.

The North Coast Land Conservancy is proposing fee title acquisition of a 42 acre property in the Skipanon watershed in Clatsop County. This privately held interdunal lake is part of a system of 20 lakes stretching from the Clatsop Plains north to the Columbia River Estuary. This property, according to the application, represents the most northerly extent of interdunal lakes not currently under protection and is under imminent threat of development and degradation. The application states that the project will benefit OWEB priority species such as the Red-Legged Frog, the Pacific slope Flycatcher, and Bald Eagle.

The City of Lincoln City proposes to purchase approximately 157 acres of Sitka spruce forest and lowland riparian woodlands in the upper reach of the Schooner Creek watershed in Lincoln County. The application states that the property contains 2.5 stream miles of Schooner Creek. The property is currently owned by Lincoln County, which needs to sell it to raise funds for county operations. The application indicates that if the city does not purchase the property, the likely buyer of the property will be a commercial timber company. The city wishes to purchase and protect the property in part because Schooner Creek is a major source of the city's drinking water. The application states that the project will benefit OWEB priority species such as coho salmon, Chinook salmon, steelhead, northern spotted owl, and marbled murrelet.

Project Name: Applegate Watershed Fish Barrier List Update
Project Summary: This project will update and bring the Applegate basin fish passage barrier data together into a comprehensive, current and accurate dataset utilizing existing ODFW data sets and in the field verifications.

The project proposes to improve instream habitat conditions on the mainstem of Riley Creek and along sections of South Riley Creek located in Gold Beach. The project would build on fish passage improvement efforts undertaken by the applicant which have opened up the entire stream to coho and steelhead usage.
The applicant is submitting a Technical Assistance Type 1 project. The project proposes to develop stream restoration plans for Saunders Creek, a tributary to the Lower Rogue estuary.

The Coquille Watershed Association (CWA) is partnering with the Conservation Reserve Enhancement Program (CREP) on a two phase restoration project to enhance over wintering juvenile coho habitat on a private ranch located off of the South Fork Coquille River (SFCR). This project site is located on a private ranch in Myrtle Point between river mile 39 and 40 off the SFCR.

Project Name: East Fork Coquille River Riparian Restoration
Project Summary: The Coquille Watershed Association is proposing to restore 4.6 acres of riparian habitat and stabilize actively eroding banks along the East Fork of the Coquille River.

The proposed project is at RM 14 on the lower South Fork Coquille River (SFC). Bank erosion in the lower SFC is causing substantial loss of riparian vegetation and valuable agricultural soils, and is degrading fisheries habitat. The project will revegetate a 700ft long x 25ft high actively eroding river bank with live willow brush mattress and live willow siltation baffles.

Project Name: Camp Creek Large Wood Salmon Habitat Restoration
Project Summary: This project proposes to increase instream habitat complexity through the placement of large wood structures in Camp Creek, a tributary of Mill Creek and the Umpqua River near Scottsburg.

Project Name: Stormproofing Sucker Creek's Roads: Technical Assistance to Reduce Sediment Source and Protect Aquatic Habitat
Project Summary: The applicant is submitting a Technical Assistance Type 2 application. This project would provide technical design assistance for sediment source reduction from forest roads in Sucker Creek watershed located in the Illinois River system located within the Rogue River basin.

The applicant proposes to implement project design and outreach efforts to address degraded riparian conditions along lower Dear Creek. Deer Creek is a tributary that flow into the South Umpqua in the city limits of Roseburg.

This project seeks funding to conduct landowner outreach, perform site analysis of the top 101 anadromous migration barriers and then prioritize them according to restoration potential. This project will take place in the Umpqua River watershed.

The project proposes to place large wood and boulders within the channel, replace a barrier to fish passage, plant native vegetation, remove blackberry within the riparian area and install a streambank revetment project on a property on Tenmile Creek. Tenmile Creek is located within the Olalla~Lookingglass watershed which is a tributary to the South Umpqua River.

Project Name: Elliott State Forest Road Improvement Surveys and Evaluation
Project Summary: This project will evaluate Elliott State Forest's 530 mile road system to identify any remaining fish passage barriers or impediments (adults and juveniles), evaluate road drainage to determine hydrological connectivity between road surfaces and cut-slopes in order to estimate sediment yields and peak-flow effects, and determine improvements needed to effectively minimize road-related effects to watershed conditions.

Project Name: South Fork Coos Basin Aquatic Inventory Surveys
Project Summary: This project will fund Aquatic Habitat Inventory surveys in the upper South Fork Coos River and 19 of its named tributaries. Proposed is the surveying of over 37 miles of mainstem habitat, and 40 miles of valuable tributary habitat.

The project proposes to improve forest health on private properties located near Grants Pass. The Applegate Valley Forest Health Initiative is designed to foster forest stewardship by providing private landowners with information on forestry management and practices to improve forest health to provide sustainable forest resources.

The Technical Assistance grant will allow the applicant to hire a surveyor/engineer to survey the creek and surrounding landscape and design four railcar bridges with appropriate footings. These designs will be used by Umpqua SWCD as part of a larger more comprehensive farm plan that will minimize impacts of cattle ranching on Eslick Creek, a tributary to the lower Smith River in the Umpqua River estuary.

Project Name: Deer Creek Channel and Floodplain Restoration - Phase 1
Project Summary: The project proposes to improve summer instream water flows along a two-mile section of Deer Creek, a tributary to the Illinois River in the Rogue River watershed. The project is located approximately eight miles east of Selma on Deer Creek. The project will move the current point of diversion downstream allowing a longer stream reach to be wetted.

Project Name: Little Butte Creek Water Quality Improvement Project
Project Summary: This project proposes to hire a full-time coordinator to facilitate the review and prioritization of water quality restoration activities in the Little Butte Creek watershed, Little Butte Creek is a tributary to the Rogue River.

Project Name: North Fork Coquille Watershed Project Development and Landowner Recruitment
Project Summary: This proposal will support project design and landowner recruitment within the North Fork Coquille   River watershed and is a continuation of the North Fork Coquille River 5th Field Watershed Restoration  Implementation effort.

The applicant is submitting a Technical Assistance Type 1 project. The project proposes to develop stream restoration plans for Saunders Creek, a tributary to the Lower Rogue Estuary. Saunders Creek has been degraded by logging practices, road building, and residential development.

The project proposes to improve instream habitat conditions on Riley Creek. Riley Creek is an urban stream that flows through the City of Gold Beach. This project will improve habitat, stabilize stream banks, and provide grade control to 0.57 miles of stream.
This proposal is to construct two permanent, two-bay boat wash stations at Tenmile Lakes Coos County Park in the City of Lakeside, Oregon to help reduce the potential for spread of invasive species.

The applicant proposes to engage 150 adults and 75 high school students in six presentations and seven "living laboratory" workshops collecting data and performing restoration activities on the Rogue River following the removal of the Gold Ray Dam.

Project Name: Stream Smart - Bear Creek Clean Water Project
Project Summary: Bear Creek Watershed Council proposes to develop a "Stream Smart  Bear Creek Clean Water Project" branding and marketing campaign in order to raise awareness of water quality issues, influence attitudes and values, and promote behavior change in the watershed.

Upper Rogue Watershed Association proposes to provide a continuing program for teachers from four different schools in the Upper Rogue. The purpose of the training is to increase teachers' skills and confidence taking students outdoors for watershed learning experiences.

The project proposes to improve habitat and restore instream processes in approximately 3/4 mile of Cox Creek. Cox Creek is located in the Upper Elk Creek watershed of the Umpqua River basin.Two rock weirs will be constructed in a section of the stream that has eroded to bedrock to trap gravel and create a pool. Large wood structures and structures of both logs and boulders will be constructed at eight sites.

This project will provide the first baseline monitoring data for an 850-acre property on Deer Creek, a tributary to the Illinois River near the town of Selma. The Deer Creek Center (DCC) property is an OWEB project which has invested in a conservation easement.

The Applegate Partnership and Watershed Council propose to provide K-12 students in the Applegate and Rogue Valleys field trips to Salmon Safe farms and ranches. Participating farmers and ranchers will receive assistance in the implementation and monitoring of restoration projects and Salmon-Safe certification.

Williams Community Forest Project proposes four themed workshops with first-hand experiences in local restoration projects to residents of their community. The audience would gain increased knowledge that would inform their decisions in how they manage and interact with their land as well as skills in techniques for restoring and maintaining their land.

Project Name: North Fork Coquille Watershed Project Development and Landowner Recruitment
Project Summary: The applicant has submitted a  Type III Technical Assistance Application. The North Fork Coquille River (NFCR) is a 5th field watershed located along the southern Oregon coast within the Coquille Watershed. This proposal for project development and landowner recruitment is a continuation of the North Fork Coquille River 5th Field Watershed Restoration initiative effort. The lower reaches and tributaries of the mainstem NFCR watershed are scattered with numerous small landowners, creating a need for extensive landowner education, outreach, and project design to complete the restoration efforts in the watershed.

Project Name: North Curry Ranch Water Quality Restoration
Project Summary: The projects proposed will be implemented on seven different properties. The implementation of the best management practices on the properties is necessary to facilitate livestock exclusion and riparian buffer regeneration. The projects are designed to reduce or eliminate all factors contributing to water quality and salmonid habitat degradation at the project sites.

Project Name: Upper Floras Creek Coho Restoration Plan Development
Project Summary: The applicant has submitted a Type II Technical Assistance Application. Through this proposal, the applicant will delineate coho distribution, and then inventory instream habitat and road networks for project opportunities. Inventory data will be used to develop and prioritize large wood and sediment abatement project, which will be assembled into a Coho Restoration Plan for upper Floras Creek.

The project proposes to improve instream habitat complexity on Bilger Creek by placing large wood.  Bilger Creek is a tributary to North Myrtle Creek and is located approximately three miles northeast of Myrtle Creek in the Myrtle Creek fifth-field watershed.

Project Name: West Fork Smith River Phase III
Project Summary: The project proposes to build on previous phases which installed large wood in tributaries to the West Fork Smith River, located within the Umpqua River watershed. Phase III will include the placement of 6,100 boulders throughout 31 sites covering 5 miles on the mainstem West Fork Smith River.

Project Name: Myrtle Point Wetland Enhancement and Restoration
Project Summary: The Myrtle Point Wetland is part of a 280 acre ranch on the South Fork Coquille River in Myrtle Point, Oregon. The project proposes to enhancing the wetland and associated streams through fencing, planting, restoration of fish passage and filter runoff from 200 acres of pasture and 20 square miles of upstream residential and highway land cover which will significantly improve over-wintering juvenile coho habitat by reducing sediment, lowering water temperatures, reducing nutrient overloading, significantly increasing fish passage, and enhancing habitat complexity.

Project Name: Milk Creek In-stream and Riparian Enhancement
Project Summary: The project is on Milk Creek, a major stream in the Lower Molalla River watershed in western Clackamas County. The project encompasses about 5 acres, running through three adjacent private properties on both sides of the creek. Milk Creek is a primary production stream for Coho, listed spring Chinook, and listed winter steelhead, as well as resident cutthroat trout. The Molalla River Watershed TMDL lists Milk Creek for temperature and identifies riparian restoration and stream flow as needs. Watershed issues to be addressed are: lack of in-stream habitat, simplified channel structure, floodplain degradation, changes in stream hydrology, sediment inputs from bank erosion, high water temperature, and need for education of area residents regarding stream stewardship. Proposed solutions are: bank shaping and placement of large wood structures along 0.2 miles of stream; removal of invasive non-native vegetation on 5 acres along with heavy planting of native trees, shrubs, and cuttings; and outreach and education in the Milk Creek subwatershed.  OWEB funds will be used for materials and contracted services for bank shaping, installation of large wood structures, floodplain enhancement, invasives control, and native plantings. Partners include: Clackamas SWCD, USDA Natural Resources Conservation Service, USDA CREP, Oregon DEQ, ODFW, and Molalla River Watch.

Project Name: Lost Creek Tributaries Riparian Enhancement Project
Project Summary: The project will occur in Lane County along Wagner and Middle creeks, tributaries to Lost Creek, which in turn is a Model Watershed tributary to the Middle Fork Willamette River. Lost Creek has high summer stream temperatures, localized bank erosion and sedimentation problems, and limited habitat for fish and wildlife. One of the main limiting factors to stream quality is the riparian condition of the tributaries to Lost Creek. The applicant proposes to enhance and restore about 7.5 acres at key locations along the riparian corridor of Wagner and Middle creeks, and along Lost Creek. To provide future shade and large wood to the stream, the applicant will remove non-native invasive species on 7.5 acres and replant with native trees, shrubs, and grasses. To reduce bank erosion and the contribution of fine sediments, the applicant will use stream bank bioengineering techniques to stabilize 0.02 miles of bank. Plant establishment activities are planned for three years post-restoration implementation. Project areas will be monitored for restoration effectiveness with funding from Meyer Memorial Trust (MMT) as a part of the Model Watershed Program. In addition to MMT, partners include the five private landowners. OWEB funds will be used for purchase of native plants; contract labor for site preparation, weed removal and planting; project management; and purchase of equipment for a watering system.

Project Name: Dexter Oak Woodlands Enhancement Project - Phase II
Project Summary: This project is located at Dexter State Recreation Area in the Middle Fork Willamette Watershed in Lane County.  Oak woodlands at the park have been degraded by years of fire suppression activities, which have allowed conifers and invasive plants to invade the habitat. Due to public recreational use in the park, fire suppression activities will continue. Thus, manual control of invasives is necessary to enhance the vigor of oak woodland species and to support wildlife habitat. The applicant proposes to conduct mechanical and hand removal of small conifers and invasive plants over 22 acres of oak woodland habitat, followed by planting native shrubs and grass to prevent erosion and discourage the return of invasive plant species. OWEB funds will be used for contract labor, materials and supplies, and management elements of the project. Effectiveness monitoring will be conducted by OPRD staff and student volunteers, but no funding is necessary from OWEB to complete the monitoring effort. Partners include Oregon Parks and Recreation and the Army Corps of Engineers.

Project Name: Butte Creek Subwatershed Assessment and Action Plan
Project Summary: Butte Creek Subwatershed in the Pudding Watershed supports populations of Upper Willamette River Chinook and steelhead. The applicant seeks funding for a comprehensive Butte Creek Subwatershed Assessment and Action Plan. This subwatershed is considered high-quality habitat for salmonids by ODFW, and the Butte Creek confluence area is contained within ODFW''''s Conservation Opportunity Areas for the Lower Pudding River. The applicant will collate existing information relevant to understanding watershed processes and the range of constraints affecting aquatic habitat structure and overall subbasin function. Another key component of the project will be support for the applicants "Creekshed Stewardship Team" to drive project implementation and long-term public participation. The project will yield new datasets addressing current gaps in hydrologic modifications, including but not limited to: barrier assessments, road density analysis, floodplain fragmentation, anchor reach evaluations, and site-specific topographic data. In part, the result of the proposed action plan will be identification of 15-20 potential restoration projects for future implementation. Partners include Clackamas SWCD, ODFW, BLM, and NRCS. OWEB funds will be used principally for project management, contracted services, and production.

This project will occur along Little Buckner Creek in the Hopkins Demonstration Forest in Clackamas Countys Molalla Watershed. An existing section of Little Buckner creek is lacking large woody debris, which is causing downstream bank and trail erosion of the existing interpretive trail. The applicant proposes to use the Canby Youth Corps to place large wood instream to create a meander in the creek to redirect flow around the existing trail; create additional trail at the meander site with interpretive signage; repair the riparian zone along the interpretive trail by removing of invasive species and replanting with native vegetation; and to redevelop two fire-chance ponds, originally developed in the 1960s, to remove sediment and to restore the ponds to provide wildlife habitat and a water source for fire suppression. Finally, the Canby Youth Corps will assist with presenting educational programming to Canby Elementary and Middle schools that visit the Hopkins Forest. The Youth Corps will help develop a new brochure and corresponding web pages, targeting high school audiences. OWEB funds will be used primarily for Contracted Services. Partners include OSU Extension Service, Canby School District, ODFW, and ODF.

The primary limiting factor for salmonid health in the Yamhill Basin is elevated stream and river temperatures. The proposed technical assistance activity will include an evaluation of shade potential and near-stream riparian conditions along 30 miles of the two primary salmonid-bearing rivers in the basin, the North and South Yamhill rivers. These rivers exhibit temperatures that greatly exceed levels considered sustainable for cold water aquatic life. From this evaluation, a "guidance" document will be produced that will allow the applicant to target problem areas and specific landowners for near-stream restoration projects. Yamhill SWCD is the principal partner. OWEB funds will be used for project management, in-house personnel, contracted services, and production.

Project Name: Gales Creek Watershed Data Synthesis and Restoration Plan
Project Summary: The applicant seeks technical assistance funding to complete a habitat restoration plan for the Gales Creek 5th field subwatershed. Relevant historical data will be synthesized to develop this plan. The data will be compiled into a geodatabase, using the Computational Ecological Prioritization Process tool (CERP) developed with OWEB funds and used previously in the Tillamook Bay, North and Middle Fork John Day, and the Brownlee Reservoir watersheds. Following data synthesis and 7th-field restoration and data collection prioritization, an action plan will be developed, emphasizing the highest priority areas. This process will involve on-the-ground restoration project planning, focusing on steelhead habitat improvements. Projects will be ranked based on weighting criteria, which among other things, will include the potential for steelhead population increase, socio-economic factors, and project feasibility. Partners include Clean Water Services, Washington County Transportation, City of Tigard, ODFW, ODF, and NRCS. OWEB funds will be used principally for contracted services.

Claggett Creek, a tributary to the Willamette River, flows through the cities of Keizer and Salem, in Marion County. Urbanization has confined this creek and stormwater run-off has increased stream flow and velocities. Construction and landscaping practices have altered or destroyed much of the native vegetation once found throughout the riparian corridor. As a result, Claggett Creek is listed as a 303(d) stream under the Clean Water Act. The project is located at Claggett Creek Middle School in Keizer. Objectives are to establish 2,504 native plants and 18 pounds of grass/wildflower seed mix that will work to stabilize banks and provide habitat while lowering the streams temperature, bacteria, and mercury levels. Site evaluation and plant management will be conducted by Keizer staff with the assistance of the Claggett Creek Watershed Council and Claggett Creek Middle School students. OWEB funds will be used to provide site preparation, supplies, equipment rental, contracted labor, and plant establishment. Partners include Marion Soil and Water Conservation District, Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife, Salem-Keizer School District, City of Salem, Claggett Creek Watershed Council, Marion County and the City of Keizer.

Project Name: Cedar Creek (Molalla River) Fish Passage Project
Project Summary: This project proposes to remove a major fish passage barrier consisting of three undersized culverts and replace them with a bridge over Cedar Creek in the Molalla River Watershed. The project has been identified by ODFW as priority fish habitat due to the sites upstream spawning and rearing habitat. Completion of the project will open approximately 2.5 miles of stream and allow unimpeded access to 350 acres containing numerous forks and unnamed tributaries historically used by native winter steelhead, Chinook salmon, resident rainbow and cutthroat trout, Pacific and brook lamprey, and dace. Naturalized Coho salmon would benefit from access to the upper reaches of Cedar Creek. The project would also benefit wildlife and help reduce erosion and scour to conform to the Clean Water Act. OWEB funds will be used for some contracted services, bridge materials and administration. Partners include ODFW and Weyerhaeuser.

The applicant requests funding from OWEB for a feasibility study of fish passage issues on Rinearson Creek. The study will identify appropriate and acceptable long-term restoration activities in the lower watershed with a focus on the dam, pond, and associated surrounding floodplain areas. OWEB funding would be used to: conduct field topographic and bathymetric survey; conduct flow monitoring at site; conduct field sediment sampling and testing; conduct supplemental biological investigation; prepare flood frequency inundation study and mapping; conduct wetland mapping; conduct cultural resources investigation; estimate sediment storage behind dam; prepare permit-ready level design documents and construction cost estimates; and organize stakeholder outreach. At least five restoration alternatives will be scientifically investigated and the Rinearson Coalition will select the best alternative for future implementation. Partners include The Nature Conservancy, Metro, and ODFW. OWEB funds will be used principally for contracted services.

The Middle Reach of the Calapooia River, spanning from Sodom Dam (RM 28) to the former Brownsville Dam site (RM 36), has been identified as "dynamic river corridor for protection and restoration" by the Council''s 2004 Action Plan. The Calapooia Watershed Council has completed the Middle Calapooia River Project Implementation Plan, which divides the eight-mile reach into four, two-mile sub-reaches. Reach 2 (R2), located at Pioneer Park in Brownsville, is a 1.3-mile section of river with significant side channel and mainstem salmonid rearing habitats and winter refuge zones. The Council has completed USFS Title 11-funded designs for all five landowners along R2, which will complement multiple, large OWEB-funded instream restoration and riparian conservation easement projects immediately downstream in Reach 3. Fish species that will benefit include spring Chinook and winter steelhead, cutthroat trout, and other native non-salmonids. This OWEB request will be used to improve riparian structure and function, add instream habitat complexity, and decrease sedimentation using innovative techniques on City and private landowner properties. OWEB funds will be used principally for design and permitting, contracted services, and project management. Partners include the City of Brownsville, private landowners, and the USDA Forest Service.

The project will occur on White Creek, near its confluence with Gales Creek, in the Tualatin River Watershed. This reach of Gales Creek has been designated Essential Salmonid and Federal Critical Habitat for Winter Steelhead Trout.  The applicant seeks to remove two fish passage barriers (culverts) located on White Creek approximately 60 and 200 feet from their confluence with Gales Creek.  The project will restore access to almost 2.5 miles of refuge and rearing habitat for numerous native fish species, including winter steelhead. The applicant recently completed the Gales Creek Fish Passage Assessment and Prioritization Project, which ranks this barrier group as second highest in importance. The applicant proposes to replace the barriers with structures that meet ODFW/NOAA fish passage stream simulation requirements and to enhance the adjacent riparian corridors. Effectiveness monitoring will be performed by the applicant in compliance with its Programmatic Fish Passage Permit with ODFW. OWEB funds will be used primarily for a topographic survey, in-house personnel, contracted services, and supplies and materials.

Wapato Lake is a seasonally flooded lakebed located in the Tualatin River Valley, Oregon. Proper land management is vital to the ecological health of the lake, as well as downstream in the Tualatin River. In 2008, water discharged from Wapato Lake released toxic blue-green algae and zooplankton into the Tualatin River, causing treatment problems for water utility providers. To avoid similar events in the future, land managers with the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS) have developed a Comprehensive Conservation Plan to guide future strategies for the Wapato Lake area. As part of this plan, land managers would like to monitor water-quality conditions in and out of the lake. Interested shareholders in this research include the USFWS, the U.S. Geological Survey, and Clean Water Services. The project will collect water samples for nutrient analysis, including dissolved and total phosphorous, dissolved ammonia and carbon, nitrite plus nitrate, total nitrogen, algae, zooplankton, and other parameters. OWEB funds will be used for project coordination and supplies and materials.

Project Name: Hobart Natural Area Wetland Restoration and Bradshaw's Lomatium Recovery
Project Summary: Willamette Valley prairie is one of the most endangered habitats in Oregon, and as such, is home to many rare species, including the state and federally listed Bradshaw's lomatium. The Hobart Natural Area in Sweet Home, Oregon, contains a 15-acre wetland that hosts one of the few populations of Bradshaw's lomatium left in the Willamette Valley. The wetland area (and the Bradshaw's lomatium population) has been impacted by non-native vegetation, woody plant encroachment, and illegal vehicle usage. The applicant proposes to develop a management plan for this site, improve creek and wetland function, enhance Bradshaw's lomatium habitat, and augment the population of this listed species within the natural area in an effort to help meet recovery objectives. Effectiveness monitoring will assess creek health, plant community composition, and establishment of introduced Bradshaw's lomatium. OWEB funds will be used for creek and wetland restoration activities; Bradshaw's lomatium seed collection, cultivation, introduction and monitoring; installation of fencing and/or boulders to restrict vehicle access. Partners include the South Santiam Watershed and Youth Watershed Councils, Institute for Applied Ecology, ODA, and USFWS.

The project is located at Jackson Bottom Wetland in Hillsboro. Open to the public, the marsh is important to wildlife, but is severely degraded and suffering from altered hydrology and massive infestations of reed canary grass. This project will restore the natural hydrology and native vegetation communities to 140 acres of floodplain wetlands at Jackson Bottom. Hydrology will be restored by removing drainage structures and creating low-profile cells to trap and hold floodwaters. Native vegetation will be restored using an aggressive restoration technique that depends on intensive site preparation and high-density planting and seeding of native vegetation to prevent re-invasion of canary grass. OWEB funds will be used to purchase a portion of the native plant materials (native wetland seed) necessary for the project's success, and to pay for a portion of restoration activities and five years of plant establishment. Partners include Clean Water Services, Ducks Unlimited, Big Trees Today, PGE, City of Hillsboro, and Metro.

The applicant will convene the Row River Technical Oversight Committee (TOC) to conduct a restoration planning/project prioritization process in the Row River/ Mosby Creek sub-watersheds in the Coast Fork Willamette Watershed. Beginning in 2013, $523,000 will become available for fish habitat restoration within this planning area due to a settlement agreement associated with the Dorena hydroelectric project. A collaborative restoration planning process and project prioritization plan will develop a clear and focused effort for future improvements to habitat for spring Chinook, winter steelhead, Pacific lamprey, and cutthroat and rainbow trout. Partners include ODFW Springfield, Riverbank Power, USFS, BLM, Weyerhaeuser and the Coast Fork TOC. OWEB funds will be used for project management, in-house personnel, contracted services, supplies, production, equipment, and fiscal administration.

Project Name: North Unit Wetland Restoration and Enhancement
Project Summary: The project is located within the boundaries of the Sauvie Island Wildlife Area, northwest of Portland. Water control structures were installed throughout the island to increase available waterfowl habitat and to impede the spread of invasive plant species by inundating the plants during critical growth periods. While many of these structures have been effective in achieving the desired goals, three structures have been ineffective at impeding invasive plant growth largely because of site-specific topographic conditions and alterations to estuary flows. They have also negatively impacted wildlife habitat by reducing water quality, altering sediment processes, and reducing or eliminating juvenile salmonid access to hundreds of acres of historical fish habitat. The project proposes to design a series of actions that will result in an accessible mosaic of tidal wetland habitats suitable for juvenile salmonids, waterfowl, and other priority species. Partners include ODFW, Multnomah SWCD, and the Bonneville Power Administration. OWEB funds will be used for contracted services (topographic survey, modeling scenarios, conceptual plans, and 30 percent design) and project management.

Project Name: Butte Creek Subwatershed Assessment and Action Plan
Project Summary: Butte Creek Subwatershed in the Pudding Watershed supports populations of Upper Willamette River Chinook and steelhead. The applicant seeks funding for a comprehensive Butte Creek Subwatershed Assessment and Action Plan. This subwatershed is considered high-quality habitat for salmonids by ODFW, and the Butte Creek confluence area is contained within ODFW's Conservation Opportunity Area for the Lower Pudding River. The applicant will collate existing information relevant to understanding watershed processes and the range of constraints affecting aquatic habitat structure and overall subbasin function. Another key component of the project will be support for the applicants "Creekshed Stewardship Team" to drive project implementation and long-term public participation. The project will yield new datasets addressing current gaps in hydrologic modifications, including but not limited to: barrier assessments, road density analysis, floodplain fragmentation, anchor reach evaluations, and site-specific topographic data. In part, the result of the proposed action plan will be identification of 12-20 potential restoration projects for future implementation. Partners include Clackamas SWCD, ODFW, and the City of Salem. OWEB funds will be used principally for project management, contracted services, and production.

Project Name: Molalla River Culvert and Barrier Study
Project Summary: The Molalla River watershed provides essential spawning and rearing habitat and cold water refugia vital to two ESA-listed anadromous fish: wild winter steelhead and spring Chinook salmon. The project proposes to produce a comprehensive fish barrier assessment for the Molalla Watershed, resulting in an annotated and prioritized database for key salmon and steelhead tributaries of the Molalla River. Results will include a prioritized approach to removing key barriers having the greatest recovery benefit to target species. Existing data sources will inform the process and prioritization of subbasins for future restoration. Restoration project recommendations will be directly tied to limiting factors identified in the Upper Willamette River Conservation and Recovery Plan (Aug. 2011). Ranking criteria will be compiled through a review of successful barrier inventories in western Oregon and vetted by the applicant and representatives from ODFW, NOAA, NMFS, Molalla RiverWatch and Native Fish Society. Partners will also help establish key restoration priorities and landowner relationships for barrier assessments. The applicant will work with PC Trask and Associates throughout process. Data will be available to restoration practitioners in the Molalla River basin. OWEB funds will be used primarily for contracted services and project management.

Teachers seek opportunities to engage students in meaningful service learning opportunities, but finding the time and available funding for field trips are difficult. Students learn best with multiple styles/approaches, and need more opportunities to engage in hands-on projects. This project will involve students in service learning, provide teachers with curriculum to do this work while meeting state standards, and improve watershed health by improving habitat. By providing funding to help with field trips, as well as opportunities for on-campus restoration projects, OWEB support will make outdoor education accessible to teachers and students in the watershed, and involve parents and community members to help raise broader awareness of watershed health.  Partners include East Multnomah SWCD and the WHH Foundation. OWEB funds will be used from project management, contracted services, and supplies and materials.

Project Name: Newell Canyon Middle Segment Restoration Project
Project Summary: The project is generally located at the intersection of Hwy. 213 and Beavercreek Road near Oregon City. Newell Creek aquatic, riparian, and upland habitats are degraded, due largely to urbanization, logging, storm water issues, noxious weeds, and the lack of complexity in the upland conifer and deciduous forest. The proposed solution is to introduce in-stream large wood placement, weed treatment and revegetation elements aimed at restoring water quality, quantity, fish habitat, and aquatic health throughout the 219 acres of Newell Canyon. OWEB funds will be used for in-stream work, project engineering oversight and certification, permits, contracted services, education and outreach, travel to and from and from the site, fiscal administration, and general project management. Partners include The Nature Conservancy, Oregon City, Clackamas County SWCD, Metro, and ODFW.

Project Name: Molalla River Large Wood Placement Project Development
Project Summary: The Molalla River Watershed provides essential spawning and rearing habitat and cold water refugia vital to two ESA-listed anadromous fish: wild winter steelhead and spring Chinook salmon. Key limiting factors, identified in the Upper Willamette River Conservation and Recovery Plan (August 2011) to be addressed by this project include significantly reduced habitat complexity and high summer temperatures. OWEB funds will be used to work with ODFW, NOAA, NMFS and other partners to choose up to three specific high-priority sites for large wood placement in the watershed. Funds will also be used to work with key landowners and engineers to develop specific design concepts ready to submit to restoration funders (30% designs).

This training program will foster the creation of knowledgeable and engaged watershed leaders. Through a series of trainings, the program will create volunteer leaders with the ability to usher a project idea from planning to implementation. The program will use a mentor model to provide new volunteer leaders with community support and guidance. Outreach activities will occur in Southwest Portland and in the Tryon Creek and Tualatin River watersheds. Field trips and watershed enhancement projects will also be conducted in the target watersheds (Tualatin and Tryon) in Southwest Portland. Partners include Tualatin River Watershed Council and OSU Extension. OWEB Funds will be used to support staff time to coordinate the program, transportation, speaker fees, fiscal and grant administration and education materials.

The project is located on Nettle Creek, a tributary to Tryon Creek in the lower Willamette, and within Tryon Creek State Park in southwest Portland. The culvert has a 36" perch and presents a barrier to fish. This culvert is on the list of high priority culvert replacements for Oregon State Parks. Most of Nettle Creek has excellent riparian canopy and is habitat principally for steelhead and cutthroat trout. There are three miles of perennial low-gradient stream above the culvert, 2000' of which are protected within the state park. OWEB funds will be used to replace the culvert with a bridge, place large wood instream to counteract down cutting, and revegetate the disturbed area. Partners include Friends of Tryon Creek State Park and Tryon Creek State Park.

This project is located in a one-mile stream reach of lower Gales Creek. Watershed problems include: 1) lack of channel complexity in the mainstem; 2) lack of off-channel refugia for migrating adult and juvenile steelhead; 3) invasive riparian plant species; and 4) higher stream temperatures due to a general lack of canopy. The proposed solution is to:  1) place five large wood structures at two locations in a 0.3 mile reach to enhance existing side channel and backwater alcove habitat;  2) decommission a 0.07-mile creek access road to the side channel and stabilize the site;  3) treat invasive plant species and plant, maintain, and monitor native shrubs and trees located within the one-mile project area. Partners include the landowner, Tualatin SWCD, Clean Water Services, and ODFW. OWEB funds will be used for materials and construction of engineered logjams, road decommissioning, project management, and fiscal administration.

Project Name: Still Creek Habitat Restoration - Compression Project Area
Project Summary: Still Creek is a tributary to the Zig Zag River, located entirely within the Mt. Hood National Forest, in Northwest Oregon near the town of Rhododendron. Historically, Still Creek provided high-quality spawning and rearing habitat for native coho, spring Chinook, winter steelhead, and cutthroat trout, and has been identified by the Sandy River Basin Partners as high-quality anchor habitat for coho and winter steelhead, providing key spawning and rearing habitat. Poor riparian conditions and lack of floodplain roughness have resulted in a loss of stream sinuosity and an increase in average gradients. Over time, the channel has simplified with few pools, side channels, or off-channel habitat. This project seeks to accelerate recovery of naturally functioning conditions within stream channels and riparian areas to improve fish habitat. OWEB funds will support the construction of large wood complexes, addition of wood to existing structures as well as floodplain and off-channel areas, restoration of side channel/off-channel habitat, and riparian restoration. Partners include the City of Portland and the USDA Forest Service.

Snake-Deford Creek is a tributary to the North Santiam River with sections designated as Essential Salmonid Habitat for Chinook salmon and steelhead. The project builds on a previously funded technical assistance grant to develop a restoration strategy for the creek. The project will replace three, undersized culverts with bridges provided by Linn County Road Department. The bridges will meet SLOPES IV and ODFW fish passage requirements. Replacing crossings will provide fish passage to limited stream habitat and improve material transport. Supporting funds from other grants will be used to restore riparian buffers that will increase future large wood recruitment and shade. Linn County is the principal partner. OWEB funds will be used mainly for contracted services needed to install the bridges.

Brush Creek, a major tributary to the Calapooia River near the town of Crawfordsville, has been consistently identified as a high-priority stream for salmonid habitat enhancement primarily due to its role as crucial thermal refuge for migrating salmonids in the mainstem Calapooia. 2006 ODFW habitat surveys and recent technical team inventories revealed that Brush Creek sub-basin is severely lacking in large woody debris. The project will increase salmonid habitat at four reaches throughout the sub-basin by placing 127 logs along 3.09 miles of stream, as well as by planting two riparian acres. Habitat enhancement will yield both substantial benefits for existing winter steel head and Chinook salmon within the stream, as well as boost the stream's temperature-reducing capacity. OWEB funding will be used for materials and labor. Partners include the landowners, Linn County Roads Department and USDA Forest Service.

The Central Linn Youth Outreach Program is a partnership between the Calapooia Watershed Council and the Central Linn School District. It will reach 450 elementary school students, as well as educators and community members. This young target audience resides in the highest priority sub-basins and mainstem reaches of the Calapooia where most of the Council's restoration and conservation work occurs. While adult awareness of watershed health has increased, the local elementary school lacks a watershed program. The program's direct link to associated content standards, field activities, stream and restoration monitoring activities, and the Outdoor School, will help raise watershed awareness. Partners include the Grey Family Foundation, Spirit Mountain Community Fund, and Central Linn School District. OWEB funds will be used for project management and supplies and materials.

Beaver Creek is a tributary of Muddy Creek in the Marys River Basin. The project is focused on the Upper reach of Beaver Creek where the stream morphology and current conditions provide the best opportunity to restore natural function and improve fish habitat. Riparian conversion for agriculture and residences, and channel simplification associated with historic channel manipulation and removal of large conifers, have reduced instream wood structure. The proposed solution is to:  1) install 33 log structures over 2.5 miles to trap and store mobile bedload to keep low summer flows moving subsurface through a gravel lens rather than passing over exposed bedrock;  and  2) increase off-channel winter habitat by reconnecting two historic alcove sites. Partners include four private landowners, USFWS, ODFW, and Meyer Memorial Trust. OWEB funds will be used for pre-implementation activities, project management, equipment operation (log placement, alcoves, and riparian site preparation), and riparian planting.

The project would treat invasive juniper on 350 acres about five miles southeast of Madras in the Willow Creek watershed on the federally owned Crooked River National Grasslands.  Trees would be felled and marketable wood would be removed.  It is proposed that 20% of the juniper would be left in one acre clumps.  Post-treatment burning will occur to dispose of slash and kill small juniper trees.

Project Name: Odell Creek Hydro Project Decommissioning (Phase 1 Planning)
Project Summary: This project, with the help of a technical advisory team, will evaluate the alternatives for re-licensing or decommissioning an existing small hydroelectric facility on Odell Creek in the Hood River watershed.  Environmental and cost analysis will be done considering current fish passage and water quality requirements.  Consideration will be given to removing the concrete full spanning dam, restoring historical stream channels, addressing sediment accumulation above the dam, removing the penstock and power generating facilities and converting the hydro-power water right to an instream water right.  The proposal also includes a valuation of water rights.

This project is about ten miles southeast of Klamath Falls in the Lost River watershed.  The landowner would remove 400 acres of invasive juniper by using a caterpillar tractor and hand falling.  Slash piles would be burned and the areas that require seeding will be reseeded to perennial grasses.  The juniper occupation of the site has reduced the carrying capacity of the property by over 50%.  Restoring the presence of native grasses, forbs and shrubs should benefit mule deer.  Soil erosion has deposited sediments into the Lost River which is home to the ESA listed Lost River suckerfish.  Partners include the NRCS, the Klamath SWCD and landowners.

Project Name: TTDC Diversion Improvement and Habitat Restoration
Project Summary: This project would re-locate the point of diversion for the Tumalo Town Ditch so it is within the town of Tumalo, thus eliminating 1.2 miles of existing steel pipe, a portion of which is adjacent to the Deschutes River.  The pipe and retaining wall are threatening failure into the Deschutes River.  The new diversion, also from the Deschutes River, would be screened, pumped to a 4,000 gallon reservoir tank via 2,400 feet of 6 PVC pipe and delivered to community patrons of the district by 1700 feet of PVC 6 buried pipe in lieu of the existing open ditch.

Project Name: Lower Crooked River Riparian Zone Restoration and Fish Habitat Enhancement, Ranch at the Canyons, Terrebone, Oregon
Project Summary: This project would develop a riparian and fish habitat restoration plan for the Crooked River adjacent to the Ranch at the Canyons property.  The plan will also consider upland management and irrigation management issues in order to optimize both upland and aquatic habitats for wildlife and fisheries.

Project Name: Robinson Springs Redband Trout Habitat Enhancement, Phase I
Project Summary: This project would install 3,100 feet of gated irrigation pipe, replacing an open ditch that flood irrigates a 400 acre pasture.  It would also enhance fish passage to the water source, a spring, and enhance riparian conditions by planting 120 caged willows along Robinson Spring Creek, a tributary to Fishhole Creek and the South Fork Sprague River.  There are native redband trout in the stream. More efficient use of the water should result in less water being diverted from the natural watercourse downstream of Robinson Spring.  Juniper trees in the riparian area will be felled and grazing pressure will be reduced to support riparian plant establishment.  Partners include the landowner and Kerns Irrigation, Inc.

This project would pipe a portion of the Rock Creek Irrigation Districts main irrigation ditch and result in _ of a cfs of senior water right dedicated instream for Threemile Creek in Wasco County.  Threemile Creek is currently over-allocated leaving the lower 11 miles dry from July to October.  The creek is home to a population of redband trout genetically similar to the redband trout in the Fort Rock Basin that are considered unique by ODFW.

Project Name: Indian Ford Creek Riparian Restoration: Phalarope Phase
Project Summary: This project on Indian Ford Creek within Black Butte Ranch west of Sisters would remove noxious weeds (poison hemlock and yellow flag iris) along the creek and pond for a distance of approximately one half mile.  The area will be planted with wet and obligate wetland plants.  A quarter of mile of new fencing will be installed to connect to existing fencing to exclude livestock from the treated areas.  The total treated area is proposed to be 17.5 acres.

This project north of Powell Butte between Prineville and Redmond would create a pond to capture irrigation tailwater so it can be pumped to a new pivot sprinkler irrigation system.  The owner would purchase the irrigation equipment.  This will result in less water being used than the flood irrigation method now used on the 400 acres and less tailwater leaving the property.

Project Name: Klamath Marsh National Wildlife Refuse River Project
Project Summary: This project would re-establish the historical meander pattern of the Williamson River through the Upper Klamath Marsh.  The river has been straightened and no longer offers connectivity to the lower parts of the refuge and the river as it leaves the marsh to be joined by Spring Creek and the Sprague River.  The 41,000 acre refuge includes 35,000 acres of marsh.  Fifteen thousand acres were dissected by 20 miles of delivery and drainage ditches created in the 1900s for agriculture.  The nine fish barriers in the ditch system will be removed with one diversion remaining that will be screened to prevent fish entrainment.  The ditches will be replaced with nine miles of meandering Williamson River channel that will connect wetland habitats and the floodplain.

Project Name: Hess Wetland Protection and Irrigation Efficiency (Phase II)
Project Summary: This is a piping, irrigation efficiency project on property adjacent to the Sprague River downstream of Beatty in Klamath County.  This is a request for Phase II.  The first phase replaced ditches and flood irrigation with gated pipe to better control irrigation water and reduce overland flow and tailwater going into the Sprague River.  This project would pipe water around a spring and wetland and add gated pipe for pasture areas outside the wetland.

This proposal is to pipe two miles of an eight mile long ditch that provides water to farmers in the Silver Lake basin in Lake County.  The two miles of ditch is estimated to lose 15cfs through leaks.  With the saved water being stored in Thompson Reservoir and a more efficient delivery system, water from irrigation and from Silver Creek will have a more consistent benefit to the Paulina Marsh which is important to wetland birds and wildlife.

This project will evaluate opportunities and technologies that would improve the efficiency and fish passage of an existing irrigation diversion weir on the North Fork Sprague River in the Upper Klamath Basin.  The weir diverts up to 60cfs and serves five large ownerships.  The North Fork Sprague is home to redband trout and ESA listed suckers and bull trout.  The project will look at on-farm irrigation efficiencies with the goal of reducing the amount of water diverted so it would be feasible to install a fish screen.  Meetings will be held with landowners and technical folks to analyze options and to build support for possible future projects that would lead to reconstruction of the weir.

Project Name: Lower Crooked River Riparian Zone Enhancement, Ranch at the Canyons
Project Summary: This project would result in 90% designed plans for riparian restoration and weed treatment for 2.3 miles of the lower Crooked River contiguous to Smith Rocks State Park.  The project will also design improvements to three existing springs and address stream-bank erosion and irrigation tailwater discharge issues.  This work is being done in conjunction with the Ranch assessment of opportunities to improve wildlife habitat on the entire 1,700 acre property.

This project will assess the conditions and opportunities for stream function and condition improvement projects on 18 miles of Fishhole Creek, a tributary to the South Fork Sprague River in the Upper Klamath Basin.  The objective is to identify and prioritize streambank restoration needs and to develop 30% design detail for specific sites.  Also to be studied are barriers to fish passage.  The stream is home to redband trout.  Water temperature and flow modification have been identified as contributing factors for impaired water quality.  In some areas, there has been substantial channel modification.

This project would put one mile of Willow Creek in Jefferson County in the Conservation Reserve Enhancement Program (CREP), develop two off-stream water sources for livestock and cut 1,763 acres of juniper to improve upland range conditions and infiltration.  The ephemeral stream is inhabited with native redband trout.  Willow Creek flows into Lake Simtustus on the Deschutes River between the Pelton and the Round Butte Dams.

This project would modify two low-head concrete irrigation diversion structures to allow up and downstream fish passage and screen the irrigation diversions in Badger Creek just above its confluence with Tygh Creek in Wasco County.  Restored passage will open up 20 miles of habitat in Badger Creek to native redband trout.  Tygh Creek flows into the White River which flows into the Deschutes River but there is a natural barrier that prevents anadromous fish from moving upstream.

This project would install 9,295 feet of 34" HDPE pipe in the Rock Creek Irrigation District's main feed canal.  The project will save 1cfs of 1870 senior water right in Threemile Creek currently being lost in the ditch and .5cfs will be converted to an instream waterright.  The stream is over-appropriated and goes dry below the irrigation diversions in July.  The project is located in the White River watershed of Wasco County.

Project Name: Wetland restoration and the rare Oregon Spotted Frog in the Klamath Basin
Project Summary: This project would build on several years of monitoring Oregon Spotted Frog (OSF) populations at two locations in the Upper Klamath Basin.  The OSF is a State Sensitive-Critical and Candidate for Federal listing species.  The Crane Creek site underwent restoration in 2009 and OSF studies have been on-going and the Jack Creek site is proposed for restoration in 2012.  Pre-treatment monitoring will continue there followed by post-treatment to determine population response to these habitat restoration projects.  Treatment of completing species and OSF response will be monitored as well.  These studies will guide future OSF restoration/recovery efforts.

This project would treat a number of degraded conditions in an entire sub-watershed to the Crooked River about 25 miles east of Prineville.  Four ranches and the BLM would cut 3,000 acres of invasive juniper with approximately 1,600 acres to be have fire re-introduced, 700 acres will be re-seeded, several weed species will be treated on a total of  400 acres with monitoring and additional treatment twice a year for two years, 11 off-stream water developments will be completed, large wood will be placed in the incised channel to affect stream aggradation and the lower portion of the creek channel will be taken from a ditch and restored to its historic dimension pattern and profile.

Project Name: The Dalles Local Wetlands Inventory and Riparian Study
Project Summary: This project would map and describe wetlands in the urban growth boundary of The Dalles.  Wetlands are now threatened by industrial and commercial development.  Upon completion of the inventory, The Dalles will adopt the Local Wetlands Inventory and prepare a Goal 5 protection program.  The Oregon Freshwater Assessment Methodology will be used.

Project Name: Groundwater Footprint in Mud Springs Watershed
Project Summary: This study would attempt to study groundwater and geologic conditions that might be responsible for nitrates entering Mud Springs, a tributary to Trout Creek, an important spawning stream for steelhead in the Deschutes Basin.  Several recent years of water quality testing have not determined the source of nitrates in north Jefferson County.  While it has been assumed they were the result of agricultural practices, it appears there are nitrates inherent in one or more geological layers.  This study would attempt to determine if the geology is the source, instead of agriculture, of the nitrates showing up in springs at the north end of Jefferson County that flow into the Deschutes River and its tributaries.

This project addresses riparian and watershed function on 100 acres of USFS land in the Big Creek watershed near Medical Springs.  The USFS is proposing to treat 50 acres of noxious weeds and improve riparian conditions by providing additional water for livestock and reducing livestock access. Project components include developing three springs at different locations. Other project components include replacing a culvert with a rock ford; installing one-quarter mile of exclosure fencing on both sides of Thorn Creek; placing large woody debris (LWD) with an excavator on one mile of Lick Creek to prevent livestock access to Lick Creek and improving riparian vegetative conditions.  In addition, 750 native deciduous and 750 conifer seedlings will be planted.  Watershed benefits include improved water quality, upland and riparian vegetation, stream complexity, fish habitat and floodplain connectivity. OWEB funds are requested for in-house personnel (37%), contracted services (37%), supplies/materials (17%) and administration (9%).  The USFS and Title II are contributing cost-share.

The Jordan Valley Coordinated Weed Management Area (CWMA) has been working in the upper Owyhee watershed to address noxious weedsin an area encompassing over 4.5 million acres of rangeland.   Invasive species alter hydrologic cycles, increase sediment deposition, erosion and adversely affect other ecosystem processes.  Studies have demonstrated that surface runoff is 56% higher and sediment yield 192% higher on infested sites. Noxious weeds of concern in the Owyhee basin include Russian knapweed, perennial pepperweed (tall whitetop), leafy spurge, Scotch thistle, yellow starthistle and Medusahead rye. Project components include treating 100 acres of leafy spurge, releasing 500,000 leafy spurge (Apthona)beetles on 400 acres of Boulder Creek in the Jordan Basin; inventory and mapping 100,000 acres over the next two years; treating 500 acres of Medusahead; seeding 2,000 acres with native and/or desirable non-native species and initiate an integrated weed management program to manage invasive species within the CWMA.  A coordinator is required to facilitate this diverse group responsible for local weed management, develop common weed management objectives; facilitate effective treatment methods and coordinate weed management activities.  OWEB funds are requested for in-house personnel (65%), contracted services (12%), travel/mileage (6%), seed (5%), outreach (1%) and administration (9%) and monitoring (1%).  Cost-share partners include basin landowners, Malheur County Weed Control, BLM, ODA, ODOT, Oregon Department of State Lands, ODA and the local Sage-Grouse Working Group.

Project Name: East Cow Hollow Water Quality Improvement
Project Summary: Located 11 miles northwest of Adrian, Owyhee Watershed Council (OWC)proposes to convert 25 acres from furrow-flood irrigation to sprinkler pivot. The open-ditch delivery system results in water loss of 30 percent from evaporation and seepage. The project proposes to install 2,800 feet of 8-inch mainline to convert an open delivery ditch to pipeline; 10,880 feet of 4-inch for permanent big guns; 4 full-circle big guns and 2 part-circle big guns to irrigate 25 acres. OWEB funds are requested for project management (3%), contracted services (15%), materials- pipe, bubblers, pumps (72%) and administration (9%).  The landowner is the cost-share partner.

Project Name: Homestead Water Quality Improvement Phase II
Project Summary: This project is located west of Jordan Valley and proposes to convert 180 acres from flood irrigation to sprinkler. Mosquitoes carrying West Nile virus are drawn to ponded water on the fields and have created sage-grouse mortality. In addition, 4 fields covering 190 acres are flood irrigated with an inefficient stair-stepping method which also results in excess ponded water. Project components include installing 1,500 feet of 24-inch 80 lb PVC pipe to replace an earthen delivery ditch;  install 8,680 feet of mainline (10 to 18 inch 80 lb PVC- various lengths) to replace earthen field laterals; install 2,760 feet of 10-inch 100 lb PVC to supply water to the pivot and install  a 1,169-foot pivot to irrigate 108 acres. OWEB funds are requested for project management (1%), contracted services - engineering (2%), materials  pipe, fittings, bubbler, pumps, flowmeter (92%) and administration (4%). The landowner is the cost-share partner.

Located seven miles south of Ironside, this project addresses the lack of available water for livestock and wildlife.
