The landowner is participating in the Sage Grouse Initiative (SGI) to remove juniper on 237 acres. Four springs will be developed with troughs for offstream watering to entice livestock and wildlife to drink away from the riparian area.  Project components include 4 spring developments at different sites; bury 400 feet of 1.5-inch PVC at each site; install 600 feet of fencing at each spring site; plant a seed variety at each spring site conducive to sage-grouse and install a wildlife escape ramp at each trough. OWEB funds are requested for project management (15%), contracted services (25%), materials- fencing, troughs, spring box (46%), mileage (2%) and administration (9%), monitoring (3%).  The landowners, ODFW and NRCS are cost-share partners.

Located in the upper Malheur basin, this project will address the lack of available water for livestock and wildlife.  The landowner is also currently removing 400 acres of juniper.  To further improve upland vegetation, 3 spring sites will be developed to benefit livestock and wildlife.  Project components include 3 spring developments; bury 400 to 600 feet of 1.5-inch PVC at each site; install 600 feet of fencing at each spring site; install troughs equipped with wildlife-escape ramps and plant seed varieties in the spring enclosure conducive to sage-grouse diet. OWEB funds are requested for project management (16%), contracted services (27%), materials- fencing, troughs, spring box (45%), mileage (3%) and administration (9%).  The landowners, ODFW and NRCS are cost-share partners.

Project Name: West Sandhills Allotment Stockwater Restoration Project
Project Summary: The Pueblo Valley in southern Harney County is the location of the West Sandhills 17,976-acre BLM allotment which has 3 non-functioning livestock wells and lacks perennial water for both livestock and wildlife.  The wells are 2.4 miles and could provide water at a reasonable travel distance for livestock and wildlife. The project will install a solar unit at each well to pump water. Wildlife and livestock will benefit by having a dependable source of water throughout the year. OWEB funds are requested for design, travel, inspection, project management (16%), materials (72%), administration (9%) and monitoring (3%). The landowners and BLM will provide cash and in-kind as cost share.

Project Name: Baker/Union County Underproductive Forest Land Reforestation/Restoration Project
Project Summary: Union and Baker counties contain unhealthy forest conditions including inappropriate species mixes and understocked stands resulting from insect and disease outbreaks over the past two decades.  The applicant is proposing to plant 400 acres on 18 different landowners properties to improve long-term forest health and vigor by planting site-specific species to improve upland forest health. Individual site-specific project prescriptions will be written by ODF to optimize long-term forest health benefits and define the scope of work for each landowner.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services - planting costs/related expenses (93%) and administration (7%).  Cost-share partners include ODF and Oregon State University Extension.

The Wallowa Canyonlands partnership (WCP) is a cooperative weed management area formed to protect and restore grasslands of the Lower Snake Basin watershed.  Project components include inventory of approximately 4,000 acres in high-risk areas to identify infestation and treatment areas; conducting ground surveys; apply species-specific herbicides to high-priority noxious weeds on approximately 330 acres; revegetate 180 acres dominated by annual grasses; record site population characteristics such as species, size and density for every site and track population trends for every rush skeletonweed site.  Herbicides will be applied using backpacks, ATVs, horse-mounted sprayers.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (5%), in-house personnel (9%), contracted services (58%), travel (2%), materials (10%), education/outreach (1%), administration (9%). Cost-share partners include various landowners, Nez Perce Tribe, Rocky Mountain Elk Foundation, Weed Board, ODFW Access & Habitat and USFS.

Malheur SWCD proposes to increase the size of a constructed wetland in the Big Bend area south of Adrian.  A previously funded OWEB project constructed a three cell, 13-acre wetland to filter a portion of the Allen Drain before it enters the Snake River.  The current wetland has insufficient capacity to handle all the discharge from the Allen Drain.  The project proposes to add 5 acres of wetland. Project components include constructing a 1200-foot meander with a 2:1 slope and an average width of 55 feet and install a check structure, solid set irrigation system on banks to establish vegetation to control noxious weeds and plant wetland plants. OWEB funds are requested for project management (1%), contracted services - excavation, engineering, earthwork (77%), materials - bubbler, plants, check structures (17%) and administration (5%).  The landowner is the cost-share partner.

Butler Ranches, north of Beulah Reservoir proposes to treat 760 acres of juniper occupying historic sagebrush-steppe rangelands. Sage-grouse leks are identified in this watershed. Project components include juniper removal using a chainsaw - on slopes greater than 15 percent - on 290 acres with the slash lopped and scattered. Slopes less than 15 percent will be mechanically treated with a dozer and the slash machine piled on 470 acres.  In addition, one spring will be developed and piped to a 1,000-gallon trough; a weed management plan will be implemented and 300 acres aerially sprayed for Medusahead rye. OWEB funds are requested for project management (3%), in-house personnel (3%), mileage (2%), contracted services - juniper removal (60%), materials - seed (24%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners are the landowner, ODFW, NRCS and Malheur SWCD.  The landowner will provide juniper cutting and seed the area.

Legacy placer mining in Mormon Basin above Malheur Reservoir is the site where a mining firm proposes to re-mine tailings and after mining, put the stream channel back to its historic location. The applicant is proposing to return the creek to properly functioning condition; stabilize the riparian area with desirable vegetation; excavate 8 to 10 feet of the creek; slope the banks to a 3:1 ratio; plant the upland with native grass and plant 78,000 plants along the streambank.  Approximately 34,580 wetland yards and the riparian area encompassing 211,000 square feet are proposed for treatment. OWEB funds are requested for project management (1%), surveying and design of the affected section of streambanks (6%), mileage (2%), contracted services - grade and shape uplands, creek and riparian area and finish work (90%), materials - willow plantings (3%) and administration (4%).  Miller Mining Inc. is the cost-share partner.

Located southwest of Nyssa, the Malheur SWCD proposes to convert 74 acres from gated-pipe irrigation to sprinkler-pivot and solid-set irrigationn to eliminate irrigation-induced erosion. The project proposes to install 740 feet of 8-inch mainline to replace gated pipe; attach Berkeley pump to the pivot pad; install 1,000 feet of 10-inch pipe for the overflow drain; install 1,281-foot pivot, 6 pivot bridges, 40 pivot gates and a bubbler with screen. OWEB funds are requested for project management (2%), materials - pipe, bubbler, pump - (87%), administration (9%) and monitoring (2%).  The landowner and NRCS are cost-share partners.

The Wilcox Ditch is located west of Haines in the foothills of the Elkhorn Mountains by Rock Creek.  The ditch diverts water from Rock Creek and is situated on steep, forested slopes (up to 70%) and has blown out several times. Technical assistance is sought for guidance on hydrology, water conveyance, irrigation, topography, steep slopes and aquatic systems.  The SWCD is seeking a 60% design to develop a good budget and apply for the required permits. OWEB funds are requested for project management (9%), contracted services (86%) and administration (9%).  The Wilcox Ditch irrigators, Baker Valley SWCD, USFWS and ODFW are cost-share partners.

Medicine Creek, a tributary of Gordon Creek, was channelized many years ago to most likely drain the wet meadow and convert it to agricultural production or pasture. The planning and design phase of the project will need a topographic site survey, channel design, ESA-consultation, cultural resource survey and DSL/COE permitting.  The proposed design solution is to produce a channel design for a sinuous, meandering stream on the surface of the meadow. OWEB funds are requested for contracted services (91%) and administration (9%).  The Grande Ronde Model Watershed Program and the landowner are cost-share partners.

The Cottonwood Ranch in the Pueblo Valley of southern Harney County is proposing a project to address noxious weeds have expanded in recent years. Weed infestation reduces survival rates for native vegetation, increases erosion and soil loss and results in a loss of winter and summer habitat for mule deer and pronghorn antelope. Targeted weeds include Russian knapweed, perennial pepperweed, whitetop and Scotch thistle. The applicant proposes to treat 639 acres; seed the area with a mixture of crested wheatgrass and native seed; construct 5,200 feet of a four-strand, barbed-wire fence to connect to existing fences for improved management and develop a livestock grazing plan. OWEB funds are requested for contracted services - herbicide application (18%), materials- fencing, seed and chemcials (71%), administration (9%) and travel (1%). Cost-share partners include the landowners, ODFW, Harney County Watershed Council and the Harney County Cooperative Weed Management Association.

Harney SWCD is proposing to develop a video to share information about the local watershed efforts and natural resource issues with non-agricultural Oregonians.  Providing that information fulfills a need identified by the Harney Basin Agricultural Water Quality Local Advisory Committee (LAC).  At the last biennial review in December 2009, the LAC expressed a desire to promote the successful restoration efforts and stewardship in Harney County. OWEB funds are requested for project management (41%), contracted services (54%) and administration (%).  Harney County landowners, Harney Cattlewomen and the SWCD are cost-share partners.

Project Name: Finding the Truth in the Juniper Mahogany Conflict
Project Summary: In 2009, the Woodtick effectiveness monitoring project was established to determine the effects of juniper removal on mountain-mahogany and quaking aspen recruitment. The SWCD monitored 23 plots over the last three years.  The initial monitoring project resulted to ascertain why the reproductive capability of mountain-mahogany has been declining. The lack of recruitment could be the result of overgrazing by big game and livestock, lack of disturbance and competition from juniper and conifer encroachment. OWEB funds are requested for contracted services - $5,800 per year for 6 years (94%) and administration (6%).

Project Name: Choirboys Wetland Pond Monitoring Project Phase II
Project Summary: Choirboys Wetland was constructed in 2008 using a design different than other constructed wetlands.  Malheur SWCD proposes to monitor each individual cell to ascertain effectiveness. Cell one is a 4-feet deep sediment pond and collects organic matter and total suspended solids. Cell two is 2- to 4feet deep, the primary filter, is planted with rhizomatous grasses and wetland plants and removes fine sediment and nitrates. Cells 3 and 3a, slow-water ponds, remove nitrites and bacteria.  Cells 4 and 4a are 5- to 7-feet deep and remove nutrients and fine sediment. The final pond is 15-feet deep and removes algae and nutrients. OWEB funds are requested for project managements (8%), in-house personnel (31%), contracted services (lab analysis) 44%, travel (4%) and administration (9%).  The landowners and BOR lab are cost-share partners.

Project Name: Luther Wetland Intensive Monitoring Project - Phase 3
Project Summary: The Luther Wetland was constructed in 2003 by the Malheur SWCD.  This wetland has five cells that drain over 850 acres before it enters the Malheur River.  By monitoring the water quality in each cell in the wetland, the collected data will be used to help design future wetlands in order to ascertain the appropriate depth for the specific purpose of each individual pond.  Currently temperature and flow are measure at the inlet and outlet of the wetland.OWEB funds are requested for project managements (9%), in-house personnel (30%), contracted services (lab analysis) 50%, and administration (9%). The landowner, Idaho Power and BOR lab are cost-share partners.

The project is located eight miles northwest of Riley in the Silver Creek drainage.As Silver Creek enters the valley, it braids into numerous channels and spreads out as much as a mile-wide. The West Fork of Silver Creek crossing needs to accommodate a minimum flow of 1,000 cfs based on a 25-year storm frequency. The other three minor crossings will needs to accommodate 50 cfs combined. Currently, up to 60 cfs (cubic feet per second) flows through an undersized culvert that blocks redband trout migration and has blown out. Proposed project components include three 24-inch culverts installed in the smaller braided channels and prefabricated railroad-car bridge to span the West Fork of Silver Creek. Watershed benefits are improved water quality, fish passage and streambank stability in the Silver Creek drainage. OWEB funds are requested for project oversight (3%), contracted services  installation (31%), materials- pipe- CMP and multi-plate arch (34%), administration (8%) and (1%). Dry Mountain Ranch is the cost-share partner who will provide pit-run rock. Watershed benefits are improved water quality, fish passage and streambank stability in the Silver Creek drainage.

Harney SWCD proposes to treat Medusahead rye, a noxious weed, in an area near Crane, by spot spraying 30 acres with Plateau in the fall and drilling seed with a mixture of crested wheatgrass, perennial rye and bluebunch wheatgrass. Aerial spraying will occur on 433 acres with Plateau and a follow-up treatment conducted. In addtion, 1,800 feet of four-stranded, barbed-wire wildife accessible fencing will be installed to protect seeded areas. A rest-rotation grazing system will be established. Watershed benefits include improved upland vegetation, decreased soil erosion and improved wildlife habitat. OWEB funds are requested project management (5%), contracted services  including aerial herbicide application (41%), materials  seed, herbicide and fencing (34%), and administration (7%).  The landowner, Harney County and NRCS are cost-share participants.

Project Name: Catherine Creek - 37 Stream and Fish Habitat Restoration
Project Summary: Catherine Creek is critical juvenile Chinook salmon winter habitat. Union SWCD is proposing to restorea portion of Catherine Creek by reactivating the historic channel meanders and reconnecting the floodplain. Project components include constructing 1,300 feet of new complex meandering channel and enhance 800 feet of the existing channel; slope the banks to a 3:1 ratio to decrease soil erosion and increase riparian planting area; excavate 2.5 acres of inset floodplain; develop edge habitat; install 9 rock cross vanes, 16 J hooks and 20 large woody debris structures and reconnect two historic oxbows. Watershed benefits are improved riparian vegetation, channel complexity and fisheries habitat.OWEB funds are requested for project management (3%), in-house personnel (3%), contracted services  earthwork, log placement and mobilization (28%), materials (48%), plant material (10%) and administration (8%). Cost-share partners include landowners on both sides of Catherine Creek.

Located 11 miles northwest of Adrian, Owyhee Watershed Council (OWC) is proposing to convert 63 acres from furrow-flood irrigation to sprinkler pivot. The project proposes to install 1,460 feet of 8-inch mainline to convert an open delivery ditch to pipeline; 5,300 feet of 4-inch mainline for the pivot. A 1,084-foot pivot will irrigate 50 acres and fixed sprinklers will irrigate 13 acres.  Improved water quality is the primary watershed benefit. OWEB funds are requested for project management (2%), contracted services (23%), materials- pipe, bubblers, pumps (65%) and administration (9%).  The landowner is the cost-share partner.

The Fire Ridge Water Quality project is located adjacent to the East Cow Hollow and 11 miles northwest of Adrian.  Owyhee Watershed Council (OWC) proposes to convert 35 acres of furrow-flood irrigation to sprinkler-pivot. The project proposes to install 2,320 feet of 6-inch mainline to pipe a wheelline to irrigate 11 acres and install 1,720 feet of 4-inch mainline for 28 big guns to irrigate 24 acres.  OWEB funds are requested for project management/mileage (5%), materials (56%), contracted services (29%) and administration (9%).  The landowner is the cost-share partner.

A project located near Adrian will address seepage from a lateral that is accelerating excess alkalinity. This project will convert 10 acres from furrow to sprinkler irrigation on a 5 percent slope that is annually planted to corn. Project component include installing 1,700 feet of 27-inch pipe to replace the earthen lateral; 1,360 feet of 6-inch mainline; one headwall and a pivot to irrigate 10 acres. Improved water quality is the primary watershed benefit. OWEB funds are requested for project management (2%), contracted services (4%), materials- pipe (84%) and administration (9%).  The landowner and South Board of Control are cost-share partners.  South Board will install the 27-inch lateral.

Project Name: East Cow Hollow Water Quality Improvement
Project Summary: Located 11 miles northwest of Adrian, Owyhee Watershed Council (OWC) is proposing to convert 25 acres from furrow-flood irrigation to sprinkler pivot.  The project proposes to install 2,320 feet of 8-inch mainline to convert an open delivery ditch to pipeline; 1,320 feet of 6-inch for permanent big guns; a 1,280-foot wheelline and an 800-foot wheelline. OWEB funds are requested for project management (1%), contracted services (21%), materials- pipe, electrical and pump (68%) and administration (9%). The landowner is the cost-share partner.

Owyhee Watershed Council (OWC) is proposing to combine five fields to convert 24 acres from furrow-flood irrigation to sprinkler-pivot. Proposed components are installing 200 feet of  6-inch mainline to convert an open ditch to pipe; a 737-foot pivot to irrigate most of the acres and solid-sets in the corners. OWEB funds are requested for project management (3%), contracted services  installation (13%), materials - pumps, electrical, pipe (74%), administration (9%) and monitoring (4%). The landowner is the cost-share partner.

The Malheur and North Fork Malheur River systems contain designated critical habitat for a declining local population of ESA-listed bull trout. ONDA is proposing to construct riparian fences with water gaps that will limit livestock use of the riparian corridor and provide piping, water troughs, headwater boxes and spring protection fencing to provide alternative water sources. OWEB funds are requested for contracted services (100%) of the riparian fencing and spring site construction.  No administration or project overhead was requested.  Cost-share partners include USFS, the Burns-Paiute Tribes and ONDA.

The headwaters of the Middle Fork of the Malheur River contain critical bull trout habitat. Project components include juniper removal on 88 acres- site 1 is 30 acres near the head of the meadow.  The stage 1 juniper will be cut and left in place.  Site 2, stage 2 juniper, is 48 acres located near the mouth of the canyon where Bluebucket leaves the meadow.  Site 3, stage 2 juniper, is 10 acres located above a spring flowing to the east side of the meadow. Approximately 2.85 miles of four-strand, barbed-wire, wildlife-accessible fence installed at three locations.  Also, 500 feet of 1.5-inch pipe installed to move an 8-foot rubber tire trough outside of the riparian area and a rest-rotation grazing system developed. OWEB funds are requested for layout and project management (10%), contracted services (41%), materials (31%), travel (2%), administration (9%) and monitoring (7%). The landowner is the cost-share partner.

An earthen lateral in East Cow Hollow 11 miles northwest of Adrian has excessive evaporative and seepage loss. Malheur SWCD proposes to install 400 feet of 21-inch pipe, 1,220 feet of 18-inch pipe and 60 feet of 15-inch pipe; three turnouts; a self-cleaning screen and a radio telesite to monitor storm events. OWEB funds are requested for project management/engineering oversight (5%), materials- pipe, headwall, screen, telesite (87%) and administration (7%).  OID will install the pipe. The landowner is the cost-share partner.

Located southwest of Nyssa, the Malheur SWCD is proposing to convert 74 acres from gated-pipe irrigation to sprinkler-pivot and solid-set irrigation.  The project proposes to install 740 feet of 8-inch mainline to replace gated pipe; attach a permanent 20 HP Berkeley pump to the pivot pad; install 1,000 feet of 10-inch pipe for the overflow drain; install 1,400 feet of 15-inch drain pipe; install 300 feet of 8-inch to pipe to a field corner and connect to gated pipe; install 1,281-foot pivot, 6 pivot bridges, 18 pivot gates and a bubbler with screen. OWEB funds are requested for project management (2%), materials - pipe, bubbler, pump - (89%), administration (9%) and monitoring (2%). The landowner and NRCS are cost-share partners.

Malheur SWCD and the Vale Oregon Irrigation District (VOID) are replacing an earthen lateral that delivers water to 836 irrigated acres. This project will focus on continuing the the pipeline an additional 9,220 feet.  Malheur SWCD is proposing to install and bed 2,820 feet of 18-inch pipe; 560 feet of 15-inch pipe; 2,480 feet of 12-inch and 3,360 feet of 4-inch to 10-inch pipe. The primary watershed benefit is improved water quality. OWEB funds are requested for project management (1%), engineering (3%), materials (91%) and administration (6%). VOID will install and bed the pipe at a cash value of $103,264 or $11.30 per foot installation.

A 180-acre farm located six miles north of Ontario is currently using flood irrigation. Project components include installing:  2,500 feet of 24-inch pipe in the earthen lateral; 8,940 feet of 12-inch mainline and 1,960 feet of 6 inch mainline to replace the earthen irrigation ditch; 1,800 feet of 4-inch mainline for the wheellines; a 1,080-foot pivot for 97 acres and a 657-foot pivot for 20 acres and two wheellines to irrigate 60 acres. OWEB funds are requested for project management (1%),  materials (94%) and administration (5%). The landowner has significant cash and in-kind cost-share.  The budget also shows that the Owyhee Irrigation District (OID) will install a headgate, but they are not shown as cost-share partners.

An 81-acre farm located eight miles north of Ontario is currently using furrow-flood irrigation. Project components include installing:  1,780 feet of 8-inch pipe for the mainline replacing the ditch; 1,960 feet of 6-inch mainline for the pivots; 28 riser sets to irrigate big guns; an 8-inch flowmeter; 1,269 -foot pivot to irrigate 64 acres and big guns to irrigate 7 acres.  Watershed benefits are improved water quality. OWEB funds are requested for project management (2%), contracted services (9%), materials (79%) and administration (9%).  The landowner has significant cash and in-kind cost-share. The budget also shows that the Owyhee Irrigation District (OID) will install a headgate.

Located four miles southwest of Vale, 130 acres of uneven farmland is separated into eight fields all of which are furrow-irrigated. Project components include installing:  3,160 feet of 18-inch pipe to replace an earthen delivery lateral; 2,640 feet of 12-inch pipe to access the pivot point; headgate to divert water from the buried lateral; overflow device at the point where water is diverted from the open lateral to the buried pipe; screening device; bubbler; flow meter; 1,400 feet of conduit and 1,296-foot pivot. OWEB funds are requested for project management and layout (3%),  materials (91%) and administration (5%).  The landowner has significant cash and in-kind cost-share. Vale Oregon Irrigation District (VOID) will install the 18-inch lateral and headgate.

Project Name: Alder Creek Elimination of Irrigation Return Flow
Project Summary: Malheur Watershed Council proposes to address flood-irrigated pastures located 50 miles north of Vale. Project components include bury 2,100 feet of power line; install 1,600 feet of 10-inch pipe from the existing well pumping station to access the pivot pad; a 5-foot bubbler and 3,400 feet of 8-inch pipe will connect from the bubbler to the 10-inch pipe.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (7%), materials (53%), contracted services (33%) and administration (6%).  The landowner has significant cash and in-kind cost-share.

Malheur Watershed Council proposes to address a flood-irrigated pasture near Jamieson. Willow Creek borders both fields and both ditches run along the creek. Project components include installing 2,200 feet of 6-inch pipe from the pumping station to two pivots; a 4-foot bubbler and screen; power and electrical; 2,250 feet of electrical wire; two 7000-series pivots and four  30-inch ditch crossings to enable the pivots to cross the delivery ditch. OWEB funds are requested for project management and layout (6%), travel (2%), materials (86%) and administration (6%).  The landowner has significant cash and in-kind cost-share.

Harney SWCD and Hines Middles School (HMS) currently have an educational project that provides for three years of field trips to the Northern Great Basin Experimental Range (NGBER) for juniper-canopy related research and data collection. This project proposed to continue the partnership between HMS and WMS.  The main focus for this project will be a trip for HMS to the Willamette Valley.  The targeted audience is the students at HMS.  For two years, 80 students per year (160 total), will travel to the Willamette Valley to analyze the riparian area with the student from WMS.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (8%), contracted services  substitute teachers (10%), travel  2 trips over 2 years to WMS (64%), equipment SMART Board (14%) and administration (4%).  WMS staff, CREST staff, parent volunteers and student fundraising will provide the cost-share.

This project, located in southeast corner of Wheeler County, includes the Mountain Creek and Rock Creek watersheds, both which flow into the John Day River. The condition of streams and ultimately the John Day River, are influenced by the condition of the range and forest upland drainage. Current conditions in these uplands include significant overcrowding of pine and encroachment of Western juniper, when historically a regular fire regime kept those species in check. The project proposed to work with six landowners to pre-commercial thin 660 acres from forest, meadows and rangeland areas. Partners on this project are landowners and Jerome Natural Resource Consultants. OWEB funds were requested for project management (5%), contracted services (92%), fiscal administration (2%), and post implementation status reports (1%).

Project Name: Accessing Industrial Impacts Upper Walla Walla Basin
Project Summary: This technical assistance application would identify sensitive, steep upland areas of the Blue Mountains directly above ESA listed bull trout and steelhead habitat in the South Fork and mainstem Walla Walla River and Couse Creek in Umatilla County. These areas are being considered for extensive industrial development in the form of wind farms. This technical assistance proposal would provide research, ground-truthing and mapping on those areas most vulnerable to erosion by incorporating information on slope, aspect, soil types and vegetation. The resultant document would be made available to Umatilla County, developers, landowners and other entities considering industrial development in the rural countryside above Milton-Freewater. Partners in this endeavor include Umatilla County and the Blue Mountain Alliance. OWEB funds were requested for project management (19%), in-house personnel (40%), contracted services (28%), travel (1%), production (3%), and fiscal administration (9%).

This project is located west of Boardman, south of I-84 along the Columbia River in Morrow County and is in the Lower Umatilla Basin Groundwater Management Area (LUBGWMA). This project proposes to improve water and soil quality in this area by eliminating flood irrigation to the uneven crop and pastureland. Other problems resolved by the implementation of this project include reducing nutrients from agricultural lands leaching into groundwater, eliminating irrigation tailwater from entering the Columbia River and stopping flooding on the adjacent county road. The project will combine laterals 17 & 18 to save an estimated 372 acre-feet of water by converting 8,300 of open, earthen ditch to pipe and replacing 16 individual pumps with one variable speed pump to serve the 16 patrons. Once implemented, irrigators will be required to switch from flood to sprinkler to improve efficiency and management. Partners on this project include the West Extension Irrigation District (WEID) and the Bureau of Reclamation. OWEB funds were requested for pre-implementation (15%), contracted services (8%), travel (1%), supplies/materials (71%), fiscal administration and post implementation status reporting (6%).

Project Name: John Day River Bank Stabilization and Restoration
Project Summary: This project occurs on two different properties: one site on the lower North Fork John Day River and six sites on the mainstem of the John Day River, both located in Grant County. High water events of the past several years have eroded banks and are threatening wetlands, pasturelands, agricultural production lands and the state highway. The continuing erosion is depositing enormous amounts of soil into the river every year, contributing to heightened level of poor water quality standards for turbidity and sediment. The proposed objective of this project is to improve fish habitat while increasing protection to the adjacent property. To achieve this goal, banks will be stabilized by installing juniper root wads, rock barbs and weirs, planting riparian vegetation, and rebuilding eroded banks. At one location, a berm, that protects overflow into an agricultural field, would be extended. Partners on the project include two landowners, NRCS and Monument SWCD. OWEB funds were requested for project management (18%), travel & outreach (<1%), supplies/materials (75%), fiscal administration and post implementation status report (7%).

This project is located outside the town of Monument alongside the North Fork John Day River in Grant County. The current irrigation system is inefficient and uses more water than necessary. The overflow tailwater has potential to carry sediment directly into the North Fork. The proposed solution is to install a subsurface drip irrigation system on 70 acres of organic crops; cutting water use by 50 percent and allowing unused water to stay in the North Fork John Day River. Partners on this project include the property leasee, NRCS and the Monument SWCD. OWEB funds were requested for project management (4%), contracted services (43%), supplies/materials (44%), educational/outreach & post implementation status report (<1%), fiscal administration (9%)

Project Name: Final Rudio Creek Irrigation Efficiency Project
Project Summary: This project is located on Rudio Creek, a significant tributary to the North Fork John Day River, downstream from the town of Monument in Grant County. In January 2010, landowners, land managers, public agencies and local groups established the Rudio Creek Restoration Partnership (Partnership) with the intent of taking a strategic, landscape approach to restoration in the Rudio Creek basin. The Partnership recently was awarded a three-year NRCS Cooperative Conservation Partnership Initiative (CCPI) that would offset some of the cost of implementing the basins planned restoration. This OWEB request seeks to replace a dysfunctional, hand-dug open ditch that has an estimated ditch loss of over 50 percent and replace a rock and dirt push up diversion dam that blocks juvenile salmonid and other aquatic species passage to valuable, upstream cool water refugia. This proposal would replace the rock push-up dam with a fish friendly driven sheet steel diversion, install a headgate and water measuring device, upgrade existing fish screen and convert 7,200 feet of open ditch to pipe. Partners include the landowner, Monument SWCD and NRCS. OWEB funds were requested for project management (3%), contracted services (39%), supplies/materials (49%), travel, education/outreach and post implementation status reports (<1%), fiscal administration (9%).

Project Name: North Fork John Day Juniper Removal Project
Project Summary: The North Fork John Day Watershed Council (NFJDWC) and the Monument SWCD propose to conduct juniper removal on 1,400 acres of private lands throughout the North Fork John Day Watershed in Grant County. This project represents a joint effort between the two organizations to utilize OWEB, USFS Title II and other funding to cost-share juniper removal projects on phase I &II sites. Juniper encroachment is a significant resource problem throughout the North Fork basin. The goal of this project is to be more strategic and focused on juniper treatments. Partners on this project include landowners, USFS Title II funding, Rocky Mountain Elk Foundation, Monument SWCD & NFJDWC. OWEB funds were requested for project management (11%), in-house personnel (3%), contracted services (67%), travel (1%), supplies/materials (9%), fiscal administration (8%), and post implementation status reports (1%).

This project is located west of Boardman, Oregon, along the Columbia River in Morrow County. All project land is within the Lower Umatilla Basin Groundwater Management Area (LUB GWMA). Watershed issues and problems to be addressed include poor water quality and soil quality due to improper application of flood irrigation water to uneven crop and pasture land and an open delivery ditch in very poor condition. The degraded conveyance potentially leaches nutrients to groundwater; carries the irrigation tail water to a nearby wetland and ultimately into the Columbia River. The irrigation ditch, because it is higher than the adjacent County road, routinely floods and causes a safety issue. The 1900's era constructed leaky canal/lateral will be replaced with pressurized or gravity pipe to deliver irrigation water to WEID patrons and 16 individual pumps will be replaced with one main energy-saving pump. All patrons one these two laterals will be required to convert to sprinkler systems, which in turn will conserve water usage as well. Partners include West Extension Irrigation District, Bureau of Reclamation and Bonneville Power Administration. OWEB funds will be used for pre-implementation (5%), in-house personnel (3%), contracted services (3%), travel (1%), supplies/materials (83%), and fiscal administration (5%).

This project is located in Grant County on Rudio Creek, approximately 10 miles southwest of the town of Monument and approximately 1_ miles upstream from the confluence of Rudio Creek and the North Fork John Day River. Rudio Creek is a significant tributary to the North Fork John Day River and provides critical spawning and rearing habitat for Mid-Columbia steelhead. This project has three main components that would enhance stream conditions in Rudio Creek and improve habitat benefiting both fish and wildlife. The first component will address a fish passage obstacle by removing a push-up dam located in Rudio Creek and replace it with a fish-friendly driven sheet piling diversion, along with re-grading the streambed for improved fish movement. The second component is the conversion of 7,900 feet of open irrigation ditch with buried pipe to eliminate water loss along the length of the ditch, eliminate overland return flows, and allow less water to be removed from Rudio Creek. The third component is to rejuvenate a stand of struggling aspen that is adjacent to and immediately uphill from the area of the push-up dam. This will be accomplished through the removal of competing vegetation and the installation of exclusion fencing. Partners involved in this project include landowners, Monument SWCD, NRCS, ODFW, Rocky Mountain Elk Foundation, Blue Mountain Elk Initiative, and the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs (CTWS.) The CTWS will provide a study and comparison of pre-implementation water loss in the irrigation ditch to post-installation flows of the pipeline to document the amount of water saved with the new conveyance system. OWEB funds will be used for pre-implementation (6%), project management (3%), contracted services (38%), supplies/materials (46%), and fiscal administration and post-implementation status report (7%).

These projects are all located in the Sherman County Watersheds. 118,635 feet of terraces and 37 cropland water and sediment control basins will be constructed on unprotected cropland slopes to reduce soil erosion from overland flows. Two grassed waterways will also be installed to convey runoff from terraces, diversions, or other water concentrations without causing soil erosion or flooding. Development of four upland water sources, well developments, and 5,152 feet of fencing will improve livestock distribution and help keep riparian areas healthy. Partners include multiple landowners and the Sherman SWCD. OWEB funds will be used for project management (1%), in-house personnel (4%), contracted services (92%), outreach (<1%), fiscal administration (3%), post-implementation (<1%).

The Heppner-Lexington Conservation Pipeline Project will provide gravity-fed irrigation water to eleven farms in the Willow Creek Valley in Morrow County, Oregon, between Heppner and Lexington. The project site is along Willow Creek on an abandoned railroad bed to which Morrow County reserved an easement when Union Pacific Railroad abandoned the spur line. This project will eliminate the need to run pumps on all but three of the farms, which will still require small booster pumps to reach elevated pivots. There will be two side-by-side pipelines installed, originating at screened diversion structures to deliver water needed by the landowners. The piping project will meet regional objectives of eliminating or substantially reducing energy costs, increasing cropland productivity through an improved delivery system and application efficiency (flow meters to be installed); reducing operation and maintenance costs and reducing water loss through evapotranspiration, thus increasing overall flows in Willow Creek. Decommissioning irrigation wells to benefit ground water and removing obsolete diversion structures to improve fish passage and system connectivity are also objectives of the project. Partners include landowners, NRCS, BPA, ODFW and DEQ. OWEB funds will be used for project management (4%), contracted services & post-implementation status report (1%), supplies/materials (91%), fiscal administration (4%).

This project will address the invasion of Western juniper on the Maxwell Ranch in southwestern Wheeler County. Western juniper has adversely impacted the lands within the project area by outcompeting desirable vegetation, decreasing infiltration, increasing overland flow and allowing noxious weeds, including yellow starthistle and medusahead rye, to invade the sites. The project will remove 855 acres of Western juniper, treat 128 acres of noxious weeds, reseed 200 acres and develop three springs to provide off-channel water for livestock and wildlife. Partners on the project include the landowner and the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs. OWEB funds will be used for contracted services (78%), supplies/materials (14%), fiscal administration (7%), and post-implementation (2%).

Project Name: Broken Spur Ranch Watershed Enhancements - Phase II
Project Summary: The project area (3,000 acres) is located in the Blue Mountains along the headwaters of McKay Creek, a tributary of the Umatilla River in Umatilla County. The McKay Creek watershed, including Sevenmile Creek, supports rainbow and redband trout. Due to a lack of cross fencing and water in the uplands, livestock and big game water in Sevenmile Creek, McKay Creek and associated tributaries, causing sedimentation, potential nitrate inputs, and degraded riparian areas. The proposed solution is to install 10,000 feet of cross fencing and develop three springs as upland water sources. The landowner is the partner on this project. OWEB funds will be used for project management (3%), contracted services (86%), fiscal administration (9%), pre-implementation, travel and post-implementation (2%).

Project Name: East Birch Creek Spawning and Rearing Habitat Improvement
Project Summary: East Birch Creek in Umatilla County is important spawning and rearing habitat for the federally listed Middle Columbia steelhead species, the state listed redband trout, and other native fish species. Natural channel dynamics in East Birch Creek have been "manipulated," creating problems with bank erosion, abnormal channel degrading and aggrading, flooding and sedimentation, and a lack of riparian vegetation. These impacts jeopardize the aquatic habitat necessary for fish reproduction. This proposal is seeking funding to design and analyze alternatives to address the above listed issues on five stream miles in E. Birch Creek. The partners in this project are ODFW and six landowners. OWEB funds will be used for in-house personnel (5%), contracted services (89%), and fiscal administration (6%).

Project Name: Rudio Basin Rapid Watershed Monitoring Project
Project Summary: This rapid whole watershed monitoring proposal is designed for the Rudio Creek basin, located in Grant County. Many disparate monitoring efforts exist today which evaluate outputs rather than ecological outcomes. Local land managers, agency staff and conservation groups have expressed concerns that monitoring data is not readily available; does not communicate with a broad audience; and is not compiled at a scale most useful for land managers' decision making. With the assistance of this grant, Rudio Basin Enhancement Partnership will develop, pilot and implement a rapid, whole watershed monitoring plan which evaluates and reports trend data and cumulative effectiveness of restoration and management on: 1) upland health, 2) hydrologic function, 3) fish and wildlife populations, and 4) economic sustainability on Rudio Creek. Partners on the project include landowners, CTWS, Ecotrust, The Freshwater Trust and NRCS. OWEB funds will be used for project management (53%), in-house personnel (7%), contracted services (22%), travel (5%), supplies/materials (<1%), equipment (4%), and fiscal administration (9%).

Project Name: Lower Bridge Creek-Bear Creek Habitat Water Quality Phase #1
Project Summary: The project is located on Bridge Creek in Wheeler County at the confluence of Bridge Creek and Bear Creek. This is one of only two private in-holdings in the predominantly publicly-owned lower reaches of Bridge Creek. The area of interest contains over 2_ miles of Bridge Creek and _ mile of Bear Creek. Currently, a large portion of Bridge and Bear Creek is not fenced and livestock have access to the stream. The riparian vegetation in these unfenced locations consists primarily of Russian olive and knapweed. There is also a lack of habitat complexity, stream shading, and a high degree of erosion in this reach. This project, the first of several phases, will address the upper most _ mile of Bridge Creek within the project area with invasive species treatment, bank pullbacks, instream bioengineering work, riparian planting, and riparian fencing. An off-stream stockwater system will also be installed to mitigate the loss of stream access. Work will be done to improve separation between the landowner's CAFO and the stream. Partners include the landowner, CTWS, USFWS, and Ecotrust. OWEB funds will be used for project management (5%), contracted services (67%), supplies/materials (18%), fiscal administration (9%), and post-implementation (1%).

The project is located at the base of Dove Meadows on a significant unnamed tributary to Thompson Creek in the Bridge Creek Watershed in Wheeler County. The landowner currently irrigates approximately 65 acres on Dove Meadows with water diverted from Thompson Creek, a tributary to Gable Creek. This irrigation helps to build and maintain the shallow ground aquifer of this meadow. The large natural springs, augmented by the irrigation return at the location create significant year-round flow and wetland that contributes to Thompson Creek. Currently livestock have ready access to these springs for a water source. Juniper has also encroached on the area. This project will fence approximately 10 acres to protect the springs and wetland areas, provide off-stream stockwater, remove encroaching juniper and restore native aspens and other trees to the headwater meadow. The Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs partner with this project. OWEB funds will be used for project management (13%), contracted services (75%), supplies/materials (2%), fiscal administration (9%), and post-implementation (1%).

The project is located on Badger Creek directly below the US Forest Service Boundary on the Ochoco mountain range in Wheeler County. Badger Creek becomes Mountain Creek as it continues towards the John Day River. This is the second highest diversion in the Mountain Creek watershed and was identified as being a barrier during the Mountain Creek Reach Evaluation/Action Plan and was also classified as failing. The failure of the structure would increase erosion along with the severity of the jump. Additionally, the project area is devoid of significant riparian shading. The failing diversion will be replaced with a driven sheet-piling diversion that will provide for fish passage at all flows. The area immediately around the diversion will be fenced and large tree species will be planted in the excluded area. A portion of the open ditch will be replaced with pipe. CTWS is the partner on this project. OWEB funds will be used for project management (13%), contracted services (67%), materials/supplies (9%), fiscal administration (9%), and post-implementation status report (2%).

The project is located on Bridge Creek at the confluence of Bridge Creek and the John Day River in Wheeler County. This is one of only two private in-holdings in the predominantly publicly-owned lower reaches of Bridge Creek. The diversion itself is approximately 500 ft upstream of the confluence. This is the last fish barrier irrigation diversion on the mainstem of Bridge Creek. Legal irrigation withdrawal at the site normally exceeds stream flows and eliminates stream connectivity with the John Day River. The diversion requires annual reconstruction to remaining operational. The project will decommission the diversion and transfer the landowners' water rights to a pump site on the John Day River. The area between the diversion and the confluence will be restored to improve habitat complexity and attractive flow. The outdated, undersized and inefficient irrigation system will be replaced. OWEB funds will be used for project management (4%), contracted services (49%), supplies/materials (39%), fiscal administration (8%), post-implementation (<1%).

The project is located on Girds Creek approximately eight miles upstream from the confluence with the John Day River in Wheeler County, and approximately two miles above the end of the ODFW identified anadromous fish distribution. The project will address poor water quality/quantity inputs in the form of excessive sediment loading during annual dam construction, increased thermal and nutrient loading due to overland flow, and substantially reduced in-stream flow during critical low flow periods.  The pushup diversion will be replaced with a driven sheet-piling diversion with a ramp flume for accurately measuring irrigation withdrawals.  The existing ditch will be replaced with 5000' of PVC pipe with risers.  CTWS partners on this project. OWEB funds will be used for project management (9%), contracted services (42%), supplies/materials (41%), fiscal administration (7%), and post-implementation (1%).

The project is located the Rowe Creek Watershed in Wheeler County. This project partners with over 90% of the landowners in the watershed. Invasive species encroachment in the riparian area, loss of native vegetation, juniper encroachment, historic land use, and historic fire suppression has created a decline in quality upland habitat and reduced water quantity and quality in Rowe Creek. The project will augment a recently awarded NRCS Cooperative Conservation Partnership Initiative grant to restore natural watershed process in the Rowe Creek Watershed. The project will remove 1,500 acres of juniper, range seed 375 acres, restore 100 acres of declining aspen groves, implement 450 acres of prescribed burn, treat 500 acres of invasive species, develop 12 springs and install 15 troughs. Partners include NRCS and multiple landowners. OWEB funds will be used for project management (11%), contracted services (56%), supplies/materials (27%), fiscal administration (5%), and post-implementation (1%).

Project Name: Lower John Day River and Rowe Creek Habitat Restoration
Project Summary: The proposed project will complete 30% design plans to restore floodplain connectivity, habitat complexity, fish passage and riparian vegetation on the Lower John Day River and perennial tributary Rowe Creek, located in Wheeler County. The project site is on private land and is in agricultural production. The Freshwater Trust and partners are working to restore habitat to benefit Mid-Columbia River summer steel head and Mid-Columbia River spring run ESU Chinook at a basin-scale. Partners on the project include CTWS and Belle Vista Foundation. OWEB funds will be used for project management (10%), contracted services (86%), and fiscal administration (5%).

This project is located approximately one mile east of Monument in Grant County. This would be the final phase of a two-phase project converting the remaining portion of an open irrigation ditch to a buried pipeline. The Osburn ditch diverts water out of Cottonwood Creek for irrigation, with water rights equaling 2_ cfs. Cottonwood Creek is one of the largest tributaries to the North Fork John Day River and is a spawning and rearing stream for Mid-Columbia steelhead. During the summer months when stream temperatures rise and can become lethal to fry and juvenile steelhead, irrigation water is removed from the creek for agricultural use at many sites. This project is designed to reduce the amount of water needed to be removed from Cottonwood Creek by eliminating the water loss occurring in the open ditch through evaporation, infiltration, vegetative uptake and leakage. During the first phase, a fish-friendly driven steel sheet piling diversion was installed. This proposed project would complete the conversion of the remaining 4,670 feet of open ditch to a buried pipeline and further reduce the amount of water being lost during conveyance. Estimates are that 30-50% of the water entering the ditch is lost before it reaches the point of use. The CTWS (Confederated Tribes of the Warm Springs) will also conduct a water-loss study of the remaining open irrigation ditch to determine how much water is actually being lost during transport. This water-loss study will be funded by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), with funds distributed from the Pacific Coast Salmon Recovery Fund (PCSRF) to CTWS. Project partners include BPA, CTWS and the Monument SWCD. OWEB funds will be used for project management (3%), contracted services (58%), supplies/materials (29%), fiscal administration (9%), and post-implementation (1%).

Grantee: Upper South Fork John Day WC
Project Summary: This monitoring proposal would be done in the Upper South Fork John Day River basin in Grant County. The activities described would build upon prior monitoring, using existing monitoring resources where available and add monitoring sites to fill the data gaps identified in the Council's 2003 Watershed Assessment. The ultimate goal would be to evaluate changes and trends in the areas natural resource condition. The proposal includes collaborating with numerous partners including ODFW, CTWS, USFS, ORS and private landowners. OWEB funds will be used for project management (9%), in-house personnel (76%), travel (3%), supplies/materials (2%), and equipment (10%).

Grantee: Upper South Fork John Day WC
Project Summary: The projects proposed in this application have been identified as "early action" implementation items within the Council's Upland Initiative, which promotes watershed health from a holistic and landscape perspective with an emphasis on upland condition in the Upper South Fork John Day River basin in Grant County. While the scope of the Council's Upland Initiative is the entire upper South Fork John Day River watershed, the early implementation projects are limited to private lands. The project was designed to improve conditions for two indicator species/habitats: Aspen and Mule Deer. The project components included five wildlife water developments, juniper removal from 20 acres of drainages immediately upstream from each water development (100 ac total), enhancement of 50 acres of Mountain Mahogany/Bitterbrush stands, enhancement of 50 acres of aspen stands, and planting green forage on 100 acres with wildlife-preferred seeding. Partners on this project include five landowners, the John Day Basin Resource Center, ODFW and the Upper South Fork John Day Watershed Council. OWEB funds will be used for pre-implementation (2%), project management (15%), contracted services (78%), travel (1%), outreach (<1%), fiscal administration (2%), post-implementation (2%).

In this Restoration proposal, a contractor is working with the leadership of the Quiet Water Homeowners Association on a restoration plan for the riparian areas of a property located on the north bank of the Yachats River in the Yachats city limits. The plan includes bank re-shaping, manually removing invasive plant species, planting a variety of native tree and shrub species, installing protective wire fencing to protect the new plantings from beaver and deer, and conducting two years of release and establishment work. OWEB funds will be used for materials, labor, tree release, travel, project management and administration.

In this TA application, the Council is proposing to hire a design engineer with expertise in gravel roads to identify road features prone to failure; unstable road shoulders and cut banks, and chronic stream adjacent sediment sources on the Schooner Creek county road. The design engineer would develop a gravel road plan that would provide stabilization options to address road fill that could fail and fall into Schooner Creek; identify cut banks that could fail and plug ditches or slide onto the road surface; and provide alternatives to cross drains that currently deliver ditch runoff directly to Schooner Creek. The gravel road plan would then be provided to the Lincoln County Public Works Department and the Council would work with the county to implement the road maintenance plan. Partners include Lincoln County, Siuslaw National Forest and Lincoln City. OWEB funds would be used for the design engineer, project management, administration, travel and production.

This proposal seeks funding to help address multiple WQ issues by closing or limiting vehicular access into roughly seven miles of the riparian area of the Kilchis River in Tillamook County. Pedestrian access to the river will continue to be allowed. The project will address 12 sites along roughly 7 road miles, beginning at the MP 2.2 in the County Park property and ending at MP 9.2 in the State Forest. Vehicle limiting activities including some combination of boulder placements and tank trap development would occur at the sites and some sites would have the user created road ripped and the scarified roadbed planted with native shrub and tree species. Partners in the project include the Tillamook Bay Watershed Council, ODF, and the Northwest Oregon Restoration Partnership. OWEB funds are budgeted for contracted services, project management and a combination of administration and post implementation status reporting.

In this TA application, the Siuslaw SWCD is working with the furthest upstream agricultural landowner on mainstem Fiddle Creek, in the Siltcoos Lake basin, and an industrial timber company that owns most of the land of Morris Creek, a tributary which enters Fiddle Creek in the lower portion of the agricultural landowners property. The project would look at a variety of restoration possibilities on the two properties including: re-contouring of failing streambanks (ag-land); removal of invasive blackberries and other invasive plants (both properties); placement of large wood (both properties); development of off-channel habitat by re-connecting several intermittent tributaries to the mainstem (ag-land); removal and replacement of a culvert (timber land); consideration of road abandonment (timber land); and native plant establishment (both properties). Partners in the project would include ODFW, USFS, Siuslaw Watershed Council, Roseburg Lumber Products and the Yager family. The majority of OWEB funds would be used to hire River Design Group to develop restoration options and designs, the remainder will be used for project management and administration.

In this application the Alsea Watershed Council would improve conditions along approximately 500 feet of Lobster Creek upstream of a Benton County bridge and approximately 2,600 feet of Preacher Creek by the placement or embedment of approximately 90 pieces of large wood and the construction of three rock weirs intended to reduce velocity, encourage deposition and minimize bank erosion. Preacher Creek is a tributary of Lobster Creek. Lobster Creek is a significant tributary of Fiver Rivers, itself a triubutary of the Alsea River, entering at RM 20. Eroding stream banks would be pulled back, recontoured and planted with native shrubs and trees and livestock exclusion fencing would be installed. Partners in the project include the landowners, USFS, ODFW, BLM, Izaak Walton League, Davis Forest Management, JD McGee, Inc and King Silver. OWEB funds are budgeted for contracted services, supplies, project management and administration.

In this proposal, the Council, working with the landowner and a variety of partners, seeks funding to develop a plan for the wetland/pond, riparian area and associated floodplains of the Carmichael property on the mainstem Nehalem River at RM 41. The plan would enlarge the existing wetted areas and develop a comprehensive monitoring plan for the restored area. Deliverables include six test pits dug to determine the level of groundwater in the relic oxbow area, a LIDAR analysis, an excavation plan, a construction plan with cost estimates, a planting plan, a monitoring plan, and the landowners enrollment in the Wetland Reserve Program. Partners include the landowner, NRCS, ODFW, DEQ, ODF and Carex Consulting. OWEB funds will be used for contracted services, project management, in-house restoration staff, administration, and monitoring.

Project Name: Rock Creek - LFA - Outreach/Design/Plan - Phase I
Project Summary: In this Technical Assistance application, the Upper Nehalem Watershed Council is proposing to hire several classes of restoration professionals to provide the design and layout necessary to implement the highest priority recommendations from the Rock Creek Limiting Factors Analysis process. Rock Creek is a major tibutary of the upper Nehalem, entering at RM 91. Designs to be developed will address riparian plantings, large wood placements, off-channel habitat creation and outreach-to-landowner needs.  Partners with the Council in the project include ODFW, DEQ, the Columbia SWCD, and landowners Stimson Timber, Longview Timber and ODF. OWEB funds will be used for contracted services, project management  and administration.

This proposal would continue and expand upon a project that has been successful in the region over the course of the last thirteen years. The project entails seizing opportunities to collect whole trees, logs and other materials for restoration activities, free of charge from public and private properties, made available through storm events and land management activities (road building and/or land clearing). In addition, the project includes the ability to use a portion of the funds for the purchase of large logs from the regions timber companies at bargain rates, logs the timber companies would otherwise chip for pulp material. The expenses of this style of log salvage project come from either the purchase of the logs from the timber companies or the need to collect donated materials in a timely manner and transport them to a restoration project or storage site for use at another time, when additional transport costs would be expected to accrue. Partners in the project are expected to be USFS, ODFW, ODF, Plum Creek Timber, Forest Capital Partners Inc, and private landowners. OWEB funds are budgeted for log loading and hauling, bargain log purchase, administration and project management.

This project would take place in the Salmonberry River, a large tributary of the lower Nehalem River. The intent of the project is to quantify the distribution and abundance of juvenile coho, chinook, steelhead and resident rainbow and cutthroat trout throughout the entire extent of the Salmonberry Rivers known anadromous salmonid distribution.. The project would occur during summer low flow regimes over the course of two years. The Association of NW Steelheaders plans to contract with Bio-Surveys LLC to implement a Rapid Bio-Assessment (RBA) of the Salmonberry basin in 2013 and 2014. An RBA survey snorkels every 5th pool from the rivers mouth to the end of salmonid distribution, and all juvenile salmonids are counted and identified according to species. The results of the surveys could be used to help guide future restoration and management actions.

Project Name: Grant Creek Stream and Wetland Restoration
Project Summary: In this application, the Siuslaw Soil & Water Conservation District is working with a landowner on Grant Creek, a tributary of Maple Creek in the Tahkenitch Lake watershed, on a restoration project focused on the lower reaches of the landowners property. A variety of activities are proposed including: 1) replacing two undersized culverts (16 and 36) passing different tributaries under the small farm road with culverts sized correctly for fish passage; 2) placing fifteen conifer logs with rootwads in a series of five structures in the channelized reach of stream; 3) treating roughly 6 acres of the valley floor by mowing and mulching down to mineral soil the infestation of reed canary grass and subsequently planting the area  heavily with native willows and; 4) planting a _ acre wetland with native grasses, sedges and rushes.

This Siuslaw Watershed Council proposal would continue a project that has been useful in the Siuslaw River basin over the course of the last eleven years. The previous years projects took advantage of opportunities to collect whole trees, logs and other materials for restoration activities, free of charge, from public and private properties. The materials were made available through storm events and land management activities (road building and/or land clearing).  Project expenses come from the need to collect the materials in a timely manner and transport them either to a restoration project site or to a storage site for use at another time. This new proposal would follow the previous template, but add the ability to purchase materials when necessary.

In 2003, the USFS Siuslaw National Forest (SNF), with assistance from Western Rivers Conservancy, purchased 640 acres of primarily valley bottom of Fivemile and Bell Creeks watershed. In May 2011, the Siuslaw Watershed Council (Council), partnering with the SNF, Ecotrust, the Siuslaw SWCD and the Siuslaw Institute began implementation of a multiple phase restoration plan for the property. In this application, the Council, working with the same partners as in Phase I, seeks funding to begin Phase II activities that will include: helicopter wood placement of mature trees, excavator placement of stockpiled plantation trees, regrading and stream reconstruction of upper Bell Creek, and the continuation of riparian and wetland native plant reestablishment.

Project Name: Fiddle Creek Road Culvert Replacerment MP 0.09
Project Summary: Young Creek is a small perennial tributary of Fiddle Creek, a significant tributary to Siltcoos Lake. Lane County Road #533600 crosses Young Creek approximately 320 feet north of its confluence with Fiddle Creek through an undersized 36 diameter culvert with an outlet drop of several feet. In this proposal, Lane County is requesting funding to replace the existing undersized fish passage barrier culvert with a 108 by 60 ft long corrugated metal pipe culvert that will allow unrestricted fish passage.

Project Name: Spawning Salmon Fieldtrips: a hook for adult learning
Project Summary: The MidCoast Watersheds Council (Council) is proposing a rather unique two-year Outreach project designed to target local government officials, landowners, public works employees, service groups and college students in Lincoln and western Lane counties. Using the hook of field trips to local area streams to see salmon spawning, the Council intends to showcase habitat conservation and restoration projects, as well as water quality, floodplain interaction benefits, beaver importance and other watershed health related topics linked to the specific field trip sites. Discussion at the sites will allow participants to understand habitat conservation activities in terms of both tangible ecological and economic benefits.

Project Name: Five Rivers Subbasin Restoration LFA Prescriptions Phase
Project Summary: In this application, the MidCoast Watershed Council is seeking funding to implement a multiple activity, multiple landowner restoration project developed as a result of the previously implemented and OWEB funded Limiting Factors Analysis and Outreach projects. Activities involved will include: replacement of culverts on two properties, riparian planting on five different properties, placement of large wood instream structures on three properties and restoring a forage platform (heavy willow planting) for the recolonization of beavers on multiple sites.

The Mid Coast Watershed Council is one of the stakeholders in DEQs  new Implementation Ready TMDL process and in this application the Council is proposing to address one of the data gaps identified in that process, specifically fine sediment delivery to the rivers from the public and private roads. The end product of the project would be a report that would detail the propensity for chronic sediment delivery or road failure, road segment by road segment, and categorize the segments as high, medium, or low propensity/risk for public and agricultural roads in the Big Elk sub-basin. The report would be used to aid DEQ in informing TMDL implementation priorities and would hopefully be used by agencies and landowners that manage the different roads to develop practices and/or restoration activities to reduce the amount of fine sediment delivered from the roads into the streams.

Project Name: Side Channel Reconnection at Coyote Trails' Jefferson Nature Center
Project Summary: This is a type I Technical Assistance proposal. The project proposes to prepare a conceptual solution for review, and subsequently generate constructible, stamped technical plans and specifications to open a historic side channel on Bear Creek which has been blocked by gravel mining operations since the 1960s.

The Applegate Partnership and Watershed Council propose to restore stream habitat along 1.8 privately owned miles of Thompson Creek, an Applegate River tributary. Invasive species will be removed. Armenian blackberry competes with native vegetation and obscures stream channel on approximately 1.2 of 1.8 stream miles.

This is a type II Technical Assistance proposal. The project proposes to identify lands where restoration work is needed and recruit landowners to participate in restoration activities in the Deer Creek watershed. Deer Creek is a 6th  Field watershed located in southern Douglas County within the Lower South Umpqua basin.

This is a type II Technical Assistance proposal. This project seeks funding to conduct landowner outreach, perform site specific analysis of the top 101 anadromous migration barriers in the Umpqua watershed and then prioritize them according to restoration potential.

Project Name: Applegate Watershed Fish Barrier Assessment & Action Plan
Project Summary: This is a type II Technical Assistance proposal. The project proposes to conduct an assessment of fish passage barriers in the Applegate River watershed located in the Rogue River basin.
This is a type II Technical Assistance proposal. The project proposes to develop a long-term riparian vegetation management plan for the main stem of Williams Creek located in the Rogue River basin.

Project Name: Applegate WS LiDAR Modeling Completion Project
Project Summary: This is a type II Technical Assistance proposal. This project proposes to support the completion of the LiDAR dataset in the Applegate River watershed located in the Rogue River basin.

Project Name: Tenmile Lakes Watershed Stream flow and Weather Monitoring
Project Summary: This proposal requests funding for two years to install and maintain two stream gaging and two weather stations in the Big and Johnson Creek sub basins as well as South Tenmile Lake. The need for this data is identified in the Tenmile Lakes TMDL and associated Water Quality Implementation Plan (ODEQ 2007).

CThe "North Curry Coho Restoration 2013" project will take place along four riparian locations on Bethel, Willow and Crystal Creeks.urry SWCD is proposing to restore and protect riparian areas along 3.12 stream miles for a total of 30.4 acres through treatment of noxious vegetation, the planting native hardwoods, conifers and shrubs  and  maintenance on 5,000 feet of fencing designed for livestock exclusion.

Project Name: Little Butte Creek Surface Water Quality Monitoring Project
Project Summary: The project proposes to install and operate a network of eight real-time water quality stations within the Little Butte Creek watershed. This network will continuously monitor stream flow, temperature, dissolved oxygen, turbidity, pH, and specific conductance. There are many restoration projects and activities underway, proposed or recently completed to improve water quality and stream flows in the Little Butte Creek watershed. Monitoring is needed to determine the effectiveness and improvements to water quality and quantity and habitat restoration.

Project Name: Whetstone Creek Restoration and Reed Canary Grass Demonstration Project
Project Summary: Whetstone Creek is a tributary of the Rogue River that drains the Whetstone Industrial Park and urbanized areas of White City before meeting the Rogue River at river mile 128.5. The project proposes to mechanically remove blackberry and other nonnative vegetation on 3.5 acres and then plant the area with native vegetation.  Additionally, the applicant would establish eight paired canary reed grass eradication demonstration sites on 1.8 acres of riparian wetland area.
This is a type II Technical Assistance proposal. The project proposes to develop a long-term riparian vegetation management plan for the main stem of Williams Creek located in the Rogue River basin.

The goals and purpose of the Seven Basins Youth project is to involve local youth in hands on monitoring, stewardship and restoration activities to increase understanding of watershed function, fish habitat and expose students to natural resources careers. They will engage in activities that will expose them ecological issues and allow them to participate in developing, planning and implementing projects that address those issues.

Applegate & Rogue Valley students (K-12), teachers, parents, farmers, ranchers, and community members will gain exposure to the Healthy Watershed program and curriculum through a partnership between the Applegate based Cultivating Healthy Watersheds Program and the Rogue Valley Farm to School program. This project will increase understanding of why healthy streams are critical to salmon and salmon habitat. The project will demonstrate farm and upland management techniques that protect streams.

Project Name: Little Butte Creek Water Quality Outreach
Project Summary: The Little Butte Creek Water Quality Outreach will target private landowners and the community to inform, train, and implement on the ground water quality improvements in the Little Butte Creek watershed. Activities will include tours, trainings, workshops, and special events that showcase equipment and methods to reduce bacteria into local tributaries. In addition, there will be workshops in the removal of invasive species and the strategies for successful riparian planting

Curtis Creek is one of the main tributaries in the Upper Elk Creek watershed located in the Umpqua River basin. The watershed provides important spawning and rearing habitat for coho and other salmonids. Past land use practices have degraded much of the habitat in the watershed. The applicant is proposing to address conditions in phases. Phase I will place approximately 24 large logs and 280 large boulders in more than one mile of Curtis and Thief Creek.

Project Name: Deer Creek Streamflow, Channel, and Floodplain Restoration - Phase I
Project Summary: The project proposes to improve summer instream water flows and instream and riparian habitats along a two-mile section of Deer Creek, a tributary to the Illinois River in the Rogue River watershed. The project proposes to transferring 3.2 cfs of water rights to a groundwater point of appropriation approximately two miles downstream, Project components include design of a downstream groundwater withdrawal system to satisfy existing water right; the drilling and casing of multiple wells at the new Point of Appropriation; and installation of irrigation system. Additional instream habitat structures will be created through placement of large wood and four acres of riparian area will be planted.

Project Name: Williams River Habitat Improvements: End of the Line
Project Summary: The applicant proposes to treat the uppermost and last 7.25 miles of the Weyerhaeuser 5000 road in the Williams River sub-basin of the Coos River watershed by installing 72 additional cross-drain culverts, replacing 15 undersized cross-drain culverts, and replacing 14 undersized stream crossings.

The applicant proposes to place large wood at approximately twenty sites using 73 logs, 7 whole  trees (logs with root wads) and 30 root wads in one mile of Joe's Creek. Joes Creek is a tributary to the upper West Fork Millicoma River.

Project Name: Channel Processes in Tyee Sandstone of the Coos Watershed
Project Summary: This is a type II Technical Assistance proposal. This project will build on Aquatic Habitat Inventories in the Coos watershed to identify geomorphic considerations for restoration project designs in Tyee Sandstone. Tyee Sandstone belt present unique challenges for successful watershed restoration: hills are landslide prone, rocks highly erodible, and gravels deteriorate into sand rapidly as they're moved within the stream. Technical assistance is needed to better understand these natural processes, how they are influenced various types of land uses and restoration projects

This project is located in Sullivan Gulch located in theSixes River estuary, on Cape Blanco State Park property. Sullivan Gulch is a 385 acre sub-watershed of the Sixes that enters the estuary.The project is  proposing approximately 4,200 ft of new stream channel  be constructed within the contemporary floodplain, create four backwater areas to provide habitat for fish, amphibians, and birds. place approximately 80 wood structures throughout the new Sullivan Gulch and tributary channels; and in the backwater areas. Additionally, three bridges will be installed to provide livestock and vehicle access over stream and slough channels. Following construction the perimeter of the project area and the interior terrace pastures will be fenced from livestock. Inundated wetland habitat will be replanted with vegetation mats salvaged during construction, and with plugs and/or locally harvested stock; seeding will also occur. Outside the area of inundation native trees and shrubs will be planted.

Project Name: Gold Ray Dam Removal Monitoring Program
Project Summary: This proposal would continue post-dam removal monitoring for approximately two years (spring of 2014 through December 2015). Project goals include the monitoring of pre and post-dam removal effects to determine changes in habitat conditions, such as channel morphology, sediment movement, hydrology, riparian vegetation, associated wetlands and water quality, as well as, biological communities, instream, such as fish assemblage, distribution, and timing and benthic invertebrates; and in the aquatic/upland interface, bird abundance and composition.

Project Name: Jackson Creek Fish Passage Restoration- Hanley Road Culvert
Project Summary: This is a Type I proposal. The applicant proposes to design a solution to the fish passage barrier on Jackson Creek at Hanley Road. Jackson Creek is a tributary to Bear Creek in the Rogue River watershed. The Hanley Road culvert is a complete passage barrier to fish migration in Jackson Creek including steel head and coho.

This project will occur at three schools that are within walking distance to a publicly-accessible stream. Candidate schools include: St. Paul Lutheran Church and School (Roseburg), Umpqua Valley Christian School (Roseburg), Glide Elementary, Elkton Grade School, Glendale Elementary, and Days Creek Charter School. The project will engage K-8 youth and teachers who have a low to moderate understanding about salmonids and their habitat needs, specifically water quality.  The applicant will address this need by incorporating ODFW's Fish Eggs to Fry program in conjunction with field monitoring into three classrooms.

Project Name: River View Natural Area Restoration Project
Project Summary: River View Natural Area (RVNA), located in southwest Portland, is one of the largest contiguous forested parcels in the City of Portland, connecting Forest Park to the north, Tryon State Natural Area to the south and the Willamette River to the east.
