Under private ownership until 2011, it was logged in the 1800''s and 1950''s. For the last 60 years, the property was subject to neglect and vulnerable to development. In July 2011, the City of Portland, in partnership with Metro and Trust for Public Land, acquired the 146-acre RVNA, which comprises approximately half the forest canopy in the 350-acre Riverview subwatershed of the lower Willamette Watershed. It is one of the largest single natural area acquisitions in the Citys history. The applicant proposes to control invasives on all 146 acres and to establish native plants. Partners include community volunteers and Lewis and Clark. OWEB funds will be used principally for contracted services and supplies and materials.

Project Name: Smith and Bybee Wetlands Bottomland Forest Restoration
Project Summary: This bottomland forest restoration project at Smith and Bybee Wetlands in north Portland will address water quality, invasive species, and habitat alteration issues. The applicant proposes to replace large stands of reed canary grass in two wetland areas with approximately 90,000 native woody plants. The total project area is about 80 acres. OWEB funds are requested for two years of site preparation, plant materials (including a grow-out contract for a locally adapted ecotype of Oregon ash), and plant installation. OWEB funds are also requested for three years of annual treatments to ensure plant establishment; Metro will fully fund up to an additional two years of annual treatments as needed for the plants to become free to grow. When they are mature, the trees and shrubs will provide shade to improve summer water temperatures and reduce much of the current reed canary grass cover. Leaf litter from the trees will provide nutrients to the wetland. The restored habitat patches will knit together fragmented habitats and wildlife corridors in the natural area.

The area surrounding the confluence of Hogan Creek (a perennial tributary) and Johnson Creek in Gresham provides some of the best habitat in the Johnson Creek watershed, but is still hampered by invasive plant species. Armenian blackberry and reed canary grass suppress native vegetation on the site and degrade the function of wetland and wet meadow complexes (one on either side of Johnson Creek). The project will enhance the entire 30-acre parcel surrounding the confluence by controlling invasive plants in upland forest, along a half-mile of riparian area, and within an acre of wetlands. The project will also install appropriate native vegetation to supplement and improve existing native flora. OWEB funds will be used to pay contract crews to remove and control invasive plants and to purchase and install native plants. The City of Gresham is partnering on the project.

Project Name: Greater Forest Park Conservation Initiative Master Plan
Project Summary: Forest Park is a 5,200-acre, city-owned, mixed-conifer forest covering eight miles of the eastern slope of the Tualatin Mountains and overlooking the Willamette River and Multnomah Channel. Despite the number of public and private agencies conducting habitat restoration work in the area, significant areas of Forest Park and the more than 10,000-acre Greater Forest Park region beyond remain threatened by a suite of invasives. Trout-bearing streams and wildlife corridors linking the park to the Oregon Coast Range are also in jeopardy. This proposed technical assistance activity is to retain consultants, researchers, technical writers and other professionals to assist the applicant and its partners (including Portland Parks and Recreation, West Multnomah Soil & Water Conservation District, Metro, and others) to develop a comprehensive plan to significantly reduce this threat to the habitat and water quality of Greater Forest Park. OWEB funds will be used principally for contracted services.

Project Name: Hobart Natural Area/Bradshaw's lomatium Management Plan
Project Summary: Willamette Valley prairie is one of the most endangered habitats in Oregon, and as such, is home to many rare species, including the state and federally listed Bradshaw's lomatium. The Hobart Natural Area in Sweet Home, Oregon, contains a 15-acre wetland that hosts one of the few populations of Bradshaw's lomatium left in the Willamette Valley. The wetland area (and the Bradshaw's lomatium population) has been impacted by non-native vegetation, woody plant encroachment, and illegal vehicle usage. The applicant proposes to develop a management plan for this site, improve creek and wetland function, enhance Bradshaw's lomatium habitat, and augment the population of this listed species within the natural area in an effort to help meet recovery objectives. Effectiveness monitoring will assess creek health, plant community composition, and establishment of introduced Bradshaw's lomatium. OWEB funds will be used for creek and wetland restoration activities; Bradshaw's lomatium seed collection, cultivation, introduction and monitoring; installation of fencing and/or boulders to restrict vehicle access. Partners include the South Santiam Watershed and Youth Watershed Councils, Institute for Applied Ecology, ODA, and USFWS.

The Turtle Ponds Restoration Project is located on 1,760 acre Government Island which lies east of Portland, Oregon in the Columbia River between river miles 111 and 117. The applicant proposes to restore native vegetation on 11 acres adjacent to a series of small, year-round ponds located in the interior of the island. These ponds and surrounding uplands provide habitat for a diversity of wildlife species, including western painted turtle and northern red-legged frog, both of which are identified as Oregon Conservation Strategy species of concern in the Willamette Valley Ecoregion.  The project area is heavily infested with Himalayan blackberry, and to a lesser extent, reed canary grass, which are out-competing native shrubs, grasses, and forbs and spreading to nearby less-impacted habitats. The applicant will control invasive weeds throughout the project area, plant one acre of native shrubs around the margins of two ponds, and plant native forbs and grasses on the remaining 10 acres. OWEB funds will be used for project management, contract labor, equipment rental, and the purchase of native shrubs and seed mix. Partners include the Port of Portland, OPRD and ODFW.

Mosby Creek in the Coast Fork Willamette Watershed is a free-flowing, Cascade-influenced stream with historic spring Chinook use. However, it is currently impaired by a bedrock-dominated channel with little gravel suitable for salmon spawning, few deep pools for adult holding/juvenile rearing, and high water temperatures during summer. A lack of large wood was identified in the 2008 ODFW Aquatic Inventory (AQI), but the flashy flows of this large stream necessitate the use of boulders and boulder structures to create a stream structure that can withstand mainstem flows. This Phase II funding request will expand on a successful effort in spring 2011 that added six weirs and other structures in Upper Mosby Creek to improve channel conditions for spring Chinook and cutthroat trout. The project will install an additional five channel spanning weirs and other habitat structures. These structures will: 1) retain and sort gravels; 2) increase channel complexity and hydraulic diversity; 3) increase bedload; and 4) improve hyporheic flow, possibly lowering stream temperatures. Effectiveness monitoring will be conducted using OWEB funds, volunteers, and strong support from Springfield ODFW. Partners include ODFW, BLM, NCASI, and Weyerhaeuser, which is providing a strong match of supplies. OWEB funds will be used for contracted services, materials, project management, and administration.

Project Name: Dart Creek Fish Passage Improvement Project
Project Summary: The project will occur on Dart Creek, a tributary to Milton Creek, which in turn, flows into Scappoose Bay. The applicant proposes to use OWEB funds to contract for the design of four crossings on Dart Creek to replace culverts that are partial or complete barriers to fish passage. The project will complement prior culvert replacement work on neighboring creeks in the Milton Creek subwatershed. The project includes one culvert on private property and three county road crossings. Partners include ODFW and Lower Columbia Engineering. OWEB funds will be used primarily for project management, contracted services, and project administration and reporting.

Two, 3-foot diameter, perched side-by-side culverts provide the forest road crossing on Hancock Creek, a tributary of Woodcock Creek in the Milk Creek drainage of the Molalla River Watershed, The four-foot drop from the outfall of the two culverts creates a barrier to fish passage, Each culvert is undersized and frequently blocked by logs causing the stream to flow over the road during 50-year flood events, The solution is to replace the culverts with a clear span bridge. Replacing the culverts will improve stream process and function, reduce potential road sediments from entering the stream, and open approximately 3.7 miles of spawning and rearing habitat for native winter steelhead, native cutthroat trout, coastal cutthroat trout, Pacific and brook lamprey, and possibly Coho and Chinook salmon. Partners include landowner Graves Trinity, LLC, ODFW and ODF. OWEB funds will be used for contracted services and fiscal administration.

Project Name: Wapato Marsh Restoration Project at Jackson Bottom Wetlands Preserve
Project Summary: The project is located at Jackson Bottom Wetland in Hillsboro. Open to the public, the marsh is important to wildlife, but is severely degraded and suffering from altered hydrology and massive infestations of reed canary grass. This project will restore the natural hydrology and native vegetation communities to 140 acres of floodplain wetlands at Jackson Bottom. Hydrology will be restored by removing drainage structures and creating low-profile cells to trap and hold floodwaters. Native vegetation will be restored using an aggressive restoration technique that depends on intensive site preparation and high-density planting and seeding of native vegetation to prevent re-invasion of canary grass. OWEB funds will be used to purchase a portion of the native plant materials (native wetland seed) necessary for the project's success, and to pay for a portion of restoration activities and five years of plant establishment. Partners include Clean Water Services, Ducks Unlimited, Big Trees Today, PGE, City of Hillsboro, and Metro.

Project Name: Lower Sandy River Restoration Implementation Phase 2 - Camp Collins
Project Summary: The Sandy River Basin Watershed Council (SRBWC) and its partners seek to restore water quality and aquatic habitat in the lower Sandy River close to the Portland metropolitan area. The project will eventually implement up to five phases of prioritized restoration within the eight-mile reach of the Sandy River from river mile 6 at Dabney State Park upstream to Oxbow Regional Park. This second phase project, at Camp Collins, includes the following project elements: reactivation and extension of the seasonality of surface flow to 3,000 feet of side channel; enhancement of the historic channel with five engineered log jams; enhancement of the channel alcove; and restoration of vegetation over 101 acres of adjacent riparian, floodplain, and upland habitat. Instream measures will occur in YMCA's Camp Collins, adjacent Metros Oxbow Regional Park, both of which offer ready public education opportunities. Revegetation measures will be spread between multiple private and publicly owned sites within the eight-mile reach, including where instream measures are implemented.

Project Name: Pond Temperature and Habitat Mitigation Planning, Beaver Creek Restoration Phase IV
Project Summary: The Beaver Creek Rapid Bio-Assessment Inventory (2009, BioSurveys LLC) described the limiting factors for cutthroat trout as excessive summer stream temperature and simplified stream channels. The inventory includes a list of restoration prescriptions, based on observations regarding opportunities for cutthroat habitat improvement and sites for stream temperature remediation. The applicant seeks funds to gather additional site-specific information regarding pond sources of excess heat and cutthroat migration timing to design tailored pond control systems that eliminate warm surface spill at four pond sites in Beaver Creek. The applicant also proposes to gather additional information on the feasibility of augmenting channel complexity on Henderson Creek, given the role of upstream ponds as bedload sinks. Landowner outreach will be integrated with this project, resulting in a restoration proposal to fund Phase IV of the Beaver Creek Subbasin Restoration Master Plan. Partners include the landowners, Benton SWCD, and the USFWS. OWEB funds will be used primarily for contracted services to conduct the necessary surveys of the four ponds.

Project Name: Restoring connectivity for salmon at a 300-acre Multnomah Channel wetland
Project Summary: The proposed project will enhance three aspects of ecological connectivity at a 300-acre Crabapple Creek floodplain wetland adjacent to the Multnomah Channel. The site consists of two large wetland basins that were artificially isolated and drained by previous land uses. The wetlands have been largely restored to native emergent wetland, shrub land, and riparian forest by Metro and its partners during the last decade. The site could provide high-quality, off-channel rearing habitat for juvenile salmonids using the Multnomah Channel. However, aquatic connectivity is limited by a barrier (#1) between the Channel and the wetlands, a barrier (#2) between the two wetland basins, and a barrier (#3) between the wetlands and the Crabapple Creek headwaters. The proposed project will improve Barrier 1 by creating two broad breaches in the natural riparian berm to connect the wetlands to the Multnomah Channel during annual high water events. Barrier 2 will be removed by replacing a set of three culverts with a bridge span. Barrier 3 will be addressed by working with NMFS, ODFW, and ODOT to develop a project design to enhance connectivity through a highway and railroad between the wetlands and their headwaters. Partners include Metro, ODFW, NOAA Fisheries. OWEB funds will be used principally for personnel and contracted services.

Project Name: Development of a Decision Support Tool for Restoration
Project Summary: Widespread loss of functioning floodplains has significantly impacted salmon and other aquatic species. Opportunities to restore and re-establish these types of systems are constrained by private land ownership and the high economic value of floodplain properties. Restoration of areas associated with former floodplain gravel operations provide a significant opportunity to recover this lost resource, but present a number of unique issues that are not found in traditional floodplain restoration projects. The applicant proposes to assess restoration guidelines and develop a Decision Support Tool (DST), which will provide an analysis framework for evaluating the benefits and risks of different on-the-ground restoration alternatives. By partnering with other conservation organizations, academia, governmental agencies and willing gravel operators, the applicant will (1) capture information and lessons-learned from ongoing restoration projects; (2) evaluate DST options, (2) develop a DST, (3) test and refine the DST at numerous gravel extraction sites and (4) publish the DST for use throughout Oregon and the Pacific northwest. OWEB funds will be used solely for the development and testing of the DST.

Project Name: Upper Willamette Urban Water Quality Outreach Project
Project Summary: The project is designed for urban homeowners who recognize the need to appreciate,  improve, and protect local water quality. Workshops will teach how to decrease water pollution in storm drain systems leading to the Willamette and McKenzie rivers. The workshop will involve handouts, a video presentation, how-to guide, and hands-on exercises. The local OSU Extension office has requested a workshop for their master gardeners, and additional workshops will be advertised locally by use of direct mailings, newspaper ads, and cold calls to reach a goal of 12, four-hour workshops. The applicant expect to enroll more than 300 urban homeowners, install 25 rain gardens, and decrease local water pollution by 30 percent. OWEB funds will be used for salaries, contracted services, production, travel and administration.

This restoration plan will identify and prioritize riparian instream restoration projects on 30 stream miles in the North Clackamas Urban Watershed. OWEB funds will be used to obtain landowner permission, collect habitat data, and conduct analysis, reporting, and prioritization. OWEB funds will be used to collect the following data: invasive species extent and location; fish passage barrier locations, type, and condition; large woody debris volume and location; spawning gravel condition and extent; instream physical habitat; riparian vegetation species and cover; and effective shade. All future restoration projects will be ranked in order of cost (high or low) and biological importance. Deliverables include a geodatabase with all collected data and proposed project locations, photo points, and a report of findings. Partners include Clackamas Water Environment Services and Clackamas County SWCD.

The applicant seeks funding for a West Willamette Restoration Partnership coordinator to assist with the existing West Multnomah SWCD Urban Watershed Mentors Program.  The coordinator will recruit landowners for restoration projects and ensure their completion.  The program will reach 20 volunteer leaders in SW Portland who are interested in gaining restoration project skills and experience.  The biggest challenges for this training are participant connection and completion of restoration projects. The Coordinator will connect participants through personal interaction, online tools, volunteer work parties, and a yearly event.  Each participant will receive training that is applied to one restoration site in SW Portland.  It is expected that they will go on to enhance the watershed in the future with their learned skills. They will also mentor a future participant. OWEB funds will be used principally for project management.

Two 3-foot diameter, perched, side-by-side culverts provide the forest road crossing on Hancock Creek, a tributary of Woodcock Creek in the Milk Creek drainage of the Molalla Watershed. The four-foot drop from the outfall of the two culverts creates a complete barrier to fish passage. Each culvert is undersized and frequently blocked by logs and debris, causing the stream to flow over the road during less than 50-year flood events and resulting in downstream scour down to bedrock. The solution is to replace the culverts with a clear span railcar bridge. Replacing the culverts will improve stream process and function, reduce potential road sediments from entering the stream, and open approximately 3.7 miles of spawning and rearing habitat for native winter steelhead, coho salmon, resident and coastal cutthroat trout, Pacific and brook lamprey, and possibly Chinook salmon. Partners include landowner, Graves Trinity, LLC; ODFW; and ODF. OWEB funds will be used for materials, in-house personnel for oversight, and fiscal administration.

Recent OWEB-funded fish surveys found that nearly all tributaries of Johnson Creek are inhabited by salmonids and other native fishes. However, no fish were detected in nearly a dozen stream reaches with good habitat, indicating that downstream barriers (in particular, culverts) are likely limiting fish access to quality habitat. As a next step, Multnomah County has committed $35k to assess all county-owned potential fish barrier culverts, which include 26 culverts in the Johnson Creek Watershed. In partnership with Multnomah County and the six other jurisdictions that manage stream culverts in the Johnson Creek Watershed (the Cities of Portland, Gresham, Damascus, Milwaukie, Clackamas County, and ODOT), we propose to survey and assess approximately 80 additional public culverts and 50 private culverts for fish passage. This watershed-scale project will result in a detailed list of the highest priority barriers for replacement, allowing a more strategic and focused approach to restoring connectivity.

The Tryon Creek watershed, located in southwest Portland, is largely undeveloped and publicly owned. Tryon Creek historically supported a number of native fish species, many of which are now either extirpated or rare. Passage barriers, especially Highway 43 and degraded habitat, are believed to be the cause of fish declines in this watershed. The applicant will continue an effort begun in 2012 to:  1) monitor and evaluate the effectiveness of restoration, including improvements to the Highway 43 crossing;  2) develop a baseline characterization of the watershed and establish a long-term citizen-based monitoring program; and  3) engage citizens in maintaining the health of the watershed. USFWS and DEQ are primary partners. Results of this monitoring will also help inform plans for improving the Highway 43 crossing. OWEB funds will be used to coordinate the effort, for personnel time, and for supplies.

Project Name: Restorative Flood Response II- Restorative Design Playbook
Project Summary: The project will develop a Restorative Design Playbook to deliver science-based information on best practices to stakeholders who plan future projects on the portions of the Sandy River that are subject to lateral channel migration and severe erosion during high water events. Reaches of the middle and upper Sandy that are the focus of this work encompass high-priority habitat, concentrated private residential developments, and significant transportation and utility infrastructure. Project activities will include work by the council's staff and a river design consulting firm to identify and compile a technically sound and broadly accessible set of design guidelines for restorative actions appropriate to the Sandy River. A graphic designer will help council staff develop and produce the Playbook that will be of use to residents, county personnel, and engineering firms. This project will continue the collaboration initiated in 2012 under Phase 1, in the wake of a historic flood and major bank erosion in January 2011. Partners include Clackamas County.

Project Name: Smith and Bybee Wetlands Bottomland Forest Restoration- Phase I
Project Summary: This bottomland forest restoration project at Smith and Bybee Wetlands in north Portland will address water quality, invasive species, and habitat alteration issues. Metro intends to treat stands of reed canary grass on about 36 acres and install and establish in their place about 56,000 woody plants. OWEB funds are requested for two years of site preparation, acquisition of plant materials (including a grow-out contract for a locally adapted ecotype of Oregon ash), and installation of native plants and marking stakes. OWEB funds are also requested for three years of annual post-implementation treatments to ensure good plant establishment; Metro will fully fund up to an additional two years of annual treatments as needed for the plants to become free to grow. When they are mature, the trees and shrubs will provide shade to improve summer water temperatures and will eventually provide woody debris to the wetland. They will shade out canary grass and reduce its cover, improve species diversity, and increase habitat complexity. Lastly, these restored habitat patches will knit together fragmented habitats and wildlife corridors in the natural area. OWEB funds will be used principally for contracted services and supplies and materials. Partners include the Columbia Slough Watershed Council.

The proposed project is located near the confluence of North Scappoose and Cedar creeks in the Scappoose Bay Watershed, Columbia County. This portion of the watershed is lacking in in-stream structure and the creeks have become channelized with limited habitat opportunities for salmonids. The proposed project includes habitat enhancement on both creeks, including large wood placement, side-channel connection and flood plain enhancement, removal of two sets of culverts, weed management, wetland enhancement, and riparian plantings on three acres. OWEB funds will be used for project design and permitting, construction, riparian planting and weed management, project management, and fiscal administration and reporting. Partners include USFWS and DEQ.

Project Name: Characterizing Spatial Variation in Stream Temperatures to Improve Effectiveness
Project Summary: The Willamette Model Watershed Program framework for assessing the effectiveness of riparian revegetation on stream temperature relies on sensors deployed longitudinally to estimate rates of warming. The hypothesis is that the rate of warming will decline over time as riparian plantings mature. Sequential, single-point measurements do not account for spatial and temporal variability and may not meaningfully characterize water quality. Distributed temperature sensing (DTS) facilitates spatial and temporal analysis that can describe the distribution of habitat and water quality much more effectively. Using DTS and a suite of environmental sensors, the applicant proposes to validate the effectiveness of single-location loggers, characterize environmental parameters for selecting sampling locations, and develop additional methods for analyzing temperature data that are already being collected for project and watershed monitoring. Partners include Meyer Memorial Trust, NEW Ag Lab at OSU, and landowners. OWEB funds will be used for pre-implementation and project management, field staffing monitoring equipment, mileage, and report production.

A Russel Creek Restoration Action Plan is needed to prioritize and coordinate restoration actions in this watershed adjacent to the high-priority Willamette Confluence/Mt Pisgah complex. The Lane Community College (LCC) wetland is a potential habitat and open space 'anchor' identified in Lane Council of Governments Willamette River Open Space Vision and Action Plan (2010). Wetland and upland ecosystems in Russel Creek are at risk of loss to development, invasive species, and climate change. LCC's new Watershed Science Technician Program is prepared to begin a robust stewardship program to facilitate restoration of the college's habitats. This project will bring together local restoration experts to evaluate and characterize habitats, conduct landowner outreach, and write a restoration plan to guide restoration efforts. Confirmed partners include Lane Community College, the City of Eugene, Camas Educational Network, and The Nature Conservancy. OWEB funds are needed for project management, in-house personnel, contracted services, and fiscal administration associated with habitat restoration planning and landowner outreach.

Polk County has over 3,465 miles of streams and rivers and around 2,950 acres of lakes and ponds within its boundaries. Restoration, enhancement, and protection of riparian areas are key priorities in Polk County. Current restoration approaches in Polk County have been opportunistic and without a formal project design or implementation plan. The Glenn-Gibson Watershed Council (GGWC) will partner with ODA, NRCS, ODF, ODFW, Polk SWCD, USF&W, USFS, BLM, local watershed councils, and other local groups to identify priority areas within Polk County for restoration and enhancement of degraded riparian areas. The project will assess the current conditions of riparian buffers within the priority areas and create an implementation strategy that identifies sites and landowners to better prioritize restoration activities in Polk County. Prioritization will allow for more efficient use of restoration dollars spent restoring riparian buffers .OWEB funds will be used for travel, project management, one full-time riparian assessment technician. This staff person will conduct assessments, recruit landowners, and prepare project designs, which will result in future restoration of 20 percent of the priority areas in the first two years.

Tryon Creek Watershed, in SW Portland, is largely protected by the Tryon Creek State Natural Area in the lower reaches and impacted by urbanization in the mid and upper watershed. Invasive species and lack of healthy riparian canopy are two of the most serious threats. To address these problems, the Tryon Creek Watershed Council (TCWC) uses a mentor program to assist landowners in restoring their properties. This project will implement restoration plans for six sites, including two large homeowner association (HOA) common areas. Invasive species will be removed, erosion controlled, and native species planted and maintained for 2-5 years with TCWC's assistance. Each site will be adopted by a mentor, who with TCWC and partners' assistance will shepherd the site through the restoration process. Most of the sites have a mentor who is a resident of the HOA or a neighbor to the site, which increases investment and follow-through. OWEB funds will be used for project management, contracting crews, native shrubs and trees, and related supplies. Partners include the City of Portland.

Project Name: South Lane Salmon Watch Education Outreach Program
Project Summary: In partnership with teachers and administrators at eight school districts in the McKenzie, Siuslaw, and Upper Willamette watersheds, the South Lane Salmon Watch Education and Outreach Program seeks to provide in-class and field-based environmental and watershed education on salmon ecology to middle and high school students while meeting Oregon Department of Education Science Standards. The program will provide students the opportunity to understand and relate to the natural world on a personal level; foster a deeper appreciation of the value of salmon to natural heritage, native cultures, and as an indicator species of watershed health; empower students with collaborative problem solving strategies in watershed management; and engage students in stewardship activities. The project will occur at multiple publicly owned locations within the McKenzie and Siuslaw Watersheds.  Partners include the USDA Forest Service and BLM. OWEB funds will be used principally for project management.

The watershed outreach element of the Willamette Futures project will target future volunteers, cooperative landowners, and financially supportive community citizens in local riverside screening events throughout the Willamette Valley in Summer 2013. Watershed outreach screening events will be coordinated to include the Valley's watershed councils, land trusts, and other conservation organizations, and will connect and enlist volunteers, landowners, and supportive citizens in the future work of these organizations. Partners include Meyer Memorial Trust, NFWF, BLM, and USDA Forest Service. OWEB funds will be used principally to support contracted services.

The project entails protecting and restoring a privately owned 93-acre property located in the floodplain of the South Fork Yamhill River near Amity. Ducks Unlimited has a proposal pending with ODFW's Willamette Valley wildlife mitigation program to protect and steward the property. While portions of the tract have been cleared, drained, and farmed since settlement, immense opportunities exist to restore fish and wildlife habitat, as well as conserve water within the Yamhill River. Ducks Unlimited requests technical assistance to finish topographic survey, collaborate with ODFW to meet fish passage requirements, investigate upgrading to a permanent diversion with a new fish screen, complete restoration design, procure environmental permits, and modify water rights. Specific design elements will entail removing a 10 ft. tall corrugated metal pipe weir in a large drainage ditch, enhancing the drainage ditch to provide off-channel fish habitat, restoring emergent wetland hydrology, and bottomland hardwood reforestation.

Project Name: Restorative Flood Response Phase II- Middle Sandy River Design
Project Summary: Restorative Flood Response Phase II will develop neighborhood plans for restoration activities in a flood-impacted area of the Middle Sandy River that encompasses priority salmonid floodplain habitat, private residential development and significant utility infrastructure. Field and modeling investigations, and extensive community consultations, will produce preliminary designs for reconnecting a side channel upstream of the developed area that is in conservation ownership, but isolated by historic diking. Analysis will also consider potential associated shoreline and floodplain actions in developed areas downstream, particularly to reduce risk to sewer and water lines that cross under the river and are vulnerable to channel migration and erosion during high water events. Project activities will continue collaboration initiated with neighborhood residents, river restoration experts, Clackamas County utility and emergency response personnel, and the Columbia Land Trust under the first Phase of Restorative Flood Response work during 2012, in the wake of a historic flood and major bank erosion in January 2011.

This project would construct/re-activate an 812 foot side-channel to Mill Creek within the city limits of The Dalles.  Endangered Species Act listed steelhead, coho and Chinook salmon spawn and rear in Mill Creek

This project would install a fish screen just below Ochoco Reservoir to prevent vegetation and fish from entering the Ochoco Irrigation District main canal.  This would also result in better water control and less herbicide use.

Project Name: Upper Beaver Creek Restoration Project Phase I
Project Summary: This project would address a number of watershed issues in Upper Beaver Creek, a tributary to the Crooked River about 80 miles east of Prineville.  This project would treat 5,000 acres of juniper by cutting and/or burning, weed treatment will occur on these lands following treatment, eight habitat structures to reduce stream velocities will be installed,  and six juniper bioengineered structures will go instream to reduce streambank erosion and riparian fencing will be built with new off-stream livestock water developments.

This project would install 9,295 feet of 34" HDPE pipe in the Rock Creek Irrigation District's main feed canal.  The project will save 1cfs of 1870 senior water right in Threemile Creek currently being lost in the ditch and .5cfs of that will be converted to an instream waterright.  The stream is over-appropriated and goes dry below the irrigation diversions in July.  The project is located in the White River watershed of Wasco County.

This project would provide funding for trapping and monitoring feral swine that have increased their presence to six counties in Central Oregon in the last 20 years.  This project will seek to locate and eradicate feral swine from remote areas by acquiring 45 additional corral traps, adding to the 23 currently in use and supporting two positions to conduct the trapping program for two summers.

Project Name: Central Oregon Low Impact Development (LID) Demonstration Project
Project Summary: This project would demonstrate different methods of addressing surface water runoff in urban areas to reduce water quality impacts on rivers and streams.  One project involves the development of a new park adjacent to the Deschutes River, one addresses roof and parking area drainage of a municipally owned building near the Deschutes River and the third demonstration site deals with urban stormwater in the City of Redmond.

Project Name: Monitoring Fourmile Creek Restoration Project - Part 1
Project Summary: This project would build on water quality data correlations with fish and habitat data collected on Fourmile Creek, a tributary to the west side of Upper Klamath Lake.  Study data collected between 2003-2006 will be used to compare data collected since restoration projects were completed in 2009 and 2011.  The monitoring will determine the effects of these projects on the water column and macroinvertebrates and fish use and production.  This project effectiveness assessment will guide future stream channel restoration and fishery habitat projects.  The system supports native redband trout and ESA listed Lost River and shortnose sucker fish.

This project east of Bonanza in Klamath County would restore/improve fish passage from Gerber Reservoir to several springs.  The springs collectively drain into Horse Canyon Creek but alterations in the form of irrigation diversions have altered the hydrology and fragmented access and habitat for ESA listed Shortnose suckers.  There is documented seasonal connectivity for the Shortnose sucker to Gerber Reservoir.

Project Name: Lateral 58-11 Conserved Water Initiative- Phase I
Project Summary: This project would pipe two miles of this five mile long irrigation canal north of Madras.  The project would eliminate irrigation tail-water from carrying sediment and nutrients into Mud Springs and Trout Creek, a tributary of the Deschutes River, an important ESA listed steelhead stream.  Water quality degradation that occurs has been well documented.  This project compliments a similar project, the piping of lateral 58-9, that previously also drained to Mud Springs, that was completed two years ago.

This forest stewardship project northeast of Sisters in the Deschutes National Forest would thin the overstocked stands of mixed conifer forest to improve forest health.  Sedimentation from open roads and overland flows from past fires are causing soil erosion.  This project would continue stewardship projects of cutting and removing trees, decommissioning and closing roads and OHV trails, noxious weed control and enhancement of wildlife habitat.

This project would enable the development of a LIDAR survey of the White River Watershed.  The USDA NRCS has allocated $1,000,000 over the next five years to implement irrigation water efficiency (delivery and application) management in the White River Watershed.  There are a number of projects under development with landowners which could result in significant flow restoration instream to benefit native redband trout.  The LIDAR survey information would facilitate the survey and design work for these projects.

Project Name: Rock Creek Piping and Threemile Creek Flow Restoration
Project Summary: This project would install 9,295 feet of 34-inch HDPE pipe in the Rock Creek Irrigation District's main feed canal.  The project will save 1 cfs of 1870 senior water right in Threemile Creek currently being lost in the ditch and .5 cfs of that will be converted to an instream water right.  The stream is over-appropriated and goes dry below the irrigation diversions in July.  The project is located in the White River watershed of Wasco County.

This project would put one mile of Willow Creek in Jefferson County in the Conservation Reserve Enhancement Program (CREP), develop two off-stream water sources for livestock.  The OWEB funding would be used to cut 1,763 acres of juniper to improve upland range conditions and infiltration.  The ephemeral stream is inhabited with native redband trout.  Willow Creek flows into Lake Simtustus on the Deschutes River between the Pelton and the Round Butte Dams.

This project east of Prineville and along the Crooked River upstream of Prineville Reservoir would remove two abandoned irrigation diversion dams that block fish passage, retrofit two active irrigation diversions for horizontal fish screens and construct several toe-wood habitat structures in Horse Heaven Creek and the Crooked River.

This project would install a fish screen just below Ochoco Reservoir to prevent vegetation and fish from entering the Ochoco Irrigation District (OID) main canal.  This would result in better water control and less herbicide use.

This proposal would support the active involvement of the watershed council with the Ochoco National Forest collaborative planning process.  Currently the collaborative is focusing on the Wolf Creek watershed, a tributary to Upper Beaver Creek and the Crooked River.  The Crooked River Watershed Council staff involvement includes technical scoping of issues, working with private landowners within the planning areas, conceptual designs and framing restoration projects.

The City of Halfway experienced significant flooding in 2006 and 2010 when Pine Creek overflowed its banks after major rain-on-snow events. Halfways wastewater treatment lagoons are located on an outside meander of the mid-valley reach of Pine Creek.  The State highway and bridge opposite the lagoons further restrict the creek. Project components include: installing six 36-inch culverts under the highway for floodwater relief;  site a new lagoon cell; bioengineer the existing streambank; install 4 large wood habitat structures (LWHS) 25 to 30-feet apart; acquire easement/title to 90 acres; establish a 12-acre storage lagoon and coordinate a design with FEMA, USFWS, ODOT and NOAA.  Plants will be established on 2 acres of wetland including 1-0 containerized seedlings. OWEB funds are requested for pre-implementation, project management, contracted services, materials, outreach, plant establishment, travel and administration.

Project Name: Virtue Flat Historic Wetland Restoration Phase I
Project Summary: Technical assistance for the Virtue Flat area east of Baker City is sought for drainages that show serious channel incision.  These incisions exacerbate quick drainage of minimal rainfall, resulting in extensive flooding and erosion during the spring thaw and desertification. Technical assistance is needed to determine the extent of the historic wetlands; design cost-effective restoration along 2.75 miles of the Second Creek drainage; develop an accurate map of the historic wetlands; video documentation of the present conditions and an engineered design to meet Corps of Engineer (COE) and DSL criteria.  OWEB funds are requested for project management, contracted services, materials (V-notch weirs , video production and administration.  The landowner is the cost-share partner.

Project Name: Sumpter Valley Dredge Tailings Implementation Plan
Project Summary: Powder Basin Watershed Council is seeking funds to develop a draft management plan to address 1,234 acres to identity specific actions to guide the County and local stakeholders in managing the public land portion of the Sumpter dredge tailings.  Legacy placer mining was very destructive to riparian and aquatic ecosystems. The plan will provide Baker County with an understanding of reach-scale hydraulic and sediment transport; identify specific actions; collect streamflow data, floodplain and channel conditions and include an existing conditions model. OWEB funds are requested for project management/in-house personnel, contracted services and administration.  Baker County, Powder Basin Watershed Council and the Work Group are the cost-share partners.

Project Name: The Rockin - Locken Water and Erosion Improvement Project
Project Summary: Rock Creek, west of Haines, had very high flows in 2010 and as a result these flows a diversion structure was washed out making it virtually unusable. Due to inadequate irrigation water conveyance, all of the water is diverted down the ditch dewatering the stream. Project components include final engineered design; remove the existing diversion structure; install a structure with 2 concrete wing walls and 2 to 3 precast concrete blocks will be placed in the stream channel to form the diversion floor; install a headgate and ramp-flume measuring device and seed the disturbed area. OWEB funds are requested for engineering,  project management,  contracted services, supplies/materials and administration.

Project Name: Joseph Creek Phase Two- Data Utilization
Project Summary: The Wallowa Canyonlands Partnership (WCP) is a cooperative weed management area formed to restore canyon grasslands of the Lower Snake Basin watershed from the invasion and degradation by noxious weeds.  This project will focus on obtaining new technologies to improve ways to accomplish weed management in the upper and lower Joseph Creek and Chesnimnus Creek.  This project will expand that effort to hire a GIS consultant to build data dictionaries and purchase new generation technology for field data. OWEB funds are requested for project management/in-house personnel, contracted services, equipment, travel and administration. Cost-share partners include various landowners, BLM, Title II, ODFW and Umatilla National Forest.

Located four miles southwest of Vale, 130 acres of uneven farmland is separated into eight furrow-irrigated fields. By converting the entire acreage to a pivot-sprinkler system, runoff will be eliminated and soil loss prevented.  Project components include installing:  3,160 feet of 18-inch pipe to replace an earthen delivery lateral; 2,640 feet of 12-inch pipe to access the pivot point; headgate to divert water from the buried lateral; overflow device at the point where water is diverted from the open lateral to the buried pipe; screening device; bubbler; flow meter; 1,400 feet of conduit and 1,296-foot pivot.  OWEB funds are requested for project management and layout,  materials and administration.  The landowner has significant cash and in-kind cost-share. Vale Oregon Irrigation District (VOID) will install the 18-inch lateral and headgate.

Project Name: Alder Creek Elimination of Irrigation Return Flow
Project Summary: Malheur Watershed Council proposes to address flood-irrigated pastures located 50 miles north of Vale above the Malheur Reservoir and addresses impaired water quality. Project components include bury 2,100 feet of power line; install 1,600 feet of 10-inch pipe from the existing well pumping station to access the pivot pad. In addition, a 5-foot bubbler and 3,400 feet of 8-inch pipe will connect from the bubbler to the 10-inch pipe.  The project will install a headgate to divert water from the buried lateral; overflow device at the point where water is diverted from the open lateral to the buried pipe; screening device; bubbler; flow meter; 1,400 feet of conduit and 1,296-foot pivot. OWEB funds are requested for project management, travel, materials, contracted services and administration.  The landowner has significant cash and in-kind cost-share.

Malheur Watershed Council proposes to address a flood-irrigated pasture located east of Jamieson on   Willow Creek. A feedlot is located on the property. Malheur Watershed Council is proposing to convert the flood irrigation system to a pivot-sprinkler system to eliminate the possibility of contaminated waste water entering Willow Creek. Project components include installing 2,200 feet of 6-inch pipe from the pumping station to two pivots; a 4-foot bubbler and screen; power and electrical; 2,250 feet of electrical wire; two 7000-series pivots and four 30-inch ditch crossings to enable the pivots to cross the delivery ditch. OWEB funds are requested for project management and layout, travel, materials and administration.  The landowner has significant cash and in-kind cost-share.

Located east of Rome and approximately 30 miles south of Jordan Valley, a BLM allotment has limited water sources for livestock and wildlife. The proposed project would tie into a previously funded OWEB project (201-693) that installed 24 miles of pipe, two 30,000-gallon tanks and 14 troughs.  Proposed project components include installing 26,938 feet of 2-inch pipe and 22,176 feet of 3-inch pipe for off-site watering; 3- 3,250-gallon troughs, 6- 1,200 gallon-troughs and 9 bird-escape ladders for each trough. OWEB funds are requested for a minor amount of project management and travel, materials and administration. The permittees and BLM are providing all the installation and over 25 percent of the materials.

Project Name: UGR Whiskey Cr. Road Relocation and Riparian Restoration
Project Summary: Located in west of La Grande off Highway 244, a draw-bottom road will be moved upslope away from the riparian area.  The current road is parallel to Whiskey Creek, which is spawning and rearing habitat for ESA- listed summer Chinook and steelhead. Construction of 3,100 of the new road will be located upslope and out of the river channel and the riparian area. Project components include installing a 35-foot I-beam bridge with Eco-blocks; eliminate 300 feet of a draw-bottom road; reconstruct 5,000 of the existing road with less than a 6 percent grade; install five 18-inch culverts and obliterate 6,840 feet of existing road. OWEB funds are requested for project management/permits, contracted services, materials and administration.

A 180-acre farm located six miles north of Ontario is currently using flood irrigation on a crop rotation of grain crop, barley, winter wheat, alfalfa and corn.  Project components include installing:  2,500 feet of 24-inch pipe in the earthen lateral; 8,660 feet of 12-inch mainline and 12-inch flowmeter; 1,960 feet of 6 inch mainline to replace the earthen irrigation ditch; 1,800 feet of 4-inch mainline for the wheellines; a 1,080-foot pivot for 97 acres and a 657-foot pivot for 20 acres and two wheellines to irrigate 60 acres. OWEB funds are requested for project management, materials and administration.  The landowner has significant cash and in-kind cost-share.  Owyhee Irrigation District (OID) will install a headgate.

The confluence of the North and South (main) Forks of the Malheur River is northeast of Juntura. The section above the confluence was channelized years ago, adversely affecting bank stability.  Eroding banks deliver excess sediment to the river. Riparian vegetation is healthy along some sections but lacks in others.  Other concerns include the infrastructure - power poles, the highway bridge and a railraod crossing.  Technical design is requested to determine the reach length to be evaluated; potential impacts upstream and downstream of the subject area; recommended riparian vegetation; potential habitat enhancement opportunities; existing infrastructure challenges and any potential required future permits. OWEB funds are requested for project management, contracted services and administration.  The landowner and Malheur SWCD are cost-share partners.

Located five miles south of Adrian, Owyhee Watershed Council (OWC) is proposing to convert 71 acres from furrow-flood irrigation to sprinkler-pivot in the Blackjack Conservation Priority area.  Project components are install:  160 feet of 8-inch pipe mainline for a 1,286-foot pivot to irrigate 66 acres; 290 feet of 6-inch mainline for a 230-foot pivot for 5 acres and 2 flowmeters.  OWEB funds are requested for project management, contracted services, materials- pipe, bubblers, pumps and administration.  The landowner is the cost-share partner.

The Kingman project,located north of Adrian, will to combine 5 fields to convert 25 acres from furrow-flood irrigation to sprinkler-pivot.  Proposed components are installing 3,000 feet of 6-inch mainline to convert an open ditch to pipe; a permanent pump and 3 bridges for canal crossing; a 733-foot pivot to irrigate most of the acres and solid-sets in the corners. OWEB funds are requested for project management, contracted services  installation, materials - pump, electrical, pipe, administration and monitoring. The landowner is the cost-share partner.

Located 14 miles south of Adrian, Owyhee Watershed Council (OWC) is proposing to convert 50 acres from furrow-flood irrigation to sprinkler-pivot. Project components are install:  1,520 feet of 10-inch mainline for a 775-foot pivot to irrigate 43 acres; 1,560 feet of 6-inch mainline for wheellines and big guns for 7 acres, 2 pumps and a flowmeter. OWEB funds are requested for project management, contracted services, materials- pipe, bubblers, pumps  and administration.  The landowner is the cost-share partner.

Malheur Watershed Council (MWC) is proposing to relocate a feedlot in the Ironside area. The feedlot is located along Rose Creek approximately 3,000 feet from its confluence with the South Fork of Willow Creek and provides the only water source for cattle. OWEB funds are requested for a minor amount of project management, materials and administration.  The landowner is the cost-share partner and is providing all of the installation and other contracted services.

Project Name: Livestock Grazing Management and Water Quality Improvement
Project Summary: Malheur Watershed Council (MWC) is assisting a landowner to improve a multi-species livestock grazing system north of Vale. Proposed actions are located on different sections of property and include replacing a headgate at the Warms Springs Irrigation District (WSID) canal, delivery ditches and fencing throughout the pasture. Project components include installing 1,300 feet of 18-inch pipe to replace an earthen irrigation-delivery ditch; install 3,300 feet of 12-inch pipe to replace earthen irrigation ditches; 7,000 feet of woven-wire fencing to make 11 smaller pastures from the existing three. OWEB funds are requested for a minimal project management, materials and administration.  The landowner and WSID are the cost-share partners and will provide all the installation.

Malheur SWCD is proposing a constructed wetland to improve water quality inputs from the Slide Drain, which has a watershed size of over 1,700 acres and flows 20 cfs.  Located three miles west of Weiser, Idaho on the Snake River, the wetland would treat 100 percent of the tailwater before entering the Snake. Project components include constructing six separate wetland cells and reshape approximately 172,000 cubic yards of material; install 1 diversion and 6 structures for the ponds. The area around the pond edges would be reseeded.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services and a minor amount of project management and administration.  The landowner is providing substantial cash match of over $141,000.

Malheur SWCD is proposing a constructed wetland to improve water quality inputs from both the Nyssa-Arcadia and the Emerson drains, which have a combined watershed size of over 1,000 acres.  Located between Nyssa and Ontario on the Snake River, the wetland would treat 100 percent of the tailwater before entering the Snake. Project components include constructing separate wetland cells and reshape approximately 382,640 cubic yards of material on 30 acres; install 100 feet of 36-inch pipe; 340 feet of 48-inch pipe; 1,100 feet of 60-inch pipe and install a structure in the drain to raise the water level to be piped into the 30-acre wetland.

MLB Ranches, west of Juntura in northwestern Malheur County has significant juniper encroachment.  This project proposes to treat 1,000 acres of juniper now occupying historic sagebrush-steppe rangelands.  Sage-grouse leks are identified in this watershed that is inside ODFWs sage-grouse core area.  Project components include juniper removal using a chainsaw - on slopes greater than 15 percent - on 700 acres with the slash lopped and scattered. OWEB funds are requested for a minor amount of project management, in-house personnel, mileage and mostly for contracted services - juniper removal and materials (seed) and administration.  Cost-share partners are the landowner, ODFW, NRCS and Malheur SWCD.  The landowner will provide juniper cutting, equipment removal, lopping and scattering, piling and burning and seeding the area.

The Kingman project will combine 5 fields to convert 25 acres from furrow-flood irrigation to sprinkler-pivot. Slopes range from 3 to 6 percent. Proposed components are installing 3,000 feet of 6-inch mainline to convert an open ditch to pipe; a permanent pump and 3 bridges for canal crossing; a 737-foot pivot to irrigate most of the acres and solid-sets in the corners.  The existing earthen and cement ditches will be recontoured into the field. OWEB funds are requested for project management, contracted services  installation, materials - pump, electrical, pipe, administration and monitoring. The landowner is the cost-share partner.

Located 11 miles NW of Adrian, Owyhee Watershed Council (OWC) proposes to convert 170 acres from furrow-flood irrigation to sprinkler-pivot. Project components include installing:  1,200 feet of 15-inch mailine from the pipeline weir to the south pivot; 2,330 feet of 12-inch mainline from the south to north pivot; 4,548-feet of mainline to the corners; a 1,345-foot pivot for 74 acres; a 946-pivot for 74 acres and handlines for 22 acres in the corners.  In addition, old buildings will be removed and that land base incorporated into the fields.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (2%), materials- pipe, bubblers, pumps (88%) and administration (9%). The landowner is the cost-share partner.

Located  20 miles north of Adrian, the Muddy Waters project will convert 57 acres of furrow-irrigated fields to sprinkler irrigation. The current configuration deposits runoff into the Old Owyhee Canal and finally the Malheur River 14 miles away. Proposed components are installing 1,200-feet of 8-inch mainline; a permanent 20-HP pump and  a 60-inch bubbler. A 1,232-foot Zimmatic pivot will be installed to irrigate most of the acres. OWEB funds are requested for project management (10%), contracted services (water-right transfer and labor to install pipe (5%), materials (73%),  administration (9%) and monitoring (21%). The landowner is the cost-share partner.

Project Name: Upper Grande Ronde Invasive Weed Control (IV)
Project Summary: The Upper Grande Ronde Invasive Weed Control project targets leafy spurge, spotted knapweed and meadow hawkweed. Project components include bio-control for leafy spurge and knapweed on 2,000 acres. The CWMA will survey treatment success on leafy spurge, meadow hawkweed and spotted knapweed on 30,000 acres from the 2009-2012 sites.  Herbicide applications are planned for 2,500 acres.  Reseeding as needed and monitoring for 5 years. Collect data on 30,000 acres of hawkweed.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (7%), in-house personnel (5%), contracted services (63%),supplies/materials (10%) and administration (9%). Cost-share partners include ODFW, USFS, Grande Ronde Model Watershed Program, State Weed Board and Union County Weed Control.

The Harney County Cooperative Weed Management Area (CWMA) is seeking to recruit landowners for participation in future projects. The noxious weed problem was exacerbated by significant wildfires that burned in the southern end of Harney County in the summer of 2012. Harney CWMA is proposing a landowner recruitment effort to those affected by the fires. OWEB funds are requested for project management/in-house personnel (86%), travel (2%), supplies/equipment (3%) and administration (9%).  The Harney County Weed Board, Burns BLM, NRCS and Harney County Weed Control are cost-share partners.

Grantee: City of La Grande Public Works
Project Summary: The City of La Grande operates a reservoir constructed in 1915 for domestic water storage during dry periods. From its confluence with the Grande Ronde, Beaver Creek has passage for 13.5 miles upstream.  The first barrier is a 7-foot, vertical-drop concrete intake structure.  There are 6 other barriers.   Project components are targeted into three separate locations:  upstream, the main diversion and dam passage.  OWEB funds are requested for pre-implementation (2%), project management  construction engineering oversight (7.5%), contracted services (81%) and administration (9%). Cost-share partners include the BPA, the City of La Grande, and USFS La Grande Ranger District.  Letters of support were provided from USFS and The Freshwater Trust (TFT).

Located east of Rome, a BLM allotment has limited water sources for livestock and wildlife. Water sources can dry up before the summer grazing season is completed resulting in insufficient water supplies. Landscape-scale fires result in mortality to sagebrush and  destroy habitat for sagebrush-obligates. The proposed project would tie into a previously funded OWEB project (201-693) that installed 24 miles of pipe, two 30,000-gallon tanks and 14 troughs. Proposed project components include installing 26,938 feet of 2-inch pipe and 22,176 feet of 3-inch pipe for off-site watering; three - 3,250-gallon troughs, six - 1,200 gallon-troughs and 9 bird-escape ladders for each trough. OWEB funds are requested for project management/travel (3%), materials (90%) and administration (6%). The permittees and BLM are providing all the installation and over 25 percent of the materials and are cost-share partners.

Owyhee Watershed Council (OWC) proposes a project that will convert 40 acres flood-irrigated to sprinkler irrigation.  Project implementation will significantly reduce the amount of runoff entering the Overstreet drain. Project components include 960 feet of 10-inch mainline; 1,020 feet of 8-inch mainline and a 653-pivot. OWEB funds are requested for project management (7%), contracted services -water-rights transfer (2%), materials (80%), administration (9%) and monitoring (2%). The landowner is the cost-share partner.

The Mahogany project is N of Jordan Valley will convert118 acres of intensively flood-irrigated pasture that is also used a winter-feeding area to spirnklers. Project components include installing: 1982-feet of 8-inch pipe for pressurized mainline with risers in the east field; 1,900 feet of 10-inch gravity line to bubbler; 1,315  feet of 12-inch gravity line to pump station in the west field; 1,320 feet of 6-inch mainline with risers in the west field; three 4-inch 1,280-foot wheellines, bubbler and two permanent pumps. OWEB funds are requested for project management (5%), contracted services -water-rights transfer (<1%), materials (83%), administration (9%) and monitoring (<1%). The landowner is the cost-share partner.

The McCoy project is 10 miles NW of Adrian and will convert 104 acres from furrow-flood irrigation to sprinkler-pivot. The property is located at the top of the Fletcher Pipeline and the steepest property on that project. Proposed components are installing 1,800 feet of 10-inch pipe to the pump station; 7,100 feet of 8-inch pipe to the pivot from the pump station; 200 feet of 12-inch perforated metal pipe to collect seepage from the Mitchell Butte lateral; a 982-foot pivot to irrigate 39 acres and a 1,216-foot pivot to irrigate 65 acres. OWEB funds are requested for project management (2%), contracted services (9%). Materials (80%) and administration (9%) and monitoring (<1%). The landowner is the cost-share partner.

The Poley-Allen ditch is located in Lostine River subbasin, habitat for ESA-listed salmonids.  Late-season low flows are limiting factors in the lower reaches.  A design is needed to consolidate the Westside and Poley-Allen ditches. A design is needed to for 6.4 miles of pressurized pipe and convert 850 acres of flood-irrigated land to sprinkler irrigation. OWEB funds are requested for project management (9%), contracted services (74%), travel (3%) and administration (14%). Cost-share partners include TFT, Energy Trust, and Farmers Conservation Alliance (FCA).

Cusick Creek has 4 priority aspen stands in the riparian area. Project components include installing 3,440 feet of buck-and-pole fencing to protect four priority stands along Cusick Creek. A limited number of hawthorn will be removed with a trackhoe. The ground disturbance will also help to stimulate aspen sprouts. OWEB funds are requested for project management (4%), contracted services  (24%), materials (62%) and administration (9%) and monitoring (<1%). The landowner, USFWS and ODFW are cost-share partners.

Crawdad waterline project addresses 640 acres and is a result of the technical assistance grant that  identified resource concerns. Project components include to develop Crawdad Spring where flow estimates are eight gallons a minute (gpm); install 500 feet of buck-and-pole fencing around the spring development and aspen clone; install two water storage tanks  one 1,000-gallon at the spring site and a 4,000-gallon on the ridge; install solar pumping station; 3,600-feet of 2-inch pipe to 2 concrete 400-gallon watering troughs on a solid base. OWEB funds are requested for project management/pre-implementation (9%), contracted services (33%), materials (46%) and administration (9%) and monitoring (<1%).

A 180-acre farm 6 miles north of Ontario will convert from flood irrigation to sprinkler-pivot. Project components include installing:  2,500 feet of 24-inch pipe in the earthen conveyance lateral; 8,660 feet of 12-inch mainline and 12-inch flowmeter; 1,960 feet of 6-inch mainline to replace the earthen irrigation ditch; 1,800 feet of 4-inch mainline for the wheellines; a 1,080-foot pivot for 97 acres and a 657-foot pivot for 20 acres and two wheellines to irrigate 60 acres.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (<1%), contracted services (2%), materials (92%) and administration (5%). The landowner and Owyhee Irrigation District are cost-share partners.

Located 16 miles west of Vale a 30-acre flood-irrigated field has runoff entering Turner Creek and will be converted to sprinklers. Project components include installing:  2,480 feet of 6-inch mainline for the two pivots; a 7.5- hp permanent pump; bubbler to clean the water before entering the mainline and two pivots. OWEB funds are requested for materials (88%), project management (3%), contracted services (14%) and administration (5%). The landowner and AWEP (Agricultural Watershed Enhancement Program) are the cost-share partners.

Project Name: Planting and Protecting the Previously Pounded Powder
Project Summary: This project is located on the Powder River where a lack of streamside vegetation resulted in increased water temperature, erosion and sediment transport.  Project components include:  install 8,300 feet of riparian fencing on both side of the river (approximately 4,100 feet on each side); drill a well; install 3,000 feet of pipeline and 2 troughs; develop a grazing management plan; develop a planting plan with a variety of willows, dogwoods and other appropriate species. OWEB funds are requested for project management/pre-implementation (12%), contracted services  (77%), and administration (9%) and monitoring (<1%).  USFWS, landowner and CREP are cost-share partners.

Project Name: Thousand Springs Riparian and Upland Restoration
Project Summary: Thousand Springs Creek, 6 miles N of Burns, flows into the Silvies River and is in critical deer winter habitat. Harney SWCD is proposing to:  hand-cut (chainsaw) 692 acres of juniper in 8 units; pile 602 acres with an excavator; burn the pile juniper within two years after curing; install 1.3 miles of four-strand, barbed-wired fencing around spring sites and wet meadows; hand-seed all burned piles; install a solar-powered spring development and clean 4 water holes of excess silt. A grazing plan will be implemented. OWEB funds are requested for pre-implementation/project management (2%), contracted services (79%), materials (15%) and administration (4).  Cost-share partners are the Harney SWCD and  landowners.

Project Name: Harney Basin Carp Inventory Phase I
Project Summary: Building on the collaborative success of the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge's Comprehensive Conservation Plan (CCP), the High Desert Partnership wants to determine the extent of carp invasion basin-wide. Funds are requested for a contractor to assist partners to compile the documented distribution of carp and produce GIS layers for carp presence. This technical assistance will identify the current basin-wide carp distributions by digitizing historical data and compiling reports sheet to prepare a comprehensive database. OWEB funds are requested for project management (18%), contracted services (70%), travel (8%), supplies (1%) and administration (6%). Cost-share partners include NRCS, ODFW, BLM, USFWS and Harney SWCD.

Project Name: UGR Whiskey Cr. Road Relocation and Riparian Restoration
Project Summary: Located in west of La Grande, a draw-bottom road will be moved upslope away from the riparian area.   Construction of 3,100 of the new road will be located out of the riparian area. Project components include installing a 35-foot by 14-foot I-beam bridge with 45 Eco-blocks; eliminate 300 feet of a draw-bottom road; reconstruct 5,000 of the existing native-clay surface road with less than a 6 percent grade; install five 18-inch culverts and obliterate 6,840 feet of existing road.  OWEB funds are requested for project management/permits (2%) contracted services (79%), materials (12%) and administration (6%).  Cost-share partners are ODF and the landowner.

Project Name: Grande Ronde River Irrigation and Water Quality Improvement
Project Summary: A 25-acre farm adjacent to the mainstem Grande Ronde uses an annual push-up dam to convey irrigation water.  This section is a salmonid migration corridor. This property has the oldest Grande Ronde water right (1866) to convey 60 acre-feet and the landowner is proposing to forfeit 6 acre-feet for permanent in-stream use.  Union SWCD and the landowner propose to replace the push-up dam with a screened open inlet, steel-and-concrete structure with a flowmeter, control valve and construct an upstream rock weir.  A 36-inch by 25-foot open-well pipe structure will store the irrigation water. The inlet will be connected by 92 feet of 12-inch perforated pipe between the inlet box and the well.

Project Name: Canyon Lands Conversion - Flood to Sprinkler
Project Summary: Located west of Ontario, a 56-acre farm has steep, uneven flood irrigated terrain planned to be converted to sprinklers. Project components include installing a 60-inch bubbler; 620 feet of 8-inch pipe; 1,340 feet of 6-inch pipe and 1,000 feet of 4-inch pipe; construct 1,100 feet of five-wire fence to separate the farm ground from the perennial stream and install big guns and a pivot. OWEB funds are requested for a project management (12%), materials (78%), administration (9%) and monitoring (<1%).  The landowner is the cost-share partner and is providing all of the installation and other contracted services.

Located 3 miles NW of Vale, a 25-acre field is flood-irrigated and proposed to be converted to sprinklers. It can tie into lateral 227 to supply a pressurized system. Project components include replacing earthen ditch and gated pipe with 2,940 feet of 6-inch mainline; 760- feet of 4-inch PVC; 840- feet of 3-inch mainline for a total of 4,540 total feet of mainline; two 1,320-foot wheellines and two big guns will also be installed. OWEB funds are requested for a project management (12%), contracted services (26%), materials (52%), administration (9%) and monitoring (<1%).  The landowner is the cost-share partner and is providing all of the installation and other contracted services.

Project Name: Livestock Grazing Management and Water Quality Improvement
Project Summary: Malheur Watershed Council (MWC) is with improvements to a multi-species livestock grazing system located on 125 acres that pastures 300 nanny goats with kids and 50 beef heifers.  Project components include installing 1,300 feet of 18-inch pipe to replace an earthen irrigation-delivery ditch; install 3,300 feet of 12-inch pipe to replace earthen irrigation ditches; 7,000 feet of woven-wire fencing to make 11 smaller pastures from 3. OWEB funds are requested for project management (4%), materials (86%) and administration(8%) and monitoring (<1%). The landowner and WSID are the cost-share partners and will provide all the installation.

Located 2 miles NW of Harper, this project will address runoff from 121 acres along the banks of Willow Spring Creek, locally referred to as Harper Wash. Malheur Watershed Council (MWC) proposes to convert 121 acres by incorporating 4 fields under 1 irrigation system. Components include: install 1,550 of electrical wire, a 4-foot bubbler, 170 feet of 12-inch pipe and 1,900 feet of 10-inch pipe from the bubbler to the pivot point; install eight 40-foot pivot crossings to cross Harper Wash; planting smooth brome and install 4,520 feet of five-wire fence between pasture and wash. OWEB funds are requested for project management (6%), materials (83%) and administration (8%) and monitoring (<1%). The landowner will provide all the installation.

Located 4 from Vale, 130 acres will be combined into one field  under sprinkler irrigation. Project components include installing:  3,160 feet of 18-inch pipe to replace an earthen delivery lateral; 2,640 feet of 12-inch pipe to access the pivot point; headgate; screening device; bubbler; flow meter; 1,400 feet of conduit and 1,296-foot pivot. OWEB funds are requested for project management/engineering (3%),  materials (91%) and administration (5%).  The landowner and Vale Oregon Irrigation District (VOID) have significant cost-share.

Oregon Cattlemens Association (OCA) is proposing an outreach effort to reach livestock producers in eastern Oregon. OCA proposes 6 workshops be held and 12 monitoring tool kits assembled; prepare a DVD tutorial; purchase data collecting equipment and develop a webpage. OWEB funds are requested for project management (45%), in-house personnel (15%), contracted services (19%) and travel (11%).  Cost-share partners include NRCS and participating landowners.  Letters of support were provided from NRCS, OSU Extension, the OCA president and several participating landowners.

This project will replace a culvert and install three (3) miles riparian fence on Indian Creek along Forest Service road #24 in the Wall Creek Watershed in Grant County. The culvert is undersized and potentially at risk of failure from storm flows. This 85 long and undersized culvert compromises fish passage, channel morphology and sediment transport processes on the East Fork Indian Creek and Indian Creek.  Once passage is improved, 3.8 miles of critical and 5 miles of viable steelhead habitat will be made available.  The match on this project is the installation of over three miles of riparian exclusion fence along Indian Creek.  Partners include Monument SWCD, Umatilla National Forest USFS, and CTWS/BPA.  OWEB dollars would provide culvert replacement funds for project management, contracted services, supplies/materials outreach, fiscal administration, and in-house personnel, travel, equipment and post implementation status reporting.

The Bull Run Culverts #35 & #7375 are located in the Granite Creek Watershed on Bull Run Creek in Grant County. Two culverts are degraded, undersized and misaligned, causing excess sedimentation and potential juvenile fish passage barriers. Culvert #7375 is on a USFS road and is misaligned and causing bank erosion when the stream washes around the pipe; Culvert #35 serves County Highway 24 and is undersized and also misaligned. This proposal would develop design plans and drawings for the replacement of these culverts: one with an open-bottom pipe arch culvert and one with a pre-cast bridge. The partner on this project is the Wallowa Whitman USFS. OWEB funds were requested for project management & travel, contracted services, and fiscal administration.

The Bull Run Culverts #33 & #7370 are located in the Granite Creek Watershed on Bull Run & Deep Creeks in Grant County. Two culverts are degraded, undersized and misaligned, causing excess sedimentation and potential juvenile fish passage barriers. Culvert #7370 is on Deep Creek and installed on a sharp turn where the creek has been moved to facilitate a forest service road. At high flows it jumps the ditch and attempts to re-enter the old channel causing excessive erosion and sediment loading to the stream. Culvert #33 serves County Highway 24 and is also undersized and misaligned. High flows jump the channel and run down the highway barrow ditch, ultimately crossing over the highway and back into Bull Run Creek loaded with sediment and road pollutants. This proposal would develop design plans and drawings for the replacement of these culverts: both with as open-bottom pipe arches. The partner on this project is the Wallowa Whitman USFS. OWEB funds were requested for project management & travel, contracted services, and fiscal administration.

Project Name: Heppner-Lexington Conservation Pipeline Line I Supplement
Project Summary: The Heppner-Lexington Conservation Pipeline #1 project will provide gravity fed irrigation water to four farms in the Willow Creek Valley in Morrow County. The project site is along Willow Creek on an abandoned railroad bed to which Morrow County reserved an easement. There will be two side-by-side 26 HDPE pipelines installed (Pipeline 2 is addressed in application #213-6005), originating at a new fish-friendly and screened diversion. This is a collaboration of a NRCS Cooperative Conservation Partnership Initiative (CCPI) Project. Partners on this project include four landowners, NRCS, ODFW and UBWC. OWEB dollars were requested to fund installation and purchase of four irrigation flow meters, and purchase 923 of 26 HDPE pipe. Project management, contracted services, supplies/materials, fiscal administration and post implementation status reporting.

The Heppner-Lexington Conservation Pipeline #2 project will provide gravity fed irrigation water to three farms in the Willow Creek Valley in Morrow County. The project site is along Willow Creek on an abandoned railroad bed to which Morrow County reserved an easement. There will be two side-by-side 26 HDPE pipelines installed (Pipeline 1 is addressed in application #213-6004), originating at a new fish friendly and screened diversion. This is a collaboration of a NRCS Cooperative Conservation Partnership Initiative (CCPI) Project. Partners on this project include six landowners, NRCS, ODFW and UBWC. OWEB dollars were requested to fund installation and purchase of three irrigation flow meters, and 960 of 26 HDPE pipe. Project management, contracted services, supplies/materials, fiscal admin and post implementation status reporting.

Project Name: Range Improvements for Riparian and Animal Inhancement
Project Summary: This project has three sites, located on three different drainages in Sherman County: Buck Hollow, DeMoss Canyon and Grass Valley Creek. To help improve management of livestock operations and take pressure off of sensitive riparian areas, this project would develop three (3) upland water sources, two using spring sources and one installing a solar panel to pump out of a well. Integrated with these water developments are two sections of cross fencing that will divide large pastures into smaller management units. Partners on this project are the three landowners and the Sherman SWCD. OWEB dollars are requested for project management, in-house personnel, contracted services, outreach, fiscal administration and post-implementation status reporting.

Project Name: Sherman County Upland Soil Conservation Projects
Project Summary: These projects are all located on farms in Sherman County. This county is one of Oregons major wheat producing areas. Cropland water and sediment control basins (WASCBs), terraces and grassed waterways will be constructed on unprotected slopes to reduce soil erosion, aid to conveying overland flow into riparian areas while at the same time filtering out any sediment and nutrients.
