The project components include re-constructing 75,736 of cropland terraces, construct 2,426of new cropland terraces, build 5 cropland WASCBs, and 494 of grassed waterways. Partners on this project include five landowners and the Sherman SWCD. OWEB funds were requested for in-house personnel, contracted services, fiscal administration and post-implementation status reporting.

Located in the Lower Umatilla Basin Groundwater Management Area (LUBGMA), this project proposes to install a new pipeline and energy efficient pump from an established point of diversion on the Stanfield Irrigation District Furnish canal to irrigated cropland that currently uses an existing deep aquifer well. LUBGMA suffers from declining groundwater and high nitrate levels. The landowner would use the well only as a secondary source during critical periods during the year. Partners on the project include the landowner and NRCS. OWEB funds were requested for project management, contracted services, pre-implementation and travel, fiscal administration and post-implementation status reporting.

Broun Dam is located on Birch Creek between Pilot Rock and Pendleton in Umatilla County. It has been identified as a fish passage barrier removal priority since 2005. Some of the issues related to either removal or modification of the structure involve the associated water rights. This proposal would help pay for Umatilla Basin Watershed Council staff time to work with the three land owners as they negotiate water right transfers with OWRD. Partners on this project include the Confederated Tribes of the Umatilla Indian Reservation, the Umatilla Basin Restoration Team, the Umatilla Basin Watershed Council and the three landowners. OWEB dollars were requested for project management, in-house personnel, travel, production and fiscal administration.

Project Name: Lower Umatilla River Habitat Enhancement- Phase I
Project Summary: The site location for this proposal is the Bureau of Reclamation-owned Oxbow Property, 220 mitigation acres in Hermiston along the Umatilla River in Umatilla County. This proposal would fund a RARE student as additional staff to the UBWC with the assigned tasks of working with partners to research, gather and document water quality, habitat and fisheries data, seek alternative restoration funding sources, engage community involvement, and ultimately develop a restoration plan incorporating the original mitigation objective of BOR and the City of Hermiston recreational goals. Partners on this proposal include the Bureau of Reclamation, City of Hermiston, UBWC Board Members and Council. OWEB funds were requested for project management, in-house personnel, contracted services, travel, production and fiscal administration.

The Fruitvale Water Users Association (FWUA) serves water rights to over 1,300 acres of farm land northwest of Milton Freewater in Umatilla County. The water source is both the Walla Walla River, via the West Little Walla Walla, and the Middle Mud Creek headwater springs. After the 2000 decision to leave water instream to protect steelhead and bull trout, FUWA began a proactive campaign to improve efficiencies and conveyance of their now reduced water allocation. This began with technical assistance grant from OWEB to design a five-year plan. From that comprehensive plan, a phased approach for implementation has been instituted. This proposal, the third construction phase, will construct seven weirs and nine pumping stations, all installed with flow measuring devices for optimal water management. Partners on this project include FUWA and BPA. OWEB dollars were requested for pre-implementation, contracted services, and fiscal administration.

This project will address the invasion of Western juniper on the Maxwell Ranch in southwestern Wheeler County. Western juniper has adversely impacted the lands within the project area by outcompeting desirable vegetation, decreasing infiltration, increasing overland flow and allowing noxious weeds, including yellow starthistle and medusahead rye, to invade the sites. The project will remove 855 acres of juniper, treat 128 acres of noxious weeds, reseed 200 acres to perennial grasses and develop three springs to provide off-channel water for livestock and wildlife. Partners on the project include the landowner and the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs. OWEB funds were requested for project management, contracted services, supplies/materials, fiscal administration and post-implementation status reporting.

This project will address the invasion of juniper in the Butte Creek Watershed in northern Wheeler County. Western juniper has adversely impacted the lands within the project area by outcompeting desirable vegetation, decreasing infiltration, increasing overland flows and allowing noxious weeds to invade the sites. The project will remove 220 acres of juniper, treat 128 acres of noxious weeds and reseed 128 acres. Partners on the project are the two landowners. OWEB funds were requested for project management, contracted services, supplies/materials, fiscal administration and post-implementation status reporting.

Project Name: Range Improvements for Riparian and Animal Enhancements
Project Summary: Located in four different locations in Sherman County, this project will develop two wildlife water facilities, one upland livestock water development; and install 5,152 feet of cross fencing to enhance livestock distribution. These improvements would complement existing riparian fencing and CRP in the enhancement of wildlife habitat. They would also assist in management solutions to get livestock out of riparian zones and obtain better utilization of forage in the uplands. Partners in these project sites include the landowners, Sherman SWCD and the Sherman Area Co Watershed Council. OWEB funds were requested for project management, in-house personnel, contracted services, fiscal administration and post-implementation status reporting.

Project Name: Bull Run Creek Culverts - Phase I
Project Summary: This project involves replacing three culverts, two on Bull Run Creek and one on Deep Creek in Grant County. The Bull Run Creek watershed has been significantly impacted by historic land use activities including the current road system and culverts. Home to steelhead and bull trout, these culverts have been identified as contributing to increased sediment and blocking fish passage. All three reside on USFS property in the Wallowa-Whitman National Forest. The proposed solution replaces these three undersized and failing culverts with bottomless arches and a concrete box culvert with recreated streambed configured within. Part of the work done on Deep Creek would also move the road and realign the channel so riparian zone and adjacent floodplain can re-establish proper riparian function. The culvert on Deep Creek will also open up 10 miles of steelhead spawning habitat. Partners on the project include the USFS Wallowa Whitman National Forest, Confederated Tribes Umatilla Indian Reservation, Wild Salmon Center, North Fork John Day Watershed Council and Ecotrust WWRI. OWEB funds were requested for pre-implementation, project management, contracted services, travel, supplies/materials, fiscal administration and post-implementation status reporting.

This project is located in the headwater area of Wegner Creek, a tributary of Birch Creek in Umatilla County. Due to the lack of developed water sources in the uplands, livestock and big game water in the creeks and drainages, causing sedimentation and potential nitrate inputs and also the overuse of grasses, forbs and shrubs in the lower elevation areas along those areas. This proposal would develop one spring, two off-channel water developments, and install 4,800 of cross fence to divide one large pasture unit into two smaller and more manageable parcels. These improvements will reduce erosion, allow uplands to be more evenly utilized, improve water quality and riparian habitats. Partners on the project include the landowner and NRCS. OWEB funds were requested for pre-implementation, project management, contracted services, travel, fiscal administration and post-implementation status reporting.

Project Name: Lower Umatilla River Habitat Enhancement and Re-vegetation - Phase I
Project Summary: This project is located in Hermiston on river mile eight of the Umatilla River in Umatilla County. The 220 acre property is targeted for restoration by multiple partners in keeping with the original intent of being a fish and wildlife zone within the city. The property has large plots of invasive weed species crowding out native riparian vegetation that historically shaded the Umatilla River and provided both fish and wildlife habitat. This project begins the multi-phased restoration by treating 20 acres by removing invasive species and re-establishing native vegetation on the flood-plain forest and riparian area. Partners include BOR, the City of Hermiston, UBWC, ODFW, CTUIR, USFWS, Umatilla County and the Hermiston Rotary Club. OWEB funds were requested for pre-implementation, project management, in-house personnel, contracted services, travel, supplies/materials, outreach, fiscal administration, post-implementation status reporting and plant establishment.

This project is located on Cottonwood Creek, a tributary to the North Fork John Day River outside of Monument in Grant County. The first phase of this two-phase project began back in 2007 when BPA funded the replacement of a pushup dam with a fish-friendly diversion and converted 4,560 of open ditch to pipe. Phase two was delayed when issues arose about access to water rights where the ditch crossed various properties on its way to the point of use. The landowner contacted Monument SWCD to see if they could help finish this project, they agreed to do so and worked with the local OWRD Watermaster to resolve the water rights questions first. This final phase and request would finish converting the final 4,700 feet of open ditch. Partners on this project include Monument SWCD and CTWS. OWEB funds were requested for project management, in-house personnel, contracted services, supplies/materials, fiscal administration and post-implementation status reporting.

This project will replace a culvert on Indian Creek along USFS Road 24 in the Wall Creek watershed in Grant County. The culvert is undersized and potentially at risk of failure from storm flows. This 85 foot long and undersized culvert compromises fish passage (especially juveniles), channel morphology and sediment transport processes on East Fork Indian Creek and Indian Creek. Once passage is improved, 3.8 miles of critical and 5 miles of viable steelhead habitat will be made available. Partners on the project include Umatilla National Forest USFS and the North Fork John Day Watershed Council. OWEB funds were requested for project management, in-house personnel, contracted services, travel, equipment (should have been under supplies/materials), fiscal administration and post-implementation status reporting.

Project Name: Little Wall Road Decommision and Reconstruction
Project Summary: The Little Wall Road Decommission and Storm Damage Risk Reduction project includes road treatments located adjacent to Three Trough Creek, Lovlett Creek and Little Wall Creek, all of which are designated critical habitat for steelhead.  Treatments were identified as high priority in a 2009 USFS watershed-wide road inventory and noted as critical projects in the 2009 Wall Creek Watershed Action Plan. The project would reduce road sedimentation and storm damage risk and improve stream channel condition in the Little Wall Creek. Partners include the Umatilla National Forest USFS, the North Fork John Day Watershed Council (NFJDWC) and one landowner. OWEB funds were requested for project management, in-house personnel, contracted services, travel, fiscal administration and post-implementation status reporting.

This project, located within the Butte Creek Watershed in north Wheeler County, will remove 670 acres of Western juniper, treat 210 acres of noxious weeds and reseed 210 acres. Encroaching juniper has degraded the landscape by outcompeting desirable vegetation, decreasing infiltration, increasing overland flow and sediment movement. Partners on this project include six landowners and the Mid-John Day Bridge Creek Watershed Council.  OWEB funds were requested for pre-implementation, project management, contracted services, fiscal administration and post-implementation status reporting.

This project is located in the Rowe Creek basin in Wheeler County. Western juniper has adversely impacted the lands within the project area by outcompeting desirable vegetation, decreasing infiltration, increasing overland flow and allowing noxious weeds, including medusahead rye, to invade the sites. The proposed project will remove 86 acres of juniper, treat 64 acres of noxious weeds, reseed 64 acres, install 8,100 feet of cross fence and develop one spring to provide for off-channel water for livestock and wildlife. The partner on this project is the landowner. OWEB funds were requested for project management, contracted services, supplies/materials, fiscal administration and post-implementation status reporting.

The project sites in this proposal are located in Long Creek and Fox Valley in Grant County. Aspen stands in this area are showing signs of decline due to competing conifers and deciduous trees, and from over-browsing and trampling by large ungulates. This project will remove competitive trees and shrubs, and fence to protect 12 acres of aspen colonies. This project is the first application resulting from an OWEB landowner recruitment technical assistance grant. The proposal uses recycled fencing and brush fencing as barriers. Partners include Long Creek School, East Cascades Audubon Society, Oregon Youth Conservation Corps (OYCC), Grant County Title II, and the NFJDWC. OWEB funds were requested for pre-implementation, project management, contracted services, travel, supplies/materials, fiscal administration and post-implementation status reporting.

This project is designed to reach three schools, comprised of 125 students and 30 educational staff. The Environmental Literacy Plan will be introduced to the schools to support environmental education meeting Oregon Curriculum Standards. The goals are to encourage the development of environmentally literate students who will treasure outdoor experiences, demonstrate love and respect for nature and become informed members of the local community. This will occur by holding training sessions, workshops, presentations and field trips. Partners include the applicant (NFJDWC), teachers and volunteers. OWEB funds are requested for project management, in-house personnel, contracted services, travel, supplies and materials, production and fiscal administration.

:  This project is located on Fox Creek, west of highway 395 near the town of Fox in Grant County. The recent watershed assessment of Fox Creek identified Reach 16 of the creek as a priority focus for restoration because of its incisional phase impacting instream habitat quality, bank stability and overall riparian health. An engineering firm prepared a restoration design that includes 96 log structures, 22 root wads, 3 rock drop structures, 4 rock cross-vanes, 1,800 willow stakes, 132 willow clumps, 225 sod mats, bank sloping, and installation of an off-channel livestock water, diversion, headgate and fish passage structures. Partners on the project include CTUIR, the landowner and the NFJDWC. OWEB funds were requested for pre-implementation, project management, contracted services, travel, supplies/materials, fiscal administration and post-implementation status reporting.

This proposal requested OWEB funds to gather baseline data on property encompassing Three Trough Creek, Little Wall Creek and Lovlett Creek, all tributaries of Big Wall Creek in Grant County. Historic land management has resulted in degraded stream condition and increased erosion. Once baseline data is collected and analyzed, a restoration plan will be written that incorporates projects including but not limited to fencing, bank stabilization, riparian planting and road decommissioning. Partners include USFS, the landowner, Trout Unlimited and NFJDWC. OWEB funds were requested for project management, in-house personnel, travel, supplies/materials, production and fiscal administration.

Project Name: Lower John Day River and Rowe Creek Habitat Restoration Project
Project Summary: This proposed project would complete 30% designs to restore floodplain connectivity and habitat complexity on the Lower John Day River and perennial tributary Rowe Creek and in-stream flow on Rowe Creek. Historic land use practices have resulted in altered disturbance regime, habitat complexity, thermal regime and sediment regime with excessive inputs; limited in-channel wood, disconnected floodplain, and reduced in-stream flow. Partners on the project include Bella Vista Foundation, CTWS, LP Brown Foundation, the landowner and the Freshwater Trust. OWEB funds would be used for project management, contracted services and fiscal administration.

Project Name: Devils Lake Watershed Wetland & Critical Habitat Restoration Project
Project Summary: Lincoln County Public Works Department seeks funding to address a long-standing fish passage and public safety issue on the southern section of Devils Lake Road in Lincoln City where the road crosses Rock Creek and the Rock Creek marsh. Project components include raising the road three feet, replacing and significantly expanding two bridge structures, driving the new bridge pilings to bedrock, realigning an existing ditched channel to a more natural meandering course, and employing a comprehensive wetland mitigation and effectiveness monitoring plan. OWEB funds, which comprise approximately 10% of the total project costs, would be used for project permitting and implementation.

Project Name: Drift Creek Aquatic Habitat Restoration Assessment
Project Summary: In this project, the Salmon Drift Creek Watershed Council (SDCWC), requests Technical Assistance funding to conduct an Aquatic Habitat Assessment of the private industrial forest and federally owned properties within the Drift Creek (Siletz River basin) watershed. Following the model of their Schooner Creek Aquatic Habitat Assessment (OWEB project 212-1009), the SDCWC will hire a skilled contractor to: 1) compile and assess GIS and LiDAR data, surveys, and reports from a variety of sources; 2) conduct habitat suitability and salmonid viability field evaluations; 3) conduct landowner outreach; 4) develop and rank restoration opportunities and; 5) develop restoration projects/application for submission to OWEB and other funders in the 2014/2015 funding cycles.

The Siuslaw Watershed Council seeks funding to fine-tune the conceptual restoration plans and finalize the designs for the future restoration actions on the Waite Ranch property in the lower Siuslaw River estuary. OWEB funds will be used to: re-contract the original TA projects engineering firm to provide the final design report; project management; mileage; and fiscal administration.

This proposal would continue a project that has been useful in the Siuslaw basin over the course of the last twelve years. The project will take advantage of opportunities to collect whole trees, logs and other materials for restoration activities, free of charge, from public and private properties. The materials are made available through storm events and land management activities (road building and/or land clearing). Project expenses are due to the need to collect the materials in a timely manner and transport them either to a restoration project site or to a storage site for use at another time. OWEB funds would be used for project management, transport of materials, and fiscal administration.

In this application the Siuslaw Soil & Water Conservation District requests OWEB funding to implement a combined large wood instream placement and riparian planting project on two private properties in the Fiddle Creek sub-basin, a tributary to Siltcoos Lake. Specific tasks proposed include placing 55 conifer logs in 0.7 miles of stream, preparing and planting eleven acres of riparian area, building 1,000 feet of livestock exclusion fence, and removing two problem culverts. OWEB funds are budgeted for contracted services, supplies, five years of plant establishment activities, project management, and fiscal administration.

Project Name: Alsea Estuary Conservation Plan and Outreach
Project Summary: In this Technical Assistance application, The Wetland Conservancy is looking to develop the Alsea Estuary Plan, which would provide an estuary scale ecological framework to assist in prioritizing on-the-ground restoration or acquisition actions; define conservation goals and performance standards; and provide an action plan for implementation. OWEB funds would be used to develop a coordinated landscape-scale ecological framework to facilitate a community conversation and involvement effort to identify the conservation needs and opportunities in the lower Alsea estuary.

Siletz Bay National Wildlife Refuge, managed by the USFWS, was established in 1991 and currently consists of a total of 558 acres, including the lands south and west of the developed portion of the Siletz Keys project and Alder Island. In this project, Ducks Unlimited, in cooperation with the USFWS, seeks OWEB funding to develop final engineered designs for estuarine restoration projects for both the 42-acre Siletz Keys and the 9-acre Alder island Tracts. OWEB funds will be used to pay for engineering design and project management services.

Project Name: Grant Creek Stream and Wetland Restoration
Project Summary: In this application, the Siuslaw Soil & Water Conservation District is working with a private landowner on a multicomponent restoration project on Grant Greek, a tributary to Maple Creek in the Siltcoos Lake watershed.  A variety of activities are proposed including: 1) replacing two undersized culverts (16 and 36) passing different tributaries under the small farm road with culverts sized (36 and 112 respectively) for fish passage; 2) placing 75 conifer logs with rootwads in a series of structures in a 4,000 foot long reach of stream and adjacent floodplain; 3) treating roughly 5.5 acres of the valley floor by mowing down to mineral soil and mulching the infestation of reed canary grass and subsequently planting the area heavily with native willows and; 4) planting a _ acre wetland with native grasses, sedges and rushes. OWEB funds will be used for contracted services, materials, project management and fiscal administration.

This project intends to use a Rapid Bio Assessment snorkel survey to cover the entire extent of the Salmonberry Rivers (Nehalem River basin)known anadromous salmonid distribution, including the entire 14.5 miles of anadromous distribution on the mainstem, and portions of the North Fork, South Fork, Wolf Creek and Kenney Creek, key tributaries of the Salmonberry. The results of the surveys could be used to help guide future restoration and management actions. OWEB funds would be spent on contracted services and fiscal administration.

Project Name: Patterson Creek Fish Passage Feasibility Study
Project Summary: In this application, the Tillamook Estuary Partnership is seeking Technical Assistance funding for the first phase of a three phase project that would address, in a holistic manner, the fish passage and watershed process problems posed by the eight culverts in the Patterson Creek sub-basin, a direct-to-Bay tributary in the Tillamook Bay watershed. In this first phase, a contractor will compile and review existing information, assess stream hydrology and the opportunities or constraints relevant to culvert replacements, prepare 30% engineering designs and cost estimates for each replacement crossing, and summarize their work in a report.

In this application, the Columbia SWCD is requesting funding to replace two problem culverts in Merrill Creek, a tributary of Tide Creek in the lower Columbia River basin. The project would also stabilize roughly 300 feet of streambank of a private property located in the reach downstream of the uppermost of the two culverts. OWEB funds would be used for engineering, contracted services (culverts and streambank stabilization), project management and fiscal administration.

Project Name: Five Rivers Subbasin Restoration LFA Prescriptions Phase I
Project Summary: The MidCoast Watershed Council seeks funding to implement a multiple activity, multiple landowner restoration project in the Five Rivers sub-basin, a large tributary to the Alsea River. Activities involved in this application include: replacing a juvenile barrier culvert under a Lane County road, riparian planting on several different private properties, placing large wood instream structures on three private properties and restoring a forage platform (heavy willow planting) for the recolonization of beavers on multiple sites. OWEB funds are budgeted for contracted services, supplies, plant establishment, project management, pre-implementation engineering and design, and fiscal administration.

In this application, the Lower Nehalem Watershed Council (Council) requests funding to replace an inadequate and failing two tidegate structure on McDonald Slough in the lower reach of the N. Fork Nehalem River. The failing structure will be replaced with a new tidegate system consisting of two 6 X 6 concrete box culverts equipped with muted tidal regulator (MTR) devices. The MTR devices will control the opening and closing of the tide gates and allow much longer periods where the gates will remain open each day, thereby providing many more hours when the slough can function more naturally and increase fish passage and utilization. OWEB funds would be used for contracted services, materials, effectiveness monitoring ($34,171), project management, and fiscal administration.

Project Name: Lower Salmon River Tributary Fish Passage Enhancement
Project Summary: In this restoration application the Salmon Drift Creek Watershed Council (Council) is proposing to replace two undersized barrier culverts under Three Rocks Road, west of highway 101. Once the culverts are replaced, the disturbed areas above the culverts will be planted with native trees and shrubs. Each of the streams has roughly 0.5 mile of quality fish habitat upstream of the pipes, half of which is utilized by coho while the remainder is cutthroat habitat. At two feet diameter, both culverts are significantly undersized and even though the gradients are less than 2%, both have high velocity flows that create velocity barriers for juvenile fish, and the unnamed tributary culvert is perched up to two feet. The Council is partnering with Lincoln County Road Department (owner of the culverts), USFWS, USFS, ODFW, REEF Program Nursery, and Community Services Consortium (CSC Natural Resource Crews). OWEB funds are budgeted for supplies (54%), contracted services (33%), fiscal administration (9%) and project management (3%).

This Lincoln SWCD Technical Assistance project would fund an engineered solution for the severe erosion area on a single property low in the Yachats River system using a combination of streambank contouring, installation of tree rootwads, and willow bioengineering. Partners with the SWCD in the project include the landowner, the MidCoast Watershed Council, ODFW and NRCS. OWEB funds are budgeted for the engineering firm (93%) and fiscal administration (7%).

Project Name: Elk Valley Tree Farm Creek Crossing
Project Summary: In this application the Lincoln SWCD, in partnership with NRCS, is proposing a combination bridge placement and riparian planting project on a privately owned 160-acre property currently being used as a Christmas tree farm in the Big Elk sub-basin (Yaquina River). The bridge would enable the landowner to limit the use of the ford currently serving as the only method to move farm equipment across the river. The unimproved farm road leading into and out of the ford is leaking sediment into the river. Partners in the project include the landowner and NRCS. Since the landowner already purchased the bridge, OWEB funds are budgeted only for bridge related activities (contracted services-49%, supplies-42%, and administration-9%).

In this project the Necanicum Watershed Council (Council) and ODFW are partnering with the Campbell Group and another private landowner to install 70 whole trees, with rootwads attached, into an approximately 0.65 mile reach of Warneke Creek. By timing the project to coincide with Campbell Groups harvest plans, the project would thereby take advantage of the harvests cable yarding system to place the large wood material in areas previously unreachable by other means. Two culverts blocking juvenile fish access to winter refugia habitat on two small tributaries downstream of the large wood placement reach would be pulled, with one replaced with a larger culvert designed to state fish passage standards and the second replaced with an engineered ford. Partners in the project include the Campbell Group and ODFW. OWEB funds are budgeted for contracted services to place the large wood and replace the stream crossings (88%), supplies (3%), project management (2%), and fiscal administration (6%).

Project Name: Lower Columbia River Watershed Council Action Plan
Project Summary: APPLICATION PULLED

Project Name: Oak Ranch Creek - Salmon Passage and Habitat Improvement - Phase 1
Project Summary: Oak Ranch Creek flows into the Nehalem River at RM 80, north of Vernonia. Oak Ranch Creek has two culverts currently limiting fish passage to 7 miles of high quality habitat. In this proposal, in partnership with Columbia County Road Department, ODF, ODFW, and the USFWS, the Upper Nehalem Watershed Council plans on replacing the furthest downstream barrier culvert in the system (double-barrel, undersized and perched) with a pre-cast arch span crossing engineered to allow unrestricted passage for all life stages of the fish native to the stream while also supporting commercial truck traffic with heavy-haul loads. In addition, large wood structures will be placed strategically in 26 sites along three miles of stream. OWEB funds are budgeted for supplies (59%), contracted services (30%), fiscal administration (5%) and project management (4%).

Grantee: Stream Restoration Alliance of the Middle Rogue
Project Name: Upper Jones Creek Fish Passage Restoration
Project Summary: The project is located in the upper reaches of Jones Creek, a small stream that empties into the Rogue River near Grants Pass. The project proposes to restore passage at two barriers, one culvert on Mina Lane on the West Fork of Jones Creek and one small dam on the East Fork of Jones Creek. These structures partially or completely block fish passage to 2.3 miles of historic steel head and coho salmon spawning and rearing habitat.

This Type I Technical Assistance (TA) proposal seeks to develop engineering alternatives to an existing culvert barrier to restore fish passage for coho and cutthroat trout to the Clear Creek sub-basin within the Tenmile Lakes Watershed.

This project proposes to replace two juvenile fish passage barrier culverts within the Shutters Creek sub-watershed located in the Tenmile Lakes basin. These projects will improve fish passage to 2 miles of stream habitat.

The Talent Irrigation District (District) is located in the Bear Creek Watershed. The District operates and maintains a diversion dam in Ashland Creek, a tributary to Bear Creek. OWEB funding is requested to assist with piping the upper reach of the Talent Canal while BOR funds will be used to remove the diversion dam.

Through this Type II Technical Assistance (TA) proposal the Curry County SWCD, in collaboration with the South Coast and Lower Rogue Watershed Councils, proposes to develop a Riparian Program Manual and a Riparian Program Action Plan.

The applicant proposes to place large wood at approximately twenty sites using 73 logs, 7 whole trees (logs with root wads) and 30 root wads in one mile of Joe''s Creek. Joes Creek is a tributary to the upper West Fork Millicoma River.

Project Name: Effective Stream and Watershed Restoration in Tyee Sandstone of the Coos Watershed
Project Summary: This Type II Technical Assistance (TA) proposal will develop a geomorphological and biological process-based approach to larger stream restoration in Tyee Sandstone domains. Technical assistance is needed to better understand physical and biological processes in mid- and large streams, and how restoration projects (large wood, boulder placements, etc) affect these processes.

Project Name: Williams River Habitat Improvements: End of the Line
Project Summary: The applicant proposes to treat the uppermost and last 7.25 miles of the Weyerhaeuser 5000 road, located in the Williams River sub-basin of the Coos River watershed, by installing 72 additional cross-drain culverts, replacing 15 undersized cross-drain culverts, and replacing 14 undersized stream crossings.

Project Name: 'COMING HOME' The Myrtle Creek Wild Salmon Viewing and Wildlife Habitat Project
Project Summary: This Type I Technical Assistance (TA) proposal seeks to secure funds to support engineering and hydrologic design work to restore large wood and improve stream function in an urban area with infrastructure concerns which need to be addressed during the design phase. The project is located in the City of Myrtle Creek.

The project proposes to implement Phase III of instream large wood placement in Brush Creek and Brush Creek Tributaries. Brush Creek is a tributary to Elk Creek and is located approximately six miles east of Elkton in the Elk Creek watershed.

The project proposes to enhance instream habitat on Lutsinger Creek by placement of large wood and boulders. Lutsinger Creek is a tributary to the Middle Umpqua River. This would be  a phase II project building on previous instream habitat work.

The project proposes to implement phase II of an effort to restore instream habitat complexity on the mainstem and tributaries of Camp Creek, a tributary to Mill Creek on the Lower Umpqua River by placing large wood instream.

This proposal is designed to address agriculture related non-point sources of nutrient loading and sedimentation in southern tributaries of the New River watershed. The projects proposed through this application will be implemented in headwater and lowland tributaries of the southern New River watershed, including lower main stem tributaries of Floras Creek and a tributary of Floras Lake.

The applicant proposes to address salmonid fish passage issues on the Beeson-Robinson Diversion Dam. The Beeson-Robinson Diversion Dam is located on Wagner Creek, 2.3 miles upstream of the confluence with Bear Creek near Talent, Oregon

Grantee: Stream Restoration Alliance of the Middle Rogue
Project Name: Upper Jones Creek Fish Passage Restoration
Project Summary: The applicant proposes to address two fish passage barriers on Jones Creek. The project is located in the upper reaches of Jones Creek, a small stream that empties into the Rogue River near Grants Pass. The project proposes to restore passage at one culvert on Mina Lane on the West Fork of Jones Creek and one small dam on the East Fork of Jones Creek.

The goal of the Seven Basins Youth Watershed Council project is to involve local youth in hands-on monitoring, stewardship and restoration activities to increase understanding of watershed function, fish habitat and expose students to natural resources careers. They will engage in activities that will expose them ecological issues and allow them to participate in developing, planning and implementing projects that address those issues.

Project Name: North Slough, Catching Slough, and Larson Slough Restoraton Project Development
Project Summary: This project development proposal will consist of development of project designs, permits, and funding proposals for on-the-ground restoration projects in three high priority sub-basins in the Coos watershed. The projects planned for implementation as a result of this grant will include riparian and wetland planting, fencing, channel reconfiguration, culvert replacement, and large wood and rootwad placement.

Project Name: South Fork Coos River Aquatic Inventory Surveys
Project Summary: This project will fund Aquatic Habitat Inventory surveys in the South Fork Coos River and 9 of its named tributaries. Surveys will cover more than 44 miles of highly productive main-stem and tributary habitat within the South Fork Coos basin. These surveys will assist the Coos Watershed Association with the baseline data needed to properly identify and evaluate restoration projects.

The applicant proposes to replace a fish passage barrier culvert on Butcherknife Creek, a tributary to Waters Creek in the Applegate River watershed. The Butcherknife Creek culvert is a full fish passage barrier to more than 3 miles of cool "high value" coho habitat

The project proposes to increase instream habitat complexity on three properties located along Munger Creek, a tributary to Williams Creek in the Applegate River watershed. The applicant proposes to place 80 key logs, 50 to 65 feet long, with 20 secondary support logs to create 25 large wood and boulder structures along a one and a half mile section of stream..

The applicant proposes to fund phase two instream enhancement activities on the North Fork Deer Creek, a tributary to the Umpqua River near Roseburg. Approximately 1.1 miles of stream will be enhanced with excavator-placed logs (91) and boulders (490).

The project proposes to enhance instream habitat on Lutsinger Creek by placement of large wood and boulders. Lutsinger Creek is a tributary to the Middle Umpqua River. This project would build on previous efforts by enhancing approximately 2 miles of stream with excavator-placed logs (62) and boulders (1,315.

Project Name: Fielder Dam Removal Phase I (awarded as 214-4047)
Project Summary: Fielder Dam, a 19 foot high, 215 long, abandoned irrigation diversion dam, is located on Evans Creek at river mile 3. Evans Creek is a tributary to the Rogue River. The project proposes to secure the services of a contractor to develop technical designs for dam removal.

Project Name: Lost Creek Hydrology and Habitat Study
Project Summary: Lost Creek, located in the Middle Fork Willamette Watershed, is a Willamette Model Watershed tributary and Conservation Opportunity Area that supports spring Chinook, summer and winter steelhead, Oregon chub, brook lamprey, and cutthroat trout.  It is characterized by low instream habitat complexity, and experiences low summer stream flows and high water temperatures.  Scope of the low flow problem is unclear because Lost Creek has never been gauged and relative contribution of potential drivers has not been investigated, making this issue difficult to address.  Low flows are likely contributing to significant stream warming.  Determining locations of cold water inputs and areas of significant warming will provide information to prioritize areas for addressing temperature issues.  Lost Creek was ranked as a high priority by ODFW and OWRD for flow restoration needs.  Habitat complexity is lacking, and significant infrastructure associated with rural residential development constrains restoration options on Lost Creek.  Technical assistance is needed to collect streamflow data, acquire thermal infrared imagery, and conduct stream habitat surveys to determine specific restoration actions needed to improve water quantity, water temperature, and habitat complexity issues on Lost Creek.  OWEB funds are requested for project management, education and outreach, contracted services for data collection, travel, and fiscal administration.  Project partners include Meyer Memorial Trust, ODFW, and Middle Fork Willamette Watershed Council.

Project is located on Clear Creek in the Tualatin Watershed and will address a fish passage barrier on an Essential Salmonid Habitat stream in a Conservation Opportunity Area.  The City of Forest Grove has two water mains, one that is active and one that is abandoned, crossing Clear Creek directly downstream of a Washington County bridge.  These exposed water pipes are fish passage barriers, and the active water line and county bridge are jeopardized by stream downcutting.  These partial barriers limit fish access to over 4 miles of quality, functioning aquatic habitat.  Removing the water lines will result in a 2 foot headcut moving upstream under the bridge, which will destabilize the bridge on a road that provides access to a municipal water supply.  Project will place large wood and boulders instream approximately 100 feet downstream of the bridge to promote bedload retention and eliminate the jump barrier while protecting valuable infrastructure.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services to purchase and install logs and boulders.  Project partners include Washington County.

Johnson Creek Watershed is a Conservation Opportunity Area and supports Lower Columbia coho, Chinook, steelhead, and resident cutthroat trout populations.  Recent OWEB-funded fish surveys found that nearly all tributaries of Johnson Creek are inhabited by salmonids and other native fish.  However, no fish were detected in nearly a dozen reaches with good habitat, indicating that downstream barriers are likely limiting fish access to quality habitat.  Technical assistance is needed to survey, assess, and prioritize approximately 80 additional public culverts and 70 private culverts for fish passage.  This watershed scale project will result in a detailed list of highest priority fish passage barriers for replacement, facilitating a strategic and focused approach to restoring habitat connectivity.  OWEB funds are request for project management, contracted services to survey culverts, travel, supplies and materials, equipment, and fiscal administration.  Project partners include Multnomah and Clackamas Counties; Cities of Portland, Gresham, Damascus and Milwaukie; ODOT; and Johnson Creek Watershed Council.

Project Name: Remediation of On-Stream Ponds as Heat Sources in Streams
Project Summary: Project will occur in Beaver Creek, a Willamette Model Watershed tributary in the Marys River Watershed.  Beaver Creek is on the 303(d) list of impaired water bodies for temperature and provides the highest quality and greatest extent of cutthroat trout habitat in the southern portion of the Marys River Watershed.  The Council has completed projects to address several limiting factors identified in a 2009 rapid bio-assessment (RBA) of Beaver Creek including 9 of 11 fish passage barriers, enhanced channel-floodplain connectivity through large wood enrichment and riparian shade, and long-term stream wood needs through riparian planting along 1.5 stream miles.  The RBA identified four locations on Beaver Creek where on-stream, man-made ponds contribute warm surface spill into the stream below, resulting in multi-week excursions above the ODEQ stream temperature standard.  In addition to creating point sources of stream heat, on-stream ponds disrupt sediment transport processes and fragment native fish habitat.  Technical assistance is needed to develop an assessment protocol that evaluates scope of temperature threat, value of degraded habitat, and options for remediation at the four ponds.  Taking ponds off-line is frequently the optimal ecological approach; however, may not be economically or socially feasible.  The assessment protocol will prescribe a suite of data to be gathered to facilitate remediation alternative selection including bottom spill from stratified ponds, changing spill timing, and taking pond off-line.  OWEB funds are requested for in-house personnel, contracted services, travel, supplies and materials, production, and fiscal administration to develop protocol, prototype equipment to eliminate surface spill and an information report, and landowner outreach.  Project partners include landowners, ODFW, USFW, Benton SWCD, and Marys River Watershed Council.

Project Name: Middle and Upper Mary Rapid Bio-Assessment and Landowner Recruitment
Project Summary: The Middle and Upper Marys River provides habitat for coastal cutthroat trout and Pacific lamprey as well as other native fish species.  The Marys River Preliminary Watershed Assessment recommended additional assessments be conducted to improve cutthroat trout distribution data and determine riparian area condition in relationship to land use.  Past Watershed Council work in adjacent areas have prompted strong landowner interest in the Upper Marys; however, the Council lacks ground-based understanding of habitat limitations in the Middle and Upper Marys River to confidently direct landowners to appropriate restoration strategies.  Technical assistance is needed to conduct a synthesis of existing information about the area, a field-based rapid bio-assessment to fill key knowledge gaps, and validate older and remotely-gathered data.  This assessment will provide landscape-scale understanding of watershed dynamics, limitations, and restoration opportunities that will be used to develop a map-based, prioritized restoration strategy in collaboration with landowners and funding partners.  This systems-based understanding of fish distribution and habitat potential will provide the Council a systemic understanding of highest value restoration opportunities prior to investing in landowner recruitment and site-specific projects.  OWEB funds are requested for project management; contracted services to support landowner outreach, field survey, data analysis, development and presentation of final report to the community and development of specific restoration proposals; travel; production; and fiscal administration.  Project partners include Benton County, OSU Lamprey Project, ODFW, and Marys Watershed Council.

Project Name: Landowner and Farmworker SCI Outreach Plan
Project Summary: Work will be focused in the Butte Creek and Lower Pudding River areas of the Pudding River Watershed.  These areas were targeted because they have Essential Salmonid Habitat for Upper Willamette spring Chinook and winter steelhead and are on the 303(d) list of water quality impaired waterbodies for exceeding summer water temperature standards.  Technical assistance is needed to hire a project manager through the Resource Assistance for Rural Environments (RARE) Program that will provide landowner recruitment.  Duties will include conducting outreach to engage stakeholder participation, developing partnerships, coordinating communications between the watershed council board and participating stakeholders, serving as a consistent point of contact for partners, public and contractors, and collaborating with partners to implement outreach events.  Activities are part of the Watershed Councils Panther Rock to Willamette Falls Sustainability Corridor and Creekshed Stewardship initiatives.  Landowner and stakeholder outreach will facilitate activities, such as rapid bio-assessment and Greater Aurora Water Sampling projects, that will enable the Watershed Council to reach out to key stakeholders, such as landowners, farm workers, community groups, and Indian tribes.  OWEB funds are requested for project management through the RARE Program and fiscal administration.  Project partners include Pudding River Watershed Council.

The Johnson Creek Watershed Council published the Johnson Creek Watershed Action Plan: An Adaptive Approach in 2002.  This document set indicator targets for watershed health, and identified priority areas and projects for restoration.  Since then, restoration projects have been implemented, monitoring data collected, advances made in watershed science, and shifts in policy that have changed the landscape of restoration in Johnson Creek Watershed creating a need for an updated Action Plan.  Technical assistance is needed to complete an updated watershed assessment and Action Plan to guide restoration activities in 2015-2025.  The project includes a watershed action planning training for Lower Willamette Watershed Councils, hosted by Johnson Creek Watershed Council.  The new action plan will provide a scientific framework for prioritizing restoration actions and monitoring watershed health, leading to more strategic restoration of the watershed.  OWEB funds are requested for project management, in-house personnel, contracted services to provide training, travel, production, equipment, and fiscal administration.  Project partners include Johnson Creek Watershed Council and the Johnson Creek Inter-Jurisdictional Committee.

Project Name: Mapping Oak in the Greater Portland Metro Area
Project Summary: Project will occur in the North Willamette Valley.  In 2012 the Intertwine Alliances Regional Conservation Strategy identified development of oak distribution maps as a high priority conservation need.  Oregon white oak habitats harbor a disproportionately high number of imperiled flora and fauna; and because of their location and increasing scarcity on the landscape are threatened disproportionately by ongoing development, agriculture, and conifer encroachment.  Oak woodlands are a strategy habitat under the Oregon Conservation Strategy; the chief problem facing Intertwine Alliance partners in restoring this habitat is very limited and incomplete maps of Oregon white oak ecosystems.  Technical assistance is needed to develop a regional oak map using remote sensing, field surveys, and accuracy assessments.  The map will be used in conservation planning, acquisitions, and restoration programs.  Metro will convene a technical advisory committee, develop preliminary maps, and hire a contractor to oversee field surveys and citizen-science volunteers to assist with field mapping.  Metro collected existing maps, conducted additional field-based mapping, and developed a remote sensing proof of concept in 2012-2013 to prepare for this effort.  Metro will compile available data sets, including high quality aerial photos, LiDAR, and NAIP imagery to produce detailed oak distribution maps using Feature Analyst or similar feature detection software.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services for remote sending analysis, field surveys, and volunteer coordination and travel for volunteers.  Partners include Kingfisher Ecological Services, volunteers, West Multnomah SWCD, Tualatin Hills Park and Recreation District, and Metro.

This 189 acre private property in the Marys River Watershed is located in a Conservation Opportunity Area and the USFWSs Fenders blue butterfly Designated Habitat near Wren, Oregon.  Technical assistance is needed to assess Fenders blue butterfly and Taylors checkerspot butterfly habitat conditions, habitat restoration opportunities, and threatened and endangered species presence; develop a 10-year management plan; and complete a Safe Harbor Agreements with Crestmont Land Trust.  These plans and cooperative agreements will facilitate implementation of practices designed to benefit prairie and oak woodland species, and contribute to recovery of Fenders blue and Taylors checkerspot butterflies.  OWEB funds are requested for project management, contracted services, supplies and materials, and fiscal administration.  Project partners include landowner and Benton SWCD.

This 93 acre property is located in the South Fork Yamhill River floodplain and between the Amity Oaks, Yamhill Oaks and Willamette River Floodplain Conservation Opportunity Areas.  The landowner is in discussions with ODFW to place a BPA-purchased easement.  Majority of the site has been cleared, drained, and farmed since Euro-American settlement.  This site has opportunities for restoring multiple Oregon Conservation Strategy habitats including riparian forest, emergent wetlands, forested wetlands, and oak savanna.   These habitats will benefit ESA-listed steelhead in addition to declining reptiles, amphibians, and priority avian species.  Technical assistance is needed to finish a topographic survey, collect baseline data, coordinate with stakeholders, complete restoration design, and prepare site specific management plan.  Currently, specific design elements include removing a large barrier to off-channel steelhead habitat, restoring emergent wetland hydrology, and restoring forested wetland and oak savanna habitats.  OWEB funds are requested for project management, in-house personnel for survey and data collection, travel, equipment, and fiscal administration.  Project partners include landowner, ODFW, Yamhill Watershed Council, and Ducks Unlimited.

Project Name: Restoration Design of Lower Chicken Creek - Tualatin River NWR
Project Summary: Chicken Creek is located on the USFWs Tualatin River National Wildlife Refuge near Sherwood, Oregon.  The creek historically meandered through a floodplain mosaic of wet and dry prairie, riparian forest, and wetlands to its connection with the Tualatin River.  In the early part of the 20th century, the creek was channelized to the western portion of the property to facilitate farming, and now exists in a linear, deeply incised ditch.  Once the creek was channelized, the mosaic of habitats was converted to agricultural lands supporting feed crops and dairy farm.  Agriculture operations occurred for almost 100 years until the property was purchased by USFW in 1996.  Technical assistance is needed to develop a complete engineered design for restoration of lower-Chicken Creek that accommodates the refuges desire to maintain an existing diversion that supports emergent marsh management while improving Upper-Willamette River steelhead rearing habitat in Chicken Creek and surrounding floodplain.  The preferred site restoration alternative was identified through a process to create a Comprehensive Conservation Plan and Environmental Assessment for the refuge.  This alternative emphasizes restoring historic connection of 1.5 miles of lower-Chicken Creek to the Tualatin River.  Project design will be used to support future permitting, full restoration fund raising, and project implementation.  OWEB funds are requested for project management; in-house personnel for topographic survey, map production and engineering design; and fiscal administration.  Project partners include Ducks Unlimited and USFW.

Project Name: Mill Creek Basin Fish Passage Restoration
Project Summary: Mill Creek is located in the Yamhill Watershed and contains high quality habitat for ESA-listed Upper Willamette River steelhead, resident cutthroat trout, and resident and anadromous lamprey species.  Greater Yamhill Watershed Council and partners recently completed an assessment and prioritization of fish passage barriers in Willamina, North Yamhill, and Mill Creek Basins and are now implementing phased actions to address priority barriers.  Mill Creek Basin is the first phase and technical assistance is needed to design replacement stream crossings for two culverts identified as barriers to juvenile and adult fish passage.  Both culverts restrict fish access to over 8 miles of high quality spawning and rearing habitat.  Technical assistance is needed to develop potential design solutions for replacement that include span bridges and bottomless culverts.  Selected design will meet ODFW criteria and Polk County and Weyerhaeuser engineering standards.  OWEB funds are requested for project management, contracted services for design, travel, production, and fiscal administration.  Project partners include BLM, Confederated Tribes of Grande Ronde, ODFW, and Greater Yamhill Watershed Council.

Boardman Creek is located in the Jennings Lodge/Oak Grove area in Clackamas County and has the largest remaining intact wetland in the area.  Specific problems identified at the Boardman Wetland Complex include untreated stormwater drains into the wetland; invasive plant species inhibit water storage and conveyance; floodplains are disconnected by deep, narrow ditching that prevents water from accessing lateral floodplain; and wetland has no native vegetative cover.  Technical assistance is needed to complete preliminary and final design plans that includes stakeholder involvement, hydraulic and hydrology modeling, plan and profile design drawings for grading plan, channel redesign, planting plans, and floodplain analysis to address frequent street flooding.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services for a design consultant.  Project partners include North Clackamas Parks and Recreation District, Jennings Lodge Community Council, North Clackamas Urban Watershed Council, and Oak Lodge Sanitary District.

Project Name: Harrold Streambank Restoration Project Phase One
Project Summary: Gettings Creek, a tributary to the Coast Fork Willamette River, originates in the Cascade foothills and flows down slope through forest, rural residence, and agricultural lands.  The project site is located within the ODA Southern Willamette Agricultural Water Quality Management Area.  The confluence of Gettings Creek is one of the most braided and healthy sections of the mainstem Coast Fork Willamette River and is likely providing high-quality rearing habitat for cutthroat trout and spring Chinook salmon.  Water quality testing indicates water temperature and E. coli levels above state standards.  The stream is severely downcutting and actively eroding over 100 tons of soil annually.  All riparian vegetation has been lost at four erosion areas of the project site located on an active 130 acre livestock and hay operation.  Project will treat 550 feet of streambank by installing instream root wad structures, keyed in and ballasted with boulders, at the four erosion areas that are located on outside bends of this alluvial stream.  Streambanks at these sites will be sloped to a 3:1 ratio, erosion control fabric installed on disturbed banks, and native trees and shrubs planted to provide root structure and soil stability to the banks.  OWEB funds are requested for project management, permitting, travel, planting labor, equipment rental, log structures, and planting supplies.  Project partners include the landowners, Coast Fork Willamette Watershed Council, ODA, NRCS, and Upper Willamette SWCD.

Project is located on multiple private properties along the Mohawk River, which is the largest tributary to the McKenzie River, Essential Salmonid Habitat, and a Conservation Opportunity Area.  Riparian and floodplain habitat in the Mohawk Basin have been altered by various historic and current land-use practices including forestry, agriculture, and residential development altering vegetative patterns and establishment of riparian forests.  This 8.5 acre project on 5-7 locations will inter-plant previously implemented riparian revegetation projects and provide five years of plant establishment.  Project monitoring results indicate these sites have largely failed to meet restoration objectives due to low plant survival and lack of invasive plant control.  Lessons learned from these past project designs will be used to adapt management at these sites by increasing plant density and providing aggressive weed control.  Project will benefit water quality, and Chinook and cutthroat trout.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services and materials for riparian plantings and plant establishment for up to five years.  Project partners include landowners and the McKenzie Watershed Council.

Project is located on the property of the Native American Youth and Family Center (NAYA) in the Columbia Slough Watershed in NE Portland.  Target audiences include the NAYA Family Center Community and residents of NAYAs neighborhood of Cully.  Community members lack information on eco-cultural restoration, awareness of their ability to inform decision-making in restoration projects, traditional ecological knowledge on site management and monitoring, understanding of culturally significant key stone species from the region, and the benefits of undertaking an eco-cultural restoration plan.  Materials and programing will be developed for field trips, site visits, workshops, hands-on trainings, web content, and public input meetings to directly engage community in learning ecology, restoration models, site assessment, and developing monitoring protocols.  Participants will apply this information in place-based restoration project planning to collaboratively build a 6.5-acre wetland restoration design.  Project will serve eco-cultural needs of the local Native American community by restoring NAYA land with culturally important plants for place-based education, heritage training, and providing materials for traditional uses; and Cully neighborhood by restoring useable green space and enhancing ecosystem services in the adjoining wetland.  OWEB funds are requested for project management, in-house personnel, contracted services, travel, supplies and materials, production, and fiscal administration.  Project partners include NAYA Family Center and Verde.

Project Name: Multnomah and Wahkeena Creeks Restoration Project
Project Summary: Multnomah and Wahkeena Creeks are tributaries of the Columbia River located at river mile 135 in the Columbia River Gorge.  Over 90% of both watersheds are in pristine condition; however, the lower portion of each stream flows through the Columbia River floodplain and are substantially altered by development of transportation infrastructure.  During construction of I-84, both streams were diverted through borrow pits that are now managed as freshwater lakes; which are negatively affecting stream water quality and temperature, and support non-native predators.  Other impacts have reduced habitat complexity and riparian health.  Applicant collected baseline data, completed a water budget for one pond, and developed a 60% design plan set for restoration actions addressing highest priority limiting factors and actions within the 2010 Oregon Recovery Plan.  Restoration actions include three acres of riparian reforestation, reducing a stream diversion by approximately 40%, improving instream habitat through large wood placement, and installing a swale to treat stormwater from 0.6 acres of parking lot.  Current project proposal will replace existing Wahkeena Creek diversion structure, modify pond outlet structure, and reforest three acres of riparian habitat.  OWEB funds are requested for project management, contracted services, supplies and materials, fiscal administration, and plant establishment.  Project partners include OPRD, East Multnomah SWCD, and Lower Columbia Estuary Partnership.

Grantee: Friends of Buford Park & Mt Pisgah
Project Summary: The 2,300-acre Buford Park is located in Southeast Lane County near the confluence of the Willamette River coast and middle forks, adjacent to TNCs 1,271-acre Willamette Confluence Preserve, and in a Conservation Opportunity Area.  Less than 2 percent of the Willamette Valleys native prairie and savanna habitats remain due to a long history of land conversion into farms, subdivision, urban areas, and vineyards.  Proposed project will restore and enhance prairie and savannah habitat across the 275-acre Meadowlark Project.  Management actions include controlling invasive shrubs; removing conifers and hardwoods to restore 57 acres of oak savannah, 50 acres of prairie, 40 acres of oak woodland, and 20 acres of conifer forest; prescribed fire on 65 acres; and sowing native grasses and forbs to enhance habitat for 189 at-risk species depending on these habitats, including Western meadowlark and acorn woodpecker.  OWEB funds are requested for pre-implementation, project management, in-house personnel, contracted services, travel, supplies and materials, outreach, reporting, fiscal administration and plant establishment.  Project partners include Lane County, ODA, OR State Weed Board, ODF, NFWF, BPA, and Friends of Buford Park and Mt. Pisgah.

Project Name: Lower North Santiam Floodplain Restoration Alternatives Analysis
Project Summary: A floodplain restoration analysis will be conducted to determine proposed floodplain restoration actions and preferred alternatives for the lower North Santiam River floodplain downstream of Stayton, Oregon.  Historic floodplain habitat and side-channels have been cut off from mainstem flow by installation of revetments, culverts, and ditches placed to control flood waters, protect farm land, and to provide year-round water for agricultural and municipal uses.  This analysis will identify feasible and practical opportunities for reconnecting side-channels and historic floodplain habitats along Dieckman Creek, several unnamed tributaries, and along the North Santiam River between approximately river miles 12.5 to 14.6.  The Council, participating landowners, consultants, and a technical team will collaboratively identify and prioritize up to 5 floodplain restoration alternatives to incorporate into the hydraulic model to determine each alternatives feasibility and potential for adverse effects to adjacent landowners.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services and fiscal administration.  Project partners include Confederated Tribes of Grand Ronde, BLM, USGS, TNC, ODFW, Santiam Water Control District, landowners, and North Santiam Watershed Council.

Project Name: Restoration Design of lower-Chicken Creek - Tualatin River NWR
Project Summary: Chicken Creek is located on the USFWs Tualatin River National Wildlife Refuge near Sherwood, Oregon.  The creek historically meandered through a floodplain mosaic of wet and dry prairie, riparian forest, and wetlands to its connection with the Tualatin River.  In the early part of the 20th century, the creek was channelized to the western portion of the property to facilitate farming, and now exists in a linear, deeply incised ditch.  Once the creek was channelized, the mosaic of habitats was converted to agricultural lands supporting feed crops and a dairy farm.  Agriculture operations occurred for almost 100 years until the property was purchased by USFW in 1996.  Technical assistance is needed to develop a complete engineered design for restoration of lower-Chicken Creek that accommodates the refuges desire to maintain an existing diversion that supports emergent marsh management while improving Upper-Willamette River steelhead rearing habitat in Chicken Creek and surrounding floodplain.  The preferred site restoration alternative was identified through a process to create a Comprehensive Conservation Plan and Environmental Assessment for the refuge.  This alternative emphasizes restoring historic connection of 1.5 miles of lower-Chicken Creek to the Tualatin River.  Project design will be used to support future permitting, full restoration fundraising, and project implementation.  OWEB funds are requested for project management; in-house personnel for topographic survey, map production and engineering design; and fiscal administration.  Project partners include Ducks Unlimited and USFWS.

This 92-acre property is located in the South Fork Yamhill River floodplain between the Amity Oaks, Yamhill Oaks and Willamette River Floodplain Conservation Opportunity Areas.  A perpetual conservation easement was recently purchased on the property through the Willamette Wildlife Mitigation Program and is held by Ducks Unlimited.  Majority of the site has been cleared, drained, and farmed since Euro-American settlement.  This site has opportunities for restoring multiple Oregon Conservation Strategy habitats including riparian forest, emergent wetlands, forested wetlands, and oak savanna.   These habitats will benefit ESA-listed steelhead in addition to declining reptiles, amphibians, and priority avian species.  Technical assistance is needed to finish a topographic survey, collect baseline data, coordinate with stakeholders, complete restoration design, and prepare site specific management plan.  Currently, specific design elements include removing a large barrier to off-channel steelhead habitat, restoring emergent wetland hydrology, and restoring forested wetland and oak savanna habitats.  OWEB funds are requested for project management, in-house personnel for survey and data collection, travel, equipment, and fiscal administration.  Project partners include landowner, ODFW, Yamhill Watershed Council, and Ducks Unlimited.

Project Name: Upper Price Creek Barrier Removal and Fish Habitat Enhancement
Project Summary: Price Creek is a tributary to the Luckiamute River in the Maxfield Creek sub-basin in northern Benton County and a Willamette Model Watershed basin.  Maxfield Creek supports ESA-listed winter steelhead, Coho, and cutthroat trout; however, upper Price Creek currently is inaccessible to anadromous fish.  Proposed project will replace two perched, undersized culverts on private timber land providing fish access to approximately 1.2 additional miles of quality habitat and leave Price Creek barrier free; and place approximately 30 log structures along two stream miles to enhance instream habitat in areas where channel is entrenched due to lack of instream large wood.  Pre- and Post- project surveys will be conducted through the Model Watershed Program to monitor changes in channel features and substrate.  OWEB funds are requested for project management, in-house personnel, contracted services, supplies and materials, and fiscal administration.  Project partners include USFWS, Meyer Memorial Trust, and Luckiamute Watershed Council.

Located on the lower Clackamas River, Fishers Bend is the focus of a cooperative multi-stakeholder effort to improve ecological habitat value for aquatic and terrestrial species, improve water quality, and maximize floodplain connectivity.  Primary project goal is to create off-channel rearing habitat for threatened juvenile salmonids at critical life cycle stages and provide refuge at elevated storm flows by reactivating an alcove and connecting the mainstem with the floodplain at lower flows, installing large wood structures in the 850 lineal foot alcove to add habitat complexity, and restoring native trees and shrubs while managing invasive weeds to provide aquatic and wildlife habitat benefits.  OWEB funds are requested for project management, in-house personnel, contracted services, travel, supplies and materials, outreach, fiscal administration, reporting, and plant establishment.  Project partners include Clackamas County Parks, ODFW, OHSU, PSU, USFS and Clackamas River Basin Council.

Wind Creek is a tributary of Mill Creek located in the Yamhill watershed, a Conservation Opportunity Area, and a Timber Conservation Zone.  Proposed project will replace an undersized culvert identified as a priority barrier restricting access to 4 miles of high-quality spawning and rearing habitat for native resident cutthroat trout, sculpin, and western brook lamprey; and interrupts gravel and wood recruitment.  The culvert will be replaced with a bridge that will allow for complete fish passage and improve natural stream process and function.  Project builds on downstream fish passage barrier removal completed by Weyerhaeuser and will complete fish passage restoration on Wind Creek.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services, supplies and materials, fiscal administration, and reporting.  Project partners include Weyerhaeuser, ODFW, BLM, and Greater Yamhill Watershed Council.

Rowell Creek, a tributary of Gooseneck Creek in the Mill Creek basin of Yamhill watershed, supports spawning and rearing habitat for salmonids.  Proposed project will design a replacement stream crossing for a culvert maintained by Polk County, which is currently a barrier to juvenile and adult fish passage.  Project builds on completed fish passage barrier assessment and prioritization, which identified this culvert as a high priority since it restricts access to 4 miles of fish habitat.  Potential design solutions include culvert replacement, bottomless culvert, or bridge.  Selected final design will meet ODFW fish passage criteria and Polk County road standards while maintaining a natural stream morphology.  OWEB funds are requested for project management, contracted services, travel, supplies and materials, production, and fiscal administration.  Project partners include Polk County, BLM, ODFW, and Greater Yamhill Watershed Council.

Project Name: Crystal Springs (Bybee & Glenwood) Culvert Replacement and Habitat Restoration
Project Summary: Crystal Springs Creek is 2.7 miles in length and is the largest tributary, by flow, in the Johnson Creek watershed.  Until recently, juvenile salmonid fish passage was impeded by 9 culverts.  To date, 7 of the 9 culverts are replaced or abandoned, leaving only 2 culverts restricting upstream passage of juvenile salmonids.  Replacing these culverts will complete efforts by City of Portland to restore fish passage and habitat in Crystal Springs Creek, connecting the lower 1.8 miles with completed restoration in the upper 0.9 miles.  Project will improve access for ESA-listed Chinook, Coho, and steelhead.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services to construct 2 culvert replacements.  Project partners include Metro, USFWS, and City of Portland.

Salmonid abundance and distribution in Milk Creek, a tributary to the Molalla River, is poorly documented.    A Year 2 Rapid Bio-Assessment (RBA) will provide trend analysis and quantify abundance and distribution of ESA-listed spring Chinook, winter steelhead, Coho, resident rainbow, and cutthroat trout species in 60 stream miles of the Milk Creek basin.  The 2012 Milk Creek inventory was unable to describe distributions of Coho because of extremely low adult escapement over Willamette Falls in 2011.  Without significant adult escapement the relationships between juvenile distribution and habitat preference are impossible to understand.  The Willamette Falls escapement for adult Coho in 2013 looks like a record run of over 20,000; making 2014 an ideal year to conduct the second Milk Creek RBA.  Data will be used to determine basin scale limiting factors, prioritize stream reaches, and guide development of a long-term strategy of prioritized prescriptions designed to restore system functions while optimizing use of limited restoration dollars.  Without clear understanding of how salmonids utilize specific reaches of Milk Creek for incubation, summer, and winter rearing; it is difficult to implement restoration actions that directly address current limitations.  OWEB funds are requested for project management, contracted services, production, and fiscal administration.  Project partners include ODFW, BLM, Native Fish Society, and Molalla River Watch.

Project Name: Lower Molalla River Floodplain Restoration and Demonstration
Project Summary: Project includes 2 private properties in the lower and middle Molalla River.  The recent Molalla River Restoration Action Plan identified priority side-channel and floodplain areas currently straightened, blocked, or lacking functional floodplain vegetation with potential for providing high quality rearing habitat for ESA-listed salmon and steelhead, especially during high flows.  Proposed project addresses sites identified in this plan by restoring off-channel floodplain habitat through large wood placement and riprap removal; and restoring and maintaining riparian vegetation on 8.5 acres along a side-channel and the Molalla River.  OWEB funds are requested for pre-implementation, project management, contracted services, supplies and materials, fiscal administration, and reporting.  Project partners include landowners, Clackamas County SWCD, Molalla High School, ODFW, and Molalla River Watch.

Project Name: Middle and Upper Marys Rapid Bio Assessment and Landowner Recruitment
Project Summary: The Middle and Upper Marys River provides habitat for coastal cutthroat trout and Pacific lamprey as well as other native fish species.  The Marys River Preliminary Watershed Assessment recommended additional assessments be conducted to improve cutthroat trout distribution data and determine riparian area condition in relationship to land use.  Past Watershed Council work in adjacent areas have prompted strong landowner interest in the Upper Marys; however, the Council lacks ground-based understanding of habitat limitations in the Middle and Upper Marys River to confidently direct landowners to appropriate restoration strategies.  Technical assistance is needed to conduct a synthesis of existing information about the area, a field-based rapid bio-assessment to fill key knowledge gaps, and validate older and remotely-gathered data.  This assessment will provide landscape-scale understanding of watershed dynamics, limitations, and restoration opportunities that will be used to develop a map-based, prioritized restoration strategy in collaboration with landowners and funding partners.  This systems-based understanding of fish distribution and habitat potential will provide the Council a systemic understanding of highest value restoration opportunities prior to investing in landowner recruitment and site-specific projects.  OWEB funds are requested for project management; contracted services to support landowner outreach, field survey, data analysis, development and presentation of final report to the community and development of specific restoration proposals; travel; production; and fiscal administration.  Project partners include landowners, Benton County, Oregon State University Lamprey Project, ODFW, and Marys River Watershed Council.

The 16-acre Lane Community College wetlands, located in the Russel Creek floodplain, is a priority open space anchor identified in the Willamette River Open Space Vision and Action Plan.  Russel Creek has been impacted by loss of wetland ecosystems due to urban development and loss of native species due to invasive species encroachment; and could be further impacted by future expansion of the City of Eugenes Urban Growth Boundary.  The proposed LCC Russel Creek Restoration Plan will enable the Community College to begin aligning its open space management practices with those of neighboring landowners, such as The Nature Conservancy, Lane County (Friends of Buford Park and Mt. Pisgah), and City of Eugene.  Technical assistance is needed for a baseline environmental inventory and restoration plan for the wetland parcel.  The resulting document will provide best management practices, timelines, and targets that support protection and improvement of this site, ultimately improving an important component of this 4,000+ acre complex of open space.  OWEB funds are requested for project management, in-house personnel, contracted services, travel, supplies and materials, equipment, and fiscal administration.  Project partners include Coast Fork Willamette Watershed Council, TNC, Lane County, and Lane Community College.

Tryon Creek watershed is located in southwest Portland.  Historically it supported a number of native fish species, many of which are now extirpated or rare.  Passage barriers, especially Highway 43, and degraded habitat are believed to be the cause of fish declines.  Proposed project will continue efforts begun in 2012 to develop a baseline watershed characterization, monitor and evaluate effectiveness of restoration (including improvements to the Highway 34 crossing), and establish a long-term citizen-based monitoring program.
