Data collection will include annual basic habitat surveys, photopoints, and macroinvertebrates; monthly water quality grab samples of turbidity, conductivity, and bacteria; and continuous temperature monitoring in 12 locations.  Results from this data collection coupled with fish surveys by USFWS will inform plans for improving the Highway 43 crossing and prioritizing future restoration efforts.  OWEB funds are requested for in-house personnel, contracted services, travel, supplies and materials, production, equipment, and fiscal administration.  Project partners include Friends of Tryon Creek, Tryon Creek State Park Natural Area, ODEQ, USFWS, Willamette Riverkeepers, and Tryon Creek Watershed Council.

Johnson Creek Watershed is a Conservation Opportunity Area and supports Lower Columbia Coho, Chinook, steelhead, and resident cutthroat trout populations.  Recent OWEB-funded fish surveys found that nearly all tributaries of Johnson Creek are inhabited by salmonids and other native fish.  However, no fish were detected in nearly a dozen reaches with good habitat, indicating that downstream barriers are likely limiting fish access to quality habitat.  The Johnson Creek Watershed Council is currently assessing 340 publicly- and privately-owned potential fish passage barriers in partnership with 6 jurisdictions that manage stream culverts and ODFW.  Technical assistance is needed to rank barriers for removal using the new APASS (Anadromous Fish Passage) Optimization Model, share results with stakeholders, and provide landowners assistance with implementing top-ranked removal project to cost effectively restore habitat connectivity for ESA-listed salmonids.  Conceptual designs with cost estimates for removal will be developed for the top 20 privately-owned barriers, which will lead to restoration of fish passage at two privately-owned priority culverts in 2015, as well, as future fish passage projects.  OWEB funds are request for project management, in-house personnel, contracted services, and fiscal administration.  Project partners include East Multnomah SWCD; Cities of Portland and Gresham; ODFW, Clackamas County, Metro, Johnson Creek Inter-Jurisdictional Committee, and Johnson Creek Watershed Council.

Project Name: Cedar Creek Riparian Enhancement Phase I
Project Summary: Cedar Creek drains 11 square miles to the north, south and east of the City of Springfield.  This McKenzie River tributary is a Conservation Opportunity Area supporting spring Chinook, cutthroat trout, Oregon chub, Pacific lamprey, and Western pond turtle.  The lower 8 miles of Cedar Creek flows through the McKenzie floodplain and includes annual and seasonal side-channels of the river.  Aquatic and riparian habitats have been altered by historic and modern land use practices associated with residential development, agriculture, and logging.  Riparian areas have been reduced in size or eliminated, and the vegetation is dominated by nonnative plant species, including Himalayan blackberry and reed canary grass.  Proposed 8-acre project on multiple private properties builds on previous work and connects with a McKenzie River Trust property.  Restoration efforts will manage invasive vegetation, establish native trees and shrubs over 5 years, and monitor plant establishment.  OWEB funds are requested for pre-implementation, project management, contracted services, travel, supplies and materials, outreach, fiscal administration, reporting, and plant establishment.  Project partners include landowners and McKenzie Watershed Council.

A 10-year watershed action plan will be developed and adopted in cooperation with partner agencies and organizations, and the public.  Plan will be prepared by Council staff collaborating with Council partners, and will rely on consultation with stakeholders and review of previously published research, assessments and studies related to the McKenzie watershed.  OWEB funds are requested for project management, in-house personnel, contracted services for GIS, travel, production, and fiscal administration.  Project partners include USFS, Army Corps of Engineers, BLM, ODFW, Eugene Water and Electric Board, Springfield Utility Board, Cities of Eugene and Springfield, McKenzie River Trust, Weyerhaeuser, International Paper, Wildish Sand and Gravel, Rice Family Farms, McKenzie Flyfishers, Northwest Steelheaders, Mohawk Watershed Partnership, Cedar Creek Partnership, McKenzie Schools, Lane County, and Upper Willamette SWCD.

Project Name: Upper Ferguson Creek Fish Passage and Habitat Enhancement
Project Summary: Ferguson Creek located west of Junction City in the Long Tom watershed is a Meyer Memorial Trust Willamette Model Watershed and a Conservation Opportunity Area.  Proposed project will address two fish passage barriers on tributaries to Ferguson Creek, connecting 1.5 miles of spawning habitat to a complex of beaver ponds and providing diverse habitat required for all life-stages of cutthroat trout and lamprey.  Perched, undersized culverts will be replaced with stream-simulation culverts.  Project will also enhance 1.5 miles of mainstem stream habitat where historic forestry practices led to poor instream conditions for fish.  Conifer logs will be placed to increase abundance and residual depth of pools, trap spawning gravels and organic matter, enhance physical cover in pools, and increase floodplain connectivity.  Effectiveness monitoring conducted through the regional Willamette Model Watershed program will include thalweg profiles, substrate surveys, and riparian zone assessments.  OWEB funds are requested pre-implementation, project management, in-house personnel, contracted services, supplies and materials, fiscal administration, and reporting.  Project partners include landowner, Lane County, Weyerhaeuser, USFWS, BLM, Meyer Memorial Trust, and Long Tom Watershed Council.

Forest Park, owned by City of Portland, is a 5,200-acre mixed conifer forest covering 8 miles of the eastern slope of the Tualatin Mountains overlooking the Willamette River and Multnomah Channel.  Directly adjacent to the park is approximately 851 acres of private property that has its own conservation program referred to as the Perimeter Program.  The Greater Forest Park Conservation Initiative is a 20-year collaborative roadmap to restore and protect this combined public and private land within the Greater Forest Park Ecosystem.  Watershed health is currently impacted by extensive populations of invasive plant species displacing native vegetation.  Proposed project will treat approximately 42 acres of invasive species within priority Perimeter Program areas using chemical and mechanical treatments followed by planting native vegetation.  All landowners have signed Conservation Plans or permission forms for weed treatments.  OWEB funds are requested for pre-implementation, project management, in-house personnel, contracted services, supplies and materials, and fiscal administration.  Project partners include landowners, West Multnomah SWCD, City of Portland, and The Forest Park Conservancy.

Rickreall Creek supports populations of Coho salmon, winter steelhead, and resident cutthroat trout from its mouth at the Willamette through its upper reaches.  The BLMs Rickreall Creek Watershed Enhancement EA (2012) found the main channel and many tributaries above the dam to be deficient in large woody debris (LWD) needed for habitat diversity.  Historic management practices, including logging operations, road construction, and stream cleaning, have led to a lack of in-stream LWD, spawning gravel, and pools.  Riparian stands in the project area currently have insufficient future large wood recruitment.  Proposed project will place approximately 600 pieces of wood in 45 structures along 6 miles of stream above Aaron Mercer Reservoir, which will meet or exceed NMFS benchmarks for LWD stocking.  OWEB funds are requested for project management, in-house personnel, contracted services, travel, supplies and materials, outreach, fiscal administration, and effectiveness monitoring to mobilize a helicopter wood placement.  Project partners include Hancock Forest Management, BLM, USFWS, and ODFW.

Grantee: North Clackamas Parks and Recreation Dist (NCPRD)
Project Summary: Spring Park is located on the lower Willamette River within the City of Milwaukie in Essential Salmonid Habitat and a Conservation Opportunity Area.  Human disturbances associated with industrial uses, transportation, and urban development have impacted alcove, floodplain, riparian, wetland, and Oregon white oak habitats by altering hydrology, increasing soil erosion, increasing water temperature, introducing invasive species, and decreasing habitat value for sensitive plant and wildlife species.  Proposed project will include education and outreach; re-routing current trail out of the wetlands and restoring those wetlands; restoring alcove habitat including creating wildlife overlook, riparian revegetation, and placing large wood; and restoring upland Oregon white oak habitat.  Restoring off-channel and floodplain rearing habitat complexity and diversity will benefit ESA-listed fish.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services for large wood placement.  Project partners include City of Milwaukie, TNC, ODFW, Metro, USFS, OPRD, Island Station Neighborhood District Association, Willamette Riverkeepers, and North Clackamas Parks and Recreation.

Project seeks to engage middle and high school teachers and students in Portland and the mid-Columbia Gorge.  Project components include workshops for Salmon Watch teachers, volunteers, and agency experts to train them for working with students in the classroom, on field trips and with community service projects; classroom instruction utilizing multidisciplinary curriculum covering watersheds, stream ecology, salmonid biology, human impacts on the environment, and importance of salmon to Native American culture; community service projects with hands-on watershed restoration projects, stream surveys, art projects, teaching younger students about watersheds and salmon, and making presentations to community groups.  OWEB funds are requested for project management, contracted services, and travel.  Project partners include Portland General Electric, Trout Unlimited, Pacific States Marine Fisheries Commission, BLM, USFS, Bill Healy Foundation, USACE, USFW, and World Salmon Center.

Project Name: Land Conservation Forecasting: Optimizing Sagebrush Conservation Practices
Project Summary: This project would look at various conservation practices across different ecological sites on the Juniper Hills Preserve (TNC) for the purpose of targeting practices for juniper treatment.  The project would create a template for cost-effective treatments to restore watershed processes across Oregons sagebrush-steppe plant communities.

This application is to secure the second half of Phase 4 funding of the Tumalo Feed Canal piping project.  In October 2012, the applicant requested an OWEB grant of $1.5 million to help fund  the entire  Phase 4 project.  The Regional Review Team recommended OWEB fund $800,000 for Phase 4, and OWEB staff also recommended $800,000 for installation of 5000 feet of pipe to complete Phase 4.  At the March Board meeting, as a result of public testimony from the applicant, the Board awarded $750,000 and directed staff to adjust the costs that OWEB would pay for, effectively funding less than the 5,000 feet of pipe recommended by the RRT and staff.

This project would continue a series of watershed improvements in Dry Creek, a tributary to Fifteenmile Creek in Wasco County that hosts ESA listed steelhead.  The project would construct ten in-stream structures that scour the channel to provide pools and provide habitat for native fish, install six open bottom culverts at intermittent stream crossings on tributary draws entering Dry Creek and install four arch culverts at farm road crossings over Dry Creek.

Project Name: Rock Creek Piping and Flow Enhancement Phase I
Project Summary: This project would install 9,295 feet of 34-inch HDPE pipe in the Rock Creek Irrigation District's main feed canal.  The project will save 1 cfs of 1870 senior water right in Threemile Creek currently being lost in the ditch and .5 cfs of that will be converted to an instream water right.  The stream is over-appropriated and goes dry below the irrigation diversions in July.  The project is located in the White River watershed of Wasco County.

This project east of Prineville and along the Crooked River upstream of Prineville Reservoir would remove two abandoned irrigation diversion dams that block fish passage, retrofit two active irrigation diversions for horizontal fish screens and construct several toe-wood habitat structures in Horse Heaven Creek and the Crooked River.

This project would place a person in the Harney County that would work with landowners and conservation interest in Lake and Harney County to implement existing programs to restore wetland habitats.  This region is a critical staging area for spring migrating waterbirds.

Project Name: Klamath Marsh NWR River and Floodplain - Phase II
Project Summary: This project would restore the natural hydrology and wetland habitat to Klamath Marsh Wildlife Refuge and the Williamson River in north Klamath County.  The 41,000 acre refuge was converted to grazing lands in the early 1900s when 20,000 acres were ditched, leveed, drained and pumped.  The miles of incised drains have lowered the water table and changed the composition of the vegetation communities and interspersion ratio of vegetation and open water.  What used to be open water wocus areas is now predominately tules, sedges and rushes.  The marsh was acquired by the National Wildlife Refuge System in 1987.

This project would complete an assessment and design treatment alternatives and recruit landowners for site specific forest restoration treatments to improve forest health and fire resistance in a 10,000 acre area in northern Klamath County along the Williamson River, Spring Creek and Larkin Creek, in the vicinity of Collier State Park.  The area is impacted by bark beetle caused tree mortality.  While the streams have undergone some habitat restoration work and are in good shape, the area ponderosa pine and aspen are in poor condition due to over-stocked forest and invasive lodgepole pine.  The area has some rural residential- forest lands fire interface issues.

This project would improve floodplain connectivity, riparian conditions, fish passage and instream habitat along three miles of Horse Heaven Creek and three-quarters of a mile along the Crooked River at their confluence.  This sub-watershed is about six miles above Prineville Reservoir in Crook County.

This proposal would form a Youth Watershed Council involving students from The Crook County High School, Culver High School and the Redmond Proficiency Academy.  They would meet weekly over one school year to learn about watershed processes and issues, develop a restoration project, seek appropriate funding to implement the project and implement the project.  They would provide a report(s) to the Crooked River Watershed Council.

This project would analyze water quality, flow, ownership, water rights, infrastructure and noxious weeds associated with this 15 mile long drainage on the western edge of Crook County.  The creek is normally dry, but  carries tailwater runoff from approximately 9,000 acres of multiple agricultural properties in the Powell Butte area.  The water quality is degraded and it contributes to degraded water quality in the Crooked River where efforts have been underway for the past five years to reintroduce steelhead trout and chinook salmon.  The technical design solution will include topographic surveying and engineered, stamped designs from a contracted engineering firm.  These solution alternatives may include tailwater recovery systems, artificial wetlands and artificial log/debris jams.

Project Name: Upper Deep Creek Fish Passage Design & Stream Reconnaissance Plan
Project Summary: This project would study existing irrigation diversions in Deep Creek, east of Lakeview, to determine the best alternatives to provide upstream and downstream fish passage to fish species unique to the Warner Watershed, including the Warner redband trout (federal species of concern).  While the main focus of the work will be on one large diversion, the study will also provide recommendations on another five irrigation diversions on five tributary streams.  The barriers prevent access to several miles of stream headwaters.

This project would take out invasive juniper trees within 200 yards of Muddy Creek for a distance of 13 miles and it would also treat noxious weeds and reseed native grasses within the treated area.  Muddy Creek is a tributary to the John Day River.  This is on the former  Rajneesh Purim property, the Big Muddy Ranch, upstream of Clarno in Wasco County.

This project would evaluate and prioritize 25 wells in the Mosier area for commingling (taking water from more than one aquifer) and repair.  Groundwater levels have been documented as declining for over 40 years.  In 2012, the USGS documented that the commingling of aquifers due to improperly cased wells accounts for up to 90% of the water declines.  Groundwater levels have dropped below stream elevations in many reaches reducing baseflow and cool water refugia.  Due to a natural barrier near the Columbia River, Mosier Creek is host to a unique species of cutthroat trout.

This project would fund a LiDAR Survey of the White River Watershed, a tributary of the Deschutes River in the vicinity of Tygh Valley.  The survey will include every irrigation ditch, reservoir and irrigated field in the watershed.  This would be done in cooperation with the USGS and the Oregon LiDAR Consortium.  The survey will enable the evaluation of storage, delivery and application systems on 27,660 acres of irrigated lands.  The area has been designated for NRCSs EQIP funding focus area.

This project would attempt to explain the cause and the effect of the low lake level of Lake Abert, a unique saline lake in Lake County.  This project would monitor the water level, water chemistry, in-flow, precipitation and evaporation rates and the major biological components (shoreflies, brine shrimp and cladocerans) and the waterfowl and shorebirds that use Abert Lake.

Project Name: Klamath Marsh NWR River and Floodplain - Phase I
Project Summary: Klamath Marsh NWR River and Floodplain Project  Phase I  This project within the Refuge in northern Klamath County seeks to restore the natural hydrology in the northern part of the Refuge where 20 miles of incised irrigation ditches with headgates have altered the course of the Williamson River into and through the marsh.  The decreased water table and lack of floodplain connectivity and water storage has altered the vegetation composition and reduced wildlife values.

Located 20 miles north of Adrian, the Muddy Waters project proposes to convert 57 acres of furrow-irrigated field to sprinkler irrigation. Proposed components are installing 1,200-feet of 8-inch mainline; a permanent 20-HP pump and a 60-inch bubbler. The existing cement ditch will be removed and that area recontoured into the field. A 1,232-foot Zimmatic pivot will be installed to irrigate most of the acres.  Pivots will use 25 percent less water than the current furrow irrigation.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (11%), materials (79%), administration (7%) and monitoring (2%). The landowner is the cost-share partner.

Owyhee Watershed Council (OWC) proposes to convert two fields totally 125 total acres from furrow-flood irrigation to sprinkler-pivot in the Blackjack Conservation Priority area. The field has 1,320-foot furrows and when planted to corn contributes excess tailwater.  Project components for the lower field are install:  2,040 feet of 8-inch mainline for a 1,216-foot pivot to irrigate 60 acres and a flow meter.  The upper field will have 1,000 feet of 8-inch mainline for a 645-foot pivot and a flowmeter to irrigate 35 acres and a wheelline will irrigate the remaining 30 acres. OWEB funds are requested for project management (5%), contracted services (1%), materials- pipe, bubblers, pumps (84%) and administration (9%). The landowner is the cost-share partner.

The Kingman project is located north of Adrian. Proposed components are installing 3,000 feet of 6-inch mainline to convert an open ditch to pipe; a permanent pump; 3 bridges for canal crossing; a 737-foot pivot to irrigate most of the acres and sprinklers in the corners.  The existing earthen and cement ditches will be recontoured into the field. OWEB funds are requested for project management (5%), contracted services-water-right transfer (1%), materials  (83%), administration (9%) and monitoring (1%).  The landower is the cost-share partner.

The Pelican Landing project is located north of Adrian. Owyhee Watershed Council (OWC) is proposing to convert 55 acres from furrow-flood irrigation to sprinkler-pivot. Tailwater from the field enters a drain that flows into the Snake River approximately 700 feet away. Proposed components are installing 760 feet of 8-inch mainline for the pivot; install 1,140 feet of 4-inch mainline for wheellines; a 701-foot pivot with an end-gun to irrigate 42 acres; wheellines to irrigate 13 acres and 3 permanent pumps. OWEB funds are requested for project management (5%), materials (84%), administration (9%) and monitoring (1%).  The landowner is the cost-share partner.

Located five miles south of Adrian, Owyhee Watershed Council (OWC) proposes to convert 47 acres from furrow-flood irrigation to sprinkler-pivot in the Blackjack Conservation Priority area.  The Owyhee Watershed Council (OWC), South Board of Control Irrigation District and NRCS are developing the Blackjack Conservation Strategy Plan. Project components are install:  1,220 feet of 10-inch pipe mainline for a 679-foot pivot to irrigate 20 acres with gravity pressure supplied from the lateral; 1,220 feet of 8-inch mainline for a 500-foot pivot for 22 acres; 960 feet of 8-inch mainline for a 365-foot pivot for 5 acres and 3 flowmeters. OWEB funds are requested for project management (2%), contracted services (<1%), materials- pipe, bubblers, pumps (87%) and administration (9%). The landowner is the cost-share partner.

Project Name: Upper Fletcher Gulch Water Quality Improvement
Project Summary: The Upper Fletcher project is located 10 miles northwest of Adrian.  Owyhee Watershed Council (OWC) proposes to convert 120 acres from furrow-flood irrigation to sprinkler-pivot. It is located at the top of the Fletcher Pipeline (211-5051) and the steepest property on that project.  Proposed components are installing 1,800 feet of 10-inch pipe to the pump station; 7,100 feet of 8-inch pipe to the pivot from the pump station;  5,682 feet of  perforated metal pipe to collect seepage from the Mitchell Butte lateral; a 982-foot pivot to irrigate 47 acres and a 1,216-foot pivot to irrigate 73 acres. OWEB funds are requested for project management (2%), contracted services  (18%), materials (75%) and administration (4%) and monitoring (<1%). The landowner is the cost-share partner.

The headwaters of the upper Powder include Cracker Creek, Pole Creek, Wind Creek and Silver Creek and are are USFWS-designated critical bull trout streams. PBWC staff will require technical assistance needs. Two members will attend the 2014 Aquatic Inventories training in Corvallis along with ODFWs seasonal crews to insure that data collected conforms to standards. Also, single-pass electrofishing inventory will be conducted and data collection, data storage and analysis. OWEB funds are requested for in-house personnel -survey crews (77%), travel - ODFW training (13%), supplies/equipment (5%) and administration (5%).  PBWC and USFS are the cost-share partners.

Project Name: North Fork Malheur River Stream Restoration
Project Summary: The project is located on the North Fork Malheur River at its confluence with the Malheur River near Juntura.  Streambank conditions are adversely affected by Highway 20 and bridge, an abandoned railroad grade and a power pole.  Project components include install 25 trees for every 100 feet of toe-wood structure; shape banks with an excavator; plant 900 feet of coyote, Pacific, Lemmon, yellow and booth willows and exclude livestock from the planted areas for two growing seasons.  In addition, 40 willow clumps will be strategically placed.  Watershed benefits include decreased bank erosion, improved riparian vegetation and improved aquatic habitat. OWEB funds are requested for project management/pre-implementation ( 24%), contracted services  (62%), administration (9%) and monitoring (<1%).  Idaho Power, Baker SWCD and the landowner are cost-share partners.

Wallowa SWCD in Enterprise is seeking to hire technical assistance to analyze juniper stands in Wallowa County. Sites will be selected in advance by the SWCD and NRCS.  Funds are sought to hire a consultant to ascertain if the Rocky Mountain juniper (RMJ)is adversely affecting ecological and hydrologic aspects in their present sites. In order to receive NRCS cost-share for juniper removal, the local NRCS office needs to ascertain if RMJ is impacting the sites and affecting watershed health.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted service (63%), travel (30%) and administration (7%).  Wallowa SWCD and NRCS are cost-share partners.

Project Name: Harney Basin Groundwater Project - Data Refinement
Project Summary: The purpose of the project is to redefine the hydrologic model in two areas of declining groundwater levels in Harney County in order to better understand groundwater flows, recharge and withdrawal.  The refinement of the hydrogeologic in these two areas will be an extension and refinement of a recently completed hydrogeologic model and geodatabase. Harney County Watershed Council (HCWC) seeks to hire a hydrogeologist.  Outcomes include a better understanding of hydrogeology; identify and map sedimentary facies that are important productive aquifers within regional hydrogeologic units that were defined in the recent basin-wide groundwater study. OWEB funds are requested for contracted services (96%), travel (2%) and administration (2%).  Cost-share partners include Watching Cat Inc., OWRD and HBWC.

The 13th  Avenue Wedge Enhancement project is located 30 miles west of Ontario on Highway 26.  The project area is a 12.5-acre field irrigated with gated pipe on 3% slope. Proposed actions include installing one pivot to sprinkler-irrigate the 10 acre-field. Project components include: installing 500 feet of cable con wire from power pole to pump; install a 533-foot pivot; 460 feet of 6-inch mainline to convey water from the lateral to the pivot point; 6-inch flowmeter ; galvanized Clemons filter to clean the water before pivot and big guns. OWEB funds are requested for project management (9%), contracted services (<1%), materials- pipe,  pumps (75%), administration (8%) and monitoring (6%). The landowner and NRCS are the cost-share partners.

The Beam Creek project is located west of Ironside near El Dorado pass. The project area is 585 acres of mostly Stage II and III juniper. Project components include juniper cutting using a chainsaw 585 acres and seeding on 250 acres where necessary to supplement present vegetation. A grazing plan will be developed.  A prescribed burn is planned in six or seven years. OWEB funds are requested for project management/layout (4%), juniper removal, lop and scatter (79%), seed (9%), mileage (1%) and administration (9%).

Located 42 miles west on Ontario on Highway 20 near Harper on the Malheur River, a 37-acre parcel is currently flood-irrigated with a ditch conveying return flow from neighboring 158 acres directly into the Malheur. Project components include installed 5 J-hook barbs each with 12 rootwads; install 36-inch rock for the barb foundation; plant 1,500 live-willow cutting around the 5 barbs and install 100 willow bundles in each barb; plant 50 willow clumps along 1,000 feet of riverbank and construct a pumpback. OWEB funds are requested for project management/engineering (23%), contracted services  (41%),  materials (27%) and administration (9%) and monitoring (<1%). The landowner and Burnt River SWCD are cost-share partners.

Located 16 miles west of Vale in the Willow Creek basin, irrigation-induced erosion is adversely affecting water quality from a 30-acre, flood-irrigated field. Project components include installing:  2,480 feet of 6-inch mainline for the two pivots to convey water from the bubbler to the pivots; a 7.5-hp permanent pump; bubbler to clean the water before entering the mainline and a 498-foot pivots and a 642-foot pivot. OWEB funds are requested for materials (85%), project management (4%), administration (5%) and monitoring (3%). The landowner and NRCS through the AWEP (Agricultural Watershed Enhancement Program) are the cost-share partners.

Malheur SWCD is proposing a constructed wetland to improve water quality inputs from the Slide Drain, which has a watershed size of over 1,700 acres and flows 20 cfs.  Project components include constructing six separate wetland cells and reshape approximately 35,100 cubic yards of material; install an inlet/outlet structure to control flow between ponds; plant aquatics and transplant live plants (9,000 total) and fill wetland and vary water levels to insure plant survival.  The area around the pond edges would be reseeded.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services (90%), project management (<2%) and administration (7%).

The Mendiola pipeline is an earthen lateral for irrigation water conveyance for 920 acres near Adrian.  Due to the high total cost, the lateral is proposed to be installed in functional segments.  Determining the functional length of a segment was crucial in considering both cost and maintaining the integrity of the delivery system. Project components include installing:  9,100 feet of 30-inch; 1,320 feet of 12-inch;  200 feet of 10inch and 200 feet of 8-inch pipe; a 24-inch gate valve; 3 flowmeters and various valves. OWEB funds are requested for project management (<1%),  materials- pipe, and fittings (98%) and administration (1%). Landowners, OID, and the Bureau of Reclamation are cost-share partners.

Kettle Water Quality Improvement project is in the Succor Creek drainage 14 south of Adrian on the stateline. Owyhee Watershed Council (OWC) proposes to convert 56 acres from furrow-flood irrigation to sprinkler-pivot. Project components include installing 1,340 of 10-inch mainline for the pivot; one 1,300-foot pivot  and flowmeter. OWEB funds are requested for project management (5%), contracted services (1%), materials- pipe, bubblers, pumps (85%) and administration (9%). The landowner is the cost-share partner.

The Mahogany project is located north of Jordan Valley west of Highway 95.  There are 118 acres of intensively flood-irrigated pasture that is also used a winter-feeding area.  Project components include installing: 1982-feet of 8-inch pipe for pressurized mainline with risers in the east field; 1,900 feet of 10-inch gravity line to bubbler; 1,315 feet of 12-inch gravity line to pump station in the west field; 1,320 feet of 6-inch mainline with risers in the west field; three 4-inch by 1,280-foot wheellines, bubbler, a 30-hp and a 25-hp permanent pumps.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (5%), materials (84%), administration (9%) and monitoring (<1%). The landowner is the cost-share partner.

The project is located three north of Burns in the Harney basin. The project proposes to construct a pumpback system to collect excess water and pump it back to the top of the field to be re-used to irrigate hay fields.  The applicant is proposing to utilize existing ditches to divert 3 cfs; capture runoff water from the fields; install 3,00 feet of 10 and 12-inch pipe; install 250 feet of 20-inch mainline from the pond to the cistern and install a 40- and 75- hp pumps. OWEB funds are requested for layout and project management 4%, contracted services (17%),  materials (69%), administration (7%) and monitoring (3%). The landowner is the cost-share partner.

Clear Creek in the Brownlee Subbasin near Halfway contains critical bull trout habitat. Some sections of Clear Creek were artificially straightened and adversely affected by significant flood events in 2006 and 2010 creating even wider channels. Riparian vegetation is lacking in many areas. PBWC is seeking technical assistance that will address in-stream habitat improvement, grazing and wildlife management and provide a plan to address increasing channel complexity and riparian health.   Participating partners would be ODFW, Idaho Power, USFS, BLM and PBWC members. OWEB funds are requested for project management (9%), contracted services (85%), travel (3%) and administration (<3%).  PBWC will provide cash and in-kind cost-share.

Project Name: Livestock Grazing Management and Water Quality Improvement
Project Summary: Malheur Watershed Council (MWC) is assisting a Willow Creek landowner on 125 acres of a 265-acre farm which pastures 300 nanny goats with kids and 50 beef heifers. Project components include installing 1,300 feet of 18-inch pipe to replace an earthen irrigation-delivery ditch; 3,300 feet of 12-inch pipe to replace earthen irrigation ditches; 18 gates and 7,000 feet of woven-wire fencing to make 11 smaller pastures from the existing three.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (4%), materials (87%) and administration (8%) and monitoring (<1%).  The landowner and WSID are the cost-share partners and will provide all the installation.

The Bench Ground project is located seven miles east of Vale on 38 acres of farm ground. Project components include installing: 200 feet of 8-inch pipe; a five-foot bubbler; 1,010 feet of 6-inch pipe installed from the bubbler to the pivot point; 1,515 feet of cable-in conduit from the 3-phase power to the pivot point; 7.5-hp permanent pump and 200 feet of 8-inch pipe from the water source to the bubbler.  In addition, approximately 5,000 yards of material will be moved to accommodate pivot travel and will reduce the slope from 12 percent to 8 percent. OWEB funds are requested for project management (15%), engineering (3%), contracted services (33%), materials (37%), travel (1%) and administration (9%). The landowner will provide cash and in-kind cost-share.

The Graham Boulevard project is located two miles west of Vale on 10 acres of uneven bench ground. The property is split into four small fields.  Irrigation runoff is contaminated with high levels of E. coli from the livestock as well as fertilizer residue that drain in the Warm Springs Irrigation District canal. Project components include installing: 1,440 feet of 6-inch pipe; 2,585 feet of 4-inch pipe; 37 riser assemblies with concrete support; concrete thrust blocks and 4 Nelson big guns. Watershed benefits are improved water quality by eliminating runoff and improving irrigation efficiency. OWEB funds are requested for project management (20%), engineering (3%),  materials (65%), travel (<1%) and administration (8%).  The landowner will provide cash and in-kind cost-share.

Lick Creek is southeast of Joseph. An existing culvert on Lick Creek is a fish passage barrier. The technical assistance grant would fund engineering design for the Lick Creek culvert. The culvert will be replaced by an open-bottom structure with a simulated stream channel. OWEB funds are requested for project management (8%), contracted services (83%) and administration (9%). USFS and Wallowa Resources are cost-share partners.  Letters of support were provided from USFS, Nez Perce Tribes (NPT), Grande Ronde Model Watershed and Wallowa Countys Natural Resources Advisory Committee (NRAC).

Whiskey Creek is the largest tributary to the lower Wallowa River and was identified Grande Ronde Subbasin Plan (2004) as a priority for steelhead restoration. Wallowa Resources (WR) will work with Wallowa County to design an open-bottom structure with a simulated stream channel to replace the culvert. OWEB funds are requested for project management (9%), in-house personnel (5%), contracted services (76%) and administration (9%).  Cost-share partners include Wallowa Resources, Wallowa County, ODFW and NPT.

Project Name: Catherine Creek Water Conservation and Irrigation Efficiency
Project Summary: The Catherine Creek Water Conservation Projectis part of a multi-phase effort to improve habitat for ESA-listed spring Chinook salmon, steelhead and bull trout. In 2013, 18 large woody debris structures were installed. Phase II includes riparian corridor enhancement through side channel construction, floodplain connectivity, in-stream complexity and riparian vegetation plantings. This proposed project dovetails into the Phase II construction by constructing two irrigation delivery pipelines to improve irrigation water conveyance. This will assist five landowners to more efficiently irrigate 267 acres. Project components include removing 4  push-up dams between RM 43.4 and 44.8; construct a consolidated diversion structure and fish screen on the north side of Catherine Creek near RM 44.8; install 8,600 feet of pipeline to convey irrigation water; and install large woody debris at various locations.

MLB Ranches west of Juntura has significant juniper encroachment leading to decreased watershed health. The applicant proposes to remove 900 acres of juniper. NRCS will advise on a grazing plan and the seed mixture. ODFW will advise on reseeding to best promote sage-grouse leks. OWEB funds are requested for project management (2%), in-house personnel (1%), mileage (1%), contracted services - juniper removal (79%), materials -seed (9%) and administration (8%). Cost-share partners are the landowner, ODFW and NRCS.  The landowner will lop and scatter juniper slash and apply the seed.

Located 18 miles west of Ontario near Vale, this project proposes to convert 18 acres of flood irrigation to sprinklers and improve conveyance to another 25 acres. Currently 25 acres is sprinkler-irrigated using 2 wheel lines with an above-ground hose as the current conveyance; 10 acres will be converted to solid sets and 8 acres will have K-line pods installed. Project components include installing 1,900 feet of mainline to connect to Lateral 227 for the 25 acres. The K-line (pod)includes 1,500 feet of 4-inch pipe with 2 risers and 2 K-line assemblies. The solid-set system requires 2,800 feet of 4-inch; 1,580 feet of 3-inch and 1,520 feet of 2-inch pipe; 49 5-foot risers and 49 big gun sprinklers.  The wheel line components include 19 4-inch risers, a filter and two Z pipe filters.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (3%), materials (85%) and administration (9%).  The landowner and Malheur SWCD are cost-share partners.

Project Name: Hibbard Gulch Riparian and Water Quality Improvement
Project Summary: Hibbard Gulch near Baker city is a tributary to Salmon Creek, which is a tributary to the Powder River. It is a flashy seasonal stream carrying a large amount of spring runoff becoming a dry channel late in the summer. Project components include installing 2,500 feet of 8-inch mainline to convert from flood to sprinkler irrigation for pasture, hay and alfalfa. Other components include: install 2,400 feet of 4-strand fence; install 100 feet of 2-inch pipe to 1 trough and plant whips and poles along 1,800 feet on the gulch. The proposed plan is for 900 poles, stock and vertical bundles to be planted. OWEB funds are requested for project management (4%), contracted services (32%), materials (55%) and administration (7%). The landowner is the cost-share partner.

Located in Baker County near Halfway, this project is in the Pine Creek drainage adjacent to Lee Creek. Poor water quality is due to livestock having unrestricted access to the riparian area and springs. Fencing will exclude livestock from the wetland/springs; install 4 troughs; pipe 3,500 feet of 2-inch pipe to convey water from the spring to the troughs and seed the areas within the exclosure.  The exclosure will be seeded with Great Basin wildrye, bluebunch wheatgrass, Idaho fescue, tufted hair-grass at a rate of 15 pounds per acre. OWEB funds are requested for project management (5%), contracted services (28%), materials (56%) and administration (7%). The landowner is the cost-share partner.

The French Flat project is located north of Jordan Valley. There are 100 acres of intensively flood-irrigated hay/pasture that is also used as a winter-feeding area.  Project components include installing: 1,400 feet of 8-inch pipe for pressurized mainline with 28 risers assemblies in the east field; 850 feet of 10-inch gravity line to bubbler; 1,320 feet of 12-inch gravity line to pump station in the west field; 1,320 feet of 6-inch mainline with 26 risers in the west field; three 4-inch by 1,280-foot wheel lines, bubbler, a 30-hp and a 25-hp permanent pumps. OWEB funds are requested for project management (4%), contracted services (10%), materials (76%), administration (9%) and monitoring (<1%). The landowner is the cost-share partner.

Located five miles south of Adrian, Owyhee Watershed Council (OWC) proposes to convert 39 acres from furrow-flood irrigation to sprinkler-pivot by installing 2 pivots. Project components are install:  a 10-inch flowmeter; 1,220 feet of 10-inch pipe mainline for a 679-foot pivot to irrigate 21 acres; 1,220 feet of 8-inch mainline to go from pivot 1 to pivot 2 to irrigate 18 acres; 1,240 feet of cable con will go from pivot 1 to 2 and 2,3960 feet of cable con from electrical source to pivot 2 with a 500-foot pivot. OWEB funds are requested for project management (2%), contracted services (25%), materials- pipe, bubblers, pumps (63%) and administration (9%). The landowner is the cost-share partner.

Project Name: Irrigation Canal and Oro Dell Ditch Diversion Consolidation and Water Conservation Project
Project Summary: The Irrigation Canal Company (ICC) and OroDell Ditch diversions are located in the upper Grande Ronde River. The two irrigation systems experience water loss and are fish-passage barriers adversely affecting temperature, water quality and quantity due to the large amount diverted.The proposed technical assistance will fund a qualified engineer to collaborate with ODFW, USFWS, NMFS and the irrigation companies to assess existing conditions. A restoration plan will be developed to provide options to improve fish passage through the diversion structures, conserve water and potentially increase in-stream flow. OWEB funds are requested for contracted services (96%) and administration (4%). Cost-share partners include OroDell Ditch, ICC and OWRD.

Project Name: Phase II - Divide Allotment - 3900 Road Fence
Project Summary: Wallowa Resources and a permittee propose to exclude cattle from Little Sheep Creek, Big Sheep Creek and Salt Creek, tributaries to the Imnaha River, on the Divide Allotment seven miles southeast of Joseph. This application is the continuation of a previous OWEB project (213- 5030) which had insufficient funds to complete the project elements.  Project components of this new project include constructing 3.2 miles of 3-strand, barbed-wire, wildlife friendly fence to exclude cattle from 4 miles of the upper reaches of Little Sheep Creek, 1 mile of most of the upper reaches of Big Sheep Creek and 1 mile of Salt Creek.  OWEB funds are requested for project management (7%) ; materials cattleguards (20%); contracted services- fencing and cattleguard installation (64%), administration and monitoring. Title II funds will purchase the fencing.

This project would replace two perched and undersized culverts on Brown Creek and Buckhorn Creek, both tributaries of Lonerock Creek in Gilliam County. Both culverts are causing downstream bed and bank erosion and both culverts have substantial jump height that are barriers to juvenile and adult fish to access over 16.5 miles of good spawning and rearing habitat. The project would replace both culverts with bottomless pipe arch culverts that incorporate the natural grade and flow in a simulated stream bed. Riparian plantings will accompany the culvert work. Partners include Gilliam East John Day Watershed Council, Gilliam SWCD, Gilliam County Road Department, and ODF&W. OWEB funds will be used for pre-implementation, project management, in-house personnel, travel, supplies/materials, outreach, fiscal administration and post-implementation status reporting.

This project is located in Lone Rock, 20 miles southeast of Condon in Gilliam County.  During irrigation season, an existing push-up dam diversion can prohibit juvenile Redband and steelhead connectivity to vital up- and downstream habitat. The proposed solution is to build a juvenile fish-friendly diversion structure that continues to provide the legal water-right for the irrigator. Partners include the landowner and the Gilliam SWCD. OWEB funds would be used for project management, contracted services, supplies/materials, fiscal administration and post-implementation status reporting.

Project Name: Walla Walla Nursery Irrigation Recycling Project
Project Summary: The Walla Walla Nursery is located on the Oregon side of the stateline road that runs between Oregon and Washington borders, just north of Milton Freewater in Umatilla County. Irrigation water comes from the Big Springs Branch, a tributary of the Walla Walla River. This project proposes to increase in-stream flows by reducing irrigation withdrawals; and reduce contamination from return flows from the nursery watering system back into the Big Springs branch and ultimately the Walla Walla River. The Big Springs ditch is an open unlined ditch that supplies approximately 80 acre feet of water during the irrigation season for the 35 acres of containerized nursery stock. It is estimated that approximately 40% of the applied irrigation water runs off the tarps under the plants. The proposed project would capture runoff at the low point in the nursery in a catchment pond and then be treated and piped back through the irrigation system to be reused. Partners include the landowner and Umatilla County SWCD. OWEB funds would be used for pre-implementation, project management, contracted services, travel, fiscal administration and post-implementation status reporting.

This project is located on private property immediately adjacent to the town of Monument and alongside the North Fork John Day River in Grant County. A historic mill pond site is now a 9.7 acre wetland separated from the river by a narrow levee. Severe bank erosion puts a section of this levee at risk of catastrophic failure from future high flow events while continuing to contribute sediment loads into the river. Levee failure could also result in the draining of this wetland site. An assessment of the wetland and levee was conducted through an OWEB technical assistance grant (213-6020) resulting in alternatives analysis on: 1) No action, 2) modification or lowering of the levee, and 3 protection of the levee. The landowner was clear in that his goal was to protect the ponds and wetlands. After several meetings and much discussion,the Technical Review Team selected a bio-engineered bank protection along 50 feet of the levee and 200 feet of large wood habitat structure to prevent future erosion while also providing in-stream habitat and preserving the wetland. This project would implement the selected restoration alternative that also includes stabilizing the existing wetland overflow channel and conducting invasive plant control in and around the wetland. Partners include the landowner Oregon Dept. of Fish and Wildlife (ODFW), Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs (CTWS) and Monument SWCD. OWEB funds would be used for project management, in-house personnel, contracted services, supplies/materials, fiscal administration and post-implementation status reporting.

Maximizing the health of basin-wide ecology requires the contribution of the Little Walla Walla River (LWWR) and Spring Branch system because of the critical functions performed within these off-channel habitats of the mainstem Walla Walla River. Located north of Milton Freewater in Umatilla County, these streams originate in Oregon and flow into Washington, and not only have significant salmonids fisheries potential, but they would increase flow and provide lower water temperatures as they discharge to the Walla Walla River. Information from the 2010 stream inventory of habitat and barriers on the West Little Walla Walla identified eight fish passage barriers. This project would correct three of those sites so all life stages of fish can migrate up and downstream. Another component of this project would fund a similar inventory on the Little East Walla Walla: identify barriers, provide outreach & education to landowners about management options in riparian zones; locate where fish screens are needed, engage in potential riparian planting and fencing and identify where weed control is needed. Partners in this project are BPA, Umatilla Co. SWCD, and the WWBWC. OWEB funds would be used for project management, in-house personnel, contracted services, travel, and fiscal administration.

Rowe Creek, a tributary to the mainstem John Day River in Central Wheeler County has recently been the focus of several upland restoration projects by NRCS and the Wheeler SWCD. Western juniper has become widespread throughout the watershed, impacting lands by outcompeting desirable native vegetation, decreasing infiltration, increasing overland flow and resulting erosion and allowing noxious and invasive weeds, such as medusahead rye, to invade the site. This project would remove 86 acres of specifically selected juniper; treat 64 acres of medusahead with herbicides; reseed 64 acres, install 8,100 feet of cross fencing and develop one upland spring site to provide water for both livestock and wildlife. The project will be monitored by photo points and vegetation line transects on select sites. Partners include the landowner and the Mid John Day Bridge Creek Watershed Council. OWEB funds would be used for project management, contracted services, supplies/materials, fiscal administration and post-implementation status reporting.

This project is located on Gable Creek, a tributary of Bridge Creek in Wheeler County. Two undersized and failing culverts are proposed to be replaced with bottomless pipe arch culverts. Because of the current size issue, both sites have overtopped and eroded due to high flows or debris plugging issues. This caused excessive sediment loading as well as creating a barrier to the native Redband trout population. Partners on this project are the landowner and Wheeler SWCD. OWEB funds would be used for pre-implementation, project management, contracted services, supplies/materials, fiscal administration and post-implementation status reporting.

Project Name: Walla Walla Nursery Irrigation Recycling Project
Project Summary: This project, located in Milton Freewater on the state line between Oregon and Washington, proposes to capture runoff from overhead irrigation on a 35-acre nursery operation, treat and re-use the water; creating a more efficient system, improving water quality of the Big Spring Branch and reducing the amount of water necessary to divert by 40 acre feet. Big Springs Branch drains into the Walla Walla River and is an ODA focus area for the SWCD. Partners on this project include the landowner and Umatilla SWCD.

This project, located in Morrow, Gilliam and Umatilla Counties, focuses on improving 1,500 acres of habitat for wildlife and converting non-productive monoculture USDA Conservation Reserve Program (CRP) grass stands by intensive site preparation, inter-seeding diverse, species-rich grass and forbs and reducing invasive weeds. Partners on this project include ODFW, Morrow SWCD and the USDA Farm Services Agency (FSA).

This technical assistance proposal would analyze recent LiDar data collected on all anadromous streams within the Birch Creek sub-basin in Umatilla County. The funds would hire a consultant to develop an analysis and action plan that will prioritize future collaborative restoration work in the sub-basin. The report deliverable will include a watershed and reach scale geomorphic assessment, restoration project identification and prioritization, conceptual project designs and flood modeling assistance. Partners on this project include Umatilla Basin Watershed Council, CTUIR, ODFW, Umatilla County SWCD, and the City of Pilot Rock.

This project is located on private property immediately adjacent to the town of Monument and alongside the North Fork John Day River in Grant County. A historic mill pond has evolved into a 9.7 acre wetland separated from the river by a degraded and now eroding levee. Severe bank erosion puts a section of this levee at risk of catastrophic failure from high-flow events while continuing to contribute sediment loads into the river. The landowner has been concerned that breaching of the levee could  result in the wetland pond being drained. An assessment of the wetland and levee was conducted through an OWEB technical assistance grant (213-6020) resulting in alternatives analysis on 1) no action, 2) modification or lowering of the levee, 3) reinforcement of the levee. After several meetings and much discussion, the technical review team selected a bio-engineered bank protection along 50 feet of the levee and 200 feet of large wood habitat structure to prevent future erosion while also providing instream habitat and preserving the wetland. This resubmit application proposed to implement the selected alternative that also would include stabilizing the existing wetland overflow channel and conducting invasive plant control in and around the wetland. Partners on this project include landowner, ODFW, CTWS, North American Wetland Conservation Act and the Monument SWCD.

This project, located in the Sherman County Grass Valley Canyon watershed, will construct 2,368 feet of new terraces, reshape 19,923 feet of historic terrace and install 15 cropland water and sediment control basins (WASCBs) to help filter and slow down overland flow and sediment from cropped fields in the headwater area of Hay Canyon. These conservation structures add benefit to previous enhancement work done upslope and to significant riparian exclusion fencing on Hay Canyon Creek, directly below this property. Partners on this project are Sherman County Area Watershed Council, Sherman SWCD, NRCS and the landowner.

This project is located in the Bridge Creek watershed, above the town of Mitchell in Wheeler County. Western juniper has encroached upland grasslands due to wildfire suppression and historic grazing practices. This project will mechanically remove phase two juniper from 840 prioritized acres and 55 acres of over-stocked ponderosa pine forest to restore function and resiliency to this combination upland grass/timber ecosystem. Additional planned projects in this area, not funded by this application, include a prescribed burn on an adjacent 365 acres and enrollment of 131 acres into CREP on streams running through the property. Partners on this project include Wheeler SWCD and CTWS.

This project is located on Indian Creek, a tributary that joins Badger Creek prior to flowing into Rock Creek in the southeast corner of Wheeler County. Currently there are three irrigation diversions on Indian Creek that block fish passage, are unscreened and have no flow measuring devices installed. The diversions feed over 11,000 feet of open ditch conveyance with a combined water right of 12.75 cfs. Ditch failure and overtopping causes water quality issues. The project will replace the upper two diversions with fish friendly diversion structure, remove the lowest diversion; and convert the open ditch to pipe. Partners on this project include Wheeler SWCD, the landowner, ODFW, NRCS and CTWS.

This project is located in the Harper Creek drainage of the Kahler Creek-Lower John Day River watershed in central Wheeler County. Western juniper encroachment has caused a loss of upland function by altering the hydrologic capacity and decreasing desirable vegetation. This project will mechanically remove 245 acres of juniper, treat 40 acres of invasive weeds, seed 40 acres and develop three springs for livestock and wildlife water sources. Partners on the project include Mid John Day Bridge Creek Watershed Council and the landowner.

This project, located in the Alder Creek basin in central Wheeler County, deals with encroaching Western juniper that impacts hydrology, upland processes and overall watershed health. The project will remove 110 acres of juniper from north aspect and deep soil sites, develop two upland springs for livestock and wildlife, treat 20 acres for weeds and reseed 20 acres. Partners on this project are the Mid John Day Bridge Creek Watershed Council and the landowner.

This project is located in the uplands of Portuguese Canyon and Bologna Creek drainage in northwestern Grant County. The property has remnant quaking aspen clones being threatened by encroaching Western juniper and browsing by both wild and domestic ungulates. This proposal would remove the juniper in the vicinity of the aspen community; construct 490 of buck and pole fence around one site and 220 of brush fence around a second site; develop one spring; cage aspen outliers to encourage expansion; and plant and cage 110 aspen saplings (purchased) and 600 bitterbrush seedlings. Partners on this project include Mid John Day Bridge Creek Watershed Council, the landowner, the Oregon Wildlife Heritage Foundation and ODFW.

Project Name: Muleshoe Creek Headwater Improvement Phase I
Project Summary: This project is located in the headwaters of Muleshoe Creek, a tributary to the John Day River in central Wheeler County. Increasing juniper populations have impacted the hydrology and upland processes of the entire basin. This project will remove 370 acres of phase-one juniper, develop and fence two springs for a clean source of water for both livestock and wildlife, treat 80 acres of invasive annual grass and reseed 80 acres with a seed mix competitive with the treated annual grasses. Partners on this project include the Mid John Day Bridge Creek Watershed Council and the landowner.

Project Name: East Little Walla Walla River Inventory/Analysis
Project Summary: This technical assistance proposal will complete a stream inventory and restoration analysis on the East Little Walla Walla and Big Spring Creek, located outside in the rural residential area of Milton Freewater in Umatilla County. The East Little Walla Walla and Big Spring system, totaling 5 miles, provide significant salmon fisheries spawning areas, juvenile rearing and cool water refugia for fish when summer temperatures limit salmonids survival in the lower Walla Walla River. Project components consist of 1) identification/prioritization of remaining fish barriers and unscreened irrigation diversions; 2) instream/riparian restoration needs on private properties; and 3) contacting landowners regarding their willingness to implement fish passage and habitat improvements. This information will be compiled into a prioritized restoration analysis and will include maps, photos and landowner contact information. Partners on this project include the Walla Walla Basin Watershed Council, BPA, Tri-State Steelheaders and the Umatilla SWCD.

This project is located on Fox Creek, on a section just west of Highway 395 south of the town of Fox in Grant County.  Fox Creek is a high meadow stream system altered by historic land management practices, yet continues to be important spawning and rearing habitat for steelhead. A recent assessment by Waterways Consulting identified this reach as a priority focus for restoration to reverse the incisional phase which is having a significant impact on instream habitat quality, bank stability and overall riparian health. The design submitted this cycle would install 19 root wad and 142 log structures, construct six rock step-pools and six whole log fish habitat structures, install a fish-friendly irrigation diversion and increase riparian vegetation with supplemental planting on over 3,000 feet. Project partners include the North Fork John Day Watershed Council, CTUIR, ODFW, two landowners, and Sisul Engineering.

This project is located on Mallory Creek, a tributary to the North Fork John Day River, and halfway between the towns of Monument and Dale in Grant County. There is approximately 1.4 miles of road that travels up the floodplain and channel of Mallory Creek, connecting the North Fork Road with the Umatilla National Forest. The present location of the road also requires two fords, one of which completely captures the stream channel and redirects the flow down the road itself for 200 yards. Mallory Creek is an important steelhead spawning and rearing stream. The proposed solution is to relocate the road up onto an adjacent ridge and utilize an abandoned road that already exists along most of this new route. Two bridges are also proposed to 1) replace the ford already present on the North Fork Road and 2) reconnect the rerouted road back to the existing route farther up and away from the channel. Partners on this project include the North Fork John Day Watershed Council, BLM, CTWS and Ecotrust.

The ten project sites are located in rangeland around Long Creek in Grant County. The identified sites are spring seeps with inadequate water for both livestock and wildlife; and what pools exist are degraded due to trampling. In order to provide a good source of water and to facilitate even distribution of livestock across the various pastures, the ranchers must haul water. The solution is to develop ten springs by installing drain pipe, collecting the water and piping to a trough where it will be available to both livestock and wildlife. Partners on this project include the North Fork John Day Watershed Council and two landowners.

In this application, the Lincoln SWCD proposes to: install 4,900 feet total of livestock exclusion fencing along both sides of Little Rock and Brush Creeks with an average setback of 25 ft; install two off-channel livestock watering stations; install two livestock crossings on Little Rock Creek; densely plant native shrubs and tree species along a combined 3,300 feet of Little Rock and Brush Creek; and conduct three years of plant release activities. Partners with the SWCD include the landowner, DEQ and NRCS. OWEB funds are budgeted for contracted services (59%), supplies (17%), project management (9%) and fiscal administration.

Project Name: Merrill Creek Private Drive Culvert Replacement
Project Summary: In this application the Columbia SWCD is requesting funding to replace an undersized culvert in Merrill Creek. The culvert would be replaced with a railcar bridge. Partners in the project include the landowner and ODFW. OWEB funds are budgeted for construction (49%), supplies/materials (29%), project management, permitting and fiscal administration.

There are a total of nine culverts on the mainstem of Thompson Creek, a tributary of Devils Lake, five of which, while undersized, have been classified as providing fish passage. The other four are undersized and/or degraded or perched to the extent they block or delay fish passage. Three of these four are on private driveways and the fourth runs under a Lincoln County road. In this application the Salmon Drift Creek Watershed Council (Council) requests funding to replace the four culverts presenting immediate problems for fish passage. Partners in the project include Lincoln County, Devils Lake Water Improvement District, ODFW, Lincoln SWCD and the Community Service Consortiums Natural Resource Crew. OWEB funds are budgeted for contracted services (49% - engineering, oversight, construction), supplies/materials (39%), project management and fiscal administration.

Project Name: Nicolai-Wickiup Fish Passage Assessment and Prioritization
Project Summary: In this application, the Nicolai-Wickiup Watershed Council (Council) seeks funding to hire crews to survey and inventory road crossings throughout their watershed. The data collected will be used to inform a prioritization process for repair or replacement of culverts with passage problems. The project goal is to characterize crossings and prioritize them based on: the degree to which fish passage is impaired; upstream habitat quality and quantity; and the species and abundance of fish in the streams; with the intent to increase access to spawning and rearing habitat for native anadromous fish. OWEB funds would be used for field verification; data base development, data entry and training field techs (77%), project management (8%) and fiscal administration.

Crow Creek is a tributary of the North Fork Siuslaw River, high up in the headwaters of the Siuslaw basin. Crow Creek crosses under the Cottage Grove-Lorane Highway through two shotgun culverts at MP 11.74, just east of the community of Lorane. The two shotgun culverts are undersized, perched, greatly impede adult passage and function as total upstream barriers to juvenile salmonids. In this application, the Lane County Public Works Department would replace the two existing culverts with a single 167 X 103 multi-plate arch pipe meeting federal and state fish passage requirements. The project will open passage to 1.5 miles of habitat. OWEB funds are budgeted for travel (1%), supplies/materials (49%), and heavy equipment/operator costs (50%).

Indian Creek is a 30,708-acre tributary basin in the Lake Creek sub-basin of the Siuslaw River watershed. In the application, the Siuslaw Watershed Council proposes to conduct a combined outreach and restoration development and design project focused on the private landowners in the Indian Creek valley, with the goal to produce at least two to four restoration projects. Activities include compilation and analysis of existing fish and habitat surveys, map development and community meetings. Partners in the project include the Forest Service, ODFW and the Siuslaw SWCD. OWEB funds are budgeted for salaries (80%), travel (6%), and supplies (4%).

Project Name: Stream Webs Student Stewardship Network Professional Development
Project Summary: This application would provide a program, designed in partnership with Oregon State Parks, which will reach staff and volunteers from agencies and organizations on the mid and north Oregon coast who serve as informal watershed educators for K-12 classrooms. The program is designed so that 40-60 trainees will gain knowledge, skills and tools to engage students in the classroom while also addressing content standards by participating in hands-on field events, group discussion, and accessing Stream Webs resources. Products will include two cohorts of trained watershed educators, four 8-hour workshops (2 for each cohort), mentoring from the Stream Webs coordinator, and 15-30 watershed field experiences for students support by trainees. Partners in the project are OSU, Oregon Sea Grant, and Oregon Parks and Recreation Department. OWEB funds are budgeted for salaries (67%), contracted services (11%), travel (9%), and administration (13%).

The Big Elk is a large tributary (~57,000-acres) of the Yaquina River. In this project the MidCoast Watershed Council would assess public and agricultural roads in the Big Elk sub-basin for their propensity to deliver fine sediment to streams, using the US Forest Service GRAIP (Geomorphic Road Analysis and Inventory Package), ODF, or equivalent protocol. Road segments will be assessed for their propensity to deliver fine sediments, and delivery routes will be documented. Best Management Practices (BMPs) will be proposed for reducing sediment delivery for road segments identified as significant, chronic or potential sources. Partners in the project include Lincoln County Public Works, DEQ, Lincoln SWCD, and ODA.  OWEB funds are budgeted for salaries (2%), contracted services (90%), and administration (8%).

Project Name: Natural Resource Restoration and Research Crew Project
Project Summary: The Natural Resource Crew (NRC) Program is designed to serve three target audiences: 1) high school students, particularly at-risk individuals; 2) crew leaders (trained college students interested in natural resource issues) and; 3) scientists and resource managers with un-met restoration, assessment or monitoring labor needs. This proposal to OWEB would fund staff to coordinate activities necessary to engage at least three crews of NRC students (5-7 students per crew) during the full year as well as crew leaders, scientists, and restoration project managers in work that has real value for natural resource research and/or management. Partners in the project include OSU Extension, Hatfield Marine Science Center (crew and lead training, lab use), ODFW, The Nature Conservancy, The Wetlands Conservancy, local schools, local watershed councils, and a variety of public and private land owners/managers. OWEB funds will be used for project management staff (90%) and administration (10%).

Moon Creek is a 5,620-acre sub-basin of the Nestucca River, entering at RM 24 just upstream of the community of Blain. In this application the Nestucca Neskowin Watershed Council (Council) seeks funding to replace two failing culverts on tributary streams flowing under County Road 858 in the Moon Creek valley bottom. Both culverts are barriers to adult and juvenile passage. The downstream culvert (#03022) is undersized, double-barreled (one is 26, the other is 36), the in-pipe slope is 9%, and the pipe is broken in the middle and at high risk of failure. The upstream culvert (#1208) is undersized (36) and separated at sections. The downstream culverts (#03022) will be replaced with one 11 ft diameter, 65 ft long round corrugated metal pipe (CMP) culvert with simulated stream bedload design. The upstream pipe (#1208) will be replaced with an 11.8 ft span, 91 rise, 60 ft long corrugated metal pipe CMP culvert with simulated stream bedload design. Partners in the project include USFS, USFWS, Tillamook County Public Works Department, and ODFW. OWEB funds are budgeted for salaries (1%), contracted services (96%), administration (2%), and post implementation reporting (1%).

In this application the Necanicum Watershed Council, in partnership with the North Coast Watershed Association, the Clatsop SWCD and the North Coast Land Conservancy, proposes to address the perceived problem that many residential landowners in Clatsop County are generally not aware of the resources available to them - through the local watershed councils, land trusts, and soil and water conservation districts - of what a landowner might do to improve habitat in and around the various waterbodies in the county. The partners would address the audience of landowners and residents of the County with a outreach program of public postings, newspaper articles, and social media designed to reach the community. All the outreach would be expected to culminate in a one-day conference to be held in Seaside to bring residents and conservation organizations together to discuss problems and successes, issues and options, and the tools and resources available to achieve the goals of habitat improvement, familiarity with the conservation entities, and a greater sense of stewardship. Partners include the Necanicum Watershed Council, the North Coast Watershed Association, the Clatsop SWCD, and the North Coast Land Conservancy. OWEB funds are budgeted for salaries (49%), contracted services (17%), travel (2%), supplies (24%), conference center rental (2%), and administration (6%).

The applicant proposes to pipe the first 4,700 feet of the Talent Main Canal located near the confluence of Ashland Creek with Bear Creek in the Rogue River watershed. The piped canal would replace the current diversion system which utilizes lower Ashland Creek and would allow the removal of a fish passage barrier on Ashland Creek.

Project Name: Jackson Creek Fish Passage Restoration at Hanley Road Culvert
Project Summary: The culvert at Hanley Road on Jackson Creek (stream mile 4.25) is a complete barrier to upstream   fish passage. The project proposes to develop a set of designs for correcting the passage issue.

The project proposes to address poor riparian and stream conditions along Daniels Creek. Daniels Creek is a tributary to the Coos River. Project components include riparian planting of approximately 1,750 native tree species and 2,500 willow cuttings, eradication of noxious weed species and maintenance of planted species.

Project Name: South Fork Coos River Aquatic Inventory Surveys
Project Summary: This project will fund Aquatic Habitat Inventory (AHI) surveys in the South Fork Coos River and 9 of its named tributaries. Surveying will cover more than 44 miles of highly productive mainstem and tributary habitat within the South Fork Coos basin.
The applicant proposes to fund instream enhancement activities on the North Fork Deer Creek, a tributary to the Umpqua River near Roseburg.

Project Name: Rogue Basinwide Barrier Removal Feasibility Analysis
Project Summary: This project proposes to hire a contractor to complete a programmatic feasibility analysis for moving forward with the removal of 65 priority fish barriers in the Rogue River watershed identified in ODFW's 2013 Statewide barrier prioritization and to recommend a systematic approach to address all of these high priority impediments to fish passage over the next decade.

The proposed project site is located along Offield Creek just off Randolph Slough at approximately Coquille River mile 8. The Coos County Road Department culvert is failing at this site and the County has scheduled to replace it in 2015. The proposed solution is to hire an engineering firm to gather and process survey data on hydrological flow and tidal inundation to determine the optimal design of tidegate and size of structure needed to support a fish-friendly Muted Tidal Regulator that meets all local, state and federal requirements.
The project proposes to address two fish passage impediments in Shutters Creek, a tributary to the Tenmile Lakes.
This project proposed to address simplified instream habitat conditions on Woodward Creek, located within the North Fork Coquille River Watershed, by placing large wood instream.  .

Project Name: Bitterlick Creek Fish Passage Improvement Alternative Development
Project Summary: This application seeks funding for alternative development for fish passage improvement at a culvert on Bitterlick Creek, tributary to Little Butte Creek. The culvert is owned by Jackson County. The project proposes to retain engineering services from a local hydraulic engineer for developing replacement alternatives and construction cost estimates for each.

Project Name: Nonpoint Source Pollution and Stream Wise Watershed Outreach Package
Project Summary: This 2-year project will reach 1,000-1,200 students, 140 teachers and 600+ community members of Jackson and Josephine Counties with outreach tied directly to restoration, water quality and conservation efforts. The target audiences will be reached through school programs, teacher mentoring, workshops, tours and event outreach.

This project is located in the Woodward Creek drainage within the North Fork Coquille River Watershed.The project proposes to address poor instream habitat conditions through the placement of large wood to improve flood plain connectivity, increase stream complexity and improve water quality.

The applicant proposes to pipe the first 4,700 feet of the Talent Main Canal located near the confluence of Ashland Creek with Bear Creek in the Rogue River watershed. This would allow the dam removal work go beyond the Bi-Op requirements and allow for the complete removal of the diversion dam in Ashland Creek.

This project targets 35,000+ K-12 students and their teachers living in the Bear Creek Watershed. Serving nine school districts and four private schools, BCWEP will host 8 teacher workshops (reaching 150 teachers); two stream cleanup events (60-100 community volunteers), two Kids and Creeks events (100-150 community members); and two watershed education symposiums (400-500 students).

Project Name: Lower Marlow Creek Channel and Riparian Restoration
Project Summary: Marlow Creek is a tributary of the East Fork Millicoma River located near the head of tide. The project proposes to implement stream channel restoration activities including: bank pullback, riparian planting and fencing, large wood placement upstream of tidal backwater, boulder and bankfull floodplain creation.

Project Name: Stock Slough Riparian Restoration & Noxious Weed Control Project
Project Summary: The proposed project is on Stock Slough, a tide-gated tributary of Catching Slough.The project proposes to work with two landowners to remove an undersized culvert, install a bridge, place root wads, plant and fence the riparian zone, and remove noxious weeds.

Project Name: East Fork Millicoma Oxbow Reconnection and Habitat Restoration
Project Summary: In 1958, two bridges crossing the East Fork Millicoma River, a tributary to the Coos River, near Coos Bay, Oregon, were filled in, forming an artificial oxbow. The project will install two bridges, one at each of the two historic oxbow crossings. Fill material from the bridge locations will be returned to the existing bypass chute creating a diversion dam that will return all flows back through the oxbow, reconnecting the river's original course.

Market Creek is a tributary to the lower Chetco River. The applicant proposes to replace two culverts with embedded fish passable arch culverts, which will open up approximately 4,200 feet of habitat, and a segment of "daylighted" channel between the culverts will be enlarged and enhanced.

The project proposal aims to improve summer instream water flows along a two-mile section of Deer Creek, a tributary to the Illinois River in the Rogue River watershed. The project proposes to increase summer stream flows and lower stream temperature along the project reach by transferring 3.2 cfs of water rights to a groundwater point of appropriation approximately two miles downstream, enabling abandonment of the current point of diversion. An infilration gallery delivery system will be designed and installed as the preferred alternative.

Project Name: Winchester Creek Coho Spawning Habitat Improvement
Project Summary: Winchester Creek is the the major freshwater source for the South Slough portion of the Coos River estuary. The project proposes to take a holistic ridge-top to ridge-top approach to enhance West Fork Winchester Creeks spawning habitat as a pilot project to inform spawning habitat restoration efforts elsewhere in the Winchester Creek system. A total of 320 yards of spawning gravel will be installed at 8 treatment sites over 260 linear feet of stream.

Siskiyou Field Institute proposes a two-year project that will reach 1,200 sixth grade students, as well as 56 parents and 32 teachers engaging them in hands-on, in the field monitoring and restoration activities.
