The applicant proposes to engage partners and stakeholders to develop a strategic plan for water quality monitoring, repeat sampling of parameters in the Oregon Water Quality Index to document status and trend over the past decade at eight stations, sample for multiple parameters on two watersheds with contrasting upland grazing management and restoration history, and supplement a Stormchaser volunteer sampling program at 90 stations.

The goal of this project is to increase public awareness and understanding of water quality issues in the Rogue basin. By utilizing diverse outreach methods and coordinating a public information campaign on water quality issues using multiple electronic and traditional methods.

Row River Nature Park is located at a braided river bend within the southeast corner of the Cottage Grove city limits, downstream of Dorena Dam.  The project site is home to a significant population of Western pond turtle, was prioritized as part of the USACE Willamette River Floodplain Restoration Feasibility Study due to its floodplain characteristics, and had vegetation enhancement completed on 42 acres by the Coast Fork Willamette Watershed Council.  Historic gravel mining transformed the gallery cottonwood forest of the lower Row River into a series of ponds, forest areas, and occasionally connected channels on this 56-acre site.  Proposed project will reconnect channels, regrade pond bank, and restore vegetation on 23 acres.  Proposed project design will implement highest value recommendations of the USACE study in a targeted area of the park without impacting local city drinking water infrastructure.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, materials and supplies, grant administration, and reporting.  Project partners include Row Basin Fisheries Fund, City of Cottage Grove, Kennedy Alternative High School, ODFW, and Coast Fork Willamette Watershed Council.

Rowell Creek, a tributary of Gooseneck Creek in the Mill Creek Basin of Yamhill watershed, supports spawning and rearing habitat for native salmonids.  Proposed technical assistance will design a replacement stream crossing for a culvert maintained by Polk County, which is currently a barrier to juvenile and adult fish passage.  Project builds on a completed fish passage barrier assessment and prioritization, which identified this culvert as a high priority because it restricts access to 4 miles of fish habitat.  Potential design solutions include culvert replacement, bottomless culvert, or bridge.  Selected final design will meet ODFW fish passage criteria and Polk County road standards while maintaining natural stream morphology.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services, travel, supplies and materials, printing, and grant administration.  Project partners include Polk County, BLM, ODFW, and Greater Yamhill Watershed Council.

Wind Creek is a tributary of Mill Creek located in the Yamhill watershed, a Conservation Opportunity Area, and in a Timber Conservation Zone.  Proposed project will replace an undersized culvert identified as a priority barrier restricting access to 4 miles of high-quality spawning and rearing habitat for native resident cutthroat trout, sculpin, and western brook lamprey; and interrupts gravel and wood recruitment.  The culvert will be replaced with a bridge that will allow for complete fish passage and improve natural stream process and function.  Project builds on downstream fish passage barrier removal completed by Weyerhaeuser and will complete fish passage restoration on Wind Creek.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services, supplies and materials, grant administration, and reporting.  Project partners include Weyerhaeuser, ODFW, BLM, and Greater Yamhill Watershed Council.

Project Name: Little Rock Creek Stream Crossing Improvement
Project Summary: Little Rock Creek is located approximately 0.24 River Miles upstream of the Mad Creek confluence with the North Santiam River near Gates, Oregon.  The Mad Creek drainage is designated Essential Salmonid Habitat and provides spawning habitat to winter steelhead.  Proposed project will replace undersized culvert with a bridge to restore juvenile and adult salmon and steelhead passage to over a mile of stream habitat, reconnect the stream with its floodplain, and improve sediment transport.  The project will involve (1) removing existing culvert and fill material, (2) constructing a new bridge, and (3) stabilizing banks immediately upstream and downstream of the bridge with large rock, soil, and native vegetation.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services, grant administration, and reporting.  Project partners include Linn County, Frank Timber Resources, ODFW, and North Santiam Watershed Council.

Project Name: Upper Price Creek Barrier Removal & Fish Hab. Enhancement
Project Summary: Price Creek is a tributary in the Luckiamute watershed in northern Benton County and a part of the Willamette Model Watershed program.  Maxfield Creek supports ESA-listed winter steelhead, Coho, and cutthroat trout; however, upper Price Creek currently is inaccessible to anadromous fish.  Proposed project will replace two perched, under-sized culverts on private timber land providing fish access to approximately 1.2 additional miles of quality stream habitat and leave Price Creek barrier free; and place approximately 30 log structures along 2.4 stream miles to enhance in-stream habitat in areas where channel is entrenched due to lack of in-stream large wood.  Pre- and Post- project surveys will be conducted through the Model Watershed Program to monitor changes in channel features and substrate.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, supplies and materials, grant administration, and reporting.  Project partners include USFWS, Meyer Memorial Trust, and Luckiamute Watershed Council.

Project Name: Lost Creek Hydrology and Habitat Study
Project Summary: Lost Creek, located in the Middle Fork Willamette Watershed, is a Willamette Model Watershed tributary and Conservation Opportunity Area that supports spring Chinook, summer and winter steelhead, Oregon chub, brook lamprey, and cutthroat trout. It is characterized by low in-stream habitat complexity, and experiences low summer stream flows and high water temperatures. Scope of the low flow problem is unclear because Lost Creek has never been gauged and relative contribution of potential drivers has not been investigated, making this issue difficult to address. Low flows are likely contributing to significant stream warming. Determining locations of cold water inputs and areas of significant warming will provide information to prioritize areas for addressing temperature issues. Lost Creek was ranked as a high priority by ODFW and OWRD for flow restoration needs. Habitat complexity is lacking, and significant infrastructure associated with rural residential development constrains restoration options on Lost Creek. Technical assistance is needed to collect stream flow data, acquire thermal infrared imagery, and conduct stream habitat surveys to determine specific restoration actions needed to improve water quantity, water temperature, and habitat complexity issues on Lost Creek. OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, travel, and grant administration. Project partners include Meyer Memorial Trust, ODFW, and Middle Fork Willamette Watershed Council.

Project Name: Irrigation Automation in Santiam Water Control District
Project Summary: Project is located at the Santiam Water Control Districts (SWCD) irrigation diversion on the North Santiam River in Stayton, Oregon.  North Santiam River water is in scarce supply for much of the year.  The SWCD currently uses two diversions with manually operated headgates resulting in inefficient water management and higher flow diversions because real-time adjustments are not feasible.  The City of Stayton utilizes the system for stormwater discharge compounding flow problems and adding potential flood and catastrophic spill risks.  Proposed project will install 14 automated headgate controls, 17 automated water level and quality monitors, and communication and control systems to manage irrigation and storm flow in real-time.  Resulting efficiency improvement of diversion management will lead to improved in-stream flows in the North Santiam River.  The proposed system is expected to provide 9% reduction in water use.  The partnership with Stayton will provide secondary benefits of efficiently utilizing storm flows and creating an automated isolation system.  Project will provide water quality and conservation benefits.  The real-time telemetry will provide ongoing data showing improvements to water diversion and transport.  Data collected will be used to develop future adaptive management to increase system efficiency.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services and materials and supplies.  Project partners include Marion County, Marion SWCD, City of Stayton, NRCS, and Santiam Water Control District.

Grantee: Friends of Buford Park & Mt Pisgah
Project Summary: The 2,363-acre Buford Park is located in Southeast Lane County near the confluence of the Willamette River coast and middle forks, adjacent to TNCs 1,271-acre Willamette Confluence Preserve, and in a Conservation Opportunity Area.  Less than 2 percent of the Willamette Valleys native prairie and savanna habitats remain due to a long history of land conversion, fire suppression, and invasive plant species.  Proposed project will restore and enhance prairie and savannah habitat across the 275-acre Meadowlark Project. Management actions include controlling invasive shrubs; removing conifers and hardwoods to restore 57 acres of oak savannah, 50 acres of prairie, 40 acres of oak woodland, and 10 acres of conifer forest; prescribed fire on 100 acres; and sowing native grasses and forbs to enhance habitat diversity.  Project is expected to benefit 17 at-risk species known to occur in the Mt. Pisgah area depending on these habitats, including Western meadowlark and acorn woodpecker.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, travel, materials and supplies, grant administration, outreach, reporting, and plant establishment.  Project partners include Lane County, ODA, ODF, BPA, USFWS, and Friends of Buford Park and Mt. Pisgah.

The Johnson Creek Watershed located in the Portland area has inadequate streamside vegetation, leaving both the mainstem and tributaries too warm to support salmonid populations.  Proposed project will implement the Councils Riparian Reforestation Strategy, and work with private landowners to control invasive weeds and install native vegetative cover for shading.  At least 30 landowners will be enrolled in the Councils CreekCare program over the next three years to restore riparian vegetation and control invasive weeds on at least 15 acres on 2 stream miles.  Plantings will be maintained for a minimum of 3 years after installation.  OWEB funds are requested for personnel, contracted services, materials and supplies, grant administration, and plant establishment.  Project partners include Clackamas SWCD, East Multnomah SWCD, and Johnson Creek Watershed Council.

Project Name: Strategic Steps Toward Splash Dam Recovery in Luckiamute Watershed
Project Summary: Historic splash damming and logging in upper reaches of salmonid-bearing streams in the Willamette Valley has caused simplified and incised channels, loss of floodplain connectivity, exposed channel bedrock, and an absence of large wood.  Reduced geomorphic diversity and floodplain connectivity has decreased availability of off-channel spawning, winter refuge, and cool summer pool habitats for fish.  The Luckiamute Watershed Council lacks adequate data concerning watershed processes, including sediment supply and transport, landslide and debris torrent dynamics, channel pinch points, and aggradation locations at fine scales needed to effectively manage and plan for risks and complexity of projects that address splash dam recovery.  Proposed project will: (1) integrate multiple datasets in a fine-scale watershed analysis to better inform project design, thereby eliminating the gap in applicants ability to effectively plan for, site, and spatially link restoration actions in scientifically valid ways; (2) field validate analysis results in selected areas with the highest restoration potential; (3) develop permit-ready design drawings and budgets for 4 projects aimed at system recovery from historical splash damming; and (4) document approach in a white paper to support project planning and implementation by similar groups.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, travel, and grant administration.  Project partners include Meyer Memorial Trust, Terrain Works, volunteer technical review team, and Luckiamute Watershed Council.

Grantee: U of O - Office of Research & Admin
Project Name: Tracking Progress Towards Restoration Goals in Tributary Floodplains
Project Summary: A spatial and informational framework (the Slices Framework, see WRB Planning Atlas 2002) has been deployed in the mainstem Willamette River floodplain for tracking landscape change, prioritizing restoration project locations, and monitoring progress towards three key restoration goals - floodplain forest extent, channel complexity and native fish habitat.  Proposed project will extend this framework up the mainstem Middle Fork Willamette River to the lowest elevation federal dam.  Over time, the goal is to extend the Slices framework up all the major westward flowing, salmon bearing tributaries of the Willamette so that the mainstem Willamette, its tributaries and their floodplains can be more effectively conceived and managed as an interconnected set of habitats.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, supplies and materials, direct administration support, and grant administration.  Project partners include University of Oregon and Oregon State University.

The Calapooia Watershed Council (CWC) has partnered with a private landowner located on the mainstem Calapooia River in Tangent, Oregon for removal of the last remaining partial fish passage barrier on the Calapooia mainstem, located at river mile 17 of 72 miles.  This channel-spanning structure with three undersized culverts was permitted by DSL and constructed in the late 1990s just prior to the listing of spring Chinook and winter steelhead.  Proposed project includes construction of a 115 free spanning bridge across the river for full, unobstructed flows and fish passage.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, travel, supplies and materials, grant administration, and reporting.  Project partners include landowner, OSU, ODOT, and Calapooia Watershed Council.

The Students Engaged in Restoring Vital Ecosystems (SERVE) targets upper elementary and middle school students to foster the next generation of watershed stewards through classroom presentations, field experiences and teacher support.  Students are engaged in all aspects of restoration, including project design, implementation and survivorship monitoring.  The objective of the SERVE program is for students to learn specific, field-based skills including native and invasive plant identification, mapping, photo monitoring, proper planting and plant removal techniques, data collection techniques, and field safety protocols.  The objectives of SERVEs classroom presentations are to teach students about their local watershed in accordance with ODE state science benchmarks.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, travel, and grant administration.  Project partners include City of Portland, The Boeing Company, Gray Family Foundation, and Columbia Slough Watershed Council.

Project Name: Kings Valley Watershed Stewards - Phase I
Project Summary: Proposed project targets 186 K through 12th grade students at Kings Valley Charter School (KVCS), 11-15 regional teachers and up to 60 community landowners.  A diverse array of interdisciplinary educational and outreach techniques will address the needs of students, teachers and community members to increase their understanding of and involvement in stewardship of their watershed--including hands-on outdoor activities, restoration site visits, multimedia presentations, and classroom instruction. Students will conduct monitoring, plant propagation and planting and invasive species control activities on neighboring properties.   A teacher training workshop will provide skills and experience for teachers to incorporate the watershed science curriculum.  Participating community landowners will view successful student projects, and will be introduced to land management techniques and assistance as part of a spring project tour--empowering them to initiate restoration projects on their own properties.  Project participants will benefit from an increased understanding of watershed function, protection and restoration, and a stronger sense of their role in the watershed stewardship.  OWEB funds are requested for salaries, contracted services, supplies, travel, and grant administration.  Project partners include landowners, Kings Valley Charter School, Benton SWCD, ODFW, Institute for Applied Ecology, Bonneville Environmental Foundation, ODFW, and Luckiamute Watershed Council.

Proposed project is located along the North Santiam River where Stout Creek, a Willamette Model Watershed tributary, joins the mainstem.  The property is a bare root nursery located in a high priority 15 river mile reach of the North Santiam River, near significant existing restoration and conservation efforts along the mainstem river and tributaries, including Stout Creek.  Restoration to date includes 13 acres of riparian vegetation restoration and placement of large wood instream structures along Stout Creek where it flows through this property.  Historic habitat was exclusively floodplain forest, as is evidenced by the large volume of cobble found in the nursery beds.  Current habitat condition is compromised due to land conversion for agriculture and nursery production.  A very narrow stand of riparian forest is all that remains, other than a narrow band of remnant floodplain forest, near the middle of the property, as well as on an adjacent island. Many resident and migratory fish species, including Threatened Upper Willamette River spring Chinook and winter steelhead, as well as Oregon chub and Pacific lamprey, utilize the North Santiam mainstem in this reach. Proposed project will restore floodplain vegetation on 24 acres.  OWEB funds are requested for project management staff, contracted services, travel, supplies and materials, land use approval, grant administration, reporting, and plant establishment.  Project partners include NFWF, Yamhill SWCD, FSA CREP, landowner, and North Santiam Watershed Council.

Project Name: Molalla Side Channels Restoration Design and Outreach
Project Summary: Proposed project will develop side-channel restoration projects on the mainstem Molalla River, which is temperature limited for salmonids.  Side-channel habitat on the Molalla River is a high priority for thermal refugia for juvenile salmonids during the summer.  Project will conduct ground truthing, long profile surveys, site specific designs and landowner contacts required for developing a 100% design for a restoration proposal to the OWEB April 2016 solicitation cycle.  Approximately 50 small private landowners will be engaged to provide access to 17 side-channels on the mainstem Molalla from Highway 213 to the North Fork Molalla confluence (12 mile reach).  OWEB funds are requested for project management staff, contracted services, supplies and materials, and grant administration.  Project partners include Clackamas SWCD, ODFW, Clackamas County, and Molalla River Watch.

Project Name: Middle Willamette Water Quality Characterization - Phase II
Project Summary: The Middle Willamette Water Quality Characterization Project was undertaken by ODA and Polk SWCD on behest of the Local Advisory Committee.  This phase 1 did not fully achieve the goal to collect status and trend information, and deliver strong conclusions from that collected data.  The proposed phase 2 project objective is to improve and expand upon previous monitoring by providing additional data points using the same water quality parameters to arrive at definitive results.  Watershed and basin-wide data is still necessary to further target restoration and enhancement efforts by agencies and non-profit organizations.  Proposed project will collect and analyze data from eight locations monthly for two years.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, supplies and materials, and grant administration.  Project partners include ODA, DEQ, Luckiamute WC, and Polk SWCD.

The GYWC and partners have identified a lack of knowledge about salmonid population abundance and distribution in the Yamhill River Watershed as a priority data gap for strategic watershed restoration planning efforts.  To address this limiting factor in prioritizing restoration actions, proposed project will conduct a year-one Rapid Bio-Assessment (RBA) across four 5th field HUCs within the Willamina Creek.  The RBA survey will quantify summer abundance and distribution of juvenile salmonid species in 358 miles of the Yamhill River Watershed, including ESA-listed Chinook salmon.  Supplemental monitoring activities include a spawning gravel inventory, knotweed noxious weed surveys, stream temperature monitoring, and fish spawning surveys.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, printing and postage, and grant administration.  Project partners include ODFW, Yamhill County, BLM, Western Invasives Network, Hampton Resources, Weyerhaeuser, Polk SWCD, Yamhill SWCD, and Greater Yamhill Basin Watershed Council.

As one of the largest remaining floodplains in the Lower Columbia River estuary, Mirror Lake is a priority for restoration of functional riparian habitats and a lynchpin in regional efforts to recover ESA-listed salmonids and at risk wildlife species.  Located in the Columbia River Gorge National Scenic Area and managed by Oregon Parks and Recreation Department (OPRD), the 390-acre site has been the focus of research and restoration since 2005.  As a result, work completed includes placement of instream structures, fish passage improvements and floodplain reforestation (including 50.7 acres funded by OWEB and partners).  Proposed project builds on those restoration gains and add 68.7 priority acres to management in the Mirror Lake floodplain.  Restoration of historic conditions, degraded through land conversion and noxious weed encroachment, will improve hydrologic function and reestablish sustainable sources of habitat structure and prey/forage; benefitting as many as 15 Evolutionarily Significant Units (ESUs) of salmonids and 20 wildlife Oregon Conservation Strategy species.  Project includes thorough site preparation, plant installation and plant establishment treatments.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services, supplies and materials, grant administration, reporting, and plant establishment.  Project partners include OPRD, ODFW, East Multnomah SWCD, NFWF, and Cascade Pacific RC&D.

Project Name: Middle Fork Willamette Watershed Rangers & Stewards Project
Project Summary: Project targets third to twelfth grade students in the Middle Fork Willamette watershed to engage students in making connections between outdoor experiences, in-class studies and local conservation issues by providing field experiences, service-learning projects and natural resources industry job skill development.   Project includes place-based interdisciplinary watershed curriculum, classroom lessons, field trips, restoration projects to promote stewardship ethic, high school professional development in restoration project evaluation, and effectiveness monitoring.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services, travel, supplies and materials, and grant administration.  Project partners include Pleasant Hill School District, Bureau of Land Management, US Forest Service, Springfield Utility Board, US Army Corps of Engineers, private donors, and Middle Fork Willamette Watershed Council.

Project Name: Rattlesnake and Lost Creek Fish Passage Restoration Project Phase 2
Project Summary: Lost and Rattlesnake Creeks are two undammed tributaries to the Middle Fork Willamette River.  Improving fish passage at three high priority culverts will open over 8.5 miles of essential habitat to ESA-listed spring Chinook, summer and winter steelhead, cutthroat trout, lamprey, and Oregon chub.  The two privately owned and one BLM owned undersized, perched culverts are fish migration barriers limiting access to prime spawning and rearing habitats.  Proposed project will replace culverts with bridges and remove a rock check dam.  Project builds on OWEB Technical Assistant grants to conduct culvert surveys, prioritize culverts for replacement and develop engineering designs.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, travel, permit fees, grant administration, and reporting.  Project partners include BLM, Meyer Memorial Trust, landowners, ODFW, and Middle Fork Willamette Watershed Council.

Project Name: Dorris Ranch Oak Release, Prairie Restoration and Bottomland Forest Enhancement
Project Summary: The 258-acre Dorris Ranch Living History Farm is located at the confluence of the Middle Fork and Coast Fork Willamette rivers and at the Eugene/Springfield urban-rural interface.  Dorris Ranch is comprised of rare but degraded Willamette Valley oak woodlands and savanna, upland and wet prairie, and bottomland forests that have tremendous ecological value.  Decades of fire suppression and invasive plant species introduction resulted in overly dense oak woodlands with non-native herbaceous and woody vegetation advancing into upland and wet prairie areas.  Over time, conifer encroachment has impeded oak crown development.  Current trends point toward eventual elimination of prairie habitat, and conversion of much of the site to conifer-dominated forest.  Proposed project will implement (1) selective tree removal, invasive weed control and native planting to promote native forb and grass cover in a 38-acre upland and wet prairie area; (2) weed control and understory planting on 7 acres of Ash forested wetland; (3) strategic thinning and understory inter-planting on roughly 21 acres of oak forest to increase structural and compositional diversity; and (4) careful ecological thinning of 35 acres in a 42-acre bottomland forest to facilitate healthy crown development.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, travel, supplies and materials, permitting, grant administration, and plant establishment.  Project partners include Willamalane and Middle Fork Willamette Watershed Council.

The Johnson Creek watershed, reaching from rural Boring, Oregon to the Willamette River in Milwaukie, suffers from inadequate streamside vegetation, leaving both the mainstem and tributaries too warm to meet their full potential in supporting salmonid populations.  Having completed a Riparian Reforestation Strategy (the Strategy) to prioritize basin-wide restoration efforts, the Johnson Creek Watershed Council proposes to work with private landowners to control invasive weeds and install native riparian plantings to reduce stream temperatures by establishing streamside vegetative cover and shading.  Applicant intends to enroll at least 30 landowners in the CreekCare riparian vegetation program over the next three years, and use OWEB funds to control invasive weeds on at least 20 acres of private land and install 53,000 native plants along at least two and a half stream miles identified in the Strategy as priority restoration areas. Planting will be maintained for a minimum of three years after installation, and tracked using visual estimates of percent survival and photo points.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, materials and supplies, grant administration, and plant establishment.  Project partners include Clackamas SWCD, East Multnomah SWCD and Johnson Creek Watershed Council.

Project Name: The Meldrum Bar Restoration and Outreach Project (Meldrum Bar Project)
Project Summary: The Meldrum Bar Project engages students, teachers and parents from 14 third to sixth grade classrooms from lower Willamette and Clackamas River watersheds.  Proposed project offers flexible program design and delivery, projects and curriculum aligned with state standards.  Additionally, LCEP provides coordination, sites, tools, and leadership necessary to directly engage students, parents and community members in hands-on activities that restore Meldrum Bar Park habitat.  Resulting place based connections increase environmental awareness and promote behavior that benefits fish and wildlife.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, and supplies and materials.  Project partners include City of Gladstone and LCEP.

Proposed project will address elevated summer stream temperature and simplified channel form in Greasy Creek (Marys River).  Marys River Watershed Council will partner with stream-adjacent landowners to place logs in 14 large wood complexes in locations selected for their ability to provide floodplain connection to low terraces; and winter slack-water habitats will be reconnected to the channel at two locations.  Long-term monitoring of stream temperature and channel complexity will be provided as part of the Willamette Model Watershed Program.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, travel, land use approval, permitting, grant administration, and reporting.  Project partners include Coast Range Stewardship Group, Meyer Memorial Trust, Finley National Wildlife Refuge, and Marys River Watershed Council.

Project Name: Irrigation Automation in Santiam Water Control District
Project Summary: Project is located on the North Santiam River in Stayton, OR where the Santiam Water Control District (District) diverts irrigation flow to 17,000 acres of farmland between Stayton and Salem.  North Santiam River water is in scarce supply for much of the year.  The District currently uses two diversions with manually operated headgates resulting in inefficient water management and higher flow diversions because real-time adjustments are not feasible.  The City of Stayton utilizes the system for stormwater discharge compounding flow problems and adding potential flood and catastrophic spill risks.  Proposed project will install 14 automated headgate controls, 17 automated water level and quality monitors, and communication and control systems to manage irrigation and storm flow in real-time.  Resulting efficiency improvement of diversion management will lead to improved instream flows in the North Santiam River.  The partnership with Stayton will provide secondary benefits of efficiently utilizing storm flows and creating an automated isolation system.  Project will provide water quality and conservation benefits for ESA-listed fish species.  The real-time telemetry will provide ongoing data showing improvements to water diversion and transport.  Data collected will be used to develop future adaptive management to increase system efficiency.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services, and materials and supplies.  Project partners include Marion County, Marion SWCD, City of Stayton, NRCS, and Santiam Water Control District.

The Upper Rickreall is the primary source area for the City of Dallas domestic drinking water supply and is a regionally significant system for water quantity.  Stand replacement fires and historic forest management have impaired wood recruitment resulting in limited access to refugial habitats, fragmented habitat, excessive sediment erosion, channel entrenchment, and simplified channel structure.  The loss of LWD in the project area has accelerated sediment transport, which has resulted in significant loss of storage capacity in the upper third of Mercer Reservoir.  Propose project will enhance and restore stream function by placing approximately 350 whole trees in 21 structures along 2 miles of stream above Aaron Mercer Reservoir.  This will reduce the amount of sediment and water exiting the upper drainage system during high water freshets, and subsequently enhance water quantity and quality later in the spring and early summer in the project area and downstream.  Phase I, which included ground-based LWD placement on 1 mile of the Upper Rickreall, was completed in 2013 with OWEB small grant funds and has accumulated a substantial amount of sediment in a relatively small timeframe.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services for helicopter wood placement, grant administration, and monitoring.  Project partners include Hancock Forest Management, City of Dallas, BLM, ODFW, Polk SWCD, and Rickreall Watershed Council.

Proposed project will restore side-channel flow, and enhance channel complexity and wild salmon habitat in a priority Sandy River reach with intensive residential and infrastructure development.  Project actions include removal of 300 of historic levee installed following the record 1964 floods, which isolated the floodplain from all but highest flood flows and intensified downstream erosion and channel migration.  Log jams at a restored side-channel inlet will be constructed to guide flow into the 2,900-foot side-channel and currently isolated 30-acre floodplain that was acquired in 2007 for conservation management by Columbia Land Trust.  Project designs came from a multi-year community dialog to develop Restorative Flood Response approaches using habitat restoration to reduce risk of channel migration and bank erosion in areas impacted by 2011 and other recent floods.  Steps to reduce channel confinement and re-activate the side-channel at a greater range of flows address reach-specific limiting factors for ESA-listed wild salmon and steelhead within the larger Sandy River Partners basin-wide restoration strategy.  This project is also an initial demonstration for future reconnection projects identified through reach-scale geomorphic analysis, which will assist landowners on the mainstem Sandy in understanding the process and benefits of large scale restoration.  This will help guide landowners and agencies planning future restoration efforts on the dynamic, high energy mainstem Sandy River.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, travel, materials and supplies, equipment, grant administration, and reporting.  Project partners include Columbia Land Trust, Portland Water Bureau Habitat Fund, City of Sandy, ODFW, PGE Habitat Fund, and Sandy River Basin Watershed Council.

Project Name: Watershed Restoration Experience and Diverse Youth (WREaDY) Program
Project Summary: Project targets high school students in the Willamette Valley in locations historically underserved by watershed restoration training programs.  Outdoor workshops and hands-on restoration work with local watershed councils will be used to increase awareness about aquatic ecology and watershed issues, and boost interest in becoming involved in projects and careers related to natural resource management.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, travel, supplies and materials, and grant administration.  Project partners include Oregon State University.

This mentor training program targets people interested in gaining skills in basic urban habitat restoration planning and implementation.  People in underserved communities will be invited to develop skills in habitat restoration to support their employability and connections in this field of work.  This training will provide hands-on experience necessary to implement restoration assessment and planning at specific sites.  Project will result in site evaluations and restoration plans for 10-15 individual sites per year for a total of 20-30 projects.  Trained site mentors will assist with restoration plan implementation or adoption of additional sites for planning.  Additionally, project will include development of program materials (including recruitment fliers, website, social networking, and direct conversations with potential participants) and handbook.  Finally, workshops, field trips to project sites and open house presentation of plans will be offered.  An assessment of the program and outcomes will inform plans for future trainings, workshops and planting work parties.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, travel, supplies and materials, room rental, and grant administration.  Project partners include West Multnomah SWCD and Tryon Creek Watershed Council.

Project targets a basin-wide audience with project activities addressing various needs and opportunities for residents in rural, forested upstream spawning sub-basins and more urbanized tributary sub-basins in the Lower Sandy.  Project activities will integrate workshops, watershed tours and localized on-line information development to engage watershed residents in interactive outreach tailored to upper and lower watershed restoration projects to restore wild salmon habitat.  Information will be adapted to multiple learning styles (e.g. printed and digital information, workshops, and hands-on restoration experiences), and focus on creating a ladder of increasing involvement to create community leaders that advocate for restoration actions locally.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, travel, supplies and materials, equipment, and grant administration.  Project partners include Multnomah and Clackamas Counties, Clackamas SWCD, and Sandy River Basin Watershed Council.

Clackamas Community Colleges John Inskeep Environmental Learning Center (ELC) is a five-acre natural area located at the headwaters of Newell Creek on the college campus in Oregon City.  Non-point source pollution and spread of invasive plants has left the ELC site physically and ecologically degraded and has impacted overall watershed health.  Restoration of Newell Creek headwaters will improve wetland and riparian functions and the quality of water flowing into Newell Creek Canyon.  Proposed project will remove invasive plants and acquire plant materials that align with the ELC site design.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services.  Project partners include Ann and Bill Swindells Charitable Trust, Meyer Memorial Trust, Metro, Greater Oregon City Watershed Council, Clackamas SWCD, and Clackamas Community College.

Cottonwood Creek is a tributary to Thompson Creek which flows into Goose Lake (currently dry) in Goose Lake Basin, Lake County. Goose Lake Basin is home to at least seven endemic fish species, most of which are Oregon State Sensitive Species, and all can be expected to use the lower reaches of Cottonwood Creek as some life stage. Land use practices including over grazing, diversions for irrigation (many unscreened), and extreme draught have all impacted riparian and aquatic habitat in the basin. This project will combine two irrigation diversions to one of the existing points of diversion. The upstream structure functioning as the combined point of diversion will be replaced with a pre-cast weir and fish ladder.  The lower structure will remain to prevent headcutting, but will be made passable for fish and other species through grade control structures below the diversion. The structure will include a flow measuring device and a pre-cast screen box for future fish screen installation. Stream bank and channel restoration will be included in the project. Partners in this project include the landowner and Ducks Unlimited.

Fly Creek is part of the Lower Metolius River watershed and flows directly into the Metolius arm of Lake Billy Chinook, the largest reservoir of the Pelton-Round Butte Hydroelectric Project (PBR). This project is located on Fly Creek and is adjacent to both the PBR and USDA Crooked River National Grasslands, both of which include ongoing restoration projects. The area has seen recent and current catastrophic fire due to forest heavily loaded with fuels. The project is in an area where commercial harvest is not currently cost effective.     The Flymon Stewardship Project is part of a Master Stewardship Agreement with the National Wild Turkey Federation and the Deschutes National Forest. It includes 530 acres of juniper removal, 663 acres of conifer stand density management, 2 mi. of road and OHV decommissioning, 75 acres of noxious weed control, and wildlife habitat restoration.  The area is habitat for redband trout, mule deer, mountain quail, white headed woodpecker, and culturally-significant plant species to the Warms Springs Tribe.     Partners in this project include Deschutes National Forest  Sisters Ranger District, National Wild Turkey Federation, Oregon Hunters Association, and PGE Pelton Funds.

This project takes place on Mud Springs Creek upstream of the town of Madras. Mud Springs is a tributary to Trout Creek. Mud Springs enters Trout Creek two miles upstream of its confluence with the Deschutes River, just downstream of Warm Springs. Trout Creek provides the southernmost naturally-accessible habitat for steelhead in the Deschutes River watershed. This project would build on previous juniper treatments in the area funded through OWEB small grants, treating 358 acres of juniper with lop and scatter, weed control, areal-seeding, and a post treatment grazing management in order to improve the Mud Springs Creek, a Sub-watershed of Trout Creek in the Deschutes River Basin. Trout creek is a steelhead bearing stream. Partners on this project include the Jefferson County SWCD and NRCS.

Project Name: Willow Creek Upland and Riparian Enhancement
Project Summary: This project takes place on Willow Creek above the town of Madras. Willow Creek is a tributary of the Deschutes River that flows into Lake Simtustus above Pelton dam. Above Madras, the creek flows through a narrow canyon on Crooked River National Grasslands (CRNG). The riparian area is largely intact and the creek supports a population of native redband trout. There are also large ponderosa pines adjacent to the riparian and within the canyon that area used by nesting bald eagles. However, there are areas of heavy juniper invasion into what used to be sage-steppe uplands. Below CRNG, Willow Creek is heavily impacted by agricultural and urban land use with passage barriers, dewatering and channelization. This project is a continuation of non-OWEB funded work downstream in the canyon.  Juniper will be cut and burned, and where appropriate, left in the creek to encourage stream complexity and provide instream habitat. Partners in this project include USFS-CRNG and Jefferson County SWCD.

This project would improve floodplain connectivity, riparian conditions, fish passage and instream habitat along three miles of Horse Heaven Creek and three-quarters of a mile of the Crooked River their confluence. This sub-watershed is about six miles above Prineville Reservoir in Crook County.     The project area has been impacted by historical overgrazing and Horse Heaven Creek includes a large reservoir and four downstream diversions, all of which are barriers (or at least seasonal barriers) to fish passage. There has been active management by the landowner in conjunction with the Crooked River Watershed Council and other partners of juniper and historical grazing issues to help restore native species in upland habitats and restore watershed function on this 32,000 acre sub-watershed, of which, 18,600 is owned by a single landowner. Some of this work was funded through a previous OWEB grant and the landowner has also born significant costs related to restoration activates. This project would install fish screens and provide passage at two active diversions, remove two diversions which are passage barriers and are no longer used, construct several instream wood structures for bank stabilization/fish habitat, and plant native riparian area species. Much of the area has been fenced for improved livestock management. There are native redband trout actively using Horse Heaven creek for spawning.     Partners in this project include the landowner and USFWS Partners Program.

The Dry River is an ephemeral drainage that flows into the lower Crooked River to the north of Powell Butte. Water in the system is largely from agricultural irrigation runoff, occasional irrigation canal overflow, and periodic weather events. The drainage is surrounded and heavily impacted by agricultural land use resulting in chronically poor water quality. The project would include water quality monitoring, flow data collection, GIS mapping, landowner outreach, noxious week surveying and data analysis.  Partners include Crook SWCD, Crooked River Watershed Council, Central Oregon Irrigation District, and Crooked River Week Management Area.

Project Name: Landscape Restoration in Upper Crooked River Basin
Project Summary: The Nature Conservancys Juniper Hills Preserve lies in the Upper Crooked River Basin near Post, Oregon.   This project is part of a larger plan to restore 10,000 acres of sagebrush-steppe, dry pine, forest-sagebrush and juniper woodlands on the preserve. Project components include pre-burn treatment and prescribed fire on 1,830 acres, juniper cutting on 1,030 acres, planting native seed with Precision Restoration techniques including new seed treatment (seed are encased in charcoal so they withstand initial herbicide treatment for noxious weeds) and targeted weed treatment. There is no grazing by domestic livestock on Juniper Hills. There are no funding partners involved in this project; however, they do have letters of support from Crooked River Watershed Council, Crook County Soil and Water Conservation District, and USDA- Forest Service Paulina Ranger District.

This project is located around Mosier Creek, a tributary to the Columbia River, just upstream from Hood River. This proposal will help fund evaluation of commingling and prioritization for repair of 25 ground water wells impacting base flows in Mosier Creek. Reduced flows result in water quality issues such as increased temperature and limit fish passage during low flows. Mosier Creek is isolated from the Columbia River by a natural falls barrier, but is home to an isolated population of native cutthroat trout. Partners in this project include Wasco County SWCD and Mosier Watershed Council.

Klamath Basin Rangeland Trust will reach out to landowners in the Lost River basin (below Klamath Lake) to provide information on irrigation and water management practices that may help in the conservation of the Lost River sucker, as identified in the USFWS Recovery Plan for federally endangered Lost River and shortnose sucker fish. The Lost River is a heavily impacted system with a complex hydrology, and the plight of sucker fish in this area has received relatively little attention as compared to other resource issues in the Klamath Basin.

Project Name: Sellers Marsh Wetland Restoration Engineering Design Development
Project Summary: Ducks Unlimited will use LiDAR and field surveys to design restoration of the hydrology of Sellers Marsh, an approximately 1,300 acre, high-elevation historical wetland located Southeast of Chiloquin, Oregon, that was drained decades ago for cattle grazing. Restoration of the marsh represents a potential hydrological benefit to upper Klamath & Deschutes Basins, a stopover for migratory waterfowl, breeding areas for amphibians, and habitat for a variety of wetland plant species and other wildlife.

Baker Valley SWCD is seeking funds to design a pipeline for 1.5 miles of MaHarry-Belvins Ditch from the Wolf Creek reservoir to the P-2 connector inlet.  The open ditch experiences at least 20% to 30% evaporation and seepage loss during the The ditch irrigates 3,707 acres of cropland comprised primarily of potatoes, alfalfa, mint, hay and pasture.  The maximum flow is 45 cfs.  ESA-listed bull trout reside above the reservoir. Baker Valley SWCD is seeking a professional engineer with expertise with hydrology, ditch practices and pipelines. OWEB funds are requested for contracted services (93%) and administration (7%). Powder Valley Water Control District and Baker Valley SWCD are the cost-share partners.

The Newt-Young ditch is located above New Bridge in the Richland area of Baker County. Significant amounts of bedload are transported down Eagle Creek periodically, a high water quality stream. The ditch services 1604 acres of irrigated land with 35 different users. An OWEB technical assistance grant provided 60% engineering designs for the proposed structure.  This project seeks funding for the final 40% design and project implementation.  A new diversion will be installed 300 feet upstream of the current site which necessitates the need for an upstream point-of-diversion transfer. The new diversion will be located in a natural pool area in the stream channel. Watershed benefits include improved fish passage, decreased streambank erosion and sediment improved water quality and improved vegetation.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services (44%), materials (46%) and administration (9%). Idaho Power, USFWS, OWRD, Newt-Young Ditch Compnay area all cost-share partners.

Project Name: Zumwalt Prairie and Imnaha Medusahead Rye
Project Summary: The Wallowa Canyonlands Partnership (WCP) is a cooperative weed management area formed to protect and  restore both private and public canyon grasslands of the lower Snake Basin watershed from invasion and  degradation by noxious weeds. This project will focus on weed management activities in upper Joseph Creek, Little Sheep Creek, lower Imnaha River and Chesnimnus Creek watersheds.  The topography is steep, semi-arid native grasslands that are very subject to natural disturbances from heavy rainfall, fire or constant erosion. Project components include an aerial inventory/sketch-mapping of approximately 60,000 acres in high-risk areas to identify infestation and treatment areas; treat noxious weed infestations on 600 acres and restore degraded lands to productive plant communities after treatment on approximately 100 acres Aerial inventory will be targeted towards Medusahead, yellow starthistle and rush skeltonweed. OWEB funds are requested for wages (14%), contracted services (48%), travel (<1%), materials (22%) and administration (13%). Cost-share partners include various landowners, BLM, Roberts Land & Cattle, TNC, Oregon Weed Board and the McClaran Ranch.

Project Name: Phase II- Divide Allotment- 3900 Road Fence
Project Summary: Wallowa Resources and a permittee propose to exclude cattle from Little Sheep Creek, Big Sheep Creek and Salt Creek, tributaries to the Imnaha River, on the Divide Allotment seven miles southeast of Joseph.  These perennial tributaries support Snake River steelhead and bull trout.  Grazing in the riparian area can negatively affect riparian habitat quantity, quality and connectivity. This application is the continuation of a previous OWEB project (213- 5030) which had insufficient funds to complete the project elements.  Project components of this new project include constructing 3.2 miles of 3-strand, barbed-wire, wildlife friendly fence to exclude cattle from 4 miles of the upper reaches of Little Sheep Creek, 1 mile of most of the upper reaches of Big Sheep Creek and 1 mile of Salt Creek.  OWEB funds are requested for wages (5%); materials (11%); contracted services- fencing installation (67%), administration (14%) and monitoring (4%). Title II funds will purchase the fencing.

Clear Creek, a tributary of Pine Creek in the Brownlee Subbasin near Halfway, has critical bull trout habitat in the headwaters.  Some sections of Clear Creek were artificially straightened and adversely affected by significant flood events in 2006 and 2010 creating even wider channels. Riparian vegetation is lacking in many areas. The Brownlee Watershed Assessment identified this reach as having high potential for stream shade improvements since currently there is less than 40 percent canopy closure.    PBWC is seeking technical assistance for 2.3 miles of the lower reaches of Clear Creek along seven ownerships.  The resulting restoration project will address in-stream habitat improvement, grazing and wildlife management and provide a plan to address increasing channel complexity and riparian health.  OWEB funds are requested for wages/salaries (13%), contracted services (84%), travel (1%) and administration (<1%). Jubitz Family Foundation, PBWC and council volunteers will provide cash and in-kind cost-share.

MLB Ranches, west of Juntura in northwestern Malheur County, has significant juniper encroachment throughout the ownership. To address the encroaching juniper and enhance sage-grouse habitat, the applicant is proposing to remove 900 acres of juniper.  The applicant proposes to use a masticator on 200 acres on flat or mild slopes (less than 20%) where the bole is shredded by a rotary head mounted on a tracked vehicle.  OWEB funds are requested for wages/project management (3%), contracted services - juniper removal (81%), materials -seed (6%) and administration (7%).  The landowner is the cost-share partner.

The South Bridge Creek Enhancement project is located south of Ironside in the Little Malheur River basin. Invasive juniper has encroached into western sage-grouse habitat. Project components include juniper removal using a chainsaw on 145 acres cutting as close to the ground as possible and leaving no green material. Slash will be dispersed by lopping-and-scattering.  OWEB funds are requested for project management/layout (12%), juniper removal (71%), mileage (3%), administration (10%) and post-implementation status reporting (5%). Cost-share partners are the landowner and NRCS.

South Willow Creek is located southwest of Ironside in the upper Willow Creek basin. The lack of vegetative diversity, due to juniper expansion, has also adversely affected sage-grouse habitat as well as mule deer and elk forage opportunities. Project components include juniper removal using a chainsaw on 200 acres cutting as close to the ground as possible and leaving no green material. OWEB funds are requested for wages (9%), contracted services (76%), mileage (2%), administration (9%) and post-implementation monitoring (4%). Cost-share partners are the landowner and NRCS. The landowner will provide labor for lop and scattering of juniper.

Connecting the Corner on Hyline is located in the Hyline Bench Conservation Implementation Strategy Area.This project will treat the corner of the 180-acre field by converting an open-take out to pressurized sprinklers. The applicant is proposes to install:  1,380 feet of 6-inch mainline from an existing pressurized pipeline that ties into the OIDs North Canal; a 6-inch flowmeter, 1,400 feet of wire for the pivot and a 366-foot pivot to irrigate 6 acres. OWEB funds are requested for wages/project management (5.6%), contracted services (24%), materials (56%), administration (7%) and post-implementation status reporting (7%).  The project has 260% cost0share with the landowners providing cash and in-kind.

Located 38 miles southwest of Ontario near Harper, an 80-acre flood-irrigated field borders the north side of Highway 20 and the south side of the Malheur River.  To eliminate the runoff from the field, the applicant proposes to install a pivot that will transport water from an existing pond.  The proposed project will convey water from a pond near the bottom of the field. Project components include install a 25-hp pump; electrical power and panel box; 2,240 feet of 8-inch mainline from the pond to the pivot point and a 1,060-foot Zimmatic pivot to irrigate 80 acres. OWEB funds are requested for wages/project management (4%), contracted services (2%), travel (1%), materials (84%), administration (6%) and monitoring (3%). The landowner is the cost-share partner.

Clover Creek Slash Abatement is located on Clover Creek, a tributary to Bully Creek in northwestern Malheur County and inside the target area for Sage Grouse Initiative (SGI) and within ODFW-designated core sage-grouse area. NRCS will provide funding for juniper removal but none for slash abatement.  This ranch comprises approximately 9,000 acres.  The applicant is seeking OWEB funds to assist with hand piling on 115 acres and lop and scatter on 730 acres. NRCS and the landowner will provide funding for juniper cutting on 2,000 acres and reseeding on 200 acres. OWEB funds are requested for wages (4%), contracted services (84%), mileage (1%), administration (10%) and post-implementation monitoring (1%). Cost-share partners are the landowner and NRCS.

Project Name: Oregon State Parks & Recreation Invasive Plant Assessment & Planning
Project Summary: Oregon State Parks and Recreation (OSPR) administers about 5,000 acres of land across northeast Oregon. These lands provide for stewardship of plant, animals and recreational resources in Oregon. A district-wide strategy is needed to facilitate consistency in weed management activities across northeast OSPR various parks and waysides that will reduce the spread and abundance of weeds and protect and enhance diverse natural and recreational resources. Over 10 OSPR park facilities are located in Union, Umatilla, Baker, Malheur and Wallowa Counties. OWEB funds are requested for salaries (50%), contracted services (31%), travel (3%), equipment (3%) and administration (11%).  Cost-share partners are BLM, Title II, Baker County weed Board, Wallowa County Weed Board, Wallowa Resources and Malheur Weed Board.

Project Name: Saving Greater Sage Grouse in Malheur County
Project Summary: Malheur County SWCD formed a steering committee in February 2014 with the purpose of developing a Candidate Conservation Agreement with Assurances (CCAA) for the greater sage-grouse on private range land in Malheur County. Malheur County SWCD seeks technical assistance funding from OWEB to hire two range conservationists to write individual site-specific plans. The SWCD is seeking to hire two contractors for two years. OWEB funds are requested for salaries (2%), contracted services (97%) and administration (1%). Malheur County Sage-grouse Steering Committee, NRCS and OSU Livestock and Range Agent are cost-share partners.

Located in eastern Baker County near Halfway, this project is in the Pine Creek drainage on Lee Creek.  The Posy Valley ditch runs through this property. It diverts water from Lee Creek conveying the water to Sag Creek which empties into Pine Creek. Project components include developing two springs for year-round water; installing 4 troughs; 1,710 feet of fencing around the springs; pipe 4,050 feet of 2-inch pipe to convey water from the springs the troughs and pond; install 900 feet of gated-pipe; a 1,000-gallon cistern and seed the disturbed areas.  OWEB funds are requested for wages/project management (1%), contracted services (63%), materials (21%) and administration (13%).  The landowner is the cost-share partner providing 57% cost-share and will provide the cistern and labor for the pond.

The Jacobs Spring project proposes to develop two springs and convey water to four rubber-tire watering troughs to become the secondary water source.  A cistern will be installed just below the second spring. The springs are centrally located to minimize livestock travel distance. Project components include develop one spring using perforated collector pipe; install four 12-foot tire watering troughs; 7,880 feet of 2-inch pipe to convey water from the spring to the troughs; bury a 2,500-gallon cistern and reseed all disturb areas. OWEB funds are requested for wages/project management (1%), contracted services (60%), materials (22%) and administration (15%).  The landowner is the cost-share partner providing 44% cost-share and will provide labor and materials.

Project Name: Little Crane Creek and 16 Road Enclosures
Project Summary: The Burns-Paiute Tribes (BPT) is proposing to replace and/or reconstruct approximately 10.5 miles of fence to facilitate protection and enhancement of ESA-listed bull trout along critical habitat of Crane Creek and Little Crane Creek. These streams are strongholds for bull trout spawning in the North Fork Malheur watershed, headwaters of the upper Malheur River system.Fencing will be 4-strand, barbed-wire with a smooth lower wire and a minimum of 16 inches from the ground.  The top wire will be 42 inches above the ground to allow for wildlife access. OWEB funds are requested for materials (100%).  Grant administration will be provided by BPT. The USFS and BPT are providing 92% cost-share.

The Powder Basin Watershed Council (PBWC) in Baker City expanded its monitoring effort in the Powder Basin that began in 2013. PBWC proposes to add a pilot season of flow monitoring.  They want to hire two water quality interns to collect flow data and assist the water quality monitoring efforts.  It is proposed to monitor flow at 43 sites monthly.  OWEB funds are requested for wages (84%), travel (8%), materials (2%) and administration (7%).  DEQ, BOR, Idaho Power and the USFS are providing significant cost-share.  DEQ provided a letter of support.

The project location is six miles north of Ontario and proposes to install:  740 feet of 8-inch conveyance pipe; 300 feet of 6-inch mainline with 4 risers, electrical power, a 10-hp pump; 8-inch flowmeter; and bubbler to clean the water before its enters the proposed wheel line.  NRCS will design the project to meet required specifications.  Permanent pasture will be planted. OWEB funds are requested for wages/project management (4%), contracted services (30%), materials (59%), administration (6%) and post-implementation status reporting (71).  The project has 92% cost-share with the landowners and NRCS providing cash and in-kind.

This project is in the newly created Vale Bench Focus Area. Project components include installing:  1,320 feet of 6-inch mainline from Lateral 227; 320 feet of cable-con wire from the power pole to the pivot center; a Clemons filter; electrical panel and a 589-foot pivot.  In addition, there are seven remaining flood-irrigated acres that will have a permanent cover crop which will reduce sediment loss and overland flow. OWEB funds are requested for wages/project management (7%), contracted services (29%), materials (49%), administration (12%) and post-implementation status reporting (3%).  The project has 317% cost-share with the landowners and NRCS.

Located approximately seven miles west of North Powder in the Pilcher Creek watershed, Stoves Draw is a 300-acre drainage basin where several smaller drainage areas converge. The proposed solution is to re-route 1.1 miles of road out of the draw bottom to the ridgetop where excavation and fill will be kept to a minimum to reduce long-term soil erosion and subsequent sediment runoff into waterway.  The road will not cross any stream and/or ditches. OWEB funds are requested for contracted services (82%), materials (8%), administration (8%) and monitoring (5%). Cost-share partners are ODF, ODFW and the landowner and cost-share is 56% of the OWEB-requested amount.

The Little Creek Channel Complexity Project is located near Union. Project components include re-grading the floodplain terrace of approximately 4,450 yds2 of channel bank.  Large woody debris (LWD) comprised of 17 pieces will be placed within the project area.  Logs will be buried in the bank and backfilled with a gravel-cobble-topsoil mix.  In areas where riprap is removed, the floodplain with be re-graded and LWD installed.  Restoration of the wetland swale includes exclosure fencing, re-grading and replanting.  Within the riparian fenced area, re-vegetation and weed treatment will also occur. OWEB funds are requested for wages (9%), contracted services (51%) and materials (38%). DEQ, BOR, Union SWCD and the landowner are providing 136% cost-share of the OWEB requested amount.

Located 10 miles from Jordan Valley, this project is situated in core sage-grouse habitat on a BLM allotment southeast of Cow Lakes. Project components include install 2 miles of 1.25-inch conveyance pipe; replace propane pump with solar pumps to reduce noise and carbon footprint and replace two troughs.  Watershed benefits include ensuring a dependable source of water and improving sage-grouse habitat by eliminating generator noise during mating and brood-rearing seasons. OWEB funds are requested for wages (3%), contracted services (4%), materials (85%), and administration (6%).  The permittees will provide 55% of the OWEB-requested amount as cost-share.

The Up in Smoke project is located 20 miles south of Ironside and within ODFWs core sage-grouse habitat. 1,100 acres of the ranch were burned by the Kitten Canyon fire in 2014 and are planned to be seeded with this project. OWEB funds are requested for wages (4%), materials (86%), administration (9%) and monitoring (<1%).  The landowner is the cost-share partner with 96% of the OWEB-requested funds.

Lick Creek is a tributary of the Middle Fork John Day River in Grant County. ODFW identifies it as a steelhead stream, but historic land management has resulted in weed encroachment, degraded riparian vegetation and poor channel function. The upstream landowner has recently taken over managing this section of Lick Creek and would like to see it back in better health. He has a solid track record of completing numerous successful restoration projects on his own land. The project proposes to fence both sides of a _ mile section of Lick Creek; create a water gap for livestock water access; build an additional _ mile of fence to facilitate better management of livestock rotation in adjacent pastures; treat 50 acres of scotch thistle and reseed with grass in treated areas.  Partners include the landowner/manager and the North Fork John Day Watershed Council.

These project sites are located along the northern slopes of the Middle Fork John Day River in the Malheur National Forest in Grant County. The Reed and Summit fires burned over 40,000 acres in 1994 and 1996 respectively. Due to successful planting and natural regeneration, seedling density within these sites has created potential for another high intensity, stand replacing fire. Repeated, severe fires can have detrimental impacts to soil properties; create potential for extreme erosion and sediment loading events to downslope streams and rivers. This proposal is phase two of a ten-year plan that will result in thinning over 6,890 acres of selected, high priority sites within the impacted area. This phase (P2) would treat 15 units totaling 709 acres. Trees would be thinned using chainsaws, hand-piled and burned one year later.  A pool of local contractors has already been established based on price, technical proposal and benefit to the local communities. Partners on this project include Malheur National Forest USFS, R6 Competitive Challenge Cost Share, the NE Oregon Forests Resource Advisory Committee Title II, and the North Fork John Day Watershed Council.

This project is located along a section of the Mill Ditch, an irrigation conveyance that diverts water from Long Creek, a tributary of the Middle Fork John Day River in Grant County. Long Creek provides spawning and rearing habitat for summer steelhead but routinely goes dry in the middle of summer. A seepage study done by the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs (CTWS) indicated the average loss from a 2,340 foot section of the ditch to be 1.97 cfs. This proposal would install a trash screen, water measuring device and pipe along the leaky section of the ditch to help leave more water instream. Partners in the project include the landowner, the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs, the Confederated Tribes of Umatilla Indian Reservation (CTUIR) and Grant SWCD.

This project is located on Cottonwood Creek, a significant tributary to the North Fork John Day River just outside the town of Monument in Grant County. There are two irrigation push-up dams in close proximity to each other near the mouth of Cottonwood Creek creating fish passage barriers for juvenile steelhead and Chinook salmon attempting to reach cool water refugia in the upper Cottonwood Creek Basin. One of these irrigation diversion is unscreened and resolving that issue has been problematic due to the layout of the diversion and the existing roadway alongside the creek. The other diversion supplies water to 1,000 feet of leaky above-ground mainline. This project proposes to combine the two PODs to a single location; install a new fish-friendly rock weir-style diversion structure and new ODFW fish screen; the irrigators sharing water from the new diversion and the above ground pipe would be replaced with buried PVC mainline. Partners on the project include ODFW, USFWS, Monument SWCD, landowners, and the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs.

Project Name: Lower South Fork Walla Walla Habitat
Project Summary: This site for this technical assistance for design is located on the Lower South Fork of the Walla Walla River, upstream from the town of Milton Freewater in Umatilla County. The South Fork Walla Walla is home to ESA listed summer steelhead and bull trout, as well as spring Chinook salmon. Landowners on both sides of the river are interested in a project that will create better instream habitat, improve the riparian area, create meanders and side channels and improve bank stability. Part of the restoration would include removing _ mile of rip rap along banks from historic attempts to alleviate flooding and bank erosion.   This TA would help fund a topographical survey, geomorphic assessment and development of habitat enhancement alternative plans and final report. The final deliverables would be the survey data, assessment and design alternatives necessary for landowner buy-in prior to final designs, permitting and costing out construction of a _ mile long habitat project along this reach of the Lower South Fork Walla Walla River. Match funds would be BPA funding through the Walla Walla Basin Watershed Council.

Project Name: West Little Walla Walla River Fish Passage
Project Summary: This project is located on the West Little Walla Walla River, a tributary of the Walla Walla River just outside the town of Milton Freewater in Umatilla County. The Little Walla Walla and Spring Branch systems provide habitat for ESA listed summer steelhead spawning, rearing and cool water refugia for juveniles from high temperatures in the mainstem Walla Walla River during the summer. The West Little Walla Walla underwent a stream inventory and assessment to locate and identify fish passage barriers, identify restoration opportunities in areas of degraded habitat and outreach to landowners along the stream. From that assessment, four priority fish passage barriers were selected for correction. These four are lowest in the system and will provide the most benefit to fish migrating in from Washington, where passage barriers have already been corrected. Partners in the project include the Tri-State Steelheaders, ODFW, BPA and the Walla Walla Basin Watershed Council.

Project Name: Upper Greasewood Creek Flood Control Alternatives
Project Summary: This technical assistance proposal for project design covers the area around the town of Helix and Greasewood Creek, a tributary of Wildhorse Creek in Umatilla County. Historically, this area has had reoccurring flooding and erosion events. This area is mostly agriculture land, focusing on cereal grain production. Traditional farming practices of conventional tillage and fallow rotation has exacerbated the problem of erosion in the croplands. But recently new and innovative farming techniques such as no-till, direct seed and/or riparian buffers have begun to emerge. Landowners, farmers, Helix Parks & Recreation, City of Helix, Umatilla County SWCD, Oregon Department of Agriculture, NRCS, Oregon Department of Transportation, and the Umatilla County Planning & Roads are all joining forces to find a workable solution to this problem. The TA would offset costs to hire an environmental consultant to conduct biological, ecological and/or environmental assessments to determine the scope of the problem and alternative solutions. The funding would cover: alternative designs, an action plan outlining options to alleviate the problem, and town-hall meetings with stakeholders to determine the course of action feasible to resolve the problem. The final deliverable would be an action plan for a restoration project.  Partners on this effort include landowners, community members, NRCS, ODA, ODOT, City of Helix, Helix Parks and Recreation, Umatilla County and the Umatilla Co. SWCD.

This project is located on Butte Creek, a steelhead producing tributary to the John Day River in Wheeler County. Four fish passage barriers would be addressed including three undersized culverts (one with a significant drop on downstream end) and one headcut. Two of the four locations are complete barriers, with the other two sites being partial barriers during certain times of the year. The three culverts would be replaced with bottomless pipe arch culverts that meet ODFW fish passage requirements for steelhead; and the headcut would be corrected by the installation of a stream simulated riffle creating stability between the transitions of channel gradient. Partners on this project are the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs (CTWS) and the Wheeler SWCD.

This project site is located on Indian Creek, a tributary of Mountain Creek in the southeast corner of Wheeler County. Mountain Creek and its significant tributaries are considered important spawning and rearing habitat for ESA listed summer steelhead. The three irrigation diversions on this section of Indian Creek exist as barriers for aquatic species during certain times of the year; they are not screened so stranding fish is a concern, and water quality is hampered when ditch conveyances fail. This proposal would replace the upper and middle diversions with fish-friendly irrigation structures and decommission the lower diversion. The system will be designed to divert the majority of the irrigation water right from the middle diversion and the associated ditch converted to pipe. The upper diversion would continue to divert to an open ditch but at lesser amounts. Partners on the project include the landowner, NRCS, ODFW and the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs (CTWS).

The project site is located in the upper Bridge Creek watershed, southeast of the town of Mitchell in Wheeler County. Fire suppression and historic land use practices have encouraged western juniper to extend out of its normal range into riparian areas and upland deep soil sites, crowding out native vegetation, increasing topsoil loss by erosion from overland flows, and decreasing groundwater reserves. This project would fund the removal of 400 acres of juniper and non-commercially thin 55 acres of overstocked Ponderosa pine. This work would complement an additional 440 acres of juniper removal funded by the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs (CTWS) and 80 acres of non-commercial thinning funded by NRCS. Partners on this project include CTWS and Wheeler SWCD.

Project Name: Rowe Creek Floodplain Restoration Preliminary Design
Project Summary: The site of this proposed technical assistance for design is located at the floodplain and confluence of Rowe Creek and the mainstem John Day River near the town of Twickenham in Wheeler County. Issues and concerns at the site that limit fish production include 1) limited fish migration passage into and upstream in Rowe Creek; 2) limited or reduced floodplain connectivity; 3) lack of channel and floodplain habitat complexity; 4) poor riparian vegetation conditions; 5) high summer instream water temperature; and 6) low instream flow.  Causal factors for these problems are prior conversion of historically complex habitat to agricultural production, including levee construction, floodplain grading, vegetation removal, tributary channelization, and water withdrawal. This TA would develop action alternatives and preliminary designs for new alignment and geomorphology of lower Rowe Creek for improved fish passage and habitat conditions, levee removal along the JDR downstream of the Rowe Creek confluence, wetland enhancement and possibly off-channel habitat creation through the construction of a backwater channel. The Freshwater Trust and the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs were partners on this proposal.

This proposal seeks funding for a five-year monitoring program in Trail Creek watershed, located in the headwaters of the North Fork John Day River in the Wallowa Whitman National Forest in northeast Grant County. As the Wallowa Whitman National Forest was completing the Watershed Restoration Action Plan for this watershed, they realized there was little to no baseline data available. This request would fund data collection for flow, temperature, turbidity, macro invertebrates, redd counts, and stream profiles for one-year of baseline and four years post project implementation to show effectiveness/changes after restoration projects are implemented. Partners include the North Fork John Day Watershed Council, the Wallowa Whitman National Forest and the Confederated Tribes Indian Reservation of Umatilla (CTUIR).

As a part of a ten-year pre-commercial thinning proposal, this phase of the project would thin, hand pile and burn piles on 675 acres out of the targeted 6,890 acres along the north slope of the Middle Fork John Day River on the Malheur National Forest in Grant County. The 1994 Reed and 1996 Summit stand-replacing fires burned over 40,261 acres. Both sites were extensively replanted and along with natural regeneration resulted in a very dense, 15-20 year even-aged forest with extremely heavy fuel loads. These conditions provide for increased fire hazard, with a high probability that another fire would again be high intensity and stand replacing, scorching riparian areas and damaging soil health. Partners on the project include Malheur National Forest, North Fork John Day Watershed Council, NE Oregon Forests Resource Advisory Title II, and the Region 6 Competitive Challenge Cost Share.

Project Name: Water Quality, Conservation & Conversion of Hermiston Irrigation District B3 Line
Project Summary: This project is located seven miles east of Hermiston in the Cold Springs drainage area of Umatilla County. The B3 line of the Hermiston Irrigation District (HID) is a 105 year old open ditch and leaking concrete pipe that services inefficient flood irrigation systems. Pollution of tailwater from the flood irrigated livestock pastures and cropland into ditches and drains running into the Columbia River is a major concern. Since 1999, HID has been proactively and successfully converting old concrete or open ditches to buried pipe and working toward a closed water delivery system. This project would install 11,640 of PVC pipe and delivery points for the water users of the B3 line. As a requirement of the line improvement, all water users would be required to convert their flood irrigation to efficient sprinkler systems. Partners on this project are Umatilla SWCD and the Hermiston Irrigation District.

Located in the northeast corner of Grant County, the Granite Creek watershed has been altered by historic logging and mining operations resulting in reduced effective habitat, large wood recruitment and degraded riparian vegetation. This project proposes to add large wood debris (LWD) to two miles of Bull Run Creek.
