This work will be a part of a larger restoration proposal in Corral Creek, Channel Creek and Deep Creek that removes one fish barrier culvert, enacts floodplain restoration, adds LWD and conducts riparian planting. The project is a priority component of the Watershed Restoration Action Plan (WRAP) for the Bull Run Subwatershed written by the Wallowa-Whitman National Forest. Partners on this project include the Wallowa-Whitman National Forest, WWRI (USFS), and the North Fork John Day Watershed Council.

This project is located along the Middle Fork of the John Day River, near the historic Ritter Hot Springs. Juniper has encroached into upland and riverside fields due to historic land use practices and fire suppression. This project would remove 95 acres of phase one juniper in the upland field and 36 acres of phase two juniper in the riverside field. Debris would be piled and burned, with burn sites reseeded after one year. An interpretive sign would be designed and installed at the Ritter Hot Springs to explain restoration in the context of water flow. Partners on this project are the landowner and the North Fork John Day Watershed Council.

This application seeks funding to hire a liaison to coordinate with a local working group towards the goal of moving regulatory controls toward an equitable system that involves local participation to better meet both landowner and agency goals. There would also be some outreach activities related to the Intensively Monitored Watershed (IMW) in the Middle Fork John Day River. This outreach project would focus on the upper reaches of the John Day Basin, but would also involve outreach to agencies at the state level.  Partners on this project include the North Fork John Day Watershed Council, NOAA and a liaison.

This project, located in the Butte Creek watershed in north Wheeler County, proposed to remove 1006 acres of western juniper, treat 280 acres of noxious weeds and reseed 210 acres. Due to historic fire suppression and year-round grazing, western juniper has encroached and adversely impacted the landscape by outcompeting desirable vegetation, decreasing infiltration, increasing overland flows and erosion and allowing invasive weeds to invade degraded sites. The sites were selected basis an analysis that incorporates soil type, aspect, slope and phase of juniper growth. This application is also a result of the work done on a recently completed OWEB landowner outreach technical assistance grant in this same area. Partners on the project include six landowners and the Mid John Day Bridge Creek Watershed Council.

This project, located in the Kahler basin area of northeast Wheeler County, proposed to remove 1,761 acres of juniper encroachment on select sites; treat 135 acres of medusahead, reseed 50 acres of disturbed ground and install eight spring developments. Fire suppression and land use have created declines in upland health, increasing invasive species and allowing for juniper encroachment. The project complements planned landscape scale restoration work by the Umatilla Forest Collaborative and the Natural Resources Conservation Service. Partners on the project include the Mid John Day Bridge Creek Watershed Council, NRCS, Umatilla National Forest, Wheeler SWCD and multiple landowners.

Project Name: Columbia River - Westport Slough Conservation Project

Project Summary: This project seeks to fund a Watershed Council Coordinator for the Seven Basins Watershed Council. Council identified watershed limiting factors include  habitat access - impaired access to habitat, hydrograph/water quantity - altered hydrology, knowledge gaps - lack of information, physical habitat quality - altered quality of physical habitat, water quality -altered physical, chemical, or biological water characteristics.
Open 19.7 miles of habitat to salmonids by replacing or improving 11 culverts which are impediments to fish passage.
Unallocated Klamath County Earmark from PCSRF FFY 02
Develop statewide funding priorities
Coastal Data - USGS/PNAMP funding
Unallocated Coastal Data

Project Name: Chetco River Boat Basin Flow Restoration Project
Project Summary: Alter existing breakwater that separates the Main Channel at the Chetco river mouth from the Port of Brookings Habor's Boat Basin I to improve water quality.

Project Name: Resource Assistance for Rural Environments Watershed Program
Project Summary: To fund the placement of (8) technical assistants in watersheds across Oregon from 10-97 to 08-98.

Project Name: Small Acreage Steward Education Outreach Project
Treatment of Pesticide Runoff Constructed Wetlands
